original: 1. Evaṃ me sutaṃ…pe… mallesu viharatīti pāthikasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā.🔽Mallesu viharatīti mallā nāma jānapadino rājakumārā, tesaṃ nivāso ekopi janapado🔽ruḷhīsaddena “mallā”ti vuccati, tasmiṃ mallesu janapade. “Anupiyaṃ nāma mallānaṃ🔽nigamo”ti anupiyanti evaṃnāmako mallānaṃ janapadassa eko nigamo, taṃ gocaragāmaṃ🔽katvā ekasmiṃ chāyūdakasampanne vanasaṇḍe viharatīti attho. Anopiyantipi pāṭho. Pāvisīti
analyzed: evam me sutaṃpe mallesu viharati iti pāthika suttam tatra ayam apubba pada vaṇṇanā  mallesu viharati iti mallāḥ nāma jānapadinaḥ rāja kumārāḥ tesam nivāsaḥ ekaḥ api janapadaḥ  ruḷhī saddena mallāti vuccati tasmin mallesu janapade anupiyam nāma mallānam  nigamaḥ ti evaṃnāmakaḥ mallānam janapadassa ekaḥ nigamaḥ tam gocaragāmam  katvā ekasmin chāyu udaka sampanne vana saṇḍe viharati iti atthaḥ
translated: Thus have I heard. … He was living in the Mallas’ country. … The Pāṭika Sutta. Herein, the commentary on the words not already commented on will be given as occasion arises.

original: paviṭṭho. Bhagavā pana na tāva paviṭṭho, pavisissāmīti nikkhantattā pana pāvisīti
analyzed: paviṭṭhaḥ bhagavā pana na tāva paviṭṭhaḥ pavisissāmi iti nikkhanta ttā pana pāvisi iti
translated: He was living in the Mallas’ country: the Mallas are princes of the country. Their country is called “the Mallas’ country” by the established expression. In the Mallas’ country. Anupiyā is the name of a town of the Mallas’ country. He was living in a forest grove with a pond and shade not far from that village, which was his resort. The reading is also anupiyā. He entered: he went in. But the Blessed One did not go in then; he went in with the intention of going in, so he is said to have entered.

original: vutto. Yathā kiṃ, yathā “gāmaṃ gamissāmī”ti nikkhanto puriso taṃ gāmaṃ apattopi “kuhiṃ🔽itthannāmo”ti vutte “gāmaṃ gato”ti vuccati, evaṃ. Etadahosīti gāmasamīpe ṭhatvā sūriyaṃ🔽olokentassa etadahosi. Atippago khoti ativiya pago kho, na tāva kulesu yāgubhattaṃ🔽niṭṭhitanti. Kiṃ pana bhagavā kālaṃ ajānitvā nikkhantoti? Na ajānitvā. Paccūsakāleyeva
analyzed: vuttaḥ yathā kim yathā gāmam gamissāmi iti nikkhantaḥ purisaḥ tam gāmam a pattaḥ api kuhim  itthannāmaḥ iti vutte gāmam gataḥ ti vuccati evam etat ahosi iti gāma samīpe ṭhatvā sūriyam  olokentassa etat ahosi atippago kho ti ativiya pago kho na tāva kulesu yāgu bhattam  niṭṭhitam ti kim pana bhagavā kālam a jānitvā nikkhantaḥ iti na a jānitvā
translated: “As what?” As when a man sets out, “I will go to the village,” and when he is asked, “Where is so-and-so going?” people say, “He is going to the village,” even though he has not yet reached the village. “This occurred to him”: standing near the village and looking at the sun, this occurred to him. “It is too early”: it is too early for the rice-gruel and rice to be ready in the families. But did the Blessed One set out without knowing the time? He did not set out without knowing. He set out in the last watch of the night.

original: hi bhagavā ñāṇajālaṃ pattharitvā lokaṃ volokento ñāṇajālassa anto paviṭṭhaṃ bhaggavagottaṃ🔽channaparibbājakaṃ disvā “ajjāhaṃ imassa paribbājakassa mayā pubbe katakāraṇaṃ samāharitvā🔽dhammaṃ kathessāmi, sā dhammakathā assa mayi pasādappaṭilābhavasena saphalā bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: hi bhagavā ñāṇa jālam pattharitvā lokam volokentaḥ ñāṇa jālassa antar paviṭṭham bhaggavaga uttam 🔽channa paribbājakam disvā ajja aham imassa paribbājakassa mayā pubbe kata kāraṇam samāharitvā 🔽dhammam kathessāmi sā dhamma kathā assa mayi pasāda paṭilābha vasena saphalā bhavissati iti
translated: “As what?” As when a man sets out, “I will go to the village,” and when he has reached the village, he is said to have “gone to the village” even though he has not gone there for the first time. “This thought occurred to him”: standing near the village and looking at the sun, this thought occurred to him. “It is too late”: it is too late to go to the families. “The rice-gruel and meal are not yet ready.” But did the Blessed One set out without knowing the time? He did not. For the Blessed One, having extended his mind with knowledge, surveyed the world at dawn, and seeing the wanderer of the Bhaggava clan who had entered the net of his knowledge, thought: “Today I will recall to him a service I formerly rendered him, and I will preach the Dhamma to him. That discourse on the Dhamma will be fruitful for him, for it will be accompanied by confidence in me.”

original: ñatvāva paribbājakārāmaṃ pavisitukāmo atippagova nikkhami. Tasmā tattha pavisitukāmatāya
analyzed: ñatvā ava paribbājaka ārāmam pavisitu kāmo atippagaḥ uva nikkhami tasmā tattha pavisitu kāma tāya
translated: and, knowing that he wanted to enter the Wanderers’ Rest Hut, he went out to meet him. Therefore, because of his desire to enter there,

original: evaṃ cittaṃ uppādesi.
analyzed: evam cittam uppādesi
translated: and he wanted to enter the park, he went straight on. Therefore he aroused the thought of entering there.

analyzed: nisinnāsanam papphoṭetvā sampādetvā dadamānaḥ evam āha sunakkhatto licchavi putto ti

translated: Sunakkhatta was the son of the Licchavi chief Likhita. It seems that he was a friend of the householder’s, and from time to time he went to see him.

analyzed: santikam gacchati paccakkhāto ti paccakkhāmi dāna aham bhante bhagavantam na dāna aham
translated: “He has disavowed the Buddha”: “I disavow the Lord, I will not live the holy life under the Lord,

original: 3. Bhagavantaṃ uddissāti bhagavā me satthā “bhagavato ahaṃ ovādaṃ paṭikaromī”ti evaṃ🔽apadisitvā. Ko santo kaṃ paccācikkhasīti yācako vā yācitakaṃ paccācikkheyya, yācitako🔽vā yācakaṃ. Tvaṃ pana neva yācako na yācitako, evaṃ sante, moghapurisa, ko santo
analyzed: bhagavantam uddissa ati bhagavā me satthā bhagavataḥ aham ovādam paṭikaromi iti evam  a padisitvā kaḥ santaḥ kam paccācikkhasi iti yācakaḥ vā yācitakam paccācikkheyya yācitako  vā yācakam tvam pana na iva yācakaḥ na yācitakaḥ evam sante mogha purisa kaḥ santo
translated: “Under the Buddha”: “The Lord is my teacher,” and “I carry out the Lord’s instruction.”🔽“Who are you to disavow whom?” Either the beggar might disavow the one who is begged, or the one who is begged might disavow the beggar. But you are neither a beggar nor one who is begged, so, foolish man, who are you to disavow whom?

original: ko samāno kaṃ paccācikkhasīti dasseti. Passa moghapurisāti passa tucchapurisa. Yāvañca
analyzed: kaḥ samānaḥ kam paccācikkhasi iti dassa iti passa mogha purisa ati passa tuccha purisa yāvañca
translated: “Foolish man, look!” — you are a fool, a void, a hollow man.

original: te idaṃ aparaddhanti yattakaṃ idaṃ tava aparaddhaṃ, yattako te aparādho tattako dosoti
analyzed: te idam aparaddhanti yattakam idam tava aparaddham yattakaḥ te aparādhaḥ tattakaḥ dosaḥ iti
translated: “They say that you have fallen into misfortune” means “Whatever misfortune you have fallen into, whatever your fault is, that is your fault.”

original: evāhaṃ bhaggava tassa dosaṃ āropesinti dasseti.
analyzed: eva aham bhaggava tassa dosam āropesinti dassa iti
translated: Thus he shows that he attributes the fault to him.

original: 4. Uttarimanussadhammāti pañcasīladasasīlasaṅkhātā manussadhammāuttari. Iddhipāṭihāriyanti
analyzed: uttari manussa dhammā ti pañca sīla dasa sīla saṅkhātāḥ manussa dhammā uttari iddhi pāṭihāriyanti
translated: “A superhuman state”: the state of a human being is the five precepts and the ten precepts. “A wonder of supernormal power”:

original: iddhibhūtaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ. Kate vāti katamhi vā. Yassatthāyāti yassa dukkhakkhayassa🔽atthāya. So niyyāti takkarassāti so dhammo takkarassa yathā mayā dhammo desito, tathā
analyzed: iddhi bhūtam pāṭihāriyam kate vā ati katamhi vā yassa atthāya ati yassa dukkha kkhayassa  atthāya so niyyāti takkarassa ati so dhammo takkarassa yathā mayā dhammo desito tathā
translated: a wonder that is a supernormal power. “In what has been done”: in what has been done or in what has been left undone. “For the sake of which”: for the sake of which destruction of suffering.

original: kārakassa sammā paṭipannassa puggalassa sabbavaṭṭadukkhakkhayāya amatanibbānasacchikiriyāya
analyzed: kārakassa sammā paṭipannassa puggalassa sabba vaṭṭa dukkha kkhayāya amata nibbāna sacchikiriyāya
translated: “It leads to the goal of the earnest man”: that Dhamma leads to the realization of the deathless, Nibbāna, to the destruction of all the suffering of the round, for the person who practices rightly, as the Dhamma is taught by me.

original: gacchati, na gacchati, saṃvattati, na saṃvattatīti pucchati. Tatra sunakkhattāti
analyzed: gacchati na gacchati saṃvattati na saṃvattati iti pucchati tatra su nakkhattā ati
translated: “It leads,” “it does not lead,” “it succeeds,” “it does not succeed”—he asks. “In that case, Sunakkhatta”:

original: tasmiṃ sunakkhatta mayā desite dhamme takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya saṃvattamāne
analyzed: tasmin sunakkhatta mayā desite dhamme takkarassa sammā dukkha kkhayāya saṃvattamāne
translated: in that case, Sunakkhatta, when the Dhamma taught by me succeeds for the earnest man in the complete destruction of suffering,

original: kiṃ uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ kataṃ karissati, ko tena katena attho. Tasmiñhi🔽katepi akatepi mama sāsanassa parihāni natthi, devamanussānañhi amatanibbānasampāpanatthāya
analyzed: kim uttari manussa dhammā iddhi pāṭihāriyam katam karissati kaḥ tena katena atthaḥ tasmin hi  kate api a kate pi mama sāsanassa natthi deva manussānam hi amata nibbāna sampāpana tthāya
translated: What is the use of a miracle, a superhuman wonder? What is the use of performing a miracle?

original: ahaṃ pāramiyo pūresiṃ, na pāṭihāriyakaraṇatthāyāti pāṭihāriyassa niratthakataṃ dassetvā
analyzed: aham pāramiyaḥ pūresim na pāṭihāriya karaṇa tthāya ati pāṭihāriyassa niratthaka tam dassetvā
translated: For whether it is performed or not, my Dispensation will not decline. For it was for the attainment of the deathless Nibbāna by gods and men that I fulfilled the perfections, not for the performance of miracles.” Thus he showed the futility of the miracle.

original: “passa, moghapurisā”ti dutiyaṃ dosaṃ āropesi.
analyzed: passa moghapurisa ati dutiyam dosaṃ āropesi
translated: Then he charged him with the second fault, saying: “See, foolish man.”

analyzed: aggaññanti loka paññattim idam nāma lokassa agganti evam jānitabbam pi aggam mariyādam na tam paññapeti iti vadati sesam ettha anantara vāda anusārena iva veditabbam  aneka pariyāyena kho ti idam kasmai āraddham sunakkhatto kira bhagavataḥ guṇam makkhessāmi
translated: “The foremost”: he does not proclaim the foremost, the limit, that is to say, the creation of the world, which should be known thus: “This is the foremost of the world.” The rest can be understood by the method of the preceding section.🔽“In many ways”: why was this said? Sunakkhatta, it seems, thought: “I will disparage the virtues of the Blessed One,

analyzed: dosam paññapessāmi iti ettakam vippalapitvā bhagavato katham suṇantaḥ appatiṭṭhaḥ niravaḥ aṭṭhāsi
translated: and I will proclaim his faults.” After prattling so much, he stood there speechless, with nothing more to say, listening to the Blessed One’s talk.

original: Atha bhagavā – “sunakkhatta, evaṃ tvaṃ makkhibhāve ṭhito sayameva garahaṃ pāpuṇissasī”ti🔽makkhibhāve ādīnavadassanatthaṃ anekapariyāyenātiādimāha. Tattha anekapariyāyenāti
analyzed: atha bhagavā sunakkhattaḥ evam tvam makkhi bhāve ṭhitaḥ sayam eva garaham pāpuṇissasi iti  makkhi bhāve ādīnava dassana attham aneka pariyāyena ati ādim āha tattha aneka pariyāyena ati
translated: Then the Exalted One said: “Sunakkhatta, you have stood in the role of a slanderer and have brought upon yourself the censure .

analyzed: aneka kāraṇena vajji gāmā iti vajji rājānam gāme vesālī nagare no visahi iti na asakkhi  so a visahanto ti so su nakkhatto yassa pubbe tiṇṇam ratanānam vaṇṇam kathentassa mukham  nappahoti saḥ dāni tena iva mukhena avaṇṇam katheti addhā a visahantaḥ a sakkontaḥ brahmacariyam  caritum attanaḥ bāla tāya avaṇṇam kathetvā hīnāya avattaḥ buddhaḥ pana su buddhaḥ iva dhammo
translated: In order to show the danger in the role of a slanderer, the Exalted One said: “In many a figure, etc.” Herein, in many a figure means by many a reason. In the Vajjian capital means in the city of Vesäli, the capital of the Vajjians. He could not endure means he was not able.

original: svākkhātova, saṅgho suppaṭipannova. Evaṃ tīṇi ratanāni thomentā manussā tuyheva dosaṃ
analyzed: su ākkhātaḥ iva saṅghaḥ su paṭipannaḥ iva evam tīṇi ratanāni thomentā manussā tuyhā iva dosam
translated: He could not endure means Sunakkhatta, whose face was not able to look at the three jewels when their praise was being spoken, now spoke their dispraise with that very face. Surely, being unable to endure, being unable to live the holy life, he spoke dispraise through his own foolishness and fell away from the lay state. But the Buddha is well-spoken of, the Dhamma is well-taught, and the Saògha is well-practicing. Thus those who praise the three jewels will point out your very fault.

original: dassessantīti. Iti kho teti evaṃ kho te, sunakkhatta, vattāro bhavissanti. Tato evaṃ
analyzed: dassessanti iti iti kho te iti evam kho te sunakkhatta vattāraḥ bhavissanti tatas evam

translated: But he did not speak beforehand. This is what is shown by the words “You cannot say that he did not know.”🔽He departed: he departed, or he died.

analyzed: uṭṭhahitvā kathetum samattham nāma natthi idam katham kathesi iti buddha anubhāvena
translated: with a lie.” For this reason he approached. He knocked: he struck it. I know, friend: there is no one able to make a dead body rise up and speak. How did this happen? By the Buddha’s power.

original: Bhagavā kira korakkhattiyaṃ asurayonito ānetvā sarīre adhimocetvā kathāpesi. Tameva
analyzed: bhagavā kira korakkhattiyam asura yonitaḥ ānetvā sarīre adhimocetvā kathāpesi tam eva
translated: The Blessed One, it seems, brought down a warrior of Koṅkana from the asura world and had him possessed and made to speak.

original: vā sarīraṃ kathāpesi, acinteyyo hi buddhavisayo.
analyzed: vā sarīram kathāpesi acinteyyaḥ hi buddha visayaḥ
translated: Or he had him possessed and made to speak while still in the asura world. For the domain of Buddhas is inconceivable.

original: 10. Tatheva taṃ vipākanti tassa vacanassa vipākaṃ tatheva, udāhu noti liṅgavipallāso kato, tatheva so vipākoti attho. Keci pana “vipakka”ntipi paṭhanti, nibbattanti attho.
analyzed: tathā iva tam vipākam ti tassa vacanassa vipākam tathā iva udāhu no ti liṅga vipallāso kato tathā iva so vipāko ti attho keci pana vipakkam tipi paṭhanti nibbattanti attho
translated: “The same result”: the result of his words was the same. Or the text has been miswritten; the meaning is “the same result as that”. But some read “vipakka” , the meaning being “will be reborn”.

original: Ettha ṭhatvā pāṭihāriyāni samānetabbāni. Sabbāneva hetāni pañca pāṭihāriyāni honti.
analyzed: ettha ṭhatvā pāṭihāriyāni samānetabbāni ha etāni pañca pāṭihāriyāni honti
translated: The miracles should be brought in here. All these are fivefold miracles.

original: “Sattame divase marissatī”ti vuttaṃ, so tatheva mato, idaṃ paṭhamaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ.
analyzed: sattame divase marissati iti vuttam saḥ tathā iva mataḥ idam paṭhamam pāṭihāriyam
translated: “He will die on the seventh day” was said, and he died accordingly. This is the first miracle.

original: “Alasakenā”ti vuttaṃ, alasakeneva mato, idaṃ dutiyaṃ. “Kālakañcikesu nibbattissatī”ti
analyzed: alasakena ati vuttam alasakena iva mataḥ idam dutiyam kālakañcikesu nibbattissati iti
translated: “By poison” was said, and he died by poison. This is the second. “He will be reborn in the Kālakañja hell” was said,

original: vuttaṃ, tattheva nibbatto, idaṃ tatiyaṃ. “Bīraṇatthambake susāne chaḍḍessantī”ti
analyzed: vuttam tattha iva nibbatto idam tatiyam bīraṇatthambake susāne chaḍḍessanti iti
translated: and he was reborn there. This is the third. “They will throw him on a charnel-ground bīraṇa heap” was said,🔽and they did so. This is the fourth.

original: vuttaṃ, tattheva chaḍḍito, idaṃ catutthaṃ. “Nibbattaṭṭhānato āgantvā sunakkhattena
analyzed: vuttam tattha iva chaḍḍitaḥ idam catuttham nibbatta ṭṭhānataḥ āgantvā sunakkhattena
translated: and he was abandoned right there, this was the fourth.

original: saddhiṃ kathessatī”ti vutto, so kathesiyeva, idaṃ pañcamaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ.
analyzed: saddhim kathessati iti vutto saḥ kathesiya iva idam pañcamam pāṭihāriyam
translated: It was said, and he was left there. This was the fourth miracle. “He will converse with Sunakkhatta after coming from the place of his birth.” He did converse. This was the fifth miracle.

original: Acelakaḷāramaṭṭakavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽11. Kaḷāramaṭṭakoti nikkhantadantamattako. Nāmameva vā tassetaṃ. Lābhaggappattoti🔽lābhaggaṃ patto, aggalābhaṃ pattoti vuttaṃ hoti. Yasaggappattoti yasaggaṃ aggaparivāraṃ🔽patto. Vatapadānīti vatāniyeva, vatakoṭṭhāsā vā. Samattānīti gahitāni. Samādinnānīti🔽tasseva vevacanaṃ. Puratthimena vesālinti vesālito avidūre puratthimāya disāya. Cetiyanti
analyzed: acela kaḷāramaṭṭaka vatthu vaṇṇanā  kaḷāramaṭṭakaḥ ti nikkhanta dantamattakaḥ nāmam eva vā tassa etam lābha gga ppatto ti  lābhaggam patto agga lābham patto ti vuttam hoti yasagga patto ti yasaggam agga parivāram  pattaḥ vata padāni iti vatāniyā iva vata koṭṭhāsāḥ vā sa mattāni iti gahitāni samādinnāni iti  tassa iva vevacanam puratthimena vesālinti vesālitaḥ avidūre puratthimāya disāya cetiyanti
translated: The story of the naked ascetic Kālāramaṭṭaka

original: yakkhacetiyaṭṭhānaṃ. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: yakkha cetiya ṭṭhānam esa nayo sabbattha
translated: Kālāramaṭṭaka: one who has a beard only a finger’s breadth long. Or it is just his name. He had attained the highest gains: he had attained the highest gains, he had attained the best gains, is what is meant. He had attained the highest fame: he had attained the highest fame, the best retinue, is what is meant. He was living on what he had stored up: he was living on what he had stored up, on what he had collected. He was living on what he had stored up: this is a synonym for the former phrase. To the east of Vesālī: not far from Vesālī, in the eastern direction. A shrine: a place for a spirit-deity’s shrine. The same method applies in all cases.

original: 12. Yena acelakoti bhagavato vattaṃ katvā yena acelo kaḷāramaṭṭako tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: yena acelakaḥ iti bhagavataḥ vattam katvā yena acelaḥ kaḷāramaṭṭako tena upasaṅkami
translated: By which he went to the naked ascetic Kālāramaṭṭaka.

original: Pañhaṃ apucchīti gambhīraṃ tilakkhaṇāhataṃ pañhaṃ pucchi. Na sampāyāsīti na sammā🔽ñāṇagatiyā pāyāsi, andho viya visamaṭṭhāne tattha tattheva pakkhali. Neva ādiṃ, na
analyzed: pañham apucchi iti gambhīram tilakkhaṇa āhatam pañham pucchi na sampāyāsi iti na sammā  ñāṇa gatiyā andhaḥ viya visama ṭṭhāne tattha tattha iva pakkhali na iva ādim na
translated: He asked a question: he asked a deep question, one that had been struck by the three characteristics. He did not arrive: he did not arrive at the right path of knowledge. Like a blind man, he stumbled here and there on uneven ground. He did not arrive at the beginning, the middle, or the end.

original: pariyosānamaddasa. Atha vā “na sampāyāsī”ti na sampādesi, sampādetvā kathetuṃ nāsakkhi.
analyzed: pariyosānam addasa atha vā na sampāyāsi iti na sampādesi sampādetvā kathetum na asakkhi
translated: He asked a question: he asked a deep question, one that had been struck by the three characteristics. He did not answer: he did not go to the answer by means of right knowledge. He stumbled here and there like a blind man on uneven ground. He did not see the beginning or the end. Or alternatively, he did not answer means he did not make an answer. He was unable to explain after making an answer.

original: Asampāyantoti kabarakkhīni parivattetvā olokento “asikkhitakassa santike vuṭṭhosi,
analyzed: a sampāyantaḥ ti kabarakkhīni parivattetvā olokentaḥ asikkhitakassa santike vuṭṭho asi
translated: He did not answer: he turned his head this way and that, and saying, “You were given the Going-forth in the presence of one who is not trained,

original: anokāsepi pabbajito pañhaṃ pucchanto vicarasi, apehi mā etasmiṃ ṭhāne aṭṭhāsī”ti🔽vadanto. Kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsīti kuppanākāraṃ kopaṃ, dussanākāraṃ
analyzed: anokāse pi pabbajitaḥ pañham pucchantaḥ vicarasi apehi mā etasmim ṭhāne aṭṭhāsi iti  vadantaḥ kopam ca dosam ca appaccayam ca pātvā akāsi kuppana ākāram kopam dussana ākāram
translated: you have gone forth in an unsuitable place, you wander about asking questions, get out of here, do not stand in this place,”

original: dosaṃ, atuṭṭhākārabhūtaṃ domanassasaṅkhātaṃ appaccayañca pākaṭamakāsi. Āsādimhaseti🔽āsādiyimha ghaṭṭayimha. Mā vata no ahosīti aho vata me na bhaveyya. Maṃ vata no ahosītipi
analyzed: dosam atuṭṭhā ākāra bhūtam domanassa saṅkhātam appaccayam ca pākaṭam akāsi āsādimhaseti 🔽āsādiyimha ghaṭṭayimha mā vata naḥ ahosi iti aho vata me na bhaveyya mama vata naḥ ahosi itipi
translated: he made anger, which is the state of being angry, and hate, which is the state of hating, and contempt, which is the state of being contemptuous, manifest. We were defeated: we were defeated, we were struck down.

original: pāṭho. Tattha manti sāmivacanatthe upayogavacanaṃ, ahosi vata nu mamāti attho. Evañca🔽pana cintetvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā “khamatha me, bhante”ti taṃ khamāpesi. Sopi ito
analyzed: tattha manti sāmivacana tthe upayoga vacanam ahosi vata nu mama ati evam ca  pana cintetvā ukkuṭikam nisīditvā khamatha me bhante ti tam khamāpesi saḥ api itas
translated: Pāṭho. Herein, manti is a word of address in the sense of “friend”; the meaning is “it has happened to me, friend”.🔽Having reflected thus, he sat down cross-legged and asked for forgiveness, saying “Pardon me, venerable sir”. The other said “From now on you will not ask any more questions, will you?”

original: paṭṭhāya aññaṃ kiñci pañhaṃ nāma na pucchissasīti. Āma na pucchissāmīti. Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya aññam kiñci pañham nāma na pucchissasi iti āma na pucchissāmi iti yadi evam
translated: “No, I will not ask any more questions.” “If that is so,

original: gaccha, khamāmi teti taṃ uyyojesi.
analyzed: gaccha khamāmi te iti tam uyyojesi
translated: go, I pardon you.”

original: 14. Parihitoti paridahito nivatthavattho. Sānucārikoti anucārikā vuccati bhariyā,🔽saha anucārikāya sānucāriko, taṃ taṃ brahmacariyaṃ pahāya sabhariyoti attho. Odanakummāsanti
analyzed: parihitaḥ ti paridahitaḥ nivattha vattho sa anucāriko ti anucārikā vuccati bhariyā  saha anucārikāya sa anucārikaḥ tam tam brahmacariyam pahāya sa bhariyaḥ ti attho odana kummā asanti
translated: Parihito: he was paridahito, i.e. he had put on his under robe. Sānucāriko: a wife is called an anucārikā .

original: surāmaṃsato atirekaṃ odanampi kummāsampi bhuñjamāno. Yasā nihīnoti yaṃ lābhaggayasaggaṃ🔽patto, tato parihīno hutvā. “Kataṃ hoti uttarimanussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriya”nti idha
analyzed: surā maṃsataḥ atirekam odanam pi kummāsam pi bhuñjamānaḥ yasā yam yam  pattaḥ tatas parihīnaḥ hutvā katam hoti uttari manussa dhammā iddhi pāṭihāriyanti idha
translated: With an anucārikā he is sānucāriko. The meaning is that he had abandoned the life of celibacy and had taken a wife. Odanakummās: eating rice and cakes in addition to the flesh of the flesh-eaters. Yasā nihīno: having fallen away from the pre-eminence in gain and honour

original: sattavatapadātikkamavasena satta pāṭihāriyāni veditabbāni.
analyzed: sattavata pada atikkama vasena satta pāṭihāriyāni veditabbāni
translated: that he had attained. “The wonder of supernormal power that is superhuman and beyond the capacity of human beings has been performed” . Herein, the seven wonders should be understood as follows: the seven wonders are the seven wonders of supernormal power, the seven wonders of mind-reading, the seven wonders of body-projection, the seven wonders of creation, the seven wonders of transformation, the seven wonders of resolution, and the seven wonders of intervention.

original: Acelapāthikaputtavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: acela pāthika putta vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the naked ascetic Pāṭika

original: 15. Pāthikaputtoti pāthikassa putto. Ñāṇavādenāti ñāṇavādena saddhiṃ. Upaḍḍhapathanti
analyzed: pāthika putto ti pāthikassa puttaḥ ñāṇa vādena ati ñāṇa vādena saddhim
translated: Pāṭika’s son: Pāṭika’s son. With a claim to knowledge: with a claim to knowledge. Half the way:

original: yojanaṃ ce, no antare bhaveyya, gotamo aḍḍhayojanaṃ, ahaṃ aḍḍhayojanaṃ. Esa nayo
analyzed: yojanam ce naḥ antare bhaveyya gotamaḥ aḍḍha yojanam aham aḍḍha yojanam
translated: if it is a yojana, it will be half a yojana for Gotama and half a yojana for me. The same method applies

original: aḍḍhayojanādīsu. Ekapadavārampi atikkamma gacchato jayo bhavissati, anāgacchato parājayoti.
analyzed: aḍḍha yojana ādīsu eka pada vāram pi atikkamma gacchataḥ jayaḥ bhavissati an āgacchataḥ parājayo ti
translated: to a yojana and a half, etc. If he goes beyond the first stage, he will win, and if he does not go, he will lose.”

original: Te tatthāti te mayaṃ tattha samāgataṭṭhāne. Taddiguṇaṃ taddiguṇāhanti tato tato diguṇaṃ
analyzed: te tattha ati te mayam tattha samāgata ṭṭhāne tad diguṇam tad diguṇā hanti tato tato diguṇam
translated: There: there, at the place where we had met. Double that: double that.

original: diguṇaṃ ahaṃ karissāmi, bhagavatā saddhiṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ kātuṃ asamatthabhāvaṃ jānantopi
analyzed: diguṇam aham karissāmi bhagavatā saddhim pāṭihāriyam kātum asamattha bhāvam jānantaḥ api
translated: Although he knew that he was unable to perform a miracle with the Exalted One,

original: “uttamapurisena saddhiṃ paṭṭhapetvā asakkuṇantassāpi pāsaṃso hotī”ti ñatvā evamāha.
analyzed: uttama purisena saddhim paṭṭhapetvā a sakkuṇantassa api pāsaṃso hoti iti ñatvā evam āha
translated: he said this, thinking, “Even if one cannot perform a miracle after challenging an excellent person, one is still praised.”

original: Nagaravāsinopi taṃ sutvā “asamattho nāma evaṃ na gajjati, addhā ayampi arahā bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: nagara vāsinaḥ api tam sutvā asamatthaḥ nāma evam na gajjati addhā ayam pi arahā bhavissati iti
translated: The city-dwellers, hearing this, thought, “One who is unable does not speak in this way. Surely he too must be an arahant.”

original: tassa mahantaṃ sakkāramakaṃsu.
analyzed: tassa mahantam sakkāram akaṃsu
translated: So they paid him great honor.

original: 16. Yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamīti “sunakkhatto kira pāthikaputto evaṃ vadatī”ti assosi. Athassa hīnajjhāsayattā hīnadassanāya cittaṃ udapādi.
analyzed: yena aham tena upasaṅkami iti sunakkhatto kira pāthika putto evam vadati iti assosi atha assa hīna ajjhāsaya tā hīna dassanāya cittam udapādi
translated: “I will go to him” : he heard that Sunakkhatta was saying this. Then, because of his low disposition and his low view, his mind arose in a low way.

original: So bhagavato vattaṃ katvā bhagavati gandhakuṭiṃ paviṭṭhe pāthikaputtassa santikaṃ
analyzed: saḥ bhagavato vattam katvā bhagavati gandhakuṭim paviṭṭhe pāthikaputtassa santikam
translated: After doing the proper duties to the Blessed One, when the Blessed One had entered the Fragrant Cell, he went to Pāṭika-putta

original: gantvā pucchi “tumhe kira evarūpiṃ kathaṃ kathethā”ti? “Āma, kathemā”ti. Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: gantvā pucchi tumhe kira evarūpim katham kathetha ati āma kathema iti yadi evam
translated: and asked him, “Is it true that you are saying such and such?” “Yes, I am saying it.” “If that is so,

original: “mā bhāyittha vissatthā punappunaṃ evaṃ vadatha, ahaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa upaṭṭhāko,
analyzed: mā bhāyittha vissatthā punappunam evam vadatha aham samaṇassa gotamassa upaṭṭhāko
translated: then don’t be afraid. Be confident and say it again and again. I am the attendant of the contemplative Gotama,

original: tassa visayaṃ vijānāmi, tumhehi saddhiṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ kātuṃ na sakkhissati, ahaṃ samaṇassa
analyzed: tassa visayam vijānāmi tumhehi saddhim pāṭihāriyam kātum na sakkhissati aham samaṇassa
translated: I know his range. He will not be able to work a miracle together with you. I will talk with the contemplative Gotama

original: gotamassa kathetvā bhayaṃ uppādetvā taṃ aññato gahetvā gamissāmi, tumhe mā bhāyitthā”ti
analyzed: gotamassa kathetvā bhayam uppādetvā tam aññatas gahetvā gamissāmi tumhe mā bhāyittha ati
translated: and, arousing fear in him, I will take him away by some means or other. You need not be afraid.”

original: taṃ assāsetvā bhagavato santikaṃ gato. Tena vuttaṃ “yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamī”ti. Taṃ
analyzed: tam assāsetvā bhagavato santikam gataḥ tena vuttam yena aham tena upasaṅkami iti tam
translated: After reassuring him, he went to the Blessed One. Thus it was said, “I will go to him.”

original: vācantiādīsu “ahaṃ abuddhova samāno buddhomhīti vicariṃ, abhūtaṃ me kathitaṃ nāhaṃ🔽buddho”ti vadanto taṃ vācaṃ pajahati nāma. Raho nisīditvā cintayamāno “ahaṃ ‘ettakaṃ🔽kālaṃ abuddhova samāno buddhomhī’ti vicariṃ, ito dāni paṭṭhāya nāhaṃ buddho”ti cintayanto🔽taṃ cittaṃ pajahati nāma. “Ahaṃ ‘ettakaṃ kālaṃ abuddhova samāno buddhomhī’ti pāpakaṃ🔽diṭṭhiṃ gahetvā vicariṃ, ito dāni paṭṭhāya imaṃ diṭṭhiṃ pajahāmī”ti pajahanto taṃ🔽diṭṭhiṃ paṭinissajjati nāma. Evaṃ akaronto pana taṃ vācaṃ appahāya taṃ cittaṃ appahāya
analyzed: aham abuddhaḥ uva samānaḥ buddhaḥ asmi iti abhūtam me kathitam na aham  buddha uti vadantaḥ tam vācam pajahati nāma rahaḥ nisīditvā cintayamānaḥ aham ettakam  kālam abuddhaḥ uva samānaḥ buddhaḥ asmi iti vicarim itas dāni paṭṭhāya na aham buddhaḥ iti cintayanto  tam cittam pajahati nāma aham ettakam kālam abuddhaḥ uva samānaḥ buddhaḥ asmi iti pāpakam  diṭṭhim gahetvā vicarim itas dāni paṭṭhāya imam diṭṭhim pajahāmi iti pajahanto tam  diṭṭhim paṭinissajjati nāma evam a karontaḥ pana tam vācam appahāya tam cittam appahāya
translated: In the case of the words, etc., he abandons the speech by saying, “I have been wandering about saying, ‘I am a Buddha though not a Buddha,’ and I have been telling a lie. I am not a Buddha.” He abandons the cognizance by thinking, “I have been wandering about saying, ‘I am a Buddha though not a Buddha,’ while sitting in private and thinking. From now on I am not a Buddha.” He abandons the view by thinking, “I have been wandering about holding the evil view, ‘I am a Buddha though not a Buddha.’ From now on I abandon this view.” He relinquishes the view by relinquishing it thus. But when he does not act thus, he does not abandon the speech, he does not abandon the cognizance,

original: taṃ diṭṭhiṃ appaṭinissajjitvāti vuccati. Vipateyyāti bandhanā muttatālapakkaṃ viya🔽gīvato pateyya, sattadhā vā pana phaleyya.
analyzed: tam diṭṭhim a paṭinissajjitvā ati vuccati vipateyya ati bandhanā mutta tāla pakkam viya 🔽gīvataḥ pateyya sattadhā vā pana phaleyya
translated: In the case of the words, etc., he abandons the speech by saying, “I have been wandering about saying, ‘I am enlightened, though I am not enlightened,’ and I have been telling a deliberate lie. I am not enlightened.” He abandons the cognizance by thinking, “I have been wandering about saying, ‘I am enlightened, though I am not enlightened,’ while sitting in private and reflecting. From now on I am not enlightened.” He abandons the view by thinking, “I have been holding this evil view, ‘I am enlightened, though I am not enlightened,’ and wandering about. From now on I abandon this view.” He relinquishes the view by relinquishing it thus. But one who does not act thus is said not to abandon the speech, not to abandon the cognizance, not to relinquish the view. He would split in seven parts: he would fall from his mouth like a ripe palm fruit freed from its stem or he would split into seven parts.

original: 17. Rakkhatetanti rakkhatu etaṃ. Ekaṃsenāti nippariyāyena. Odhāritāti bhāsitā. Acelo
analyzed: rakkhata itanti rakkhatu etam ekaṃsena ati nippariyāyena odhāritā ati bhāsitā acelaḥ
translated: 17. Rakkhatetanti rakkhatu etaṃ. Ekaṃsenāti nippariyāyena. Odhāritāti bhāsitā. Acelo

original: ca, bhante, pāthikaputtoti evaṃ ekaṃsena bhagavato vācāya odhāritāya sace acelo pāthikaputto.🔽Virūparūpenāti vigatarūpena vigacchitasabhāvena rūpena attano rūpaṃ pahāya adissamānena
analyzed: ca bhante pāthika putto ti evam ekaṃsena bhagavataḥ vācāya odhāritāya sace acelaḥ pāthika putto  virūpa rūpena ati vigata rūpena vigacchita sabhāvena rūpena attanaḥ rūpam pahāya a dissamānena
translated: ‘May he guard it’: may he guard this. ‘Without remainder’: without exception. ‘Is uttered’: is spoken. ‘The naked ascetic Pāṭika, venerable Sir’: thus, without remainder, the Blessed One’s words are uttered. If the naked ascetic Pāṭika,

original: kāyena. Sīhabyagghādivasena vā vividharūpena sammukhībhāvaṃ āgaccheyya. Tadassa bhagavato
analyzed: kāyena sīha byaggha ādi vasena vā vividha rūpena sammukhībhāvam āgaccheyya tat assa bhagavataḥ
translated: ‘With a form that is not his own’: with a form that is not his own nature, with a form that is not his own real nature, having abandoned his own form, with a body that is not visible. Or else, with a form that is various, like a lion, a tiger, etc., he might come into presence. Then,

original: musāti evaṃ sante bhagavato taṃ vacanaṃ musā bhaveyyāti musāvādena niggaṇhāti. Ṭhapetvā
analyzed: musā ati evam sante bhagavato tam vacanam musā bhaveyya iti musāvādena niggaṇhāti ṭhapetvā
translated: ‘The Blessed One’s words would be false’: if it were so, the Blessed One’s words would be false. Thus he reproves him with the reproach of falsehood. It is said that,

original: kira etaṃ na aññena bhagavā musāvādena niggahitapubboti.
analyzed: kira etam na aññena bhagavā musāvādena niggahita pubbaḥ ti
translated: except for this, the Blessed One has never before been reproved with the reproach of falsehood by anyone.

original: 18. Dvayagāminīti sarūpena atthibhāvaṃ, atthena natthibhāvanti evaṃ dvayagāminī. Alikatucchanipphalavācāya etaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: dvaya gāminī iti sarūpena atthi bhāvam atthena evam dvaya gāminī alika tuccha nipphala vācāya adhivacanam
translated: ‘Going in two ways’: it goes in two ways, namely, by the form it has existence, and by the meaning it has non-existence. This is a term for a statement that is empty, hollow, and fruitless.

original: 19. Ajitopi nāma licchavīnaṃ senāpatīti so kira bhagavato upaṭṭhāko ahosi, so kālamakāsi.
analyzed: ajitaḥ api nāma licchavīnam senāpati iti saḥ kira bhagavataḥ upaṭṭhākaḥ ahosi saḥ kālam akāsi
translated: Ajita, the general of the Licchavis, was a supporter of the Exalted One. He died.

original: Athassa sarīrakiccaṃ katvā manussā pāthikaputtaṃ pucchiṃsu “kuhiṃ nibbatto senāpatī”ti?🔽So āha – “mahāniraye nibbatto”ti. Idañca pana vatvā puna āha “tumhākaṃ senāpati mama
analyzed: athassa sarīra kiccam katvā manussā pāthika puttam pucchiṃsu kuhim nibbattaḥ senāpati iti  saḥ āha mahāniraye nibbatto ti idam ca pana vatvā puna āha tumhākam senāpati mama
translated: After his funeral, the people asked Patikaputta, “Where was the general reborn?”🔽He said, “In the Great Hell.” Then he added, “Your general came to me and said, ‘I will not do as you say but will support the doctrine of the recluse Gotama.’

original: santikaṃ āgamma ahaṃ tumhākaṃ vacanamakatvā samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ patiṭṭhapetvā🔽niraye nibbattomhī”ti paroditthāti. Tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāyāti ettha “pāṭihāriyakaraṇatthāyā”ti
analyzed: santikam āgamma aham tumhākam vacanam a katvā samaṇassa gotamassa vādam patiṭṭhapetvā  niraye nibbattomhi iti tena upasaṅkami divāvihārāya ati ettha pāṭihāriya karaṇa tthāya ati
translated: He was reborn in hell, weeping and lamenting, ‘I have been defeated by the recluse Gotama.’ ”

original: kasmā na vadati? Abhāvā. Sammukhībhāvopi hissa tena saddhiṃ natthi, kuto pāṭihāriyakaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: kasmā na vadati abhāvā sammukhībhāvaḥ api hi ssa tena saddhim natthi kutas pāṭihāriya karaṇam
translated: Why does the commentator not say that the Exalted One went to him in order to perform a miracle? Because there was no such reason. For he was not even present before the Exalted One, let alone that he had any intention of performing a miracle.

original: tasmā tathā avatvā “divāvihārāyā”ti āha.
analyzed: tasmai tathā avatvā divāvihārāya ati āha
translated: Therefore, without saying that, the commentator says, “in order to spend the day.”

original: Iddhipāṭihāriyakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: iddhi pāṭihāriya kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the miracle of twin-disappearance

original: 20. Gahapatinecayikāti gahapati mahāsālā. Tesañhi mahādhanadhaññanicayo, tasmā “necayikā”ti
analyzed: gahapatinecayikā ati gahapati mahā sālā tesam hi mahā dhana dhañña nicayo tasmā necayikā ati
translated: Householders who are rich in possessions: great householders who are rich in great wealth and grain.

original: vuccanti. Anekasahassāti sahassehipi aparimāṇagaṇanā. Evaṃ mahatiṃ kira parisaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: vuccanti aneka sahassā ati sahassehi pi aparimāṇa gaṇanā evam mahatim kira parisam ṭhapetvā
translated: are called. Many thousands: the counting of the immeasurable by thousands. So, having set up a great assembly like this,

original: sunakkhattaṃ añño sannipātetuṃ samattho natthi. Teneva bhagavā ettakaṃ kālaṃ sunakkhattaṃ gahetvā vicari.
analyzed: sunakkhattam aññaḥ sannipātetum samatthaḥ na atthi tena iva bhagavā ettakam kālam sunakkhattam gahetvā vicari
translated: there is no one else able to assemble Sunakkhatta. For this very reason the Blessed One went about for so long taking Sunakkhatta with him.

original: 21. Bhayanti cittutrāsabhayaṃ. Chambhitattanti sakalasarīracalanaṃ. Lomahaṃsoti lomānaṃ🔽uddhaggabhāvo. So kira cintesi – “ahaṃ atimahantaṃ kathaṃ kathetvā sadevake loke
analyzed: bhayanti cittu trāsa bhayam sakala sarīra calanam loma haṃsaḥ iti lomānam  uddhagga bhāvaḥ saḥ kira cintesi aham ati mahantam katham kathetvā sa devake loke
translated: Fear: the fear of mental terror. Fright: the trembling of the whole body. Hairs standing on end:

original: aggapuggalena saddhiṃ paṭiviruddho, mayhaṃ kho panabbhantare arahattaṃ vā pāṭihāriyakaraṇahetu
analyzed: agga puggalena saddhim paṭiviruddhaḥ mayham kho pana abbhantare arahattam vā pāṭihāriya karaṇa hetu
translated: the hairs of the body standing on end. He thought: “I have argued a great deal, and I have argued against the foremost person in the world together with the gods.

original: vā natthi, samaṇo pana gotamo pāṭihāriyaṃ karissati, athassa pāṭihāriyaṃ disvā mahājano
analyzed: vā natthi samaṇaḥ pana gotamo pāṭihāriyam karissati athassa pāṭihāriyam disvā mahā janaḥ
translated: But I have neither Arahantship nor the cause for performing a miracle within me. But the ascetic Gotama will perform a miracle. Then, having seen his miracle, the great crowd

original: ‘tvaṃ dāni pāṭihāriyaṃ kātuṃ asakkonto kasmā attano pamāṇamajānitvā loke aggapuggalena
analyzed: tvam dāni pāṭihāriyam kātum a sakkontaḥ kasmai attanaḥ pamāṇam a jānitvā loke agga puggalena
translated: will say: ‘You are unable to perform a miracle now. Why, not knowing your own measure, did you challenge the foremost person in the world🔽to a miracle?

original: saddhiṃ paṭimallo hutvā gajjasī’ti kaṭṭhaleḍḍudaṇḍādīhi viheṭhessatī”ti. Tenassa
analyzed: saddhim paṭimallaḥ hutvā gajjasi iti kaṭṭha leḍḍu daṇḍa ādīhi viheṭhessati iti tenassa
translated: “I’ll get the better of him in debate and then I’ll beat him with sticks, clods of earth, and fists.”

original: mahājanasannipātañceva tena bhagavato ca āgamanaṃ sutvā bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā
analyzed: mahā jana sannipātam ca iva tena bhagavataḥ ca āgamanam sutvā bhayam vā chambhi tattam vā
translated: When he heard of the great crowd and of the Blessed One’s arrival, he was seized with fear, alarm, and terror.

original: lomahaṃso vā udapādi. So tato dukkhā muccitukāmo tindukakhāṇukaparibbājakārāmaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: lomahaṃsaḥ vai udapādi saḥ tatas dukkhā muccitu kāmo tinduka khāṇuka paribbājaka ārāmam agamāsi
translated: He went to the Tinduka lodging of the wanderers, wishing to be free from that fear.

original: Tamatthaṃ dassetuṃ atha kho bhagavātiādimāha. Tattha upasaṅkamīti na kevalaṃ upasaṅkami,
analyzed: tam attham dassetum atha kho bhagavā iti ādim āha tattha upasaṅkami iti na kevalam upasaṅkami
translated: To show that meaning, he said, “Then the Blessed One approached.” There he did not just approach;

original: upasaṅkamitvā pana dūraṃ aḍḍhayojanantaraṃ paribbājakārāmaṃ paviṭṭho. Tatthapi cittassādaṃ
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā pana dūram aḍḍha yojana antaram paribbājaka ārāmam paviṭṭho tattha api
translated: after approaching, he entered the wanderers’ park, a distance of half a league. There too, not finding satisfaction in his mind,

original: alabhamāno antantena āvijjhitvā ārāmapaccante ekaṃ gahanaṭṭhānaṃ upadhāretvā pāsāṇaphalake
analyzed: a labhamānaḥ anta antena āvijjhitvā ārāma paccante ekam gahana ṭṭhānam upadhāretvā pāsāṇa phalake
translated: he went out by the back gate and, after looking around, he sat down on a flat rock in a secluded place at the edge of the park.

original: nisīdi. Atha bhagavā cintesi – “sace ayaṃ bālo kassacideva kathaṃ gahetvā idhāgaccheyya,
analyzed: nisīdi atha bhagavā cintesi sace ayam bālo kassacid eva katham gahetvā idha āgaccheyya
translated: Then the Blessed One thought, “If this fool comes here, taking up some story,

original: mā nassatu bālo”ti “nisinnapāsāṇaphalakaṃ tassa sarīre allīnaṃ hotū”ti adhiṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: mā nassatu bālo ti nisinna pāsāṇa phalakam tassa sarīre allīnam hotu uti adhiṭṭhāsi
translated: may he not be lost. May he stick to the flat rock where he is sitting.” He resolved, “May the flat rock where he is sitting stick to his body.”

original: Saha adhiṭṭhānacittena taṃ tassa sarīre allīyi. So mahāaddubandhanabaddho viya chinnapādo viya ca ahosi.
analyzed: saha adhiṭṭhāna cittena tam tassa sarīre allīyi saḥ mahā addu bandhana baddhaḥ viya chinna pādaḥ viya ca ahosi
translated: As soon as he had formed the resolution, it stuck to his body, and he was as if bound with a great rope or as if his foot had been caught in a snare.

original: Assosīti ito cito ca pāthikaputtaṃ pariyesamānā parisā tassa anupadaṃ gantvā nisinnaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: assosi iti itas citas ca pāthika puttam pariyesamānā parisā tassa anupadam gantvā nisinna ṭhānam
translated: “Heard of” : a crowd of people searching here and there for Patikaputta came upon the place where he was sitting.

original: ñatvā āgatena aññatarena purisena “tumhe kaṃ pariyesathā”ti vutte pāthikaputtanti.
analyzed: ñatvā āgatena aññatarena purisena tumhe kam pariyesatha ati vutte pāthika puttanti
translated: When a certain man who had come with them asked, “Whom are you searching for? “ they replied, “Patikaputta.”

original: So “tindukakhāṇukaparibbājakārāme nisinno”ti vuttavacanena assosi.
analyzed: so tinduka khāṇuka paribbājaka ārāme nisinnaḥ ti vutta vacanena assosi
translated: When he told them that Patikaputta was sitting in the Tinduka-fruit hermitage, they heard of him.

original: 22. Saṃsappatīti osīdati. Tattheva sañcarati. Pāvaḷā vuccati ānisadaṭṭhikā.
analyzed: saṃsappati iti osīdati tattha iva sañcarati pāvaḷā vuccati ānisadaṭṭhikā
translated: “Slithers” : sinks down, moves about right there. “Hip” is a name for the hip-bone.

original: 23. Parābhūtarūpoti parājitarūpo, vinaṭṭharūpo vā.
analyzed: parābhūta rūpo ti parājita rūpaḥ vinaṭṭha rūpaḥ vā
translated: “Defeated” : in the sense of being defeated, or in the sense of being destroyed.

original: 25. Goyugehīti goyuttehi satamattehi vā sahassamattehi vā yugehi. Āviñcheyyāmāti ākaḍḍheyyāma. Chijjeyyunti chindeyyuṃ. Pāthikaputto vā bandhaṭṭhāne chijjeyya.
analyzed: go yugehi iti go yuttehi satamattehi vā sahassamattehi vā yugehi āviñcheyyāma ati ākaḍḍheyyāma chijjeyyunti chindeyyum pāthika putto vā bandha ṭṭhāne chijjeyya
translated: “With a yoke of oxen” : with a yoke of oxen worth a hundred or a thousand. “We would drag him along” : we would pull him along. “They would break” : they would break. Either Patikaputta would break at the place where he was bound,

original: 26. Dārupattikantevāsīti dārupattikassa antevāsī. Tassa kira etadahosi “tiṭṭhatu
analyzed: dārupattika antevāsī iti dārupattikassa antevāsī tassa kira etat ahosi tiṭṭhatu
translated: The pupil of the owner of the timber: the pupil of the owner of the timber. It seems that he thought: “Let the owner of the timber do it. I am his pupil. Why should I do it?

original: tāva pāṭihāriyaṃ, samaṇo gotamo ‘acelo pāthikaputto āsanāpi na vuṭṭhahissatī’ti āha.🔽Handāhaṃ gantvā yena kenaci upāyena taṃ āsanā vuṭṭhāpemi. Ettāvatā ca samaṇassa gotamassa
analyzed: tāva pāṭihāriyam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ acelaḥ pāthika putto āsanā api na vuṭṭhahissati iti āha  handa aham gantvā yena kenacid upāyena tam āsanā vuṭṭhāpemi ettāvatā ca samaṇassa gotamassa
translated: Dārupattikantevāsī: a pupil of Dārupattika. It seems that he thought: “Let alone the miracle, the ascetic Gotama said: ‘The naked ascetic Pāṭikaputta will not rise from his seat.’

original: parājayo bhavissatī”ti. Tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: parājayaḥ bhavissati iti tasmai evam āha
translated: So I will go and make him rise from his seat by some means or other. In this way the ascetic Gotama will be defeated.” That is why he said this.

original: 27. Sīhassāti cattāro sīhā tiṇasīho ca kāḷasīho ca paṇḍusīho ca kesarasīho ca. Tesaṃ🔽catunnaṃ sīhānaṃ kesarasīho aggataṃ gato, so idhādhippeto. Migaraññoti sabbacatuppadānaṃ
analyzed: sīhassa ati cattāro sīhā tiṇasīhaḥ ca kāḷasīhaḥ ca paṇḍusīho ca kesarasīho ca tesam  catunnam sīhānam kesarasīhaḥ aggatam gataḥ saḥ idha adhippetaḥ migarañño ti sabba catu padānam
translated: Sīha: there are four kinds of lions: the grass lion, the black lion, the white lion, and the tawny lion.

original: rañño. Āsayanti nivāsaṃ. Sīhanādanti abhītanādaṃ. Gocarāya pakkameyyanti āhāratthāya
analyzed: raññaḥ āsayanti nivāsam sīha nādanti abhīta nādam gocarāya pakkameyyanti āhāra atthāya
translated: Of these four lions, the tawny lion is the best. He is meant here. Migarañño: king of all four-footed animals. Āsayanti: a dwelling place. Sīhanāda: a fearless roar. Gocarāya pakkameyyanti I would go out for food.

original: pakkameyyaṃ. Varaṃ varanti uttamuttamaṃ, thūlaṃ thūlanti attho. Mudumaṃsānīti mudūni
analyzed: pakkameyyam varam varanti uttamuttamam thūlam thūlanti attho mudu maṃsāni iti mudūni
translated: Varaṃ varanti: the best, the most excellent. The meaning is: the thick, the fat. Mudumaṃsānīti: soft flesh.

original: maṃsāni. “Madhumaṃsānī”tipi pāṭho, madhuramaṃsānīti attho. Ajjhupeyyanti upagaccheyyaṃ.
analyzed: maṃsāni madhu maṃsāni iti pi pāṭhaḥ madhura maṃsāni iti atthaḥ ajjhupeyyanti upagaccheyyam
translated: “Honey and meat” is the reading in some texts; the meaning is “sweet meat.” I would eat: I would approach.

original: Sīhanādaṃ naditvāti ye dubbalā pāṇā, te palāyantūti attano sūrabhāvasannissitena kāruññena naditvā.
analyzed: sīha nādam naditvā ati ye dubbalā pāṇā te palāyantu iti attanaḥ sūra bhāva sannissitena kāruññena naditvā
translated: Having roared a lion’s roar: having roared out of compassion, depending on his own sweet nature, thinking “Let the weak creatures flee.”

original: 28. Vighāsasaṃvaḍḍhoti vighāsena saṃvaḍḍho, vighāsaṃ bhakkhitā tirittamaṃsaṃ khāditvā
analyzed: vighāsa saṃvaḍḍho ti vighāsena saṃvaḍḍhaḥ vighāsam bhakkhitā tiritta maṃsam khāditvā
translated: Having grown fat on scraps: having grown fat on scraps, having grown fat by eating the flesh of small animals.

original: vaḍḍhito. Dittoti dappito thūlasarīro. Balavāti balasampanno. Etadahosīti kasmā ahosi? Asmimānadosena.
analyzed: vaḍḍhitaḥ dittoti dappitaḥ thūla sarīraḥ balavāti bala sampannaḥ etat ahosi iti kasmai ahosi asmimāna dosena
translated: Having grown fat: having become fat, having become one with a large body. Having become strong: having become endowed with strength. This occurred to him: why did it occur to him? Out of self-conceit.

original: Tatrāyaṃ anupubbikathā – ekadivasaṃ kira so sīho gocarato nivattamāno taṃ siṅgālaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam anupubbi kathā eka divasam kira saḥ sīhaḥ gocarataḥ nivattamānaḥ tam siṅgālam
translated: Here is the connected story. One day, it seems, that lion, on his return from the alms round, saw that jackal

original: bhayena palāyamānaṃ disvā kāruññajāto hutvā “vayasa, mā bhāyi, tiṭṭha ko nāma tva”nti
analyzed: bhayena palāyamānam disvā kāruñña jātaḥ hutvā mā bhāyi tiṭṭha kaḥ nāma tvanti
translated: fleeing in fear. Out of compassion he said to him, “Don’t be afraid, my dear jackal. Stop a moment. What is your name?”

original: āha. Jambuko nāmāhaṃ sāmīti. Vayasa, jambuka, ito paṭṭhāya maṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ sakkhissasīti.
analyzed: āha jambukaḥ nāma aham sāmi iti vayasa jambukaḥ itas paṭṭhāya mam upaṭṭhātum sakkhissasi iti
translated: “My name is Jackal, master.” “Well then, my dear Jackal, from now on you will be able to attend on me.”

original: Upaṭṭhahissāmīti. So tato paṭṭhāya upaṭṭhāti. Sīho gocarato āgacchanto mahantaṃ mahantaṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhahissāmi iti so tatas paṭṭhāya upaṭṭhāti sīhaḥ gocarataḥ āgacchantaḥ mahantam mahantam
translated: ‘I’ll look after you.’ And he looks after him. The lion comes back from his walk and

original: maṃsakhaṇḍaṃ āharati. So taṃ khāditvā avidūre pāsāṇapiṭṭhe vasati. So katipāhaccayeneva🔽thūlasarīro mahākhandho jāto. Atha naṃ sīho avoca – “vayasa, jambuka, mama vijambhanakāle
analyzed: maṃsa khaṇḍam āharati saḥ tam khāditvā avidūre pāsāṇa piṭṭhe vasati saḥ katipāhaccayena iva  thūla sarīraḥ mahā khandhaḥ jātaḥ atha nam sīhaḥ avoca jambuka mama vijambhana kāle
translated: I will attend on you.” And from then on he attended on the lion. The lion brought back a large piece of meat from his hunt, and the jackal ate it. He stayed on a rock not far from the lion. After a few days

original: avidūre ṭhatvā ‘viroca sāmī’ti vattuṃ sakkhissasī”ti. Sakkomi sāmīti. So tassa vijambhanakāle
analyzed: avidūre ṭhatvā viroca sāmi iti vattum sakkhissasi iti sakkomi sāmi iti so tassa vijambhana kāle
translated: he became fat and his body grew large. Then the lion said to him, “Jackal, when I yawn, you will be able to stand close by and say, ‘The lord is radiant.’ ” “I can do that, lord.” When the lion yawned, the jackal did as he was told.

original: tathā karoti. Tena sīhassa atireko asmimāno hoti.
analyzed: tathā karoti tena sīhassa atirekaḥ asmimānaḥ hoti
translated: This made the lion’s conceit increase even more.

original: Athekadivasaṃ jarasiṅgālo udakasoṇḍiyaṃ pānīyaṃ pivanto attano chāyaṃ olokento addasa
analyzed: atha eka divasam jarasiṅgālaḥ udaka soṇḍiyam pānīyam pivantaḥ attano chāyam olokentaḥ addasa
translated: One day the old jackal was drinking water at a pond. As he looked at his reflection, he saw

original: attano thūlasarīratañceva mahākhandhatañca. Disvā ‘jarasiṅgālosmī’ti manaṃ akatvā
analyzed: thūla sarīra tat ca iva mahā khandha tat ca disvā jarasiṅgālaḥ asmi iti manaṃ a katvā
translated: his fat body and large belly. Not realizing that he was an old jackal,🔽he thought, “I have become a lion.” Then he said to himself, “Jackal, it is not right

original: “ahampi sīho jāto”ti maññi. Tato attanāva attānaṃ etadavoca – “vayasa, jambuka, yuttaṃ
analyzed: aham pi sīhaḥ jātaḥ iti maññi tatas attanā ava attānam etat avoca
translated: for you

original: nāma tava iminā attabhāvena parassa ucchiṭṭhamaṃsaṃ khādituṃ, kiṃ tvaṃ puriso na
analyzed: nāma tava iminā atta bhāvena parassa ucchiṭṭha maṃsam khāditum kim tvam purisaḥ na
translated: “You are not a man, are you, since you eat the leavings of another’s mouth in this form of yours?

original: hosi, sīhassāpi cattāro pādā dve dāṭhā dve kaṇṇā ekaṃ naṅguṭṭhaṃ, tavapi sabbaṃ tatheva,
analyzed: hosi sīhassa api cattāro pādāḥ dve dāṭhā dve kaṇṇā ekam naṅguṭṭham tava api sabbam tathā iva
translated: The lion has four feet, two fangs, two ears, and a tail; you have all these too.

original: kevalaṃ tava kesarabhāramattameva natthī”ti. Tassevaṃ cintayato asmimāno vaḍḍhi.
analyzed: kevalam tava kesara bhāra mattam eva natthi iti tassa evam cintayataḥ asmimānaḥ vaḍḍhi
translated: Only the mane is lacking.” As he thus reflected, his conceit increased.

original: Athassa tena asmimānadosena etaṃ “ko cāha”ntiādi maññitamahosi. Tattha ko cāhanti
analyzed: athassa tena asmimāna dosena etam ko ca ahanti ādi maññitam ahosi tattha ko ca ahanti
translated: Then, through that conceit, he had the thought expressed in the words, “Who is he? ” etc. Herein, who is he?

original: ahaṃ ko, sīho migarājā ko, na me ñāti, na sāmiko, kimahaṃ tassa nipaccakāraṃ karomīti
analyzed: aham kaḥ sīhaḥ miga rājā kaḥ na me ñāti na sāmikaḥ kim aham tassa nipaccakāram karomi iti
translated: I am the lion, king of beasts; he is not my kinsman or my master; why should I do him honour?

original: adhippāyo. Siṅgālakaṃyevāti siṅgālaravameva. Bheraṇḍakaṃyevāti appiyaamanāpasaddameva.🔽Ke ca chave siṅgāleti ko ca lāmako siṅgālo. Ke pana sīhanādeti ko pana sīhanādo siṅgālassa
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ siṅgālakaṃyā iva ati siṅgāla ravam eva bheraṇḍakaṃyā iva ati appiya amanāpa saddam eva  ke ca chave siṅgāla iti ko ca lāmakaḥ siṅgālaḥ ke pana sīhanāde iti kaḥ pana sīhanādaḥ siṅgālassa
translated: This is the purport. The mere sound of a jackal: the mere sound of a jackal’s howl. The mere sound of a donkey: the mere sound of an unpleasant, disagreeable sound.🔽Who are these jackals? Who are these lions? What connection is there between the jackal’s howl and the lion’s roar?

original: ca sīhanādassa ca ko sambandhoti adhippāyo. Sugatāpadānesūti sugatalakkhaṇesu. Sugatassa
analyzed: ca sīhanādassa ca kaḥ sambandhaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ sugata apadānesu iti sugata lakkhaṇesu sugatassa
translated: This is the purport. In the marks of the Well-Farer: in the characteristics of the Well-farer.

original: sāsanasambhūtāsu tīsu sikkhāsu. Kathaṃ panesa tattha jīvati? Etassa hi cattāro paccaye
analyzed: sāsana sambhūtāsu tīsu sikkhāsu katham pana esa tattha jīvati etassa hi cattāro paccaye
translated: in the three trainings that have arisen in the Dispensation. But how does he live on that?

original: dadamānā sīlādiguṇasampannānaṃ sambuddhānaṃ demāti denti, tena esa abuddho samāno
analyzed: dadamānā sīla ādi guṇa sampannānam sambuddhānam dema iti denti tena esa abuddhaḥ samānaḥ
translated: For when they give him the four requisites, they give them to the Enlightened Ones who are endowed with virtue and other qualities. Thus, though he is not a Buddha,🔽he lives on the gifts of the faithful by using the requisites that are restricted to Buddhas.

original: buddhānaṃ niyāmitapaccaye paribhuñjanto sugatāpadānesu jīvati nāma. Sugatātirittānīti
analyzed: buddhānam niyāmita paccaye paribhuñjantaḥ sugata apadānesu jīvati nāma sugata atirittāni iti
translated: The words sugatātirittāni mean

original: tesaṃ kira bhojanāni dadamānā buddhānañca buddhasāvakānañca datvā pacchā avasesaṃ🔽sāyanhasamaye denti. Evamesa sugatātirittāni bhuñjati nāma. Tathāgateti tathāgataṃ
analyzed: tesam kira bhojanāni dadamānāḥ buddhānam ca buddha sāvakānam da tvā pacchā avasesam  sāyanha samaye denti sugata atirittāni bhuñjati nāma tathāgata iti tathāgatam
translated: that when they give him food, they give it to the Buddhas and the Buddhas’ disciples and then give him the remainder.🔽Thus he lives on the leftovers of the Buddhas.🔽The words tathāgateti tathāgataṃ mean🔽that he should be brought to, should be brought face to face with, the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

original: arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ āsādetabbaṃ ghaṭṭayitabbaṃ. Atha vā “tathāgate”tiādīni
analyzed: arahantam sammāsambuddham āsādetabbam ghaṭṭayitabbam atha vā tathāgata iti ādīni
translated: Or alternatively, the words tathāgate, etc.,🔽are plural in form but are to be taken as singular.

original: upayogabahuvacanāneva. Āsādetabbanti idampi bahuvacanameva ekavacanaṃ viya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: upayoga bahuvacanān eva āsādetabbanti idam pi bahuvacanam eva ekavacanam viya vuttam
translated: The word āsādetabbaṃ is singular in form but is to be taken as plural.

original: Āsādanāti ahaṃ buddhena saddhiṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ karissāmīti ghaṭṭanā.
analyzed: āsādanā ati aham buddhena saddhim pāṭihāriyam karissāmi iti ghaṭṭanā
translated: The word āsādanā means bringing face to face with, making face to face with, thinking: “I will perform a miracle with the Buddha.”

original: 29. Samekkhiyānāti samekkhitvā, maññitvāti attho. Amaññīti puna amaññittha kotthūti siṅgālo.
analyzed: samekkhiyānā ati samekkhitvā maññitvā ati attho amaññi iti puna amaññittha kotthu iti siṅgālo
translated: ‘Samekkhiyan’: having seen, having imagined, is the meaning. ‘Amaññī’: he imagined again. ‘Kotthū’: a jackal.

original: 30. Attānaṃ vighāse samekkhiyāti soṇḍiyaṃ ucchiṭṭhodake thūlaṃ attabhāvaṃ disvā.
analyzed: attānam vighāse samekkhiyāti soṇḍiyam ucchiṭṭha udake thūlam atta bhāvam disvā
translated: ‘Attānaṃ vighāse samekkhiya’: having seen his own large body in the water-hole.🔽‘Yāva attānaṃ na passatī’: as long as he does not see himself as he really is,

original: Yāva attānaṃ na passatīti yāva ahaṃ sīhavighāsasaṃvaḍḍhitako jarasiṅgāloti evaṃ yathābhūtaṃ🔽attānaṃ na passati. Byagghoti maññatīti sīhohamasmīti maññati, sīhena vā samānabalo
analyzed: yāva attānam na passati iti yāva aham sīha vighāsa saṃvaḍḍhitakaḥ jarasiṅgālaḥ iti evam yathābhūtam  attānam na passati byagghaḥ ti maññati iti sīhā uham asmi iti maññati sīhena vā samāna balaḥ
translated: as an old jackal grown fat on the leavings of the lion’s kill.

original: byagghoyeva ahanti maññati.
analyzed: byagghoyā iva ahanti maññati
translated: ‘Byaggho’ti maññati: he thinks ‘I am a lion’, or he thinks ‘I am a tiger who is equal in strength to a lion’.

original: 31. Bhutvāna bheketi āvāṭamaṇḍūke khāditvā. Khalamūsikāyoti khalesu mūsikāyo ca khāditvā.
analyzed: bhutvāna bheka iti āvāṭa maṇḍūke khāditvā khala mūsikāyāḥ iti khalesu ca khāditvā
translated: ‘Bhutvāna bheketi’: having eaten the frogs in the water-hole. ‘Khalamūsikāyo’: having eaten the rats in the stubble.

original: Kaṭasīsu khittāni ca koṇapānīti susānesu chaḍḍitakuṇapāni ca khāditvā. Mahāvaneti
analyzed: kaṭasīsu khittāni ca koṇapāni iti susānesu chaḍḍita kuṇapāni ca khāditvā mahā vanā iti
translated: ‘Kaṭasīsu khittāni ca koṇapānī’: having eaten the corpses thrown out in the charnel ground. ‘Mahāvane’:

original: mahante vanasmiṃ. Suññavaneti tucchavane. Vivaḍḍhoti vaḍḍhito. Tatheva so siṅgālakaṃ
analyzed: mahante vanasmim tuccha vane vivaḍḍho ti vaḍḍhito tathā iva saḥ siṅgālakam
translated: in a great forest. ‘Suññavane’: in an empty forest. ‘Vivaḍḍho’: grown. Then the jackal

original: anadīti evaṃ saṃvaḍḍhopi migarājāhamasmīti maññitvāpi yathā pubbe dubbalasiṅgālakāle,🔽tatheva so siṅgālaravaṃyeva aravīti. Imāyapi gāthāya bhekādīni bhutvā vaḍḍhitasiṅgālo
analyzed: anadī iti evam saṃvaḍḍhaḥ api miga rājā aham asmi iti maññitvā api yathā pubbe dubbala siṅgāla kāle  tathā iva saḥ siṅgāla ravaṃyā iva aravīti gāthāya bheka ādīni bhutvā vaḍḍhita siṅgālaḥ
translated: Though he had grown so big, the king of beasts still thought, “I am the same as I was when I was a weak jackal.”🔽And just as he had done in the past, he still only howled like a jackal.

original: viya lābhasakkāragiddho tvanti pāthikaputtameva ghaṭṭesi.
analyzed: viya lābha sakkāra giddhaḥ pāthika puttam eva ghaṭṭesi
translated: In this stanza too, the Buddha rebukes Pāṭika by comparing him to a jackal that has grown fat by eating frogs and other creatures.

original: Nāgehīti hatthīhi. Mahābandhanāti mahatā kilesabandhanā mocetvā. Mahāviduggāti mahāviduggaṃ nāma cattāro oghā. Tato uddharitvā nibbānathale patiṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: nāgehi iti hatthīhi mahā bandhanā ati mahatā kilesa bandhanā mocetvā mahāviduggā ati mahāviduggam nāma cattāraḥ oghā tatas uddharitvā nibbāna thale patiṭṭhapetvā
translated: “With elephants” means with the elephants. “Great bonds” means the great bonds of defilements. “Great danger” means the four floods. Having delivered them from that, he established them in the state of Nibbāna.

original: Aggaññapaññattikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: aggañña paññatti kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “Discourse on the Description of the Beginning.”

original: 36. Iti “bhagavā ettakena kathāmaggena pāṭihāriyaṃ na karotī”ti padassa anusandhiṃ
analyzed: iti bhagavā ettakena kathāmaggena pāṭihāriyam na karoti iti padassa anusandhim
translated: Having thus shown the connection of the phrase “the Blessed One does not perform a miracle with such a discourse,”

original: dassetvā idāni “na aggaññaṃ paññāpetī”ti imassa anusandhiṃ dassento aggaññañcāhanti
analyzed: dassetvā idāni na aggaññam paññāpeti iti imassa anusandhim dassentaḥ aggaññam ca āhanti
translated: he now begins the explanation of the phrase “does not describe a beginning,” saying “He does not describe a beginning.”

original: desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha aggaññañcāhanti ahaṃ, bhaggava, aggaññañca pajānāmi lokuppatticariyavaṃsañca.
analyzed: desanam ārabhi tattha aham bhaggava aggaññañca pajānāmi loka uppatti cariya vaṃsam ca
translated: There, “He does not describe a beginning” means “I, Bhaggava, understand the beginning, the origination of the world.”

original: Tañca pajānāmīti na kevalaṃ aggaññameva, tañca aggaññaṃ pajānāmi. Tato ca uttaritaraṃ
analyzed: tat ca pajānāmi iti na kevalam aggaññam eva tat ca aggaññam pajānāmi tatas ca uttaritaram
translated: And I know that: not only the beginning, but also that beginning I know. And what is beyond that:

original: sīlasamādhito paṭṭhāya yāva sabbaññutaññāṇā pajānāmi. Tañca pajānaṃ na parāmasāmīti
analyzed: sīla samādhito paṭṭhāya yāva sabbaññu taññāṇā pajānāmi tat ca pajānam na parāmasāmi iti
translated: from virtue and concentration up to the knowledge of omniscience I know. And knowing that, I do not cling:

original: tañca pajānantopi ahaṃ idaṃ nāma pajānāmīti taṇhādiṭṭhimānavasena na parāmasāmi.
analyzed: tat ca pajānantaḥ api aham idam nāma pajānāmi iti taṇhā diṭṭhi māna vasena na parāmasāmi
translated: though I know that, I do not cling to it by craving, views, or conceit, thinking, “I know this.”

original: Natthi tathāgatassa parāmāsoti dīpeti. Paccattaññeva nibbuti viditāti attanāyeva
analyzed: natthi tathāgatassa parāmāsaḥ ti dīpeti paccattaññā iva nibbuti viditā ati attanāya iva
translated: There is no clinging for the Tathāgata: this shows that there is no clinging for the Tathāgata. Nibbana is known by me alone:🔽the extinction of defilements in myself

original: attani kilesanibbānaṃ viditaṃ. Yadabhijānaṃ tathāgatoti yaṃ kilesanibbānaṃ jānanto
analyzed: attani kilesa nibbānam viditam tathāgataḥ iti yam kilesa nibbānam jānantaḥ
translated: is known by me alone. The Tathāgata is known as one who knows:🔽the Tathāgata is known as one who knows the extinction of defilements. He does not fall into misfortune:

original: tathāgato. No anayaṃ āpajjatīti aviditanibbānā titthiyā viya anayaṃ dukkhaṃ byasanaṃ nāpajjati.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ no anayam āpajjati iti avidita nibbānā titthiyā viya anayam dukkham byasanam na āpajjati
translated: unlike the sectarians who do not know the extinction of defilements, he does not fall into misfortune, into suffering and disaster.

original: 37. Idāni yaṃ taṃ titthiyā aggaññaṃ paññapenti, taṃ dassento santi bhaggavātiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yam tam titthiyāḥ aggaññam paññapenti tam dassento santi bhaggavāti ādim āha
translated: Now, showing the beginning that the sectarians describe, he said: “There are, Bhaggava, some ascetics and Brahmins, teachers of teachers, who declare and believe that the world is eternal, and they give as a reason for this belief that ‘the world is a unity, and the Tathāgata is a unity, and when the Tathāgata is fully extinguished, the world will be extinguished.’“

original: Tattha issarakuttaṃ brahmakuttanti issarakataṃ brahmakataṃ, issaranimmitaṃ brahmanimmitanti
analyzed: tattha issarakuttam brahmakuttanti issarakatam brahmakatam issaranimmitam brahmanimmitanti
translated: Herein, the world of the Creator, the world of Brahma: the creation of the Creator, the creation of Brahma;

original: attho. Brahmā eva hi ettha ādhipaccabhāvena issaroti veditabbo. Ācariyakanti ācariyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ brahmā eva hi ettha ādhipacca bhāvena issaraḥ ti veditabbaḥ ācariyakanti ācariya bhāvam
translated: for the meaning is that Brahmā is the lord in the sense of being the overlord.🔽The teacher’s view: the state of being a teacher,

original: ācariyavādaṃ. Tattha ācariyavādo aggaññaṃ. Aggaññaṃ pana ettha desitanti katvā so🔽aggaññaṃ tveva vutto. Kathaṃ vihitakanti kena vihitaṃ kinti vihitaṃ. Sesaṃ brahmajāle
analyzed: ācariya vādam tattha ācariya vādaḥ aggaññam aggaññam pana ettha desitanti katvā so  aggaññam tu eva vuttaḥ katham vihitakanti kena vihitam kinti vihitam sesam brahmajāle
translated: the teacher’s doctrine. Herein, the teacher’s doctrine is the beginning. But since the beginning is taught here,

original: vitthāritanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vitthāri tanayena iva veditabbam
translated: it is called the beginning. How made? By whom made? What made? The rest can be understood by the method of the exposition in the Brahmajāla .

original: 41. Khiḍḍāpadosikanti khiḍḍāpadosikamūlaṃ.🔽47. Asatāti avijjamānena, asaṃvijjamānaṭṭhenāti attho. Tucchāti tucchena antosāravirahitena.
analyzed: khiḍḍāpadosikanti khiḍḍāpadosika mūlam  asatā ati avijjamānena asaṃvijjamāna ṭhena ati attho tuccha ati tucchena antosāra virahitena
translated: . Play-pen: the root of the play-pen.🔽. Not being: not existing, not found, is the meaning. Empty: empty, lacking inner essence.

original: Musāti musāvādena. Abhūtenāti bhūtatthavirahitena. Abbhācikkhantīti abhiācikkhanti.
analyzed: musā ati musāvādena abhūtena ati bhūtattha virahitena abbhācikkhanti iti abhiācikkhanti
translated: Lie: by a lie. Unreal: devoid of what is real. Misrepresenting: misrepresent.

original: Viparītoti viparītasañño viparītacitto. Bhikkhavo cāti na kevalaṃ samaṇo gotamoyeva,
analyzed: viparītaḥ ti viparīta saññaḥ viparīta cittaḥ bhikkhavaḥ ca ati na kevalam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ yā iva
translated: Perverted: with perverted perception and perverted cognizance. And the bhikkhus: not only the ascetic Gotama,

original: ye ca assa anusiṭṭhiṃ karonti, te bhikkhū ca viparītā. Atha yaṃ sandhāya viparītoti
analyzed: ye ca assa anusiṭṭhim karonti te bhikkhū ca viparītāḥ atha yam sandhāya
translated: but also the bhikkhus who carry out his instructions are perverted. Then, referring to whom,🔽.

original: vadanti, taṃ dassetuṃ samaṇo gotamotiādi vuttaṃ. Subhaṃ vimokkhanti vaṇṇakasiṇaṃ.
analyzed: vadanti tam dassetum samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ ti ādi vuttam subham vaṇṇa kasiṇam
translated: In order to show that, the words “The recluse Gotama” are said. “The pleasant deliverance”: the kasiṇa of color.

original: Asubhantvevāti subhañca asubhañca sabbaṃ asubhanti evaṃ pajānāti. Subhantveva tasmiṃ
analyzed: asubhantu eva ati subham ca asubham ca sabbam asubhanti evam pajānāti subhantu eva tasmin
translated: “But only the unpleasant”: he understands all that is pleasant and unpleasant as only unpleasant.

original: samayeti subhanti eva ca tasmiṃ samaye pajānāti, na asubhaṃ. Bhikkhavo cāti ye te
analyzed: samaya iti subhanti eva ca tasmin samaye pajānāti na asubham bhikkhavaḥ ca ati ye te
translated: “But only the pleasant”: and at that time he understands only the pleasant, not the unpleasant.

original: evaṃ vadanti, tesaṃ bhikkhavo ca antevāsikasamaṇā viparītā. Pahotīti samattho paṭibalo.
analyzed: evam vadanti tesam bhikkhavaḥ ca antevāsika samaṇā viparītā pahoti iti samattho paṭibalo
translated: “The bhikkhus”: those who say thus, their bhikkhus and pupil-recluses are mistaken.🔽“Is able”: is capable.

original: 48. Dukkaraṃ khoti ayaṃ paribbājako yadidaṃ “evaṃpasanno ahaṃ, bhante”tiādimāha,
analyzed: dukkaram kho ti ayam paribbājakaḥ yat idam evaṃpasannaḥ aham bhante tiādim āha
translated: “Difficult”: this wanderer says this, “Thus, venerable sir, I have confidence in the recluse Gotama,”

original: taṃ sāṭheyyena kohaññena āha. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – “samaṇo gotamo mayhaṃ ettakaṃ🔽dhammakathaṃ kathesi, tamahaṃ sutvāpi pabbajituṃ na sakkomi, mayā etassa sāsanaṃ
analyzed: tam sāṭheyyena kohaññena āha evam kirassa ahosi samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ mayham ettakam  dhamma katham kathesi tam aham sutvā api pabbajitum na sakkomi mayā etassa sāsanam
translated: through deceit and hypocrisy. He thought thus: “The recluse Gotama has given me this much talk on Dhamma,

original: paṭipannasadisena bhavituṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. Tato so sāṭheyyena kohaññena evamāha. Tenassa
analyzed: paṭipanna sadisena bhavitum vaṭṭati iti tatas saḥ sāṭheyyena kohaññena evam āha tena assa
translated: but even after hearing it I am unable to go forth. I must act as if I were practicing his dispensation.” Then he said this through deceit and hypocrisy.

original: bhagavā mammaṃ ghaṭṭento viya “dukkaraṃ kho etaṃ, bhaggava tayā aññadiṭṭhikenā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhagavā mammam ghaṭṭentaḥ viya dukkaram kho etam bhaggava tayā aññadiṭṭhikena ati ādim āha
translated: The Blessed One said, “It is hard for you, Bhaggava, who have a different view, a different approval, and a different advice, to live with me” .

original: Taṃ poṭṭhapādasutte vuttatthameva. Sādhukamanurakkhāti suṭṭhu anurakkha.
analyzed: tam poṭṭhapāda sutte vutta ttham eva sādhukam anurakkhāti suṭṭhu anurakkha
translated: The meaning of this is given in the Poṭṭhapāda Sutta . “Guard well” means guard thoroughly.

original: Iti bhagavā pasādamattānurakkhaṇe paribbājakaṃ niyojesi. Sopi evaṃ mahantaṃ suttantaṃ
analyzed: iti bhagavā pasāda matta anurakkhaṇe paribbājakam niyojesi saḥ api evam mahantam suttantam
translated: So the Blessed One appointed the wanderer to the task of guarding the mere faith. And although he heard this great sutta,

original: sutvāpi nāsakkhi kilesakkhayaṃ kātuṃ. Desanā panassa āyatiṃ vāsanāya paccayo ahosi.
analyzed: sutvā api nā asakkhi kilesa kkhayam kātum desanā panassa āyatim vāsanāya paccayaḥ ahosi
translated: he was still unable to destroy the defilements. But it became a condition for his future purification.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in all its aspects.

original: Sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the commentary to the Dīgha Nikāya called the Sumangalavilāsinī,

original: Pāthikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pāthika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: the commentary on the Pāṭika Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Udumbarikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: udumbarika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Udumbarika Sutta

original: Nigrodhaparibbājakavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: nigrodha paribbājaka vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of the wanderer Nigrodha

original: 49. Evaṃ me sutanti udumbarikasuttaṃ. Tatrāyamapubbapadavaṇṇanā – paribbājakoti channaparibbājako.
analyzed: evam me sutam ti udumbarika suttam tatra ayam apubba pada vaṇṇanā paribbājako ti channa paribbājako
translated: Thus I heard. The Udumbarika Sutta . Here is the commentary on the first part of the sutta: The wanderer was the wanderer Channa.

original: Udumbarikāya paribbājakārāmeti udumbarikāya deviyā santake paribbājakārāme. Sandhānoti
analyzed: udumbarikāya paribbājaka ārāme iti udumbarikāya deviyā santake paribbājaka ārāme sandhānā uti
translated: In the park of the wanderers belonging to the female lay follower Udumbarikā means in the park of the wanderers belonging to the female lay follower Udumbarikā. Sandhāna means

original: tassa nāmaṃ. Ayaṃ pana mahānubhāvo parivāretvā vicarantānaṃ pañcannaṃ upāsakasatānaṃ
analyzed: tassa nāmam ayam pana mahā anubhāvaḥ parivāretvā vicarantānam pañcannam upāsaka satānam
translated: But this man of great power, the foremost of the five hundred lay followers who went about in his retinue,
