translated: For the great ocean can receive the waters of the rivers, even a thousand or a hundred thousand rivers,

original: samaṇasatassa samaṇasahassassa samaṇasatasahassassa vā pītisomanassaṃ pavedentassa🔽sabbesaṃ manaṃ gaṇhanto paṭiggahetuṃ sakkoti. Sesā samaṇabrāhmaṇādayo candabhāgaṃ🔽kusumbhakandarā viya mama somanassaṃ sampaṭicchituṃ na sakkonti. Handāhaṃ mama pītisomanassaṃ🔽satthunova ārocemīti pallaṅkaṃ vinibbhujitvā cammakkhaṇḍaṃ papphoṭetvā ādāya sāyanhasamaye
analyzed: samaṇa satassa samaṇa sahassassa samaṇa sata sahassassa vā pīti somanassam pavedentassa  sabbesam manam gaṇhantaḥ paṭiggahetum sakkoti sesā samaṇa brāhmaṇa ādayo canda bhāgam  kusumbha kandarāḥ viya mama somanassam sampaṭicchitum na sakkonti handa aham mama pīti somanassam  satthunā uva ārocemi iti pallaṅkam vinibbhujitvā camma kkhaṇḍam papphoṭetvā ādāya sāyanha samaye
translated: and it is not filled thereby; nor does it overflow. So too the Teacher can receive the joy and gladness of a thousand or a hundred thousand ascetics like me,🔽and it is not filled thereby; nor does it overflow. Other ascetics and brahmans, like the rivers Kusumbha and Kandaraka,🔽cannot receive my joy and gladness. Let me therefore announce my joy and gladness to the Teacher himself.” So he folded his sitting cloth in four, spread it out, and taking his hide-cloak, in the evening

original: pupphānaṃ vaṇṭato chijjitvā paggharaṇakāle satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā attano somanassaṃ
analyzed: pupphānam vaṇṭataḥ chijjitvā paggharaṇa kāle satthāram upasaṅkamitvā attano somanassam
translated: he went to the Teacher, and announcing his joy and gladness, said: “Thus, revered sir, am I filled with confidence.”

original: pavedento evaṃpasanno ahaṃ, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha evaṃpasannoti evaṃ uppannasaddho,
analyzed: pavedentaḥ evaṃpasannaḥ aham bhante tiādim āha tattha evaṃpasannaḥ ti evam uppanna saddhaḥ
translated: Herein, thus, revered sir, am I filled with confidence means thus have I arisen in faith,

original: evaṃ saddahāmīti attho. Bhiyyobhiññataroti bhiyyataro abhiññāto, bhiyyatarābhiñño
analyzed: evam saddahāmi iti atthaḥ bhiyyobhiññataro ti bhiyyataraḥ abhiññātaḥ bhiyyatara abhiñño
translated: Bhiyyobhiññataro: he is more distinguished by his direct-knowledge, or he has more distinguished direct-knowledge. The meaning is: he has higher knowledge.

original: vā, uttaritarañāṇoti attho. Sambodhiyanti sabbaññutaññāṇe arahattamaggañāṇe vā, arahattamaggeneva
analyzed: vā uttaritara ñāṇo ti attho sambodhiyanti sabbaññuta ññāṇe arahatta magga ñāṇe vā arahatta maggena iva
translated: Sambodhiya: in the knowledge of omniscience or in the knowledge of the path of arahatship. For the qualities of a Buddha are included only by the path of arahatship.

original: hi buddhaguṇā nippadesā gahitā honti. Dve hi aggasāvakā arahattamaggeneva sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ
analyzed: hi buddha guṇāḥ nippadesāḥ gahitāḥ honti dve hi aggasāvakāḥ arahatta maggena iva sāvaka pāramīñāṇam
translated: For the two chief disciples obtain the knowledge of the perfection of disciples only by the path of arahatship;

original: paṭilabhanti. Paccekabuddhā paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ. Buddhā sabbaññutaññāṇañceva sakale
analyzed: paṭilabhanti paccekabuddhā pacceka bodhi ñāṇam buddhā sabbaññuta ññāṇam ca iva sakale
translated: the paccekabuddhas obtain the knowledge of paccekabodhi; and the Buddhas obtain the knowledge of omniscience and all the qualities of a Buddha.

original: ca buddhaguṇe. Sabbañhi nesaṃ arahattamaggeneva ijjhati. Tasmā arahattamaggañāṇaṃ🔽sambodhi nāma hoti. Tena uttaritaro bhagavatā natthi. Tenāha “bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro
analyzed: ca buddha guṇe sabbam hi na īsam arahatta maggena iva ijjhati tasmai arahatta magga ñāṇam  sambodhi nāma hoti tena uttaritaraḥ bhagavatā na atthi tena āha bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro
translated: For all of them this is successful only by the path of arahatship. Therefore the knowledge of the path of arahatship

original: yadidaṃ sambodhiya”nti.
analyzed: yat idam sambodhiyanti
translated: is called sambodhi. There is no one higher than the Exalted One. Therefore it is said: “There is none more distinguished by direct-knowledge than the Exalted One, that is to say, in regard to sambodhi.”

original: 142. Uḷārāti seṭṭhā. Ayañhi uḷārasaddo “uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādantī”tiādīsu madhure
analyzed: uḷārā ati seṭṭhā ayam hi uḷāra saddaḥ uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādanti itiādīsu madhure
translated: Uḷārā: excellent. For this word uḷāra is used in the sense of “sweet” in such passages as “eating excellent food” .

original: āgacchati. “Uḷārāya khalu bhavaṃ, vacchāyano, samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pasaṃsāya pasaṃsatī”tiādīsu
analyzed: āgacchati uḷārāya khalu bhavam vacchāyanaḥ samaṇam gotamam pasaṃsāya pasaṃsati itiādīsu
translated: “He is coming, sir, who praises the recluse Gotama with high praise indeed” ,🔽in the sense of “best”; “The light was immeasurable, high, and sublime” ,

original: seṭṭhe. “Appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso”tiādīsu vipule. Svāyamidha seṭṭhe āgato. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭhe appamāṇaḥ uḷāraḥ obhāsaḥ ti ādīsu vipule seṭṭhe āgato tena vuttam
translated: in the sense of “vast.” Here it is in the sense of “best” that it is used. Hence it is said:🔽“High” means “best.”

original: – “uḷārāti seṭṭhā”ti. Āsabhīti usabhassa vācāsadisī acalā asampavedhī. Ekaṃso gahitoti🔽anussavena vā ācariyaparamparāya vā itikirāya vā piṭakasampadānena vā ākāraparivitakkena
analyzed: uḷārā ati seṭṭhā ati āsabhī iti usabhassa vācā asadisī acalā asampavedhī ekaṃsaḥ gahito ti  anussavena vā ācariya paramparāya vā itikirāya vā piṭaka sampadānena vā ākāra parivitakkena
translated: “Lion’s roar”: a voice like that of a bull, unshakable, unperturbed. “Taken up in one way”:

original: vā diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā vā takkahetu vā nayahetu vā akathetvā paccakkhato ñāṇena
analyzed: vā diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhantiyā vā takka hetu vā naya hetu vā a kathetvā paccakkhataḥ ñāṇena
translated: without relying on mere oral tradition, or on the authority of a teacher or on inference from general principles, or on mere logic or inference, or on the acceptance of a view as true because it happens to be liked by oneself, or on the ground that “the reasoner himself is a brahmin,”🔽but rather as if it had been penetrated by knowledge through direct experience,

original: paṭivijjhitvā viya ekaṃso gahito, sanniṭṭhānakathāva kathitāti attho.
analyzed: paṭivijjhitvā viya ekaṃsaḥ gahito sanniṭṭhāna kathā ava kathitā ti attho
translated: and then spoken of with finality.

original: Sīhanādoti seṭṭhanādo, neva dandhāyantena na gaggarāyantena sīhena viya uttamanādo
analyzed: sīha nādaḥ ti seṭṭha nādaḥ na iva dandhāyantena na gaggarāyantena sīhena viya uttama nādaḥ
translated: “Lion’s roar”: the best roar, a roar like that of a lion who does not roar either in a cowardly way or in a boastful way,🔽but rather with a noble roar.

original: naditoti attho. Kiṃ te sāriputtāti imaṃ desanaṃ kasmā ārabhīti? Anuyogadāpanatthaṃ.
analyzed: naditoti attho kim te sāriputta ati imam desanam kasmai ārabhi iti anuyoga dāpana attham
translated: “Why, Sāriputta?”: for what reason did he begin this teaching? In order to question and instruct.

original: Ekacco hi sīhanādaṃ naditvā attano sīhanāde anuyogaṃ dātuṃ na sakkoti, nighaṃsanaṃ🔽nakkhamati, lepe patitamakkaṭo viya hoti. Yathā dhamamānaṃ aparisuddhalohaṃ jhāyitvā
analyzed: ekaccaḥ hi sīha nādam naditvā attano sīha nāde anuyogam dātum na sakkoti nighaṃsanam  na khamati lepe patita makkaṭaḥ viya hoti yathā dhamamānam a parisuddha loham jhāyitvā
translated: For one man may roar a lion’s roar and yet be unable to bear the challenge,🔽he is like a monkey fallen into a glue-pit. Just as a piece of iron, when heated in the fire,

original: jhāmaaṅgāro hoti, evaṃ jhāmaṅgāro viya hoti. Eko sīhanāde anuyogaṃ dāpiyamāno dātuṃ
analyzed: jhāma aṅgāraḥ hoti evam jhāma aṅgāraḥ viya hoti ekaḥ sīha nāde anuyogam dāpiyamānaḥ dātum
translated: becomes all the more brittle, so he becomes like a piece of red-hot iron. Another man, when challenged, is able to bear the challenge,

original: sakkoti, nighaṃsanaṃ khamati, dhamamānaṃ niddosajātarūpaṃ viya adhikataraṃ sobhati,🔽tādiso thero. Tena naṃ bhagavā “anuyogakkhamo aya”nti ñatvā sīhanāde anuyogadāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: sakkoti nighaṃsanam khamati dhamamānam niddosa jātarūpam viya adhikataram sobhati  tādisaḥ theraḥ tena nam bhagavā anuyoga kkhamaḥ ayanti ñatvā sīhanāde anuyoga dāpana attham
translated: he shines all the more, like a piece of gold when heated in the fire.

original: imampi desanaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: imam pi desanam
translated: The Elder was such a man. The Exalted One, knowing that he was able to bear the challenge, began this discourse in order to challenge him to a lion’s roar.

original: Tattha sabbe teti sabbe te tayā. Evaṃsīlātiādīsu lokiyalokuttaravasena sīlādīni pucchati. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā mahāpadāne kathitāva.
analyzed: tattha sabbe te iti sabbe te tayā evaṃsīlā ati ādīsu lokiya lokuttara vasena sīla ādīni pucchati tesam vitthāra kathā mahāpadāne kathitā ava
translated: Herein, all those who will be your equals means all those who will be your equals in virtue, etc. He asks about virtue, etc., in terms of the mundane and supramundane. The detailed explanation of these has been given in the Mahāpadāna .

original: Kiṃ pana te, sāriputta, ye te bhavissantīti atītā ca tāva niruddhā, apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: kim pana te sāriputta ye te bhavissanti iti atītā ca tāva niruddhā apaṇṇattika bhāvam
translated: But, Sāriputta, what will they be? Even those of the past have already ceased and passed away. The future has not yet come into existence.

original: gatā dīpasikhā viya nibbutā, evaṃ niruddhe apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ gate tvaṃ kathaṃ jānissasi,
analyzed: gatāḥ dīpasikhāḥ viya nibbutāḥ evam niruddhe apaṇṇattika bhāvam gate tvam katham jānissasi
translated: “When they have gone out like the flame of a lamp, when they have been extinguished and have disappeared, how will you know

original: anāgatabuddhānaṃ pana guṇā kinti tayā attano cittena paricchinditvā viditāti pucchanto🔽evamāha. Kiṃ pana te, sāriputta, ahaṃ etarahīti anāgatāpi buddhā ajātā anibbattā
analyzed: anāgata buddhānam pana guṇā kinti tayā cittena paricchinditvā viditā ati pucchanto  evam āha kim pana te sāriputta aham etarahi iti anāgatāḥ api buddhāḥ a jātāḥ a nibbattā
translated: “But how can you know the qualities of future Buddhas by your own mind?”🔽“But how can you know future Buddhas who are unborn, unarisen, and unappeared?”

original: anuppannā, tepi kathaṃ tvaṃ jānissasi? Tesañhi jānanaṃ apade ākāse padadassanaṃ viya🔽hoti. Idāni mayā saddhiṃ ekavihāre vasasi, ekato bhikkhāya carasi, dhammadesanākāle
analyzed: an uppannā te api katham tvam jānissasi tesam hi jānanam a pade ākāse pada dassanam viya  hoti idāni mayā saddhim eka vihāre vasasi ekatas bhikkhāya carasi dhamma desanā kāle
translated: For it is as if one were to see footprints in the sky.

original: dakkhiṇapasse nisīdasi, kiṃ pana mayhaṃ guṇā attano cetasā paricchinditvā viditā🔽tayāti anuyuñjanto evamāha.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa passe nisīdasi kim pana mayham guṇāḥ cetasā paricchinditvā viditā  tayā ati evam āha
translated: “You live in the same monastery as I do, you go on alms round in the same place as I do, you sit on the right hand side of me when I teach the Dhamma. How is it that you know my qualities by your own mind?”🔽The Elder, however, denied each question as it was asked.

original: Thero pana pucchite pucchite “no hetaṃ, bhante”ti paṭikkhipati. Therassa ca viditampi
analyzed: theraḥ pana pucchite pucchite no ha etam bhante ti paṭikkhipati therassa ca viditam pi
translated: The Elder’s knowledge of the future was not like the knowledge of the Buddha, who knows the future by his own mind.

original: atthi aviditampi atthi, kiṃ so attano viditaṭṭhāne paṭikkhepaṃ karoti, aviditaṭṭhāneti?
analyzed: atthi aviditam pi atthi kim so attanaḥ vidita ṭhāne paṭikkhepam karoti avidita ṭṭhāne iti
translated: “There is what is not known to him. Why does he deny only what he knows and not what he does not know?

original: Viditaṭṭhāne na karoti, aviditaṭṭhāneyeva karotīti. Thero kira anuyoge āraddheyeva
analyzed: vidita ṭṭhāne na karoti karoti iti thero kira anuyoge
translated: “He denies only what he knows, not what he does not know.” The Elder, it seems, knew this as soon as the questioning began.

original: aññāsi. Na ayaṃ anuyogo sāvakapāramīñāṇe, sabbaññutaññāṇe ayaṃ anuyogoti attano sāvakapāramīñāṇe
analyzed: aññāsi na ayam anuyogo sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe sabbaññuta ññāṇe ayam anuyogo ti attano sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe
translated: “This questioning is not about knowledge of the perfection of the disciple; it is about knowledge of omniscience. So he denies only what he does not know,

original: paṭikkhepaṃ akatvā aviditaṭṭhāne sabbaññutaññāṇe paṭikkhepaṃ karoti. Tena idampi🔽dīpeti “bhagavā mayhaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ buddhānaṃ sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttikāraṇajānanasamatthaṃ
analyzed: paṭikkhepam a katvā avidita ṭṭhāne sabbaññuta ññāṇe paṭikkhepam karoti tena idam api  dīpeti bhagavā mayham atīta anāgata paccuppannānam buddhānam sīla samādhi paññā vimutti kāraṇa jānana samattham
translated: not denying what he does know. Thus he shows that

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ natthī”ti.
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇam na atthi iti
translated: the Exalted One does not have the knowledge of omniscience, which is able to know the virtue, concentration, understanding, and deliverance of the Buddhas of the past, future, and present.

original: Etthāti etesu atītādibhedesu buddhesu. Atha kiñcarahīti atha kasmā evaṃ ñāṇe asati tayā evaṃ kathitanti vadati.
analyzed: ettha iti etesu atīta ādi bhedesu buddhesu atha kiñcarahi iti atha kasmai evam ñāṇe asati tayā evam kathitam iti vadati
translated: “There” means “among the Buddhas of the past, future, and present.” “Then what is lacking in you?” means “Then why do you speak thus if you do not have that knowledge?”

original: 143. Dhammanvayoti dhammassa paccakkhato ñāṇassa anuyogaṃ anugantvā uppannaṃ anumānañāṇaṃ
analyzed: dhamma nvayaḥ ti dhammassa paccakkhataḥ ñāṇassa anuyogam anugantvā uppannam anumāna ñāṇam
translated: “The conformity knowledge of the Dhamma” is the inferential knowledge that arises in conformity with the knowledge of the Dhamma by direct experience.

original: nayaggāho vidito. Sāvakapāramīñāṇe ṭhatvāva imināva ākārena jānāmi bhagavāti vadati.🔽Therassa hi nayaggāho appamāṇo apariyanto. Yathā sabbaññutaññāṇassa pamāṇaṃ vā pariyanto
analyzed: sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe ākārena jānāmi bhagavā iti vadati  therassa hi naya ggāhaḥ appamāṇaḥ a pariyantaḥ yathā sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa pamāṇam vā pariyantaḥ
translated: He knows the Master’s method. He says: “I know the Blessed One to be such and such, to be the Supreme Teacher, by this and this method,” for the Elder’s knowledge of the Master’s method is immeasurable and boundless.

original: vā natthi, evaṃ dhammasenāpatino nayaggāhassa. Tena so “iminā evaṃvidho, iminā anuttaro🔽satthā”ti jānāti. Therassa hi nayaggāho sabbaññutaññāṇagatiko eva. Idāni taṃ nayaggāhaṃ🔽pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ upamāya dassento seyyathāpi, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha yasmā majjhimapadese
analyzed: vā na atthi evam dhamma senāpatinaḥ naya ggāhassa tena saḥ iminā evaṃvidhaḥ iminā anuttaraḥ  satthā iti jānāti therassa hi naya ggāhaḥ sabbaññuta ññāṇa gatikaḥ eva idāni tam naya ggāham  pākaṭam kātum upamāya dassento seyyathā api bhante ti ādim āha tattha yasmā majjhima padese
translated: Just as the knowledge of omniscience has no measure or limit, so the Elder’s knowledge of the Master’s method has no measure or limit. Therefore he knows: “By this method he is such and such, by this method he is the Supreme Teacher.”

original: nagarassa uddhāpapākārādīni thirāni vā hontu, dubbalāni vā, sabbaso vā pana mā hontu,🔽corāsaṅkā na hoti, tasmā taṃ aggahetvā paccantimanagaranti āha. Daḷhuddhāpanti thirapākārapādaṃ.
analyzed: nagarassa uddhā papākāra ādīni thirāni vā hontu dubbalāni vā sabbaso vā pana mā hontu 🔽cora āsaṅkā na hoti tasmai tam aggahetvā āha
translated: For the Elder’s knowledge of the Master’s method is itself the knowledge of omniscience. Now, in order to make that knowledge of the Master’s method clear, he gives a simile, “Just as, venerable sir,” etc. Herein, since in the Middle Country there is no fear of thieves whether the city gates are strong or weak or whether they are left unguarded,🔽he says “a city with strong gates” and “a city with weak gates.”

original: Daḷhapākāratoraṇanti thirapākārañceva thirapiṭṭhasaṅghāṭañca. Ekadvāranti kasmā āha?
analyzed: daḷha pākāra toraṇanti thira pākāram ca iva thira piṭṭha saṅghāṭam ca eka dvāranti kasmai āha
translated: Why does he say “one gate”?

original: Bahudvāre hi nagare bahūhi paṇḍitadovārikehi bhavitabbaṃ. Ekadvāre ekova vaṭṭati.
analyzed: bahu dvāre hi nagare bahūhi paṇḍita dovārikehi bhavitabbam eka dvāre ekaḥ iva vaṭṭati
translated: For if the city had many gates, there would have to be many gatekeepers. But with one gate, only one is needed.

original: Therassa ca paññāya sadiso añño natthi. Tasmā attano paṇḍitabhāvassa opammatthaṃ
analyzed: therassa ca paññāya sadisaḥ aññaḥ na atthi tasmai attano paṇḍita bhāvassa opammattham
translated: And there is no one else equal to the Elder in wisdom. Therefore, in order to show that he himself is wise,🔽he says “one gate” in order to illustrate his own wisdom.

original: ekaṃyeva dovārikaṃ dassetuṃ ekadvāra”nti āha. Paṇḍitoti paṇḍiccena samannāgato. Byattoti
analyzed: ekam yeva dovārikam dassetum eka dvāram ti āha paṇḍito ti paṇḍiccena samannāgataḥ byattaḥ ti
translated: “Wise” means endowed with wisdom. “Skilled” means🔽endowed with skill, having clear knowledge. “Intelligent” means

original: veyyattiyena samannāgato visadañāṇo. Medhāvīti ṭhānuppattikapaññāsaṅkhātāya medhāya
analyzed: veyyattiyena samannāgataḥ visada ñāṇaḥ medhāvī iti ṭhānuppattika paññā saṅkhātāya medhāya
translated: endowed with intelligence called “wisdom arisen from the conditions.”

original: samannāgato. Anupariyāyapathanti anupariyāyanāmakaṃ pākāramaggaṃ. Pākārasandhinti
analyzed: samannāgataḥ anupariyāya pathanti anupariyāya nāmakam pākāra maggam pākāra sandhinti
translated: “The path around the rampart” means the path around the rampart called “the path around.” “The joints of the rampart” means

original: dvinnaṃ iṭṭhakānaṃ apagataṭṭhānaṃ. Pākāravivaranti pākārassa chinnaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: dvinnam iṭṭhakānam apagata ṭṭhānam pākāra vivaranti pākārassa chinna ṭṭhānam
translated: the place where two bricks are joined. “A hole in the rampart” means a broken place in the rampart.

original: Cetaso upakkileseti pañca nīvaraṇāni cittaṃ upakkilesenti kiliṭṭhaṃ karonti upatāpenti
analyzed: cetasaḥ upakkileseti pañca nīvaraṇāni cittam upakkilesenti kiliṭṭham karonti upatāpenti
translated: “Defilements of the mind” means the five hindrances defile the mind, make it dirty, and torment it.

original: vibādhenti, tasmā “cetaso upakkilesā”ti vuccanti. Paññāya dubbalīkaraṇeti nīvaraṇā
analyzed: vibādhenti tasmā cetasaḥ upakkilesā ati vuccanti paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā iti nīvaraṇā
translated: They are called “mental defilements” because they obstruct the mind. They are called “hindrances” because they hinder understanding.

original: uppajjamānā anuppannāya paññāya uppajjituṃ na denti, uppannāya paññāya vaḍḍhituṃ
analyzed: uppajjamānāḥ anuppannāya paññāya uppajjitum na denti uppannāya paññāya vaḍḍhitum
translated: When they arise, they prevent the arising of understanding that has not yet arisen, and they prevent the increase of understanding that has already arisen.

original: na denti, tasmā “paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā”ti vuccanti. Suppatiṭṭhitacittāti catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu🔽suṭṭhu ṭhapitacittā hutvā. Satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtanti satta bojjhaṅge yathāsabhāvena
analyzed: na denti tasmā paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā ati vuccanti su patiṭṭhita cittā ati catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu  suṭṭhu ṭhapita cittā hutvā satta bojjhaṅge satta bojjhaṅge yathā sabhāvena
translated: They are called “weaknesses of understanding” for this reason. “With their minds well steadied”: having steadied their minds well in the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: bhāvetvā. Anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhinti arahattaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ vā paṭivijjhiṃsūti dasseti.
analyzed: bhāvetvā anuttaram sammāsambodhin ti arahattam sabbaññu ta ññāṇam vā paṭivijjhiṃsu iti dasseti
translated: “Having developed the seven factors of enlightenment as they really are”: having developed the seven factors of enlightenment in accordance with their true nature. “The supreme perfect enlightenment”: he shows that they penetrated to arahatship or to omniscient knowledge.

original: Apicettha satipaṭṭhānāti vipassanā. Sambojjhaṅgā maggo. Anuttarāsammāsambodhi arahattaṃ.
analyzed: apica ittha vipassanā sambojjhaṅgā maggaḥ anuttarā sammāsambodhi arahattam
translated: And here the foundations of mindfulness are insight, the factors of enlightenment are the path, and the supreme perfect enlightenment is arahatship.🔽Or the foundations of mindfulness and the path are mixed with the factors of enlightenment, and the supreme perfect enlightenment is arahatship alone.

original: Satipaṭṭhānāti vā maggāti vā bojjhaṅgamissakā. Sammāsambodhi arahattameva. Dīghabhāṇakamahāsīvatthero
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā ati vā maggā ati vā bojjhaṅga missakā sammāsambodhi arahattam eva dīghabhāṇaka mahāsīva thero
translated: The Elder Mahā-Sīva, a reciter of the Digha Nikāya,

original: panāha “satipaṭṭhāne vipassanāti gahetvā bojjhaṅge maggo ca sabbaññutaññāṇañcāti
analyzed: pana āha sati paṭṭhāne vipassanā ti gahetvā bojjhaṅge maggo ca sabbaññuta ññāṇam ca ati
translated: “If he had taken the foundations of mindfulness as insight, and the enlightenment factors, path, and knowledge of all things as the ‘treasure,’

original: gahite sundaro pañho bhaveyya, na panevaṃ gahita”nti. Iti thero sabbaññubuddhānaṃ
analyzed: gahite sundaraḥ pañhaḥ bhaveyya na pana ivam gahitanti iti thero sabbaññu buddhānam
translated: then the question would have been a good one. But he did not take it that way.” So the Elder showed that there is no difference between the enlightenment of all the Enlightened Ones

original: nīvaraṇappahāne satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya sambodhiyañca majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇarajatānaṃ🔽viya nānattābhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ppahāne sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya sambodhiyam ca majjhe  viya nānatta abhāvam dasseti
translated: in the abandoning of the hindrances, in the development of the foundations of mindfulness, and in the middle of the enlightenment tree.

original: Idha ṭhatvā upamā saṃsandetabbā – āyasmā hi sāriputto paccantanagaraṃ dassesi, pākāraṃ
analyzed: idha upamā saṃsandetabbā  āyasmā hi sāriputto paccanta nagaram dassesi pākāram
translated: Here the simile should be completed as follows: The venerable Sāriputta showed the city, the wall,

original: dassesi, pariyāyapathaṃ dassesi, dvāraṃ dassesi, paṇḍitadovārikaṃ dassesi, nagaraṃ🔽pavesanakanikkhamanake oḷārike pāṇe dassesi, paṇḍitadovārikassa tesaṃ pāṇānaṃ pākaṭabhāvañca
analyzed: dassesi pariyāya patham dassesi dvāram dassesi paṇḍita dovārikam dassesi nagaram  pavesanaka nikkhamanake oḷārike pāṇe dassesi paṇḍita dovārikassa tesam pāṇānam pākaṭa bhāvañca
translated: the main road, the gate, the gatekeeper, the people entering and leaving the city, and the gatekeeper’s knowledge of the people.

original: dassesi. Tattha kiṃ kena sadisanti ce. Nagaraṃ viya hi nibbānaṃ, pākāro viya sīlaṃ,
analyzed: dassesi tattha kim kena sadisanti ce nagaram viya hi nibbānam pākāraḥ viya sīlam
translated: Here, what is like what? Nibbāna is like the city, virtue is like the wall,

original: pariyāyapatho viya hirī, dvāraṃ viya ariyamaggo, paṇḍitadovāriko viya dhammasenāpati,
analyzed: pariyāya pathaḥ viya hirī dvāram viya ariya maggo paṇḍita dovārikaḥ viya dhamma senāpati
translated: Hiri is like a bypath, the noble path is like a door, the general of the Dhamma is like a gatekeeper.

original: nagarappavisanakanikkhamanakaoḷārikapāṇā viya atītānāgatapaccuppannā buddhā, dovārikassa🔽tesaṃ pāṇānaṃ pākaṭabhāvo viya āyasmato sāriputtassa atītānāgatapaccuppannabuddhānaṃ
analyzed: nagara ppavisanaka nikkhamanaka oḷārika pāṇāḥ viya atīta anāgata paccuppannāḥ buddhāḥ dovārikassa  tesam pāṇānam pākaṭa bhāvaḥ viya āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa atīta anāgata paccuppanna buddhānam
translated: The Buddhas of the past, future, and present are like the people who enter and leave the city through the gate.🔽The gatekeeper’s knowledge of those people is like the Venerable Sariputta’s knowledge of the Buddhas of the past, future, and present.

original: sīlasamathādīhi pākaṭabhāvo. Ettāvatā therena bhagavā evamahaṃ sāvakapāramīñāṇe ṭhatvā
analyzed: sīla samatha ādīhi ettāvatā therena bhagavā evam aham sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe ṭhatvā
translated: This is how the Elder has given his own lion’s roar by saying: “Standing upon the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship,

original: dhammanvayena nayaggāhena jānāmīti attano sīhanādassa anuyogo dinno hoti.
analyzed: dhammanvayena nayaggāhena jānāmi iti attanaḥ sīhanādassa anuyogaḥ dinnaḥ hoti
translated: I know by inference through the Dhamma.”

original: 144. Idhāhaṃ, bhante, yena bhagavāti imaṃ desanaṃ kasmā ārabhi? Sāvakapāramīñāṇassa
analyzed: idha aham bhante yena bhagavā ati imam desanam kasmai ārabhi sāvaka pāramī ñāṇassa
translated: Why did the Elder begin his teaching with the words “Here, venerable sir, I approached the Blessed One”?

original: nipphattidassanatthaṃ. Ayañhettha adhippāyo, bhagavā ahaṃ sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ paṭilabhanto
analyzed: nipphatti dassana attham ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ bhagavā aham sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam paṭilabhantaḥ
translated: In order to show the fruit of the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship. The meaning intended is this: “When I, venerable sir, was attaining the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship,

original: pañcanavutipāsaṇḍe na aññaṃ ekampi samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā sāvakapāramīñāṇampi
analyzed: pañcanavuti pāsaṇḍe na aññam ekam pi samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā upasaṅkamitvā sāvaka pāramīñāṇampi
translated: I did not approach any other recluse or brahmin and ask: ‘How, venerable sir, should things be seen …? ‘

original: paṭilabhiṃ, tumheyeva upasaṅkamitvā tumhe payirupāsanto paṭilabhinti. Tattha idhāti
analyzed: paṭilabhim tumheyeva upasaṅkamitvā tumhe payis upāsanto paṭilabhinti tattha idha ati
translated: I attained it by approaching you and worshipping you. Here means

original: nipātamattaṃ. Upasaṅkamiṃ dhammasavanāyāti tumhe upasaṅkamanto panāhaṃ na cīvarādihetu
analyzed: nipāta mattam upasaṅkamim dhammasavanāya ati tumhe upasaṅkamantaḥ pana aham na cīvara ādi hetu
translated: in this place. I approached for the sake of hearing the Dhamma means that I approached you, not for the sake of robes, etc.,

original: upasaṅkamanto, dhammasavanatthāya upasaṅkamanto. Evaṃ upasaṅkamitvā sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ
analyzed: upasaṅkamantaḥ dhamma savana tthāya upasaṅkamantaḥ evam upasaṅkamitvā sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam
translated: but for the sake of hearing the Dhamma. Having approached in this way, I attained the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship.

original: paṭilabhiṃ. Kadā pana thero dhammasavanatthāya upasaṅkamantoti. Sūkarakhataleṇe bhāgineyyadīghanakhaparibbājakassa
analyzed: kadā pana theraḥ dhamma savana tthāya upasaṅkamanto ti sūkarakhataleṇe bhāgineyya dīghanakha paribbājakassa
translated: But when did the Elder approach for the sake of hearing the Dhamma? He approached on the day when he related the Discourse on the Investigation of Feeling to his nephew, the wanderer Dīghanakha, in the Sūkara-khadhā Cave.

original: vedanāpariggahasuttantakathanadivase upasaṅkamanto, tadāyeva sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ paṭilabhīti.
analyzed: vedanā pariggaha suttanta kathana divase upasaṅkamantaḥ tadāya iva sāvaka pāramīñāṇam paṭilabhi iti
translated: On that very day he attained the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship.

original: Taṃdivasañhi thero tālavaṇṭaṃ gahetvā bhagavantaṃ bījamāno ṭhito taṃ desanaṃ sutvā
analyzed: taṃ divasam hi theraḥ tālavaṇṭam gahetvā bhagavantam bījamānaḥ ṭhitaḥ tam desanam sutvā
translated: For on that day the Elder, holding a fan of palm leaves, stood fanning the Blessed One. Having heard that teaching,

original: tattheva sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ hatthagataṃ akāsi. Uttaruttaraṃ paṇītapaṇītanti uttaruttarañceva
analyzed: tattha iva sāvaka pāramīñāṇam hattha gatam akāsi uttaruttaram paṇīta paṇītam ti uttaruttaram ca iva
translated: he made the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship his own right there. Higher and higher, more and more excellent means higher and higher,🔽and more and more excellent.

original: paṇītapaṇītañca katvā desesi. Kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāganti kaṇhañceva sukkañca. Tañca🔽kho sappaṭibhāgaṃ savipakkhaṃ katvā. Kaṇhaṃ paṭibāhitvā sukkaṃ, sukkaṃ paṭibāhitvā
analyzed: paṇīta paṇītam ca katvā desesi kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgam ti kaṇham ca iva sukkam ca tam ca  kho sa paṭibhāgam sa vipakkham katvā kaṇham paṭibāhitvā sukkam sukkam paṭibāhitvā
translated: and he taught it by making it clear that it was good and bad. He taught it as good and bad with their opposites,🔽having made the bad the opposite of the good and the good the opposite of the bad.

original: kaṇhanti evaṃ sappaṭibhāgaṃ katvā kaṇhasukkaṃ desesi, kaṇhaṃ desentopi ca saussāhaṃ🔽savipākaṃ desesi, sukkaṃ desentopi saussāhaṃ savipākaṃ desesi.🔽Tasmiṃ dhamme abhiññā idhekaccaṃ dhammaṃ dhammesu niṭṭhamagamanti tasmiṃ desite dhamme
analyzed: kaṇham ti evam sa paṭibhāgam katvā kaṇha sukkam desesi kaṇham desentaḥ api ca saussāham  sa vipākam desesi sukkam desentaḥ api saussāham sa vipākam desesi  tasmin dhamme abhiññāḥ idha ekaccam dhammam dhammesu niṭṭham agamanti tasmin desite dhamme
translated: And he taught it as good and bad with their opposites in such a way that when he taught the bad he taught it with urgency and with result, and when he taught the good he taught it with urgency and with result.🔽And in that Dhamma some came to the conclusion about ideas,

original: ekaccaṃ dhammaṃ nāma sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ sañjānitvā dhammesu niṭṭhamagamaṃ. Katamesu
analyzed: ekaccam dhammam nāma sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam sañjānitvā dhammesu niṭṭham agamam katamesu
translated: having recognized the idea called the perfection of the disciple’s knowledge in that Dhamma taught. In what ideas?

original: dhammesūti? Catusaccadhammesu. Etthāyaṃ therasallāpo, kāḷavallavāsī sumatthero tāva
analyzed: dhammesu iti catu sacca dhammesu ettha ayam thera sallāpo kāḷavalla vāsī suma thero tāva
translated: In the ideas of the Four Truths. Here is the Elder’s discussion: the Elder Sumana of Kalavali village 1 said:

original: vadati “catusaccadhammesu idāni niṭṭhagamanakāraṇaṃ natthi. Assajimahāsāvakassa hi
analyzed: vadati catu sacca dhammesu idāni niṭṭha gamana kāraṇam na atthi assaji mahāsāvakassa hi
translated: “There is no coming to a conclusion now in the ideas of the Four Truths. For the Great Hearer Assaji

original: diṭṭhadivaseyeva so paṭhamamaggena catusaccadhammesu niṭṭhaṃ gato, aparabhāge sūkarakhataleṇadvāre
analyzed: diṭṭha divaseya iva saḥ paṭhama maggena catu sacca dhammesu niṭṭham gataḥ apara bhāge
translated: On the very day he saw the Elder, he reached the conclusion regarding the Four Noble Truths by means of the first path. Later, at the entrance to the Boar’s Belly Cave,

original: upari tīhi maggehi catusaccadhammesu niṭṭhaṃ gato, imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne ‘dhammesū’ti
analyzed: upari tīhi maggehi catu sacca dhammesu niṭṭham gataḥ imasmin pana ṭhāne dhammesu uti
translated: he reached the conclusion regarding the Four Noble Truths by means of the three higher paths. At this point, however, he reached the conclusion regarding the qualities of the Buddha.

original: buddhaguṇesu niṭṭhaṃ gato”ti. Lokantaravāsī cūḷasīvatthero pana “sabbaṃ tatheva vatvā
analyzed: buddha guṇesu niṭṭham gataḥ ti lokantara vāsī cūḷasīva theraḥ pana sabbam tathā iva vatvā
translated: The Elder Cūḷa-Sīva, who lived in another world, said, “All this is the same,

original: imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne ‘dhammesū’ti arahatte niṭṭhaṃ gato”ti āha. Dīghabhāṇakatipiṭakamahāsīvatthero
analyzed: imasmin pana ṭhāne dhammesu iti arahatte niṭṭham gato ti āha dīghabhāṇaka tipiṭaka mahāsīva thero
translated: but at this point he reached the conclusion regarding the qualities of the Buddha, that is, arahantship.” The Elder Mahā-Sīva, a Dīghabhāṇaka and a Tipiṭaka master,

original: pana “tatheva purimavādaṃ vatvā imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne ‘dhammesū’ti sāvakapāramīñāṇe🔽niṭṭhaṃ gato”ti vatvā “buddhaguṇā pana nayato āgatā”ti āha.
analyzed: pana tathā iva purima vādam vatvā imasmin pana ṭhāne dhammesu iti sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe  niṭṭham gataḥ iti vatvā buddha guṇā pana nayataḥ āgatā iti āha
translated: said, “All this is the same, but at this point he reached the conclusion regarding the qualities of the Buddha, that is, the knowledge of the perfections of a disciple.🔽He reached the conclusion regarding the qualities of the Buddha by way of the knowledge of the perfections of a disciple.”

original: Satthari pasīdinti evaṃ sāvakapāramīñāṇadhammesu niṭṭhaṃ gantvā bhiyyosomattāya “sammāsambuddho
analyzed: satthari pasīdinti evam sāvaka pāramī ñāṇa dhammesu niṭṭham gantvā bhiyyosomattāya sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: “He became confident in the Teacher” means that after reaching the conclusion regarding the qualities of the Buddha, that is, the knowledge of the perfections of a disciple, he became even more confident, thinking, “The Blessed One is indeed fully enlightened!

original: vata so bhagavā”ti satthari pasīdiṃ. Svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammoti suṭṭhu akkhāto
analyzed: vata saḥ bhagavā ati satthari pasīdim su ākkhātaḥ bhagavatā dhammo ti suṭṭhu akkhātaḥ
translated: The Dhamma is well-expounded by the Blessed One” means that the Dhamma is well-proclaimed by the Blessed One.

original: sukathito niyyāniko maggo phalatthāya niyyāti rāgadosamohanimmadanasamattho.
analyzed: su kathitaḥ niyyānikaḥ maggo phala atthāya niyyāti rāga dosa moha nimmadana samattho
translated: It is well-proclaimed, it leads out, it is to be directly experienced by the wise, it is to be seen here and now, it is a way to emancipation, and it is to be directly experienced by the wise, and it is able to destroy the intoxications that cause rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm, and wrong view and wrong practice.

original: Suppaṭipanno saṅghoti buddhassa bhagavato sāvakasaṅghopi vaṅkādidosavirahitaṃ sammāpaṭipadaṃ paṭipannattā suppaṭipannoti pasannomhi bhagavatīti dasseti.
analyzed: suppaṭipanno saṅghaḥ ti buddhassa bhagavataḥ sāvaka saṅghaḥ api vaṅka ādi dosa virahitam sammā paṭipadam paṭipanna ttā suppaṭipannaḥ ti pasannaḥ mhi bhagavati iti dasseti
translated: The Sangha is practicing well: the Sangha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing well because they are practicing the right practice, free from crookedness and corruption. I have confidence in the Buddha.

original: Kusaladhammadesanāvaṇṇanā🔽145. Idāni divāṭṭhāne nisīditvā samāpajjite soḷasa aparāpariyadhamme dassetuṃ aparaṃ
analyzed: kusala dhamma desanā vaṇṇanā  idāni divāṭṭhāne nisīditvā samāpajjite soḷasa apara apariya dhamme dassetum aparam
translated: The explanation of the teaching on wholesome qualities🔽Now, in order to show the sixteen qualities of further-men, which he had attained while sitting in the day-time abode, he began the discourse with the words, “But, Lord, this unsurpassed

original: pana bhante etadānuttariyanti desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha anuttariyanti anuttarabhāvo.
analyzed: pana bhante desanam ārabhi tattha anuttariyanti anuttara bhāvaḥ
translated: teaching of the Dhamma.” Herein, unsurpassed is the state of being unsurpassed.

original: Yathā bhagavā dhammaṃ desetīti yathā yenākārena yāya desanāya bhagavā dhammaṃ deseti,
analyzed: yathā bhagavā dhammam deseti iti yathā yena ākārena yāya desanāya bhagavā dhammam deseti
translated: In the way the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma: in the way, in the manner, in which the Blessed One teaches the Dhamma.

original: sā tumhākaṃ desanā anuttarāti vadati. Kusalesu dhammesūti tāya desanāya desitesu
analyzed: sā tumhākam desanā anuttarā iti vadati kusalesu dhammesu uti tāya desanāya desitesu
translated: Your teaching is unsurpassed: he says that your teaching is unsurpassed.🔽In wholesome qualities: he shows that the Blessed One is unsurpassed even in the wholesome qualities taught by that teaching.

original: kusalesu dhammesupi bhagavāva anuttaroti dīpeti. Yā vā sā desanā, tassā bhūmiṃ dassentopi
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu pi bhagavā ava anuttaraḥ ti dīpeti yā vā sā desanā tassā bhūmim dassentaḥ api
translated: Or else, showing the ground for that teaching,

original: “kusalesu dhammesū”ti āha. Tatrime kusalā dhammāti tatra kusalesu dhammesūti vuttapade🔽ime kusalā dhammā nāmāti veditabbā. Tattha ārogyaṭṭhena, anavajjaṭṭhena, kosallasambhūtaṭṭhena,
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu iti āha tatra ime kusalāḥ dhammā ti tatra kusalesu dhammesu iti vutta pade  ime kusalāḥ dhammāḥ nāma ati veditabbā tattha ārogya ṭṭhena anavajja ṭṭhena kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena
translated: “In profitable ideas” is said. Herein,🔽these are called profitable ideas. Herein, the profitable should be understood as fivefold:🔽in the sense of health, in the sense of blameless, in the sense of being originated by ability,

original: niddarathaṭṭhena, sukhavipākaṭṭhenāti pañcadhā kusalaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tesu jātakapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: niddaratha ṭhena sukha vipāka ṭṭhena ati pañcadhā kusalam veditabbam tesu jātaka pariyāyam
translated: in the sense of being unprovoked, and in the sense of having a happy outcome.

original: patvā ārogyaṭṭhena kusalaṃ vaṭṭati. Suttantapariyāyaṃ patvā anavajjaṭṭhena. Abhidhammapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: patvā ārogya ṭṭhena kusalam vaṭṭati suttanta pariyāyam patvā anavajja ṭṭhena abhidhamma pariyāyam
translated: Among them, in the case of the Thread’s Mode of Conveying, the profitable is allowable in the sense of health. In the case of the Discourses’ Mode of Conveying, it is in the sense of blameless. In the case of the Abhidhamma Mode of Conveying,

original: patvā kosallasambhūtaniddarathasukhavipākaṭṭhena. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne bāhitikasuttantapariyāyena
analyzed: patvā kosalla sambhūta niddaratha sukha vipāka ṭṭhena imasmin pana ṭhāne bāhitika suttanta pariyāyena
translated: it is in the sense of being originated by ability, in the sense of being unprovoked, and in the sense of having a happy outcome. But in this instance, in the case of the Thread’s Mode of Conveying,

original: anavajjaṭṭhena kusalaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: anavajja ṭṭhena kusalam daṭṭhabbam
translated: the profitable should be regarded as in the sense of blameless.

original: Cattāro satipaṭṭhānāti cuddasavidhena kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ, navavidhena vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhānā ti cuddasavidhena kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam navavidhena vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam
translated: Four foundations of mindfulness: the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body, which is fourteenfold; the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feelings, which is ninefold;

original: soḷasavidhena cittānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ, pañcavidhena dhammānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: soḷasavidhena citta anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam pañcavidhena dhamma anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam
translated: the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of cognizance, which is sixteenfold; and the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of ideas, which is fivefold.

original: evaṃ nānānayehi vibhajitvā samathavipassanāmaggavasena lokiyalokuttaramissakā cattāro
analyzed: evam nānā nayehi vibhajitvā samatha vipassanā magga vasena lokiya lokuttara missakā cattāro
translated: Having thus divided them by various methods, they are fourfold as mundane, supramundane, and mixed, by way of serenity, insight, and path.

original: satipaṭṭhānā desitā. Phalasatipaṭṭhānaṃ pana idha anadhippetaṃ. Cattāro sammappadhānāti🔽paggahaṭṭhena ekalakkhaṇā, kiccavasena nānākiccā. “Idha bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā desitā phala sati paṭṭhānam pana idha anadhippetam cattāro sammappadhānā ti  paggaha ṭṭhena eka lakkhaṇā kicca vasena nānā kiccā idha bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam
translated: Having thus analyzed them by different methods, the four foundations of mindfulness are taught by way of serenity and insight, and of the mundane and supramundane paths. But the fruition foundation of mindfulness is not intended here.

original: akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāyā”tiādinā nayena samathavipassanāmaggavasena lokiyalokuttaramissakāva
analyzed: akusalānam dhammānaṃ anuppādāya ati ādinā nayena samatha vipassanā magga vasena lokiya lokuttara missakā ava
translated: The four right efforts are of one characteristic as exertion, and of different functions. By way of serenity and insight, and of the mundane and supramundane paths, the four right efforts are taught thus: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu for the non-arising of unarisen evil unwholesome states … “

original: cattāro sammappadhānā desitā. Cattāro iddhipādāti ijjhanaṭṭhena ekasaṅgahā, chandādivasena🔽nānāsabhāvā. “Idha bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāvetī”tiādinā
analyzed: cattāro sammappadhānā desitā cattāro iddhipādā ti ijjhan aṭṭhena eka saṅgahā chanda ādi vasena  idha bhikkhu chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam iddhipādam bhāveti itiādinā
translated: The four bases of success are of one inclusion as success, and of different natures by way of will, etc.

original: nayena samathavipassanāmaggavasena lokiyalokuttaramissakāva cattāro iddhipādā desitā.
analyzed: nayena samatha vipassanā magga vasena lokiya lokuttara missakā va cattāraḥ iddhipādāḥ desitā
translated: By way of serenity and insight, and of the mundane and supramundane paths, the four bases of success are taught thus: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops the basis of success that possesses will and is accompanied by concentration by mind-fulness … “

original: Pañcindriyānīti ādhipateyyaṭṭhena ekalakkhaṇāni, adhimokkhādisabhāvavasena nānāsabhāvāni.
analyzed: pañca indriyāni iti ādhipateyya ṭṭhena eka lakkhaṇāni adhimokkha ādi sabhāva vasena nānā sabhāvāni
translated: The five faculties have the single characteristic of predominance, but they are of different natures as having the nature of resolution, etc.,

original: Samathavipassanāmaggavaseneva ca lokiyalokuttaramissakāni saddhādīni pañcindriyāni
analyzed: samatha vipassanā magga vasena iva ca lokiya lokuttara missakāni saddhā ādīni pañca indriyāni
translated: and they are taught as the five faculties of faith, etc., in the sense of serenity and insight and the path, and as mundane and supramundane, mixed and unmixed.

original: desitāni. Pañca balānīti upatthambhanaṭṭhena akampiyaṭṭhena vā ekasaṅgahāni, salakkhaṇena🔽nānāsabhāvāni. Samathavipassanāmaggavaseneva lokiyalokuttaramissakāni saddhādīni
analyzed: desitāni pañca balāni iti upatthambhana ṭṭhena akampiya ṭṭhena vā eka saṅgahāni sa lakkhaṇena  nānā sabhāvāni samatha vipassanā magga vasena iva lokiya lokuttara missakāni saddhā ādīni
translated: The five powers have the single characteristic of supporting, or the single characteristic of unshakability, but they are of different natures as having the single characteristic of faith, etc.,🔽and they are taught as the five powers of faith, etc., in the sense of serenity and insight and the path, and as mundane and supramundane, mixed and unmixed.

original: pañca balāni desitāni. Satta bojjhaṅgāti niyyānaṭṭhena ekasaṅgahā, upaṭṭhānādinā
analyzed: pañca balāni desitāni satta bojjhaṅgā ti niyyāna aṭṭhena eka saṅgahāḥ upaṭṭhāna ādinā
translated: The seven enlightenment factors have the single characteristic of outlet, but they are of different natures as having the single characteristic of mindfulness, etc.,

original: salakkhaṇena nānāsabhāvā. Samathavipassanā maggavaseneva lokiyalokuttaramissakā satta bojjhaṅgā desitā.
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇena nānā sabhāvā samatha vipassanā magga vasena iva lokiya lokuttara missakā satta bojjhaṅgā desitā
translated: and they are taught as the seven enlightenment factors in the sense of serenity and insight and the path, and as mundane and supramundane, mixed and unmixed.

original: Ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggoti hetuṭṭhena ekasaṅgaho, dassanādinā salakkhaṇena nānāsabhāvo. Samathavipassanāmaggavaseneva lokiyalokuttaramissako ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo desitoti attho.
analyzed: ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo ti hetu ṭṭhena eka saṅgahaḥ dassana ādinā sa lakkhaṇena nānā sabhāvaḥ samatha vipassanā magga vasena iva lokiya lokuttara missakaḥ ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggaḥ desito ti attho
translated: The Noble Eightfold Path is a single category in the sense of cause, but it is of various natures in the sense of its specific characteristics, such as seeing and so on. The meaning is that the Noble Eightfold Path, which is a mixture of mundane and supramundane, is taught by way of the path of serenity and insight.

original: Idha, bhante, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayāti idaṃ kimatthaṃ āraddhaṃ? Sāsanassa pariyosānadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: idha bhante bhikkhu āsavānam khayā ti idam kimattham āraddham sāsanassa pariyosāna dassana attham
translated: Here, venerable sir, a bhikkhu … the destruction of the taints: for the purpose of showing the culmination of the dispensation.

original: Sāsanassa hi na kevalaṃ maggeneva pariyosānaṃ hoti, arahattaphalena pana hoti. Tasmā🔽taṃ dassetuṃ idamāraddhanti veditabbaṃ. Etadānuttariyaṃ, bhante, kusalesu dhammesūti🔽bhante yā ayaṃ kusalesu dhammesu evaṃdesanā, etadānuttariyaṃ. Taṃ bhagavāti taṃ desanaṃ
analyzed: sāsanassa hi na kevalam maggena iva pariyosānam hoti arahatta phalena pana hoti tasmā  tam dassetum idam āraddha nti veditabbam etat ānuttariyam bhante kusalesu dhammesu iti  bhante yā ayam kusalesu dhammesu evaṃdesanā etat ānuttariyam tam bhagavā ati tam desanam
translated: For the dispensation does not culminate only in the path, but also in the fruit of arahantship. Therefore🔽it should be understood that this was undertaken in order to show that. This is unsurpassed, venerable sir, in the training of those who train in wholesome states.🔽Venerable sir, this teaching of the training of those who train in wholesome states is unsurpassed. That, venerable sir, the Blessed One knows. That the Blessed One makes known.

original: bhagavā asesaṃ sakalaṃ abhijānāti. Taṃ bhagavatoti taṃ desanaṃ bhagavato asesaṃ abhijānato.
analyzed: bhagavā asesam sakalam abhijānāti tam bhagavataḥ iti tam desanam bhagavataḥ asesam abhijānataḥ
translated: That the Blessed One knows in its entirety, without exception, is the teaching.

original: Uttari abhiññeyyaṃ natthīti taduttari abhijānitabbaṃ natthi, ayaṃ nāma ito añño dhammo🔽vā puggalo vā yaṃ bhagavā na jānātīti idaṃ natthi. Yadabhijānaṃ añño samaṇo vāti
analyzed: uttari abhiññeyyam natthi iti tad uttari abhijānitabbam natthi ayam nāma itas aññaḥ dhammo  vā puggalaḥ vā yam bhagavā na jānāti iti idam na atthi aññaḥ samaṇaḥ vā ati
translated: There is nothing further to be directly known: there is nothing further to be directly known beyond that, there is no other state or person

original: yaṃ tumhehi anabhiññātaṃ, taṃ añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā abhijānanto bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro
analyzed: yam tumhehi an abhiññātam tam aññaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā abhijānantaḥ bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataraḥ
translated: that the Exalted One does not know. That no other recluse or brahmin: that no other recluse or brahmin, having directly known what you have not directly known, would be more directly known than the Exalted One,

original: assa, adhikatarapañño bhaveyya. Yadidaṃ kusalesu dhammesūti ettha yadidanti nipātamattaṃ,🔽kusalesu dhammesu bhagavatā uttaritaro natthīti ayametthattho. Iti bhagavāva kusalesu
analyzed: assa adhikatara paññaḥ bhaveyya yat idam kusalesu dhammesu iti ettha yat idam ti nipāta mattam  kusalesu dhammesu bhagavatā uttaritaraḥ natthi iti ayam etthatthaḥ iti bhagavā ava kusalesu
translated: would have higher wisdom than the Exalted One, in regard to states that are wholesome. Herein, in regard to states that are wholesome: the words “in regard to” are mere conjunction;

original: dhammesu anuttaroti dassento “imināpi kāraṇena evaṃpasanno ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatī”ti🔽dīpeti. Ito paresu aparaṃ panātiādīsu visesamattameva vaṇṇayissāma. Purimavārasadisaṃ
analyzed: dhammesu anuttaraḥ ti dassento iminā api kāraṇena evaṃpasannaḥ aham bhante bhagavati iti  dīpa iti itas paresu aparam pana ati ādīsu visesa mattam eva vaṇṇayissāma purima vāra sadisam
translated: the meaning is that there is no one higher than the Exalted One in regard to states that are wholesome. Thus showing that the Exalted One is unsurpassed in regard to states that are wholesome, he shows that he is satisfied with the Exalted One in this way.

original: pana vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: As regards the rest, beginning with “apart from this,” we shall explain only the difference. But the rest should be understood in the same way as stated above in the first section.

original: Āyatanapaṇṇattidesanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: āyatana paṇṇatti desanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the teaching on the description of the sense bases

original: 146. Āyatanapaṇṇattīsūti āyatanapaññāpanāsu. Idāni tā āyatanapaññattiyo dassento
analyzed: āyatana paṇṇattīsu iti āyatana paññāpanāsu idāni tāḥ āyatana paññattiyaḥ dassento
translated: The exposition of the bases: in the expositions of the bases. Now, showing those expositions of the bases,

original: chayimāni, bhantetiādimāha. Āyatanakathā panesā visuddhimagge vitthārena kathitā,
analyzed: bhante ti ādim āha āyatana kathā pana isā visuddhi magge vitthārena kathitā
translated: he said, “Venerable sir, there are these six,” etc. But this discussion of the bases is given in detail in the Path of Purity,

original: tena na taṃ vitthārayissāma, tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva sā vitthārato veditabbā.
analyzed: tena na tam vitthārayissāma tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva sā vitthārataḥ veditabbā
translated: so we shall not elaborate it here. It should be understood in detail according to what is said there.

original: Etadānuttariyaṃ, bhante, āyatanapaṇṇattīsūti yāyaṃ āyatanapaṇṇattīsu ajjhattikabāhiravavatthānādivasena evaṃ desanā, etadānuttariyaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: etat ānuttariyam bhante āyatana paṇṇattīsu iti yā ayam āyatana paṇṇattīsu ajjhattika bāhira vavatthāna ādi vasena evam desanā etat ānuttariyam sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: This is the unsurpassed teaching of the exposition of the bases, venerable sir: this is the unsurpassed teaching among the teachings of the exposition of the bases, which is given in this way by way of the internal and external determinations, etc. The rest is as already stated.

original: Gabbhāvakkantidesanāvaṇṇanā🔽147. Gabbhāvakkantīsūti gabbhokkamanesu. Tā gabbhāvakkantiyo dassento catasso imā,🔽bhantetiādimāha. Tattha asampajānoti ajānanto sammūḷho hutvā. Mātukucchiṃ okkamatīti
analyzed: gabbhā vakkanti desanā vaṇṇanā  gabbha avakkantīsu iti gabbha ukkamanesu tāḥ gabbha avakkantiyaḥ dassento catassaḥ imāḥ  bhanta iti ādim āha tattha a sampajānoti a jānantaḥ sammūḍhaḥ hutvā mātukucchim okkamati iti
translated: The explanation of the teaching of descent into the womb

original: paṭisandhivasena pavisati. Ṭhātīti vasati. Nikkhamatīti nikkhamantopi asampajāno
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena pavisati ṭhāti iti vasati nikkhamati iti nikkhamantaḥ api asampajāno
translated: The teaching of descent into the womb: in the descents into the womb. Now, showing those descents into the womb, he said, “Venerable sir, there are these four,” etc. Herein, unmindfully: not mindfully, not fully aware, confused. Enters the womb: enters by way of rebirth-linking. Abides: dwells. Emerges: also emerges unmindfully.

original: sammūḷhova nikkhamati. Ayaṃ paṭhamāti ayaṃ pakatilokiyamanussānaṃ paṭhamā gabbhāvakkanti.
analyzed: sammūḷhaḥ iva nikkhamati ayam paṭhamā ati ayam pakatilokiya manussānam paṭhamā gabbhāvakkanti
translated: and he emerges confused. This is the first kind.

original: Sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamatīti okkamanto sampajāno asammūḷho hutvā okkamati.
analyzed: sampajānaḥ mātukucchim okkamati iti okkamantaḥ sampajānaḥ a sammūḍhaḥ hutvā okkamati
translated: He enters the womb consciously: he enters the womb conscious and unconfused.

original: Ayaṃ dutiyāti ayaṃ asītimahātherānaṃ sāvakānaṃ dutiyā gabbhāvakkanti. Te hi pavisantāva jānanti, vasantā ca nikkhamantā ca na jānanti.
analyzed: ayam dutiyā ti ayam asīti mahā therānam sāvakānam dutiyā te hi pavisantā ava jānanti vasantā ca nikkhamantā ca na jānanti
translated: This is the second kind. This is the kind of the eighty great disciples. They knew when they were entering but not when they were staying and emerging.

original: Ayaṃ tatiyāti ayaṃ dvinnañca aggasāvakānaṃ paccekabodhisattānañca tatiyā gabbhāvakkanti.
analyzed: ayam tatiyā iti ayam dvinnam ca aggasāvakānam paccekabodhisattānam ca tatiyā
translated: This is the third kind. This is the kind of the two chief disciples and the Paccekabuddhas.

original: Te kira kammajehi vātehi adhosirā uddhaṃpādā anekasataporise papāte viya yonimukhe
analyzed: te kira kamma jehi vātehi adhosirāḥ uddhaṃpādāḥ aneka sata porise papāte viya yoni mukhe
translated: They are, it seems, thrown into the opening of the womb headfirst by the karmically acquired winds, as though into a pit a hundred leagues deep.

original: khittā tāḷacchiggaḷena hatthī viya sambādhena yonimukhena nikkhamamānā anantaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: khittā tāḷa chiggaḷena hatthī viya sambādhena yonimukhena nikkhamamānā anantam dukkham
translated: And as they emerge from the womb’s opening, which is as narrow as the mouth of a needle, they experience the most extreme pain, like an elephant in a clay hole.

original: pāpuṇanti. Tena nesaṃ “mayaṃ nikkhamamhā”ti sampajānatā na hoti. Evaṃ pūritapāramīnampi
analyzed: pāpuṇanti tena mayam nikkhamamha ati sampajānatā na hoti evam pūrita pāramīnam pi
translated: So they do not know that they are emerging. This is the kind of those who have fulfilled the pāramīs.

original: ca sattānaṃ evarūpe ṭhāne mahantaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjatīti alameva gabbhāvāse nibbindituṃ alaṃ virajjituṃ.
analyzed: ca sattānam evarūpe ṭhāne mahantam dukkham uppajjati iti alam eva gabbha āvāse nibbinditum alam virajjitum
translated: and great suffering arises for beings in such a place. So it is enough to be repelled and enough to be free from passion for the womb.🔽This is the fourth,

original: Ayaṃ catutthāti ayaṃ sabbaññubodhisattānaṃ vasena catutthā gabbhāvakkanti. Sabbaññubodhisattā
analyzed: ayam catutthā ati ayam sabbaññu bodhisattānam vasena catutthā sabbaññu bodhisattā
translated: for the Bodhisattas who are omniscient,

original: hi mātukucchismiṃ paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhantāpi jānanti, tattha vasantāpi jānanti, nikkhamantāpi
analyzed: hi mātukucchismim paṭisandhim gaṇhantā api jānanti tattha vasantā api jānanti nikkhamantā api
translated: for when they take rebirth-linking in the mother’s womb they know it, and while they are there they know it, and when they are coming forth they know it.

original: jānanti, nikkhamanakālepi ca te kammajavātā uddhaṃpāde adhosire katvā khipituṃ na
analyzed: jānanti nikkhamana kāle pi ca te kamma ja vātāḥ uddhaṃpāde adhosire katvā khipitum na
translated: And at the time of coming forth the winds of karma cannot make them come forth head downwards or feet first;

original: sakkonti, dve hatthe pasāretvā akkhīni ummīletvā ṭhitakāva nikkhamanti. Bhavaggaṃ
analyzed: sakkonti dve hatthe pasāretvā akkhīni ummīletvā ṭhitakāḥ va nikkhamanti bhavaggam
translated: they come forth with their two hands raised and their eyes looking straight ahead.

original: upādāya avīciantare añño tīsu kālesu sampajāno nāma natthi ṭhapetvā sabbaññubodhisatte.
analyzed: upādāya avīci antare añño tīsu kālesu sampajānaḥ nāma natthi ṭhapetvā sabbaññu bodhisatte
translated: Except for the Bodhisattas who are omniscient there is no one else in the three times who is fully aware in the three modes of deportment,

original: Teneva nesaṃ mātukucchiṃ okkamanakāle ca nikkhamanakāle ca dasasahassilokadhātu kampatīti.
analyzed: tena iva na isam mātukucchim okkamana kāle ca nikkhamana kāle ca dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampati iti
translated: and that is why the ten-thousandfold world system shakes when they enter their mother’s womb and when they come forth from it.

original: Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sesam ettha vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The rest should be understood in the way already described.

original: Ādesanavidhādesanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: ādesana vidhā desanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the exposition of the way of arrival is ended.

original: 148. Ādesanavidhāsūti ādesanakoṭṭhāsesu. Idāni tā ādesanavidhā dassento catasso imātiādimāha.
analyzed: ādesana vidhāsu iti ādesana koṭṭhāsesu idāni tāḥ ādesana vidhāḥ dassento catassaḥ imā iti ādim āha
translated: The four kinds of surmise are the four kinds of surmise mentioned in the Schedule of Consecutive Single Terms . Now, in order to show those four kinds of surmise, he said “There are these four kinds of surmise” .

original: Nimittena ādisatīti āgatanimittena gatanimittena ṭhitanimittena vā idaṃ nāma bhavissatīti katheti.
analyzed: nimittena ādisati iti āgata nimittena gata nimittena ṭhita nimittena vā idam nāma bhavissati iti kathā iti
translated: He surmises by a sign: he says “This is what it will be” by a sign of what has been seen, a sign of what has been heard, or a sign of what has been sensed.

original: Tatridaṃ vatthu – eko rājā tisso muttā gahetvā purohitaṃ pucchi “kiṃ me, ācariya,
analyzed: tatra idam vatthu ekaḥ rājā tissaḥ muttāḥ gahetvā purohitam pucchi kim me
translated: Here is a case. A king took three pearls and asked his chaplain, “What have I got in my hand, teacher?

original: hatthe”ti? So ito cito ca olokesi. Tena ca samayena ekā sarabū “makkhikaṃ gahessāmī”ti
analyzed: hattha iti saḥ itas citas ca olokesi tena ca samayena ekā sarabū makkhikam gahessāmi iti
translated: ” The chaplain looked this way and that. At that moment a female monkey was stretching out her hand to catch a fly.

original: pakkhandi, gahaṇakāle makkhikā palātā, so makkhikāya muttattā “muttā mahārājā”ti
analyzed: gahaṇa kāle makkhikā palātā saḥ makkhikāya muttattā muttā mahā rājā ati
translated: At the moment of catching it the fly escaped, and because of the fly the chaplain said, “Pearls, great king.”

original: āha. Muttā tāva hotu, kati muttāti? So puna nimittaṃ olokesi. Atha avidūre kukkuṭo
analyzed: āha muttā tāva hotu kati muttā ati saḥ puna nimittam olokesi atha avidūre kukkuṭaḥ
translated: “Let them be pearls, but how many?” The chaplain looked for a sign again. Then a cock crowed twice not far away.

original: tikkhattuṃ saddaṃ nicchāresi. Brāhmaṇo “tisso mahārājā”ti āha. Evaṃ ekacco āgatanimittena
analyzed: tikkhattum saddam nicchāresi brāhmaṇaḥ tissaḥ mahārājā iti āha evam ekaccaḥ āgata nimittena
translated: The brahmin said, “Three, great king.” So he said by a sign of what has been heard.

original: katheti. Etenupāyena gataṭhitani mittehipi kathanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: kathā iti etena upāyena gata ṭhita ni mittehi pi kathanam veditabbam
translated: In this way he said by a sign of what has been seen, by a sign of what has been heard, and by a sign of what has been sensed.

original: Amanussānanti yakkhapisācādīnaṃ. Devatānanti cātumahārājikādīnaṃ. Saddaṃ sutvāti
analyzed: amanussānam ti yakkha pisāca ādīnam devatānam ti cātumahārājika ādīnam saddam sutvā iti
translated: ‘Non-human beings’ are spirits, ogres, etc.; ‘deities’ are the deities of the Four Kings’ heaven, etc.; ‘Having heard a sound’:

original: aññassa cittaṃ ñatvā kathentānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā. Vitakkavipphārasaddanti vitakkavipphāravasena🔽uppannaṃ vippalapantānaṃ suttapamattādīnaṃ saddaṃ. Sutvāti taṃ saddaṃ sutvā. original: vā samādhi bhavissati, ṭhitibhāgiyo vā visesabhāgiyo vā nibbedhabhāgiyo vā abhiññāyo🔽vā nibbattessatīti jānāti.

original: Tattha puthujjano cetopariyañāṇalābhī puthujjanānaṃyeva cittaṃ jānāti, na ariyānaṃ.
analyzed: tattha puthujjano cetaḥ pariya ñāṇa lābhī puthujjanānam yeva cittam jānāti na ariyānam
translated: Herein, one who has obtained knowledge of penetration of hearts knows the hearts of ordinary men but not of Noble Ones.

original: Ariyesupi heṭṭhimo heṭṭhimo uparimassa uparimassa cittaṃ na jānāti, uparimo pana
analyzed: ariyesu pi heṭṭhimaḥ heṭṭhimaḥ uparimassa uparimassa cittam na jānāti uparimaḥ pana
translated: And in the case of noble persons, the lower does not know the higher, but the higher knows the lower.

original: heṭṭhimassa jānāti. Etesu ca sotāpanno sotāpattiphalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati. Sakadāgāmī,
analyzed: heṭṭhimassa jānāti etesu ca sotāpannaḥ sotāpatti phala samāpattim samāpajjati sakadāgāmī
translated: And of these, the stream-enterer enters upon the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry, the once-returner the fruit of once-returning,

translated: the non-returner the fruit of non-returning, and the arahant the fruit of arahantship. But the higher does not enter upon the lower.

original: Tesañhi heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā samāpatti tatrupapattiyeva hoti. Tatheva taṃ hotīti idaṃ
analyzed: tesam hi heṭṭhimā heṭṭhimā samāpatti hoti tathā iva tam hoti iti idam
translated: For the lower and lower attainments are only the kinds of rebirth corresponding to them.

original: ekaṃsena tatheva hoti. Cetopariyañāṇavasena ñātañhi aññathābhāvī nāma natthi. Sesaṃ
analyzed: ekaṃsena tathā iva hoti cetaḥ pariya ñāṇa vasena ñātaṃ hi aññathābhāvī nāma natthi sesam
translated: That is just as it is: this is invariable. For what is known by means of knowledge of penetration of minds does not become otherwise. The rest

original: purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: purima nayena iva yojetabbam

original: Dassanasamāpattidesanāvaṇṇanā🔽149. Ātappamanvāyātiādi brahmajāle vitthāritameva. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo, ātappanti
analyzed: dassana samāpatti desanā vaṇṇanā  ātappam anvāyāti ādi brahmajāle vitthāritam eva ayam pana ittha saṅkhepaḥ ātappanti
translated: The explanation of the section on the kinds of direct knowledge and the kinds of attainment is ended.🔽Zeal, etc., are given in detail in the Brahmajāla Sutta . Here is a brief explanation of them: Zeal is energy. That is exertion because it is to be exerted,

original: vīriyaṃ. Tadeva padahitabbato padhānaṃ. Anuyuñjitabbato anuyogo. Appamādanti satiavippavāsaṃ.
analyzed: vīriyam tat eva padahitabbataḥ padhānam anuyuñjitabbataḥ anuyogaḥ appamādanti sati a vippavāsam

original: Sammāmanasikāranti anicce aniccantiādivasena pavattaṃ upāyamanasikāraṃ. Cetosamādhinti🔽paṭhamajjhānasamādhiṃ. Ayaṃ paṭhamā dassanasamāpattīti ayaṃ dvattiṃ sākāraṃ paṭikūlato
analyzed: sammāmanasikāranti anicce anicca nti ādi vasena pavattam upāya manasikāram cetosamādhinti  paṭhama jhāna samādhim ayam paṭhamā dassana samāpatti iti ayam dvattim sa ākāram paṭikūlato
translated: Right reflection is reflection by a suitable means, occurring as “impermanent, impermanent,” and so on. Mental unification is

original: manasikatvā paṭikūladassanavasena uppāditā paṭhamajjhānasamāpatti paṭhamā dassanasamāpatti
analyzed: manasikatvā paṭikūla dassana vasena uppāditā paṭhama jhāna samāpatti paṭhamā dassana samāpatti
translated: unification in the first jhāna. This is the first kind of direct-knowledge attainment: this is the first jhāna attainment produced by giving attention to repulsiveness in the thirty-two aspects and by seeing the repulsiveness in it.

original: nāma, sace pana taṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā sotāpanno hoti, ayaṃ nippariyāyeneva paṭhamā dassanasamāpatti.
analyzed: nāma sace pana tam jhānam pādakam katvā sotāpannaḥ hoti ayaṃ nippariyāyena iva paṭhamā dassana samāpatti
translated: It is called the first kind of direct-knowledge attainment. If one becomes a stream-enterer with that jhāna as the basis, then this is the first kind of direct-knowledge attainment in the true sense.

original: Atikkamma cāti atikkamitvā ca. Chavimaṃsalohitanti chaviñca maṃsañca lohitañca. Aṭṭhiṃ🔽paccavekkhatīti aṭṭhi aṭṭhīti paccavekkhati. Aṭṭhi aṭṭhīti paccavekkhitvā uppāditā

translated: Having transcended: having gone beyond. Skin, flesh, and blood: skin, flesh, and blood. Bone:

analyzed: aṭṭhi ārammaṇā dibba cakkhu pādaka jjhāna samāpatti dutiyā dassana samāpatti nāma sace

If one becomes a non-returner with that jhāna as the basis, then this is the second kind of direct-knowledge attainment in the true sense.

original: pana taṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā sakadāgāmimaggaṃ nibbatteti. Ayaṃ nippariyāyena dutiyā
analyzed: pana tam jhānam pādakam katvā sakadāgāmi maggam nibbatteti ayaṃ nippariyāyena dutiyā

original: dassanasamāpatti. Kāḷavallavāsī sumatthero pana “yāva tatiyamaggā vaṭṭatī”ti āha.🔽Viññāṇasotanti viññāṇameva. Ubhayato abbocchinnanti dvīhipi bhāgehi acchinnaṃ. Idha🔽loke patiṭṭhitañcāti chandarāgavasena imasmiñca loke patiṭṭhitaṃ. Dutiyapadepi eseva🔽nayo. Kammaṃ vā kammato upagacchantaṃ idha loke patiṭṭhitaṃ nāma. Kammabhavaṃ ākaḍḍhantaṃ
analyzed: dassana samāpatti kāḷavalla vāsī suma theraḥ pana yāva tatiya maggā vaṭṭati iti āha  viññāṇa sotanti viññāṇam eva ubhayatas bhāgehi acchinnam idha  loke patiṭṭhitam ca ati chanda rāga vasena imasmin ca loke patiṭṭhitam dutiya pade pi esā iva  nayo kammam vā kammataḥ upagacchantam idha loke patiṭṭhitam nāma kamma bhavam ākaḍḍhantam
translated: But he generates the path of once-returner by making that jhāna the basis for it. This is the second kind of “seeing” in the sense of penetration. But the Elder Sumana of Kāḷavalle said: “It extends as far as the path of the third jhāna.”

original: paraloke patiṭṭhitaṃ nāma. Iminā kiṃ kathitaṃ? Sekkhaputhujjanānaṃ cetopariyañāṇaṃ
analyzed: para loke patiṭṭhitam nāma iminā kim kathitam sekkha puthujjanānam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam
translated: “Consciousness stream”: consciousness itself. “Not cut off at both ends”: not cut off at both ends, that is, in both the past and the future. “Rooted in this world”: rooted in this world by means of will and lust. The same method of explanation applies to the second clause. Or alternatively, kamma that occurs in this world is called “rooted in this world,” and kamma that occurs in the next world is called “rooted in the next world.” What is meant?

original: kathitaṃ. Sekkhaputhujjanānañhi cetopariyañāṇaṃ tatiyā dassanasamāpatti nāma.
analyzed: kathitam sekkha puthujjanānam hi cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam tatiyā dassana samāpatti nāma
translated: The knowledge of penetration of another’s consciousness of those in training and ordinary men is called the third kind of “seeing” in the sense of penetration.

original: Idha loke appatiṭṭhitañcāti nicchandarāgattā idhaloke ca appatiṭṭhitaṃ. Dutiyapadepi
analyzed: idha loke appatiṭṭhitam ca ati nicchanda rāga ttā idha loke ca appatiṭṭhitam dutiya pade pi
translated: “Not rooted in this world”: not rooted in this world by means of will and lust. The same method of explanation applies to the second clause.

original: eseva nayo. Kammaṃ vā kammato na upagacchantaṃ idha loke appatiṭṭhitaṃ nāma. Kammabhavaṃ🔽anākaḍḍhantaṃ paraloke appatiṭṭhitaṃ nāma. Iminā kiṃ kathitaṃ? Khīṇāsavassa cetopariyañāṇaṃ
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ kammam vā kammataḥ na upagacchantam idha loke appatiṭṭhitam nāma kamma bhavam  an ākaḍḍhantam para loke appatiṭṭhitam nāma iminā kim kathitam khīṇāsavassa cetaḥ pariyañāṇam
translated: So too with the rest. Or again, kamma that does not reach from here to the next world is called “not established in this world.” Kamma-process becoming that does not drag along the next rebirth-linking is called “not established in the next world.” What is meant by this? The knowledge of the destruction of cankers

original: kathitaṃ. Khīṇāsavassa hi cetopariyañāṇaṃ catutthā dassanasamāpatti nāma.🔽Apica dvattiṃsākāre āraddhavipassanāpi paṭhamā dassanasamāpatti. Aṭṭhiārammaṇe āraddhavipassanā
analyzed: kathitam khīṇāsavassa hi cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam catutthā dassana samāpatti nāma  apica dvattiṃsa ākāre āraddha vipassanā api paṭhamā dassana samāpatti aṭṭhi ārammaṇe āraddha vipassanā
translated: So too with the rest. Or again, kamma that does not reach from here to the next world is called “not established in this world.” Kamma-process becoming that does not reach to the next world is called “not established in the next world.” What is stated by this? The knowledge of penetration of minds in one whose cankers are destroyed is stated. For the knowledge of penetration of minds in one whose cankers are destroyed is called the fourth supramundane jhāna.

original: dutiyā dassanasamāpatti. Sekkhaputhujjanānaṃ cetopariyañāṇaṃ khīṇāsavassa cetopariyañāṇanti
analyzed: dutiyā dassana samāpatti sekkha puthujjanānam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam khīṇāsavassa cetaḥ pariya ñāṇam ti
translated: Moreover, insight that has begun on the thirty-two aspects is the first supramundane jhāna. Insight that has begun on the skeleton is the second supramundane jhāna. The knowledge of penetration of minds in disciples in higher training and in ordinary people, and the knowledge of penetration of minds in one whose cankers are destroyed,

original: idaṃ padadvayaṃ niccalameva. Aparo nayo paṭhamajjhānaṃ paṭhamā dassanasamāpatti.🔽Dutiyajjhānaṃ dutiyā. Tatiyajjhānaṃ tatiyā. Catutthajjhānaṃ catutthā dassanasamāpatti.
analyzed: idam pada dvayam niccalam eva aparaḥ nayaḥ paṭhama jhānam paṭhamā dassana samāpatti  dutiya jhānam dutiyā tatiya jhānam tatiyā catuttha jhānam catutthā dassana samāpatti
translated: these two are unmoved. Another method: the first jhāna is the first supramundane jhāna.🔽The second jhāna is the second. The third jhāna is the third. The fourth jhāna is the fourth supramundane jhāna.

original: Tathā paṭhamamaggo paṭhamā dassanasamāpatti. Dutiyamaggo dutiyā. Tatiyamaggo tatiyā.
analyzed: tathā paṭhama maggo paṭhamā dassana samāpatti dutiya maggaḥ dutiyā tatiya maggo tatiyā
translated: So too, the first path is the first supramundane jhāna. The second path is the second. The third path is the third.

original: Catutthamaggo catutthā dassanasamāpattīti. Sesamettha purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha maggo catutthā dassana samāpatti iti sesam ettha purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: The fourth path is the fourth kind of fruition attainment. The rest here should be construed in the same way as before.

original: Puggalapaṇṇattidesanāvaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Ascertainment of Persons

original: 150. Puggalapaṇṇattīsūti lokavohāravasena “satto puggalo naro poso”ti evaṃ paññāpetabbāsu
analyzed: puggala paṇṇattīsu iti loka vohāra vasena sattaḥ puggalo naro poso ti evam paññāpetabbāsu
translated: In the case of the “Discourse on the Ascertainment of Persons,” the ascertainment of persons is to be done by the expression “a being, a person, a man, a human being” in the way customary in the world.

original: lokapaññattīsu. Buddhānañhi dve kathā sammutikathā, paramatthakathāti poṭṭhapādasutte vitthāritā.🔽Tattha puggalapaṇṇattīsūti ayaṃ sammutikathā. Idāni ye puggale paññapento puggalapaṇṇattīsu
analyzed: loka paññattīsu buddhānam hi dve kathā sammuti kathā paramattha kathā ati poṭṭhapāda sutte vitthāritā  tattha puggala paṇṇattīsu iti ayam sammuti kathā idāni ye puggale paññapentaḥ puggala paṇṇattīsu
translated: For the Buddhas have two kinds of talk, namely, talk on the conventional level and talk on the ultimate level, as given in detail in the Poṭṭhapāda Sutta .

original: bhagavā anuttaro hoti, te dassento sattime bhante puggalā. Ubhatobhāgavimuttotiādimāha.
analyzed: bhagavā anuttaraḥ hoti te dassento sattime bhante puggalāḥ ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti ādim āha
translated: Herein, the “Discourse on the Ascertainment of Persons” is talk on the conventional level. Now, in the ascertainment of persons, the Blessed One is unsurpassed in teaching the persons to be ascertained.
