original: Tattha ubhatobhāgavimuttoti dvīhi bhāgehi vimutto, arūpasamāpattiyā rūpakāyato vimutto,
analyzed: tattha ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti dvīhi bhāgehi vimuttaḥ arūpa samāpattiyāḥ rūpa kāyataḥ vimuttaḥ
translated: He is liberated by the material-form-sphere liberation from the material body,

original: maggena nāmakāyato. So catunnaṃ arūpasamāpattīnaṃ ekekato vuṭṭhāya saṅkhāre sammasitvā
analyzed: maggena nāmakāyato so catunnam arūpa samāpattīnam ekekataḥ vuṭṭhāya saṅkhāre sammasitvā
translated: and by the immaterial-form-sphere liberation from the mental body. Having emerged from each of the four immaterial-form attainments, he comprehends formations.

original: arahattappattānaṃ, catunnaṃ, nirodhā vuṭṭhāya arahattappattaanāgāmino ca vasena pañcavidho hoti.
analyzed: arahatta pattānam catunnam nirodhā vuṭṭhāya arahatta patta anāgāmino ca vasena pañcavidhaḥ hoti
translated: and the five kinds of non-returners who have reached Arahantship after emerging from the attainment of cessation.

original: Pāḷi panettha “katamo ca puggalo ubhatobhāgavimutto? Idhekacco puggalo aṭṭhavimokkhe
analyzed: pana ittha katamaḥ ca puggalo ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ idha ekacco puggalo aṭṭha vimokkhe
translated: But in the text the five kinds of both-ways-liberated are given as those who have attained the eight deliverances,

original: kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā hontī”ti evaṃ aṭṭhavimokkhalābhino🔽vasena āgatā. Paññāya vimuttoti paññāvimutto. So sukkhavipassako ca, catūhi jhānehi
analyzed: kāyena phusitvā viharati paññāya ca ssa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti iti evam aṭṭha vimokkha lābhino  vasena āgatā paññāya vimuttoti paññā vimutto so sukkha vipassako ca catūhi jhānehi
translated: and who have “seen with understanding and … exhausted the taints” .🔽The “understanding-liberated” is the bare-insight worker.

original: vuṭṭhāya arahattaṃ pattā cattāro cāti imesaṃ vasena pañcavidhova hoti.🔽Pāḷi panettha aṭṭhavimokkhapaṭikkhepavaseneva āgatā. Yathāha “na heva kho aṭṭha vimokkhe
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya arahattam pattā cattāro ca ati imesam vasena pañcavidhaḥ uva hoti  pana ittha aṭṭha vimokkha paṭikkhepa vasena iva āgatā yathā āha na ha iva kho aṭṭha vimokkhe
translated: And the four who have reached Arahantship after emerging from the four jhānas make five kinds.🔽But in the text they are given as those who have not attained the eight deliverances,

original: kāyena phusitvā viharati. Paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti. Ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: kāyena phusitvā viharati paññāya ca ssa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti ayam vuccati
translated: as it is said, “He has not attained the eight deliverances with his body, though his taints have been destroyed by his seeing with understanding. This person is called

original: puggalo paññāvimutto”ti.
analyzed: puggalo paññā vimutto ti
translated: understanding-liberated” .

original: Phuṭṭhantaṃ sacchi karotīti kāyasakkhi. So jhānaphassaṃ paṭhamaṃ phusati, pacchā🔽nirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ sacchikaroti, so sotāpattiphalaṭṭhaṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva arahattamaggaṭṭhā🔽chabbidho hotīti veditabbo. Tenevāha “idhekacco puggalo aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā🔽viharati, paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo kāyasakkhī”ti.
analyzed: phuṭṭhantam sacchi karoti iti kāyasakkhi so jhāna phassam paṭhamam phusati pacchā  nirodham nibbānam sacchikaroti saḥ sotāpatti phala ṭṭham ādim katvā yāva arahatta magga ṭṭhā  chabbidhaḥ hoti iti veditabbaḥ tena iva āha idha ekaccaḥ puggalo aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā  viharati paññāya cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti ayam vuccati puggalo kāya sakkhī ti
translated: He makes the truth his foot-print, thus he is a body-witness. He first touches the jhāna-touch, and afterwards🔽he realizes the cessation of Nibbāna. He should be understood as being of six kinds, beginning with the fruit of stream-entry and ending with the path of arahatship. Hence it is said, “Here someone contacts with the body and abides in the eight emancipations, and through his wisdom he sees as it really is this: ‘These are the emancipations that are peaceful and immaterial, transcending forms.’ For him, through being frequently practiced, the path comes to fulfilment in its culmination. He reaches the termination of all suffering. This is called a person who is a body-witness” .🔽🔽

original: Diṭṭhantaṃ pattoti diṭṭhippatto. Tatridaṃ saṅkhepalakkhaṇaṃ, dukkhā saṅkhārā sukho🔽nirodhoti ñātaṃ hoti diṭṭhaṃ viditaṃ sacchikataṃ passitaṃ paññāyāti diṭṭhippatto.🔽Vitthārato panesopi kāyasakkhi viya chabbidho hoti. Tenevāha – “idhekacco puggalo
analyzed: diṭṭhantam patto ti diṭṭhi ppatto tatra idam saṅkhepa lakkhaṇam dukkhā saṅkhārā sukho  nirodhaḥ iti ñātam hoti diṭṭham viditam sacchikatam passitam paññāyāti diṭṭhi ppatto  vitthārato pana esaḥ api kāya sakkhi viya chabbidhaḥ hoti tena iva āha idha ekaccaḥ puggalo
translated: He makes the truth his feet , thus he is a “feet-maker” . He first touches the jhāna-touch, and afterwards he realizes cessation, Nibbāna. He should be understood as of six kinds classed according to the path of stream-entry, and so on, up to the path of Arahantship. That is why it is said: “Here someone contacts with his body and abides in those deliverances that are peaceful and immaterial, transcending forms, and he sees no sign of form. With the complete surmounting of perceptions of matter, with the disappearance of perceptions of resistance, with non-attention to perceptions of diversity, ‘Space is infinite,’ he enters upon and abides in the base of infinite space. He contacts with his body and abides in this attainment, and he sees no sign of form. This is called a person who is a body-witness. He has realized the state of a body-witness by means of the six kinds of direct- knowledge. He has realized the state of a body-witness by means of the six kinds of direct-knowledge” . He has reached the seen by means of the seen , thus he is a “seen-maker” . Here is a brief description: he knows, sees, understands, realizes, and penetrates thus, “ Formations are suffering,

original: idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti…pe… ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti pe ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam
translated: cessation is bliss” , thus he is a “seen-maker” . But in detail he is of six kinds like the body-witness. That is why it is said: “Here someone understands as it actually is: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: pajānāti, tathāgatappaveditā cassa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhā honti vocaritā, paññāya
analyzed: pajānāti tathāgata ppaveditā ca assa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhāḥ honti vocaritā paññāya
translated: he knows it, and the teachings proclaimed by the Tathāgata are accepted by him after being pondered to a sufficient degree with wisdom,

original: cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo diṭṭhippatto”ti.
analyzed: cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti ayam vuccati puggalo diṭṭhi ppatto ti
translated: he understands as they really are, and the Tathagata’s rules of training are undertaken by him with understanding and reflection, and by his seeing and insight some of his taints are destroyed. This is called a person who has reached by view.

original: Saddhāya vimuttoti saddhāvimutto. Sopi vuttanayeneva chabbidho hoti. Tenevāha – “idhekacco🔽puggalo idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti,🔽ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ🔽pajānāti, tathāgatappaveditā cassa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhā honti vocaritā, paññāya
analyzed: saddhāya vimuttaḥ ti saddhā vimuttaḥ saḥ api vutta nayena iva chabbidhaḥ hoti tena iva āha idha ekacco  puggalaḥ idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti  ayam dukkha nirodhaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam  pajānāti tathāgata ppaveditā ca assa dhammā paññāya vodiṭṭhāḥ honti vocaritā paññāya
translated: “Freed by faith” : freed by faith. He too is of six kinds in the way already stated. Hence it is said:

original: cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇā honti no ca kho yathā diṭṭhippattassa. Ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: cassa disvā ekacce āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti no ca kho yathā diṭṭhi ppattassa ayam vuccati
translated: “Here someone understands as they really are the four noble truths, that is to say, he understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering,’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’ The Tathagata’s rules of training are undertaken by him with understanding and reflection, and by his seeing and insight some of his taints are destroyed, but not as much as in one who has reached by view. This is called a person freed by faith” .

original: puggalo saddhāvimutto”ti. Etesu hi saddhāvimuttassa pubbabhāgamaggakkhaṇe saddahantassa
analyzed: puggalo saddhā vimutto ti etesu hi saddhā vimuttassa pubbabhāga magga kkhaṇe saddahantassa
translated: For in the case of one freed by faith, at the time of the path in the prior stage, he has faith in the path, and he is called “freed by faith” because he is freed by the faith that is purified by seeing.

original: viya, okappentassa viya, adhimuccantassa viya ca kilesakkhayo hoti. Diṭṭhippattassa
analyzed: viya okappentassa viya adhimuccantassa viya ca kilesa khayaḥ hoti diṭṭhippattassa
translated: and when he is resolving, and when he is resolving with confidence, then there is exhaustion of cankers.

original: pubbabhāgamaggakkhaṇe kilesacchedakaṃ ñāṇaṃ adandhaṃ tikhiṇaṃ sūraṃ hutvā vahati.
analyzed: pubbabhāga magga kkhaṇe kilesa chedakam ñāṇam adandham tikhiṇam sūram hutvā vahati
translated: In the case of one who has reached by faith, the knowledge that cuts off the defilements proceeds in the path of stream-entry as blunt, dull, and slow.

original: Tasmā yathā nāma nātitikhiṇena asinā kadaliṃ chindantassa chinnaṭṭhānaṃ na maṭṭhaṃ🔽hoti, asi na sīghaṃ vahati, saddo suyyati, balavataro vāyāmo kātabbo hoti, evarūpā
analyzed: tasmai yathā nāma na ati tikhiṇena asinā kadalim chindantassa chinna ṭhānam na maṭṭham  hoti asi na sīgham vahati saddaḥ suyyati balavataraḥ vā āyāmaḥ kātabbaḥ hoti evarūpā
translated: Therefore, just as when one cuts a plantain with a blunt knife, the place cut is not smooth,🔽the knife does not proceed swiftly, a sound is not heard, and great effort is needed, so too, the development of the path in the case of one of unshaken wisdom is like this.

original: saddhāvimuttassa pubbabhāgamaggabhāvanā. Yathā pana atinisitena asinā kadaliṃ chindantassa🔽chinnaṭṭhānaṃ maṭṭhaṃ hoti, asi sīghaṃ vahati, saddo na suyyati, balavataraṃ vāyāmakiccaṃ
analyzed: saddhā vimuttassa pubbabhāga magga bhāvanā yathā pana ati nisitena asinā kadalim chindantassa  chinna ṭṭhānam maṭṭham hoti asi sīgham vahati saddaḥ na balavataram vāyāma kiccam
translated: But just as when one cuts a plantain with a sharp knife,

original: na hoti, evarūpā paññāvimuttassa pubbabhāgamaggabhāvanā veditabbā.
analyzed: na hoti evarūpā paññā vimuttassa pubbabhāga magga bhāvanā veditabbā
translated: the place cut is smooth, the knife proceeds swiftly, no sound is heard, and the function of great effort is not needed, so too, the development of the path in the case of one of unshaken wisdom should be understood as like this.

original: Dhammaṃ anussaratīti dhammānusārī. Dhammoti paññā, paññāpubbaṅgamaṃ maggaṃ bhāvetīti
analyzed: dhammaṃ anussarati iti dhamma anusārī dhammo ti paññā paññā pubbaṅgamam maggam bhāveti iti
translated: He recollects the Dhamma: thus he is a Dhamma-follower. The Dhamma is wisdom. He develops the path with wisdom as the forerunner.

original: attho. Saddhānusārimhipi eseva nayo, ubhopete sotāpattimaggaṭṭhāyeva. Vuttampi cetaṃ
analyzed: attho saddhā anusārimhi pi esa iva nayaḥ ubha upete sotāpatti magga ṭṭhāya iva vuttam pi
translated: and the meaning. The same method applies to the faith-follower. Both are only candidates for the fruit of stream-entry. And this is said:

original: “yassa puggalassa sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa paññindriyaṃ adhimattaṃ
analyzed: yassa puggalassa sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa paññindriyam adhimattam
translated: “When a person is practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry, if his wisdom faculty is outstanding,

original: hoti, paññāvāhiṃ paññāpubbaṅgamaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāveti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo dhammānusārī”ti.
analyzed: hoti paññā vāhim paññā pubbaṅgamam ariya maggam bhāveti ayam vuccati puggalo dhamma anusārī iti
translated: he develops the noble path with wisdom as his forerunner and with wisdom as his guide. This person is called a Dhamma-follower.”

original: Tathā “yassa puggalassa sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa saddhindriyaṃ adhimattaṃ
analyzed: tathā yassa puggalassa sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannassa saddhi indriyam adhimattam
translated: Similarly: “When a person is practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry, if his faith faculty is outstanding,

original: hoti, saddhāvāhiṃ saddhāpubbaṅgamaṃ ariyamaggaṃ bhāveti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo saddhānusārī”ti.🔽Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato panesā ubhatobhāgavimuttādikathā visuddhimagge paññābhāvanādhikāre
analyzed: hoti saddhā vāhim saddhā pubbaṅgamam ariya maggam bhāveti ayam vuccati puggalo saddhā anusārī iti  ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana isā ubhatobhāga vimutta ādi kathā visuddhi magge paññā bhāvanā adhikāre
translated: he develops the noble path with faith as his forerunner and with faith as his guide. This person is called a faith-follower.”

original: vuttā. Tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttā tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbā sesam idha api purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: This is the brief account. But the detailed account of the kinds of liberations, etc., is given in the Path of Purification in the chapter on the development of understanding. So it should be understood as set forth there. And the rest of this chapter should be understood in the way already described.

original: Padhānadesanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: padhāna desanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the heading “Development” is ended.

original: 151. Padhānesūti idha padahanavasena “satta bojjhaṅgā padhānā”ti vuttā. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā mahāsatipaṭṭhāne vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: padhānesu iti idha padahana vasena satta bojjhaṅgā padhānā ti vuttā tesam vitthāra kathā mahāsatipaṭṭhāne vutta nayena iva veditabbā sesam idha api purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: In the case of the kinds of striving, the seven enlightenment factors are called “striving” in the sense of striving in the development of them. The detailed explanation of them should be understood in the way given in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta. The rest here should be construed in the same way as before.

original: Paṭipadādesanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭipadā desanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the path

original: 152. Dukkhapaṭipadādīsu ayaṃ vitthāranayo – “tattha katamā dukkhapaṭipadā dandhābhiññā
analyzed: dukkha paṭipadā ādīsu ayam vitthāra nayaḥ tattha katamā dukkha paṭipadā dandha abhiññā
translated: In the case of the painful practice with slow intuition, etc., the method of explanation is this. “Herein, what is painful practice with slow intuition?

original: paññā? Dukkhena kasirena samādhiṃ uppādentassa dandhaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ abhijānantassa🔽yā paññā pajānanā…pe… amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi, ayaṃ vuccati dukkhapaṭipadā
analyzed: paññā dukkhena kasirena samādhim uppādentassa dandham tam ṭhānam abhijānantassa  yā paññā pajānanā pe amohaḥ dhamma vicayo sammādiṭṭhi ayam vuccati dukkha paṭipadā
translated: When one who finds concentration difficult and slow arouses concentration, and when he has slow understanding of that state,🔽the understanding, the act of understanding, the faculty and the power of understanding, the investigation-of-states enlightenment factor, the path factor of right view, and the understanding that is the root cause of profitable states—this is called painful practice with slow intuition.

original: dandhābhiññā paññā. Tattha katamā dukkhapaṭipadā khippābhiññā paññā? Dukkhena kasirena
analyzed: dandha abhiñā paññā tattha katamā dukkha paṭipadā khippa abhiññā paññā dukkhena kasirena
translated: Herein, what is painful practice with swift intuition?

original: samādhiṃ uppādentassa khippaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ abhijānantassa yā paññā pajānanā…pe… sammādiṭṭhi,
analyzed: samādhim uppādentassa khippam tam ṭhānam abhijānantassa yā paññā pajānanāpe sammādiṭṭhi
translated: When one who finds concentration difficult and slow arouses concentration, and when he has swift understanding of that state, the understanding, the act of understanding, the faculty and the power of understanding, the investigation-of-states enlightenment factor, the path factor of right view, and the understanding that is the root cause of profitable states—this is called painful practice with swift intuition.

original: ayaṃ vuccati dukkhapaṭipadā khippābhiññā paññā. Tattha katamā sukhapaṭipadā dandhābhiññā
analyzed: ayam vuccati dukkha paṭipadā khippa abhiññā paññā tattha katamā sukha paṭipadā dandha abhiññā
translated: Herein, what is the kind of understanding called “the pleasant way with sluggish acquaintance”?

original: paññā? Akicchena akasirena samādhiṃ uppādentassa dandhaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ abhijānantassa
analyzed: paññā akicchena a kasirena samādhim uppādentassa dandham tam ṭhānam abhijānantassa
translated: When one who has aroused concentration without difficulty, without trouble, has sluggish acquaintance with that state,

original: yā paññā pajānanā…pe… sammādiṭṭhi, ayaṃ vuccati sukhapaṭipadā dandhābhiññā paññā.
analyzed: yā paññā pajānanā āpe sammādiṭṭhi ayam vuccati sukha paṭipadā dandha abhiññā paññā
translated: the understanding that is his act of fathoming that, his act of fully understanding that, his act of penetrating that, his act of seeing that, his act of knowing that, his act of touching that, his act of realizing that—this is the kind of understanding called “the pleasant way with sluggish acquaintance”.🔽Herein, what is the kind of understanding called “the pleasant way with swift acquaintance”?

original: Tattha katamā sukhapaṭipadā khippābhiññā paññā? Akicchena akasirena samādhiṃ uppādentassa🔽khippaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ abhijānantassa yā paññā pajānanā…pe… sammādiṭṭhi, ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: tattha katamā sukha paṭipadā khippa abhiññā paññā akicchena akasirena samādhim uppādentassa  khippam tat ṭhānam abhijānantassa yā paññā pajānanā pe sammādiṭṭhi ayam vuccati
translated: When one who has aroused concentration without difficulty, without trouble, has swift acquaintance with that state,🔽the understanding that is his act of fathoming that, his act of fully understanding that, his act of penetrating that, his act of seeing that, his act of knowing that, his act of touching that, his act of realizing that—this is the kind of understanding called “the pleasant way with swift acquaintance”.

original: sukhapaṭipadā khippābhiññā paññā”ti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge
analyzed: sukha paṭipadā khippa abhiññā paññā ati ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge
translated: This is in brief. The detail is given in the Path of Purity .

original: vutto. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttaḥ sesam idha api purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: The rest here should be construed in the same way as before.

original: Bhassasamācārādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhassa samācāra ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of conduct in speech, etc.,

original: 153. Na ceva musāvādūpasañhitanti bhassasamācāre ṭhitopi kathāmaggaṃ anupacchinditvā
analyzed: na ca iva musāvāda upasañhitanti bhassa samācāre ṭhitaḥ api kathāmaggam an upacchinditvā
translated: is as follows. He is not one who pursues talk that is mixed with lies: he does not pursue talk that is mixed with lies, he does not pursue talk that is mixed with falsehood, he does not pursue talk that is mixed with what is not fact, he does not pursue talk that is mixed with what is not truth, he does not pursue talk that is mixed with what is not fact and truth,

original: kathentopi idhekacco bhikkhu na ceva musāvādūpasañhitaṃ bhāsati. Aṭṭha anariyavohāre
analyzed: kathentaḥ pi idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu na ca iva musāvāda upasañhitam bhāsati aṭṭha anariya vohāre
translated: When he speaks, he does not speak with words that are false,

original: vajjetvā aṭṭha ariyavohārayuttameva bhāsati. Na ca vebhūtiyanti bhassasamācāre ṭhitopi
analyzed: vajjetvā aṭṭha ariya vohāra yuttam eva bhāsati na ca vebhūtiyanti bhassa samācāre ṭhitaḥ api
translated: but he speaks with the eight kinds of noble speech, avoiding the eight kinds of ignoble speech. He does not speak with words that are divisive,

original: bhedakaravācaṃ na bhāsati. Na ca pesuṇiyanti tassāyevetaṃ vevacanaṃ. Vebhūtiyavācā
analyzed: bheda kara vācam na bhāsati na ca vevacanam vebhūtiya vācā
translated: but he does not speak with words that are divisive, which is a synonym for the same term.

original: hi piyabhāvassa suññakaraṇato “pesuṇiya”nti vuccati. Nāmamevassā etanti mahāsīvatthero
analyzed: hi piya bhāvassa suñña karaṇato pesuṇiyanti vuccati nāmam evassa etat ti mahāsīva thero
translated: For such speech is called “divisive” because it is empty of affection. The elder Mahā-Siva🔽said that this is just a name for it. He does not speak with words that are harsh,

original: avoca. Na ca sārambhajanti sārambhajā ca yā vācā, tañca na bhāsati. “Tvaṃ dussīlo”ti🔽vutte, “tvaṃ dussīlo tavācariyo dussīlo”ti vā, “tuyhaṃ āpattī”ti vutte, “ahaṃ piṇḍāya
analyzed: avoca na ca sārambha janti sārambha jā ca yā vācā tat ca na bhāsati tvam dussīlā iti  vutte tvam dussīlo tava ācariyaḥ dussīlaḥ ti vā tuyham āpatti iti vutte aham piṇḍāya
translated: but he does not speak with words that are harsh, such as “You are immoral”

original: caritvā pāṭaliputtaṃ gato”tiādinā nayena bahiddhā vikkhepakathāpavattaṃ vā karaṇuttariyavācaṃ
analyzed: caritvā pāṭaliputtam gataḥ ti ādinā nayena bahiddhā vikkhepa kathā pavattam vā karaṇa uttariya vācam
translated: or “Your teacher is immoral,” or “You have committed an offense,” or “I went to Pāṭaliputta on my alms round” and so on, which is a form of talk that is irrelevant and outside the topic.🔽He does not speak with words that are frivolous,

original: na bhāsati. Jayāpekkhoti jayapurekkhāro hutvā, yathā hatthako sakyaputto titthiyā
analyzed: na bhāsati jayāpekkho ti jayapura īkkhāraḥ hutvā yathā hatthako sakya putto titthiyā
translated: but he does not speak with words that are frivolous, such as the following: “The naked ascetics are well-off; they have no need to work; they go about begging for alms without shame; they are free from the stain of work.”

original: nāma dhammenapi adhammenapi jetabbāti saccālikaṃ yaṃkiñci bhāsati, evaṃ jayāpekkho
analyzed: nāma dhammena api adhammena api jetabbā ati sacca ālikam yaṃ kiñci bhāsati evam jaya apekkhaḥ
translated: He speaks with the desire to benefit, with the wish to benefit, with the hope of benefiting.🔽He speaks after reflection, not without reflection.🔽He speaks after investigation, not without investigation.🔽He speaks at the proper time, not at the wrong time.

original: jayapurekkhāro hutvā na bhāsatīti attho. Mantā mantā ca vācaṃ bhāsatīti ettha mantāti
analyzed: jayapura īkkhāraḥ hutvā na bhāsati iti atthaḥ mantā mantā ca vācam bhāsati iti ettha mantā ati
translated: He speaks what is true, not what is false.🔽He speaks what is connected with the goal of the holy life, not what is unconnected with it.🔽He speaks what is loving, not what is unloving.🔽He speaks what is beneficial, not what is unbeneficial.🔽He speaks what is connected with the Dhamma, not what is not connected with the Dhamma.

original: vuccati paññā, mantāya paññāya. Puna mantāti upaparikkhitvā. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, bhassasamācāre
analyzed: vuccati paññā mantāya paññāya puna mantā ati upaparikkhitvā idam vuttam hoti bhassa samācāre
translated: He speaks what is connected with the Vinaya, not what is not connected with the Vinaya.🔽He speaks what he has seen for himself, not what he has not seen.🔽He speaks what he has heard, not what he has not heard.🔽He speaks what he has sensed, not what he has not sensed.

original: ṭhito divasabhāgampi kathento paññāya upaparikkhitvā yuttakathameva kathetīti. Nidhānavatinti
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ divasa bhāgam pi kathento paññāya upaparikkhitvā yutta katham eva katheti iti
translated: He speaks what he has known, not what he has not known.

original: hadayepi nidahitabbayuttaṃ. Kālenāti yuttapattakālena.
analyzed: hadaye pi nidahitabba yuttam kālena ati yutta patta kālena
translated: He speaks what is timely, not what is untimely.🔽He speaks truth, not falsehood.🔽He speaks what is connected with the goal of the holy life, not what is unconnected with it.🔽He speaks what is loving, not what is unloving.🔽He speaks what is beneficial, not what is unbeneficial.🔽He speaks what is connected with the Dhamma, not what is not connected with the Dhamma.

original: Evaṃ bhāsitā hi vācā amusā ceva hoti apisuṇā ca apharusā ca asaṭhā ca asamphappalāpā
analyzed: evam bhāsitā hi vācā amusā ca iva hoti a pisuṇā ca a pharusā ca a saṭhā ca a samphappalāpā
translated: He speaks what is connected with the Vinaya, not what is not connected with the Vinaya.🔽He speaks what he has seen for himself, not what he has not seen.🔽He speaks what he has heard, not what he has not heard.🔽He speaks what he has sensed, not what he has not sensed.🔽He speaks what he has known, not what he has not known.

original: ca. Evarūpā ca ayaṃ vācā catusaccanissitātipi sikkhattayanissitātipi dasakathāvatthunissitātipi
analyzed: ca evarūpā ca ayam vācā catu sacca nissitā atipi sikkhattaya nissitā atipi dasa kathā vatthu nissitā atipi
translated: He speaks what is timely, not what is untimely.🔽He speaks truth, not falsehood.🔽He speaks what is connected with the goal of the holy life, not what is unconnected with it.🔽He speaks what is loving, not what is unloving.🔽He speaks what is beneficial, not what is unbeneficial.

original: terasadhutaṅganissitātipi sattattiṃsabodhipakkhiyadhammanissitātipi magganissitātipi
analyzed: terasa dhutaṅga nissitā atipi sattattiṃsa bodhi pakkhiya dhamma nissitā atipi magga nissitā atipi
translated: He speaks what is connected with the D

original: vuccati. Tenāha etadānuttariyaṃ, bhante, bhassasamācāreti taṃ purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati tena āha etat ānuttariyam bhante bhassa samācāra iti tam purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: is said. Hence he said: “This is the unsurpassed teaching of bodily conduct,” which should be construed in the same way as above.

original: Sacco cassa saddho cāti sīlācāre ṭhito bhikkhu sacco ca bhaveyya saccakatho saddho
analyzed: saccaḥ cassa saddhaḥ ca ati sīla ācāre ṭhitaḥ bhikkhu saccaḥ ca bhaveyya sacca kathaḥ saddho
translated: He is truthful and has faith: a bhikkhu who is established in bodily conduct should be truthful and have faith, that is, be endowed with faith.

original: ca saddhāsampanno. Nanu heṭṭhā saccaṃ kathitameva, idha kasmā puna vuttanti? Heṭṭhā
analyzed: ca saddhā sampannaḥ nanu heṭṭhā saccam kathitam eva idha kasmā puna vuttan ti heṭṭhā
translated: But was not truthfulness already mentioned above? Why is it mentioned again here?🔽The truthfulness of speech was mentioned above.

original: vācāsaccaṃ kathitaṃ. Sīlācāre ṭhito pana bhikkhu antamaso hasanakathāyapi musāvādaṃ
analyzed: vācāsaccam kathitam sīla ācāre ṭhitaḥ pana bhikkhu antamasaḥ musāvādam
translated: But a bhikkhu who is established in bodily conduct does not tell a lie even in jest.

original: na karotīti dassetuṃ idha vuttaṃ. Idāni so dhammena samena jīvitaṃ kappetīti dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: na karoti iti dassetum idha vuttam idāni so dhammena samena jīvitam kappeti iti dassana attham
translated: In order to show this, it is mentioned here. Now, in order to show that he makes his living righteously,

original: na ca kuhakotiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha “kuhako”tiādīni brahmajāle vitthāritāni.
analyzed: na ca kuhaka iti ādi vuttam tattha kuhaka iti ādīni brahmajāle vitthāritāni
translated: “He is not a cheat” and so on is said. Here “cheat” and so on are explained in the Brahmajala Sutta .

original: Indriyesu guttadvāro, bhojane mattaññūti chasu indriyesu guttadvāro bhojanepi pamāṇaññū.
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ bhojane mattaññū ti chasu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ bhojane pi pamāṇaññū
translated: He is one who guards the doors of his sense faculties and is moderate in eating: he is one who guards the doors of his six sense faculties and is moderate in his consumption of food.

original: Samakārīti samacārī, kāyena vācāya manasā ca kāyavaṅkādīni pahāya samaṃ caratīti
analyzed: sama kārī iti sama cārī kāyena vācāya manasā ca kāya vaṅka ādīni pahāya samam carati iti
translated: He is one who acts equally: he is one who acts equally, that is, he acts equally by abandoning bodily crookedness, etc., with his body, speech, and mind.

original: attho. Jāgariyānuyogamanuyuttoti rattindivaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā “divasaṃ caṅkamena🔽nisajjāyā”ti vuttanayeneva jāgariyānuyogaṃ yuttappayutto viharati. Atanditoti nittandī🔽kāyālasiyavirahito. Āraddhavīriyoti kāyikavīriyenāpi āraddhavīriyo hoti, gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ
analyzed: attho jāgariya anuyogam anuyutto ti rattindivam cha koṭṭhāse katvā divasam caṅkamena  nisajjāya āti vutta nayena iva jāgariya anuyogam yutta ppayuttaḥ viharati atanditaḥ iti nittandī  kāya alasiya virahitaḥ āraddha vīriyaḥ ti kāyika vīriyena api āraddha vīriyaḥ hoti gaṇa saṅgaṇikam
translated: Meaning. He is devoted to the practice of being watchful: he is devoted to the practice of being watchful by dividing the day and night into six periods and conducting himself in accordance with the method stated thus: “By day, while walking and sitting” . He is not lazy: he is not indolent,🔽he is free from bodily sloth. He is energetic: he is energetic also by bodily energy, not only by mental energy. He is resolute: he is resolute in the sense of being firm in the undertaking of the practice of being watchful.

original: vinodetvā catūsu iriyāpathesu aṭṭhaārabbhavatthuvasena ekavihārī. Cetasikavīriyenāpi🔽āraddhavīriyo hoti, kilesasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya vinodetvā aṭṭhasamāpattivasena ekavihārī.🔽Api ca yathā tathā kilesuppattiṃ nivārento cetasikavīriyena āraddhavīriyo hoti. Jhāyīti
analyzed: vinodetvā catūsu iriyāpathesu aṭṭha ārabbha vatthu vasena eka vihārī cetasika vīriyena api  āraddha vīriyaḥ hoti kilesa saṅgaṇikam pahāya vinodetvā aṭṭha samāpatti vasena ekavihārī  api ca yathā tathā kilesa uppattim nivārento cetasika vīriyena āraddha vīriyaḥ hoti jhāyī iti
translated: The meaning is: he is devoted to the practice of wakefulness. He is devoted to the practice of wakefulness by dividing the day and night into six periods and by practicing wakefulness in the way described thus: “By day he walks and sits, and he cleanses his mind of obstructive states” . He is not lazy. He is not indolent. He is free from bodily sloth. He has aroused energy. He has aroused energy by bodily energy too. He lives alone, having removed the society of the multitude, by means of the eight and ten things beginning with the postures. He has aroused energy by mental energy too. He lives alone by means of the eight attainments.

original: ārammaṇalakkhaṇūpanijjhānavasena jhāyī. Satimāti cirakatādianussaraṇasamatthāya satiyā samannāgato.
analyzed: ārammaṇa lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna vasena jhāyī satimā ati cirakata ādi anussaraṇa samatthāya satiyā samannāgataḥ
translated: Moreover, he has aroused energy by mental energy by warding off the arising of defilements in whatever way they arise. He is a meditator. He is a meditator by means of the meditation subject and the characteristics . He is possessed of mindfulness. He is possessed of mindfulness that is capable of recalling what was done long ago and so on.

original: Kalyāṇapaṭibhānoti vākkaraṇasampanno ceva hoti paṭibhānasampanno ca. Yuttapaṭibhāno
analyzed: kalyāṇa paṭibhāno ti vāc karaṇa sampanno ca iva hoti paṭibhāna sampanno ca yutta paṭibhāno
translated: He is of good delivery: he is endowed with both a good voice and a good delivery. He is of apt delivery:

original: kho pana hoti no muttapaṭibhāno. Sīlasamācārasmiñhi ṭhitabhikkhu muttapaṭibhāno na
analyzed: kho pana hoti no mutta paṭibhānaḥ sīla samācārasmin hi ṭhita bhikkhu mutta paṭibhānaḥ na
translated: he is not of prompt delivery. For a bhikkhu who is established in virtue and conduct is not of prompt delivery,🔽but he is of apt delivery, like the Elder Vangīsa.

original: hoti, yuttapaṭibhāno pana hoti vaṅgīsatthero viya. Gatimāti gamanasamatthāya paññāya
analyzed: hoti yutta paṭibhāno pana hoti vaṅgīsa theraḥ viya gatimā ati gamana samatthāya paññāya
translated: He is of ready speech: he is endowed with the understanding that is capable of going.🔽He is of retentive speech: he is endowed with the understanding that is capable of retaining.

original: samannāgato. Dhitimāti dhāraṇasamatthāya paññāya samannāgato. Matimāti ettha pana
analyzed: samannāgataḥ dhitimā ati dhāraṇa samatthāya paññāya samannāgataḥ matimā ati ettha pana
translated: He is of wise speech: here the word “wise” is a synonym for understanding,

original: matīti paññāya nāmameva, tasmā paññavāti attho. Iti tīhipi imehi padehi paññāva kathitā.
analyzed: matī iti paññāya nāmam eva tasmā paññavā ati attho iti tīhi pi imehi padehi paññā ava kathitā
translated: so the meaning is, “he is endowed with understanding.” Thus understanding is spoken of by means of these three terms.

original: Tattha heṭṭhā samaṇadhammakaraṇavīriyaṃ kathitaṃ, idha buddhavacanagaṇhanavīriyaṃ.🔽Tathā heṭṭhā vipassanāpaññā kathitā, idha buddhavacanagaṇhanapaññā. Na ca kāmesu
analyzed: tattha heṭṭhā samaṇa dhamma karaṇa vīriyam kathitam idha buddha vacana gaṇhana vīriyam  tathā heṭṭhā vipassanā paññā kathitā idha buddha vacana gaṇhana paññā na ca kāmesu
translated: Herein, the energy for doing the ascetic’s duties is spoken of below , and here the energy for receiving the Buddha’s word is spoken of.🔽And likewise insight is spoken of below , and here the understanding for receiving the Buddha’s word is spoken of.

original: giddhoti vatthukāmakilesakāmesu agiddho. Sato ca nipako cāti abhikkantapaṭikkantādīsu
analyzed: giddho ti vatthu kāma kilesa kāmesu agiddho sato ca nipako ca ati abhikkanta paṭikkanta ādīsu
translated: He is not greedy for sensual desires: he is not greedy for sensual desires as objects and for the defilements of sensual desire.🔽He is mindful and fully aware: in going forward and returning,

original: sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ceva ñāṇena ca samannāgato caratīti attho. Nepakkanti paññā,🔽tāya samannāgatattā nipakoti vutto. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ca iva ñāṇena ca samannāgato carati iti attho nepakkam ti paññā  tāya samannāgata ttā nipakaḥ ti vutto sesam idha api purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: He is possessed of mindfulness and full awareness in these seven instances: this is the meaning. He is skilled in the ways of an outlet: he is skilled in the way of outlet, that is to say, in the way of dispassion, in the way of fading away, in the way of cessation, in the way of relinquishment.

original: Anusāsanavidhādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: anusāsana vidha ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: He is skilled in meaning, skilled in Dhamma, skilled in the phrasing of expressions, skilled in sequence, and he is possessed of a good friend, of easy application, of quick understanding, of ripe intelligence.🔽He is one who asks for requisites that are proper, not for what is improper, not for what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.

original: 154. Paccattaṃ yoniso manasikārāti attano upāyamanasikārena. Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā
analyzed: paccattam yonisas manasikārā ti attanaḥ upāya manasikārena yathā anusiṭṭham tathā
translated: He is one who is content with the requisites of life that are in conformity with the True Idea, not with those that are contrary to it.🔽He is one who is not a hoarder, not a niggard, not a user of stored-up requisites, not one who uses them up, not one who is a miser with requisites.

original: paṭipajjamānoti yathā mayā anusiṭṭhaṃ anusāsanī dinnā, tathā paṭipajjamāno. Tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭipajjamānaḥ ti yathā mayā anusiṭṭham anusāsanī dinnā tathā paṭipajjamānaḥ tiṇṇam
translated: He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.🔽He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.🔽He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.🔽He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.🔽He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.

original: saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayātiādi vuttatthameva. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṃyojanānam parikkhaya ātiādi vutta ttham eva sesam idha api purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.🔽He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.🔽He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.

original: 155. Parapuggalavimuttiñāṇeti sotāpannādīnaṃ parapuggalānaṃ tena tena maggena kilesavimuttiñāṇe. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: para puggala vimutti ñāṇa iti sotāpanna ādīnam para puggalānam tena tena maggena kilesa vimutti ñāṇe sesam idha api purima nayena iva yojetabbam
translated: He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to the True Idea and Discipline.

original: 156. Amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmoti eko pubbenivāsaṃ anussaranto nāmagottaṃ pariyādiyamāno
analyzed: amutra asim evaṃnāmaḥ ti ekaḥ pubbenivāsam anussarantaḥ nāma gottam pariyādiyamāno
translated: He is one who is not a doer of what is improper, not a doer of what is contrary to

original: gacchati. Eko suddhakhandheyeva anussarati, eko hi sakkoti, eko na sakkoti. Tattha
analyzed: gacchati ekaḥ suddha khandheya iva anussarati ekaḥ hi sakkoti ekaḥ na sakkoti tattha
translated: One goes back to the time of the pure mind-body only, while the other remembers back to the time of the formation of the mind-body. Herein,

original: yo sakkoti, tassa vasena aggahetvā asakkontassa vasena gahitaṃ. Asakkonto pana kiṃ
analyzed: yaḥ sakkoti tassa vasena aggahetvā asakkontassa vasena gahitam asakkontaḥ pana kim
translated: the one who can remember back to the time of the pure mind-body is the one to be taken as the authority, not the other. But what does the other do?

original: karoti? Suddhakhandheyeva anussaranto gantvā anekajātisatasahassamatthake ṭhatvā
analyzed: karoti anussarantaḥ gantvā aneka jāti sata sahassa matthake ṭhatvā
translated: He goes back to the time of the pure mind-body, and then he stands at the end of the many hundreds of thousands of past lives and descends,

original: nāmagottaṃ pariyādiyamāno otarati. Taṃ dassento evaṃnāmotiādimāha. So evamāhāti so
analyzed: nāma gottam pariyādiyamānaḥ otarati tam dassento evaṃnāmā iti ādim āha saḥ evam āha ati so
translated: as it were, to the present by discovering the name and clan of the past existences. Showing this, the commentator says, “So-and-so by name” , etc.

original: diṭṭhigatiko evamāha. Tattha kiñcāpi sassatoti vatvā “te ca sattā saṃsarantī”ti vadantassa🔽vacanaṃ pubbāparaviruddhaṃ hoti. Diṭṭhigatikattā panesa etaṃ na sallakkhesi. Diṭṭhigatikassa
analyzed: diṭṭhigatikaḥ evam āha tattha kiñcā api sassatī ti vatvā te ca sattā saṃsaranti iti vadantassa  vacanam pubba apara viruddham hoti diṭṭhigatika ttā pana esa etam na sallakkhesi diṭṭhigatikassa
translated: He says thus: the one who has fallen into views says thus. Herein, although the statement “They are eternal” is contradicted by the statement “These beings wander on,”

original: hi ṭhānaṃ vā niyamo vā natthi. Imaṃ gahetvā imaṃ vissajjeti, imaṃ vissajjetvā imaṃ
analyzed: hi ṭhānam vā niyamaḥ vā na atthi imam gahetvā imam vissajjeti imam vissajjetvā imam
translated: nevertheless the theorist does not notice this because for a theorist there is no such thing as a position or a rule. He takes up one statement and lets go another,

original: gaṇhātīti brahmajāle vitthāritamevetaṃ. Ayaṃ tatiyo sassatavādoti thero lābhisseva
analyzed: gaṇhāti iti brahmajāle vitthāritam eva etam ayam tatiyaḥ sassata vādaḥ ti theraḥ lābhissa iva
translated: and he lets go one statement and takes up another. This is explained in detail in the Brahmajala Sutta . This is the third eternalist doctrine.

original: vasena tayo sassatavāde āha. Bhagavatā pana takkīvādampi gahetvā brahmajāle cattāro
analyzed: vasena tayo sassata vāde āha bhagavatā pana takkīvādam pi gahetvā brahmajāle cattāro
translated: and he spoke of the three eternalists in this way. But the Blessed One, taking the theorists as well, spoke of four in the Brahmajāla:

original: vuttā. Etesaṃ pana tiṇṇaṃ vādānaṃ vitthārakathā brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: vuttāḥ etesam pana tiṇṇam vādānam vitthāra kathā brahmajāle vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: He spoke of the three eternalists in this way. But in the Brahmajāla Sutta the Exalted One spoke of four eternalists, including the theorist who reasons from his own experience. The detailed explanation of these three theories should be understood in the way given in the Brahmajāla commentary.

original: Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva vitthāretabbaṃ.🔽157. Gaṇanāya vāti piṇḍagaṇanāya. Saṅkhānenāti acchiddakavasena manogaṇanāya. Ubhayathāpi🔽piṇḍagaṇanameva dasseti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, vassānaṃ satavasena sahassavasena satasahassavasena
analyzed: sesam idha api purima nayena iva vitthāretabbam  gaṇanāya vā ati piṇḍa gaṇanāya saṅkhānena ati acchiddaka vasena manaḥ gaṇanāya ubhayathā api  piṇḍa gaṇanam eva dasseti idam vuttam hoti vassānam sata vasena sahassa vasena sata sahassa vasena
translated: The rest of the sutta should be explained here in the same way as above.

original: koṭivasena piṇḍaṃ katvāpi ettakāni vassasatānīti vā ettakā vassakoṭiyoti vā evaṃ🔽saṅkhātuṃ na sakkā. Tumhe pana attano dasannaṃ pāramīnaṃ pūritattā sabbaññutaññāṇassa
analyzed: koṭi vasena piṇḍam katvā api ettakāni vassa satāni iti vā ettakāḥ vassa koṭiyaḥ iti vā evam  saṅkhātum na sakkā tumhe pana attanaḥ dasannam pāramīnam pūrita ttā sabbaññuta ññāṇassa
translated: “By counting”: by counting the groups of years. “By reckoning”: by reckoning the years in the mind without interruption. In both cases he shows counting by groups. The meaning is: it is not possible to count these years by making groups of a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, or a koṭi, saying, “So many are the years, so many are the hundreds of years, so many the thousands of years, so many the hundreds of thousands of years, so many the koṭis of years.”

original: suppaṭividdhattā yasmā vo anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ sūraṃ vahati. Tasmā desanāñāṇakusalataṃ
analyzed: suppaṭividdha ttā yasmai vaḥ anāvaraṇa ñāṇam sūram vahati tasmai desanā ñāṇa kusala tam
translated: But you, by fulfilling the ten perfections and by penetrating the knowledge of omniscience, have attained unobstructed knowledge, which is like a powerful light. Therefore, because of your skill in teaching,

original: purakkhatvā vassagaṇanāyapi pariyantikaṃ katvā kappagaṇanāyapi paricchinditvā ettakanti
analyzed: purakkhatvā vassa gaṇanāya api pariyantikam katvā kappa gaṇanāya api paricchinditvā ettakanti
translated: and having defined it by the number of years, he defines it by the number of world-cycles, saying, “It is this much.”

original: dassethāti dīpeti. Pāḷiyattho panettha vuttanayoyeva. Sesamidhāpi purimanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.

translated: “Bhante, this knowledge of the passing away and rebirth of beings is unsurpassed. Bhante, this teaching of knowledge regarding the passing away and rebirth of beings is unsurpassed. It is the same with the Buddhas of the past,

analyzed: desayittha iminā api kāraṇena evaṃpasannaḥ aham bhante bhagavati iti dīpeti pāḷiyatthaḥ
translated: it will be the same with the Buddhas of the future. You, Bhante, have taught it by connecting it with the knowledge of the Buddhas of the past and the future. original: panettha vitthāritoyeva.
analyzed: pana itthā

translated: This is the unsurpassed teaching in regard to the

analyzed: mahā purisena an uppattam tam bhagavatā ati tat sabbam atīta anāgata buddhehi pattabbam

analyzed: ettha āṇā vattati visaya khettassa pana parimāṇam natthi buddhānam hi yāvatakam
translated: and at the time of his final Nibbana, this world-system shakes. The field of command is a world-system consisting of a thousand million worlds. For the Buddha’s command extends to this extent. But the field of influence has no limit, for the knowledge of the Buddhas extends as far as their influence extends.🔽“As far as his knowledge extends, so far extends his influence;

original: ñāṇaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ, yāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ tāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ, ñāṇapariyantikaṃ ñeyyaṃ,
analyzed: ñāṇam tāvatakam ñeyyam yāvatakam ñeyyam tāvatakam ñāṇam ñāṇa pariyantikam ñeyyam
translated: as far as his influence extends, so far extends his knowledge. His knowledge and his influence are co-extensive.”

original: ñeyyapariyantikaṃ ñāṇa”nti vacanato avisayo nāma natthi.🔽Imesu pana tīsu khettesu ṭhapetvā imaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ aññasmiṃ cakkavāḷe buddhā uppajjantīti
analyzed: ñeyya pariyantikam ñāṇan ti vacanataḥ avisayaḥ nāma natthi  imesu pana tīsu khettesu ṭhapetvā imam cakkavāḷam aññasmin cakkavāḷe buddhāḥ uppajjanti iti
translated: But there is no such thing as a non-object.🔽But as to these three fields, there is no sutta to the effect that Buddhas arise in a world-sphere other than this one, though there is a sutta to the effect that they do not arise there.

original: suttaṃ natthi, nuppañjantīti pana atthi. Tīṇi piṭakāni vinayapiṭakaṃ, suttantapiṭakaṃ
analyzed: suttam natthi nuppañjanti iti pana atthi tīṇi piṭakāni vinaya piṭakam suttanta piṭakam
translated: The three Piṭakas are the Vinaya Piṭaka, the Suttanta Piṭaka,

original: abhidhammapiṭakaṃ. Tisso saṅgītiyo mahākassapattherassa saṅgīti, yasattherassa saṅgīti,🔽moggaliputtatissattherassa saṅgītīti. Imā tisso saṅgītiyo āruḷhe tepiṭake buddhavacane
analyzed: abhidhammapiṭakam tissaḥ saṅgītiyaḥ mahākassapa therassa saṅgīti yasa therassa saṅgīti  moggaliputta tissa therassa saṅgītī iti imāḥ tissaḥ saṅgītiyaḥ āruḷhe tepiṭake buddha vacane
translated: and the Abhidhamma Piṭaka. The three Recitals are the recital by the Elder Mahā Kassapa, the recital by the Elder Yasa,

original: “imaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ muñcitvā aññattha buddhā uppajjantī”ti suttaṃ natthi, nuppajjantīti pana atthi.
analyzed: imam cakkavāḷam muñcitvā aññattha buddhāḥ uppajjanti iti suttam natthi na uppajjanti iti pana atthi
translated: and the recital by the Elder Tissa, Moggaliputta’s son. As to these three Recitals, there is no sutta to the effect that Buddhas arise outside this world-sphere, though there is a sutta to the effect that they do not arise there.

original: Apubbaṃ acarimanti apure apacchā ekato nuppajjanti, pure vā pacchā vā uppajjantīti
analyzed: a pubbam a carimanti a pure apacchā ekatas nu uppajjanti pure vā pacchā vā uppajjanti iti
translated: They did not arise simultaneously: they did not arise together, one before and one after.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha bodhipallaṅke “bodhiṃ apatvā na uṭṭhahissāmī”ti nisinnakālato
analyzed: vuttam hoti tattha bodhipallaṅke bodhim a patvā na uṭṭhahissāmi iti nisinna kālataḥ
translated: They arose either before or after. Herein, from the time when he sat down determined on enlightenment in the Enlightenment-tree’s shade, saying “I will not rise up without reaching enlightenment,”

original: paṭṭhāya yāva mātukucchismiṃ paṭisandhiggahaṇaṃ, tāva pubbeti na veditabbaṃ. Bodhisattassa
analyzed: paṭṭhāya yāva mātukucchismim paṭisandhi ggahaṇam tāva pubbā iti na veditabbam bodhisattassa
translated: and from the time of his descent from the Tusita heaven until the conception in the womb, it should not be understood as past.

original: hi paṭisandhiggahaṇe dasasahassacakkavāḷakampaneneva khettapariggaho kato. Aññassa🔽buddhassa uppattipi nivāritā hoti. Parinibbānato paṭṭhāya ca yāva sāsapamattāpi dhātuyo
analyzed: hi paṭisandhi ggahaṇe dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa kampanena iva khetta pariggaho kataḥ aññassa  buddhassa uppatti pi nivāritā hoti parinibbānato paṭṭhāya ca yāva sāsapa mattā api dhātuyo
translated: For when the Bodhisatta’s conception is taken, the field is appropriated by the quaking of the ten-thousand world-element.🔽And the appearance of another Buddha is prevented.🔽And from the time of the parinibbāna until the relics are no more than the size of a mung-bean, it should not be understood as future.

original: tiṭṭhanti, tāva pacchāti na veditabbaṃ. Dhātūsu hi ṭhitāsu buddhāpi ṭhitāva honti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti tāva pacchā ati na veditabbam dhātūsu hi ṭhitāsu buddhāḥ api ṭhitāḥ ava honti
translated: For as long as the relics last, so long do the Buddhas last.

original: Tasmā etthantare aññassa buddhassa uppatti nivāritāva hoti. Dhātuparinibbāne pana
analyzed: tasmai etthantare aññassa buddhassa uppatti nivāritā ava hoti dhātu parinibbāne pana
translated: So the appearance of another Buddha is prevented during that time. But when the relics have finally disappeared,

original: jāte aññassa buddhassa uppatti na nivāritā.
analyzed: jāte aññassa buddhassa uppatti na nivāritā
translated: the appearance of another Buddha is no longer prevented.

original: Tipiṭakaantaradhānakathā🔽Tīṇi antaradhānāni nāma pariyattiantaradhānaṃ, paṭivedhaantaradhānaṃ, paṭipattiantaradhānanti.
analyzed: tipiṭaka antaradhāna kathā  tīṇi antaradhānāni nāma pariyatti antaradhānam paṭivedha antaradhānam paṭipatti antaradhānanti
translated: The Disappearance of the Three Baskets🔽There are three kinds of disappearance called the disappearance of the tradition, the disappearance of the penetration, and the disappearance of the practice.

original: Tattha pariyattīti tīṇi piṭakāni. Paṭivedhoti saccappaṭivedho. Paṭipattīti paṭipadā.
analyzed: tattha pariyatti iti tīṇi piṭakāni paṭivedho ti saccappaṭivedho paṭipatti iti paṭipadā
translated: Herein, the “tradition” is the three Piṭakas. The “penetration” is the penetration of the truths. The “practice” is the way.

original: Tattha paṭivedho ca paṭipatti ca hotipi na hotipi. Ekasmiñhi kāle paṭivedhakarā bhikkhū
analyzed: tattha paṭivedho ca paṭipatti ca hoti pi na hoti pi ekasmin hi kāle paṭivedha karāḥ bhikkhū
translated: Herein, penetration and practice may or may not be. For at one time there are many bhikkhus who are penetrating,

original: bahū honti, esa bhikkhu puthujjanoti aṅguliṃ pasāretvā dassetabbo hoti. Imasmiṃyeva
analyzed: bahū honti esa bhikkhu puthujjanaḥ ti aṅgulim pasāretvā dassetabbo hoti imasmin yeva
translated: and this bhikkhu is a worldling, and he can be pointed out by extending the forefinger. In this very island

original: dīpe ekavāraṃ puthujjanabhikkhu nāma nāhosi. Paṭipattipūrakāpi kadāci bahū honti,
analyzed: dīpe eka vāram puthujjana bhikkhu nāma na ahosi paṭipatti pūrakā api kadāci bahū honti
translated: there was never a worldling bhikkhu. And those who fulfil the practice are sometimes many,

original: kadāci appā. Iti paṭivedho ca paṭipatti ca hotipi na hotipi. Sāsanaṭṭhitiyā pana
analyzed: kadāci iti paṭivedho ca paṭipatti ca hoti pi na hoti pi sāsana ṭṭhitiyā pana
translated: sometimes few. So penetration and practice may or may not be. But the scriptures are the measure for the duration of the Dispensation.

original: pariyatti pamāṇaṃ. Paṇḍito hi tepiṭakaṃ sutvā dvepi pūreti.
analyzed: pamāṇam paṇḍitaḥ hi tepiṭakam sutvā dve api pūreti
translated: For the wise man fulfils both by learning the three Piṭakas.

original: Yathā amhākaṃ bodhisatto āḷārassa santike pañcābhiññā satta ca samāpattiyo nibbattetvā🔽nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyā parikammaṃ pucchi, so na jānāmīti āha. Tato udakassa
analyzed: yathā amhākam bodhisattaḥ āḷārassa santike pañca abhiññā satta ca samāpattiyaḥ nibbattetvā  nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana samāpattiyā parikammam pucchi saḥ na jānāmi iti āha tatas udakassa
translated: For example, our Bodhisatta, after producing the five kinds of supernormal power and the seven kinds of concentration in Āḷāra’s presence,🔽asked about the preliminary work for the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception. Āḷāra said he did not know. Then he went to Uddaka and,

original: santikaṃ gantvā adhigatavisesaṃ saṃsanditvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanassa parikammaṃ
analyzed: santikam gantvā adhigata visesam saṃsanditvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanassa parikammam
translated: after discussing the special qualities he had acquired, asked about the preliminary work for the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: pucchi, so ācikkhi, tassa vacanasamanantarameva mahāsatto taṃ jhānaṃ sampādesi, evameva
analyzed: pucchi saḥ ācikkhi tassa vacana samanantaram eva mahāsatto tam jhānam sampādesi evam eva
translated: He asked the Elder, and the Elder explained it to him. As soon as he heard it, the Great Being reached Arahantship.

original: paññavā bhikkhu pariyattiṃ sutvā dvepi pūreti. Tasmā pariyattiyā ṭhitāya sāsanaṃ
analyzed: paññavā bhikkhu pariyattim sutvā dve api pūreti tasmai pariyattiyā ṭhitāya sāsanam
translated: So too, a wise bhikkhu, after learning the scriptures, fulfils both of these things. Therefore, when the scriptures are established, the Dispensation

original: ṭhitaṃ hoti. Yadā pana sā antaradhāyati, tadā paṭhamaṃ abhidhammapiṭakaṃ nassati.
analyzed: ṭhitam hoti yadā pana sā antaradhāyati tadā paṭhamam abhidhamma piṭakam nassati
translated: is established. But when they disappear, then first the Abhidhamma Piṭaka disappears.

original: Tattha paṭṭhānaṃ sabbapaṭhamaṃ antaradhāyati. Anukkamena pacchā dhammasaṅgaho, tasmiṃ
analyzed: tattha paṭṭhānam sabba paṭhamam antaradhāyati anukkamena pacchā dhamma saṅgaho tasmin
translated: Herein, the Paṭṭhāna is the first to disappear. Then gradually afterwards the Dhammasanganī disappears,

original: antarahite itaresu dvīsu piṭakesu ṭhitesupi sāsanaṃ ṭhitameva hoti.🔽Tattha suttantapiṭake antaradhāyamāne paṭhamaṃ aṅguttaranikāyo ekādasakato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: anta rahite itaresu dvīsu piṭakesu sāsanam ṭhitam eva hoti  tattha suttanta piṭake antaradhāyamāne paṭhamam aṅguttara nikāyo ekādasakataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: and when that has disappeared, the Dispensation is still established though the other two Piṭakas remain.🔽Herein, when the Sutta Piṭaka is disappearing, first the Anguttara Nikāya disappears beginning with the Elevens

original: yāva ekakā antaradhāyati, tadanantaraṃ saṃyuttanikāyo cakkapeyyālato paṭṭhāya yāva
analyzed: yāva ekakā antaradhāyati tad anantaram saṃyutta nikāyo cakkapeyyālato paṭṭhāya yāva
translated: and ending with the Ones. Next the Saṃyutta Nikāya disappears beginning with the Cakka-peyyāla and ending with the

original: oghataraṇā antaradhāyati. Tadanantaraṃ majjhimanikāyo indriyabhāvanato paṭṭhāya yāva
analyzed: ogha taraṇā antaradhāyati tad anantaram majjhima nikāyaḥ indriya bhāvanataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva
translated: Ogha-peyyāla. Next the Majjhima Nikāya disappears beginning with the Indriyabhāvanā and ending with the

original: mūlapariyāyā antaradhāyati. Tadanantaraṃ dīghanikāyo dasuttarato paṭṭhāya yāva brahmajālā
analyzed: mūla pariyāyāḥ tad anantaram dīgha nikāyaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva brahmajālā
translated: The root text disappears. Next the Dīgha Nikāya disappears, starting from the Dasuttara Sutta and ending with the Brahmajāla Sutta.

original: antaradhāyati. Ekissāpi dvinnampi gāthānaṃ pucchā addhānaṃ gacchati, sāsanaṃ dhāretuṃ
analyzed: antaradhāyati ekissā api dvinnam pi gāthānam pucchā addhānam gacchati sāsanam dhāretum
translated: If even one verse of these two is asked about, the Dispensation is gone, and it can no longer be upheld, like the questions of Sabhiya and Āḷavaka.

original: na sakkoti, sabhiyapucchā āḷavakapucchā viya ca. Etā kira kassapabuddhakālikā antarā🔽sāsanaṃ dhāretuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu.🔽Dvīsu pana piṭakesu antarahitesupi vinayapiṭake ṭhite sāsanaṃ tiṭṭhati. Parivārakkhandhakesu
analyzed: na sakkoti sabhiya pucchā āḷavaka pucchā viya ca etā kira kassapa buddha kālikā antarā  sāsanam dhāretum na asakkhiṃsu  dvīsu pana piṭakesu antara hitesu pi vinaya piṭake ṭhite sāsanam tiṭṭhati parivāra kkhandhakesu
translated: It seems that these two were unable to uphold the Dispensation during the interval between the Buddha Kassapa and the Buddha Gotama.🔽But even when two of the three Piṭakas have disappeared, the Dispensation remains as long as the Vinaya Piṭaka remains.🔽When the Parivāra and the Khandhaka are disappeared, the Dispensation remains as long as the two Vibhaṅgas remain.

original: antarahitesu ubhatovibhaṅge ṭhite ṭhitameva hoti. Ubhatovibhaṅge antarahite mātikāyapi
analyzed: anta rahitesu ubhatas vibhaṅge ṭhite ṭhitam eva ubhatas vibhaṅge anta rahite
translated: When the two Vibhaṅgas have disappeared, the Dispensation remains as long as the Mātikā remains.

original: ṭhitāya ṭhitameva hoti. Mātikāya antarahitāya pātimokkhapabbajjāupasampadāsu ṭhitāsu
analyzed: ṭhitāya ṭhitam eva hoti mātikāya antarahitāya pātimokkha pabbajjā upasampadāsu ṭhitāsu
translated: When the Mātikā has disappeared, the Dispensation remains as long as the Pāṭimokkha, the going forth, and the higher ordination remain.

original: sāsanaṃ tiṭṭhati. Liṅgaṃ addhānaṃ gacchati. Setavatthasamaṇavaṃso pana kassapabuddhakālato
analyzed: sāsanam tiṭṭhati liṅgam addhānam gacchati setavattha samaṇa vaṃso pana kassapa buddha kālato
translated: The sign is gone. The lineage of the white-clothed lay followers goes back to the time of the Buddha Kassapa.

original: paṭṭhāya sāsanaṃ dhāretuṃ nāsakkhi. Paṭisambhidāpattehi vassasahassaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Chaḷabhiññehi
analyzed: paṭṭhāya sāsanam dhāretum na asakkhi paṭisambhidā pattehi vassa sahassam aṭṭhāsi chaḷabhiññehi
translated: For a thousand years with those who had the six kinds of direct knowledge.

original: vassasahassaṃ. Tevijjehi vassasahassaṃ. Sukkhavipassakehi vassasahassaṃ. Pātimokkhehi🔽vassasahassaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Pacchimakassa pana saccappaṭivedhato pacchimakassa sīlabhedato
analyzed: vassa sahassam tevijjehi vassa sahassam sukkha vipassakehi vassa sahassam pātimokkhehi  vassa sahassam aṭṭhāsi pacchimakassa pana sacca ppaṭivedhataḥ pacchimakassa sīlabhedato
translated: For a thousand years with those who had the three knowledges. For a thousand years with those who were dry-insight workers. For a thousand years with those who had mastered the Pāṭimokkha.🔽After that, the Dispensation is said to have declined, beginning with the last person’s penetration of the truths and the last person’s breach of morality.

original: paṭṭhāya sāsanaṃ osakkitaṃ nāma hoti. Tato paṭṭhāya aññassa buddhassa uppatti na nivāritā.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya sāsanam osakkitam nāma hoti tatas paṭṭhāya aññassa buddhassa uppatti na nivāritā
translated: After that, the appearance of another Buddha is not prevented.

original: Sāsanaantarahitavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāsana antara hita vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Disappearance of the Dispensation

original: Tīṇi parinibbānāni nāma kilesaparinibbānaṃ khandhaparinibbānaṃ dhātuparinibbānanti.
analyzed: tīṇi parinibbānāni nāma kilesa parinibbānam khandha parinibbānam dhātu parinibbānanti
translated: There are three kinds of Final Nibbāna, namely, the Final Nibbāna of defilements, the Final Nibbāna of the aggregates, and the Final Nibbāna of the elements.

original: Tattha kilesaparinibbānaṃ bodhipallaṅke ahosi. Khandhaparinibbānaṃ kusinārāyaṃ. Dhātuparinibbānaṃ
analyzed: tattha kilesa parinibbānam bodhi pallaṅke ahosi khandha parinibbānam kusinārāyam dhātu parinibbānam
translated: Herein, the Final Nibbāna of defilements took place on the throne of enlightenment. The Final Nibbāna of the aggregates took place at Kusināra. The Final Nibbāna of the elements

original: anāgate bhavissati. Sāsanassa kira osakkanakāle imasmiṃ tambapaṇṇidīpe dhātuyo sannipatitvā
analyzed: anāgate bhavissati sāsanassa kira osakkana kāle imasmin tambapaṇṇidīpe dhātuyaḥ sannipatitvā
translated: will take place in the future. When the Dispensation is disappearing, it seems, the relics in this Island of Tambapaṇṇi will assemble

original: mahācetiyaṃ gamissanti. Mahācetiyato nāgadīpe rājāyatanacetiyaṃ. Tato mahābodhipallaṅkaṃ
analyzed: mahācetiyam gamissanti mahācetiyataḥ nāgadīpe rāja āyatana cetiyam tatas mahābodhipallaṅkam
translated: and will go to the Great Shrine. From the Great Shrine they will go to the Shrine of the King’s Residence on the Island of the Nāgas. From there they will go to the Great Bodhi Tree.

original: gamissanti. Nāgabhavanatopi devalokatopi brahmalokatopi dhātuyo mahābodhipallaṅkameva
analyzed: gamissanti nāga bhavanataḥ pi deva lokataḥ pi brahma lokataḥ pi dhātuyaḥ mahā bodhi pallaṅkam eva
translated: From the abode of the Nāgas, from the world of the gods, from the world of Brahmā, the relics will go to the Great Bodhi Tree.

original: gamissanti. Sāsapamattāpi dhātuyo na antarā nassissanti. Sabbadhātuyo mahābodhipallaṅke
analyzed: gamissanti sāsapa mattāḥ api dhātuyaḥ na antarā nassissanti sabba dhātuyaḥ mahā bodhi pallaṅke
translated: Not even a relic the size of a mustard seed will be lost on the way. All the relics will be gathered together at the Great Bodhi Tree,

original: rāsibhūtā suvaṇṇakkhandho viya ekagghanā hutvā chabbaṇṇarasmiyo vissajjessanti.
analyzed: rāsi bhūtā suvaṇṇa kkhandhaḥ viya ekagghanā hutvā chabbaṇṇa rasmiyaḥ vissajjessanti
translated: and like a heap of gold they will become one mass, and will emit a six-colored radiance.

original: Tā dasasahassilokadhātuṃ pharissanti, tato dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatā sannipatitvā
analyzed: tāḥ dasa sahassi lokadhātum pharissanti tatas dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa devatā sannipatitvā
translated: This radiance will extend to the ten thousand world systems, and the gods of the ten thousand world systems will assemble and say,

original: “ajja satthā parinibbāti, ajja sāsanaṃ osakkati, pacchimadassanaṃ dāni idaṃ amhāka”nti
analyzed: ajja satthā parinibbāti ajja sāsanam osakkati pacchima dassanam dāni idam amhākan ti
translated: “Today the Teacher will attain final Nibbāna. Today the Dispensation will decline. This is our last glimpse of him.”

original: dasabalassa parinibbutadivasato mahantataraṃ kāruññaṃ karissanti. Ṭhapetvā anāgāmikhīṇāsave
analyzed: dasabalassa parinibbuta divasataḥ mahantataram kāruññam karissanti ṭhapetvā anāgāmi khīṇāsave
translated: They will feel greater compassion on the day of the ten powers’ final Nibbāna than they will on the day of his birth, his renunciation, his enlightenment, or his setting in motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma.🔽Except for the non-returners and the perfected ones,

original: avasesā sakabhāvena sandhāretuṃ na sakkhissanti. Dhātūsu tejodhātu uṭṭhahitvā yāva
analyzed: avasesā saka bhāvena sandhāretum na sakkhissanti dhātūsu tejodhātu uṭṭhahitvā yāva
translated: no one will be able to bear the pain.

original: brahmalokā uggacchissati. Sāsapamattāyapi dhātuyā sati ekajālā bhavissati. Dhātūsu
analyzed: brahma lokā uggacchissati dhātuyā sati ekajālā bhavissati dhātūsu
translated: and it will rise up to the Brahma-world. As long as there is even a mustard seed’s quantity of the element of form left, there will be a single world-element.

original: pariyādānaṃ gatāsu upacchijjissati. Evaṃ mahantaṃ ānubhāvaṃ dassetvā dhātūsu antarahitāsu
analyzed: pariyādānam gatāsu upacchijjissati evam mahantam ānubhāvam dassetvā dhātūsu antarahitāsu
translated: When the elements have been exhausted, it will be destroyed. After showing such great power, when the elements have disappeared,

original: sāsanaṃ antarahitaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: sāsanam antarahitam nāma hoti
translated: the Dispensation is said to have disappeared.

original: Yāva na evaṃ antaradhāyati, tāva acarimaṃ nāma hoti. Evaṃ apubbaṃ acarimaṃ uppajjeyyuṃ,
analyzed: yāva na evam antaradhāyati tāva acarimam nāma hoti evam apubbam acarimam uppajjeyyuṃ
translated: As long as it does not disappear in this way, it is said to be not yet disappeared. It is impossible that it could arise again,

original: netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati. Kasmā pana apubbaṃ acarimaṃ nuppajjantīti? Anacchariyattā.
analyzed: na etam ṭhānam vijjati kasmā pana apubbam a carimam na uppajjanti iti an acchariya tā
translated: never having done so before. But why does it not arise again, never having done so before? Because it is not a marvel.

original: Buddhā hi acchariyamanussā. Yathāha – “ekapuggalo, bhikkhave, loke uppajjamāno uppajjati🔽acchariyamanusso. Katamo ekapuggalo? Tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho”ti. Yadi ca
analyzed: buddhāḥ hi acchariya manussāḥ yathā āha eka puggalaḥ bhikkhave loke uppajjamānaḥ uppajjati  acchariya manusso katamaḥ eka puggalaḥ tathāgataḥ araham sammāsambuddhaḥ iti yadi ca
translated: For Buddhas are marvellous men. As it is said: “Bhikkhus, one person only arises in the world,

original: jātā, evaṃ buddhāpi bhaveyyuṃ, tasmā nuppajjanti. Desanāya ca visesābhāvato. Yañhi🔽satipaṭṭhānādibhedaṃ dhammaṃ eko deseti. Aññena uppajjitvāpi sova desetabbo siyā,
analyzed: jātāḥ evam buddhāḥ api bhaveyyum tasmā na uppajjanti desanāya ca visesa abhāvataḥ yat hi  sati paṭṭhāna ādi bhedam dhammam ekaḥ deseti aññena uppajjitvā api saḥ uva desetabbaḥ siyā
translated: And so would the Buddhas be. That is why they do not appear. And because there would be no difference in the teaching. For if one were to teach the Dhamma classed as the Foundations of Mindfulness, etc.,🔽another might appear and teach the same. He would not be so remarkable.

original: tato anacchariyo siyā. Ekasmiṃ pana dhammaṃ desente desanāpi acchariyā hoti, vivādabhāvato🔽ca. Bahūsu hi buddhesu uppannesu bahūnaṃ ācariyānaṃ antevāsikā viya amhākaṃ buddho
analyzed: tatas an acchariyaḥ siyā ekasmin pana dhammam desente desanā api acchariyā hoti vivāda bhāvato  ca bahūsu hi buddhesu uppannesu bahūnam ācariyānam antevāsikāḥ viya amhākam buddhaḥ
translated: But when one teaches the Dhamma, the teaching is remarkable.

original: pāsādiko, amhākaṃ buddho madhurassaro lābhī puññavāti vivadeyyuṃ. Tasmāpi evaṃ nuppajjanti.

original: Api cetaṃ kāraṇaṃ milindaraññāpi puṭṭhena nāgasenattherena vitthāritameva. Vuttañhi tattha –

analyzed: bhante nāgasena bhāsitam pi ha itam bhagavatā aṭṭhānam etam bhikkhave anavakāsaḥ

original: ca tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhāpenti, anusāsamānā ca appamādappaṭipattiyaṃ anusāsanti. Yadi,
analyzed: ca tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhāpenti anusāsamānā ca appamāda paṭipattiyam anusāsanti yadi
translated: “But, revered Nāgasena, all the Tathāgatas teach the thirty-seven requisites of enlightenment, and when they speak they speak of the Four Noble Truths, and when they train they train in the three trainings, and when they instruct they instruct in the practice of heedfulness.

original: bhante nāgasena, sabbesampi tathāgatānaṃ ekā desanā ekā kathā ekasikkhā ekānusāsanī,
analyzed: bhante nāgasena sabbesam pi tathāgatānam ekā desanā ekā kathā eka sikkhā eka anusāsanī
