original: loke uppajjatīti. Sukathito, bhante nāgasena, pañho opammehi kāraṇehīti.
analyzed: loke uppajjati iti su kathitaḥ bhante nāgasena pañhaḥ opammehi kāraṇehi iti
translated: in the world.” “Revered Nāgasena, the question that you have so cleverly explained by means of these parables is well explained.”

original: Dhammassa cānudhammanti navavidhassa lokuttaradhammassa anudhammaṃ pubbabhāgappaṭipadaṃ. Sahadhammikoti sakāraṇo. Vādānuvādoti vādoyeva.
analyzed: dhammassa ca anudhammam ti navavidhassa lokuttara dhammassa anudhammam pubbabhāga paṭipadam sahadhammikaḥ iti sa kāraṇaḥ vādānuvādo ti
translated: The Dhamma and the way of the Dhamma: the ninefold supramundane Dhamma and the way of the Dhamma, the practice that is its forerunner. In accordance with the Dhamma: with a reason. A counter-argument: an argument that is a counter-argument.

original: Acchariyaabbhutavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Wonderful and Marvellous

original: 162. Āyasmā udāyīti tayo therā udāyī nāma – lāḷudāyī, kāḷudāyī, mahāudāyīti. Idha
analyzed: udāyī iti therā udāyī nāma  lāḷudāyī kāḷudāyī mahāudāyī iti
translated: The venerable Udāyī: there were three elders named Udāyī, namely, Lāḷudāyī, Kāḷudāyī, and Mahāudāyī. Here

original: mahāudāyī adhippeto. Tassa kira imaṃ suttaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā suṇantassa
analyzed: mahā udāyī adhippeto tassa kira imam suttaṃ āditaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā suṇantassa
translated: Mahāudāyī is intended. It seems that while he was listening to this sutta from beginning to end,

original: abbhantare pañcavaṇṇā pīti uppajjitvā pādapiṭṭhito sīsamatthakaṃ gacchati, sīsamatthakato
analyzed: abbhantare pañca vaṇṇā pīti uppajjitvā pāda piṭṭhitaḥ sīsa matthakam gacchati sīsa matthakato
translated: a rapture of five kinds of colour arose in his heart and went from the soles of his feet to the top of his head, and from the top of his head

original: pādapiṭṭhiṃ āgacchati, ubhato paṭṭhāya majjhaṃ otarati, majjhato paṭṭhāya ubhato
analyzed: pāda piṭṭhim āgacchati ubhatas paṭṭhāya majjham otarati majjhatas paṭṭhāya ubhatas
translated: to the soles of his feet, and it descended from both ends to the middle, and it went from the middle to both ends.

original: gacchati. So nirantaraṃ pītiyā phuṭasarīro balavasomanassena dasabalassa guṇaṃ kathento
analyzed: gacchati saḥ nirantaram pītiyā phuṭa sarīraḥ balava somanassena dasa balassa guṇam kathentaḥ
translated: He, his body suffused with uninterrupted rapture, spoke of the ten powers of the Buddha with strong joy,

original: acchariyaṃ bhantetiādimāha. Appicchatāti nittaṇhatā. Santuṭṭhitāti catūsu paccayesu🔽tīhākārehi santoso. Sallekhatāti sabbakilesānaṃ sallikhitabhāvo. Yatra hi nāmāti
analyzed: acchariyam bhante tiādim āha appiccha tā iti nittaṇha tā santuṭṭhi tā ati catūsu paccayesu  tīhākārehi santosaḥ sallekha tā ati sabba kilesānam sallikhita bhāvaḥ yatra hi nāma ati
translated: saying “It is wonderful, venerable sir,” etc. “Little desire” is non-greed. “Contentment” is satisfaction with the four requisites

original: yo nāma. Na attānaṃ pātukarissatīti attano guṇe na āvi karissati. Paṭākaṃ parihareyyunti
analyzed: yaḥ nāma na attānam pātukarissati iti attanaḥ guṇe na āvi karissati paṭākam parihareyyunti
translated: in three ways. “Relinquishment” is the relinquishing of all defilements. “Where” is where. “He will not make himself known” is he will not reveal his own virtues. “He will remove the flag” is

original: “ko amhehi sadiso atthī”ti vadantā paṭākaṃ ukkhipitvā nāḷandaṃ vicareyyuṃ.
analyzed: kaḥ amhehi sadisaḥ atthi iti vadantā paṭākam ukkhipitvā na āḷandam vicareyyuṃ
translated: “Who is there equal to us?” and they would go about Nāḷandā with their banners flying.

original: Passa kho tvaṃ, udāyi, tathāgatassa appicchatāti passa udāyi yādisī tathāgatassa🔽appicchatāti therassa vacanaṃ sampaṭicchanto āha. Kiṃ pana bhagavā neva attānaṃ pātukaroti,🔽na attano guṇaṃ kathetīti ce? Na, na katheti. Appicchatādīhi kathetabbaṃ, cīvarādihetuṃ🔽na katheti. Tenevāha – “passa kho tvaṃ, udāyi, tathāgatassa appicchatā”tiādi. Bujjhanakasattaṃ
analyzed: passa kho tvam udāyi tathāgatassa appicchatā ati passa udāyi yādisī tathāgatassa  therassa vacanam sampaṭicchantaḥ āha kim pana bhagavā na iva attānam pātukaroti  na attanaḥ guṇam katheti iti ce na na katheti appiccha tā ādīhi kathetabbam cīvara ādi hetum  na kathā iti tena iva āha passa kho tvam udāyi tathāgatassa appiccha tā ati ādi bujjhanaka sattam
translated: See, Udayin, the Tathāgata’s fewness of wishes. See, Udayin, what sort of fewness of wishes the Tathāgata has.

original: pana āgamma veneyyavasena katheti. Yathāha –
analyzed: pana āgamma veneyya vasena kathā iti yathā āha
translated: The elder said this in order to show his approval of the Blessed One’s fewness of wishes. But why does the Blessed One not make himself known or proclaim his own special qualities? He does not fail to do so. He does not proclaim his fewness of wishes, etc., for the sake of robes, alms food, resting place, and medicinal requisites. That is why he said: “See, Udayin, the Tathāgata’s fewness of wishes” and so on. But he does proclaim it for the sake of beings who are ready to be trained. As it is said:

original: “Na me ācariyo atthi, sadiso me na vijjati;
analyzed: na me ācariyaḥ atthi sadisaḥ me na vijjati
translated: “I have no teacher, And one like me does not exist;

original: Sadevakasmiṃ lokasmiṃ, natthi me paṭipuggalo”ti. ;
analyzed: sa devakasmim lokasmim na atthi me paṭipuggalo ti
translated: In the world with its gods, There is no one my equal” .

original: Evaṃ tathāgatassa guṇadīpikā bahū gāthāpi suttantāpi vitthāretabbā.
analyzed: evam tathāgatassa guṇa dīpikā bahū gāthā api suttantā api vitthāretabbā
translated: And so on. Many verses and discourses can be quoted here to illustrate the special qualities of the Tathāgata.

original: 163. Abhikkhaṇaṃ bhāseyyāsīti punappunaṃ bhāseyyāsi. Pubbaṇhasamaye me kathitanti
analyzed: abhikkhaṇam bhāseyyāsi iti punappunam bhāseyyāsi pubbaṇha samaye me kathitam ti
translated: ‘You should speak again and again’: you should speak again and again. ‘You told me in the morning’:

original: mā majjhanhikādīsu na kathayittha. Ajja vā me kathitanti mā paradivasādīsu na kathayitthāti
analyzed: mā majjhanhikā ādīsu na kathayittha ajja vā me mā para divasa ādīsu na kathayittha ati
translated: don’t tell me in the middle of the day or in the evening. ‘You told me today’: don’t tell me tomorrow or the next day.

original: attho. Pavedesīti kathesi. Imassa veyyākaraṇassāti niggāthakattā idaṃ suttaṃ “veyyākaraṇa”nti🔽vuttaṃ. Adhivacananti nāmaṃ. Idaṃ pana “iti hida”nti paṭṭhāya padaṃ saṅgītikārehi
analyzed: attho pavedesi iti kathesi imassa veyyākaraṇassa ati niggāthaka ttā idam suttam veyyākaraṇanti  vuttam adhivacananti nāmam idam pana iti paṭṭhāya padam saṅgīti kārehi
translated: ‘You explained’: you told. ‘This explanation’: because it is a verse, this sutta is called ‘explanation’.🔽‘Designation’: name. But this word ‘iti hidaṃ’ is placed by the compilers

original: ṭhapitaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽Sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: ṭhapitam sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati  sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: of the canon beginning from here. The rest is all clear in meaning everywhere.

original: Sampasādanīyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sampasādanīya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sampasādanīya Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Pāsādikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pāsādika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Pāsādika Sutta

original: Nigaṇṭhanāṭaputtakālaṅkiriyavaṇṇanā🔽164. Evaṃ me sutanti pāsādikasuttaṃ. Tatrāyamanuttānapadavaṇṇanā – vedhaññā nāma
analyzed: evam me sutam ti pāsādika suttam tatra ayam anuttāna pada vaṇṇanā vedhaññā nāma
translated: The description of the adornment of Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta🔽‘Thus have I heard’: the Pāsādika Sutta. Here is the commentary on the uncommon words: ‘The Sakyans called Vedhaññā’ are some Sakyans who had trained in archery and were called Vedhaññā. In the mango grove of those

original: sakyāti dhanumhi katasikkhā vedhaññanāmakā eke sakyā. Tesaṃ ambavane pāsādeti tesaṃ
analyzed: sakyā ti dhanumhi kata sikkhāḥ vedhañña nāmakāḥ eke sakyā tesam ambavane pāsāde ti tesam
translated: Sakyans called Vedhaññā.

original: ambavane sippaṃ uggaṇhatthāya kato dīghapāsādo atthi, tattha viharati. Adhunā kālaṅkatoti
analyzed: ambavane sippam uggaṇha tthāya kataḥ dīgha pāsādaḥ atthi tattha viharati adhunā
translated: There is a long-walk constructed in the Mango Grove for the purpose of learning the arts; he is living there. Recently deceased:🔽has just died. Become divided into two factions: become divided into two parts. Quarrel:

original: sampati kālaṅkato. Dvedhikajātāti dvejjhajātā, dvebhāgā jātā. Bhaṇḍanādīsu bhaṇḍanaṃ
analyzed: kālaṅkataḥ dvedhika jātā ati dvejjha jātāḥ dvebhāgāḥ jātāḥ bhaṇḍana ādīsu bhaṇḍanam
translated: quarrel in the preliminary stage. Dispute:

original: pubbabhāgakalaho, taṃ daṇḍādānādivasena paṇṇattivītikkamavasena ca vaḍḍhitaṃ kalaho.
analyzed: pubba bhāga kalahaḥ tam daṇḍa ādāna ādi vasena paṇṇatti vītikkama vasena ca vaḍḍhitam kalahaḥ
translated: quarrel developed by the transgression of the rules of the Order, by the taking of a vote, etc.

original: “Na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsī”tiādinā nayena viruddhavacanaṃ vivādo. Vitudantāti
analyzed: na tvam imam dhamma vinayam ājānāsi iti ādinā nayena viruddha vacanam vivādaḥ
translated: “You do not understand this Dhamma and Discipline” — such contradictory speech is a dispute. They are split:🔽they are divided. My words are connected with the goal:

original: vijjhantā. Sahitaṃ meti mama vacanaṃ atthasañhitaṃ. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattanti🔽yaṃ tava adhiciṇṇaṃ cirakālāsevanavasena paguṇaṃ, taṃ mama vādaṃ āgamma nivattaṃ.
analyzed: vijjhantā sahitam mā iti mama vacanam attha sañhitam adhiciṇṇam te viparāvattanti  yam tava adhiciṇṇam cira kāla āsevana vasena paguṇam tam mama vādam āgamma nivattam
translated: my words are connected with the goal of the ascetic life. Your practice has turned back:🔽your practice, which has been developed by long practice, has turned back because of my doctrine. Your doctrine has been refuted:

original: Āropito te vādoti tuyhaṃ upari mayā doso āropito. Cara vādappamokkhāyāti bhattapuṭaṃ
analyzed: āropito te vādo ti tuyham upari mayā doso āropito cara vāda ppamokkhāya ati bhatta puṭam
translated: a fault has been imputed to you by me. Go and seek release for your doctrine:

original: ādāya taṃ taṃ upasaṅkamitvā vādappamokkhatthāya uttari pariyesamāno vicara. Nibbeṭhehi
analyzed: ādāya tam tam upasaṅkamitvā vāda ppamokkha tthāya uttari pariyesamānaḥ vicara nibbeṭhehi
translated: taking your bowl and robe, go here and there and seek further, seeking release for your doctrine. Free yourself:

original: vāti atha vā mayā āropitadosato attānaṃ mocehi. Sace pahosīti sace sakkosi. Vadhoyevāti
analyzed: vā ati atha vā mayā āropita dosataḥ attānam mocehi sace pahosi iti sace sakkosi
translated: Or else, if I have accused you falsely, then free yourself. If you can, then do so. It is only death:

original: maraṇameva. Nāṭaputtiyesūti nāṭaputtassa antevāsikesu. Nibbinnarūpāti ukkaṇṭhitasabhāvā
analyzed: maraṇam eva nāṭa puttiyesu ti nāṭa puttassa antevāsikesu nibbinna rūpā ati ukkaṇṭhita sabhāvā
translated: it is only death. Among the disciples of the Nigantha: among the pupils of the Nigantha. Disgusted: of a nature to be disgusted.

original: abhivādanādīnipi na karonti. Virattarūpāti vigatapemā. Paṭivānarūpāti tesaṃ sakkaccakiriyato
analyzed: abhivādana ādīni pi na karonti viratta rūpā ati vigata pemā paṭivāna rūpā ati tesam
translated: They do not even pay homage. Dispassionate: free from affection. Turned away: of a nature to turn away from their respectful service.

original: nivattanasabhāvā. Yathā tanti yathā durakkhātādisabhāve dhammavinaye nibbinnavirattappaṭivānarūpehi
analyzed: nivattana sabhāvā yathā tanti yathā durakkhāta ādi sabhāve dhamma vinaye nibbinna viratta paṭivāna rūpehi
translated: Just as in the Dhamma and Discipline that is badly expounded, etc., one should be disgusted, dispassionate, and turned away, so it is in the Nigantha discipline. That is the meaning.

original: bhavitabbaṃ, tatheva jātāti attho. Durakkhāteti dukkathite. Duppavediteti duviññāpite.
analyzed: bhavitabbam tathā iva jātā ati attho durakkhātā iti dukkathite duppaveditā iti du viññāpite
translated: Badly expounded: badly taught. Ill-proclaimed: ill-revealed.

original: Anupasamasaṃvattaniketi rāgādīnaṃ upasamaṃ kātuṃ asamatthe. Bhinnathūpeti bhindappatiṭṭhe.
analyzed: anupasama saṃvattanikā iti rāga ādīnam upasamam kātum asamatthe bhinnathūpā iti bhindappatiṭṭhe
translated: Not conducive to peace: not capable of producing the peace of lust, etc. Broken to: established in the breaking of.

original: Ettha hi nāṭaputtova nesaṃ patiṭṭhaṭṭhena thūpo. So pana bhinno mato. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: ettha hi nāṭa putto va nesam patiṭṭha ṭṭhena thūpo so pana bhinnaḥ mataḥ tena vuttam
translated: Herein, the Nigantha himself is the “to” in the sense of the basis. He is “broken” in being dead. Hence it was said above: “When the Nigantha was dead” .

original: “bhinnathūpe”ti. Appaṭisaraṇeti tasseva abhāvena paṭisaraṇavirahite.
analyzed: bhinna thūpe iti appaṭisaraṇa iti tassa iva abhāvena paṭisaraṇa virahite
translated: Without shelter: without a shelter owing to the absence of that.

original: Nanu cāyaṃ nāṭaputto nāḷandavāsiko, so kasmā pāvāyaṃ kālaṅkatoti? So kira upālinā
analyzed: nanu ca ayam nāṭa putto nāḷanda vāsiko so kasmā so kira upālinā
translated: But was not this Nāṭaputta a resident of Nāḷandā? Why then did he die at Pāvā? It seems that he was a pupil of the Elder Upāli.

original: gahapatinā paṭividdhasaccena dasahi gāthāhi bhāsite buddhaguṇe sutvā uṇhaṃ lohitaṃ
analyzed: gahapatinā paṭividdha saccena dasahi gāthāhi bhāsite buddha guṇe sutvā uṇham lohitam
translated: But was not this actor a resident of Nāḷandā? Why did he die at Pāvā? It seems that he heard the Elder Upāli, a householder who had penetrated the truths, recite the Buddha’s qualities in ten stanzas, and he vomited hot blood.

original: chaḍḍesi. Atha naṃ aphāsukaṃ gahetvā pāvaṃ agamaṃsu. So tattha kālamakāsi. Kālaṃ🔽kurumāno ca cintesi – “mama laddhi aniyyānikā sāravirahitā, mayaṃ tāva naṭṭhā, avasesajanopi
analyzed: chaḍḍesi atha nam a phāsukam gahetvā pāvam agamaṃsu saḥ tattha kālam akāsi kālam  kurumāno ca cintesi mama laddhi aniyyānikā sāra virahitā mayam tāva naṭṭhāḥ avasesa janaḥ api
translated: Then, taking him in his last illness, they went to Pāvā. There he died.

original: mā apāyapūrako ahosi, sace panāhaṃ ‘mama sāsanaṃ aniyyānika’nti vakkhāmi, na saddahissanti,
analyzed: mā apāya pūrakaḥ ahosi sace pana aham mama sāsanam aniyyānikam ti vakkhāmi na saddahissanti
translated: And as he was dying, he thought, “My claim was not definitive and was devoid of the essence. Now I am lost, and the rest of the people will not fill up the states of loss. But if I say, ‘My doctrine was not definitive,’ they will not believe me.

original: yaṃnūnāhaṃ dvepi jane na ekanīhārena uggaṇhāpeyyaṃ, te mamaccayena aññamaññaṃ vivadissanti,
analyzed: yat nūna aham dve api jane na eka nīhārena uggaṇhāpeyyam te mamaccayena aññamaññam vivadissanti
translated: Why should I not get two people to learn it in two different ways so that after my death they will dispute with each other?

original: satthā taṃ vivādaṃ paṭicca ekaṃ dhammakathaṃ kathessati, tato te sāsanassa mahantabhāvaṃ jānissantī”ti.
analyzed: satthā tam vivādam paṭicca ekam dhamma katham kathessati tatas te sāsanassa mahanta bhāvam jānissanti iti
translated: The Master will give a discourse on the True Idea in order to settle the dispute, and then they will know the greatness of the Dispensation.”

original: Atha naṃ eko antevāsiko upasaṅkamitvā āha – “bhante tumhe dubbalā, mayhampi imasmiṃ🔽dhamme sāraṃ ācikkhatha, ācariyappamāṇa”nti. “Āvuso, tvaṃ mamaccayena sassatanti🔽gaṇheyyāsī”ti. Aparopi upasaṅkami, taṃ ucchedaṃ gaṇhāpesi. Evaṃ dvepi jane ekaladdhike🔽akatvā bahū nānānīhārena uggaṇhāpetvā kālamakāsi. Te tassa sarīrakiccaṃ katvā sannipatitvā🔽aññamaññaṃ pucchiṃsu – “kassāvuso, ācariyo sāraṃ ācikkhī”ti? Eko uṭṭhahitvā mayhanti
analyzed: atha nam ekaḥ antevāsikaḥ upasaṅkamitvā āha bhante tumhe dubbalāḥ mayham pi imasmin  dhamme sāram ācikkhatha ācariya ppamāṇam ti āvuso tvam mamaccayena  gaṇheyyāsi iti aparaḥ api upasaṅkami tam ucchedam evam dve api jane ekaladdhike  a katvā bahū nānā nīhārena uggaṇhāpetvā kālam akāsi te tassa sarīra kiccam katvā sannipatitvā  aññam aññam pucchiṃsu kassa āvuso ācariyo sāram ācikkhi iti ekaḥ uṭṭhahitvā mayhanti
translated: A certain pupil came to him and said, “Reverend Sir, you are weak; tell me the essence of the Law, I am worthy of instruction.” “Friend, after my death you will hold the doctrine of eternalism.” Another came to him and said, “Tell me the essence of the Law.” “Friend, after my death you will hold the doctrine of annihilation.” Thus he taught many pupils, without regard to the number of pupils he had taught, but according to the inclination of each. After he had thus taught many pupils, he died. After his funeral rites had been performed, the pupils assembled and asked one another, “What did our teacher teach you, friends?” One said, “My teacher taught me the doctrine of eternalism.”🔽

original: āha. Kiṃ ācikkhīti? Sassatanti. Aparo taṃ paṭibāhitvā “mayhaṃ sāraṃ ācikkhī”ti āha.🔽Evaṃ sabbe “mayhaṃ sāraṃ ācikkhi, ahaṃ jeṭṭhako”ti aññamaññaṃ vivādaṃ vaḍḍhetvā akkose
analyzed: āha kim ācikkhi iti aparaḥ tam paṭibāhitvā mayham sāram ācikkhi iti āha 🔽evam sabbe mayham sāram ācikkhi aham jeṭṭhako ti aññamaññam vivādam vaḍḍhetvā akkose
translated: A certain pupil came to him and said, “Reverend Sir, you are weak; tell me the essence of the Law, I am worthy of the Teacher’s confidence.” “My son, after my death you will hold the doctrine of eternalism.” Another came to him and he taught him the doctrine of annihilation. Thus he taught many pupils, without regard to order of precedence, the various doctrines, and then died. After his funeral rites had been performed, they assembled and asked one another, “What did our teacher teach you, friends?” One said, “He taught me this,” and another said, “He taught me that.” Thus they increased their mutual animosity, saying, “He taught me the essence of the Law; I am the eldest son.”

original: ceva paribhāse ca hatthapādappahārādīni ca pavattetvā ekamaggena dve agacchantā nānādisāsu pakkamiṃsu.
analyzed: ca iva paribhāse ca hattha pāda pahāra ādīni ca pavattetvā eka maggena dve agacchantā nānā disāsu pakkamiṃsu
translated: and they went out in different directions, one by one, after having reviled each other and struck each other with their hands and feet, etc.

original: 165. Atha kho cundo samaṇuddesoti ayaṃ thero dhammasenāpatissa kaniṭṭhabhātiko. Taṃ
analyzed: atha kho cundaḥ samaṇuddeso ti ayam theraḥ dhammasenāpatissa kaniṭṭha bhātiko taṃ
translated: “Cunda, the novice attendant”: this Elder was the younger brother of the General of the Dhamma.

original: bhikkhū anupasampannakāle “cundo samaṇuddeso”ti samudācaritvā therakālepi tatheva
analyzed: bhikkhū an upasampanna kāle cundaḥ samaṇuddeso ti samudācaritvā thera kāle pi tathā iva
translated: The bhikkhus, while he was still a novice, used to address him as “Cunda, the novice attendant.”🔽Even after he had become an Elder, they continued to address him in the same way.

original: samudācariṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ – “cundo samaṇuddeso”ti.
analyzed: samudācariṃsu tena vuttam cundo samaṇa uddeso ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Cunda, the novice attendant.”

original: kathenti, kadāci maggaṃ kathenti, kadāci phalaṃ kadāci nibbānanti adhippāyo. Jānatāti
analyzed: kathenti kadāci maggam kathenti kadāci phalam kadāci nibbānanti adhippāyaḥ jānata ati
translated: “They have tongues” : whatever they want, that they speak. Sometimes they speak of the path, sometimes of fruition, sometimes of nibbana—this is the meaning.🔽“Knowing” : knowing with the knowledge of omniscience.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇena jānantena. Passatāti pañcahi cakkhūhi passantena. Gambhīranemoti
analyzed: sabbaññu ta ññāṇena jānantena passatā ati pañcahi cakkhūhi passantena gambhīranemo ti
translated: “Seeing” : seeing with the five eyes. “The deep ocean” :

original: gambhīrabhūmiṃ anupaviṭṭho. Sunikhātoti suṭṭhu nikhāto. Evameva kho, āvusoti evaṃ
analyzed: gambhīra bhūmim anupaviṭṭhaḥ su nikhātaḥ iti suṭṭhu nikhātaḥ evam eva kho āvuso ti evam
translated: has penetrated to the deep place. Well-planted: well-planted, well-established. Just so, friend:

original: khīṇāsavo abhabbo nava ṭhānāni ajjhācarituṃ. Tasmiṃ anajjhācāro acalo asampavedhī.
analyzed: khīṇāsavaḥ abhabbaḥ nava ṭhānāni ajjhācaritum tasmin an ajjhācāraḥ acalaḥ a sampavedhī
translated: and he is well-planted on the plane of the deep. He is well-planted: he is well-planted in the noble fruit. Just so, friend: just so, friend, the one whose cankers are destroyed is incapable of transgression in these nine cases. He is incapable of transgression in them, he is unshakable, he is unassailable.

original: Tattha sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropanādīsu sotāpannādayopi abhabbā. Sannidhikārakaṃ🔽kāme paribhuñjitunti vatthukāme ca kilesakāme ca sannidhiṃ katvā paribhuñjituṃ. Seyyathāpi
analyzed: tattha sañcit ca pāṇam jīvitā voropana ādīsu sotāpanna ādayaḥ api abhabbā sannidhi kārakam  kāme paribhuñjitunti vatthu kāme ca kilesa kāme ca sannidhim katvā paribhuñjitum sā iyyathā api
translated: Herein, stream-enterers, etc., are incapable of the killing of a saint, etc., even when intending to do so.🔽He is incapable of using stored-up sensual desires: he is incapable of using sensual desires after storing them up, that is, after hoarding them. Just as

original: pubbe agārikabhūtoti yathā pubbe gihibhūto paribhuñjati, evaṃ paribhuñjituṃ abhabbo.
analyzed: pubbe agārika bhūto ti yathā pubbe gihi bhūto paribhuñjati evam paribhuñjitum abhabbaḥ
translated: he used to do when he was a householder: he is incapable of using sensual desires as he used to do when he was a householder.

original: Pañhabyākaraṇavaṇṇanā🔽187. Agāramajjhe vasantā hi sotāpannādayo yāvajīvaṃ gihibyañjanena tiṭṭhanti. Khīṇāsavo
analyzed: agāra majjhe vasantāḥ hi sotāpanna ādayaḥ yāvajīvam gihi byañjanena tiṭṭhanti khīṇa asavaḥ
translated: The explanation of the questions🔽For stream-enterers, etc., who live in the midst of the house life remain as householders for life. But one whose cankers are destroyed attains Nibbāna either as a human being or after he has gone forth.

original: pana arahattaṃ patvāva manussabhūto parinibbāti vā pabbajati vā. Cātumahārājikādīsu
analyzed: pana arahattam patvā ava manussa bhūtaḥ parinibbāti vā pabbajati vā cātumahārājika ādīsu
translated: In the case of the Cātummahārājika gods, etc.,

original: kāmāvacaradevesu muhuttampi na tiṭṭhati. Kasmā? Vivekaṭṭhānassa abhāvā. Bhummadevattabhāve
analyzed: kāmāvacara devesu muhuttam pi na tiṭṭhati kasmā viveka ṭṭhānassa abhāvā bhumma devatta bhāve
translated: He does not stay even a moment among the sense-sphere gods. Why? Because there is no place for seclusion there. The gods of the earth

original: pana ṭhito arahattaṃ patvāpi tiṭṭhati. Tassa vasena ayaṃ pañho āgato. Bhinnadosattā
analyzed: pana ṭhitaḥ arahattam patvā api tiṭṭhati tassa vasena ayam pañhaḥ āgataḥ bhinna dosa ttā
translated: He does not stay even for a moment among the sense-sphere gods. Why? Because there is no place for seclusion there. But he stays when he has reached Arahantship and is established in the state of a world-ruling deity. It is in this sense that the question is asked. But his state as a bhikkhu should be understood as continuing unbroken.

original: panassa bhikkhubhāvo veditabbo. Atīrakanti atīraṃ aparicchedaṃ mahantaṃ. No ca kho🔽anāgatanti anāgataṃ pana addhānaṃ ārabbha evaṃ na paññapeti, atītameva maññe samaṇo
analyzed: panassa bhikkhu bhāvaḥ veditabbo atīrakam ti a tīram a paricchedam mahantam no ca kho  anāgatam ti anāgatam pana addhānam ārabbha evam na paññapeti atītam eva maññe samaṇo
translated: Infinite: boundless, unlimited, great.🔽But he does not declare:

original: gotamo jānāti, na anāgataṃ. Tathā hissa atīte aḍḍhachaṭṭhasatajātakānussaraṇaṃ paññāyati.
analyzed: gotamaḥ jānāti na anāgatam tathā hi ssa atīte aḍḍha chaṭṭha sata jātaka anussaraṇam paññāyati
translated: He does not declare in this way about the future. He seems to know only the past, not the future. For it is said of him that he remembers the past in the six-and-a-half myriads of Jātakas.

original: Anāgate evaṃ bahuṃ anussaraṇaṃ na paññāyatīti imamatthaṃ maññamānā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ.
analyzed: anāgate evam bahum anussaraṇam na paññāyati iti imam attham maññamānāḥ evam vadeyyuṃ
translated: Thinking that he does not remember the future in this way, they would say thus.

original: Tayidaṃ kiṃ sūti anāgate apaññāpanaṃ kiṃ nu kho? Kathaṃsūti kena nu kho kāraṇena
analyzed: tayidam kim su iti anāgate apaññāpanam kim nu kho kathaṃsūti kena nu kho kāraṇena
translated: What is the reason? Why does he not declare the future?

original: ajānantoyeva nu kho anāgataṃ nānussarati, ananussaritukāmatāya nānussaratīti. Aññavihitakena
analyzed: a jānantaḥ yā iva nu kho anāgatam na anussarati an anussaritu kāma tāya na anussarati iti aññavihitakena
translated: Does he not remember the future because he does not know it, or because he does not want to remember it?

original: ñāṇadassanenāti paccakkhaṃ viya katvā dassanasamatthatāya dassanabhūtena ñāṇena aññatthavihitakena
analyzed: ñāṇa dassanena ati paccakkham viya katvā dassana samattha tāya dassana bhūtena ñāṇena aññattha vihitakena
translated: “By knowledge and vision”: by knowledge that is vision, that is capable of seeing as if facing it.

original: ñāṇena aññaṃ ārabbha pavattena, aññavihitakaṃ aññaṃ ārabbha pavattamānaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ🔽saṅgāhetabbaṃ paññāpetabbaṃ maññanti. Te hi carato ca tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa
analyzed: ñāṇena aññam ārabbha pavattena aññavihitakam aññam ārabbha pavattamānam ñāṇa dassanam  saṅgāhetabbam paññāpetabbam maññanti te hi carataḥ ca tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa
translated: Knowledge that occurs in one way is called “knowledge and vision” that occurs in another way.🔽They think that it can be brought together and demonstrated. For they think that knowledge and vision is constantly and continuously present whether one is walking or standing or sleeping or awake.

original: ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ maññanti, tādisañca ñāṇaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitam maññanti tādisam ca ñāṇam nāma natthi
translated: But there is no such knowledge.

original: Tasmā yathariva bālā abyattā, evaṃ maññantīti veditabbo.
analyzed: tasmai yathari iva bālāḥ abyattāḥ evam maññanti iti veditabbaḥ
translated: Therefore it should be understood that they think in this way like fools, like the unskillful.

original: Satānusārīti pubbenivāsānussatisampayuttakaṃ. Yāvatakaṃ ākaṅkhatīti yattakaṃ ñātuṃ🔽icchati, tattakaṃ jānissāmīti ñāṇaṃ pesesi. Athassa dubbalapattapuṭe pakkhandanārāco
analyzed: sata anusārī iti pubbenivāsa anussati sampayuttakam yāvatakam ākaṅkhati iti yattakam ñātum  icchati tattakam jānissāmi iti ñāṇam pesesi athassa dubbala patta puṭe pakkhanda nārācaḥ
translated: “Following recollection”: associated with the recollection of past lives.🔽“As far back as he wishes”: he sends out knowledge thinking, “I shall know as much as I want to know.” Then his knowledge goes unobstructed and unhampered, like an arrow shot by a strong archer,

original: viya appaṭihataṃ anivāritaṃ ñāṇaṃ gacchati, tena yāvatakaṃ ākaṅkhati tāvatakaṃ anussarati.
analyzed: viya a paṭihatam a nivāritam ñāṇam gacchati tena yāvatakam ākaṅkhati tāvatakam anussarati
translated: and he recollects as far back as he wishes.

original: Bodhijanti bodhimūle jātaṃ. Ñāṇaṃ uppajjatīti catumaggañāṇaṃ uppajjati. Ayamantimā
analyzed: bodhi janti bodhi mūle jātam ñāṇam uppajjati iti catu magga ñāṇam uppajjati ayam antimā
translated: “They know” means that the knowledge of the four paths arises.

original: jātīti tena ñāṇena jātimūlassa pahīnattā puna ayamantimā jāti. Natthidāni punabbhavoti🔽aparampi ñāṇaṃ uppajjati. Anatthasaṃhitanti na idhalokatthaṃ vā paralokatthaṃ vā
analyzed: jātī iti tena ñāṇena jāti mūlassa pahīna ttā puna ayam antimā jāti natthi idāni punabbhavoti  aparam pi ñāṇam uppajjati anattha saṃhitanti na idha loka ttham vā para loka ttham vā
translated: “He knows”: the four path-knowledges arise. “This is the last birth”: by that knowledge the root of birth is abandoned, so there is no more birth for him. “There is now no more becoming”:

original: nissitaṃ. Na taṃ tathāgato byākarotīti taṃ bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇasadisaṃ aniyyānikakathaṃ
analyzed: nissitam na tam tathāgataḥ byākaroti iti tam bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa sadisam aniyyānika katham
translated: another knowledge arises. “Not conducive to welfare”: not based on welfare in this world or in the next. “The Tathāgata does not declare”: the Tathāgata does not speak such talk as is not conducive to welfare, such as the Bhārata war or the abduction of Sītā.

original: tathāgato na katheti. Bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ anatthasaṃhitanti rājakathāditiracchānakathaṃ.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ na kathā iti bhūtam taccham anattha saṃhitanti
translated: “True, real, not conducive to welfare”: such talk as the talk of kings, etc., or animal talk.

original: Kālaññū tathāgato hotīti kālaṃ jānāti. Sahetukaṃ sakāraṇaṃ katvā yuttapattakāleyeva katheti.🔽188. Tasmā tathāgatoti vuccatīti yathā yathā gaditabbaṃ, tathā tatheva gadanato dakārassa
analyzed: kālaññū tathāgataḥ hoti iti kālam jānāti sa hetukam sa kāraṇam katvā yutta patta kālā iya iva kathā iti  tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti yathā yathā gaditabbam tathā tathā iva gadanataḥ dakārassa
translated: “The Tathāgata is timely”: he knows the time. He speaks only when it is appropriate, after considering the cause and reason.🔽“Therefore he is called the Tathāgata”: the meaning is that he is called the Tathāgata because he speaks just as he should, after changing the d- to t- in the word tathā .

original: takāraṃ katvā tathāgatoti vuccatīti attho. Diṭṭhanti rūpāyatanaṃ. Sutanti saddāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: takāram katvā tathāgato ti vuccati iti atthaḥ diṭṭhanti rūpa āyatanam sutanti sadda āyatanam
translated: “Seen”: the visible-form base. “Heard”: the sound base.

original: Mutanti mutvā patvā gahetabbato gandhāyatanaṃ rasāyatanaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ. Viññātanti🔽sukhadukkhādidhammāyatanaṃ. Pattanti pariyesitvā vā apariyesitvā vā pattaṃ. Pariyesitanti🔽pattaṃ vā apattaṃ vā pariyesitaṃ. Anuvicaritaṃ manasāti cittena anusañcaritaṃ. “Tathāgatena
analyzed: mutanti mutvā patvā gahetabbataḥ gandha āyatanam rasa āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam viññātanti  sukha dukkha ādi dhamma āyatanam pattanti pariyesitvā vā a pariyesitvā vā pattam pariyesitanti  pattam vā a pattam vā pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā ati cittena anusañcaritam tathāgatena
translated: “Odour” is the odour base, because it can be seized by smelling and by falling over it. “Taste” is the taste base. “Tangible datum” is the tangible-data base. “Idea” is the idea base. “Obtained” is obtained by searching or without searching. “Searched for” is searched for as obtained or not obtained. “Contemplated with the mind” is what has been gone about with the mind. “By the Tathāgata” is by the Blessed One, the Tathāgata.

original: abhisambuddha”nti iminā etaṃ dasseti, yañhi aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa sadevakassa
analyzed: abhisambuddhanti iminā etam dasseti yat hi aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa sa devakassa
translated: “Smelt” : the odour base, the flavour base, the tangible base, because they are to be smelt, etc., by smelling, etc. “Known” : the idea base, because it is to be known by consciousness. “Attained” : the visible-form base, the sound base, the mind base, the mind-object base, because they are to be attained by the eye faculty, etc., respectively. “Sought” : the visible-form base, etc., because they are to be sought by the eye faculty, etc. “Considered by the mind” : the visible-form base, etc., because they are to be considered by the mind. “The Tathagata has fully awakened to” : this shows that the Tathagata has fully awakened to the fact that in the countless world systems of the universe, the visible-form object, etc., which come within the range of the eye faculty, etc., of this world with its gods, is blue, yellow, etc. And he has fully awakened to the fact that at a given moment, this being, having seen a visible-form object, is glad, sad, or indifferent;

original: lokassa nīlaṃ pītakantiādi rūpārammaṇaṃ cakkhudvāre āpāthamāgacchati, “ayaṃ satto
analyzed: lokassa nīlam pīta kanti ādi rūpa ārammaṇam cakkhu dvāre āpātham āgacchati ayam satto
translated: and that in the countless world systems of the universe, the visible-form object, etc., which come within the range of the eye faculty, etc., of this world with its gods, is blue, yellow, etc.;

original: imasmiṃ khaṇe imaṃ nāma rūpārammaṇaṃ disvā sumano vā dummano vā majjhatto vā jāto”ti🔽sabbaṃ taṃ tathāgatassa evaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ. Tathā yaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa
analyzed: imasmin khaṇe imam nāma rūpa ārammaṇam disvā sumanaḥ vā dummanaḥ vā majjhattaḥ vā jātaḥ ti 🔽sabbam tat tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham tathā yam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa
translated: and that at a given moment, this being, having seen a visible-form object, is glad, sad, or indifferent.

original: sadevakassa lokassa bherisaddo mudiṅgasaddotiādi saddārammaṇaṃ sotadvāre āpāthamāgacchati.🔽Mūlagandho tacagandhotiādi gandhārammaṇaṃ ghānadvāre āpāthamāgacchati. Mūlaraso khandharasotiādi🔽rasārammaṇaṃ jivhādvāre āpāthamāgacchati. Kakkhaḷaṃ mudukantiādi pathavīdhātutejodhātuvāyodhātubhedaṃ
analyzed: sa devakassa lokassa bheri saddaḥ mudiṅga saddaḥ tiādi sadda ārammaṇam sotadvāre āpātham āgacchati  mūla gandho taca gandho tiādi gandha ārammaṇam ghāna dvāre āpātham āgacchati mūla raso khandha rasaḥ itiādi  rasa ārammaṇam jivhā dvāre āpātham āgacchati kakkhaḷam mudu kanti ādi pathavī dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu bhedam
translated: Sounds such as the sound of a drum, the sound of a tabor, etc., which are objects of sound, come within the scope of the ear door.🔽Smells such as the smell of the root, the smell of the flower, etc., which are objects of smell, come within the scope of the nose door. Tastes such as the taste of the root, the taste of the bark, etc.,

original: phoṭṭhabbārammaṇaṃ kāyadvāre āpāthamāgacchati. “Ayaṃ satto imasmiṃ khaṇe imaṃ nāma
analyzed: phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam kāya dvāre āpātham āgacchati ayam satto imasmin khaṇe imam nāma
translated: which are objects of taste, come within the scope of the tongue door. Textures such as the hard, the soft, etc., which are objects of touch, come within the scope of the body door.

original: phoṭṭhabbārammaṇaṃ phusitvā sumano vā dummano vā majjhatto vā jāto”ti sabbaṃ taṃ🔽tathāgatassa evaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ. Tathā yaṃ aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa sadevakassa
analyzed: phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇam phusitvā sumanaḥ vā dummanaḥ vā majjhattaḥ vā jātaḥ iti sabbam tam  tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham tathā yam aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu imassa sa devakassa
translated: “At this moment this being is experiencing such and such a texture, and he is pleased, displeased, or indifferent.” All this

original: lokassa sukhadukkhādibhedaṃ dhammārammaṇaṃ manodvārassa āpāthamāgacchati, “ayaṃ satto
analyzed: lokassa sukha dukkha ādi bhedam dhamma ārammaṇam manaḥ dvārassa āpātham āgacchati ayam satto
translated: the Tathāgata has penetrated thus. Likewise, the objects of mind such as the happiness, suffering, etc., of the beings in the immeasurable world systems, which come within the scope of the mind door,🔽“This being has such and such a mental object, and he is pleased, displeased, or indifferent.” All this

original: imasmiṃ khaṇe idaṃ nāma dhammārammaṇaṃ vijānitvā sumano vā dummano vā majjhatto vā
analyzed: imasmin khaṇe idam nāma dhamma ārammaṇam vijānitvā sumanaḥ vā dummanaḥ vā majjhattaḥ vā
translated: at this moment, having known such and such a thing as the object of the mind, whether happy, unhappy, or neither unhappy nor happy,🔽

original: jāto”ti sabbaṃ taṃ tathāgatassa evaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ.🔽Yañhi, cunda, imesaṃ sattānaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ tattha tathāgatena adiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: jātaḥ iti sabbam tat tathāgatassa evam abhisambuddham  yat hi cunda imesam sattānam diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam tattha tathāgatena a diṭṭham
translated: At this moment, having known such and such an object of thought, he was glad, or he was sad, or he was neutral.” All this the Tathāgata has fully awakened to.

original: vā asutaṃ vā amutaṃ vā aviññātaṃ vā natthi. Imassa mahājanassa pariyesitvā pattampi🔽atthi, pariyesitvā appattampi atthi. Apariyesitvā pattampi atthi, apariyesitvā appattampi
analyzed: vā asutam vā amutam vā aviññātam vā natthi imassa mahājanassa pariyesitvā pattam pi  atthi pariyesitvā appattam pi atthi a pariyesitvā pattam pi atthi a pariyesitvā appattam pi
translated: For, Cunda, there is nothing seen, heard, sensed, or known by these beings that has not been seen, heard, sensed, or known by the Tathāgata. Among this great multitude there are some who, having searched, have found,

original: atthi. Sabbampi taṃ tathāgatassa appattaṃ nāma natthi, ñāṇena asacchikataṃ nāma.🔽“Tasmā tathāgatoti vuccatī”ti. Yaṃ yathā lokena gataṃ tassa tatheva gatattā “tathāgato”ti
analyzed: atthi sabbam pi tam tathāgatassa appattam nāma natthi ñāṇena asacchikatam nāma  tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti yam yathā lokena gatam tassa tathā iva gata ttā tathāgataḥ ti
translated: and there are some who, having searched, have not found. There are some who, without having searched, have found, and there are some who, without having searched, have not found. But for the Tathāgata there is nothing that has not been found, nothing that has not been fully awakened to by knowledge.

original: vuccati. Pāḷiyaṃ pana abhisambuddhanti vuttaṃ, taṃ gatasaddena ekatthaṃ. Iminā nayena
analyzed: vuccati pāḷiyam pana abhisambuddhanti vuttam tam gata saddena ekattham iminā nayena
translated: “Therefore he is called the Tathāgata.” He is called the Tathāgata because he has gone in the same way as the world goes. But in the text it is said “awakened to,” which is the same as the word “gone.”

original: sabbavāresu “tathāgato”ti nigamanassa attho veditabbo, tassa yutti brahmajāle tathāgatasaddavitthāre vuttāyeva.
analyzed: sabba vāresu tathāgato ti nigamanassa attho veditabbo tassa yutti brahmajāle tathāgata sadda vitthāre vuttāya eva
translated: The meaning of the conclusion “the Tathāgata” in all the passages should be understood as stated in the Brahmajāla Sutta in the detailed explanation of the word “Tathāgata.”

original: Abyākataṭṭhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: abyākata ṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Undetermined Questions

original: 189. Evaṃ attano asamataṃ anuttarataṃ sabbaññutaṃ dhammarājabhāvaṃ kathetvā idāni
analyzed: evam attanaḥ asama tam anuttara tam sabbaññu tam dhamma rāja bhāvam kathetvā idāni
translated: Having thus spoken of his own incomparable, unsurpassed, all-knowing, and royal state of the Dhamma, the Exalted One now,

original: “puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ laddhīsu mayā aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ nāma natthi, sabbaṃ mama ñāṇassa
analyzed: puthu samaṇa brāhmaṇānam laddhīsu mayā aññātam adiṭṭham nāma natthi sabbam mama ñāṇassa
translated: roaring his lion’s roar, “There is nothing that I do not know or see among the attainments of the various ascetics and brahmins. All that is within my knowledge.🔽It all turns within my knowledge,”
