original: Daḷhasamādānoti thiragahaṇo. Kusalesu dhammesūti dasakusalakammapathesu. Avatthitasamādānoti
analyzed: daḷha samādānaḥ ti thira gahaṇo kusalesu dhammesu iti dasa kusala kamma pathesu avatthita samādānaḥ ti
translated: “Firmly resolute” is a term for one who is steadfast. “In wholesome states” means in the ten wholesome courses of action. “Resolutely firm” is a term for one who is steadfast,

original: niccalagahaṇo anivattitagahaṇo. Mahāsattassa hi akusalakammato aggiṃ patvā kukkuṭapattaṃ
analyzed: niccala gahaṇaḥ a nivattita gahaṇaḥ mahāsattassa hi akusala kammataḥ aggim patvā kukkuṭa pattam
translated: a term for one who does not turn back. For the mind of a Great Man recoils from unwholesome states like a cock’s feather from fire,

original: viya cittaṃ paṭikuṭati, kusalaṃ patvā vitānaṃ viya pasāriyati. Tasmā daḷhasamādāno
analyzed: viya cittam paṭikuṭati kusalam patvā vitānam viya pasāriyati tasmāt daḷha samādānaḥ
translated: and it expands towards wholesome states like a wet cloth in the wind. Therefore he is firmly resolute and resolutely firm.

original: hoti avatthitasamādāno. Na sakkā kenaci samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena🔽vā brahmunā vā kusalasamādānaṃ vissajjāpetuṃ.
analyzed: hoti avatthita samādānaḥ na sakkā kenacid samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena 🔽vā brahmunā vā kusala samādānam vissajjāpetum
translated: No ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, Brahmā, or anyone in the world can make him give up his wholesome resolution.

original: Tatrimāni vatthūni – pubbe kira mahāpuriso kalandakayoniyaṃ nibbatti. Atha deve vuṭṭhe
analyzed: tatra imāni vatthūni pubbe kira mahā purisaḥ kalandaka yoniyam nibbatti atha deve vuṭṭhe
translated: Here are the stories. It seems that in a former birth the Great Being was reborn in the womb of a Kalandaka bird. Then the rains came to an end,

original: ogho āgantvā kulāvakaṃ gahetvā samuddameva pavesesi. Mahāpuriso “puttake nīharissāmī”ti
analyzed: oghaḥ āgantvā kulāvakam gahetvā samuddam eva pavesesi mahā purisaḥ puttake nīharissāmi iti
translated: and a flood came down and carried off the nest and the young ones and plunged them into the sea. The Great Being thought, “I will get out my young ones.”

original: naṅguṭṭhaṃ temetvā temetvā samuddato udakaṃ bahi khipi. Sattame divase sakko āvajjitvā🔽tattha āgamma “kiṃ karosī”ti pucchi? So tassa ārocesi. Sakko mahāsamuddato udakassa
analyzed: naṅguṭṭham temetvā temetvā samuddataḥ udakam bahi khipi sattame divase sakkaḥ āvajjitvā  tattha āgamma kim karosi iti pucchi so tassa ārocesi sakkaḥ mahā samuddataḥ udakassa
translated: So he shook his wings and shook the water off, and threw it out of the sea. On the seventh day Sakka, having perceived the situation,

original: dunnīharaṇīyabhāvaṃ kathesi. Bodhisatto tādisena kusītena saddhiṃ kathetumpi na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: dunnīharaṇīya bhāvam kathesi bodhisatto tādisena kusītena saddhim kathetum pi na vaṭṭati
translated: came there and asked, “What are you doing?” The Great Being told him. Sakka told him how difficult it was to get the water out of the sea. The Great Being thought, “It is not proper for me to talk with such a lazy fellow.”

original: “Mā idha tiṭṭhā”ti apasāresi. Sakko “anomapurisena gahitagahaṇaṃ na sakkā vissajjāpetu”nti🔽tuṭṭho tassa puttake ānetvā adāsi. Mahājanakakālepi mahāsamuddaṃ taramāno “kasmā
analyzed: mā idha tiṭṭhāti apasāresi sakkaḥ anoma purisena gahita gahaṇam na sakkā vissajjāpetunti  tuṭṭhaḥ tassa puttake ānetvā adāsi mahā janaka kāle pi mahā samuddam taramāno kasmā
translated: So he said, “Get out of here,” and drove him away. Sakka thought, “It is not possible to get away from one who has seized me with his incomparable manliness.”

original: mahāsamuddaṃ tarasī”ti devatāya puṭṭho “pāraṃ gantvā kulasantake raṭṭhe rajjaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: mahā samuddam tarasi iti devatāya puṭṭhaḥ pāram gantvā kulasantake raṭṭhe rajjam gahetvā
translated: So he was pleased, and he brought the young ones and gave them back to the Great Being. In the time of the Great People also, when he was crossing the great sea, he was asked by a deity, “Why are you crossing the great sea?” He replied, “I am going to the other side to take over the kingdom in the country of the Kusa grass.”

original: dānaṃ dātuṃ tarāmī”ti āha. Tato devatāya – “ayaṃ mahāsamuddo gambhīro ceva puthulo
analyzed: dānam dātum tarāmi iti āha tatas devatāya ayam mahā samuddaḥ gambhīraḥ ca iva puthulaḥ
translated: “I am eager to give alms.” Then the deity said, “This great ocean is deep and wide.

original: ca, kadā naṃ tarissatī”ti vutte so āha “taveso mahāsamuddasadiso, mayhaṃ pana ajjhāsayaṃ
analyzed: ca kadā nam tarissati iti vutte saḥ āha tava īsaḥ mahā samudda sadisaḥ mayham pana ajjhāsayam
translated: When will you cross it?” When this was said, he replied, “This great ocean is like that, but to me, who have set my heart on it,

original: āgamma khuddakamātikā viya khāyati. Tvaṃyeva maṃ dakkhissasi samuddaṃ taritvā samuddapārato🔽dhanaṃ āharitvā kulasantakaṃ rajjaṃ gahetvā dānaṃ dadamāna”nti. Devatā “anomapurisena
analyzed: āgamma khuddaka mātikā viya khāyati tvam yā iva mama dakkhissasi samuddam taritvā samudda pāratas  dhanam āharitvā kula santakam rajjam gahetvā dānam dadamānanti devatāḥ anomapurisena
translated: it seems as small as a puddle. You will see me cross the ocean,🔽bring back wealth, take over the kingdom from my kinsmen, and give alms.” The deity thought, “It is not possible to dissuade this man, who is a true man,

original: gahitagahaṇaṃ na sakkā vissajjāpetu”nti bodhisattaṃ āliṅgetvā haritvā uyyāne nipajjāpesi.
analyzed: gahita gahaṇam na sakkā vissajjāpetunti bodhisattam āliṅgetvā haritvā uyyāne nipajjāpesi
translated: from his resolve.” So she embraced the Bodhisatta, carried him off, and laid him down in a pleasure garden.

original: So chattaṃ ussāpetvā divase divase pañcasatasahassapariccāgaṃ katvā aparabhāge nikkhamma
analyzed: saḥ chattam ussāpetvā divase divase pañca sata sahassa pariccāgam katvā apara bhāge nikkhamma
translated: He had an umbrella held over him and gave away five hundred thousand pieces of money every day. Later he went forth

original: pabbajito. Evaṃ mahāsatto na sakkā kenaci samaṇena vā…pe… brahmunā vā kusalasamādānaṃ
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ evam mahāsatto na sakkā kenacid samaṇena vā āpe brahmunā vā kusala samādānam
translated: and became a monk. Thus it is not possible for any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or anyone in the world to dissuade a great being🔽from his resolve to do what is skillful.

original: vissajjāpetuṃ. Tena vuttaṃ – “daḷhasamādāno ahosi kusalesu dhammesu avatthitasamādāno”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam daḷha samādānaḥ ahosi kusalesu dhammesu avatthita samādānaḥ ti
translated: He was one who had undertaken the undertaking of wholesome states with a strong will, with a strong aspiration.

original: Idāni yesu kusalesu dhammesu avatthitasamādāno ahosi, te dassetuṃ kāyasucaritetiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yesu kusalesu dhammesu avatthita samādānaḥ ahosi te dassetum kāya su carita iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show in what wholesome states he had undertaken the undertaking with a strong will, the Exalted One said, “In bodily good conduct,” and so forth.

original: Dānasaṃvibhāgeti ettha ca dānameva diyyanavasena dānaṃ, saṃvibhāgakaraṇavasena saṃvibhāgo.
analyzed: dāna saṃvibhāga iti ettha ca dānam eva diyyana vasena dānam saṃvibhāga karaṇa vasena saṃvibhāgaḥ
translated: In the passage, “in giving and sharing,” giving is giving in the sense of giving away, and sharing is sharing in the sense of making others partake.

original: Sīlasamādāneti pañcasīladasasīlacatupārisuddhisīlapūraṇakāle. Uposathūpavāseti cātuddasikādibhedassa
analyzed: sīla samādāne iti pañca sīla dasa sīla catu pārisuddhi sīla pūraṇa kāle uposatha upavāse iti cātuddasika ādi bhedassa
translated: In the passage, “in the undertaking of the precepts,” the undertaking of the precepts is the undertaking of the five precepts, the ten precepts, and the precepts of purification.🔽In the passage, “in the observance of the Uposatha,” the observance of the Uposatha is the observance of the Uposatha of the four requisites.

original: uposathassa upavasanakāle. Matteyyatāyāti mātukātabbavatte. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: uposathassa upavasana kāle matteyya tāya āti mātu kātabba vatte sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: In the passage, “in the duties to a mother,” a mother is one who has performed the duties of a mother. The same method applies to the other terms.

original: Aññataraññataresu cāti aññesu ca evarūpesu. Adhikusalesūti ettha atthi kusalā, atthi🔽adhikusalā. Sabbepi kāmāvacarā kusalā kusalā nāma, rūpāvacarā adhikusalā. Ubhopi
analyzed: aññatara aññataresu ca ati aññesu ca evarūpesu adhikusalesu iti ettha atthi kusalā atthi 🔽adhikusalā sabbe pi kāmāvacarā kusalā kusalā nāma rūpāvacarā adhikusalā ubho pi
translated: In the passage, “in other things that are highly profitable,” other things are other such things.

original: te kusalā nāma, arūpāvacarā adhikusalā. Sabbepi te kusalā nāma, sāvakapāramīpaṭilābhapaccayā
analyzed: te kusalāḥ nāma arūpāvacarāḥ adhikusalā sabbe pi te kusalāḥ nāma sāvaka pāramī paṭilābha paccayā
translated: They are called “wholesome” and are “more wholesome” in the sense of the supramundane wholesome. All these are called “wholesome” and are “more wholesome” in the sense of the wholesome of the disciple who has attained the perfections.

original: kusalā adhikusalā nāma. Tepi kusalā nāma, paccekabodhipaṭilābhapaccayā kusalā adhikusalā.
analyzed: kusalāḥ adhikusalāḥ nāma te pi kusalāḥ nāma pacceka bodhi paṭilābha paccayā kusalāḥ adhikusalā
translated: They are called “wholesome” and are “more wholesome” in the sense of the wholesome of the paccekabuddha who has attained enlightenment.

original: Tepi kusalā nāma, sabbaññutaññāṇappaṭilābhapaccayā pana kusalā idha “adhikusalā”ti
analyzed: te pi kusalāḥ nāma sabbaññu taññāṇa paṭilābha paccayā pana kusalāḥ idha adhikusalā ti
translated: They are called “wholesome” and are “more wholesome” in the sense of the wholesome of the Buddha who has attained omniscient knowledge.

original: adhippetā. Tesu adhikusalesu dhammesu daḷhasamādāno ahosi avatthitasamādāno.
analyzed: adhippetā tesu adhi kusalesu dhammesu daḷha samādānaḥ ahosi avatthita samādānaḥ
translated: He had a firm resolve, an unswerving resolve, with regard to these more wholesome states.

original: Kaṭattā upacitattāti ettha sakimpi kataṃ katameva, abhiṇhakaraṇena pana upacitaṃ
analyzed: kaṭa ttā upacita ttā ati ettha katam katam eva abhiṇha karaṇena pana upacitam
translated: “Done and stored up”: what is done once is just done; it is stored up by doing it again and again.

original: hoti. Ussannattāti piṇḍīkataṃ rāsīkataṃ kammaṃ ussannanti vuccati. Tasmā “ussannattā”ti🔽vadanto mayā katakammassa cakkavāḷaṃ atisambādhaṃ, bhavaggaṃ atinīcaṃ, evaṃ me ussannaṃ
analyzed: hoti ussanna ttā ati piṇḍīkatam rāsīkatam kammaṃ ussannanti vuccati tasmai ussanna ttā ati  vadantaḥ mayā kata kammassa cakkavāḷam ati sambādham bhavaggam ati nīcam evam me ussannam
translated: “Abundant”: the kamma that is heaped up, piled up, is called “abundant.” Thus by saying “abundant” he shows that the world-sphere of the kamma he has done is too narrow, the peak of existence too low, and that his kamma is so abundant that

original: kammanti dasseti. Vipulattāti appamāṇattā. Iminā “anantaṃ aparimāṇaṃ mayā kataṃ kamma”nti
analyzed: kammanti dasseti vipula ttā ati appamāṇa ttā iminā anantam aparimāṇam mayā katam kammanti
translated: it has overflowed. “Extensive”: immeasurable. By this he shows that the kamma he has done is infinite, immeasurable.

original: dasseti. Adhiggaṇhātīti adhibhavati, aññehi devehi atirekaṃ labhatīti attho. Paṭilabhatīti adhigacchati.
analyzed: dasseti adhiggaṇhāti iti adhibhavati aññehi devehi atirekam labhati iti attho paṭilabhati iti adhigacchati
translated: He shows. He overpowers: the meaning is that he surpasses other gods. He obtains: he reaches.

original: Sabbāvantehi pādatalehīti idaṃ “samaṃ pādaṃ bhūmiyaṃ nikkhipatī”ti etassa vitthāravacanaṃ.
analyzed: sabbāvantehi pāda talehi iti idam samam pādam bhūmiyam nikkhipati iti etassa vitthāra vacanam
translated: With the whole of the soles: this is the detailed explanation of ‘he places his foot evenly on the ground’.

original: Tattha sabbāvantehīti sabbapadesavantehi, na ekena padesena paṭhamaṃ phusati, na
analyzed: tattha sabbāvantehi iti sabba padesa vantehi na ekena padesena paṭhamam phusati na
translated: Herein, with the whole of the soles means with the whole of the surface of the soles. He does not touch the ground first with one part of the sole and then draw up the rest after it,

original: ekena pacchā, sabbeheva pādatalehi samaṃ phusati, samaṃ uddharati. Sacepi hi tathāgato🔽“anekasataporisaṃ narakaṃ akkamissāmī”ti pādaṃ abhinīharati. Tāvadeva ninnaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vātapūritā viya kammārabhastā unnamitvā pathavisamaṃ hoti. Unnataṭṭhānampi anto pavisati.
analyzed: ekena pacchā sabbehi iva pāda talehi samam phusati samam uddharati sace pi hi tathāgato  aneka sata porisam narakam akkamissāmi iti pādam abhinīharati tāvat eva ninna ṭṭhānam  vāta pūritāḥ kammāra bhastāḥ unnamitvā pathavi samam hoti unnata ṭṭhānam pi antar pavisati
translated: but he touches it and lifts it up evenly with the whole of the soles. For if the Perfect One extends a foot🔽thinking ‘I shall tread on hell’, then the low place immediately rises up like a bellows being filled with air and becomes level with the ground. And the high place subsides.

original: “Dūre akkamissāmī”ti abhinīharantassa sineruppamāṇopi pabbato suseditavettaṅkuro
analyzed: dūre akkamissāmi iti abhinīharantassa sineru pamāṇaḥ api pabbataḥ su sedita vettaṅkuraḥ
translated: If he extends a foot thinking ‘I shall tread far away’, then a mountain, even if it were as high as Sineru, would be levelled down like a mat of grass being planed down with a razor.

original: viya onamitvā pādasamīpaṃ āgacchati. Tathā hissa yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ katvā “yugandharapabbataṃ🔽akkamissāmī”ti pāde abhinīhaṭe pabbato onamitvā pādasamīpaṃ āgato. Sopi taṃ akkamitvā
analyzed: viya onamitvā pāda samīpam āgacchati tathā hissa yamaka pāṭihāriyam katvā yugandhara pabbatam  akkamissāmi iti pāde abhinīhaṭe pabbataḥ onamitvā pāda samīpam āgataḥ saḥ api tam akkamitvā
translated: and it comes to his feet. For when he had performed the Twin Miracle and thought, “I shall ascend Mount Yugandhara,” the mountain bent down so that he could ascend it. He ascended it and

original: dutiyapādena tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ akkami. Na hi cakkalakkhaṇena patiṭṭhātabbaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: dutiya pādena tāvatiṃsa bhavanam akkami na hi cakka lakkhaṇena patiṭṭhātabba ṭṭhānam
translated: then descended to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven with his second step. For the place where the Wheel-Treasure is to be established cannot be uneven. Stumps, thorns, gravel, and pebbles disappear,

original: visamaṃ bhavituṃ sakkoti. Khāṇu vā kaṇṭako vā sakkharā vā kathalā vā uccārapassāvakheḷasiṅghāṇikādīni🔽vā purimataraṃ vā apagacchanti, tattha tattheva vā pathaviṃ pavisanti. Tathāgatassa🔽hi sīlatejena puññatejena dhammatejena dasannaṃ pāramīnaṃ ānubhāvena ayaṃ mahāpathavī
analyzed: visamam bhavitum sakkoti khāṇu vā kaṇṭakaḥ vā sakkharā vā kathalā vā uccāra passāva kheḷa siṅghāṇika ādīni  vā purimataram vā apagacchanti tattha tattha iva vā pathavim pavisanti tathāgatassa  hi sīla tejena puñña tejena dhamma tejena dasannam pāramīnam ānubhāvena ayam mahā pathavī
translated: and excrement, urine, spittle, and snot disappear and sink into the earth. For the great earth is well watered and well tilled

original: sammā mudupupphābhikiṇṇā hoti.
analyzed: sammā mudu pupphā abhikiṇṇā hoti
translated: by the splendor of the Tathāgata’s virtue, by the splendor of his merit, by the splendor of his Dhamma, and by the power of his ten perfections.

original: 202. Sāgarapariyantanti sāgarasīmaṃ. Na hi tassa rajjaṃ karontassa antarā rukkho
analyzed: sāgara pariyantam ti sāgara sīmam na hi tassa rajjam karontassa antarā rukkho
translated: As far as the ocean’s shore: as far as the ocean’s boundary. For when he rules, no tree in his realm withers or is blown down or is cut down by axes.

original: vā pabbato vā nadī vā sīmā hoti mahāsamuddova sīmā. Tena vuttaṃ “sāgarapariyanta”nti.
analyzed: vā pabbataḥ vā nadī vā sīmā hoti mahā samuddaḥ iva sīmā tena vuttam sāgara pariyantan ti
translated: and a mountain, a river, or the ocean, is a boundary. Hence ‘as far as the ocean’ is said.🔽‘Free from oppression’ means free from thieves. For thieves are called ‘oppression’ because of the painful contact they give,

original: Akhilamanimittamakaṇṭakanti niccoraṃ. Corā hi kharasamphassaṭṭhena khilā, upaddavapaccayaṭṭhena
analyzed: akhilam animittam akaṇṭakam ti niccoram corāḥ hi khara samphassa ṭṭhena khilāḥ upaddava paccaya ṭṭhena
translated: ‘sign’ because of the condition they give for calamity,

original: nimittā, vijjhanaṭṭhena kaṇṭakāti vuccanti. Iddhanti samiddhaṃ. Phītanti sabbasampattiphāliphullaṃ.🔽Khemanti nibbhayaṃ. Sivanti nirupaddavaṃ. Nirabbudanti abbudavirahitaṃ, gumbaṃ gumbaṃ
analyzed: nimittāḥ vijjhana ṭṭhena kaṇṭakā ti vuccanti iddhanti samiddham phītanti sabba sampatti phāli phullam  khemanti nibbhayam sivanti nirupaddavam nirabbudanti abbuda virahitam gumbam gumbam
translated: ‘thorn’ because of the piercing they give. ‘Prosperous’ means well-developed. ‘Flourishing’ means fully developed with all kinds of success.🔽‘Safe’ means free from fear. ‘Happy’ means free from calamity. ‘Free from turmoil’ means free from turmoil. The meaning is: free from thieves who go about robbing after breaking into houses.

original: hutvā carantehi corehi virahitanti attho. Akkhambhiyoti avikkhambhanīyo. Na naṃ koci
analyzed: hutvā carantehi corehi virahitanti atthaḥ akkhambhiyā ti a vikkhambhanīyaḥ na nam koci
translated: ‘Unassailable’ means unassailable. No one

original: ṭhānato cāletuṃ sakkoti. Paccatthikenāti paṭipakkhaṃ icchantena. Paccāmittenāti paṭiviruddhena
analyzed: ṭhānataḥ cāletum sakkoti paccatthikena ati paṭipakkham icchantena pacca amittena ati paṭiviruddhena
translated: can move him from his place. ‘By an enemy’ means by one who wishes him ill. ‘By a foe’ means by one who is opposed to him.

original: amittena. Ubhayampetaṃ sapattavevacanaṃ. Abbhantarehīti anto uṭṭhitehi rāgādīhi.
analyzed: amittena ubhayampetam sapattavevacanam abbhantarehi iti antare uṭṭhitehi rāga ādīhi
translated: Both terms are synonyms for an adversary. ‘By any inner foe’ means by greed, etc., that arise internally.

original: Bāhirehīti samaṇādīhi. Tathā hi naṃ bāhirā devadattakokālikādayo samaṇāpi soṇadaṇḍakūṭadaṇḍādayo
analyzed: bāhirehi iti samaṇa ādīhi tathā hi naṃ bāhirāḥ devadatta kokālika ādayaḥ soṇadaṇḍa kūṭadaṇḍa ādayaḥ
translated: “By outsiders” means by ascetics and so on. For the outsiders, such as Devadatta, Kokālika, and so on, were ascetics,🔽and such as Soṇadaṇḍa, Kūṭadanta, and so on, were brahmans,

original: brāhmaṇāpi sakkasadisā devatāpi satta vassāni anubandhamāno māropi bakādayo brahmānopi
analyzed: brāhmaṇā api sakka sadisā devatā api satta vassāni anubandhamānaḥ māraḥ api baka ādayaḥ brahmānaḥ api
translated: and such as Sakka, who is equal to Brahmā, and the gods, and such as Māra, the crow, and so on, who are equal to Brahmā,

original: vikkhambhetuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu.
analyzed: vikkhambhetum na asakkhiṃsu
translated: were unable to suppress it for seven years while pursuing him.

original: Ettāvatā bhagavatā kammañca kammasarikkhakañca lakkhaṇañca lakkhaṇānisaṃso ca vutto
analyzed: ettāvatā bhagavatā kammañca kamma sarikkhakañca lakkhaṇañca lakkhaṇa anisaṃso ca vutto
translated: At this point the Buddha has spoken of the deed, the characteristic similar to the deed, the characteristic, and the benefit of the characteristic.

original: hoti. Kammaṃ nāma satasahassakappādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni daḷhavīriyena hutvā
analyzed: hoti kammam nāma sata sahassa kappa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni daḷha vīriyena hutvā
translated: The “deed” is the deed done by him with firm energy for four incalculables and a hundred thousand eons.

original: kataṃ kammaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma daḷhena hutvā katabhāvaṃ sadevako loko jānātūti
analyzed: katam kammam kammasarikkhakam nāma daḷhena hutvā kata bhāvam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ jānātu uti
translated: The “characteristic similar to the deed” is the characteristic of a great man called “well-planted feet,” which he said, “Let the world with its gods know that it was done with firmness.”

original: suppatiṭṭhitapādamahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma suppatiṭṭhitapādatā. Lakkhaṇānisaṃso
analyzed: su patiṭṭhita pāda mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam lakkhaṇam nāma su patiṭṭhita pāda tā lakkhaṇa anisaṃso
translated: The “characteristic” is the well-planted feet. The “benefit of the characteristic”

original: nāma paccatthikehi avikkhambhanīyatā.
analyzed: nāma paccatthikehi a vikkhambhanīya tā
translated: is the fact that he cannot be suppressed by adversaries.

original: 203. Tatthetaṃ vuccatīti tattha vutte kammādibhede aparampi idaṃ vuccati, gāthābandhaṃ
analyzed: tattha etam vuccati iti tattha vutte kamma ādi bhede aparam pi idam vuccati gāthābandham
translated: . “So it is said” : after the deed and so on have been spoken of in this way, this is also said, in verse form:

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Etā pana gāthā porāṇakattherā “ānandattherena ṭhapitā vaṇṇanāgāthā”ti
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam etā pana gāthā porāṇaka therā ānanda therena ṭhapitā vaṇṇanā gāthā ti
translated: and he spoke with reference to this. But these verses were handed down by the ancient elders with the comment that they were “explanatory verses set up by the Elder Ānanda.”

original: vatvā gatā. Aparabhāge therā “ekapadiko atthuddhāro”ti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: vatvā gatāḥ apara bhāge therāḥ ekapadiko āhaṃsu
translated: Later the elders said that they were “a single-line summary.”

original: Tattha sacceti vacīsacce. Dhammeti dasakusalakammapathadhamme. Dameti indriyadamane.🔽Saṃyameti sīlasaṃyame. “Soceyyasīlālayuposathesu cā”ti ettha kāyasoceyyādi tividhaṃ
analyzed: tattha sacca iti vacī sacce dhamme iti dasa kusala kammapatha dhamme dame iti indriya damane  saṃyama iti sīla saṃyame soceyya sīla ālayu posathesu ca ati ettha kāya soceyya ādi tividham
translated: Herein, in truth : in verbal truth. In Dhamma : in the Dhamma of the ten profitable courses of action. In self-control : in self-control of the faculties.🔽In restraint : in restraint by virtue. In the case of “in virtue, in the basis for virtue, in the Uposatha” , what is meant is the threefold virtue of bodily purity, etc.,

original: soceyyaṃ. Ālayabhūtaṃ sīlameva sīlālayo. Uposathakammaṃ uposatho. Ahiṃsāyāti avihiṃsāya.
analyzed: soceyyam ālaya bhūtam sīlam eva sīla ālayaḥ uposatha kammam uposathaḥ ahiṃsāya ati a vihiṃsāya
translated: and the virtue that is the basis for virtue, and the Uposatha rite. In harmlessness : in non-violence.

original: Samattamācarīti sakalaṃ acari.
analyzed: sa mattam ācari iti sakalam acari
translated: He practised the whole : he practised the whole of it.

original: Anvabhīti anubhavi. Veyyañjanikāti lakkhaṇapāṭhakā. Parābhibhūti pare abhibhavanasamattho. Sattubhīti sapattehi akkhambhiyo hoti.
analyzed: anvabhi iti anubhavi veyyañjanikā ati lakkhaṇa pāṭhakā para abhibhūti pare abhibhavana samattho sattu bhi iti sa pattehi akkhambhiyaḥ hoti
translated: He experienced : he experienced it. The reciters of the characteristic say “Veyyañjana” . He was able to overpower others : he was able to overpower others. He was not overcome by his enemies : he was not overcome by his opponents.

original: Na so gacchati jātu khambhananti so ekaṃseneva aggapuggalo vikkhambhetabbataṃ na gacchati. Esā hi tassa dhammatāti tassa hi esā dhammatā ayaṃ sabhāvo.
analyzed: na saḥ gacchati jātu khambhanan ti saḥ ekaṃsena iva agga puggalaḥ vikkhambhetabba tam na gacchati esā hi tassa dhamma tā ati tassa hi esā dhamma tā ayam sabhāvaḥ
translated: He never goes to the suppression : he never goes to the suppression of the foremost position by any means. This is his nature : this is his nature, this is his essence.

original: Pādatalacakkalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽204. Ubbegauttāsabhayanti ubbegabhayañceva uttāsabhayañca. Tattha corato vā rājato
analyzed: ubbega auttāsa bhayanti ubbega bhayañca iva uttāsa bhayañca tattha corataḥ vā rājato
translated: The explanation of the mark of wheels on the soles of the feet.

original: vā paccatthikato vā vilopanabandhanādinissayaṃ bhayaṃ ubbego nāma, taṃmuhuttikaṃ
analyzed: vā paccatthikataḥ vā vilopana bandhana ādi nissayam bhayam ubbegaḥ nāma taṃ muhuttikam
translated: Fear of terror and fear of fright : fear of terror and fear of fright. Herein, fear of terror is fear of loss of life, of imprisonment, etc., due to thieves, kings, or enemies. That is momentary

original: caṇḍahatthiassādīni vā ahiyakkhādayo vā paṭicca lomahaṃsanakaraṃ bhayaṃ uttāsabhayaṃ
analyzed: caṇḍa hatthi assa ādīni vā ahi yakkha ādayaḥ vā paṭicca loma haṃsana karam bhayam uttāsa bhayam
translated: Fear of fright is fear that causes the hair to stand erect, due to a fierce elephant, horse, etc., or to a snake, ogre, etc. All that is removed and allayed.

original: nāma. Taṃ sabbaṃ apanuditā vūpasametā. Saṃvidhātāti saṃvidahitā. Kathaṃ saṃvidahati?🔽Aṭaviyaṃ sāsaṅkaṭṭhānesu dānasālaṃ kāretvā tattha āgate bhojetvā manusse datvā ativāheti,
analyzed: nāma tat sabbam apanuditā vūpasametā saṃvidhātā ati saṃvidahitā katham saṃvidahati  aṭaviyam sāsaṅka ṭṭhānesu dāna sālam kāretvā tattha āgate bhojetvā manusse da tvā ativāha iti
translated: He has provided : he has provided. How has he provided?🔽In a forest in a place of danger he has a rest-house built and has given food to those who come there, and he has them escorted beyond the place.

original: taṃ ṭhānaṃ pavisituṃ asakkontānaṃ manusse pesetvā paveseti. Nagarādīsupi tesu tesu
analyzed: tam ṭhānam pavisitum a sakkontānam manusse pesetvā paveseti nagara ādīsu pi tesu tesu
translated: He sends men to those who are unable to enter the place and has them escorted in. In towns, etc., too, he has rest-houses built and has given food to those who come there, and he has them escorted beyond the place.

original: ṭhānesu ārakkhaṃ ṭhapeti, evaṃ saṃvidahati. Saparivārañca dānaṃ adāsīti annaṃ pānanti
analyzed: ṭhānesu ārakkham ṭhapeti evam saṃvidahati sa parivāram ca dānam adāsi iti annam pānanti
translated: He made arrangements for protection in the places where the gifts were to be given. He gave gifts together with the requisites.

original: dasavidhaṃ dānavatthuṃ.
analyzed: dasavidham
translated: The requisites are the ten kinds of gifts beginning with food and drink.🔽Herein, food is rice gruel and cooked food.

original: Tattha annanti yāgubhattaṃ. Taṃ dadanto na dvāre ṭhapetvā adāsi, atha kho antonivesane
analyzed: tattha annam ti yāgu bhattam tam dadantaḥ na dvāre ṭhapetvā adāsi atha kho antonivesane
translated: When he gave this, he did not give it by placing it at the door. Instead, he had it placed in the inner palace

original: haritupalittaṭṭhāne lājā ceva pupphāni ca vikiritvā āsanaṃ paññapetvā vitānaṃ bandhitvā🔽gandhadhūmādīhi sakkāraṃ katvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ nisīdāpetvā yāguṃ adāsi. Yāguṃ dento
analyzed: harita upalitta ṭṭhāne lājā ca iva pupphāni ca vikiritvā āsanam paññapetvā vitānam bandhitvā  gandha dhūma ādīhi sakkāram katvā bhikkhu saṅgham nisīdāpetvā yāgum adāsi yāgum dentaḥ
translated: on a green and white cloth, and after strewing it with jasmine flowers, he prepared a seat, put up a canopy,🔽and after honoring it with incense, perfumes, etc., he had the Community of Bhikkhus sit down and gave them the rice gruel.🔽When he gave the rice gruel, he gave it with condiments.

original: ca sabyañjanaṃ adāsi. Yāgupānāvasāne pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā nānappakārakaṃ
analyzed: ca sa byañjanam adāsi yāgu pāna avasāne pāde dhovitvā telena makkhetvā nānappakārakam
translated: After the rice gruel and the meal of cooked rice, he washed their feet, anointed them with oil, gave them various kinds of

original: anantaṃ khajjakaṃ datvā pariyosāne anekasūpaṃ anekabyañjanaṃ paṇītabhojanaṃ adāsi.
analyzed: anantam khajjakam da tvā pariyosāne aneka sūpam aneka byañjanam paṇīta bhojanam adāsi
translated: inexhaustible mouthfuls of food, and finally gave them the excellent meal with many curries and condiments.

original: Pānaṃ dento ambapānādiaṭṭhavidhaṃ pānaṃ adāsi, tampi yāgubhattaṃ datvā. Vatthaṃ dento
analyzed: pānam dentaḥ amba pāna ādi aṭṭhavidham pānam adāsi tam pi yāgu bhattam da tvā vattham dentaḥ
translated: When he gave the drink, he gave the eight kinds of drinks beginning with mango drink. He gave this after the rice gruel and the meal of cooked rice. When he gave the cloth,

original: na suddhavatthameva adāsi, ekapaṭṭadupaṭṭādipahonakaṃ pana datvā sucimpi adāsi, suttampi
analyzed: na suddhavattham eva adāsi eka paṭṭa dupaṭṭa ādi pahonakam pana da tvā adāsi suttampi
translated: He did not give only pure cloth, but he gave what was pure after giving a piece of cloth, a small piece of cloth, etc., and he gave what was spun,

original: adāsi, suttaṃ vaṭṭesi, sūcikammakaraṇaṭṭhāne bhikkhūnaṃ āsanāni, yāgubhattaṃ, pādamakkhanaṃ,🔽piṭṭhimakkhanaṃ, rajanaṃ, paṇḍupalāsaṃ, rajanadoṇikaṃ, antamaso cīvararajanakaṃ kappiyakārakampi adāsi.
analyzed: adāsi suttam vaṭṭesi sūcikamma karaṇa ṭṭhāne bhikkhūnam āsanāni yāgu bhattam pāda makkhanam  piṭṭhi makkhanam rajanam paṇḍu palāsam rajana doṇikam antamasaḥ cīvara rajanakam kappiya kārakam pi adāsi
translated: he spun yarn, he had seats made for the monks in the place where the needlework was done, and he gave them rice gruel, rice, foot ointment,🔽back ointment, dye, green leaves, a dye-pot, and he even gave a dye-maker who was an attendant.

original: Yānanti upāhanaṃ. Taṃ dadantopi upāhanatthavikaṃ upāhanadaṇḍakaṃ makkhanatelaṃ heṭṭhā
analyzed: yānanti upāhanam tam dadantaḥ api upāhana thavikam upāhana daṇḍakam makkhana telam heṭṭhā
translated: Conveyance: a pair of sandals. When giving that, he gave the case for the sandals, the stick for the sandals, the oil for anointing the feet,

original: vuttāni ca annādīni tasseva parivāraṃ katvā adāsi. Mālaṃ dentopi na suddhamālameva
analyzed: vuttāni ca anna ādīni tassa iva parivāram katvā adāsi mālam dentaḥ api na suddha mālam eva
translated: and the things mentioned above, beginning with food, as its attendant. When giving a garland, he did not give only a pure garland,

original: adāsi, atha kho naṃ gandhehi missetvā heṭṭhimāni cattāri tasseva parivāraṃ katvā
analyzed: adāsi atha kho nam gandhehi missetvā heṭṭhimāni cattāri tassa iva parivāram katvā
translated: but he mixed it with perfumes and he gave the four things mentioned above as its attendant. When giving perfume,

original: adāsi. Bodhicetiyaāsanapotthakādipūjanatthāya ceva cetiyagharadhūpanatthāya ca gandhaṃ
analyzed: adāsi bodhi cetiya āsana potthaka ādi pūjana tthāya ca iva cetiya ghara dhūpana tthāya ca gandham
translated: he gave it for the purpose of worshipping the Bodhi Tree, the shrine, the seats, the books, etc., and for the purpose of incense in the shrine.

original: dentopi na suddhagandhameva adāsi, gandhapisanakanisadāya ceva pakkhipanakabhājanena
analyzed: dentaḥ api na suddha gandham eva adāsi gandha pisanaka nisadāya ca iva pakkhipanaka bhājanena
translated: and he did not give pure perfume, but perfume mixed with other things, and in a container for keeping it in,

original: ca saddhiṃ heṭṭhimāni pañca tassa parivāraṃ katvā adāsi. Cetiyapūjādīnaṃ atthāya🔽haritālamanosilācīnapiṭṭhādivilepanaṃ dentopi na suddhavilepanameva adāsi, vilepanabhājanena🔽saddhiṃ heṭṭhimāni cha tassa parivāraṃ katvā adāsi. Seyyāti mañcapīṭhaṃ. Taṃ dentopi🔽na suddhakameva adāsi, kojavakambalapaccattharaṇamañcappaṭipādakehi saddhiṃ antamaso
analyzed: ca saddhim heṭṭhimāni pañca tassa parivāram katvā adāsi cetiya pūjā ādīnam atthāya  haritāla manaḥ silā cīna piṭṭha ādi vilepanam dentaḥ api na suddha vilepanam eva adāsi vilepana bhājanena  saddhim heṭṭhimāni cha tassa parivāram katvā adāsi mañca pīṭham tam dentaḥ api  na suddhakam eva adāsi kojava kambala paccattharaṇa mañca paṭipādakehi saddhim antamasaḥ
translated: He did not give pure perfume, but he gave the five lower things together with the perfume, the box for the perfume, and the receptacle for the perfume.🔽He did not give pure ointment, but he gave the six lower things together with the ointment, the ointment box,

original: maṅgulasodhanadaṇḍakaṃ heṭṭhimāni ca satta tassa parivāraṃ katvā adāsi. Āvasathaṃ🔽dentopi na gehamattameva adāsi, atha kho naṃ mālākammalatākammapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ supaññattaṃ
analyzed: maṅgula sodhana daṇḍakam heṭṭhimāni ca satta tassa parivāram katvā adāsi āvasathaṃ  dentaḥ api na geha mattam eva adāsi atha kho nam mālā kamma latā kamma paṭimaṇḍitam su paññattam
translated: and the receptacle for the ointment. “Bed” means a bed and a chair. He did not give pure ones, but he gave the seven lower things together with the bed and the chair, the bedspread, the pillow, the mattress, the mosquito net, the bed net,

original: mañcapīṭhaṃ kāretvā heṭṭhimāni aṭṭha tassa parivāraṃ katvā adāsi. Padīpeyyanti padīpatelaṃ.
analyzed: mañca pīṭham kāretvā heṭṭhimāni aṭṭha tassa parivāram katvā adāsi padīpeyyanti padīpa telam
translated: and the bed pole. “Dwelling” means a house. He did not give a pure house, but he gave the eight lower things together with the house, the bed, the chair, the bedspread, the pillow, the mattress, the mosquito net, the bed net,🔽and the bed pole. “Lamp” means lamp oil.

original: Taṃ dento cetiyaṅgaṇe bodhiyaṅgaṇe dhammassavanagge vasanagehe potthakavācanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: tam dento cetiya aṅgaṇe bodhiyaṅgaṇe dhammassavana gge vasana gehe potthaka vācanaṭṭhāne
translated: When he gave it, he gave it in the shrine-terrace, in the Bo-tree terrace, in the preaching-hall, in the dwelling-place, in the place for reading the scriptures,

original: iminā dīpaṃ jālāpethāti na suddhatelameva adāsi, vaṭṭi kapallakatelabhājanādīhi saddhiṃ
analyzed: iminā dīpam na suddha telam eva adāsi vaṭṭi kapallaka tela bhājana ādīhi saddhim
translated: ‘With this let him light the island’—he did not give just pure oil, but he gave it with wicks, with oil-pots, with oil-vessels, etc.,

original: heṭṭhimāni nava tassa parivāraṃ katvā adāsi. Suvibhattantarānīti suvibhattaantarāni.
analyzed: heṭṭhimāni nava tassa parivāram katvā adāsi su vibhatta antarāni iti su vibhatta antarāni
translated: and he gave the nine lower ones as his attendant retinue. ‘Well-divided intervals’: the intervals are well-divided.

original: Rājānoti abhisittā. Bhogiyāti bhojakā kumārāti rājakumārā. Idha kammaṃ nāma saparivāraṃ
analyzed: rājānaḥ iti abhisittāḥ bhogiyā ati bhojakā kumārā ati rāja kumārāḥ idha kammam nāma sa parivāram
translated: ‘King’: one who is anointed. ‘Enjoyers’: those who enjoy. ‘Princes’: royal princes. Herein, the ‘ deed’ is a gift with attendant retinue.

original: dānaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma saparivāraṃ katvā dānaṃ adāsīti iminā kāraṇena sadevako
analyzed: dānam kammasarikkhakam nāma sa parivāram katvā dānam adāsi iti iminā kāraṇena sa devakaḥ
translated: ‘The deed’s equal’ is a gift given with attendant retinue. For this reason let the world know with its gods

original: loko jānātūti nibbattaṃ cakkalakkhaṇaṃ. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma tadeva cakkalakkhaṇaṃ. Ānisaṃso mahāparivāratā.
analyzed: lokaḥ jānātu uti nibbattam cakka lakkhaṇam lakkhaṇam nāma tat eva cakka lakkhaṇam ānisaṃsaḥ mahā parivāra tā
translated: that the wheel-mark has appeared. The ‘ mark’ is that very wheel-mark. The ‘advantage’ is the possession of a great retinue.

original: 205. Tatthetaṃ vuccatīti imā tadatthaparidīpanā gāthā vuccanti. Duvidhā hi gāthā
analyzed: tattha etam vuccati iti imāḥ tad attha paridīpanāḥ gāthāḥ vuccanti duvidhā hi gāthā
translated: . So this is said: these verses explaining the meaning are said. For there are two kinds of verses,

original: honti – tadatthaparidīpanā ca visesatthaparidīpanā ca. Tattha pāḷiāgatameva atthaṃ
analyzed: honti tad attha paridīpanā ca visesa attha paridīpanā ca tattha pāḷi āgatam eva attham
translated: namely, those explaining the meaning and those explaining the special meaning. Herein, the meaning that is given in the text

original: paridīpanā tadatthaparidīpanā nāma. Pāḷiyaṃ anāgataṃ paridīpanā visesatthaparidīpanā🔽nāma. Imā pana tadatthaparidīpanā. Tattha pureti pubbe. Puratthāti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: paridīpanā tad attha paridīpanā nāma pāḷiyam anāgatam paridīpanā visesa attha paridīpanā  nāma imā pana tad attha paridīpanā tattha purā iti pubbe puratthā ti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: and the explanation of the meaning is called the “explanation of the meaning of that.” The explanation of what is not in the text is called the “explanation of the special meaning.”🔽But these are the explanations of the meaning. Herein, “formerly” means “previously.” “Before” is a synonym for that.

original: Purimāsu jātīsūti imissā jātiyā pubbekatakammapaṭikkhepadīpanaṃ. Ubbegauttāsabhayāpanūdanoti
analyzed: purimāsu jātīsu iti imissā jātiyā pubbekata kamma paṭikkhepa dīpanam ubbega uttāsa bhaya apanūdanaḥ ti
translated: “In former births” is said to be a rejection of this birth. “The dispeller of fear, terror, and dread”

original: ubbegabhayassa ca uttāsabhayassa ca apanūdano. Ussukoti adhimutto.
analyzed: ubbega bhayassa ca uttāsa bhayassa ca apanūdanaḥ ussukoti adhimuttaḥ
translated: is the dispeller of the fear of terror and the fear of dread. “Eager” means “bent on.”

original: Satapuññalakkhaṇanti satena satena puññakammena nibbattaṃ ekekaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: sata puñña lakkhaṇam ti satena satena puñña kammena nibbattam ekekam lakkhaṇam evam
translated: “The marks of a hundred merits” means that each mark is produced by a hundredfold meritorious action.

original: sante yo koci buddho bhaveyyāti na rocayiṃsu, anantesu pana cakkavāḷesu sabbe sattā
analyzed: sante yaḥ koci buddhaḥ bhaveyya ati na rocayiṃsu anantesu pana cakkavāḷesu sabbe sattā
translated: If that is so, they did not approve of anyone becoming a Buddha. But in the infinite world systems all beings

original: ekekaṃ kammaṃ satakkhattuṃ kareyyuṃ, ettakehi janehi kataṃ kammaṃ bodhisatto ekova
analyzed: ekekam kammam sata kkhattum kareyyuṃ ettakehi janehi katam kammam bodhisatto ekaḥ iva
translated: would perform each action a hundred times. The Bodhisatta alone was born

original: ekekaṃ sataguṇaṃ katvā nibbatto. Tasmā “satapuññalakkhaṇo”ti imamatthaṃ rocayiṃsu.
analyzed: ekekam sataguṇam katvā nibbattaḥ tasmā sata puñña lakkhaṇaḥ ti imam attham rocayiṃsu
translated: having performed the action done by those people a hundred times each. Therefore they approved of the meaning “the marks of a hundred merits.”

original: Manussāsurasakkarakkhasāti manussā ca asurā ca sakkā ca rakkhasā ca.
analyzed: manussa asura sakka rakkhasā ti manussā ca asurā ca sakkā ca rakkhasā ca
translated: “Humans, suras, Sakkas, and rakkhasas” are humans, suras, Sakkas, and rakkhasas.

original: Āyatapaṇhitāditilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āyata paṇhita āditi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristic of long fingers, etc.

original: 206. Antarāti paṭisandhito sarasacutiyā antare. Idha kammaṃ nāma pāṇātipātā virati.
analyzed: paṭisandhito sarasa cutiyā antare idha kammam nāma pāṇa atipātāḥ virati
translated: “In between” means between rebirth-linking and the death of a living being. Herein, the “deed” is the abstention from killing living beings.

original: Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma pāṇātipātaṃ karonto padasaddasavanabhayā aggaggapādehi akkamantā
analyzed: kammasarikkhakam nāma pāṇātipātam karontaḥ pada sadda savana bhayā aggagga pādehi akkamantā
translated: The “similar kamma” is that when one who is killing living beings goes, stepping on the heads of others with the tips of his feet out of fear of hearing the sound of their feet,

original: gantvā paraṃ pātenti. Atha te iminā kāraṇena tesaṃ taṃ kammaṃ jano jānātūti antovaṅkapādā
analyzed: gantvā param atha te iminā kāraṇena tesam tam kammam janaḥ jānātu iti antar vaṅka pādā
translated: and kills others, then because of this reason, “Let people know this deed of mine,” he becomes one with inward-turned feet,

original: vā bahivaṅkapādā vā ukkuṭikapādā vā aggakoṇḍā vā paṇhikoṇḍā vā bhavanti. Aggapādehi
analyzed: vā bahi vaṅka pādāḥ vā ukkuṭika pādāḥ vā agga koṇḍāḥ vā paṇhi koṇḍāḥ vā bhavanti agga pādehi
translated: or outward-turned feet, or pigeon-toed, or knock-kneed.

original: gantvā parassa amāritabhāvaṃ pana tathāgatassa sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti
analyzed: gantvā parassa a mārita bhāvam pana tathāgatassa sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti
translated: But when he goes, stepping on the heads of others with the tips of his feet, and kills others, then because of this reason, “Let the world with its gods know that this one is not a human being,”🔽the characteristic of long fingers, which is a mark of a Great Man, is produced.

original: āyatapaṇhi mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Tathā paraṃ ghātentā unnatakāyena gacchantā
analyzed: āyata paṇhi mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam nibbattati tathā param ghātentā unnata kāyena gacchantā
translated: Likewise, when he goes, killing others with an elevated body,

original: aññe passissantīti onatā gantvā paraṃ ghātenti. Atha te evamime gantvā paraṃ ghātayiṃsūti
analyzed: aññe passissanti iti onatāḥ gantvā param ghātenti atha te evam ime gantvā param ghātayiṃsu iti
translated: ‘Others will see them’ means that they go bent over and kill others. Then, ‘They have gone and killed others’

original: nesaṃ taṃ kammaṃ iminā kāraṇena paro jānātūti khujjā vā vāmanā vā pīṭhasappi vā bhavanti.
analyzed: na īsam tam kammam iminā kāraṇena paraḥ jānātu uti khujjāḥ vā vāmanāḥ vā pīṭhasappi vā bhavanti
translated: means that they are hunchbacks, dwarfs, or lame.

original: Tathāgatassa pana evaṃ gantvā paresaṃ aghātitabhāvaṃ iminā kāraṇena sadevako loko
analyzed: tathāgatassa pana evam gantvā paresam a ghātita bhāvam iminā kāraṇena sa devakaḥ lokaḥ
translated: But the Tathāgata, ‘By this reason may the world with its gods

original: jānātūti brahmujugattamahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Tathā paraṃ ghātentā āvudhaṃ
analyzed: jānātu uti brahmu ju gatta mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam nibbattati tathā param ghātentā āvudham
translated: know that I have gone and not killed others’ produces the Great Man Mark of the straight-limbed one.

original: vā muggaraṃ vā gaṇhitvā muṭṭhikatahatthā paraṃ ghātenti. Te evaṃ tesaṃ parassa ghātitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vā muggaram vā gaṇhitvā muṭṭhikata hatthāḥ param ghātenti te evam tesam parassa ghātita bhāvaṃ
translated: But those who kill others, ‘By this reason may people know that we have killed others’

original: iminā kāraṇena jano jānātūti rassaṅgulī vā rassahatthā vā vaṅkaṅgulī vā phaṇahatthakā🔽vā bhavanti. Tathāgatassa pana evaṃ paresaṃ aghātitabhāvaṃ sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena
analyzed: iminā kāraṇena janaḥ jānātu uti rassaṅgulī vā rassahatthā vā vaṅkaṅgulī vā phaṇahatthakā  vā bhavanti tathāgatassa pana evam paresam a ghātita bhāvam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena
translated: produce short fingers, short hands, crooked fingers, or webbed hands.

original: jānātūti dīghaṅgulimahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Idamettha kammasarikkhakaṃ. Idameva
analyzed: jānātu uti dīgha aṅguli mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam nibbattati idam ettha kamma sarikkhakam idam eva
translated: But the Tathāgata, ‘By this reason may the world with its gods know that I have not killed others’ produces the Great Man Mark of long fingers. This is the corresponding deed. This is the

original: pana lakkhaṇattayaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ nāma. Dīghāyukabhāvo lakkhaṇānisaṃso.
analyzed: pana lakkhaṇattayam lakkhaṇam nāma dīgha āyuka bhāvaḥ lakkhaṇa anisaṃso
translated: but the three characteristics are called the characteristic. The state of long life is the benefit of the characteristic.

original: 207. Maraṇavadhabhayattanoti ettha maraṇasaṅkhāto vadho maraṇavadho, maraṇavadhato🔽bhayaṃ maraṇavadhabhayaṃ, taṃ attano jānitvā. Paṭivirato paraṃmāraṇāyāti yathā mayhaṃ
analyzed: ettha maraṇa saṅkhātaḥ vadhaḥ maraṇa vadhaḥ maraṇa vadhāt  bhayam maraṇa vadha bhayam tam jānitvā paṭivirataḥ paraṃmāraṇāya ati yathā mayham
translated: . Having known the fear of death and killing for himself: here, the killing called death is death and killing. The fear from death and killing🔽is the fear of death and killing. Having known that for himself, he was restrained from killing another: just as I have fear of death, my life is dear to me,

original: maraṇato bhayaṃ mama jīvitaṃ piyaṃ, evaṃ paresampīti ñatvā paraṃ māraṇato paṭivirato
analyzed: maraṇataḥ bhayam mama jīvitam piyam evam paresam pi iti ñatvā param māraṇataḥ paṭivirataḥ
translated: so it is for others too, thinking thus, he was restrained from killing another.

original: ahosi. Sucaritenāti suciṇṇena. Saggamagamāti saggaṃ gato.
analyzed: ahosi su caritena ati su ciṇṇena saggam agama ati saggam gataḥ
translated: By good conduct: by good practice. He went to the heavenly world: he went to heaven.

original: Caviya punaridhāgatoti cavitvā puna idhāgato. Dīghapāsaṇhikoti dīghapaṇhiko. Brahmāva sujūti brahmā viya suṭṭhu uju.🔽Subhujoti sundarabhujo. Susūti mahallakakālepi taruṇarūpo. Susaṇṭhitoti susaṇṭhānasampanno.
analyzed: caviya punar idhāgato ti cavitvā punar idhāgataḥ dīgha pāsaṇhikaḥ iti dīghapaṇhikaḥ brahmā ava suju iti brahmā viya suṭṭhu uju  su bhujaḥ iti sundara bhujaḥ taruṇa rūpaḥ su saṇṭhitaḥ iti su saṇṭhāna sampannaḥ
translated: Having died, he came here again: having died, he came here again. He was long-lived: he was long-lived. He was upright like Brahmā: he was upright like Brahmā.🔽He was well-proportioned: he was well-proportioned. He was young: even in old age he had the appearance of a youth. He was well-built: he was endowed with a good build.

original: Mudutalunaṅguliyassāti mudū ca talunā ca aṅguliyo assa. Tībhīti tīhi. Purisavaraggalakkhaṇehīti
analyzed: mudu talunā aṅguliyassa ati mudū ca talunā ca aṅguliyaḥ assa tībhi iti tīhi purisa varagga lakkhaṇehi iti
translated: He had soft and tender fingers: he had soft and tender fingers. With three: with three. With the characteristics of a great man:

original: purisavarassa aggalakkhaṇehi. Cirayapanāyāti ciraṃ yāpanāya, dīghāyukabhāvāya.
analyzed: purisa varassa agga lakkhaṇehi cira yapanāya ati ciram yāpanāya dīgha āyuka bhāvāya
translated: and the characteristics of the foremost of men. For the sake of long endurance: for the sake of long endurance, for the sake of a long life.

original: Ciraṃ yapetīti ciraṃ yāpeti. Cirataraṃ pabbajati yadi tatoti tato cirataraṃ yāpeti, yadi pabbajatīti attho. Yāpayati ca vasiddhibhāvanāyāti vasippatto hutvā iddhibhāvanāya yāpeti.
analyzed: ciram yapeti iti ciram yāpeti cirataram pabbajati yadi tato ti tato cirataram yāpeti yadi pabbajati iti atthaḥ yāpayati ca vasi ddhi bhāvanāya ati vasi ppattaḥ hutvā iddhi bhāvanāya yāpeti
translated: He endures for a long time: he endures for a long time. He endures for a longer time if he goes forth: if he goes forth, he endures for a longer time. This is the meaning. And he endures by developing psychic power: having become one who has attained psychic power, he endures by developing psychic power.

original: Sattussadatālakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattussada tā lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the seven characteristics of being well-filled.

original: 208. Rasitānanti rasasampannānaṃ. “Khādanīyāna”ntiādīsu khādanīyāni nāma piṭṭhakhajjakādīni.🔽Bhojanīyānīti pañca bhojanāni. Sāyanīyānīti sāyitabbāni sappinavanītādīni. Lehanīyānīti
analyzed: rasitānanti rasa sampannānam khādanīya ananti ādīsu khādanīyāni nāma piṭṭhakhajjaka ādīni  bhojanīyāni iti pañca bhojanāni sāyanīyāni iti sāyitabbāni sappi navanīta ādīni lehanīyāni iti
translated: With the best flavors: with flavors that are excellent. In the passage beginning “edible” , “edible” means cakes, pastries, etc.🔽“Drinkable” means the five kinds of drinks. “Suckable” means what should be sucked, such as ghee, curd, etc.🔽“Swallowable” means what should be swallowed, such as rice porridge, etc.

original: nillehitabbāni piṭṭhapāyāsādīni. Pānānīti aṭṭha pānakāni.
analyzed: nillehitabbāni piṭṭhapāyāsa ādīni pānāni iti aṭṭha pānakāni
translated: “Drink” means the eight kinds of beverages.

original: Idha kammaṃ nāma kappasatasahassādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni dinnaṃ idaṃ paṇītabhojanadānaṃ.
analyzed: kammam nāma kappa sata sahassa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni dinnam idam paṇīta bhojana dānam
translated: Herein, the deed is the giving of this excellent food for a period of four incalculables and a hundred thousand eons.

original: Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma lūkhabhojane kucchigate lohitaṃ sussati, maṃsaṃ milāyati. Tasmā
analyzed: kammasarikkhakam nāma lūkha bhojane kucchi gate lohitam sussati maṃsam milāyati tasmā
translated: When coarse food is eaten, blood dries up and flesh wastes away.

original: lūkhadāyakā sattā iminā kāraṇena nesaṃ lūkhabhojanassa dinnabhāvaṃ jano jānātūti🔽appamaṃsā appalohitā manussapetā viya dullabhannapānā bhavanti. Paṇītabhojane pana
analyzed: lūkha dāyakā sattā iminā kāraṇena na īsam lūkha bhojanassa dinna bhāvam janaḥ jānātu uti  appamaṃsāḥ appalohitāḥ manussa petāḥ viya bhavanti paṇīta bhojane pana
translated: Therefore, thinking “Let people know that I have given them coarse food,”🔽beings who give coarse food become, for this reason, like human ghosts, with little blood and little flesh, and with food and drink hard to obtain.

original: kucchigate maṃsalohitaṃ vaḍḍhati, paripuṇṇakāyā pāsādikā abhirūpadassanā honti. Tasmā
analyzed: kucchi gate maṃsa lohitam vaḍḍhati paripuṇṇa kāyā pāsādikāḥ abhirūpa dassanāḥ honti tasmā
translated: But when fine food is eaten, blood increases and flesh grows firm.

original: tathāgatassa dīgharattaṃ paṇītabhojanadāyakattaṃ sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti
analyzed: tathāgatassa dīgha rattam paṇīta bhojana dāyaka ttam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti
translated: Therefore, thinking “Let the world know that I have given fine food for a long time,”

original: sattussadamahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma sattussadalakkhaṇameva.
analyzed: sattussada mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam nibbattati lakkhaṇam nāma sattussada lakkhaṇam eva
translated: the mark of the Great Man consisting in having well-proportioned limbs arises. The mark is the mark of the well-proportioned limbs.

original: Paṇītalābhitā ānisaṃso.
analyzed: paṇīta lābhi tā ānisaṃsaḥ
translated: The benefit is that he obtains the best kinds of food.

original: 209. Khajjabhojjamathaleyyasāyitanti khajjakañca bhojanañca lehanīyañca sāyanīyañca. Uttamaggarasadāyakoti uttamo aggarasadāyako, uttamānaṃ vā aggarasānaṃ dāyako.
analyzed: khajja bhojja matha leyya sāyitanti khajjakam ca bhojanam ca lehanīyañca sāyanīyañca uttama agga rasa dāyakaḥ iti uttamaḥ agga rasa dāyakaḥ uttamānam vā agga rasānam dāyakaḥ
translated: “Hard food, soft food, and drinks, and also things to suck and to chew” : hard food , soft food , and drinks , and also things to suck and to chew. “He gives the best kinds of food”: he gives the best, the most excellent kinds of food, or he gives the best, the most excellent foods.

original: Satta cussadeti satta ca ussade. Tadatthajotakanti khajjabhojjādijotakaṃ, tesaṃ lābhasaṃvattanikanti
analyzed: satta ca ussade ti satta ca ussade tad attha jotakanti khajja bhojja ādi jotakam tesam lābha saṃvattanikam ti
translated: Seven kinds of praise and seven kinds of blame. The meaning is: the praise consisting of the words “He eats what is picked up and so on,” which is conducive to his gain.

original: attho. Pabbajampi cāti pabbajamānopi ca. Tadādhigacchatīti taṃ adhigacchati. Lābhiruttamanti lābhi uttamaṃ.
analyzed: pabbajam pi ca ati pabbajamānaḥ api ca tadā adhigacchati iti tam adhigacchati lābhiḥ uttamam ti lābhi uttamam
translated: And also the going forth: and also the going forth. He attains: he attains that. The best gain: the best gainer.

original: Karacaraṇādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kara caraṇa ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the characteristics beginning with the hands

original: 210. Dānenātiādīsu ekacco dāneneva saṅgaṇhitabbo hoti, taṃ dānena saṅgahesi. Pabbajitānaṃ pabbajitaparikkhāraṃ, gihīnaṃ gihiparikkhāraṃ adāsi.
analyzed: dānena ati ādīsu ekaccaḥ dānena iva saṅgaṇhitabbaḥ hoti tam dānena saṅgahesi pabbajitānam pabbajita parikkhāram gihīnam gihi parikkhāram adāsi
translated: In regard to what is said with “by giving” and so on, some people are to be won over by giving, and he won them over by giving. He gave the requisites of the bhikkhus to the bhikkhus and the requisites of the householders to the householders.

original: Peyyavajjenāti ekacco hi “ayaṃ dātabbaṃ nāma deti, ekena pana vacanena sabbaṃ makkhetvā
analyzed: peyya vajjena ati ekaccaḥ hi ayam dātabbam nāma deti ekena pana vacanena sabbam makkhetvā
translated: By the gift of water: for some people say, “He gives what should be given, but he insults everyone with a single word and

original: nāseti, kiṃ etassa dāna”nti vattā hoti. Ekacco “ayaṃ kiñcāpi dānaṃ na deti, kathento
analyzed: na āseti kim etassa dānanti vattā hoti ekaccaḥ ayam kiñcā api dānam na deti kathento
translated: throws it away. What is the use of his giving?” But some say, “Although he does not give a gift, when he speaks he

original: pana telena viya makkheti. Eso detu vā mā vā, vacanameva tassa sahassaṃ agghatī”ti
analyzed: pana telena viya makkheti esaḥ detu vā mā vā vacanam eva tassa sahassam agghati iti
translated: insults with it as if with oil. Whether he gives or not, his word alone is worth a thousand.”

original: vattā hoti. Evarūpo puggalo dānaṃ na paccāsīsati, piyavacanameva paccāsīsati. Taṃ
analyzed: vattā hoti evarūpaḥ puggalaḥ dānam na paccāsīsati piya vacanam eva paccāsīsati taṃ
translated: He does not want to give a gift. He wants only to speak pleasantly.

original: piyavacanena saṅgahesi.
analyzed: piya vacanena saṅgahesi
translated: He has won him over by pleasant speech.

original: Atthacariyāyāti atthasaṃvaḍḍhanakathāya. Ekacco hi neva dānaṃ, na piyavacanaṃ paccāsīsati.
analyzed: attha cariyāya ati attha saṃvaḍḍhana kathāya ekaccaḥ hi na iva dānam na piya vacanam paccāsīsati
translated: By service of welfare: by talk that increases welfare. For some people do not want to give a gift or to speak pleasantly.🔽They want only talk that increases their own welfare. He has won such a person over

original: Attano hitakathaṃ vaḍḍhitakathameva paccāsīsati. Evarūpaṃ puggalaṃ “idaṃ te kātabbaṃ,
analyzed: attanaḥ hita katham vaḍḍhita katham eva paccāsīsati evarūpam puggalam idam te kātabbam
translated: by saying, “This is what you should do,

original: idaṃ te na kātabbaṃ. Evarūpo puggalo sevitabbo, evarūpo puggalo na sevitabbo”ti evaṃ
analyzed: idam te na kātabbam evarūpaḥ puggalo sevitabbaḥ evarūpaḥ puggalo na sevitabbaḥ iti evam
translated: this is what you should not do. This is the sort of person you should associate with, this is the sort of person you should not associate with.”

original: atthacariyāya saṅgahesi.
analyzed: attha cariyāya saṅgahesi
translated: He has won him over by service of welfare.

original: Samānattatāyāti samānasukhadukkhabhāvena. Ekacco hi dānādīsu ekampi na paccāsīsati,
analyzed: samānattatāya ati samāna sukha dukkha bhāvena ekaccaḥ hi dāna ādīsu ekam pi na paccāsīsati
translated: By sameness of purpose: by sharing in his pleasures and pains. For some people do not want to give a gift or to speak pleasantly or to serve welfare.

original: ekāsane nisajjaṃ, ekapallaṅke sayanaṃ, ekato bhojananti evaṃ samānasukhadukkhataṃ
analyzed: eka āsane nisajjam eka pallaṅke sayanam ekatas bhojana nti evam samāna sukha dukkha tam
translated: They want only to share in his pleasures and pains by sitting on the same seat, lying on the same bed, and eating the same food.

original: paccāsīsati. Tattha jātiyā hīno bhogena adhiko dussaṅgaho hoti. Na hi sakkā tena
analyzed: tattha jātiyāḥ hīnaḥ bhogena adhikaḥ dussaṅgahaḥ hoti na hi sakkā tena
translated: Herein, one who is inferior in birth but superior in wealth is difficult to win over. For it is not possible to say to him, “Sit here,” or “Lie down here,” or “Eat this.”

original: saddhiṃ ekaparibhogo kātuṃ, tathā akariyamāne ca so kujjhati. Bhogena hīno jātiyā
analyzed: saddhim eka paribhogaḥ kātum tathā a kariyamāne ca saḥ kujjhati bhogena hīnaḥ jātiyā
translated: and he is angry if it is not done. The one who is inferior in wealth but superior in birth

original: adhikopi dussaṅgaho hoti. So hi “ahaṃ jātimā”ti bhogasampannena saddhiṃ ekaparibhogaṃ🔽na icchati, tasmiṃ akariyamāne kujjhati. Ubhohipi hīno pana susaṅgaho hoti. Na hi
analyzed: adhikaḥ api dussaṅgahaḥ hoti saḥ hi aham jātimā ati bhoga sampannena saddhim eka paribhogam  na icchati tasmin a kariyamāne kujjhati ubhohi pi hīnaḥ pana su saṅgahaḥ hoti na hi
translated: is hard to associate with. For he does not want to share a meal with one who is wealthy, thinking “I am superior in birth.”🔽And he is angry if it is done. But the one who is inferior in both is easy to associate with. For he does not want to share a meal with the other,

original: so itarena saddhiṃ ekaparibhogaṃ icchati, na akariyamāne ca kujjhati. Ubhohi sadisopi
analyzed: saḥ itarena saddhim eka paribhogam icchati na a kariyamāṇe ca kujjhati ubhohi sadisaḥ api
translated: and he is not angry if it is not done. The one who is equal in both is also easy to associate with.

original: susaṅgahoyeva. Bhikkhūsu dussīlo dussaṅgaho hoti. Na hi sakkā tena saddhiṃ ekaparibhogo
analyzed: su saṅgahaḥ yā iva bhikkhūsu dussīlaḥ dussaṅgahaḥ hoti na hi sakkā tena saddhim eka paribhogaḥ
translated: Among bhikkhus, the one who is immoral is hard to associate with. For it is not possible to share a meal with him,

original: kātuṃ, tathā akariyamāne ca kujjhati. Sīlavā susaṅgaho hoti. Sīlavā hi adīyamānepi
analyzed: kātum tathā a kariyamāne ca kujjhati sīlavā su saṅgahaḥ hoti sīlavā hi a dīyamāne pi
translated: and he is angry if it is not done. But the virtuous one is easy to associate with. For the virtuous one is not angry if it is not done

original: akariyamānepi na kujjhati. Aññaṃ attanā saddhiṃ paribhogaṃ akarontampi na pāpakena
analyzed: a kariyamāne api na kujjhati aññam attanā saddhim paribhogam a karontam pi na pāpakena
translated: or if it is not offered. He does not look with evil intent on another who does not share a meal with him or does not offer him one.

original: cittena passati. Paribhogopi tena saddhiṃ sukaro hoti. Tasmā evarūpaṃ puggalaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: cittena passati paribhogaḥ api tena saddhim sukaraḥ hoti tasmai evarūpam puggalam evam
translated: And it is easy to share a meal with him. Therefore one should associate with such a person

original: samānattatāya saṅgahesi.
analyzed: samānatta tāyai saṅgahesi
translated: by equality.

original: Susaṅgahitāssa hontīti susaṅgahitā assa honti. Detu vā mā vā detu, karotu vā mā vā🔽karotu, susaṅgahitāva honti, na bhijjanti. “Yadāssa dātabbaṃ hoti, tadā deti. Idāni🔽maññe natthi, tena na deti. Kiṃ mayaṃ dadamānameva upaṭṭhahāma? Adentaṃ akarontaṃ
analyzed: su saṅgahitāḥ assa honti iti su saṅgahitāḥ assa honti detu vā mā vā detu karotu vā mā vā  karotu su saṅgahitā ava honti na bhijjanti yadā assa dātabbam hoti tadā deti idāni  maññe natthi tena na deti kim mayam dadamānam eva upaṭṭhahāma a dentam a karontam
translated: They are well-kept: they are well-kept. Whether he gives or does not give, whether he does or does not do, they are well-kept, they do not break up. “When it is time to give, he gives. Now it seems there is none, therefore he does not give. Do we attend only on him when he is giving? When he is not giving, not doing,

original: na upaṭṭhahāmā”ti evaṃ cintenti.🔽Idha kammaṃ nāma dīgharattaṃ kataṃ dānādisaṅgahakammaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma yo🔽evaṃ asaṅgāhako hoti, so iminā kāraṇenassa asaṅgāhakabhāvaṃ jano jānātūti thaddhahatthapādo🔽ceva hoti, visamaṭṭhitāvayavalakkhaṇo ca. Tathāgatassa pana dīgharattaṃ saṅgāhakabhāvaṃ🔽sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti imāni dve lakkhaṇāni nibbattanti. Lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: na upaṭṭhahāma iti evam cintenti  idha kammam nāma dīgharattam katam dāna ādi saṅgaha kammam kammasarikkhakam nāma yaḥ  evam asaṅgāhakaḥ hoti saḥ iminā kāraṇena assa asaṅgāhaka bhāvam janaḥ jānātu uti thaddha hattha pādaḥ  ca iva hoti visama ṭṭhita avayava lakkhaṇo ca tathāgatassa pana dīgharattam saṅgāhaka bhāvam  sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti imāni dve lakkhaṇāni nibbattanti lakkhaṇam
translated: They are well-disposed to him: they are well-disposed to him. Whether he gives or does not give, whether he does or does not do what they want, they are well-disposed to him, they do not desert him. They think: “When he has something to give he gives it. Now he has nothing, that is why he does not give. Are we to wait only when he is giving? When he is not giving and not doing what we want, are we not to wait on him?”

original: nāma idameva lakkhaṇadvayaṃ. Susaṅgahitaparijanatā ānisaṃso.
analyzed: nāma idam eva lakkhaṇa dvayam su saṅgahita parijana tā ānisaṃso
translated: Herein, the deed is the deed of giving, etc., done for a long time. The resemblance to the deed is that the man who is so ungenerous has hard hands and feet and limbs that are rough and uneven. So that the world may know that he is ungenerous, these two characteristics appear. But the characteristic is these two characteristics themselves. The benefit is that he has a well-disposed retinue.

original: 211. Kariyāti karitvā. Cariyāti caritvā. Anavamatenāti anavaññātena. “Anapamodenā”tipi pāṭho, na appamodena, na dīnena na gabbhitenāti attho.
analyzed: kariyā ati karitvā cariyā ati caritvā anavamatena ati anavaññātena anapamodena ati pi pāṭhaḥ na appamodena na dīnena na gabbhitena ati attho
translated: ‘Having done’: having done. ‘Having gone’: having gone. ‘Without disrespect’: without disrespect. ‘Without lack of delight’ is another reading; without lack of delight, without being mean, without being stingy.

original: Caviyāti cavitvā. Atirucira suvaggu dassaneyyanti atirucirañca supāsādikaṃ suvaggu ca suṭṭhu chekaṃ dassaneyyañca daṭṭhabbayuttaṃ. Susu kumāroti suṭṭhu sukumāro.

translated: ‘Having died’: having died. ‘Very lovely, beautiful, good to look at’: very lovely and very inspiring, and beautiful, very fine, and good to look at, fit to be looked at. ‘Very tender’: very delicate.

original: Parijanassavoti parijano assavo vacanakaro. Vidheyyoti kattabbākattabbesu yathāruci🔽vidhātabbo. Mahimanti mahiṃ imaṃ. Piyavadū hitasukhataṃ jigīsamānoti piyavado hutvā
analyzed: parijana ssavaḥ ti parijanaḥ assavaḥ vacana karaḥ vidheyyaḥ ti kattabba a kattabbesu yathāruci  vidhātabbaḥ mahimanti mahim imam piyavadū jigīsamānaḥ iti piyavadaḥ hutvā
translated: ‘With a retinue’: with a retinue that is obedient, that obeys. ‘To be directed’: to be directed as he wishes🔽in what should and should not be done. ‘Power’: this power. ‘Seeking what is dear, welfare and pleasure’: seeking what is dear,

original: hitañca sukhañca pariyesamāno. Vacanapaṭikarassā bhippasannāti vacanapaṭikarā assa
analyzed: hitam ca sukham ca pariyesamānaḥ vacana paṭikarassa bhippasannā ati vacana paṭikarā assa
translated: welfare and pleasure, being one who speaks what is dear. ‘With confidence in the reply’: with confidence in the reply

original: abhippasannā. Dhammānudhammanti dhammañca anudhammañca.
analyzed: abhippasannāḥ dhamma anudhammanti dhammañca anudhammañca
translated: to him. ‘In conformity with the True Idea’: in the True Idea and in what is in conformity with the True Idea.

original: Ussaṅkhapādādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ussaṅkha pāda ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Characteristics of the Elephant’s Footprint, etc.

original: 212. Atthūpasaṃhitanti idhalokaparalokatthanissitaṃ. Dhammūpasaṃhitanti dasakusalakammapathanissitaṃ.
analyzed: atthu upasaṃhitanti idhaloka paraloka attha nissitam dhammu upasaṃhitanti dasa kusala kammapatha nissitam
translated: “In conformity with welfare” means in conformity with the welfare of this world and of the other world. “In conformity with the Dhamma” means in conformity with the ten courses of wholesome kamma.

original: Bahujanaṃ nidaṃsesīti bahujanassa nidaṃsanakathaṃ kathesi. Pāṇīnanti sattānaṃ. “Aggo”tiādīni🔽sabbāni aññamaññavevacanāni. Idha kammaṃ nāma dīgharattaṃ bhāsitā uddhaṅgamanīyā
analyzed: bahu janam nidaṃsesi iti bahu janassa nidaṃsana katham kathesi pāṇīnam ti sattānam agga uti ādīni  sabbāni aññamañña vevacanāni idha kammam nāma dīgharattam bhāsitā uddhaṅgamanīyā
translated: “He instructed the multitude” means he spoke a discourse that instructs the multitude. “Beings” means living beings. “Foremost” and so on are

translated: synonyms. Herein, “kamma” is speech that is spoken for a long time and that leads to a high rebirth and is in conformity with welfare. “Kamma-like” is the fact that one who does not speak such high speech is

analyzed: iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti ussaṅkha pāda lakkhaṇañca uddhagga loma lakkhaṇañca nibbattati
translated: for that reason as the characteristic of having a voice that is high and the characteristic of having body hair that is up-turned.

translated: “Characteristic” is just these two characteristics. The “excellence” is the benefit.

translated: He is a speaker who leads on: he is a speaker who leads on many people. He shows what is beneficial: he shows what is beneficial for many people. By the Dhamma: by the gift of the Dhamma.

translated: His body-hairs stand on end: his body-hairs stand on end upwards. His ankles do not protrude: his ankles do not protrude. His feet are well-placed: his feet are well-placed. His flesh is firm and compact: his flesh is firm and compact.

original: pañcasīlaṃ dasasīlaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ. Kammanti kammassakatājānanapaññā. Kilisseyyunti
analyzed: pañca sīlam dasa sīlam pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam kammanti kammassaka tā jānana paññā kilisseyyunti
translated: the five precepts, the ten precepts, the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha. ‘Skill’ means the understanding of the ownership of one’s actions. ‘Should be ashamed’ means

original: kilameyyuṃ. Antevāsikavattaṃ nāma dukkhaṃ, taṃ nesaṃ mā ciramahosīti cintesi.🔽Rājārahānīti rañño anurūpāni hatthiassādīni, tāniyeva rañño senāya aṅgabhūtattā rājaṅgānīti
analyzed: kilameyyum antevāsika vattam nāma dukkham tam na īsam mā ciram ahosi iti cintesi  rājārahāni iti raññaḥ anurūpāni hatthi assa ādīni raññaḥ senāya aṅga bhūta ttā rājaṅgāni iti

They are called “the king’s requisites” because they are limbs of the king’s army.

original: vuccanti. Rājūpabhogānīti rañño upabhogaparibhogabhaṇḍāni, tāni ceva sattaratanāni🔽ca. Rājānucchavikānīti rañño anucchavikāni. Tesaṃyeva sabbesaṃ idaṃ gahaṇaṃ. Samaṇārahānīti
analyzed: vuccanti rāja upabhogāni iti raññaḥ upabhoga paribhoga bhaṇḍāni tāni ca iva satta ratanāni  ca rāja anucchavikāni iti raññaḥ anucchavikāni tesam yeva sabbesam idam gahaṇam samaṇa arahāni iti
translated: “Fit for a king to use” means the king’s personal belongings, such as the seven treasures.

original: samaṇānaṃ anurūpāni cīvarādīni. Samaṇaṅgānīti samaṇānaṃ koṭṭhāsabhūtā catasso parisā.
analyzed: samaṇānaṃ anurūpāni cīvara ādīni samaṇaṅgāni iti samaṇānam koṭṭhāsa bhūtā catasso parisā
translated: “Fit for a king to enjoy” means the same as the previous. “Fit for recluses” means robes, etc., which are suitable for recluses. “The requisites of a recluse” means the four assemblies, which are limbs of a recluse.

original: Samaṇūpabhogānīti samaṇānaṃ upabhogaparikkhārā. Samaṇānucchavikānīti tesaṃyeva adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: samaṇa upabhogāni iti samaṇānam upabhoga parikkhārā samaṇa anucchavikāni iti tesam yeva adhivacanaṃ
translated: “Fit for recluses to use” means the requisites of a recluse. “Fit for recluses to enjoy” is a synonym for the same.

original: Idha pana kammaṃ nāma dīgharattaṃ sakkaccaṃ sippādivācanaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma
analyzed: idha pana kammam nāma dīgharattam sakkaccam sippa ādi vācanam kammasarikkhakam nāma
translated: “Skill” here means the ability to teach a craft well for a long time.

original: yo evaṃ sakkaccaṃ sippaṃ avācento antevāsike ukkuṭikāsanajaṅghapesanikādīhi kilameti,
analyzed: yaḥ evam sakkaccam sippam a vācentaḥ antevāsike ukkuṭikā āsana jaṅgha pesanikā ādīhi kilameti
translated: He who teaches a craft to pupils by making them stand in a squatting position, or by making them sit on their haunches, or by making them stand on their toes, etc.,

original: tassa jaṅghamaṃsaṃ likhitvā pātitaṃ viya hoti. Tathāgatassa pana sakkaccaṃ vācitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tassa jaṅgha maṃsam likhitvā pātitam viya hoti tathāgatassa pana sakkaccam vācita bhāvam
translated: wears out the flesh of his legs, which then become like those of a camel. But the camel-like legs of the Tathāgata were produced by his habit of teaching a craft to pupils without making them stand in a squatting position, or sit on their haunches, or stand on their toes, etc.,

original: sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti anupubbauggatavaṭṭitaṃ eṇijaṅghalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati.
analyzed: sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti anupubba oggata vaṭṭitam eṇijaṅgha lakkhaṇam nibbattati
translated: so that the world with its gods might know that he had taught a craft with great respect.

original: Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma idameva lakkhaṇaṃ. Anucchavikalābhitā ānisaṃso.🔽215. Yadūpaghātāyāti yaṃ sippaṃ kassaci upaghātāya na hoti. Kilissatīti kilamissati.🔽Sukhumattacotthatāti sukhumattacena pariyonaddhā. Kiṃ pana aññena kammena aññaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇam nāma idam eva lakkhaṇam anucchavika lābhi tā ānisaṃso  yadu upaghātāya ati yam sippam kassaci upaghātāya na hoti kilissati iti kilamissati  sukhumat taca uttha tā ati sukhumat tacena pariyonaddhā kim pana aññena kammena aññam lakkhaṇam
translated: The mark is the very mark itself. The benefit is called “conforming” .🔽“For the sake of no harm”: a craft that does not cause harm to anyone. “He would tire”: he would become tired.

original: nibbattatīti? Na nibbattati. Yaṃ pana nibbattati, taṃ anubyañjanaṃ hoti, tasmā idha vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nibbattati iti na nibbattati yam pana nibbattati tam anubyañjanam hoti tasmai idha vuttam
translated: “Covered by a fine film”: covered by a very fine film. But how can a mark be produced by a different action? It cannot be produced. But what is produced is a secondary mark, and therefore it is mentioned here.

original: Sukhumacchavilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the mark of fine skin.

original: 216. Samaṇaṃ vāti samitapāpaṭṭhena samaṇaṃ. Brāhmaṇaṃ vāti bāhitapāpaṭṭhena brāhmaṇaṃ.
analyzed: samaṇam vāti samita pāpa ṭṭhena samaṇam brāhmaṇam vāti bāhita pāpa ṭṭhena brāhmaṇam
translated: “A recluse” : one who has gathered together evil qualities is a recluse. “A brahmin” : one who has expelled evil qualities is a brahmin.

original: Mahāpaññotiādīsu mahāpaññādīhi samannāgato hotīti attho. Tatridaṃ mahāpaññādīnaṃ nānattaṃ.
analyzed: mahāpañño ti ādīsu mahāpañña ādīhi samannāgataḥ hoti iti attho tatra idam mahāpañña ādīnam nānattam
translated: “Great wisdom” and so forth: the meaning is that he is endowed with great wisdom and so forth. Herein, the difference between great wisdom and so forth is this.

original: Tattha katamā mahāpaññā? Mahante sīlakkhandhe pariggaṇhātīti mahāpaññā, mahante samādhikkhandhe
analyzed: tattha katamā mahā paññā mahante sīla kkhandhe pariggaṇhāti iti mahā paññā mahante samādhi kkhandhe
translated: Herein, what is great wisdom? He grasps the great aggregate of virtue, the great aggregate of concentration,

analyzed: paññā kkhandhe vimutti kkhandhe vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandhe pariggaṇhāti iti mahāpaññā
translated: the great aggregate of wisdom, the great aggregate of emancipation, the great aggregate of the knowledge and vision of emancipation. Thus he is of great wisdom.

original: Mahantāni ṭhānāṭhānāni mahantā vihārasamāpattiyo mahantāni ariyasaccāni mahante satipaṭṭhāne
analyzed: mahantāni ṭhānāṭhānāni mahantā vihāra samāpattiyaḥ mahantāni ariya saccāni mahante satipaṭṭhāne
translated: He grasps the great bases and grounds, the great abidings and attainments, the great noble truths, the great foundations of mindfulness,

analyzed: sammappadhāne iddhipāde mahantāni indriyāni balāni mahante bojjhaṅge mahante ariya magge
translated: the great right efforts, the great bases of psychic power, the great faculties, the great powers, the great factors of enlightenment, the great noble path,

analyzed: mahantāni sāmañña phalāni mahantā abhiññāyaḥ mahantam paramattham nibbānam pariggaṇhāti iti mahāpaññā
translated: the great fruits of asceticism, the great kinds of direct knowledge, the great ultimate goal, Nibbāna. Thus he is of great wisdom.

original: Katamā puthupaññā? Puthunānākhandhesu ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti puthupaññā. Puthunānādhātūsu
analyzed: katamā puthu paññā puthu nānā khandhesu ñāṇam pavattati iti puthu paññā puthu nānā dhātūsu
translated: What is wide-dispersing understanding? Understanding that occurs in regard to the various aggregates, the various elements,

analyzed: puthu nānā āyatanesu puthu nānā paṭiccasamuppādesu puthu nānā suññatama nupalabbhesu puthu nānā atthesu
translated: the various sense bases, the various dependent originations, the various voidnesses, the various meanings,

analyzed: dhammesu niruttīsu paṭibhānesu puthu nānā sīla kkhandhesu puthu nānā samādhi paññā vimutti vimutti ñā dassana kkhandhesu  puthu nānā ṭhāna aṭhānesu puthu nānā vihāra samāpattīsu puthu nānā ariya saccesu puthu nānā sati paṭṭhānesu
translated: the various dhammas, the various verbal expressions, the various kinds of virtue, the various kinds of concentration, understanding, deliverance, and vision of the Dhamma,🔽the various kinds of grounds and nongrounds, the various kinds of abidings and attainments, the various kinds of noble truths, the various kinds of foundations of mindfulness,

original: sammappadhānesu iddhipādesu indriyesu balesu bojjhaṅgesu puthunānāariyamaggesu sāmaññaphalesu
analyzed: sammappadhānesu iddhipādesu indriyesu balesu bojjhaṅgesu puthu nānā ariya maggesu sāmañña phalesu
translated: the various kinds of right efforts, the various kinds of bases of spiritual success, the various kinds of faculties, the various kinds of powers, the various kinds of factors of enlightenment, the various kinds of noble paths, the various kinds of fruits of asceticism,

original: abhiññāsu puthujjanasādhāraṇe dhamme samatikkamma paramatthe nibbāne ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti puthupaññā.
analyzed: abhiññāsu puthujjana sādhāraṇe dhamme samatikkamma paramatthe nibbāne ñāṇam pavattati iti puthupaññā
translated: the various kinds of direct knowledges, the various kinds of dhammas shared by worldlings, and the ultimate goal, Nibbāna, is called wide-dispersing understanding.

original: Katamā hāsapaññā? Idhekacco hāsabahulo vedabahulo tuṭṭhibahulo pāmojjabahulo sīlaṃ
analyzed: katamā hāsa paññā idha ekaccaḥ hāsa bahulaḥ veda bahulaḥ tuṭṭhi bahulaḥ pāmojja bahulaḥ sīlam
translated: What is understanding that is smiling? Here someone is full of smiles, full of joy, full of delight, and he is virtuous,

original: paripūreti indriyasaṃvaraṃ paripūreti bhojane mattaññutaṃ jāgariyānuyogaṃ sīlakkhandhaṃ
analyzed: paripūreti indriya saṃvaram paripūreti bhojane mattaññu tam jāgariya anuyogam sīla kkhandham
translated: he fulfills the restraint of the sense faculties, he fulfills moderation in eating, he fulfills watchfulness, he fulfills the aggregate of virtue,

original: samādhikkhandhaṃ paññākkhandhaṃ vimuttikkhandhaṃ vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhaṃ paripūretīti
analyzed: samādhi kkhandham paññā kkhandham vimutti kkhandham vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandham paripūreti iti
translated: he fulfills the aggregate of concentration, he fulfills the aggregate of wisdom, he fulfills the aggregate of freedom, he fulfills the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of freedom.

original: hāsapaññā. Hāsabahulo…pe… pāmojjabahulo ṭhānāṭhānaṃ paṭivijjhatīti hāsapaññā. Hāsabahulo🔽vihārasamāpattiyo paripūretīti hāsapaññā. Hāsabahulo ariyasaccāni paṭivijjhatīti🔽hāsapaññā. translated: He has laughter-wisdom. He has much laughter. … He penetrates what is possible and impossible. He has laughter-wisdom. He has much laughter.

original: paṭivijjhatīti hāsapaññā. Hāsabahulo vedatuṭṭhipāmojjabahulo paramatthaṃ nibbānaṃ🔽sacchikarotīti hāsapaññā.
analyzed: paṭivijjhati iti hāsa paññāḥ hāsa bahulaḥ veda tuṭṭhi pāmojja bahulaḥ paramattham nibbānam 🔽sacchikaroti iti hāsa paññā
translated: He fulfills the abidings and the attainments. He has laughter-wisdom. He penetrates the noble truths. He has laughter-wisdom. original: Katamā javanapaññā? Yaṃkiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ🔽taṃ rūpaṃ aniccato khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā. Dukkhato khippaṃ anattato khippaṃ

translated: What is understanding as quickening? Whatever materiality there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—

original: javatīti javanapaññā. Yā kāci vedanā…pe… yaṃkiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ,
analyzed: javati iti javana paññā yā kāci yaṃ kiñci viññāṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam

original: sabbaṃ taṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccato dukkhato anattato khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā. Cakkhu…pe…🔽jarāmaraṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccato dukkhato anattato khippaṃ javatīti javanapaññā.

translated: all consciousness is impermanent, painful, and not-self, he quickens to understand. The eye…🔽old age and death, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—

original: Rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ aniccaṃ khayaṭṭhena dukkhaṃ bhayaṭṭhena anattā asārakaṭṭhenāti

translated: all old age and death is impermanent, painful, and not-self, he quickens to understand. Materiality is impermanent in the sense of destruction, painful in the sense of terror, and not-self in the sense of having no core.

original: tulayitvā tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā vibhūtaṃ katvā rūpanirodhe nibbāne khippaṃ javatīti
analyzed: tulayitvā tīrayitvā vibhāvayitvā vibhūtam katvā rūpa nirodhe nibbāne khippam javati iti

original: javanapaññā. Vedanā saññā saṅkhārā viññāṇaṃ cakkhu…pe… jarāmaraṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ
