translated: Therefore, one who is easily angered and has not given cloth and coverings, for this reason,

original: jano kodhanādibhāvaṃ jānātūti dubbaṇṇo hoti dussaṇṭhāno. Akkodhanassa pana mukhaṃ
analyzed: janaḥ kodhana ādi bhāvam jānātu uti dubbaṇṇaḥ hoti dussaṇṭhānaḥ akkodhanassa pana mukham
translated: “Let people know that I am easily angered” he is ugly and ill-favored. But one who is not easily angered has a face

original: virocati, chavivaṇṇo vippasīdati. Sattā hi catūhi kāraṇehi pāsādikā honti āmisadānena
analyzed: virocati chavi vaṇṇaḥ vippasīdati sattāḥ hi catūhi kāraṇehi pāsādikāḥ honti āmisa dānena
translated: that shines, and his complexion becomes clear and bright. For beings are pleasing on account of four reasons: by giving material things,

original: vā vatthadānena vā sammajjanena vā akkodhanatāya vā. Imāni cattāripi kāraṇāni dīgharattaṃ
analyzed: vā vattha dānena vā sammajjanena vā akkodhana tāya vā imāni cattāri pi kāraṇāni dīgharattam
translated: by giving robes, by bathing and massaging, and by not being easily angered. And the Tathāgata has performed these four reasons

original: tathāgatena katāneva. Tenassa imesaṃ katabhāvaṃ sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti
analyzed: tathāgatena katān eva tena assa imesam kata bhāvam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti
translated: for a long time. Therefore, “Let the world with its gods know that I have performed these”

original: suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma idameva lakkhaṇaṃ. Sukhumattharaṇādilābhitā ānisaṃso.🔽219. Abhivissajīti abhivissajjesi. Mahimiva suro abhivassanti suro vuccati devo, mahāpathaviṃ abhivassanto devo viya.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam nibbattati lakkhaṇam nāma idam eva lakkhaṇam sukhuma tharaṇa ādi lābhi tā ānisaṃsaḥ  abhivissaji iti abhivissajjesi mahim iva suraḥ abhivassanti suraḥ vuccati devaḥ mahā pathavim abhivassantaḥ devaḥ viya
translated: the mark of a Great Man, a golden complexion, is produced. The mark is just that. The benefit is the obtaining of fine bedding, etc.🔽. He rains down, as it were, on the earth, a god: a god is called a “god” ; raining down on the great earth, he is like a god.

original: Suravarataroriva indoti surānaṃ varataro indo viya.
analyzed: sura vara taroḥ iva indo ti varataraḥ indo
translated: Like the moon, best of gods: like the moon, best of gods.

original: Apabbajjamicchanti apabbajjaṃ gihibhāvaṃ icchanto. Mahatimahinti mahantiṃ pathaviṃ.
analyzed: a pabbajjam icchanti a pabbajjam gihi bhāvam icchantaḥ mahatimahinti mahantim pathavim
translated: He wishes to go forth, he wishes to go forth from the world, to the life of a layman. The great earth, the great earth.

original: Acchādanavatthamokkhapāvuraṇānanti acchādanānañceva vatthānañca uttamapāvuraṇānañca. Panāsoti vināso.
analyzed: acchādana vattha mokkha pāvuraṇānanti acchādanānam ca iva vatthānam ca uttama pāvuraṇānam panāsaḥ ti vināsaḥ
translated: Clothing, cloth, upper and lower garments. Destruction, loss.

original: Kosohitavatthaguyhalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristics of the sheathed genitals.

original: 220. Mātarampi puttena samānetā ahosīti imaṃ kammaṃ rajje patiṭṭhitena sakkā kātuṃ.
analyzed: mātaram pi puttena samānetā ahosi iti imam kammam rajje patiṭṭhitena sakkā kātum
translated: He would have brought together even his mother and son. This deed can be done by one established in a kingdom.

original: Tasmā bodhisattopi rajjaṃ kārayamāno antonagare catukkādīsu catūsu nagaradvāresu🔽bahinagare catūsu disāsu imaṃ kammaṃ karothāti manusse ṭhapesi. Te mātaraṃ kuhiṃ
analyzed: tasmai bodhisattaḥ api rajjam kārayamānaḥ antar nagare catukka ādīsu catūsu nagara dvāresu  bahi nagare catūsu disāsu imam kammam karotha ati manusse ṭhapesi te mātaram kuhim
translated: Therefore, the Bodhisatta, while ruling the kingdom, in the four city gates of the inner city and in the four directions outside the city🔽he placed men, saying, “Do this work.” They, seeing a mother who was crying, “Where is my son? I do not see my son,” and searching,

original: me putto puttaṃ na passāmīti vilapantiṃ pariyesamānaṃ disvā ehi, amma, puttaṃ dakkhasīti
analyzed: me puttaḥ puttam na passāmi iti vilapantim pariyesamānam disvā ehi amma puttam dakkhasi iti
translated: saying, “Come, mother, you will see your son,”

original: taṃ ādāya gantvā nahāpetvā bhojetvā puttamassā pariyesitvā dassenti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: tam ādāya gantvā nahāpetvā bhojetvā putta massā pariyesitvā dassenti esa nayaḥ sabbattha
translated: taking her, going, bathing her, feeding her, searching for her son, showed him to her. This is the method everywhere.

original: Idha kammaṃ nāma dīgharattaṃ ñātīnaṃ samaṅgibhāvakaraṇaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma ñātayo
analyzed: idha kammam nāma dīgharattam ñātīnam samaṅgi bhāva karaṇam kammasarikkhakam nāma ñātayaḥ
translated: Herein, the “deed” is the making of kinsmen for a long time. The “deed-like” is🔽kinsmen who have become kinsmen. For they conceal one another’s faults.

original: hi samaṅgībhūtā aññamaññassa vajjaṃ paṭicchādenti. Kiñcāpi hi te kalahakāle kalahaṃ
analyzed: hi samaṅgībhūtāḥ aññam aññassa vajjam paṭicchādenti kiñca api hi te kalaha kāle kalaham
translated: For although they quarrel at the time of a quarrel,

original: karonti, ekassa pana dose uppanne aññaṃ jānāpetuṃ na icchanti. Ayaṃ nāma etassa dosoti
analyzed: karonti ekassa pana dose uppanne aññam jānāpetum na icchanti ayam nāma etassa doso ti
translated: when the fault of one of them has arisen they do not want to make it known to another. When it is said “So and so is his fault,”

original: vutte sabbe uṭṭhahitvā kena diṭṭhaṃ kena sutaṃ, amhākaṃ ñātīsu evarūpaṃ kattā nāma
analyzed: vutte sabbe uṭṭhahitvā kena diṭṭham kena sutam amhākam ñātīsu evarūpam kattā nāma
translated: they all get up and say “By whom was it seen? By whom was it heard? There is no one among our kinsmen who would do such a thing.”

original: natthīti. Tathāgatena ca taṃ ñātisaṅgahaṃ karontena dīgharattaṃ idaṃ vajjappaṭicchādanakammaṃ
analyzed: na atthi iti tathāgatena ca tam ñāti saṅgaham karontena dīgharattam idam vajja ppaṭicchādana kammaṃ
translated: And when the Tathāgata, who is making a collection of kinsmen, has done this deed of concealing faults for a long time,

original: nāma kataṃ hoti. Athassa sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena evarūpassa kammassa katabhāvaṃ
analyzed: nāma katam hoti athassa sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena evarūpassa kammassa kata bhāvam
translated: then the world with its gods should know that he has done such a deed.

original: jānātūti kosohitavatthaguyhalakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma idameva lakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: jānātu uti kosohita vattha guyha lakkhaṇam nibbattati lakkhaṇam nāma idam eva lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic of the sheathed genitals is the characteristic of the genitals themselves.

original: Pahūtaputtatā ānisaṃso.
analyzed: pahūta putta tā ānisaṃso
translated: The “abundance of children” is the benefit.

original: 221. Vatthachādiyanti vatthena chādetabbaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ.
analyzed: vatthachādiyanti vatthena chādetabbam vattha guyham
translated: The “covering with cloth” is the covering with cloth of the genitals.

original: Amittatāpanāti amittānaṃ patāpanā. Gihissa pītiṃ jananāti gihibhūtassa sato pītijananā.
analyzed: amitta tāpanā ati amittānam patāpanā gihissa pītim jananā ati gihi bhūtassa sataḥ pīti jananā
translated: “He is a tormentor of enemies” means he torments enemies. “He causes joy to the householder” means he causes joy to the one who has become a householder.

original: Parimaṇḍalādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the characteristics beginning with “even”

original: 222. Samaṃ jānātīti “ayaṃ tārukkhasamo ayaṃ pokkharasātisamo”ti evaṃ tena tena samaṃ
analyzed: samam jānāti iti ayam tārukkhasamaḥ ayam pokkharasātisamaḥ ti evam tena tena samam
translated: “He knows what is even” means he knows what is even by this or that, “This is even like a taruka tree, this is even like a pokkharasati.”

original: jānāti. Sāmaṃ jānātīti sayaṃ jānāti. Purisaṃ jānātīti “ayaṃ seṭṭhasammato”ti purisaṃ
analyzed: jānāti sāmam jānāti iti sayam jānāti purisam jānāti iti ayam seṭṭha sammataḥ ti purisam
translated: “He knows what is even by himself” means he knows by himself. “He knows a man” means he knows “This one is considered the best.”

original: jānāti. Purisavisesaṃ jānātīti muggaṃ māsena samaṃ akatvā guṇavisiṭṭhassa visesaṃ🔽jānāti. Ayamidamarahatīti ayaṃ puriso idaṃ nāma dānasakkāraṃ arahati. Purisavisesakaro🔽ahosīti purisavisesaṃ ñatvā kārako ahosi. Yo yaṃ arahati, tasseva taṃ adāsi. Yo hi
analyzed: jānāti purisa visesam jānāti iti muggam māsena samam a katvā guṇa visiṭṭhassa visesam  jānāti ayam idam arahati iti ayam purisaḥ idam nāma dāna sakkāram arahati purisa visesa karo  ahosi iti purisa visesam ñatvā kārakaḥ ahosi yaḥ yam arahati tassa iva tam adāsi yaḥ hi
translated: “He knows the distinction of a man” means without making a mung bean equal to a māsa, he knows the distinction of one who is distinguished by qualities.

original: kahāpaṇārahassa aḍḍhaṃ deti, so parassa aḍḍhaṃ nāseti. Yo dve kahāpaṇe deti, so attano
analyzed: kahāpaṇa arahassa aḍḍham deti so parassa aḍḍham na āseti yaḥ dve kahāpaṇe deti so attano
translated: “This one deserves this” means this man deserves such and such a gift and honor. “He became the maker of distinctions of men” means having known the distinction of men, he became the maker. He gave to each what he deserved. For he who gives half to one who deserves a kahāpanṇa, he destroys the other’s half. He who gives two kahāpaṇṇas, he destroys his own.

original: kahāpaṇaṃ nāseti. Tasmā idaṃ ubhayampi akatvā yo yaṃ arahati, tassa tadeva adāsi.
analyzed: kahāpaṇam nāseti tasmai idam ubhayam pi a katvā yaḥ yam arahati tassa tat eva adāsi
translated: He should not be fined a kahāpaṇa. Therefore, without doing either of these, he should give him whatever he deserves.

original: Saddhādhanantiādīsu sampattipaṭilābhaṭṭhena saddhādīnaṃ dhanabhāvo veditabbo.🔽Idha kammaṃ nāma dīgharattaṃ purisavisesaṃ ñatvā kataṃ samasaṅgahakammaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ
analyzed: saddhā dhana nti ādīsu sampatti paṭilābha ṭṭhena saddhā ādīnam dhana bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ  idha kammam nāma dīgha rattam purisa visesam ñatvā katam sama saṅgaha kammam kamma sarikkhakam
translated: In the case of the wealth of faith, etc., the state of being wealth should be understood in the sense of the acquisition of excellence.🔽Herein, the deed is the act of assigning the two characteristics after having known the man’s excellence for a long time.

original: nāma tadassa kammaṃ sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti imāni dve lakkhaṇāni nibbattanti.
analyzed: nāma tat assa kammam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti imāni dve lakkhaṇāni nibbattanti
translated: The deed similar to the deed is the act of assigning the two characteristics after having known the man’s excellence for a short time.

original: Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma idameva lakkhaṇadvayaṃ. Dhanasampatti ānisaṃso.
analyzed: lakkhaṇam nāma idam eva lakkhaṇa dvayam dhana sampatti ānisaṃso
translated: The characteristic is the two characteristics themselves. The benefit is the excellence of wealth.

original: 223. Tuliyāti tulayitvā. Paṭivicayāti paṭivicinitvā. Mahājanasaṅgāhakanti mahājanasaṅgahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: tuliyā ati tulayitvā paṭivicayā ati paṭivicinitvā mahājana saṅgāhakam iti mahājana saṅgahaṇam
translated: Weighing: having weighed. Investigating: having investigated. Gathering a great multitude: gathering a great multitude.

original: Samekkhamānoti samaṃ pekkhamāno. Atinipuṇā manujāti atinipuṇā sukhumapaññā lakkhaṇapāṭhakamanussā.
analyzed: samekkhamānaḥ ti samam pekkhamānaḥ ati nipuṇā manujāti ati nipuṇā sukhuma paññā lakkhaṇa pāṭhaka manussā
translated: Looking on equally: looking on equally. Very clever men: very clever, subtle-minded men who can read characteristics.

original: Bahuvividhā gihīnaṃ arahānīti bahū vividhāni gihīnaṃ anucchavikāni paṭilabhati. Daharo
analyzed: bahu vividhā gihīnam paṭilabhati
translated: Many kinds of things suitable for householders: he obtains many kinds of things suitable for householders.

original: susu kumāro “ayaṃ daharo kumāro paṭilabhissatī”ti byākaṃsu mahīpatissāti rañño.
analyzed: susu kumāraḥ ayam daharo kumāro paṭilabhissati iti byākaṃsu mahīpatissa ati rañño
translated: The seers declared: “This young prince will obtain it.” “The king’s” means the king’s.

original: Sīhapubbaddhakāyādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the characteristics beginning with the lion-like upper arms

original: 224. Yogakkhemakāmoti yogato khemakāmo. Paññāyāti kammassakatapaññāya. Idha kammaṃ
analyzed: yoga khema kāmo ti yogataḥ khema kāmo paññāya ati idha kammaṃ
translated: “Desiring the security of yoga” : desiring the security that comes from yoga. “By wisdom” : by the wisdom of ownership of kamma. Herein, kamma

original: nāma mahājanassa atthakāmatā. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma taṃ mahājanassa atthakāmatāya
analyzed: nāma mahājanassa attha kāma tā kammasarikkhakam nāma tam mahājanassa attha kāma tāya
translated: is the desire for the welfare of the great multitude. Kamma-like is the desire for the welfare of the great multitude by means of that .

original: vaḍḍhimeva paccāsīsitabhāvaṃ sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti imāni samantaparipūrāni
analyzed: vaḍḍhim eva paccāsīsita bhāvam sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti imāni samanta paripūrāni
translated: The world together with the gods should know by this reason that these three characteristics are produced complete and perfect

original: aparihīnāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni nibbattanti. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma idameva lakkhaṇattayaṃ. Dhanādīhi
analyzed: a parihīnāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni nibbattanti lakkhaṇam nāma idam eva lakkhaṇa ttayam dhana ādīhi
translated: and not diminished. A characteristic is just this triad of characteristics. The benefit is the non-diminution by means of the wealth, etc.,

original: ceva saddhādīhi ca aparihāni ānisaṃso.
analyzed: ca iva saddhā ādīhi ca ānisaṃsaḥ
translated: and the faith, etc.

original: 225. Saddhāyāti okappanasaddhāya pasādasaddhāya. Sīlenāti pañcasīlena dasasīlena.
analyzed: saddhāya ati okappana saddhāya pasāda saddhāya sīlena ati pañca sīlena dasa sīlena
translated: “By faith” : by the faith of resolution and the faith of confidence. “By virtue” : by the virtue of the five precepts and the virtue of the ten precepts.

original: Sutenāti pariyattisavanena. Buddhiyāti etesaṃ buddhiyā, “kinti etehi vaḍḍheyyu”nti
analyzed: sutena ati pariyatti savanena buddhiyā ati etesam buddhiyā kinti etehi vaḍḍheyyunti
translated: “By learning” : by learning the texts. “By intelligence” : by the intelligence of these . “How may these increase?”

original: evaṃ cintesīti attho. Dhammenāti lokiyadhammena. Bahūhi sādhūhīti aññehipi bahūhi
analyzed: evam cintesi iti atthaḥ dhammena ati lokiya dhammena bahūhi sādhūhi iti aññehi pi bahūhi
translated: The meaning is, he thought thus. By the Dhamma: by the worldly Dhamma. With many a good: with other many

original: uttamaguṇehi. Asahānadhammatanti aparihīnadhammaṃ.
analyzed: uttama guṇehi a sahāna dhamma tanti a parihīna dhammam
translated: excellent qualities. Incomparable Dhamma: undiminished Dhamma.

original: Rasaggasaggitālakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rasa agga saggi tā lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the characteristic of the taste of the supreme ghee

original: 226. Samābhivāhiniyoti yathā tilaphalamattampi jivhagge ṭhapitaṃ sabbattha pharati,
analyzed: yathā tila phala mattam pi jivhagge ṭhapitam sabbattha pharati
translated: Flowing evenly: just as a sesame seed placed on the tip of the tongue spreads everywhere,

original: evaṃ samā hutvā vahanti. Idha kammaṃ nāma aviheṭhanakammaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ nāma
analyzed: evam samāḥ hutvā vahanti idha kammam nāma a viheṭhana kammam kammasarikkhakam nāma
translated: so they flow evenly. Here, the action is the action of non-harming. The action similar to that is

original: pāṇiādīhi pahāraṃ laddhassa tattha tattha lohitaṃ saṇṭhāti, gaṇṭhi gaṇṭhi hutvā antova
analyzed: pāṇi ādīhi pahāram laddhassa tattha tattha lohitam saṇṭhāti gaṇṭhi gaṇṭhi hutvā antova
translated: when one who has received a blow with the hand, etc., has blood spread here and there, and it becomes a lump,

original: pubbaṃ gaṇhāti, antova bhijjati, evaṃ so bahurogo hoti. Tathāgatena pana dīgharattaṃ
analyzed: pubbam gaṇhāti antar iva bhijjati evam saḥ bahu rogaḥ hoti tathāgatena pana dīgharattam
translated: it takes hold of the inside, it breaks inside, and so he has many diseases. But the Tathāgata has done

original: imaṃ ārogyakaraṇakammaṃ kataṃ. Tadassa sadevako loko iminā kāraṇena jānātūti ārogyakaraṃ
analyzed: imam ārogya karaṇa kammam katam tat assa sa devakaḥ lokaḥ iminā kāraṇena jānātu uti ārogya karam
translated: this action that brings about health for a long time. Let the world with its gods know this reason,

original: rasaggasaggilakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Lakkhaṇaṃ nāma idameva lakkhaṇaṃ. Appābādhatā ānisaṃso.
analyzed: rasagga saggi lakkhaṇam nibbattati lakkhaṇam nāma idam eva lakkhaṇam appa ābādha tā ānisaṃso
translated: and so the characteristic of the taste of the supreme ghee that brings about health arises. The characteristic is just this characteristic. The benefit is the absence of disease.

original: 227. Maraṇavadhenāti “etaṃ māretha etaṃ ghātethā”ti evaṃ āṇattena maraṇavadhena. Ubbādhanāyāti bandhanāgārappavesanena.
analyzed: maraṇa vadhena ati etam māretha etam ghātetha ati evam āṇattena maraṇa vadhena ubbādhanāya ati bandhanāgāra ppavesanena
translated: By the threat of death: by the threat of death thus, “Kill him, slay him.” By the threat of bonds: by the threat of imprisonment in the place of bonds.

original: Abhinīlanettādilakkhaṇavaṇṇanā🔽228. Na ca visaṭanti kakkaṭako viya akkhīni nīharitvā na kodhavasena pekkhitā ahosi.
analyzed: abhinīla netta ādi lakkhaṇa vaṇṇanā  na ca kakkaṭakaḥ viya akkhīni nīharitvā na kodha vasena pekkhitā ahosi
translated: As to the description of the eye’s characteristic of being blue-black, etc.,🔽and not rolling: she did not look with anger, thrusting out her eyes like a crab.🔽And not rolling: she did not look with a sidelong glance like a cat.

original: Na ca visācīti vaṅkakkhikoṭiyā pekkhitāpi nāhosi. Na ca pana viceyya pekkhitāti viceyya🔽pekkhitā nāma yo kujjhitvā yadā naṃ paro oloketi, tadā nimmīleti na oloketi, puna
analyzed: na ca visāci iti vaṅkakkhi koṭiyā pekkhitā api na ahosi na ca pana viceyya pekkhitā ati viceyya  pekkhitā nāma yaḥ kujjhitvā yadā nam paras oloketi tadā nimmīleti na oloketi puna
translated: And not looking askance: she did not look askance,

original: gacchantaṃ kujjhitvā oloketi, evarūpo nāhosi. “Vineyyapekkhitā”tipi pāṭho, ayamevattho.
analyzed: gacchantam kujjhitvā oloketi evarūpaḥ na ahosi vineyya pekkhitā iti pi pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ
translated: looking at him when he was angry and then closing her eyes and not looking, and then looking again when he had gone away and was angry. The reading is “vineyyapekkhitā,” and the meaning is the same.

original: Ujuṃ tathā pasaṭamujumanoti ujumano hutvā uju pekkhitā hoti, yathā ca ujuṃ, tathā
analyzed: ujum tathā pasaṭam uju mano ti uju manaḥ hutvā uju pekkhitā hoti yathā ca ujum tathā
translated: Straight and open-countenanced: she looked straight and open-countenanced. And as straight,

original: pasaṭaṃ vipulaṃ vitthataṃ pekkhitā hoti. Piyadassanoti piyāyamānehi passitabbo.
analyzed: pasaṭam vipulam vitthatam pekkhitā hoti piya dassanaḥ ti piyāyamānehi passitabbo
translated: so open: she looked open, extensive, wide. Lovely to look on: to be looked on by those who love.

original: Idha kammaṃ nāma dīgharattaṃ mahājanassa piyacakkhunā olokanakammaṃ. Kammasarikkhakaṃ🔽nāma kujjhitvā olokento kāṇo viya kākakkhi viya hoti, vaṅkakkhi pana āvilakkhi ca

analyzed: kamma kileso ti vuttaḥ adinnādāna ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ atha aparan ti aparam pi etad attha paridīpakam eva

translated: illustrates the same meaning.

analyzed: catu ṭhāna ādi vaṇṇanā  pāpa kammam karoti iti idam bhagavā yasmai kārake dassite akārakaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti tasmai
translated: The explanation of the fourth section

analyzed: pāpa kammam na karoti iti mātikam ṭhapetvā api desanā kusala tāya paṭhamataram kārakam  dassentaḥ āha tattha chanda agatim gacchanto ti chandena pemena agatim gacchantaḥ a kattabbam  karontaḥ para padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ tattha yaḥ ayam me mittaḥ vā sambhattaḥ vā sandiṭṭhaḥ
translated: . The Blessed One said, “He does not do evil deeds,” in order to show the doer after first setting up the heading, “He does not do evil deeds,” because the doer is obvious when the deed is shown.🔽In the first place, he said this in order to show the doer, because of his skill in teaching. Herein, he goes by the bias of desire: he goes by the bias of affection, he does what should not be done. The same method applies in the case of the other terms. Herein, one who makes what is not one’s own into one’s own through affection, thinking, “This is my friend, relative, acquaintance, or blood-relation,” or through gain, thinking, “This man gives me a bribe,”

analyzed: vā ñātakaḥ vā lañjam vā pana me deti iti chanda vasena assāmikam sāmikam karoti ayam
translated: is one who goes by the bias of desire.

analyzed: chandāgatim gacchantaḥ pāpa kammam karoti nāma yaḥ ayam me pakati vera vasena  taṅkhaṇa uppanna kodha vasena vā sāmikam assāmikam karoti ayam dosa āgatim gacchantaḥ pāpa kammam
translated: He who goes by the way of desire is said to do evil action. He who, because of enmity,

analyzed: karoti nāma yaḥ pana mandattā momūhattā yam vā tam vā vatvā assāmikam sāmikam karoti

Yo pana “ayaṃ rājavallabho vā visamanissito🔽vā anatthampi me kareyyā”ti bhīto assāmikaṃ sāmikaṃ karoti, ayaṃ bhayāgatiṃ gacchanto🔽pāpakammaṃ karoti nāma. analyzed: ayam moha āgatim gacchantaḥ pāpa kammam karoti nāma yaḥ pana ayam rāja vallabhaḥ vā visama nissito  vā anattham pi me kareyya ati bhītaḥ a sāmikam sāmikam karoti ayam bhaya āgatim gacchantaḥ  pāpa kammam karoti nāma yaḥ pana yaṃ kiñci bhājentaḥ ayam me sandiṭṭhaḥ vā sambhatto  vāti pema vasena atirekam deti ayam me verī iti dosa vasena ūnakam deti momūhattā
translated: is said to do evil action by going by the way of delusion. But he who, being afraid, thinking “this one is a king’s favourite or is connected with a powerful man,

But he who, when distributing something, gives more to one out of love, thinking “this one is a friend or a relation of mine,” gives less to another out of hate, thinking “this one is my enemy,” and, not knowing what he has given or not, gives less to one and more to another out of stupidity, thinking “this one, if not given,🔽will tell,”

analyzed: mayham anattham pi kareyya ati bhīto kassaci atirekam deti so catubbidhaḥ api yathā anukkamena
translated: and he might do me harm.” In his fear he gives more than he should.

original: chandāgatiādīni gacchanto pāpakammaṃ karoti nāma.
analyzed: chandāgati ādīni gacchantaḥ pāpa kammam karoti nāma
translated: He who does evil by any of these four means is called “one who does evil.”

original: Ariyasāvako pana jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpuṇantopi chandāgatiādīni na gacchati. Tena vuttaṃ – “imehi catūhi ṭhānehi pāpakammaṃ na karotī”ti.

translated: But the noble disciple does not do evil by any of these four means even if it should cost him his life.

original: Nihīyati yaso tassāti tassa agatigāmino kittiyasopi parivārayasopi nihīyati parihāyati.
analyzed: nihīyati yasaḥ tassa ati tassa agati gāminaḥ kitti yasaḥ pi parivāra yasaḥ pi nihīyati parihāyati
translated: “His fame diminishes” means that the fame and the retinue of the one who goes to a bad destination diminish, decrease.

original: Chaapāyamukhādivaṇṇanā🔽247. Surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānānuyogoti ettha surāti piṭṭhasurā pūvasurā odanasurā🔽kiṇṇapakkhittā sambhārasaṃyuttāti pañca surā. Merayanti pupphāsavo phalāsavo madhvāsavo
analyzed: cha apāya mukha ādi vaṇṇanā  ettha surā ati piṭṭha surā pūva surā odana surā  kiṇṇa pakkhittā sambhāra saṃyuttā ati pañca surāḥ merayanti pupphāsavaḥ phalāsavaḥ madhvāsavaḥ
translated: The explanation of the six bases of coming together🔽. “The practice of liquor, wines, or intoxicants which cause heedlessness” : here, surā means the five kinds of surā, namely, piṭṭhasurā, pūvasurā, odanasurā,🔽kiṇṇapakkhittā, and sambhārasaṃyuttā. Merayanti means the five kinds of meraya, namely, pupphāsava, phalāsava, madhvāsava,

analyzed: guḷāsavo sambhāra saṃyutto ti pañca āsavā tam sabbam pi mada karaṇa vasena majjam pamāda ṭṭhānam ti
translated: guḷāsava, and sambhārasaṃyutta. All of this is called majja because it causes intoxication. The practice of liquor, wines, or intoxicants which cause heedlessness is called pamādaṭṭhāna.

original: pamādakāraṇaṃ. Yāya cetanāya taṃ majjaṃ pivati, tassa etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Anuyogoti
analyzed: pamāda kāraṇam yāya cetanāya tam majjam pivati tassa etam adhivacanam
translated: The intention by which he drinks that liquor is what is meant here.🔽Practice: the practice, the repeated practice, of that resort for the manifestation of negligence due to liquor, wine, and besotting drink.

original: tassa surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānassa anuanuyogo punappunaṃ karaṇaṃ. Yasmā panetaṃ
analyzed: tassa surā meraya majja ppamāda ṭṭhānassa anuanuyogaḥ punappunam karaṇam yasmai
translated: But because of this practice,

analyzed: anuyuttassa uppannā ca iva bhogā parihāyanti anuppannā ca na uppajjanti tasmā bhogānaṃ  apāya mukhanti vuttam vikāla visikhā cariyā anuyogo ti avelāya visikhāsu cariyā anuyutta tā
translated: both the wealth that has arisen perishes and that which has not arisen does not arise,🔽and that is why it is said that it is the “door to the wasting of wealth.”🔽Practice of wandering about at unfitting times and on forbidden paths: being devoted to wandering about on forbidden paths at unfitting times.🔽Attendance at fairs: going to fairs in order to see dancing, etc.

original: Samajjābhicaraṇanti naccādidassanavasena samajjāgamanaṃ. Ālasyānuyogoti kāyālasiyatāya yuttappayuttatā.
analyzed: sa majja abhicaraṇanti nacca ādi dassana vasena sa majjā gamanam ālasya anuyogo ti kāya ālasiya tāya yutta ppayutta tā
translated: Practice of idleness: being devoted to the idleness of body.

original: Surāmerayassa chaādīnavādivaṇṇanā🔽248. Evaṃ channaṃ apāyamukhānaṃ mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā idāni tāni vibhajanto cha kho me,
analyzed: evam channam mātikam ṭhapetvā idāni tāni vibhajantaḥ cha kho me
translated: The explanation of the six dangers in liquor, wine, and besotting drink,

analyzed: gahapati puttaḥ ādīnavā tiādim āha tattha sandiṭṭhikā ti sāmam passitabbā idha loka bhāvinī
translated: Having thus set forth the schedule of the six doors of wastage, he now said “Six dangers, householder’s son,” in order to analyse them. Herein, visible in this very life means to be seen by oneself, to be experienced in this very world.

original: Dhanajānīti dhanahāni. Kalahappavaḍḍhanīti vācākalahassa ceva hatthaparāmāsādikāyakalahassa
analyzed: dhana jāni iti dhana hāni kalaha ppavaḍḍhanī iti vācā kalahassa ca iva hattha parāmāsa ādi kāya kalahassa
translated: Dhanajānī means loss of wealth. Kalahappavaḍḍhanī means increasing of verbal quarrels and quarrels with blows, etc.

analyzed: suram pivitvā hi mātaram pi paharanti pitaram pi aññam bahum pi a vattabbam vadanti
translated: drinking liquor, they strike even their mother and father, and they say many things that should not be said,

analyzed: guyha ṭṭhānam hi vivariyamānam hirim kopeti vināseti tasmā vuccati surā mada mattā

analyzed: ca tam tam aṅgam vivaritvā vicaranti tena na īsam sā surā kopīnassa nidaṃsanataḥ kopīna nidaṃsanī iti
translated: wander about exposing this and that limb. Therefore that liquor of theirs is called “the exposer of the private parts” because it exposes the private parts.

analyzed: vuccati paññāya dubbali karaṇī iti sāgata ttherassa viya kammassakata paññam dubbalam
translated: It is said: “It weakens understanding” : it weakens the understanding of self-responsibility, as in the case of the Elder Sāgata.

analyzed: karoti tasmā paññāya dubbalikaraṇī iti vuccati magga paññam pana dubbalam kātum  na sakkoti adhigata maggānam hi sā antomukham eva na pavisati chaṭṭham chaṭṭham kāraṇam
translated: But it cannot weaken the understanding of the path.🔽For it does not enter the mouth of those who have attained the path.🔽The sixth reason:

original: 249. Attāpissa agutto arakkhito hotīti avelāya caranto hi khāṇukaṇṭakādīnipi akkamati,🔽ahināpi yakkhādīhipi samāgacchati, taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ gacchatīti ñatvā verinopi naṃ nilīyitvā
analyzed: attā api ssa a guttaḥ a rakkhitaḥ hoti iti avelāya carantaḥ hi khāṇu kaṇṭaka ādīni pi akkamati  samāgacchati tam tam ṭhānam gacchati iti ñatvā nilīyitvā
translated: His self is unguarded and unprotected: for one who goes out at the wrong time may tread on stumps and thorns,🔽and he may encounter snakes, yakkhas, etc.,

original: gaṇhanti vā hananti vā. Evaṃ attāpissa agutto hoti arakkhito. Puttadārāpi “amhākaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhanti vā hananti vā evam attā api assa aguttaḥ hoti arakkhitaḥ putta dārā api amhākam
translated: and knowing that he is going to such and such a place, his enemies may lie in wait and seize him or kill him. Thus his self is unguarded and unprotected.

original: pitā amhākaṃ sāmi rattiṃ vicarati, kimaṅgaṃ pana maya”nti itissa puttadhītaropi bhariyāpi
analyzed: pitā amhākam sāmi rattim vicarati kim aṅgam pana itissa putta dhītaraḥ api bhariyā api
translated: His children and wife: his children and wife

original: bahi patthanaṃ katvā rattiṃ carantā anayabyasanaṃ pāpuṇanti. Evaṃ puttadāropissa
analyzed: bahi patthanam katvā rattim carantāḥ anaya byasanam pāpuṇanti evam
translated: may go out at night, too, following his example, and come to destruction. Thus his children and wife

original: agutto arakkhito hoti. Sāpateyyanti tassa puttadāraparijanassa rattiṃ caraṇakabhāvaṃ🔽ñatvā corā suññaṃ gehaṃ pavisitvā yaṃ icchanti, taṃ haranti. Evaṃ sāpateyyampissa🔽aguttaṃ arakkhitaṃ hoti. Saṅkiyo ca hotīti aññehi katapāpakammesupi “iminā kataṃ🔽bhavissatī”ti saṅkitabbo hoti. Yassa yassa gharadvārena yāti, tattha yaṃ aññena corakammaṃ🔽paradārikakammaṃ vā kataṃ, taṃ “iminā kata”nti vutte abhūtaṃ asantampi tasmiṃ rūhati
analyzed: a guttaḥ a rakkhitaḥ hoti sāpateyya nti tassa putta dāra parijanassa rattim caraṇaka bhāvam  ñatvā corā suññam geham pavisitvā yam icchanti tam haranti evam sāpateyyam pissa  a guttam a rakkhitam hoti saṅkiyaḥ ca hoti iti aññehi kata pāpa kammesu pi iminā katam  bhavissati iti saṅkitabbaḥ hoti yassa yassa ghara dvārena yāti tattha yam aññena cora kammaṃ  paradārika kammam vā katam tam iminā kata nti vutte abhūtam asantam pi tasmin rūhati
translated: He is unguarded and unprotected. As to his property: having found out that his wife and children and his servants are out at night, thieves enter his empty house and take whatever they want. Thus his property is unguarded and unprotected. He is suspected: he is suspected by others of having committed the crime, thinking “It must have been he who did it.” Wherever he goes through a village gate, if a crime has been committed or adultery practised there, when it is said “It was he who did it,” then even if it is untrue and not so, it is laid to his charge.

original: patiṭṭhāti. Bahūnañca dukkhadhammānanti ettakaṃ dukkhaṃ, ettakaṃ domanassanti vattuṃ🔽na sakkā, aññasmiṃ puggale asati sabbaṃ vikālacārimhi āharitabbaṃ hoti, iti so bahūnaṃ🔽dukkhadhammānaṃ purakkhato puregāmī hoti.
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti bahūnam ca dukkha dhammānam ti ettakam dukkham ettakam domanassanti vattum 🔽na sakkā aññasmin puggale asati sabbam vikāla cārimhi āharitabbam hoti iti saḥ bahūnam 🔽dukkha dhammānam purakkhataḥ puregāmī hoti
translated: He is unguarded and unprotected. As to his property: having found out that his wife and children and his retinue are abroad by night, thieves enter his empty house and carry off whatever they like. So his property is unguarded and unprotected. He is suspected: he is suspected by others of having committed the crime, thinking “It must have been done by him.” Wherever he goes by any house door, there whatever crime has been committed by thieves or whatever crime has been committed by others with another’s wife, when it is said “It was done by him,” it grows and becomes established in him even though it is untrue and does not exist. He is beset by many kinds of painful states: it cannot be said that there is this much pain or this much grief, for when there is no other person than him, all that occurs by day and night must be brought in. So he is beset by many kinds of painful states.

original: 250. Kva naccanti “kasmiṃ ṭhāne naṭanāṭakādinaccaṃ atthī”ti pucchitvā yasmiṃ gāme🔽vā nigame vā taṃ atthi, tattha gantabbaṃ hoti, tassa “sve naccadassanaṃ gamissāmī”ti
analyzed: kva naccanti kasmin ṭhāne naṭa nāṭaka ādi naccam atthi iti pucchitvā yasmin gāme  vā nigame vā tat atthi tattha gantabbam hoti tassa sve nacca dassanam gamissāmi iti
translated: Where is dancing? Where is there dancing with actors and actresses, etc.? When he has asked this, he will go to the village or town where there is dancing.

original: ajja vatthagandhamālādīni paṭiyādentasseva sakaladivasampi kammacchedo hoti, naccadassanena
analyzed: ajja vattha gandha mālā ādīni paṭiyādentassa iva sakala divasam pi kamma chedaḥ hoti nacca dassanena
translated: He will spend the whole day preparing betel, scents, garlands, etc., thinking, “I shall go and see the dancing tomorrow.”

original: ekāhampi dvīhampi tīhampi tattheva hoti, atha vuṭṭhisampattiyādīni labhitvāpi vappādikāle🔽vappādīni akarontassa anuppannā bhogā nuppajjanti, tassa bahi gatabhāvaṃ ñatvā anārakkhe
analyzed: ekāham pi dvīham pi tīham pi tattha iva hoti atha vuṭṭhi sampattiyā ādīni labhitvā api vappa ādi kāle  vappa ādīni a karontassa an uppannāḥ bhogāḥ na uppajjanti tassa bahi gata bhāvam ñatvā anārakkhe
translated: He will go there and stay for a day, or for two or three days to see the dancing.🔽Then, even though he has obtained a good opportunity for making an effort, he will not do the work of ploughing, etc., that should be done at the time of ploughing, etc.

original: gehe corā yaṃ icchanti, taṃ karonti, tenassa uppannāpi bhogā vinassanti. Kva gītantiādīsupi
analyzed: gehe corāḥ yam icchanti tam karonti tena assa uppannā api bhogāḥ vinassanti kva gīta nti ādīsu pi
translated: As a result, the wealth that has not yet arisen does not arise. And when he is away from home, thieves will do as they please in his unprotected house.🔽Thus the wealth that has arisen is destroyed. The meaning of the rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: eseva nayo. Tesaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ brahmajāle vuttameva.
analyzed: tesam nānākaraṇam brahmajāle vuttam eva
translated: The difference between them is given in the Brahmajāla Sutta .

original: 251. Jayaṃ veranti “jitaṃ mayā”ti parisamajjhe parassa sāṭakaṃ vā veṭhanaṃ vā gaṇhāti,
analyzed: jayam veranti jitam mayā ati parisamajjhe parassa sāṭakam vā veṭhanam vā gaṇhāti
translated: Victory through hatred: he seizes another’s garment or turban in the midst of an assembly, thinking “I have won.”

original: so “parisamajjhe me avamānaṃ karosi, hotu, sikkhāpessāmi na”nti tattha veraṃ bandhati,
analyzed: saḥ parisamajjhe me avamānam karosi hotu sikkhāpessāmi tattha veram bandhati
translated: He thinks, “You are insulting me in the midst of the assembly. Well, I’ll train you,” and he creates enmity there.

original: evaṃ jinanto sayaṃ veraṃ pasavati. Jinoti aññena jito samāno yaṃ tena tassa veṭhanaṃ🔽vā sāṭako vā aññaṃ vā pana hiraññasuvaṇṇādivittaṃ gahitaṃ, taṃ anusocati “ahosi vata
analyzed: evam jinantaḥ sayam veram pasavati jinoti aññena jitaḥ samānaḥ yam tena tassa veṭhanam  vā sāṭakaḥ vā aññam vā pana hirañña suvaṇṇa ādi vittam gahitam tam anusocati ahosi vata
translated: Thus, when he wins, he creates enmity by himself. When he is defeated, he grieves over the loss.

original: me, taṃ taṃ vata me natthī”ti tappaccayā socati. Evaṃ so jino vittaṃ anusocati. Sabhāgatassa
analyzed: me tam tam vata me natthi iti tad paccayā socati evam saḥ jinaḥ vittam anusocati sabhā gatassa
translated: Whatever he has taken as a stake—a turban, a garment, or some other wealth such as gold or silver—he grieves over it, thinking, “I had it, but now I don’t have it.” He grieves because of that. Thus, when he is defeated, he grieves over the loss.🔽His words are not accepted by his fellows.

original: vacanaṃ na rūhatīti vinicchayaṭṭhāne sakkhipuṭṭhassa sato vacanaṃ na rūhati, na patiṭṭhāti,
analyzed: vacanam na rūhati iti vinicchaya ṭṭhāne sakkhi puṭṭhassa sataḥ vacanam na rūhati na patiṭṭhāti
translated: When he is questioned as a witness, his words are not accepted, are not established.

original: “ayaṃ akkhasoṇḍo jūtakaro, mā tassa vacanaṃ gaṇhitthā”ti vattāro bhavanti. Mittāmaccānaṃ🔽paribhūto hotīti tañhi mitāmaccā evaṃ vadanti – “samma, tvampi nāma kulaputto jūtakaro
analyzed: ayam akkha soṇḍaḥ jūta karaḥ mā tassa vacanam gaṇhittha ati vattāraḥ bhavanti mitta amaccānam  paribhūtaḥ hoti iti tat hi mitāmaccāḥ evam vadanti samma tvam pi nāma kula putto jūta karo
translated: They say, “This is a cheat, a gambler. Don’t accept his words.”🔽He is despised by his friends and companions.

original: chinnabhinnako hutvā vicarasi, na te idaṃ jātigottānaṃ anurūpaṃ, ito paṭṭhāya mā
analyzed: chinna bhinnakaḥ hutvā vicarasi na te idam jāti gottānam anurūpam itas paṭṭhāya mā
translated: His friends and companions say, “You, a gentleman, are a gambler, wandering about with torn and dirty clothes. This is not suitable for your family and lineage. From now on, don’t

original: evaṃ kareyyāsī”ti. So evaṃ vuttopi tesaṃ vacanaṃ na karoti. Tato tena saddhiṃ ekato
analyzed: evam kareyyāsi iti saḥ evam vuttaḥ api tesam vacanam na karoti tatas tena saddhim ekatas
translated: “You should act like this.” But he does not do what they say. Then they all get together

original: na tiṭṭhanti na nisīdanti. Tassa kāraṇā sakkhipuṭṭhāpi na kathenti. Evaṃ mittāmaccānaṃ paribhūto hoti.🔽Āvāhavivāhakānanti āvāhakā nāma ye tassa gharato dārikaṃ gahetukāmā. Vivāhakā nāma
analyzed: na tiṭṭhanti na nisīdanti tassa kāraṇā sakkhipuṭṭhā api na kathenti evam mitta amaccānam paribhūtaḥ hoti  āvāha vivāhakānanti āvāhakāḥ nāma ye tassa gharataḥ dārikam ga hetu kāmāḥ vivāhakāḥ nāma
translated: He does not do as they say. Then they do not stand with him, sit with him, or talk with him. When they are asked to be witnesses, they do not give evidence for him. In this way he is despised by his friends and companions.

original: ye tassa gehe dārikaṃ dātukāmā. Apatthito hotīti anicchito hoti. Nālaṃ dārabharaṇāyāti🔽dārabharaṇāya na samattho. Etassa gehe dārikā dinnāpi etassa gehato āgatāpi amhehi
analyzed: ye tassa gehe dārikam dātu kāmāḥ a patthitaḥ hoti iti an icchitaḥ hoti na alam dāra bharaṇāya ati  dāra bharaṇāya na samatthaḥ etassa gehe dārikā dinnā api etassa gehataḥ āgatā api amhehi
translated: Those who invite and those who are invited: those who invite are those who want to take a girl from his house. Those who are invited are those who want to give a girl to his house. He is not sought after: he is not wanted. He is not good enough to support a wife: he is not able to support a wife.

original: eva positabbā bhavissatiyeva.
analyzed: eva positabbā bhavissatiyā iva
translated: Even if a girl is given to his house, or if a girl comes from his house, we will have to look after her ourselves.

original: Pāpamittatāya chaādīnavādivaṇṇanā🔽252. Dhuttāti akkhadhuttā. Soṇḍāti itthisoṇḍā bhattasoṇḍā pūvasoṇḍā mūlakasoṇḍā.
analyzed: pāpa mitta tāya cha ādīnava ādi vaṇṇanā  dhuttā ati akkhadhuttā soṇḍā ati itthi soṇḍā bhatta soṇḍā pūva soṇḍā mūlaka soṇḍā
translated: The explanation of the six dangers in having bad friends,🔽Gamblers: gamblers with dice. Drunkards: drunkards on women, drunkards on food, drunkards on drink, drunkards on roots, drunkards on greed.

original: Pipāsāti pānasoṇḍā. Nekatikāti patirūpakena vañcanakā. Vañcanikāti sammukhāvañcanāhi
analyzed: pipāsā ati pāna soṇḍā nekatikā ati pati rūpakena vañcanakā vañcanikā ati
translated: Addicted: drunkards on drink. Cheats: cheats by pretending to be suitable. Swindlers: swindlers by cheating in the presence of others.

original: vañcanikā. Sāhasikāti ekāgārikādisāhasikakammakārino. Tyāssa mittā hontīti te assa
analyzed: vañcanikā sāhasikā ati ekāgārika ādi sāhasika kamma kārino mittāḥ honti iti te assa
translated: Deceivers.  Violent: they do the violent kinds of work such as guarding a village, etc.  They are his friends: they are his friends.

original: mittā honti. Aññehi sappurisehi saddhiṃ na ramati gandhamālādīhi alaṅkaritvā varasayanaṃ
analyzed: mittāḥ honti aññehi sappurisehi saddhim na ramati gandha mālā ādīhi alaṅkaritvā vara sayanam
translated: He does not delight in the company of other good people.

original: āropitasūkaro gūthakūpamiva, te pāpamitteyeva upasaṅkamati. Tasmā diṭṭhe ceva dhamme
analyzed: āropita sūkaraḥ gūtha kūpam iva te upasaṅkamati tasmai diṭṭhe ca iva dhamme
translated: He is like a pig that is loaded on to a fine couch decorated with perfumes, garlands, etc., and goes to his bad friends.🔽Therefore he comes to great harm in this very life

original: samparāyañca bahuṃ anatthaṃ nigacchati.🔽253. Atisītanti kammaṃ na karotīti manussehi kālasseva vuṭṭhāya “etha bho kammantaṃ
analyzed: samparāyan ca bahum anattham nigacchati  atisītanti kammam na karoti iti manussehi kālassa iva vuṭṭhāya etha bho kammantam
translated: and in the next life.

original: gacchāmā”ti vutto “atisītaṃ tāva, aṭṭhīni bhijjanti viya, gacchatha tumhe pacchā
analyzed: gacchāma iti vuttaḥ atisītam tāva aṭṭhīni bhijjanti viya gacchatha tumhe pacchā
translated: It is too cold: he does not work. When people get up early in the morning and say, “Come, let us go to work,” he says, “It is too cold. The bones are breaking. You go. I will come later

original: jānissāmī”ti aggiṃ tapanto nisīdati. Te gantvā kammaṃ karonti. Itarassa kammaṃ parihāyati.
analyzed: jānissāmi iti aggim tapantaḥ nisīdati te gantvā kammam karonti itarassa kammam parihāyati
translated: and find out.” He sits warming himself by the fire. They go and work. The other’s work falls behind.

original: Atiuṇhantiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ati uṇhanti ādī supi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies to “It is too hot,” etc.

original: Hoti pānasakhā nāmāti ekacco pānaṭṭhāne surāgeheyeva sahāyo hoti. “Pannasakhā”tipi
analyzed: hoti pānasakhā nāma ati ekacco pānaṭṭhāne surā geheya iva sahāyaḥ hoti pannasakhā atipi
translated: A drinking companion: he has a companion in drinking places, in a tavern. “A drinking companion” is also a reading.

original: pāṭho, ayamevattho. Sammiyasammiyoti samma sammāti vadanto sammukheyeva sahāyo hoti,
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ ayam eva attho sammiya sammiyaḥ ti samma samma ati vadantaḥ sammukheya iva sahāyaḥ hoti
translated: The meaning is the same. ‘If you say “Yes, yes,” you are a friend only face to face;

original: parammukhe verīsadiso otārameva gavesati. Atthesu jātesūti tathārūpesu kiccesu samuppannesu.
analyzed: parammukhe verī sadisaḥ otāram eva gavesati atthesu jātesu iti tathārūpesu kiccesu samuppannesu
translated: behind your back you seek his undoing, as if he were an enemy. ‘ ‘When things arise’ means when such and such affairs arise.

original: Verappasavoti verabahulatā. Anatthatāti anatthakāritā. Sukadariyatāti suṭṭhu kadariyatā
analyzed: vera ppasavaḥ ti vera bahula tā anattha tā ati anattha kāri tā su kadariya tā ati suṭṭhu kadariya tā
translated: ‘The growth of hate’ means the increase of hate. ‘Harm’ means doing harm. ‘Stinginess’ means being very stingy,

original: thaddhamacchariyabhāvo. Udakamiva iṇaṃ vigāhatīti pāsāṇo udakaṃ viya saṃsīdanto iṇaṃ vigāhati.
analyzed: udakam iva iṇam vigāhati iti pāsāṇaḥ udakam viya saṃsīdantaḥ iṇam vigāhati
translated: being hard and miserly. ‘The debt is drowned like water’ means the debt is drowned like a stone in water.

original: Rattinuṭṭhānadessināti rattiṃ anuṭṭhānasīlena. Atisāyamidaṃ ahūti idaṃ atisāyaṃ jātanti
analyzed: rattim anuṭṭhāna sīlena ati sāyam idam ahu iti idam ati sāyam jātan ti
translated: ‘By the virtue of rising at night’ means by the virtue of rising at night. ‘This is too much’ means this is excessive.

original: ye evaṃ vatvā kammaṃ na karonti. Iti vissaṭṭhakammanteti evaṃ vatvā pariccattakammante.
analyzed: ye evam vatvā kammam na karonti iti vissaṭṭha kammante iti evam vatvā pariccatta kammante
translated: Those who say this and do not do the work. ‘Thus in work that is put off’ means in work that is put off by saying this.

original: Atthā accenti māṇaveti evarūpe puggale atthā atikkamanti, tesu na tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: atthā māṇava iti evarūpe puggale atthāḥ atikkamanti tesu na tiṭṭhanti
translated: ‘The good things pass by the young man’ means such good things pass by such a person, they do not stay with him.

original: Tiṇā bhiyyoti tiṇatopi uttari. So sukhaṃ na vihāyatīti so puriso sukhaṃ na jahāti,
analyzed: tiṇā tiṇataḥ api uttari saḥ sukham na vihāyati iti saḥ purisaḥ sukham na jahāti
translated: ‘More than grass’ means more than grass. ‘He does not lose happiness’ means that man does not lose happiness,

original: sukhasamaṅgīyeva hoti. Iminā kathāmaggena imamatthaṃ dasseti “gihibhūtena satā ettakaṃ
analyzed: sukha samaṅgīyā iva hoti iminā kathā maggena imam attham dasseti gihi bhūtena satā ettakam
translated: he is endowed with happiness. By this method of explanation he shows this meaning: “When one is a layman one should

original: kammaṃ na kātabbaṃ, karontassa vaḍḍhi nāma natthi. Idhaloke paraloke garahameva pāpuṇātī”ti.
analyzed: kammam na kātabbam karontassa vaḍḍhi nāma natthi idha loke para loke garaham eva pāpuṇāti iti
translated: He is happy. By this method of exposition he shows the meaning of this stanza thus: “When one is a layman, this kind of action should not be done. There is no increase for one who does it. He gets only blame in this world and the next.”

original: Mittapatirūpakādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: mitta pati rūpaka ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Counterfeit Friend

original: 254. Idāni yo evaṃ karoto anattho uppajjati, aññāni vā pana yāni kānici bhayāni yekeci
analyzed: idāni yaḥ evam karotaḥ anatthaḥ uppajjati aññāni vā pana yāni kānici bhayāni ye keci
translated: Now, the harm that arises to one who acts thus, and whatever other dangers,

original: upaddavā yekeci upasaggā, sabbe te bālaṃ nissāya uppajjanti. Tasmā “evarūpā bālā
analyzed: upaddavāḥ upasaggāḥ sabbe te bālam nissāya uppajjanti tasmai evarūpāḥ bālā
translated: calamities, and misfortunes there may be, all arise because of the fool. Therefore, “such fools

original: na sevitabbā”ti bāle mittapatirūpake amitte dassetuṃ cattārome, gahapatiputta amittātiādimāha.
analyzed: na sevitabbā iti bāle mitta patirūpake amitte dassetum cattāro me gahapati putta amitta ati ādim āha
translated: should not be attended on.” In order to show that the counterfeit friend is a fool, he said, “There are these four kinds of friends, householder’s son.”

original: Tattha aññadatthuharoti sayaṃ tucchahattho āgantvā ekaṃsena yaṃkiñci haratiyeva.🔽Vacīparamoti vacanaparamo vacanamatteneva dāyako kārako viya hoti. Anuppiyabhāṇīti
analyzed: sayam tuccha hatthaḥ āgantvā eka aṃsena yaṃkiñci  vacī paramaḥ ti vacana paramaḥ vacana mattena iva dāyakaḥ kārakaḥ viya hoti anuppiya bhāṇī iti
translated: Herein, the one who takes away what belongs to others comes empty-handed and takes away whatever he likes.🔽The one who is devoted to talk is devoted to mere talk. He is like a giver and a doer by mere talk. The one who speaks what is agreeable

original: anuppiyaṃ bhaṇati. Apāyasahāyoti bhogānaṃ apāyesu sahāyo hoti.
analyzed: anuppiyam bhaṇati apāya sahāyaḥ ti bhogānam apāyesu sahāyaḥ hoti
translated: speaks what is disagreeable. The one who is a companion in misfortune is a companion in the misfortune of wealth.

original: 255. Evaṃ cattāro amitte dassetvā puna tattha ekekaṃ catūhi kāraṇehi vibhajanto catūhi
analyzed: evam cattāraḥ amitte dassetvā puna tattha ekekam catūhi kāraṇehi vibhajantaḥ catūhi
translated: Having thus shown the four kinds of enemies, the Master again divided each of them into four kinds, saying, “There are four kinds of friends, householder’s son” ,

original: kho, gahapatiputtātiādimāha. Tattha aññadatthuharo hotīti ekaṃsena hārakoyeva hoti.🔽Sahāyassa gehaṃ rittahattho āgantvā nivatthasāṭakādīnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, so “ativiya
analyzed: kho gahapati puttā tiādim āha tattha añña datthu haraḥ hoti iti ekaṃsena hoti  sahāyassa geham ritta hatthaḥ āgantvā nivattha sāṭaka ādīnam vaṇṇam bhāsati saḥ ativiya
translated: and so on. Herein, he is a taker of gifts: he is a taker of gifts only.

original: tvaṃ samma imassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsasī”ti aññaṃ nivāsetvā taṃ deti. Appena bahumicchatīti
analyzed: tvam samma imassa vaṇṇam bhāsasi iti aññam nivāsetvā tam deti appena bahum icchati iti
translated: He goes to his friend’s house empty-handed and praises the beauty of the clothes he is wearing, etc., and his friend, thinking, “You praise it so much, my good man,” gives him another pair to wear. He wants much for little:

original: yaṃkiñci appakaṃ datvā tassa santikā bahuṃ pattheti. Bhayassa kiccaṃ karotīti attano🔽bhaye uppanne tassa dāso viya hutvā taṃ taṃ kiccaṃ karoti, ayaṃ sabbadā na karoti,
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci appakam da tvā tassa santikā bahum pattheti bhayassa kiccam karoti iti attano  bhaye uppanne tassa dāsaḥ viya hutvā tam tam kiccam karoti ayam sabbadā na karoti
translated: he asks for much from him in return for something quite insignificant. He does a service out of fear:🔽when danger threatens him, he does this and that service for him as if he were his slave. He does not do this all the time, but he does it when danger arises. He does not do it out of affection.

original: bhaye uppanne karoti, na pemenāti amitto nāma jāto. Sevati atthakāraṇāti mittasanthavavasena
analyzed: bhaye uppanne karoti na pemena ati amittaḥ nāma jātaḥ sevati attha kāraṇā ati mitta santhava vasena
translated: He associates for the sake of self-interest:

original: na sevati, attano atthameva paccāsīsanto sevati.
analyzed: na sevati attanaḥ attham eva paccāsīsantaḥ sevati
translated: he does not associate with him as a friend, but he associates with him because he expects something from him.

original: 256. Atītena paṭisantharatīti sahāye āgate “hiyyo vā pare vā na āgatosi, amhākaṃ
analyzed: atītena paṭisantharati iti sahāye āgate hiyyas vā pare vā na āgataḥ asi amhākam
translated: He welcomes with the past: when friends come, he welcomes them with the past thus, “You did not come yesterday or the day before,

original: imasmiṃ vāre sassaṃ ativiya nipphannaṃ, bahūni sāliyavabījādīni ṭhapetvā maggaṃ olokentā🔽nisīdimha, ajja pana sabbaṃ khīṇa”nti evaṃ atītena saṅgaṇhāti. Anāgatenāti “imasmiṃ
analyzed: imasmin vāre sassam ativiya nipphannam bahūni sāli yava bīja ādīni ṭhapetvā maggaṃ olokentā  nisīdimha ajja pana sabbam khīṇanti evam atītena saṅgaṇhāti anāgatena ati imasmin
translated: but we were looking out for you on the road, having set aside much rice, barley, etc.,🔽because our harvest was very good this year.”

original: vāre amhākaṃ sassaṃ manāpaṃ bhavissati, phalabhārabharitā sāliādayo, sassasaṅgahe
analyzed: vāre amhākam sassam manāpam bhavissati phala bhāra bharitā sāli ādayo sassa saṅgahe
translated: He welcomes with the future: “In this year’s harvest we shall have a good crop, the rice, etc., will be laden with ears and full of grain,

original: kate tumhākaṃ saṅgahaṃ kātuṃ samatthā bhavissāmā”ti evaṃ anāgatena saṅgaṇhāti. Niratthakenāti
analyzed: kate tumhākam saṅgaham kātum samatthāḥ bhavissāma ati evam anāgatena saṅgaṇhāti niratthakena ati
translated: and when the harvest is gathered in we shall be able to welcome you.”

original: hatthikkhandhe vā assapiṭṭhe vā nisinno sahāyaṃ disvā “ehi, bho, idha nisīdā”ti vadati.
analyzed: hatthi kkhandhe vā assa piṭṭhe vā nisinnaḥ sahāyam disvā ehi bho idha nisīda ati vadati
translated: He welcomes with the useless: when he is seated in the place of honour on an elephant or a horse, he says to a friend who has come, “Come, friend, sit here in the place of honour,”

original: Manāpaṃ sāṭakaṃ nivāsetvā “sahāyakassa vata me anucchaviko añño pana mayhaṃ natthī”ti
analyzed: manāpam sāṭakam nivāsetvā sahāyakassa vata me anucchavikaḥ añño pana mayham natthi iti
translated: and he wears a smart sarong, saying, “This is suitable for my friend, but not for me.”

original: vadati, evaṃ niratthakena saṅgaṇhāti nāma. Paccuppannesu kiccesu byasanaṃ dassetīti
analyzed: vadati evam niratthakena saṅgaṇhāti nāma paccuppannesu kiccesu byasanam dasseti iti
translated: He welcomes with the useless in this way. He shows concern for troubles in present business:

original: “sakaṭena me attho”ti vutte “cakkamassa bhinnaṃ, akkho chinno”tiādīni vadati.🔽257. Pāpakampissa anujānātīti pāṇātipātādīsu yaṃkiñci karomāti vutte “sādhu samma🔽karomā”ti anujānāti. Kalyāṇepi eseva nayo. Sahāyo hotīti “asukaṭṭhāne suraṃ pivanti,
analyzed: sakaṭena me attho ti vutte cakkam assa bhinnam akkho chinno ti ādīni vadati  pāpa kampissa anujānāti iti pāṇa atipāta ādīsu yaṃ kiñci karoma ati vutte sādhu samma  karoma iti anujānāti kalyāṇe pi esa iva sahāyaḥ hoti iti asuka ṭṭhāne suram pivanti
translated: “I need a cart,” he says, “but its wheel is broken, its axle is split,” and so on.🔽He approves of evil: when told “Let’s kill someone,” he says, “Good, friend, let’s do it.” The opposite of this is the good friend.

original: ehi tattha gacchāmā”ti vutte sādhūti gacchati. Esa nayo sabbattha. Iti viññāyāti
analyzed: ehi tattha gacchāma iti vutte sādhu uti gacchati esa nayo sabbattha iti viññāya ati
translated: He is a companion: when told “They are drinking liquor at such and such a place, let’s go,” he goes, saying, “Good.” The same method applies in all cases.

original: “mittapatirūpakā ete”ti evaṃ jānitvā.
analyzed: mitta pati rūpakāḥ ete iti evam jānitvā
translated: Knowing thus: knowing that these are counterfeit friends.

original: Suhadamittādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: suhada mitta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of good friends

original: 260. Evaṃ na sevitabbe pāpamitte dassetvā idāni sevitabbe kalyāṇamitte dassento puna cattārome, gahapatiputtātiādimāha. Tattha suhadāti sundarahadayā.🔽261. Pamattaṃ rakkhatīti majjaṃ pivitvā gāmamajjhe vā gāmadvāre vā magge vā nipannaṃ
analyzed: evam na sevitabbe pāpa mitte dassetvā idāni sevitabbe kalyāṇa mitte dassentaḥ puna cattāro me gahapati putta ati ādim āha tattha suhadā ti sundara hadayā 🔽pamattam rakkhati iti majjam pivitvā gāma majjhe vā gāma dvāre vā magge vā nipannam
translated: Having thus shown the bad friends who should not be served, the Master now said “Again, householders’ sons,” etc., in order to show the good friends who should be served.🔽Herein, well-disposed is one with a good heart.

original: disvā “evaṃnipannassa kocideva nivāsanapārupanampi hareyyā”ti samīpe nisīditvā pabuddhakāle
analyzed: disvā evaṃnipannassa kocid eva nivāsana pārupanam pi hareyya ati samīpe nisīditvā pabuddha kāle
translated: Seeing him, he thinks, “Someone might steal even his inner and outer garments,” so he sits near him.🔽When the other wakes up, he takes him and goes.

original: gahetvā gacchati. Pamattassa sāpateyyanti sahāyo bahigato vā hoti suraṃ pivitvā vā
analyzed: gahetvā gacchati pamattassa sāpateyyanti sahāyaḥ bahigataḥ vā hoti suram pivitvā vā
translated: “The property of the heedless”: a friend is either away from home or heedless through drinking liquor,

original: pamatto, gehaṃ anārakkhaṃ “kocideva yaṃkiñci hareyyā”ti gehaṃ pavisitvā tassa dhanaṃ
analyzed: pamattaḥ geham anārakkham kocid eva yaṃ kiñci hareyya ati geham pavisitvā tassa dhanaṃ
translated: and his house is unguarded. Thinking, “Someone might steal something,” he enters the house and🔽guards his property.

original: rakkhati. Bhītassāti kismiñcideva bhaye uppanne “mā bhāyi, mādise sahāye ṭhite kiṃ
analyzed: rakkhati bhītassa ati kismiñcid eva bhaye uppanne mā bhāyi mādise sahāye ṭhite kim
translated: “The frightened”: when some danger arises, he says, “Don’t be afraid, don’t be afraid. With a friend like me to stand by you,🔽what have you to fear?” and he removes the danger and becomes a refuge.

original: bhāyasī”ti taṃ bhayaṃ haranto paṭisaraṇaṃ hoti. Taddiguṇaṃ bhoganti kiccakaraṇīye🔽uppanne sahāyaṃ attano santikaṃ āgataṃ disvā vadati “kasmā āgatosī”ti? Rājakule kammaṃ
analyzed: bhāyasi iti tam bhayam harantaḥ paṭisaraṇam hoti tad diguṇam kicca karaṇīye  uppanne sahāyam attano santikam āgatam disvā vadati kasmai āgataḥ asi iti rāja kule kammaṃ
translated: “The double portion”: when some task has to be done,

original: atthīti. Kiṃ laddhuṃ vaṭṭatīti? Eko kahāpaṇoti. “Nagare kammaṃ nāma na ekakahāpaṇena
analyzed: atthi iti kim laddhum vaṭṭati iti ekaḥ kahāpaṇo ti nagare kammam nāma na eka kahāpaṇena
translated: he sees his friend come to him and says, “Why have you come?” “There’s work in the king’s palace.” “What should be done?” “One kahāpaṇa should be obtained.” “Work in the city is not accomplished with just one kahāpaṇa.

original: nipphajjati, dve gaṇhāhī”ti evaṃ yattakaṃ vadati, tato diguṇaṃ deti.
analyzed: nipphajjati dve gaṇhāhi iti evam yattakam vadati tatas diguṇam deti
translated: Take two.” Thus he gives double the amount his friend asks for.

original: 262. Guyhamassa ācikkhatīti attano guyhaṃ nigūhituṃ yuttakathaṃ aññassa akathetvā
analyzed: guyham assa ācikkhati iti attanaḥ guyham nigūhitum yutta katham aññassa a kathetvā
translated: He tells him his secrets: he does not tell anyone else the kind of talk that should be kept secret,

original: tasseva ācikkhati. Guyhamassa parigūhatīti tena kathitaṃ guyhaṃ yathā añño na jānāti,
analyzed: tassa iva ācikkhati guyham assa parigūhati iti tena kathitam guyham yathā aññaḥ na jānāti
translated: but he tells it to him. He keeps his secrets: he guards the secrets that he tells in such a way that others do not know them.

original: evaṃ rakkhati. Āpadāsu na vijahatīti uppanne bhaye na pariccajati. Jīvitampissa atthāyāti🔽attano jīvitampi tassa sahāyassa atthāya pariccattameva hoti, attano jīvitaṃ agaṇetvāpi
analyzed: evam rakkhati āpadāsu na vijahati iti uppanne bhaye na pariccajati jīvitam pissa atthāya ati  attanaḥ jīvitam pi tassa sahāyassa atthāya pariccattam eva hoti attanaḥ jīvitam a gaṇetvā api
translated: He does not desert him in misfortune: he does not abandon him when some calamity befalls him.

original: tassa kammaṃ karotiyeva.🔽263. Pāpā nivāretīti amhesu passantesu passantesu tvaṃ evaṃ kātuṃ na labhasi, pañca
analyzed: tassa kammam  pāpā nivāreti iti amhesu passantesu passantesu tvam evam kātum na labhasi pañca
translated: His life is for his friend’s sake: his own life is given up for the sake of his friend. He does not count his own life as dear when he does a service for him.

original: verāni dasa akusalakammapathe mā karohīti nivāreti. Kalyāṇe nivesetīti kalyāṇakamme
analyzed: verāni dasa akusala kamma pathe mā karohi iti nivāreti kalyāṇe niveseti iti kalyāṇa kamme
translated: He restrains him from evil: “While I am looking on you cannot do this,” he restrains him, saying, “Do not commit the five crimes, do not commit the ten courses of unprofitable action.”

original: tīsu saraṇesu pañcasīlesu dasakusalakammapathesu vattassu, dānaṃ dehi puññaṃ karohi
analyzed: tīsu saraṇesu pañca sīlesu dasa kusala kamma pathesu vattassu dānam dehi puññam karohi
translated: He establishes him in what is wholesome: “You should practice in the three refuges, in the five precepts, in the ten courses of profitable action; you should give gifts and make merit.”

original: dhammaṃ suṇāhīti evaṃ kalyāṇe niyojeti. Assutaṃ sāvetīti assutapubbaṃ sukhumaṃ nipuṇaṃ
analyzed: dhammam suṇāhi iti evam kalyāṇe niyojeti assutam sāveti iti assuta pubbam sukhumam nipuṇam
translated: He tells him what he has not heard before when he explains to him the subtle and refined meaning of the Dhamma.

original: kāraṇaṃ sāveti. Saggassa magganti idaṃ kammaṃ katvā sagge nibbattantīti evaṃ saggassa maggaṃ ācikkhati.🔽264. Abhavenassa na nandatīti tassa abhavena avuḍḍhiyā puttadārassa vā parijanassa
analyzed: kāraṇam sāveti saggassa magganti idam kammam katvā sagge nibbattanti iti evam saggassa maggam ācikkhati  abhavena assa na nandati iti tassa abhavena avuḍḍhiyā putta dārassa vā parijanassa
translated: He shows him the path to heaven when he tells him, “By doing this action you will be reborn in heaven.”

original: vā tathārūpaṃ pārijuññaṃ disvā vā sutvā vā na nandati, anattamano hoti. Bhavenāti
analyzed: vā tathārūpam pārijuññam disvā vā sutvā vā na nandati anatta manaḥ hoti bhavena ati
translated: He does not rejoice at his loss: when he sees or hears that his son, wife, or other relative has suffered a loss or misfortune, he does not rejoice, he is not pleased.

original: vuḍḍhiyā tathārūpassa sampattiṃ vā issariyappaṭilābhaṃ vā disvā vā sutvā vā nandati,🔽attamano hoti. Avaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānaṃ nivāretīti “asuko virūpo na pāsādiko dujjātiko🔽dussīlo”ti vā vutte “evaṃ mā bhaṇi, rūpavā ca so pāsādiko ca sujāto ca sīlasampanno
analyzed: vuḍḍhiyā tathārūpassa sampattim vā issariya ppaṭilābham vā disvā vā sutvā vā nandati  atta manaḥ hoti avaṇṇam bhaṇamānam nivāreti iti asukaḥ virūpaḥ na pāsādikaḥ dujjātikaḥ  dussīlaḥ ti vā vutte evam mā bhaṇi rūpavā ca so pāsādiko ca su jātaḥ ca sīla sampanno
translated: He rejoices at his gain: when he sees or hears that his son, wife, or other relative has gained some prosperity or has acquired some property, he rejoices, he is pleased.🔽He stops others from criticizing him: when someone says, “So-and-so is ugly, not good-looking, of low birth,🔽of bad character,” he stops him, saying, “Don’t say that. He is good-looking, of good birth, and virtuous.”

original: cā”tiādīhi vacanehi paraṃ attano sahāyassa avaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānaṃ nivāreti. Vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānaṃ
analyzed: ca ati ādīhi vacanehi param attanaḥ sahāyassa avaṇṇam bhaṇamānam nivāreti vaṇṇam bhaṇamānam
translated: He praises him when he sees or hears of his good qualities.

original: pasaṃsatīti “asuko rūpavā pāsādiko sujāto sīlasampanno”ti vutte “aho suṭṭhu vadasi,
analyzed: pasaṃsati iti asukaḥ rūpavā pāsādikaḥ su jātaḥ sīla sampannaḥ ti vutte aho suṭṭhu vadasi
translated: “Praising” means that when someone says, “So-and-so is handsome, good-looking, well-born, and virtuous,” he praises the other person, saying, “You speak well.

original: subhāsitaṃ tayā, evametaṃ, esa puriso rūpavā pāsādiko sujāto sīlasampanno”ti evaṃ🔽attano sahāyakassa paraṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānaṃ pasaṃsati.
analyzed: su bhāsitam tayā evam etam esa purisaḥ rūpavā pāsādikaḥ su jātaḥ sīla sampanno ti evam  attano sahāyakassa param vaṇṇam bhaṇamānam pasaṃsati
translated: You speak well indeed. It is just as you say. That person is handsome, good-looking, well-born, and virtuous.”

original: 265. Jalaṃ aggīva bhāsatīti rattiṃ pabbatamatthake jalamāno aggi viya virocati.
analyzed: jalam aggi iva bhāsati iti rattim pabbata matthake jalamānaḥ aggi viya virocati
translated: “He shines like a fire in the night on a mountain top” means that he shines like a fire burning on a mountain top at night.🔽“As he gathers wealth” means that he gathers wealth righteously, without oppressing himself or others.

original: Bhoge saṃharamānassāti attānampi parampi apīḷetvā dhammena samena bhoge sampiṇḍentassa
analyzed: bhoge saṃharamānassa ati attānam pi param pi a pīḷetvā dhammena samena bhoge sampiṇḍentassa
translated: “Making a heap” means that he makes a great heap of wealth.

original: rāsiṃ karontassa. Bhamarasseva irīyatoti yathā bhamaro pupphānaṃ vaṇṇagandhaṃ apothayaṃ
analyzed: rāsim karontassa bhamarassa iva irīyataḥ iti yathā bhamaraḥ pupphānam vaṇṇa gandham apothayam
translated: “As he goes about like a bee” means that just as a bee, without destroying the color and fragrance of a flower,

original: tuṇḍenapi pakkhehipi rasaṃ āharitvā anupubbena cakkappamāṇaṃ madhupaṭalaṃ karoti,
analyzed: tuṇḍena pi pakkhehi pi rasam āharitvā anupubbena cakkappamāṇam madhu paṭalam karoti
translated: takes the juice with its mouth and wings and gradually makes a honeycomb the size of a wheel,🔽so he gradually makes a great heap of wealth.

original: evaṃ anupubbena mahantaṃ bhogarāsiṃ karontassa. Bhogā sannicayaṃ yantīti tassa bhogā
analyzed: evam anupubbena mahantam bhoga rāsim karontassa bhogā sannicayam yanti iti tassa bhogā
translated: “His wealth grows” means that his wealth

original: nicayaṃ gacchanti. Kathaṃ? Anupubbena upacikāhi saṃvaḍḍhiyamāno vammiko viya. Tenāha
analyzed: nicayam gacchanti katham anupubbena upacikāhi saṃvaḍḍhiyamānaḥ vammikaḥ viya tena āha
translated: How? Like an ant-hill gradually growing by the ants adding to it. Hence it is said:

original: “vammikovupacīyatī”ti. Yathā vammiko upaciyati, evaṃ nicayaṃ yantīti attho.
analyzed: iti yathā vammikaḥ evam nicayam yanti iti attho
translated: “It grows like an ant-hill.” The meaning is: they go on accumulating like an ant-hill.

original: Samāhatvāti samāharitvā. Alamatthoti yuttasabhāvo samattho vā pariyattarūpo gharāvāsaṃ saṇṭhāpetuṃ.
analyzed: samāhatvā iti samāharitvā alam attho ti yutta sabhāvaḥ samatthaḥ vā pariyatta rūpaḥ ghara āvāsam saṇṭhāpetum
translated: Having gathered: having collected. Enough: suitable, able, sufficient, to maintain a household life.

original: Idāni yathā vā gharāvāso saṇṭhapetabbo, tathā ovadanto catudhā vibhaje bhogetiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yathā vā ghara āvāso saṇṭhapetabbo tathā ovadantaḥ catudhā vibhaje bhoga iti ādim āha
translated: Now, advising how a household life should be maintained, he said: “Divide your wealth into four parts,” etc.

original: Tattha sa ve mittāni ganthatīti so evaṃ vibhajanto mittāni ganthati nāma abhejjamānāni
analyzed: tattha sa ve mittāni ganthati iti saḥ evam vibhajantaḥ mittāni ganthati nāma a bhejjamānāni
translated: Herein, he binds his friends means he binds, i.e., establishes, unbreakable

original: ṭhapeti. Yassa hi bhogā santi, so eva mitte ṭhapetuṃ sakkoti, na itaro.🔽Ekena bhoge bhuñjeyyāti ekena koṭṭhāsena bhoge bhuñjeyya. Dvīhi kammaṃ payojayeti
analyzed: ṭhapeti yassa hi bhogāḥ santi saḥ eva mitte ṭhapetum sakkoti na itaro  ekena bhoge bhuñjeyya ati ekena koṭṭhāsena bhoge bhuñjeyya dvīhi kammam payojaya iti
translated: friendships by dividing his wealth in this way. For one who has wealth can establish friendships, not another.🔽With one part he should enjoy himself: with one quarter he should enjoy himself. With two he should make his business pay:

original: dvīhi koṭṭhāsehi kasivāṇijjādikammaṃ payojeyya. Catutthañca nidhāpeyyāti catutthaṃ
analyzed: dvīhi koṭṭhāsehi kasi vāṇijja ādi kammam payojeyya catuttham ca nidhāpeyya ati catuttham
translated: with two quarters he should make his business of agriculture, trade, etc., pay. And the fourth part he should set aside:🔽and the fourth part

original: koṭṭhāsaṃ nidhāpetvā ṭhapeyya. Āpadāsu bhavissatīti kulānañhi na sabbakālaṃ ekasadisaṃ🔽vattati, kadāci rājādivasena āpadāpi uppajjanti, tasmā evaṃ āpadāsu uppannāsu bhavissatīti
analyzed: koṭṭhāsam nidhāpetvā ṭhapeyya āpadāsu bhavissati iti kulānam hi na sabbakālam eka sadisam  vattati kadāci rāja ādi vasena āpadā api uppajjanti tasmai evam āpadāsu uppannāsu bhavissati iti
translated: and he should set aside one portion, thinking, “This will be for emergencies.” For it is not always the case that families are in the same position all the time.🔽Sometimes emergencies arise through kings, etc., So he said, “He should set aside one portion, thinking, ‘This will be for emergencies’ when emergencies arise.”

original: “ekaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ nidhāpeyyā”ti āha. Imesu pana catūsu koṭṭhāsesu katarakoṭṭhāsaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: ekam koṭṭhāsam nidhāpeyya iti āha imesu pana catūsu koṭṭhāsesu katara koṭṭhāsam gahetvā
translated: But which of these four portions should be taken and what should be done with it?

original: kusalaṃ kātabbanti? “Bhoge bhuñjeyyā”ti vuttakoṭṭhāsaṃ. Tato gaṇhitvā bhikkhūnampi
analyzed: kusalam kātabbanti bhoge bhuñjeyya ati vutta koṭṭhāsam tatas gaṇhitvā bhikkhūnam pi
translated: The portion called “for enjoyment” should be taken. After taking it, he should give to the bhikkhus,

original: kapaṇaddhikādīnampi dātabbaṃ, pesakāranhāpitādīnampi vetanaṃ dātabbaṃ.
analyzed: kapaṇaddhika ādīnam pi dātabbam pesaka aranhāpita ādīnam pi vetanam dātabbam
translated: to the poor and destitute, and he should pay the wages of those who work for him, such as weavers, barbers, etc.

original: Chaddisāpaṭicchādanakaṇḍavaṇṇanā🔽266. Iti bhagavā ettakena kathāmaggena evaṃ gahapatiputtassa ariyasāvako catūhi kāraṇehi
analyzed: chaddisā paṭicchādana kaṇḍa vaṇṇanā  iti bhagavā ettakena kathā maggena evam gahapatiputtassa ariyasāvako catūhi kāraṇehi
translated: The Description of the Section on the Six Directions

original: akusalaṃ pahāya chahi kāraṇehi bhogānaṃ apāyamukhaṃ vajjetvā soḷasa mittāni sevanto
analyzed: akusalam pahāya chahi kāraṇehi bhogānam apāya mukham soḷasa mittāni sevantaḥ
translated: Thus, by this method of exposition, the noble disciple, the householder, has abandoned unprofit by four grounds, has avoided the six grounds for the loss of property, and is associating with the sixteen kinds of friends.

original: gharāvāsaṃ saṇṭhapetvā dārabharaṇaṃ karonto dhammikena ājīvena jīvati, devamanussānañca
analyzed: ghara āvāsam saṇṭhapetvā dāra bharaṇam karontaḥ dhammikena ājīvena jīvati deva manussānam ca
translated: He lives by a righteous means of livelihood, and he shines among gods and men like a flame.

original: antare aggikkhandho viya virocatīti vajjanīyadhammavajjanatthaṃ sevitabbadhammasevanatthañca
analyzed: antare aggi kkhandhaḥ viya virocati iti vajjanīya dhamma vajjana ttham sevitabba dhamma sevana ttham ca
translated: The purpose of this is to show the avoidance of what is blameworthy and the practice of what is praiseworthy.

original: ovādaṃ datvā idāni namassitabbā cha disā dassento kathañca gahapatiputtātiādimāha.
analyzed: ovādam da tvā idāni namassitabbā cha disāḥ dassento katham ca gahapati putta ati ādim āha
translated: Having given this advice, he now said “How should a clansman serve the six directions?” in order to show the six directions that should be honoured.

original: Tattha chaddisāpaṭicchādīti yathā chahi disāhi āgamanabhayaṃ na āgacchati, khemaṃ🔽hoti nibbhayaṃ evaṃ viharanto “chaddisāpaṭicchādī”ti vuccati. “Puratthimā disā mātāpitaro
analyzed: tattha yathā chahi disāhi āgamana bhayam naḥ āgacchati khemam  hoti nibbhayam evam viharantaḥ chaddisāpaṭicchādī iti vuccati puratthimā disā mātā pitaro
translated: Herein, he is a “protector of the six directions” in the sense that he is safe and fearless, since he has no fear of danger coming from the six directions.

original: veditabbā”tiādīsu mātāpitaro pubbupakāritāya puratthimā disāti veditabbā. Ācariyā🔽dakkhiṇeyyatāya dakkhiṇā disāti. Puttadārā piṭṭhito anubandhanavasena pacchimā disāti.
analyzed: veditabbā ati ādīsu mātā pitaraḥ pubbupakāritāya puratthimā disā ati veditabbāḥ ācariyāḥ  dakkhiṇeyyatāya dakkhiṇā disā ati putta dārā piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhana vasena pacchimā disā ati
translated: “The eastern direction” should be understood as the parents, because they are the eastern direction in the sense of rising first.🔽The teachers are the southern direction because they are worthy of offerings.🔽The wife and children are the western direction because they follow behind.

original: Mittāmaccā yasmā so mittāmacce nissāya te te dukkhavisese uttarati, tasmā uttarā
analyzed: mitta amaccā yasmai saḥ mitta amacce nissāya te te dukkha visese uttarati tasmai uttarā
translated: Friends and companions are the northern direction because one overcomes various misfortunes by depending on friends and companions.

original: disāti. Dāsakammakarā pādamūle patiṭṭhānavasena heṭṭhimā disāti. Samaṇabrāhmaṇā guṇehi
analyzed: disā ati dāsa kammakarā pāda mūle patiṭṭhāna vasena heṭṭhimā disā ati samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ guṇehi
translated: “The lower direction”: slaves and servants, because they stand at the foot of the master’s feet. “Monks and brahmans”:

original: upari ṭhitabhāvena uparimā disāti veditabbā.🔽267. Bhato ne bharissāmīti ahaṃ mātāpitūhi thaññaṃ pāyetvā hatthapāde vaḍḍhetvā mukhena
analyzed: upari ṭhita bhāvena uparimā disā ati veditabbā  bhato ne bharissāmi iti aham mātā pitūhi thaññam pāyetvā hattha pāde vaḍḍhetvā mukhena
translated: The lower direction: slaves and servants are the lower direction because they are at the foot of the master’s feet. The higher direction: ascetics and brahmins are the higher direction because they are above in virtue.

original: siṅghāṇikaṃ apanetvā nahāpetvā maṇḍetvā bhato bharito jaggito, svāhaṃ ajja te mahallake
analyzed: siṅghāṇikam apanetvā nahāpetvā maṇḍetvā bhataḥ bharitaḥ jaggitaḥ svāham ajja te mahallake
translated: . ‘I was fed and brought up’ means: my parents fed me with milk and so on, they increased my hands and feet, they removed my snot with their mouths, they bathed me, they adorned me, they fed me, they brought me up, they looked after me. Now I, a young man,

original: pādadhovananhāpanayāgubhattadānādīhi bharissāmi.🔽Kiccaṃ nesaṃ karissāmīti attano kammaṃ ṭhapetvā mātāpitūnaṃ rājakulādīsu uppannaṃ🔽kiccaṃ gantvā karissāmi. Kulavaṃsaṃ saṇṭhapessāmīti mātāpitūnaṃ santakaṃ khettavatthuhiraññasuvaṇṇādiṃ
analyzed: pāda dhovana nhāpana yāgu bhatta dāna ādīhi bharissāmi  kiccam na isam karissāmi iti attanaḥ kammam ṭhapetvā mātā pitūnam rāja kula ādīsu uppannam  kiccam gantvā karissāmi kula vaṃsam saṇṭhapessāmi iti mātā pitūnam santakam khetta vatthu hirañña suvaṇṇa ādim
translated: will feed and bring up my old parents by washing their feet, bathing them, giving them gruel and meals, and so on.

original: avināsetvā rakkhantopi kulavaṃsaṃ saṇṭhapeti nāma. Mātāpitaro adhammikavaṃsato hāretvā
analyzed: a vināsetvā rakkhantaḥ api kula vaṃsam saṇṭhapeti nāma mātā pitaraḥ adhammika vaṃsataḥ hāretvā
translated: ‘I will do what has to be done for them’ means: I will put aside my own work and go and do whatever work has to arise for my parents in the king’s court and so on. ‘I will maintain the family tradition’ means: I will maintain the family tradition by protecting and not destroying the family’s property such as fields, land, gold, silver, and so on, which belongs to my parents. ‘I will carry on the family business’ means: I will carry on the family business by not abandoning the family’s business such as agriculture, trade, cattle-breeding, and so on, which belongs to my parents.

original: dhammikavaṃse ṭhapentopi, kulavaṃsena āgatāni salākabhattādīni anupacchinditvā pavattentopi
analyzed: dhammika vaṃse ṭhapentaḥ api kula vaṃsena āgatāni salākabhatta ādīni an upacchinditvā pavattentaḥ api
translated: and by establishing them in the Dhamma line, and by not cutting off the family’s food-alms, etc., that have come down from the family line,

original: kulavaṃsaṃ saṇṭhapeti nāma. Idaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “kulavaṃsaṃ saṇṭhapessāmī”ti.
analyzed: kula vaṃsam saṇṭhapeti nāma idam sandhāya vuttam kula vaṃsam saṇṭhapessāmi iti
translated: he establishes the family line. It is in reference to this that it is said: “I shall establish the family line.”

original: Dāyajjaṃ paṭipajjāmīti mātāpitaro attano ovāde avattamāne micchāpaṭipanne dārake
analyzed: dāyajjam paṭipajjāmi iti mātā pitaraḥ attano ovāde avattamāne micchā paṭipanne dārake
translated: I shall conduct myself as an heir: if parents’ children do not follow their advice, they conduct themselves wrongly,

original: vinicchayaṃ patvā aputte karonti, te dāyajjārahā na honti. Ovāde vattamāne pana kulasantakassa
analyzed: vinicchayam patvā aputte karonti te dāyajja āra hā na honti ovāde vattamāne pana kula santakassa
translated: and when the case is decided, they are made heirs to no one. But if they follow their advice, they are made heirs to the family’s property.

original: sāmike karonti, ahaṃ evaṃ vattissāmīti adhippāyena “dāyajjaṃ paṭipajjāmī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sāmike karonti aham evam vattissāmi iti adhippāyena dāyajjam paṭipajjāmi iti vuttam
translated: The meaning is: “I shall conduct myself with the intention of being an heir.”

original: Dakkhiṇaṃ anuppadassāmīti tesaṃ pattidānaṃ katvā tatiyadivasato paṭṭhāya dānaṃ anuppadassāmi.
analyzed: dakkhiṇam anuppadassāmi iti tesam patti dānam katvā tatiya divasataḥ paṭṭhāya dānam anuppadassāmi
translated: I shall give the funeral rites: having given them the funeral shroud, I shall give the funeral rites from the third day on.

original: Pāpā nivārentīti pāṇātipātādīnaṃ diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaṃ ādīnavaṃ vatvā, “tāta,
analyzed: pāpāḥ nivārenti iti pāṇātipāta ādīnam diṭṭhadhammika samparāyikam ādīnavam vatvā tāta
translated: I shall restrain them from evil: having pointed out the danger in killing living beings, etc., in this world and the next, saying, “Dear,

original: mā evarūpaṃ karī”ti nivārenti, katampi garahanti. Kalyāṇe nivesentīti anāthapiṇḍiko
analyzed: nivārenti garahanti kalyāṇe nivesenti iti
translated: don’t do this,” they restrain them from evil. And when they have done evil, they rebuke them. I shall establish them in good: Anathapindika

original: viya lañjaṃ datvāpi sīlasamādānādīsu nivesenti. Sippaṃ sikkhāpentīti attano ovāde🔽ṭhitabhāvaṃ ñatvā vaṃsānugataṃ muddāgaṇanādisippaṃ sikkhāpenti. Patirūpenāti kulasīlarūpādīhi anurūpena.🔽Samaye dāyajjaṃ niyyādentīti samaye dhanaṃ denti. Tattha niccasamayo kālasamayoti🔽dve samayā. Niccasamaye denti nāma “uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya imaṃ gaṇhitabbaṃ gaṇha, ayaṃ
analyzed: viya lañjam da tvā api sīla samādāna ādīsu nivesenti sippam sikkhāpenti iti attano ovāde  ṭhita bhāvam ñatvā vaṃsa anugatam muddā gaṇanā ādi sippam sikkhāpenti patirūpena ati kula sīla rūpa ādīhi anurūpena  samaye dāyajjam niyyādenti iti samaye dhanam denti tattha nicca samayaḥ kāla samayaḥ ti  dve samayā nicca samaye denti nāma uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya imam gaṇhitabbam gaṇha ayam
translated: They make them learn a craft. They make them learn a craft such as calculation, etc., which is handed down by tradition, knowing that they will be established in their own advice. They give them a suitable wife. They give them a wife who is suitable in family and virtue, etc. They give them their inheritance at the right time. They give them wealth at the right time. Herein, there are two times: the time of need and the time of opportunity. They give at the time of need thus: “You must take this and take that when you are in need of it.”

original: te paribbayo hotu, iminā kusalaṃ karohī”ti denti. Kālasamaye denti nāma sikhāṭhapanaāvāhavivāhādisamaye
analyzed: te paribbayaḥ hotu iminā kusalam karohi iti denti kāla samaye denti nāma sikhāṭhapana āvāha vivāha ādi samaye
translated: They make them learn a craft. They make them learn a craft such as calculation, etc., which is handed down by tradition. They give them a suitable dowry. They give them a dowry in keeping with their family, virtue, beauty, etc. They give them in marriage at the right time. They give them at the right time, that is, at the time when they will not be poor. Herein, there are two times: the permanent time and the occasional time. They give them at the permanent time when they give them saying, “Take this and take it as your own. Make merit with it”;🔽and they give them at the occasional time when they give them on an occasion such as the making of a topknot, a going to the bathing place, a marriage, etc.

original: denti. Apica pacchime kāle maraṇamañce nipannassa “iminā kusalaṃ karohī”ti dentāpi
analyzed: denti apica pacchime kāle maraṇa mañce nipannassa iminā kusalam karohi iti dentā api
translated: Moreover, they give them at the right time when they give them saying, “Make merit with this” to one who is lying on a deathbed in the last watch of the last watch of life.

original: samaye denti nāma. Paṭicchannā hotīti yaṃ puratthimadisato bhayaṃ āgaccheyya, yathā
analyzed: samaye denti nāma paṭicchannā hoti iti yam puratthima disataḥ bhayam āgaccheyya yathā
