original: dhaje ussāpetvā gehadvāresu puṇṇaghaṭe ca kadaliyo ca ṭhapāpetvā sakalanagaraṃ dīpamālādīhi🔽vippakiṇṇatārakaṃ viya katvā khīrapāyake dārake khīraṃ pāyyetha, dahare kumāre lahuṃ
analyzed: dhaje ussāpetvā geha dvāresu puṇṇa ghaṭe ca kadaliyaḥ ca sakala nagaram dīpa mālā ādīhi  vippakiṇṇa tārakam viya katvā khīra pāyake dārake khīram pāyyetha dahare kumāre lahum
translated: and flags hoisted, and full water-pots and plantain trees placed at the doors of the houses, and the whole city🔽lit up with garlands of lamps so that it was like the sky spangled with stars. He had the children who were being fed with milk told to drink it, and the young boys told to eat quickly,

original: lahuṃ bhojāpetvā sayāpetha, uccāsaddaṃ mā karittha, ajja ekarattiṃ satthā antogāme
analyzed: lahum bhojāpetvā sayāpetha uccāsaddam mā karittha ajja eka rattim satthā antogāme
translated: and then to lie down, and he told them not to make a noise, saying, “The Master will stay in the village for one night only.

original: vasissati, buddhā nāma appasaddakāmā hontīti bheriṃ carāpetvā sayaṃ daṇḍadīpikaṃ
analyzed: vasissati buddhāḥ nāma appasadda kāmāḥ honti iti bherim carāpetvā sayam daṇḍadīpikam
translated: Buddhas are fond of quiet.” And having had this proclamation made with drums, he himself took a torch

original: ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
analyzed: ādāya yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamiṃsu
translated: and went to the Blessed One.

original: 299. Bhagavantaṃyeva purakkhatvāti bhagavantaṃ purato katvā. Tattha bhagavā bhikkhūnañceva
analyzed: bhagavantam yeva purakkhatvā iti bhagavantam puratas katvā tattha bhagavā bhikkhūnam ca iva
translated: With the Blessed One in front: having made the Blessed One go in front. There the Blessed One, sitting in the midst of the bhikkhus and lay devotees,

original: upāsakānañca majjhe nisinno ativiya virocati, samantapāsādiko suvaṇṇavaṇṇo abhirūpo
analyzed: upāsakānam ca majjhe nisinnaḥ ativiya virocati samanta pāsādikaḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ abhirūpaḥ
translated: shone forth in splendour, being lovely on all sides, golden-hued,

original: dassanīyo. Purimakāyato suvaṇṇavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: dassanīyaḥ purima kāyataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattham ṭhānam gaṇhāti
translated: and it is worth seeing. From his front part a golden-coloured radiance issues and extends for eighty cubits.

original: Pacchimakāyato. Dakkhiṇahatthato. Vāmahatthato suvaṇṇavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā asītihatthaṃ🔽ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti. Upari kesantato paṭṭhāya sabbakesāvaṭṭehi moragīvavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā🔽gaganatale asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti. Heṭṭhā pādatalehi pavāḷavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā
analyzed: pacchima kāyataḥ dakkhiṇa hatthataḥ vāma hatthataḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā asīti hattham  ṭhānam gaṇhāti upari kesantataḥ paṭṭhāya sabba kesāvaṭṭehi moragī vavaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā  gagana tale asīti hattham ṭhānam gaṇhāti heṭṭhā pāda talehi pavāḷa vaṇṇā rasmi uṭṭhahitvā
translated: From his back part, from his right hand, from his left hand, a golden-coloured radiance issues and extends for eighty cubits.🔽From the top of his head, starting from the hair-line, from all the hair-rings, a peacock-necked-coloured radiance issues and extends for eighty cubits🔽in the sky. From the soles of his feet, a coral-coloured radiance issues and extends for eighty cubits

original: ghanapathaviyaṃ asītihatthaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti. Evaṃ samantā asīti hatthamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ghana pathaviyam asīti hattham ṭhānam gaṇhāti evam samantā asīti hattha mattam ṭhānam
translated: in the solid earth. Thus all round, for eighty cubits,

original: chabbaṇṇā buddharasmiyo vijjotamānā vipphandamānā vidhāvanti. Sabbe disābhāgā suvaṇṇacampakapupphehi
analyzed: chabbaṇṇāḥ buddha rasmiyaḥ vijjotamānāḥ vipphandamānāḥ vidhāvanti sabbe disābhāgā suvaṇṇa campaka pupphehi
translated: the six-coloured Buddha-rays shine, shine forth, shine forth brightly, and spread out. All the directions are as if strewn with golden campaka flowers,

original: vikiriyamānā viya suvaṇṇaghaṭato nikkhantasuvaṇṇarasadhārāhi siñcamānā viya pasāritasuvaṇṇapaṭaparikkhittā
analyzed: vikiriyamānā viya suvaṇṇa ghaṭataḥ nikkhanta suvaṇṇa rasa dhārāhi siñcamānā viya pasārita suvaṇṇa paṭa parikkhittā
translated: as if sprinkled with streams of golden liquid issuing from a golden jar, as if surrounded by extended golden cloths,

original: viya verambhavātasamuṭṭhitakiṃsukakaṇikārapupphacuṇṇasamākiṇṇā viya ca vippakāsanti.
analyzed: viya verambha vāta samuṭṭhita kiṃsuka kaṇikāra puppha cuṇṇa samākiṇṇāḥ viya ca vippakāsanti
translated: and they shine as if covered with the pollen of kimsuka and karnikara flowers stirred up by the wind from Verambha.

original: Bhagavatopi asītianubyañjanabyāmappabhādvattiṃsavaralakkhaṇasamujjalaṃ sarīraṃ samuggatatārakaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ pi asi iti anubyañjana byāma ppabhā advat tiṃsa vara lakkhaṇa samujjalam sarīram samuggata tārakam
translated: and the rays of the thirty-two major marks and the eighty minor marks of the Blessed One shone forth,

original: viya gaganatalaṃ, vikasitamiva padumavanaṃ, sabbapāliphullo viya yojanasatiko pāricchattako
analyzed: viya gagana talam vikasitam iva paduma vanam sabba pāli phullaḥ viya yojana satikaḥ pāricchattako
translated: like the sky with its stars, like a lotus pond with its lotuses, like a coral tree with its flowers,

original: paṭipāṭiyā ṭhapitānaṃ dvattiṃsacandānaṃ dvattiṃsasūriyānaṃ dvattiṃsacakkavattirājānaṃ
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā dvattiṃsa candānam dvattiṃsa sūriyānam dvattiṃsa cakkavatti rājānam
translated: like the thirty-two moons on the last day of the waxing fortnight, like the thirty-two suns on the last day of the waning fortnight, like the thirty-two world-ruling monarchs,

original: dvattiṃsadevarājānaṃ dvattiṃsamahābrahmānaṃ siriyā siriṃ abhibhavamānaṃ viya virocati.🔽Parivāretvā nisinnā bhikkhūpi sabbeva appicchā santuṭṭhā pavivittā asaṃsaṭṭhā āraddhavīriyā
analyzed: dvattiṃsa devarājānam dvattiṃsa mahābrahmānam siriyā sirim abhibhavamānam viya virocati  parivāretvā nisinnāḥ bhikkhū pi sabbe eva appicchāḥ santuṭṭhāḥ pavivittāḥ asaṃsaṭṭhāḥ āraddha vīriyāḥ
translated: like the thirty-two gods of the Tavatimsa heaven, like the thirty-two Maha Brahma gods,

original: vattāro vacanakkhamā codakā pāpagarahino sīlasampannā samādhisampannā paññāvimutti
analyzed: vattāraḥ vacana kkhamā codakā pāpa garahino sīla sampannā samādhi sampannā paññā vimutti
translated: and the bhikkhus sitting in attendance on the Blessed One were all of few wishes, contented, secluded, unassociated with the laity, and devoted to meditation.

original: vimuttiñāṇadassanasampannā. Tehi parivārito bhagavā rattakambalaparikkhitto viya
analyzed: vimutti ñāṇa dassana sampannā tehi parivāritaḥ bhagavā ratta kambala parikkhittaḥ viya
translated: and endowed with the knowledge and conduct of emancipation. Surrounded by them the Lord shone like a golden casket

original: suvaṇṇakkhandho, rattapadumavanasaṇḍamajjhagatā viya suvaṇṇanāvā, pavāḷavedikāparikkhitto🔽viya suvaṇṇapāsādo virocittha.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa kkhandhaḥ ratta paduma vana saṇḍa majjha gatā viya suvaṇṇa nāvā pavāḷa vedikā parikkhitto  viya suvaṇṇa pāsādaḥ virocittha
translated: with a red blanket spread over it, like a golden ship in the midst of a forest of red lotuses, like a golden palace surrounded by a rampart of rubies.

original: Asītimahātherāpi naṃ meghavaṇṇaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ pārupitvā maṇivammavammitā viya mahānāgā
analyzed: asīti mahā therā api nam megha vaṇṇam paṃsukūlam pārupitvā maṇi vamma vammitāḥ viya mahā nāgā
translated: The eighty great elders, too, wearing their dusty rags the colour of rainclouds, surrounded him like great elephants

original: parivārayiṃsu vantarāgā bhinnakilesā vijaṭitajaṭā chinnabandhanā kule vā gaṇe vā
analyzed: parivārayiṃsu vanta rāgā bhinna kilesā vijaṭita jaṭā chinna bandhanā kule vā gaṇe vā
translated: with their she-elephants, with their inner passions destroyed, their defilements ended, their matted hair unraveled, their bonds cut,

original: alaggā. Iti bhagavā sayaṃ vītarāgo vītarāgehi, vītadoso vītadosehi, vītamoho vītamohehi,
analyzed: alaggāḥ iti bhagavā sayam vīta rāgaḥ vīta rāgehi vīta dosaḥ vīta dosehi vīta mohaḥ vīta mohehi
translated: without regard for family or clan. Thus the Lord, himself free from passion, was surrounded by those free from passion; himself free from hatred, by those free from hatred; himself free from delusion, by those free from delusion;

original: nittaṇho nittaṇhehi, nikkileso nikkilesehi, sayaṃ buddho bahussutabuddhehi parivārito
analyzed: nittaṇhaḥ nittaṇhehi nikkilesaḥ nikkilesehi sayam buddhaḥ bahussuta buddhehi parivāritaḥ
translated: himself free from desire, by those free from desire; himself free from defilement, by those free from defilement; himself enlightened, by those enlightened in discipleship;

original: pattaparivāritaṃ viya kesaraṃ, kesaraparivāritā viya kaṇṇikā, aṭṭhanāgasahassaparivārito
analyzed: patta parivāritam viya kesaram kesara parivāritā viya kaṇṇikā aṭṭha nāga sahassa parivārito
translated: surrounded by them, he shone like a lotus by its stalks, like a jasmine by its creepers, like a Nāga by its thousand young elephants.

original: viya chaddanto nāgarājā, navutihaṃsasahassaparivārito viya dhataraṭṭho haṃsarājā,
analyzed: viya chaddantaḥ nāga rājā navuti haṃsa sahassa parivāritaḥ viya dhataraṭṭhaḥ haṃsa rājā
translated: like the king of geese, Dhataraṭṭha, surrounded by ninety thousand geese,

original: senaṅgaparivārito viya cakkavattirājā, marugaṇaparivārito viya sakko devarājā, brahmagaṇaparivārito
analyzed: senaṅga parivāritaḥ viya cakkavatti rājā maru gaṇa parivāritaḥ viya sakkaḥ devarājā brahma gaṇa parivāritaḥ
translated: like the universal monarch, surrounded by his army, like Sakka, the king of the gods, surrounded by the Maruts,🔽like the great Brahmā, Hārita, surrounded by the Brahmā group,

original: viya hārito mahābrahmā, asamena buddhavesena aparimāṇena buddhavilāsena tassaṃ parisati
analyzed: viya hāritaḥ mahābrahmā asamena buddha vesena aparimāṇena buddha vilāsena tassam parisati
translated: seated in that assembly,

original: nisinno pāveyyake malle bahudeva rattiṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā uyyojesi.
analyzed: nisinnaḥ pāveyyake malle bahudeva rattim dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā uyyojesi
translated: after instructing the Mallas of Pāvā for much of the night with a talk about the Dhamma, he dismissed them, saying:

original: Ettha ca dhammikathā nāma sandhāgāraanumodanappaṭisaṃyuttā pakiṇṇakakathā veditabbā.🔽Tadā hi bhagavā ākāsagaṅgaṃ otārento viya pathavojaṃ ākaḍḍhanto viya mahājambuṃ matthake🔽gahetvā cālento viya yojaniyamadhugaṇḍaṃ cakkayantena pīḷetvā madhupānaṃ pāyamāno
analyzed: ettha ca dhammikathā nāma sandhāgāra anumodana paṭisaṃyuttā pakiṇṇaka kathā veditabbā  tadā hi bhagavā ākāsagaṅgam otārentaḥ viya pathavojam ākaḍḍhantaḥ viya mahājambum matthake  gahetvā cālentaḥ yojaniya madhu gaṇḍam cakkayantena pīḍetvā madhu pānam pāyamānaḥ
translated: “The talk about the Dhamma” here should be understood as miscellaneous talk connected with the hall of truth and rejoicing.🔽For at that time the Blessed One gave the Mallas of Pāvā miscellaneous talk that was conducive to welfare and happiness,🔽like one pouring down the celestial Ganges, like one dragging along the earth, like one shaking a great rose-apple tree by the top,

original: viya ca pāveyyakānaṃ mallānaṃ hitasukhāvahaṃ pakiṇṇakakathaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: viya ca pāveyyakānam mallānam hita sukha āvaham pakiṇṇaka katham kathesi
translated: like one drinking honey-wine by pressing with a wheel-weapon a lump of honey the size of a yojana,

original: 300. Tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtanti yaṃ yaṃ disaṃ anuviloketi, tattha tattha tuṇhībhūtameva.🔽Anuviloketvāti maṃsacakkhunā dibbacakkhunāti dvīhi cakkhūhi tato tato viloketvā.
analyzed: tuṇhībhūtam yam yam disam tattha tattha tuṇhībhūtam eva  anuviloketvā ti maṃsa cakkhunā dibba cakkhunā ati dvīhi cakkhūhi tatas tatas viloketvā
translated: ‘Silent, silent’: in whatever direction he looked, it was silent there.🔽‘Having looked around’: having looked here and there with the two kinds of eyes, that is, with the fleshly eye and with the divine eye.

original: Maṃsacakkhunā hi nesaṃ bahiddhā iriyāpathaṃ pariggahesi. Tattha ekabhikkhussāpi neva
analyzed: maṃsa cakkhunā hi nesam bahiddhā iriyāpatham pariggahesi tattha eka bhikkhussa api na eva
translated: For with the fleshly eye he discerned their deportment externally. There🔽not even a single bhikkhu had any fidgeting with the hands or fidgeting with the feet,

original: hatthakukkuccaṃ na pādakukkuccaṃ ahosi, na koci sīsamukkhipi, na kathaṃ kathesi,
analyzed: hattha kukkuccam na pāda kukkuccam ahosi na koci sīsam ukkhipi na katham kathesi
translated: no one tossed his head about or talked or sat dozing.

original: na niddāyanto nisīdi. Sabbepi tīhi sikkhāhi sikkhitā nivāte padīpasikhā viya niccalā
analyzed: na niddāyantaḥ nisīdi sabbe api tīhi sikkhāhi sikkhitāḥ nivāte padīpa sikhā viya niccalā
translated: All were sitting like the flame of a lamp in a sheltered place, trained in the three trainings.

original: nisīdiṃsu. Iti nesaṃ imaṃ iriyāpathaṃ maṃsacakkhunā pariggahesi. Ālokaṃ pana vaḍḍhayitvā
analyzed: nisīdiṃsu iti na isam imam iriyāpatham maṃsa cakkhunā pariggahesi ālokam pana vaḍḍhayitvā
translated: So with the fleshly eye he discerned their deportment. But after increasing the light

original: dibbacakkhunā hadayarūpaṃ disvā abbhantaragataṃ sīlaṃ olokesi. So anekasatānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: dibba cakkhunā hadaya rūpam disvā abbhantara gatam sīlam olokesi saḥ aneka satānam bhikkhūnam
translated: with the divine eye he saw the heart-basis materiality and looked at the virtue within. He saw the virtue of many hundreds of bhikkhus🔽approaching Arahantship like a lamp in a pot.

original: antokumbhiyaṃ jalamānaṃ padīpaṃ viya arahattupagaṃ sīlaṃ addasa. Āraddhavipassakā
analyzed: antokumbhiyam jalamānam padīpam viya arahatta upagam sīlam addasa āraddha vipassakā
translated: Those who had begun insight

original: hi te bhikkhū. Iti nesaṃ sīlaṃ disvā “imepi bhikkhū mayhaṃ anucchavikā, ahampi imesaṃ🔽anucchaviko”ti cakkhutalesu nimittaṃ ṭhapetvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ oloketvā āyasmantaṃ🔽sāriputtaṃ āmantesi “piṭṭhi me āgilāyatī”ti. Kasmā āgilāyati? Bhagavato hi chabbassāni
analyzed: hi te bhikkhū iti nesam sīlam disvā ime api bhikkhū mayham anucchavikāḥ aham pi imesam  anucchavikaḥ ti cakkhu talesu nimittam ṭhapetvā bhikkhu saṅghaṃ oloketvā āyasmantam  sāriputtam āmantesi piṭṭhi me āgilāyati iti kasmai āgilāyati bhagavataḥ hi chabbassāni
translated: “These bhikkhus are like me.” And he set up a sign in his eyes, looking at the Community of Bhikkhus, and he addressed the venerable Sāriputta, saying: “My back aches.” Why did it ache? For six years the Lord had not sat down, and so his back ached.

original: mahāpadhānaṃ padahantassa mahantaṃ kāyadukkhaṃ ahosi. Athassa aparabhāge mahallakakāle piṭṭhivāto uppajji.🔽Saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvāti sandhāgārassa kira ekapasse te rājāno kappiyamañcakaṃ paññapesuṃ🔽“appeva nāma satthā nipajjeyyā”ti. Satthāpi catūhi iriyāpathehi paribhuttaṃ imesaṃ
analyzed: mahā padhānam padahantassa mahantam kāya dukkham ahosi athassa aparabhāge mahallaka kāle piṭṭhivātaḥ uppajji  saṅghāṭim paññāpetvā ti sandhāgārassa kira eka passe te rājāno kappiya mañcakam paññapesuṃ  appā iva nāma satthā nipajjeyya ati satthā api catūhi iriyāpathehi paribhuttam imesam
translated: “They are bhikkhus, too.” So he looked at the Community of Bhikkhus, having set up a sign on the surface of his eye, thinking “ These bhikkhus are suitable for me and I am suitable for them.” Then he addressed the venerable Sariputta, saying “My back aches” . Why did it ache? For the Blessed One, while he was doing the Great Deed for six years, had great bodily pain. Then later on, when he was an old man, a back-wind arose in him.

original: mahapphalaṃ bhavissatīti tattha saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvā nipajji.
analyzed: mahapphalam bhavissati iti tattha saṅghāṭim paññāpetvā nipajji
translated: “He had his outer robe arranged” . It seems that on one side of the Rest House those kings had a suitable couch arranged, thinking “ Perhaps the Master will lie down.” The Master thought “ It will be of great fruit for them if I use the four postures on it” . So he had his outer robe arranged there and lay down.

original: Bhinnanigaṇṭhavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhinna nigaṇṭha vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The Story of the Broken Thighs

original: 301. Tassa kālaṅkiriyāyātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: tassa kālaṅkiriyāya ati ādīsu yam vattabbam tam sabbam heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: As to what should be said about “ when he had passed away” and the rest, all that has already been said above.

original: 302. Āmantesīti bhaṇḍanādivūpasamakaraṃ svākhyātaṃ dhammaṃ desetukāmo āmantesi.
analyzed: āmantesi iti bhaṇḍana ādi vūpasama karam su ākhyātam dhammam desetu kāmaḥ āmantesi
translated: He addressed them: he addressed them because he wanted to teach the Dhamma, which is well proclaimed and so on, in order to allay the dispute and so on.

original: Ekakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the single

original: 303. Tatthāti tasmiṃ dhamme. Saṅgāyitabbanti samaggehi gāyitabbaṃ, ekavacanehi aviruddhavacanehi
analyzed: tattha ati tasmin dhamme saṅgāyitabbam ti samaggehi gāyitabbam eka vacanehi aviruddha vacanehi
translated: Therein: in that Dhamma. They should sing together: they should sing with a single voice, with a non-contradictory voice.

original: bhaṇitabbaṃ. Na vivaditabbanti atthe vā byañjane vā vivādo na kātabbo. Eko dhammoti
analyzed: bhaṇitabbam na vivaditabbanti atthe vā byañjane vā vivādaḥ na kātabbaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ ti
translated: They should not dispute: they should not dispute about the meaning or the phrasing. There is one Dhamma:

original: ekakadukatikādivasena bahudhā sāmaggirasaṃ dassetukāmo paṭhamaṃ tāva “eko dhammo”ti
analyzed: ekaka duka tika ādi vasena bahudhā sāmaggi rasam dassetu kāmo paṭhamam tāva ekaḥ dhammaḥ ti
translated: wanting to show the word “unity” in its many senses such as “single” and “pair” and so on, he said “one Dhamma”

original: āha. Sabbe sattāti kāmabhavādīsu saññābhavādīsu ekavokārabhavādīsu ca sabbabhavesu🔽sabbe sattā. Āhāraṭṭhitikāti āhārato ṭhiti etesanti āhāraṭṭhitikā. Iti sabbasattānaṃ
analyzed: āha sabbe sattā ti kāma bhava ādīsu saññā bhava ādīsu ekavokāra bhava ādīsu ca sabba bhavesu  sabbe sattā āhāra ṭhitikā ati āhārataḥ ṭhiti etesanti āhāra ṭṭhitikāḥ iti sabba sattānam
translated: first. All beings: all beings in the sensual-desire existence and so on, in the perception-and-feeling existence and so on, in the single-constituent existence and so on.

original: ṭhiti hetu āhāro nāma eko dhammo amhākaṃ satthārā yāthāvato ñatvā sammadakkhāto āvusoti dīpeti.
analyzed: ṭhiti hetu āhāraḥ nāma ekaḥ dhammaḥ amhākam satthārā yāthāvataḥ ñatvā sammadakkhātaḥ āvuso ti dīpeti
translated: They are maintained by nutriment: their maintenance is by nutriment. Thus nutriment, which is the cause of the maintenance of all beings, is a single Dhamma that has been rightly taught by our Teacher, who knew it as it really is, and pointed it out, venerable friends.

original: Nanu ca evaṃ sante yaṃ vuttaṃ “asaññasattā devā ahetukā anāhārā aphassakā”tiādi,
analyzed: nanu ca evam sante yam vuttam asaññasattāḥ devāḥ ahetukāḥ anāhārāḥ aphassakā ti ādi
translated: But if that is so, then how is it that the following passage has been handed down? “The gods who are non-percipient beings are without root-cause, without nutriment, without contact” ,

original: taṃ vacanaṃ virujjhatīti, na virujjhati. Tesañhi jhānaṃ āhāro hoti. Evaṃ santepi
analyzed: tam vacanam virujjhati iti na virujjhati tesam hi jhānam āhāraḥ hoti evam sante pi
translated: “But that contradicts the statement: ‘The nutriment contact is a condition, as faculty condition, for the sixfold base.’ ”—It does not contradict it. For the jhāna is nutriment for them.

original: “cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārā bhūtānaṃ vā sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnaṃ vā anuggahāya.
analyzed: cattāro me bhikkhave āhārāḥ bhūtānam vā sattānam ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnam vā anuggahāya
translated: “But if that is so, then it contradicts the statement: ‘Bhikkhus, there are these four nutriments for the maintenance of beings who have come to be and for the assistance of those seeking a basis for rebirth.

original: Katame cattāro? Kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā🔽tatiyā, viññāṇaṃ catuttha”nti idampi virujjhatīti, idampi na virujjhati. Etasmiñhi
analyzed: katame cattāro kabaḷīkāro āhāraḥ oḷārikaḥ vā sukhumaḥ vā phassaḥ dutiyaḥ manaḥ sañcetanā  tatiyā viññāṇam catuttham ti idam api virujjhati iti idam api na virujjhati etasmin hi
translated: What are the four? Physical food as nutriment, gross or subtle; contact as the second; mental volition as the third; and consciousness as the fourth’ ”?

original: sutte nippariyāyena āhāralakkhaṇāva dhammā āhārāti vuttā. Idha pana pariyāyena paccayo🔽āhāroti vutto. Sabbadhammānañhi paccayo laddhuṃ vaṭṭati. So ca yaṃ yaṃ phalaṃ janeti,🔽taṃ taṃ āharati nāma, tasmā āhāroti vuccati. Tenevāha “avijjampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ
analyzed: sutte nippariyāyena āhāra lakkhaṇā va dhammā āhārā ti vuttā idha pana pariyāyena paccayo  āhāraḥ iti vuttaḥ sabba dhammānam hi paccayaḥ laddhum vaṭṭati saḥ ca yam yam phalam janeti  tam tam āharati nāma tasmai āhāraḥ iti vuccati tena iva āha avijjam pa aham bhikkhave sa āhāram
translated: —It does not contradict it. For in that sutta the nutriments are stated according to their individual characteristics in the ultimate sense. But here they are stated according to their individual characteristics in the conventional sense and as conditions.

original: vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ. Ko ca, bhikkhave, avijjāya āhāro? Pañcanīvaraṇātissa vacanīyaṃ.
analyzed: vadāmi no anāhāram kaḥ ca bhikkhave avijjāya āhāro pañca nīvaraṇātissa vacanīyam
translated: For it is proper to take all states as conditions. And whatever fruit they generate, that they bring about, that they cause to be produced, and that is why they are called nutriments. That is why it is said: “Bhikkhus, I say that ignorance has a nutriment; it is not without nutriment. And what is the nutriment of ignorance? It should be said: the five hindrances.

original: Pañcanīvaraṇepāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāre vadāmi, no anāhāre. Ko ca, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ
analyzed: pañca nīvaraṇe pa aham bhikkhave sa āhāre vadāmi no anāhāre ko ca bhikkhave
translated: “I say that the five hindrances have sustenance, not that they are without sustenance.🔽“And what is the sustenance for the five hindrances?

original: nīvaraṇānaṃ āhāro? Ayonisomanasikārotissa vacanīya”nti. Ayaṃ idha adhippeto.
analyzed: nīvaraṇānaṃ āhāraḥ a yoniso manasikāraḥ tissa vacanīyanti ayam idha adhippeto
translated: I say that the five hindrances have a nutriment; they are not without nutriment. And what is the nutriment of the five hindrances? Wrong thinking is their nutriment. Wrong thinking too has a nutriment; it is not without nutriment. And what is the nutriment of wrong thinking? Unwise attention is its nutriment. Unwise attention too has a nutriment; it is not without nutriment. And what is the nutriment of unwise attention? Ignorance is its nutriment. Ignorance too has a nutriment; it is not without nutriment. And what is the nutriment of ignorance? The five hindrances are its nutriment. Thus the nutriment for this is stated with reference to the nutriment of nutriment.🔽This is the meaning here.

original: Etasmiñhi paccayāhāre gahite pariyāyāhāropi nippariyāyāhāropi sabbo gahitova hoti.
analyzed: etasmin hi paccaya āhāre gahite pariyāya āhāraḥ api nippariyāya āhāraḥ api sabbaḥ gahitaḥ uva hoti
translated: For when the nutriment of conditions is included, the nutriment of proximate cause and the nutriment of non-proximate cause are also included.

original: Tattha asaññabhave paccayāhāro labbhati. Anuppanne hi buddhe titthāyatane pabbajitā
analyzed: tattha asañña bhave paccaya āhāraḥ labbhati anuppanne hi buddhe titthāyatane pabbajitā
translated: Now, in the existence of non-percipient beings, the nutriment of conditions is found. For when the Buddhas have not arisen in the world, some beings go forth from the home life into homelessness in a doctrine and discipline promulgated by a Private Buddha.

original: vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ katvā catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tato vuṭṭhāya dhī cittaṃ,
analyzed: vāyokasiṇe parikammam katvā catuttha jhānam nibbattetvā tatas vuṭṭhāya dhī cittam
translated: Having done so, they perform the preliminary work on the air kasiṇa and arouse the fourth jhāna. Then, on emerging from it, they think,

original: dhibbatetaṃ cittaṃ cittassa nāma abhāvoyeva sādhu, cittañhi nissāyeva vadhabandhādipaccayaṃ
analyzed: cittam cittassa nāma sādhu cittam hi nissāya iva vadha bandha ādi paccayam
translated: “It would be good if this mind could be steadied right here without wavering.” For it is only when there is a mind that suffering due to killing, binding, etc., arises with the mind as condition.

original: dukkhaṃ uppajjati. Citte asati natthetanti khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvā aparihīnajjhānā🔽kālaṅkatvā asaññabhave nibbattanti. Yo yassa iriyāpatho manussaloke paṇihito ahosi,
analyzed: dukkham uppajjati citte asati nattha itanti khantim rucim uppādetvā a parihīna jjhānā 🔽kālaṅkatvā asañña bhave nibbattanti yaḥ yassa iriyāpathaḥ manussa loke paṇihitaḥ ahosi
translated: But when there is no mind, there is no such suffering. So they arouse the wish and approval that there be no mind. Then, without letting their jhāna decline, they die and are reborn in the existence of non-percipient beings.

original: so tena iriyāpathena nibbattitvā pañca kappasatāni ṭhito vā nisinno vā nipanno vā
analyzed: so tena iriyāpathena nibbattitvā pañca kappa satāni ṭhitaḥ vā nisinnaḥ vā nipannaḥ vā
translated: and he remains standing, sitting, or lying down for five hundred aeons.

original: hoti. Evarūpānampi sattānaṃ paccayāhāro labbhati. Te hi yaṃ jhānaṃ bhāvetvā nibbattā,
analyzed: hoti evarūpānam pi sattānam paccaya āhāraḥ labbhati te hi yam jhānam bhāvetvā nibbattā
translated: Such beings too get nutriment. For they are reborn by developing jhāna,

original: tadeva nesaṃ paccayo hoti. Yathā jiyāvegena khittasaro yāva jiyāvego atthi, tāva
analyzed: tat eva na isam paccayaḥ hoti yathā jiyāvegena khitta saraḥ yāva jiyāvego atthi tāva
translated: and that jhāna itself is their condition. Just as an arrow shot by a strong man flies as long as its momentum lasts,

original: gacchati, evaṃ yāva jhānapaccayo atthi, tāva tiṭṭhanti. Tasmiṃ niṭṭhite khīṇavego🔽saro viya patanti. Ye pana te nerayikā neva uṭṭhānaphalūpajīvī na puññaphalūpajīvīti
analyzed: gacchati evam yāva jhāna paccayo atthi tāva tiṭṭhanti tasmin niṭṭhite khīṇa vegaḥ  saraḥ viya patanti ye pana te nerayikāḥ na iva uṭṭhāna phala upajīvī na puñña phala upajīvī iti
translated: so too these beings remain as long as the jhāna condition lasts. When that is finished, they fall like an arrow whose momentum is exhausted.🔽But what is the nutriment of those hell beings called ‘neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling’?”

original: vuttā, tesaṃ ko āhāroti? Tesaṃ kammameva āhāro. Kiṃ pañca āhārā atthīti ce. Pañca,
analyzed: vuttā tesam kaḥ āhāro ti tesam kammam eva āhāro kim pañca āhārāḥ atthi iti ce pañca
translated: They have kamma as their nutriment. But do they have the five kinds of nutriment or not?

original: na pañcāti idaṃ na vattabbaṃ. Nanu paccayo āhāroti vuttametaṃ. Tasmā yena kammena
analyzed: na pañca iti idam na vattabbam nanu paccayaḥ āhāraḥ iti vuttam etam tasmā yena kammena
translated: This cannot be said. But it was said that a condition is nutriment.

original: te niraye nibbattā, tadeva tesaṃ ṭhitipaccayattā āhāro hoti. Yaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: te niraye nibbattā tat eva tesam ṭhiti paccaya ttā āhāraḥ hoti yam sandhāya idam vuttam
translated: So the kamma by which they are reborn in hell is their nutriment since it is a condition for their remaining. It is with reference to this that this is said:

original: “na ca tāva kālaṅkaroti, yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantī hotī”ti.
analyzed: na ca tāva kālaṅkaroti yāva na tam pāpa kammam hoti iti
translated: “He does not die until that evil deed has been exhausted.”

original: Kabaḷīkāraṃ āhāraṃ ārabbha cettha vivādo na kātabbo. Mukhe uppanno kheḷopi hi tesaṃ
analyzed: kabaḷīkāram āhāram ārabbha ca ittha vivādaḥ na kātabbaḥ mukhe uppannaḥ kheḷaḥ api hi tesam
translated: Here, however, there is no dispute about the material food. Even the saliva that arises in the mouth of the beings in the Avici Hell

original: āhārakiccaṃ sādheti. Kheḷopi hi niraye dukkhavedaniyo hutvā paccayo hoti, sagge sukhavedaniyo.
analyzed: āhāra kiccam sādheti kheḷaḥ api hi niraye dukkha vedaniyaḥ hutvā paccayaḥ hoti sagge sukha vedaniyaḥ
translated: performs the function of food for them. The saliva is a condition for the painful feeling in hell and for the pleasant feeling in heaven.

original: Iti kāmabhave nippariyāyena cattāro āhārā. Rūpārūpabhavesu ṭhapetvā asaññaṃ sesānaṃ
analyzed: iti kāma bhave nippariyāyena cattāraḥ āhārāḥ rūpa arūpa bhavesu ṭhapetvā asaññam sesānam
translated: Thus, in the sense-sphere existence, there are four kinds of food in the literal sense. In the fine-material and immaterial existences, there are three kinds of food,🔽excluding material food, for the beings there are devoid of material food. The remaining two kinds of food are conditions for the beings in the immaterial existence.🔽Thus, the answer to the question, “Are all beings maintained by nutriment?”

original: tayo. Asaññānañceva avasesānañca paccayāhāroti iminā āhārena “sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti🔽etaṃ pañhaṃ kathetvā “ayaṃ kho āvuso”ti evaṃ niyyātanampi “atthi kho āvuso”ti puna
analyzed: tayo asaññānam ca iva avasesānam ca paccaya āhāro ti iminā āhārena sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti  etam pañham kathetvā ayam kho āvuso ti evam niyyātanam pi atthi kho āvuso ti puna
translated: is given by the statement, “Friend, it is said that all beings are maintained by nutriment.” The question, “Are all beings maintained by formations?”

original: uddharaṇampi akatvā “sabbe sattā saṅkhāraṭṭhitikā”ti dutiyapañhaṃ vissajjesi.
analyzed: uddharaṇam pi a katvā sabbe sattā saṅkhāra ṭṭhitikā ti dutiya pañham vissajjesi
translated: is answered by the statement, “Friend, it is said that all beings are maintained by formations.”

original: Kasmā pana na niyyātesi na uddharittha? Tattha tattha niyyātiyamānepi uddhariyamānepi
analyzed: kasmā pana na niyyātesi na uddharittha tattha tattha niyyātiyamāne pi uddhariyamāne pi
translated: Why did the Venerable Sariputta not give an answer to the question, “Are all beings maintained by nutriment?” and why did he not raise the question, “Are all beings maintained by formations?”

original: pariyāpuṇituṃ vācetuṃ dukkhaṃ hoti, tasmā dve ekābaddhe katvā vissajjesi. Imasmimpi
analyzed: pariyāpuṇitum vācetum dukkham hoti tasmai dve eka ābaddhe katvā vissajjesi imasmim pi
translated: and it is difficult to learn and recite them, so he has answered by combining the two into one.

original: vissajjane heṭṭhā vuttapaccayova attano phalassa saṅkharaṇato saṅkhāroti vutto. Iti
analyzed: vissajjane heṭṭhā vutta paccayaḥ va attanaḥ phalassa saṅkharaṇato saṅkhāraḥ iti vuttaḥ iti
translated: In this answer too the condition stated below is called “a formation” because it forms its own fruit.

original: heṭṭhā āhārapaccayo kathito, idha saṅkhārapaccayoti ayamettha heṭṭhimato viseso.
analyzed: heṭṭhā āhāra paccayo kathitaḥ idha saṅkhāra paccayo ti ayam ettha heṭṭhimataḥ viseso
translated: So the nutriment as a condition stated below is the same as the formation as a condition here. This is the difference here.

original: “Heṭṭhā nippariyāyāhāro gahito, idha pariyāyāhāroti evaṃ gahite viseso pākaṭo bhaveyya,🔽no ca gaṇhiṃsū’ti mahāsīvatthero āha. Indriyabaddhassapi hi anindriyabaddhassapi
analyzed: heṭṭhā nippariyāya āhāraḥ gahitaḥ idha pariyāya āhāraḥ ti evam gahite visesaḥ pākaṭaḥ bhaveyya  no ca gaṇhiṃsu iti mahāsīva theraḥ āha indriya baddhassa api hi an indriya baddhassa api
translated: “The nutriment without analysis was stated below, and the nutriment with analysis is stated here. The difference would be obvious if it were stated thus.🔽But they did not state it thus,” said the Elder Mahā-Siva.🔽For a condition is allowable for what is bound up with faculties and for what is not bound up with faculties.

original: paccayo laddhuṃ vaṭṭati. Vinā paccayena dhammo nāma natthi. Tattha anindriyabaddhassa🔽tiṇarukkhalatādino pathavīraso āporaso ca paccayo hoti. Deve avassante hi tiṇādīni
analyzed: paccayaḥ laddhum vaṭṭati vinā paccayena dhammo nāma natthi tattha an indriya baddhassa  tiṇa rukkha latā ādino pathavī rasaḥ āpo rasaḥ ca paccayaḥ hoti deve a vassante hi tiṇa ādīni
translated: There is no such thing as a state without a condition. Herein, the condition for what is not bound up with faculties🔽is the sap of the earth and the sap of water, that is to say, for grass, trees, creepers, etc.🔽For when there is no rain, grass, etc., wither,🔽and when it rains they become fresh and green. So the sap of the earth and the sap of water are the condition

original: milāyanti, vassante ca pana haritāni honti. Iti tesaṃ pathavīraso āporaso ca paccayo
analyzed: milāyanti vassante ca pana haritāni honti iti tesam pathavī rasaḥ āpo rasaḥ ca paccayo
translated: for them.

original: hoti. Indriyabaddhassa avijjā taṇhā kammaṃ āhāroti evamādayo paccayā, iti heṭṭhā
analyzed: hoti indriya baddhassa avijjā taṇhā kammam āhāro ti evamādayo paccayā iti heṭṭhā
translated: “The conditions for the dependent origination of ignorance, craving, and kamma are the faculties.”

original: paccayoyeva āhāroti kathito, idha saṅkhāroti. Ayamevettha viseso.
analyzed: paccayo yā iva āhāro ti kathitaḥ idha saṅkhāro ti ayam eva ittha viseso
translated: Thus, while the conditions are called “food” in the earlier part of the sutta, here they are called “formations.” This is the only difference.

original: Ayaṃ kho, āvusoti āvuso amhākaṃ satthārā mahābodhimaṇḍe nisīditvā sayaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇena
analyzed: ayam kho āvuso ti āvuso amhākam satthārā mahā bodhimaṇḍe nisīditvā sayam sabbaññuta ññāṇena
translated: “This one thing, friend,” the Buddha said, “was taught by the Teacher after attaining supreme enlightenment🔽under the Goatherd’s Banyan Tree in the Deer Park at Isipatana.🔽You should all recite this one thing in unison

original: sacchikatvā ayaṃ ekadhammo desito. Tattha ekadhamme tumhehi sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ
analyzed: sacchikatvā ayam eka dhammo desito tattha eka dhamme tumhehi sabbehi iva
translated: without dispute.

original: na vivaditabbaṃ. Yathayidaṃ brahmacariyanti yathā saṅgāyamānānaṃ tumhākaṃ idaṃ sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: na vivaditabbam yathayidam yathā tumhākam idam sāsana brahmacariyam
translated: In this way, the spiritual life will last long.

original: addhaniyaṃ assa. Ekena hi bhikkhunā “atthi, kho āvuso, eko dhammo sammadakkhāto.
analyzed: addhaniyam assa ekena hi bhikkhunā atthi kho āvuso ekaḥ dhammo sammadakkhāto
translated: If one bhikkhu were to say, ‘There is one thing, friends, that is rightly expounded by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened.

original: Katamo eko dhammo? Sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā. Sabbe sattā saṅkhāraṭṭhitikā”ti kathite
analyzed: katamaḥ ekaḥ dhammo sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā sabbe sattā saṅkhāra ṭṭhitikā ati kathite
translated: What is that one thing? All beings subsist on food. All beings subsist on formations,’

original: tassa kathaṃ sutvā añño kathessati. Tassapi aññoti evaṃ paramparakathāniyamena idaṃ
analyzed: tassa katham sutvā aññaḥ kathessati tassa api aññaḥ ti evam parampara kathā niyamena idam
translated: and another bhikkhu were to say, ‘The venerable one says thus and thus.🔽This is the way I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One.

original: brahmacariyaṃ ciraṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ sadevakassa lokassa atthāya hitāya bhavissatīti ekakavasena
analyzed: brahmacariyam ciram tiṭṭhamānam sa devakassa lokassa atthāya hitāya bhavissati iti ekaka vasena
translated: and that the life of purity will last long and be for the welfare and happiness of the multitude, for gods and men.

original: dhammasenāpati sāriputtatthero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: dhamma senāpati sāriputta thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: The Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, then demonstrated the concord of the Community by the method of the single factor.

original: Ekakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ekaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the single factor is ended.

original: Dukavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duka vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the double factor

original: 304. Iti ekakavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni dukavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ
analyzed: iti ekaka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni duka vasena dassetum puna desanam
translated: . Having thus demonstrated the concord of the Community by the method of the single factor, the Elder Sāriputta now began the demonstration by the method of the double factor.

original: ārabhi. Tattha nāmarūpaduke nāmanti cattāro arūpino khandhā nibbānañca. Tattha cattāro
analyzed: ārabhi tattha nāma rūpa duke nāmanti cattāro arūpino khandhāḥ nibbānam ca tattha cattāro
translated: Herein, in the double factor of mentality-materiality, mentality is the four immaterial aggregates and Nibbāna.🔽Herein, the four aggregates are mentality in the sense of mental ratiocination.🔽In the sense of mental ratiocination: in the sense of the act of giving a name.

original: khandhā nāmanaṭṭhena nāmaṃ. Nāmanaṭṭhenāti nāmakaraṇaṭṭhena. Yathā hi mahājanasammatattā
analyzed: khandhāḥ nāmana ṭṭhena nāmam nāmana ṭṭhena ati nāma karaṇa ṭṭhena yathā hi mahājana sammata ttā
translated: For just as the name “Great Elect” arose for Mahāsammata because he was agreed upon by the great multitude,

original: mahāsammatassa “mahāsammato”ti nāmaṃ ahosi, yathā mātāpitaro “ayaṃ tisso nāma hotu,
analyzed: mahāsammatassa mahāsammataḥ iti nāmam ahosi yathā mātā pitaraḥ ayam tissaḥ nāma hotu
translated: and just as parents give a son a well-known name such as “Tisā” or “Phussa,”

original: phusso nāma hotū”ti evaṃ puttassa kittimanāmaṃ karonti, yathā vā “dhammakathiko vinayadharo”ti
analyzed: phussaḥ nāma hotu uti evam puttassa kittima nāmam karonti yathā vā dhamma kathikaḥ vinaya dharo ti
translated: or just as a name is given according to some quality such as “Dhammakathika” or “Vinayadhara,”

original: guṇato nāmaṃ āgacchati, na evaṃ vedanādīnaṃ. Vedanādayo hi mahāpathavīādayo viya
analyzed: guṇataḥ nāma āgacchati na evam vedanā dīnam vedanā ādayaḥ hi mahā pathavī ādayaḥ
translated: so it is not with feeling, etc., which are like the great earth, etc.,

original: attano nāmaṃ karontāva uppajjanti. Tesu uppannesu tesaṃ nāmaṃ uppannameva hoti. Na
analyzed: attanaḥ nāmam karontā ava uppajjanti tesu uppannesu tesam nāmam uppannam eva hoti na
translated: They arise with their own names. When they arise, their names arise too.

original: hi vedanaṃ uppannaṃ “tvaṃ vedanā nāma hohī”ti, koci bhaṇati, na cassā yena kenaci
analyzed: hi vedanam uppannam tvam vedanā nāma hohi iti koci bhaṇati na ca assā yena kenacid
translated: For no one says to a feeling that has arisen, “You be called a feeling.” Nor does it have the function of being given a name for some reason.

original: kāraṇena nāmaggahaṇakiccaṃ atthi, yathā pathaviyā uppannāya “tvaṃ pathavī nāma hohī”ti🔽nāmaggahaṇakiccaṃ natthi, cakkavāḷasinerumhi candimasūriyanakkhattesu uppannesu “tvaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇena nāma ggahaṇa kiccam atthi yathā pathaviyā uppannāya tvam pathavī nāma hohi iti  nāma ggahaṇa kiccam na atthi cakkavāḷa sinerumhi candima sūriya nakkhattesu uppannesu tvam
translated: Just as when the earth arises, there is no function of giving it the name “earth,”

original: cakkavāḷaṃ nāma, tvaṃ nakkhattaṃ nāma hohī”ti nāmaggahaṇakiccaṃ natthi, nāmaṃ uppannameva🔽hoti, opapātikā paññatti nipatati, evaṃ vedanāya uppannāya “tvaṃ vedanā nāma hohī”ti
analyzed: cakkavāḷam nāma tvam nakkhattam nāma hohi iti nāma ggahaṇa kiccam natthi nāmam uppannam eva  hoti opapātikā paññatti nipatati evam vedanāya uppannāya tvam vedanā nāma hohi iti
translated: or when the moon, sun, stars, and constellations arise in the sky and on Sineru, there is no function of giving them the names “sky,” “Sineru,” “moon,” “sun,” “stars,” and “constellations,”🔽but their names arise too, so too, when a feeling arises, there is no function of giving it the name “feeling,”

original: nāmaggahaṇakiccaṃ natthi, tāya uppannāya vedanāti nāmaṃ uppannameva hoti. Saññādīsupi
analyzed: nāma ggahaṇa kiccam na atthi tāya uppannāya vedanā ati nāmam uppannam eva hoti saññā ādīsu pi
translated: but the name “feeling” arises with its arising. And so too with perception, etc.

original: eseva nayo atītepi hi vedanā vedanāyeva. Saññā. Saṅkhārā. Viññāṇaṃ viññāṇameva. Anāgatepi.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ atīte pi hi vedanā vedanāya iva saññā saṅkhārāḥ viññāṇam viññāṇam eva anāgate pi
translated: For in the past too feeling was just feeling, perception was just perception, and so too with the rest. In the future too …

original: Paccuppannepi. Nibbānaṃ pana sadāpi nibbānamevāti. Nāmanaṭṭhena nāmaṃ. Namanaṭṭhenāpi🔽cettha cattāro khandhā nāmaṃ. Te hi ārammaṇābhimukhaṃ namanti. Nāmanaṭṭhena sabbampi
analyzed: paccuppanne pi nibbānam pana sadā api nibbānam eva ati nāmana ṭṭhena nāmam namana ṭṭhena api  ca ittha cattāro khandhāḥ nāmam te hi ārammaṇa abhimukham namanti nāmanaṭṭhena sabbam pi
translated: As to the meaning of ‘name’: ‘name’ is in the sense of bending.🔽Herein, the four aggregates are ‘name’ in the sense of bending. For they bend towards the object. ‘Name’ is in the sense of bending.

original: nāmaṃ. Cattāro hi khandhā ārammaṇe aññamaññaṃ nāmenti, nibbānaṃ ārammaṇādhipatipaccayatāya
analyzed: nāmam cattāraḥ hi khandhāḥ ārammaṇe aññamaññam nāmenti nibbānam ārammaṇa adhipati paccaya tāya
translated: For all the four aggregates bend one towards the other in the object. Nibbāna is ‘name’ in the sense of bending.

original: attani anavajjadhamme nāmeti.
analyzed: attani anavajja dhamme nāma iti
translated: For it bends one to the unblameworthy state in oneself by way of object-predominance condition.

original: Rūpanti cattāro ca mahābhūtā catunnañca mahābhūtānaṃ upādāya rūpaṃ, taṃ sabbampi ruppanaṭṭhena rūpaṃ. Tassa vitthārakathā visuddhimagge vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: rūpanti cattāro ca mahābhūtā catunnam ca mahābhūtānam upādāya rūpam tam sabbam pi ruppana ṭṭhena rūpam tassa vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: As to the meaning of ‘form’: the four great entities and the form derived from the four great entities is ‘form’ in the sense of being molested. The detailed explanation of this should be understood in the way given in the Path of Purity .

original: Avijjāti dukkhādīsu aññāṇaṃ. Ayampi vitthārato visuddhimagge kathitāyeva. Bhavataṇhāti bhavapatthanā. Yathāha “tattha katamā bhavataṇhā? Yo bhavesu bhavacchando”tiādi.
analyzed: avijjā ti dukkha ādīsu aññāṇam ayam pi vitthārataḥ visuddhi magge kathitāya iva bhava taṇhā ti bhava patthanā yathā āha tattha katamā bhava taṇhā yaḥ bhavesu bhava chandaḥ tiādi
translated: As to the meaning of ‘ignorance’: it is unknowing about suffering, etc. This too is given in detail in the Path of Purity. As to the meaning of ‘craving for becoming’: it is the wish for becoming, according as it is said: “Herein, what is craving for becoming? It is will for becoming” , and so on.

original: Bhavadiṭṭhīti bhavo vuccati sassataṃ, sassatavasena uppajjanakadiṭṭhi. Sā “tattha
analyzed: bhava diṭṭhi iti bhavaḥ vuccati sassatam sassata vasena uppajjanaka diṭṭhi sā tattha
translated: The view of becoming is the view that arises in the mode of eternity, and becoming is called “eternity.” It is explained at length in the Abhidhamma as follows:

original: katamā bhavadiṭṭhi? ‘Bhavissati attā ca loko cā’ti yā evarūpā diṭṭhi diṭṭhigata”ntiādinā
analyzed: katamā bhava diṭṭhi bhavissati attā ca loko ca ati yā evarūpā diṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata nti ādinā
translated: “What is the view of becoming? It is any view such as: ‘The self and the world exist eternally’—a view that the self and the world are eternal.”

original: nayena abhidhamme vitthāritā. Vibhavadiṭṭhīti vibhavo vuccati ucchedaṃ, ucchedavasena🔽uppajjanakadiṭṭhi. Sāpi “tattha katamā vibhavadiṭṭhi? ‘Na bhavissati attā ca loko
analyzed: nayena abhidhamme vitthāritā vibhava diṭṭhī iti vibhavaḥ vuccati ucchedam uccheda vasena  uppajjanaka diṭṭhi sā api tattha katamā vibhava diṭṭhi na bhavissati attā ca loko
translated: The view of annihilation is the view that arises in the mode of annihilation, and annihilation is called “cutting off.” It is explained at length in the same place as follows:

original: cā’ti. Yā evarūpā diṭṭhi diṭṭhigata”ntiādinā nayena tattheva vitthāritā.
analyzed: ca ati yā evarūpā diṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata nti ādinā nayena tattha iva vitthāritā
translated: “What is the view of annihilation? It is any view such as: ‘The self and the world are annihilated, destroyed, and perish at death’—a view that the self and the world are annihilated.”

original: Ahirikanti “yaṃ na hirīyati hirīyitabbenā”ti evaṃ vitthāritā nillajjatā. Anottappanti “yaṃ na ottappati ottappitabbenā”ti evaṃ vitthārito abhāyanakaākāro.
analyzed: ahirikanti yam na hirīyati hirīyitabbena ati evam vitthāritā nillajja tā anottappanti yam na ottappati ottappitabbena ati evam vitthāritaḥ abhāyanaka ākāraḥ
translated: Lack of shame is the quality of being shameless, explained as follows: “One is not ashamed of what should make one ashamed.” Lack of fear of wrongdoing is the quality of being unafraid of wrongdoing, explained as follows: “One is not afraid of what should be feared.”

original: Hirī ca ottappañcāti “yaṃ hirīyati hirīyitabbena, ottappati ottappitabbenā”ti evaṃ
analyzed: hirī ca ottappan ca ati yam hirīyati hirīyitabbena ottappati ottappitabbena ati evam
translated: Shame and fear of wrongdoing are the qualities of being ashamed and afraid of wrongdoing, explained as follows: “One is ashamed of what should make one ashamed; one is afraid of what should be feared.”

original: vitthāritāni hiriottappāni. Api cettha ajjhattasamuṭṭhānā hirī, bahiddhāsamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vitthāritāni hiri ottappāni api ca ittha ajjhatta samuṭṭhānā hirī bahiddhā samuṭṭhānam
translated: For shame and fear are extended. And here shame arises from within,

original: ottappaṃ. Attādhipateyyā hirī, lokādhipateyyaṃ ottappaṃ. Lajjāsabhāvasaṇṭhitā hirī,
analyzed: ottappam attā ādhipateyyā hirī loka ādhipateyyam ottappam lajjā sabhāva saṇṭhitā hirī
translated: fear from without. Shame is governed by oneself, fear by the world. Shame is established in the nature of embarrassment,

original: bhayasabhāvasaṇṭhitaṃ ottappaṃ. Vitthārakathā panettha sabbākārena visuddhimagge vuttā.🔽Dovacassatāti dukkhaṃ vaco etasmiṃ vippaṭikūlagāhimhi vipaccanīkasāte anādare puggaleti🔽dubbaco, tassa kammaṃ dovacassaṃ, tassa bhāvo dovacassatā. Vitthārato panesā “tattha
analyzed: bhaya sabhāva saṇṭhitam ottappam vitthāra kathā pana ittha sabba ākārena visuddhi magge vuttā  dukkham vacaḥ etasmin vippaṭikūla gāhimhi vipaccanīka sāte anādare puggala iti  dubbacaḥ tassa kammam dovacassam tassa bhāvaḥ dovacassa tā vitthārato pana isā tattha
translated: fear in the nature of dread. The detailed explanation is given in the Path of Purity.

original: katamā dovacassatā? Sahadhammike vuccamāne dovacassāya”nti abhidhamme āgatā. Sā atthato
analyzed: katamā dovacassatā sahadhammike vuccamāne dovacassāyanti abhidhamme āgatā sā atthataḥ
translated: Bad-temperedness: bad-tempered is he in whom there is bad temper, which is a state of the body and mind consisting in a change in their appearance and so on, due to the disturbance of the elements in the body, and which finds expression in such words as “Get out of my sight!” and so on. The action that produces that is bad-tempering, and the state of that is bad-temperedness. But in detail it is given in the Abhidhamma as follows: “What is bad-temperedness? It is bad temper in one who is spoken to in accordance with the Dhamma” . In meaning it is

original: saṅkhārakkhandho hoti. “Catunnañca khandhānaṃ etenākārena pavattānaṃ etaṃ adhivacana”nti
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ hoti catunnam ca khandhānam etena ākārena pavattānam etam adhivacanam ti
translated: a formation aggregate. They say that it is a term for the four aggregates occurring in this way.

original: vadanti. Pāpamittatāti pāpā assaddhādayo puggalā etassa mittāti pāpamitto, tassa
analyzed: vadanti pāpa mitta tā ati pāpāḥ assaddha ādayaḥ puggalāḥ etassa mittā ati pāpa mittaḥ tassa
translated: Evil friendship: he has evil friends, that is, persons who are faithless, etc., as friends, thus he is one who has evil friends, a person of evil friends.

original: bhāvo pāpamittatā. Vitthārato panesā – “tattha katamā pāpamittatā? Ye te puggalā🔽assaddhā dussīlā appassutā maccharino duppaññā. Yā tesaṃ sevanā nisevanā saṃsevanā
analyzed: bhāvo pāpa mittatā vitthārato pana isā tattha katamā pāpa mittatā ye te puggalā  assaddhāḥ dussīlāḥ appassutāḥ maccharinaḥ duppaññāḥ yā tesam sevanā nisevanā saṃsevanā
translated: The state of having bad friends. But in detail it is this: “Herein, what is the state of having bad friends? Those persons who are without faith, who are unvirtuous, who are unlearned, who are miserly, who are of foolish understanding.🔽The associating with, frequenting, attending upon, and worshipping of them,

original: bhajanā saṃbhajanā bhatti saṃbhatti taṃsampavaṅkatā”ti evaṃ āgatā. Sāpi atthato dovacassatā viya daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: bhajanā saṃbhajanā bhatti saṃbhatti taṃsampavaṅkatā ati evam āgatā sā api atthataḥ dovacassatā viya daṭṭhabbā
translated: and the presence of bad friends. But in detail it is as follows. “Herein, what is the presence of bad friends? There are persons who are without faith, who are unvirtuous, who are unlearned, who are miserly, who are of foolish nature. There are persons who are without faith, who are unvirtuous, who are unlearned, who are miserly, who are of foolish nature. The associating with them, frequenting them, attending on them, intimacy with them, is the presence of bad friends” . And this should be regarded as similar to the presence of bad advice.

original: Sovacassatā ca kalyāṇamittatā ca vuttappaṭipakkhanayena veditabbā. Ubhopi panetā idha lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitā.

translated: The presence of good friends and the habit of attending on good friends should be understood in the opposite way to the way stated for the presence of bad friends and the habit of attending on bad friends. original: Āpattikusalatāti “pañcapi āpattikkhandhā āpattiyo, sattapi āpattikkhandhā āpattiyo. Yā tāsaṃ āpattīnaṃ āpattikusalatā paññā pajānanā”ti evaṃ vutto āpattikusalabhāvo.

translated: Skill in emergence: the understanding described as “skill in emergence” is the knowledge of the time of emergence, the knowledge of the ability to emerge from the absorption at a certain time, as when one thinks, “I will emerge when the sun has gone down that far.”

analyzed: katamam bhāvanā balam yā kusalānam dhammānam āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkammaṃ idam vuccati
translated: “Herein, what is the strength of development? It is the cultivation, development, and making much of profitable things. This is called

original: bhāvanābalaṃ. Sattabojjhaṅgā bhāvanābala”nti.
analyzed: bhāvanā balam satta bojjhaṅgāḥ bhāvanā balanti
translated: the strength of development. The seven factors of enlightenment are the strength of development” .

original: Satibalanti assatiyā akampanavasena satiyeva. Samādhibalanti uddhacce akampanavasena
analyzed: sati balanti assatiyāḥ akampana vasena satiyā iva samādhi balanti uddhacce akampana vasena
translated: The strength of mindfulness is mindfulness itself, in the sense of non-shaking through lack of mindfulness. The strength of concentration is concentration itself, in the sense of non-shaking through agitation.

original: samādhiyeva. Samatho samādhi. Vipassanā paññā. Samathova taṃ ākāraṃ gahetvā puna
analyzed: samādhiyā iva samatho samādhi vipassanā paññā samatho uva tam ākāram gahetvā puna
translated: Concentration is serenity. Understanding is insight. Concentration itself, taking on the aspect of that , is called the strength of concentration.

original: pavattetabbassa samathassa nimittavasena samathanimittaṃ paggāhanimittepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pavattetabbassa samathassa nimitta vasena samatha nimittam paggāha nimitte pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The sign of the way is the sign of the way of the abandoning of what is to be abandoned by that means. The same method applies in the case of the sign of the surmounting.

original: Paggāho vīriyaṃ. Avikkhepo ekaggatā. Imehi pana sati ca sampajaññañca paṭisaṅkhānabalañca
analyzed: paggāhaḥ vīriyam avikkhepaḥ ekagga tā imehi pana sati ca sampajaññam ca paṭisaṅkhāna balañca
translated: Surmounting is energy. Non-distraction is unification. But these are the four powers:

original: bhāvanābalañca satibalañca samādhibalañca samatho ca vippassanā ca samathanimittañca
analyzed: bhāvanā balañca sati balañca samādhi balañca samathaḥ ca vippassanā ca samatha nimittañca
translated: the power of mindfulness, the power of full awareness, the power of the equanimity of feeling, and the power of the equanimity of neutrality.🔽And these are the four strengths: the strength of mindfulness, the strength of energy, the strength of concentration, and the strength of full awareness.🔽And these are the four things: serenity, insight, the sign of the way, and surmounting.

original: paggāhanimittañca paggāho ca avikkhepo cāti chahi dukehi parato sīladiṭṭhisampadādukena
analyzed: paggāha nimittam ca paggāho ca avikkhepaḥ ca ati chahi dukehi paratas sīla diṭṭhi sampadā dukena
translated: And these are the six dyads: serenity, insight, the sign of the way, surmounting, energy, and non-distraction.

original: ca lokiyalokuttaramissakā dhammā kathitā.🔽Sīlavipattīti “tattha katamā sīlavipatti? Kāyiko vītikkamo…pe… sabbampi dussīlyaṃ
analyzed: ca lokiya lokuttara missakā dhammā kathitā  sīla vipatti iti tattha katamā sīla vipatti kāyikaḥ sabbam pi dussīlyam
translated: The things called “accomplishment in virtue and in view” are taught in the following six dyads, which are mixed with mundane and supramundane things.🔽“Failure in virtue”: non-restraint, which is the destruction of virtue, is what is meant. It is described in the way beginning, “Herein, what is failure in virtue? Bodily transgression … all of which is unvirtuous” .

original: sīlavipattī”ti evaṃ vutto sīlavināsako asaṃvaro. Diṭṭhivipattīti “tattha katamā diṭṭhivipatti?
analyzed: sīla vipatti iti evam vuttaḥ sīla vināsakaḥ asaṃvaraḥ diṭṭhi vipatti iti tattha katamā diṭṭhi vipatti
translated: “Failure in view”: wrong view, which is the destruction of right view, is what is meant. It is described in the way beginning, “Herein, what is failure in view?

original: Natthi dinnaṃ natthi yiṭṭha”nti evaṃ āgatā sammādiṭṭhivināsikā micchādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: natthi dinnam natthi yiṭṭhanti evam āgatā sammādiṭṭhi vināsikā micchādiṭṭhi
translated: There is no giving, no offering” , and so on.

original: Sīlasampadāti “tattha katamā sīlasampadā? Kāyiko avītikkamo”ti evaṃ pubbe vuttasoraccameva
analyzed: sīla sampadā ti tattha katamā sīla sampadā kāyikaḥ avītikkamaḥ ti evam pubbe vutta soraccam eva
translated: The fulfilment of virtue is the virtue already mentioned as “virtue consisting in limited purification” .

original: sīlassa sampādanato paripūraṇato “sīlasampadā”ti vuttaṃ. Ettha ca “sabbopi sīlasaṃvaro
analyzed: sīlassa sampādanataḥ paripūraṇataḥ sīla sampadā iti vuttam ettha ca sabbaḥ api sīla saṃvaro
translated: It is called “fulfilment of virtue” because it fulfils and perfects virtue. And here all virtue consisting in restraint is the fulfilment of virtue.

original: sīlasampadā”ti idaṃ mānasikapariyādānatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Diṭṭhisampadāti “tattha katamā🔽diṭṭhisampadā? Atthi dinnaṃ atthi yiṭṭhaṃ…pe… sacchikatvā pavedentīti yā evarūpā
analyzed: sīla sampadā ti idam mānasika pariyādāna attham vuttam diṭṭhi sampadā ti tattha katamā  diṭṭhi sampadā atthi dinnam atthi sacchikatvā pavedenti iti yā evarūpā
translated: This is said for the purpose of including the kind of virtue consisting in purification of the mind.

original: paññā pajānanā”ti evaṃ āgataṃ diṭṭhipāripūribhūtaṃ ñāṇaṃ.🔽Sīlavisuddhīti visuddhiṃ pāpetuṃ samatthaṃ sīlaṃ. Abhidhamme panāyaṃ “tattha katamā🔽sīlavisuddhi? Kāyiko avītikkamo vācasiko avītikkamo kāyikavācasiko avītikkamo, ayaṃ
analyzed: paññā pajānanā ti evam āgatam diṭṭhi pāripūri bhūtam ñāṇam  sīla visuddhi iti visuddhim pāpetum samattham sīlam abhidhamme pana ayam tattha katamā  kāyikaḥ avītikkamaḥ vācasikaḥ avītikkamaḥ kāyika vācasikaḥ avītikkamaḥ ayam
translated: The fulfilment of view is the knowledge described as “the fulfilment of view” in the way beginning, “Herein, what is the fulfilment of view? There is what is given … there is offering sacrifice … there is fruit and ripening of good and bad actions in the world … the wise one here and now enters upon and abides in the deliverance of mind and deliverance by wisdom that are taintless with the destruction of the taints” .🔽Purification of virtue is virtue that is capable of causing purification. But in the Abhidhamma it is said to be resolvable into virtue consisting in limited purification,

original: vuccati sīlavisuddhī”ti evaṃ vibhattā. Diṭṭhivisuddhīti visuddhiṃ pāpetuṃ samatthaṃ
analyzed: vuccati sīla visuddhi iti evam vibhattā diṭṭhi visuddhi iti visuddhim pāpetum samattham
translated: as follows: “Herein, what is purification of virtue? Non- transgression in action, non-transgression in speech, and non-transgression in action and speech: this is called purification of virtue” .🔽Purification of view is

original: dassanaṃ. Abhidhamme panāyaṃ “tattha katamā diṭṭhivisuddhi? Kammassakatañāṇaṃ saccānulomikañāṇaṃ
analyzed: dassanam abhidhamme pana ayam tattha katamā diṭṭhi visuddhi kammassa kata ñāṇam sacca ānulomika ñāṇam
translated: In the Abhidhamma it is said thus: “What is purification of view? Knowledge of the fact that one is the owner of one’s deeds, knowledge in conformity with the truths,

original: maggasamaṅgissañāṇaṃ phalasamaṅgissañāṇa”nti evaṃ vuttā. Ettha ca tividhaṃ duccaritaṃ
analyzed: magga samaṅgi sañāṇam phala samaṅgi sañāṇan ti evam vuttā ettha ca tividham duccaritam
translated: knowledge of one who possesses the path, knowledge of one who possesses the fruit.” Herein, the three kinds of misconduct

original: attanā katampi parena katampi sakaṃ nāma na hoti atthabhañjanato. Sucaritaṃ sakaṃ🔽nāma atthajananatoti evaṃ jānanaṃ kammassakatañāṇaṃ nāma. Tasmiṃ ṭhatvā bahuṃ vaṭṭagāmikammaṃ
analyzed: attanā katampi parena katampi sakam nāma na hoti attha bhañjanato su caritam sakam  nāma attha jananato ti evam jānanam kammassakatañāṇam nāma tasmim ṭhatvā bahum vaṭṭa gāmi kammaṃ
translated: are not one’s own, whether done by oneself or by another, because they destroy one’s welfare. The three kinds of good conduct are one’s own,

original: āyūhitvā sukhato sukheneva arahattaṃ pattā gaṇanapathaṃ vītivattā. Vipassanāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: āyūhitvā sukhataḥ sukhena iva arahattam pattā gaṇana patham vītivattā vipassanā ñāṇam
translated: because they bring welfare. The knowledge of this is called knowledge of the fact that one is the owner of one’s deeds. Standing upon that, having done much that leads to the round of rebirths, they attained arahatship easily and without difficulty, and they were beyond reckoning.

original: pana vacīsaccañca anulometi, paramatthasaccañca na vilometīti saccānulomikaṃ ñāṇanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pana vacī saccam ca anulomā iti paramattha saccam ca na vilomā iti iti sacca ānulomikam ñāṇan ti vuttaṃ
translated: Insight knowledge, however, is said to be knowledge in conformity with the truths because it conforms with the conventional truth and does not contradict the ultimate truth.

original: “Diṭṭhivisuddhi kho pana yathādiṭṭhissa ca padhāna”nti ettha diṭṭhivisuddhīti ñāṇadassanaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhi visuddhi kho pana yathā diṭṭhissa ca padhānan ti ettha diṭṭhi visuddhī iti ñāṇa dassanaṃ
translated: “Purification of view is the knowledge and vision of things as they really are in one who strives and exerts the right effort” . Herein, purification of view is knowledge and vision.

original: kathitaṃ. Yathādiṭṭhissa ca padhānanti taṃsampayuttameva vīriyaṃ. Api ca purimapadena
analyzed: kathitam yathā diṭṭhissa ca padhānanti tad sampayuttam eva vīriyam api ca purima padena
translated: and the energy associated with it.🔽The first term refers to the four path knowledges, and the second to the energy associated with them.

original: catumaggañāṇaṃ. Pacchimapadena taṃsampayuttaṃ vīriyaṃ. Abhidhamme pana “diṭṭhivisuddhi
analyzed: catu magga ñāṇam pacchima padena tad sampayuttam vīriyam abhidhamme pana diṭṭhi visuddhi
translated: But in the Abhidhamma the first term is explained as “purification by knowledge and vision”🔽and the second as “the energy of one who has seen.”

original: kho panāti yā paññā pajānanā amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi. Yathādiṭṭhissa ca padhānanti🔽yo cetasiko vīriyārambho sammāvāyāmo”ti evaṃ ayaṃ duko vibhatto.🔽“Saṃvego ca saṃvejanīyesu ṭhānesū”ti ettha “saṃvegoti jātibhayaṃ jarābhayaṃ byādhibhayaṃ
analyzed: kho pana ati yā paññā pajānanā amohaḥ dhamma vicayo sammādiṭṭhi yathā diṭṭhissa ca padhānanti  yo cetasikaḥ vīriya ārambho sammā vāyāmo ti evam ayam dukaḥ vibhatto  saṃvegaḥ ca saṃvejanīyesu ṭhānesu iti ettha saṃvegaḥ uti jāti bhayam jarā bhayam byādhi bhayam
translated: “Knowledge and vision” is the understanding, the knowing, the non-delusion, the investigation of the Dhamma, the right view associated with the four path knowledges.🔽“The energy of one who has seen” is the energy of one who has seen the four truths.🔽“Aversion to anything that should arouse aversion” : “Aversion” is the knowledge that sees birth, etc., as fearful.

original: maraṇabhaya”nti evaṃ jātiādīni bhayato dassanañāṇaṃ. Saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānanti jātijarābyādhimaraṇaṃ.🔽Etāni hi cattāri jāti dukkhā, jarā dukkhā, byādhi dukkho, maraṇaṃ dukkhanti evaṃ
analyzed: evam jāti ādīni bhayataḥ dassana ñāṇam saṃvejanīyam jāti jarā byādhi maraṇam  etāni hi cattāri jāti dukkhā jarā dukkhā byādhi dukkhaḥ maraṇam dukkhanti evam
translated: “Anything that should arouse aversion” is birth, aging, sickness, and death.

original: saṃveguppattikāraṇattā saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānanti vuttāni. Saṃviggassa ca yoniso padhānanti
analyzed: saṃvega uppatti kāraṇa ttā saṃvejanīyam ṭhānan ti vuttāni saṃviggassa ca yonisas padhānan ti
translated: For these four are called “anything that should arouse aversion” because they are the cause for the arising of aversion in one who sees them as suffering in the following way: “Birth is suffering, aging is suffering, sickness is suffering, death is suffering.”🔽“The earnest practice of those who are averse” is the practice of one who is averse.

original: evaṃ saṃvegajātassa upāyapadhānaṃ. “Idha bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ
analyzed: evam saṃvega jātassa upāya padhānam idha bhikkhu anuppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam
translated: This is the undertaking of the means in one who has aroused urgency.

original: dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janetī”ti evaṃ āgatavīriyassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: dhammānam an uppādāya chandam janeti iti evam āgata vīriyassa etam adhivacanam
translated: The words “and he generates desire for the non-arising of unarisen evil, unprofitable states” are a term for energy.🔽And “not being satisfied with that attainment” is a term for the desire for more and more in one who is not satisfied with the development of profitable states.

original: Asantuṭṭhitā ca kusalesu dhammesūti yā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanāya asantuṭṭhassa
analyzed: asantuṭṭhi tā ca kusalesu dhammesu iti yā kusalānam dhammānam bhāvanāya asantuṭṭhassa
translated: For it is one who is not satisfied with the development of profitable states who is called “one who desires more and more” .

original: bhiyyokamyatā, tāya hi samaṅgībhūto puggalo sīlaṃ pūretvā jhānaṃ uppādeti. Jhānaṃ
analyzed: bhiyyokamyatā tāya hi samaṅgībhūtaḥ puggalaḥ sīlam pūretvā jhānam uppādeti jhānam
translated: When he has fulfilled virtue, he arouses jhāna.🔽When he has obtained jhāna, he undertakes insight.

original: labhitvā vipassanaṃ ārabhati. Āraddhavipassako arahattaṃ agahetvā antarā vosānaṃ
analyzed: labhitvā vipassanam ārabhati āraddha vipassakaḥ arahattam a gahetvā antarā vosānam
translated: When he has begun insight, he does not come to a stop midway but reaches Arahantship.

original: nāpajjati. Appaṭivānitā ca padhānasminti “kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ bhāvanāya sakkaccakiriyatā
analyzed: na āpajjati appaṭivāni tā ca padhānasmin ti kusalānam dhammānam bhāvanāya sakkaccakiriya tā
translated: And “not shirking the task” is what is called “keenness in the development of profitable states,

original: sātaccakiriyatā aṭṭhitakiriyatā anolīnavuttitā anikkhittachandatā anikkhittadhuratā🔽āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkamma”nti evaṃ vuttā rattindivaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā jāgariyānuyogavasena
analyzed: sā atacca kiriya tā aṭṭhita kiriya tā anolīna vutti tā a nikkhitta chanda tā a nikkhitta dhura tā 🔽āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkammanti evam vuttā rattindivam cha koṭṭhāse katvā jāgariya anuyoga vasena
translated: steadfastness in the development of profitable states, resoluteness in the development of profitable states, non-remissness in the development of profitable states, non- idleness in the development of profitable states,🔽the state of one who keeps to his own sphere in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the sign of the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the desire for the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the effort for the pliability in the development of profitable states,🔽the state of one who does not abandon the application of the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the investigation of the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the search for the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the investigation of the search for the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the search for the sign of the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the investigation of the sign of the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the search for the desire for the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the investigation of the desire for the pliability in the development of profitable states, the state of one who does not abandon the search for the

original: āraddhe padhānasmiṃ arahattaṃ apatvā anivattanatā.
analyzed: āraddhe padhānasmin arahattam a patvā a nivattana tā
translated: and the non-returning of the mind from the object of concentration without reaching Arahantship.

original: Vijjāti tisso vijjā. Vimuttīti dve vimuttiyo, cittassa ca adhimutti, nibbānañca.
analyzed: vijjā ati tissaḥ vijjā vimutti iti dve vimuttiyo cittassa ca adhimutti nibbānam ca
translated: “Knowledge” is the three kinds of knowledge. “Liberation” is the two kinds of liberation, the liberation of the mind and the liberation by over- coming ignorance.

original: Ettha ca aṭṭha samāpattiyo nīvaraṇādīhi suṭṭhu muttattā adhimutti nāma. Nibbānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ nīvaraṇa ādīhi suṭṭhu mutta ttā adhimutti nāma nibbānam
translated: And here the eight attainments are called the liberation of the mind because they are well liberated from the hindrances, etc.,

original: sabbasaṅkhatato muttattā vimuttīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Khaye ñāṇanti kilesakkhayakare ariyamagge ñāṇaṃ. Anuppāde ñāṇanti paṭisandhivasena
analyzed: sabba saṅkhatataḥ mutta ttā vimutti iti veditabbam  khaye ñāṇanti kilesa khaya kare ariya magge ñāṇam anuppāde ñāṇanti paṭisandhi vasena
translated: and Nibbāna should be understood as the liberation by overcoming ignorance.🔽“Knowledge of destruction”: knowledge in the noble path that brings about the destruction of defilements.

original: anuppādabhūte taṃtaṃmaggavajjhakilesānaṃ vā anuppādapariyosāne uppanne ariyaphale
analyzed: anuppāda bhūte taṃ taṃ magga vajjha kilesānam vā anuppāda pariyosāne uppanne ariya phale
translated: “Knowledge of non-arising”: knowledge that arises in the noble fruition that is the non-arising of the respective defilements abandoned by the path, with the non-arising as condition.

original: ñāṇaṃ. Tenevāha “khaye ñāṇanti maggasamaṅgissa ñāṇaṃ. Anuppāde ñāṇanti phalasamaṅgissa🔽ñāṇa”nti. Ime kho, āvusotiādi ekake vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti pañcatiṃsāya dukānaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam tena iva āha khaye ñāṇanti magga samaṅgissa ñāṇam anuppāde ñāṇanti phala samaṅgissa  ñāṇam ti ime kho āvuso tiādi ekake vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti pañcatiṃsāya dukānam
translated: Hence it is said: “Knowledge of destruction is knowledge in one who possesses the path. Knowledge of non-arising is knowledge in one who possesses the fruition” .

original: vasena thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: vasena theraḥ sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friends, are the five aggregates” and so on should be construed in the way already stated. Thus the elder gave the simile of the council in terms of the five times thirty.

original: Dukavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: duka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the burden is ended.

original: Tikavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tika vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the triad

original: 305. Iti dukavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni tikavasena dassetuṃ puna ārabhi.
analyzed: iti duka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni tika vasena dassetum punar ārabhi
translated: Having thus shown the three terms in the sense of suffering, he now began the exposition in terms of the three roots.

original: Tattha lubbhatīti lobho. Akusalañca taṃ mūlañca, akusalānaṃ vā mūlanti akusalamūlaṃ.
analyzed: tattha lubbhati iti lobhaḥ akusalam ca tam mūlam ca akusalānam vā mūlanti akusala mūlam
translated: Herein, it stains , thus it is greed . It is unwholesome and a root , thus it is an unwholesome root .

original: Dussatīti doso. Muyhatīti moho. Tesaṃ paṭipakkhanayena alobhādayo veditabbā.
analyzed: dussati iti dosaḥ muyhati iti mohaḥ tesam paṭipakkha nayena alobha ādayaḥ veditabbā
translated: It hates , thus it is hate . It deludes , thus it is delusion . The opposite of these should be understood as non-greed, etc.,

original: Duṭṭhu caritāni, virūpāni vā caritānīti duccaritāni. Kāyena duccaritaṃ, kāyato vā🔽pavattaṃ duccaritanti kāyaduccaritaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Suṭṭhu caritāni, sundarāni
analyzed: duṭṭhu caritāni virūpāni vā caritāni iti duccaritāni kāyena duccaritam kāyataḥ vā  pavattam duccaritanti kāya duccaritam sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ suṭṭhu caritāni sundarāni
translated: Bad conduct , thus it is misconduct . Misconduct in body , or it occurs in the body , thus it is misconduct in body . The same method applies in the case of the other two.

original: vā caritānīti sucaritāni. Dvepi cete tikā paṇṇattiyā vā kammapathehi vā kathetabbā.🔽Paññattiyā tāva kāyadvāre paññattasikkhāpadassa vītikkamo kāyaduccaritaṃ. Avītikkamo
analyzed: vā caritāni iti su caritāni dve pi ca ite tikā paṇṇattiyā vā kamma pathehi vā kathetabbā  paññattiyā tāva kāya dvāre paññatta sikkhāpadassa vītikkamo kāya duccaritam a vītikkamo
translated: Good conduct , thus it is good conduct . And both these triads should be expounded either by analysis of the terms or by the courses of kamma.

original: kāyasucaritaṃ. Vacīdvāre paññattasikkhāpadassa vītikkamo vacīduccaritaṃ, avītikkamo
analyzed: kāya su caritam vacī dvāre paññatta sikkhāpadassa vītikkamaḥ vacī duccaritam a vītikkamaḥ
translated: By analysis of the terms first of all: the transgression of a training precept announced in the body door is misconduct in body; the non-transgression of it is good conduct in body. The transgression of a training precept announced in the speech door is misconduct in speech; the non-transgression of it is good conduct in speech.

original: vacīsucaritaṃ. Ubhayattha paññattassa sikkhāpadassa vītikkamova manoduccaritaṃ, avītikkamo
analyzed: vacī su caritam ubhayattha paññattassa sikkhāpadassa vītikkamaḥ uva manaḥ duccaritam a vītikkamaḥ
translated: Mental good conduct is the non-transgression of it. This is the “exposition of the training precepts.”

original: manosucaritaṃ. Ayaṃ paṇṇattikathā. Pāṇātipātādayo pana tisso cetanā kāyadvārepi vacīdvārepi
analyzed: ayam paṇṇatti kathā pāṇa atipāta ādayaḥ pana cetanā kāya dvāre pi vacī dvāre pi
translated: But the three volitions beginning with killing-breathing- things are bodily misconduct when they occur in the body door or the speech door.

original: uppannā kāyaduccaritaṃ. Catasso musāvādādicetanā vacīduccaritaṃ. Abhijjhā byāpādo
analyzed: uppannā kāya duccaritam catassaḥ musāvāda ādi cetanāḥ vacī duccaritam abhijjhā byāpādaḥ
translated: The four volitions beginning with lying are verbal misconduct.🔽The three states associated with the three volitions of covetousness, ill will, and wrong view are mental misconduct.

analyzed: micchādiṭṭhi iti tayo cetanā sampayutta dhammā manaḥ duccaritam pāṇa atipāta ādīhi viramantassa
translated: The three volitions and the three abstinences that occur in one who abstains from killing breathing things, etc.,

analyzed: uppannā tissaḥ cetanā api viratiyaḥ api kāya su caritam musāvāda ādīhi viramantassa catasso
translated: are bodily good conduct. The four volitions and the four abstinences that occur in one who abstains from lying, etc.,

analyzed: cetanā api vacī su caritam anabhijjhā a byāpādo sammādiṭṭhī iti tayo cetanā sampayutta dhammā

original: manosucaritanti ayaṃ kammapathakathā.

translated: mental good conduct. This is the “exposition of the courses of kamma.”

original: Kāmapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko kāmavitakko. Byāpādapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko byāpādavitakko.
analyzed: kāma paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakko kāma vitakkaḥ byāpāda paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ byāpāda vitakko
translated: Thinking associated with sense desire is sense-desire thinking. Thinking associated with ill will is ill-will thinking.

original: Vihiṃsāpaṭisaṃyutto vitakko vihiṃsāvitakko. Tesu dve sattesupi saṅkhāresupi uppajjanti.
analyzed: vihiṃsā paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ vihiṃsā vitakko tesu dve sattesu pi saṅkhāresu pi uppajjanti
translated: The thought associated with ill will is the thought of ill will. These two occur in regard to living beings and also in regard to formations.

original: Kāmavitakko hi piye manāpe satte vā saṅkhāre vā vitakkentassa uppajjati. Byāpādavitakko
analyzed: kāma vitakkaḥ hi piye manāpe satte vā saṅkhāre vā vitakkentassa uppajjati byāpāda vitakkaḥ
translated: For the thought of lust occurs in one who thinks thoughts of lust about a dear and lovable living being or about a desirable object such as a visible form.

original: appiye amanāpe satte vā saṅkhāre vā kujjhitvā olokanakālato paṭṭhāya yāva vināsanā
analyzed: appiye amanāpe satte vā saṅkhāre vā kujjhitvā olokana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva vināsanā
translated: The thought of ill will occurs in one who, having harboured thoughts of annoyance towards an unloved living being or object, looks at it with an eye of annoyance, and it continues to occur as long as he does so.

original: uppajjati. Vihiṃsāvitakko saṅkhāresu nuppajjati. Saṅkhāro hi dukkhāpetabbo nāma natthi.
analyzed: uppajjati vihiṃsā vitakkaḥ saṅkhāresu na uppajjati saṅkhāraḥ hi dukkha apetabbaḥ nāma natthi
translated: The thought of ill will does not occur in regard to formations. For there is no formation that can be annoyed.

original: Ime sattā haññantu vā ucchijjantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesunti cintanakāle pana sattesu uppajjati.
analyzed: ime sattāḥ haññantu vā ucchijjantu vā vinassantu vā mā vā ahesunti cintana kāle pana sattesu uppajjati
translated: But it occurs in regard to living beings when one thinks such thoughts as these: “May these living beings be killed or destroyed or annihilated or crushed or be destroyed utterly!”

original: Nekkhammapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko nekkhammavitakko. So asubhapubbabhāge kāmāvacaro hoti.
analyzed: nekkhamma paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ nekkhamma vitakko so asubha pubbabhāge kāmāvacaraḥ hoti
translated: The thought associated with renunciation is the thought of renunciation. It is of the sense sphere in the preliminary stage of the foul meditation.

original: Asubhajjhāne rūpāvacaro. Taṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā uppannamaggaphalakāle lokuttaro.
analyzed: asubha jjhāne rūpāvacaraḥ tam jhānam pādakam katvā uppanna magga phala kāle lokuttaraḥ
translated: It is of the fine-material sphere in the foul meditation itself. It is supramundane when it arises as path and fruit, using that jhāna as a basis.

original: Abyāpādapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko abyāpādavitakko. So mettāpubbabhāge kāmāvacaro hoti.

translated: The thought associated with non-ill will is the thought of non-ill will. It is of the sense sphere in the preliminary stage of loving-kindness.

original: Mettājhāne rūpāvacaro. Taṃ jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā uppannamaggaphalakāle lokuttaro.

analyzed: dve tad anvāyikāḥ bhavanti yadā tadā itare dve tad anvāyikāḥ bhavanti iti  kāma saṅkappa ādayaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbāḥ desanā mattam eva ha etam atthataḥ pana kāma vitakka ādīnam ca

translated: Perception associated with sensual desire is perception of sensual desire. Perception associated with ill will is perception of ill will. Perception associated with cruelty is perception of cruelty.

translated: craving for non-existence. The rest of the craving is craving for sense desires” . Again, in the case of craving for sense desires, etc., lust for the five strands of sense pleasure is craving for sense desires. Lust for the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming is the other two kinds of craving. But in the Abhidhamma they are given in detail thus: “Related to the sense-desire element … related to the fine-material element … related to the immaterial element” . What does this section show? It shows that all states belonging to the three planes are a basis for craving in the sense of being lovable, and that all craving is included in craving for sense desires, which is then extracted from that and the other two kinds of craving are shown. In the case of craving for form, etc., lust for the fine-material kind of becoming is craving for form. Lust for the immaterial kind of becoming is craving for the immaterial. Lust accompanied by the annihilation view is craving for cessation.
