translated: and “I am equal” conceit arise in them. For a king thinks: “What difference is there between me and other kings as regards the territory or the wealth of the treasury?”

original: aññena bhikkhunā mayhaṃ kiṃ nānākaraṇanti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti. “Seyyassa hīnohamasmī”ti🔽mānopi etesaṃyeva uppajjati. Yassa hi rañño raṭṭhaṃ vā dhanavāhanādīni vā nātisampannāni
analyzed: aññena bhikkhunā mayham kim nānākaraṇanti etam mānam karoti seyyassa hīnā uham asmi iti  mānaḥ api etesam yeva uppajjati yassa hi raññaḥ raṭṭham vā dhana vāhana ādīni vā na atisampannāni
translated: and a monk thinks: “What difference is there between me and other monks as regards virtue, the ascetic practices, etc.?”

original: honti, so mayhaṃ rājāti vohāramukhamattameva, kiṃ rājā nāma ahanti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: honti saḥ mayham rājā ati vohāra mukham attam eva kim rājā nāma ahanti etam mānam karoti
translated: “I am inferior” conceit also arises in them. For a king whose territory or wealth of the treasury is not extensive thinks: “The title ‘king’ is only a mere name for me. What is a king? I am not a king.”

original: Pabbajitopi appalābhasakkāro ahaṃ dhammakathiko bahussuto mahātheroti kathāmattakameva,
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ api appa lābha sakkāraḥ aham dhamma kathikaḥ bahu ssutaḥ mahā theraḥ iti kathā mattakam eva
translated: and a monk who has little gain and honour thinks: “I am only a mere preacher of the Dhamma, a man of much learning, an elder of great age.

original: kiṃ dhammakathiko nāmāhaṃ kiṃ bahussuto kiṃ mahāthero yassa me lābhasakkāro natthīti etaṃ mānaṃ karoti.
analyzed: kim dhammakathikaḥ nāma aham kim bahussutaḥ kim mahā thero yassa me lābha sakkāro natthi iti etam mānam karoti
translated: What is a preacher of the Dhamma? What is a man of much learning? What is an elder of great age? I have no gain and honour.”

original: “Sadisassa seyyohamasmī”ti mānādayo amaccādīnaṃ uppajjanti. Amacco vā hi raṭṭhiyo🔽vā bhogayānavāhanādīhi ko mayā sadiso añño rājapuriso atthīti vā mayhaṃ aññehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: sadisassa seyya uham asmi iti māna ādayaḥ amacca ādīnam uppajjanti amaccaḥ vā hi raṭṭhiyaḥ  vā bhoga yāna vāhana ādīhi kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ rāja purisaḥ atthi iti vā mayham aññehi saddhim
translated: “I am equal to my equal” and so on. For conceit arises in ministers and so on, thinking, “What other royal officer is there equal to me in wealth, vehicles, retinue, and so on?” Or they think, “What other royal officer is there equal to me in the king’s esteem?” Or they think, “What other royal officer is there equal to me in the king’s confidence?” Or they think, “What other royal officer is there equal to me in the king’s gifts and honors?” Or they think, “What other royal officer is there equal to me in the king’s gifts and honors?”

original: kiṃ nānākaraṇanti vā amaccoti nāmameva mayhaṃ, ghāsacchādanamattampi me natthi, kiṃ🔽amacco nāmāhanti vā ete māne karoti.🔽“Hīnassa seyyohamasmī”ti mānādayo dāsādīnaṃ uppajjanti. Dāso hi mātito vā pitito🔽vā ko mayā sadiso añño dāso nāma atthi, aññe jīvituṃ asakkontā kucchihetu dāsā jātā,🔽ahaṃ pana paveṇīāgatattā seyyoti vā paveṇīāgatabhāvena ubhatosuddhikadāsattena asukadāsena
analyzed: kim nānākaraṇanti vai mayham ghāsa chādana mattam pi me natthi kim  amaccaḥ nāma ahanti vai ete māne karoti  hīnassa seyyā uham asmi iti māna ādayaḥ dāsa ādīnam uppajjanti dāsaḥ hi mātitaḥ vā pititaḥ  vā kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ aññaḥ dāsaḥ nāma atthi aññe jīvitum a sakkontā kucchi hetu dāsā jātā  aham pana paveṇī āgata ttā seyyā uti vā paveṇī āgata bhāvena ubhatosuddhika dāsattena asuka dāsena
translated: “I am equal to my equal” and so on are conceit, etc., that arise in ministers, etc. For a minister or a citizen thinks: “Who is there equal to me? There is no other royal officer like me,” or: “What is the difference between me and the king?” or: “The name ‘minister’ is mine alone. I have no food or clothing. What is a ‘minister’?” or: “I am a minister.”

original: nāma saddhiṃ kiṃ mayhaṃ nānākaraṇanti vā kucchivasenāhaṃ dāsabya upagato, mātāpitukoṭiyā
analyzed: nāma vā kucchi vasena aham dāsa byaḥ upagataḥ mātā pitu koṭiyā
translated: “I am better than my inferior” and so on are conceit, etc., that arise in slaves, etc. For a slave thinks: “Who is there equal to me? There is no other slave like me. Others have become slaves because they could not live. I am better because I come from a good family,” or: “What is the difference between me and the slave so-and-so, who comes from a good family and is pure on both sides?” or: “I have become a slave because of my belly. My parents and ancestors were not slaves.”

original: pana me dāsaṭṭhānaṃ natthi, kiṃ dāso nāma ahanti vā ete māne karoti. Yathā ca dāso,
analyzed: pana me dāsa ṭṭhānam natthi kim dāsaḥ nāma ahanti vā ete māne karoti yathā ca dāsaḥ
translated: but I have no idea what the state of being a slave is like, what a slave is like. He makes these assumptions.

original: evaṃ pukkusacaṇḍālādayopi ete māne karontiyeva.🔽Ettha ca seyyassa seyyohamasmīti, ca sadisassa sadisohamasmīti ca hīnassa hīnohamasmīti
analyzed: evam pukkusa caṇḍāla ādayaḥ api ete māne  ettha ca seyyassa seyyā uham asmi iti ca sadisassa sadisā uham asmi iti ca hīnassa hīnā uham asmi iti
translated: But I have no one to do my work for me. What is a slave? ’ He makes these kinds of conceit. And just as he does, so too do the low-caste people such as the bamboo-plaiters, hunters, cartwrights, refuse-scavengers, and waste-paper removers.

original: ca ime tayo mānā yāthāvamānā nāma arahattamaggavajjhā. Sesā cha mānā ayāthāvamānā🔽nāma paṭhamamaggavajjhā.🔽Tayo addhāti tayo kālā. Atīto addhātiādīsu dvepariyāyā suttantapariyāyo ca abhidhammapariyāyo
analyzed: ca ime tayaḥ mānāḥ yāthāvamānāḥ nāma arahatta magga vajjhā sesā cha mānāḥ ayāthāvamānā  nāma paṭhama magga vajjhā  tayaḥ addhā ati tayaḥ kālāḥ atītaḥ addhā atiādīsu dve pariyāyā suttanta pariyāyo ca abhidhamma pariyāyo
translated: Herein, the three kinds of conceit ‘ I am superior ’, ‘ I am equal ’, and ‘ I am inferior ’ are called ‘ conceit in being ’ . They are the province of the path of arahantship. The remaining six kinds of conceit are called ‘ conceit in what is not ’ . They are the province of the first path.

original: ca. Suttantapariyāyena paṭisandhito pubbe atīto addhā nāma. Cutito pacchā anāgato🔽addhā nāma. Saha cutipaṭisandhīhi tadantaraṃ paccuppanno addhā nāma. Abhidhammapariyāyena
analyzed: ca suttanta pariyāyena paṭisandhitaḥ pubbe atītaḥ addhā nāma cutitaḥ pacchā anāgato  addhā nāma saha cuti paṭisandhīhi tad antaram paccuppannaḥ addhā nāma abhidhamma pariyāyena
translated: Three periods: three times. In the past, in the future, and in the present. Herein, the past is the period prior to rebirth-linking. The future is the period after death. The present is the interval between these two.

original: tīsu khaṇesu bhaṅgato uddhaṃ atīto addhā nāma. Uppādato pubbe anāgato addhā nāma.
analyzed: tīsu khaṇesu bhaṅgataḥ uddham atītaḥ addhā nāma uppādato pubbe anāgataḥ addhā nāma
translated: In the three instants, the past is the period after dissolution. The future is the period prior to arising. The present is the instant of arising.

original: Khaṇattaye paccuppanno addhā nāma. Atītādibhedo ca nāma ayaṃ dhammānaṃ hoti, na kālassa.
analyzed: khaṇa ttaye paccuppannaḥ addhā nāma atīta ādi bhedo ca nāma ayam dhammānam hoti na kālassa
translated: The present is called the “present time” in the three instants. And this division into past, etc., belongs to states, not to time.

original: Atītādibhede pana dhamme upādāya idha paramatthato avijjamānopi kālo teneva vohārena vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: atīta ādi bhede pana dhamme upādāya idha paramatthataḥ a vijjamānaḥ api kālo tena iva vohārena vuttaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: But time is spoken out in the sense of states, which are non-existent in the ultimate sense, by means of a designation based upon the past, etc., of states.

original: Tayo antāti tayo koṭṭhāsā. “Kāyabandhanassa anto jīratī”tiādīsu hi antoyeva anto.
analyzed: tayo antā ti tayo koṭṭhāsā kāya bandhanassa antaḥ jīrati itiādīsu hi antaḥ yā iva antaḥ
translated: Three ends: three parts. For in such passages as “It decays in the end” , “end” is the same as “inside” .

original: “Esevanto dukkhassā”tiādīsu parabhāgo anto. “Antamidaṃ, bhikkhave, jīvikāna”nti ettha
analyzed: dukkhassa ati ādīsu parabhāgaḥ antaḥ antam idam bhikkhave jīvikānam ti ettha
translated: In such passages as “This is the end of suffering” , “end” is the extreme limit.🔽In such passages as “This is the end of the life of pleasure here and now” ,🔽“end” is the state of being raw. In such passages as “The first end, friend, is the acquisition” ,

original: lāmakabhāvo anto. “Sakkāyo kho, āvuso, paṭhamo anto”tiādīsu koṭṭhāso anto. Idha koṭṭhāso
analyzed: lāmaka bhāvaḥ anto sakkāyo kho āvuso paṭhamaḥ anto ti ādīsu koṭṭhāso anto idha koṭṭhāso
translated: “end” is a part. Here it is the part that is intended.

original: adhippeto. Sakkāyoti pañcupādānakkhandhā. Sakkāyasamudayoti tesaṃ nibbattikā purimataṇhā.🔽Sakkāyanirodhoti ubhinnaṃ appavattibhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ. Maggo pana nirodhādhigamassa
analyzed: adhippeto sa kāyaḥ ti pañca upādāna khandhā sa kāya samudayaḥ ti tesam nibbattikā purima taṇhā  sakkāya nirodho ti ubhinnam appavatti bhūtam nibbānam maggo pana nirodha adhigamassa
translated: The acquisition: the five aggregates as objects of clinging. The origin of the acquisition: the craving that is the cause of their arising.🔽The cessation of the acquisition: Nibbāna, which is the non-occurrence of both.

original: upāyattā nirodhe gahite gahitovāti veditabbo.
analyzed: upāyattā nirodhe gahite gahitā uvā iti veditabbo
translated: But the path should be understood to be included when cessation is included, since it is the means to the attainment of cessation.

original: Dukkhadukkhatāti dukkhabhūtā dukkhatā. Dukkhavedanāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Saṅkhāradukkhatāti
analyzed: dukkha dukkha tā ati dukkha bhūtā dukkha tā dukkha vedanāya itam nāmam saṅkhāra dukkha tā ati
translated: Painful as pain is the kind of suffering that is suffering by way of pain. This is a term for painful feeling. Painful as formation is the kind

original: saṅkhārabhāvena dukkhatā. Adukkhamasukhāvedanāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sā hi saṅkhatattā uppādajarābhaṅgapīḷitā,🔽tasmā aññadukkhasabhāvavirahato saṅkhāradukkhatāti vuttā. Vipariṇāmadukkhatāti vipariṇāme
analyzed: saṅkhāra bhāvena dukkha tā adukkham asukhā vedanāya itam nāmam sā hi saṅkhata ttā uppāda jarā bhaṅga pīḷitā  tasmā añña dukkha sabhāva virahataḥ saṅkhāra dukkha tā ati vuttā vipariṇāma dukkha tā ati vipariṇāme
translated: of suffering that is suffering by way of formation. This is a term for neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. For that is suffering because it is formed, being oppressed by the suffering of the three formations beginning with that of birth.

original: dukkhatā. Sukhavedanāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sukhassa hi vipariṇāme dukkhaṃ uppajjati, tasmā🔽sukhaṃ vipariṇāmadukkhatāti vuttaṃ. Apica ṭhapetvā dukkhavedanaṃ sukhavedanañca sabbepi
analyzed: dukkha tā sukha vedanāya itam nāmam sukhassa hi vipariṇāme dukkham uppajjati tasmā  sukham vipariṇāma dukkha tā ti vuttam apica ṭhapetvā dukkha vedanam sukha vedanam ca sabbe pi
translated: Therefore it is called “painful as formation” because it lacks the nature of the other kinds of suffering. Painful as change is the kind of suffering that is suffering by way of change. This is a term for pleasant feeling. For suffering arises with the change of what is pleasant,

original: tebhūmakā dhammā “sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā”ti vacanato saṅkhāradukkhatāti veditabbā.
analyzed: tebhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ sabbe saṅkhārāḥ dukkhā ti vacanato saṅkhāra dukkha tā ati veditabbā
translated: and therefore it is said that what is pleasant is suffering by way of change. Furthermore, all states belonging to the three planes, except for painful feeling and pleasant feeling, should be understood as “painful as formation” according to the passage: “All formations are suffering” .

original: Micchattaniyatoti micchāsabhāvo hutvā niyato. Niyatamicchādiṭṭhiyā saddhiṃ ānantariyakammassetaṃ
analyzed: micchatta niyataḥ ti micchā sabhāvaḥ hutvā niyataḥ niyata micchādiṭṭhiyā saddhim ānantariya kammassa etam
translated: Determined by wrong: determined as having a wrong nature. This is a term for the kamma that is immediately effective together with the wrong view that is fixed.

original: nāmaṃ. Sammāsabhāve niyato sammattaniyato. Catunnaṃ ariyamaggānametaṃ nāmaṃ. Na niyatoti
analyzed: nāmam sammāsabhāve niyato catunnam ariya maggānam etam nāmam na niyato ti
translated: “Rightly directed” is rightly directed to the four noble paths. This is a name for the four noble paths. “Not rightly directed” is

original: aniyato. Avasesānaṃ dhammānametaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: aniyataḥ avasesānam dhammānam etam nāmam
translated: not rightly directed to the four noble paths. This is a name for the remaining dhammas.

original: Tayo tamāti “tamandhakāro sammoho avijjogho mahābhayo”ti vacanato avijjā tamo nāma.
analyzed: sammohaḥ avijjoghaḥ mahābhayaḥ iti vacanataḥ avijjā tamaḥ nāma
translated: “Three kinds of darkness” : according to the statement: “Darkness, gloom, delusion, ignorance, a great fear” , ignorance is called darkness.

original: Idha pana avijjāsīsena vicikicchā vuttā. Ārabbhāti āgamma. Kaṅkhatīti kaṅkhaṃ uppādeti.
analyzed: idha pana avijjā sīsena vicikicchā vuttā ārabbha ati āgamma kaṅkhati iti kaṅkham uppādeti
translated: But here doubt is stated as the darkness of ignorance. “About” : having come to. “Wavers” : generates doubt.

original: Vicikicchatīti vicinanto kicchaṃ āpajjati, sanniṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti. Nādhimucchatīti
analyzed: vicikicchati iti vicinantaḥ kiccham āpajjati sanniṭṭhātum na sakkoti na adhimucchati iti
translated: “Hesitates” : when investigating, it falls into difficulty and is unable to reach a conclusion. “Does not decide” :

original: tattha adhimucchituṃ na sakkoti. Na sampasīdatīti taṃ ārabbha pasādaṃ āropetuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: tattha adhimucchitum na sakkoti na sampasīdati iti tam ārabbha pasādam āropetum na sakkoti
translated: it is unable to decide upon that. “Does not find satisfaction” : it is unable to establish confidence in that.

original: Arakkheyyānīti na rakkhitabbāni. Tīsu dvāresu paccekaṃ rakkhaṇakiccaṃ natthi, sabbāni
analyzed: arakkheyyāni iti na rakkhitabbāni tīsu dvāresu paccekam rakkhaṇa kiccam natthi sabbāni
translated: “Not to be guarded” : they are not to be guarded. There is no function of guarding them individually at the three doors. It shows that

original: satiyā eva rakkhitānīti dīpeti. Natthi tathāgatassāti. “Idaṃ nāma me sahasā uppannaṃ
analyzed: satiyā eva rakkhitāni iti dīpeti natthi tathāgatassa ati idam nāma me sahasā uppannam
translated: all of them are guarded by mindfulness alone. “The Tathagata has no” : “This arose suddenly in me

original: kāyaduccaritaṃ, imāhaṃ yathā me paro na jānāti, tathā rakkhāmi, paṭicchādemī”ti evaṃ🔽rakkhitabbaṃ natthi tathāgatassa kāyaduccaritaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Kiṃ pana sesakhīṇāsavānaṃ
analyzed: kāya duccaritam imā aham yathā me paraḥ na jānāti tathā rakkhāmi paṭicchādemi iti evam  rakkhitabbam natthi tathāgatassa kāya duccaritam sesesu pi esa eva nayaḥ kim pana sesa khīṇāsavānam
translated: “I shall guard my bodily misconduct as I would guard a secret from others.”🔽There is no bodily misconduct that the Tathāgata has to guard in this way. The same method applies in the other cases.🔽But is it not true that the bodily conduct, etc., of other disciples who have destroyed the taints are not pure?

original: kāyasamācārādayo aparisuddhāti? No aparisuddhā. Na pana tathāgatassa viya parisuddhā.🔽Appassutakhīṇāsavo hi kiñcāpi lokavajjaṃ nāpajjati, paṇṇattiyaṃ pana akovidattā vihārakāraṃ
analyzed: kāya samācāra ādayaḥ aparisuddhā ati no aparisuddhā na pana tathāgatassa viya parisuddhā  appassuta khīṇa āsavaḥ hi kiñcā api lokavajjam na āpajjati paṇṇattiyam pana a kovida ttā vihāra kāram
translated: They are not impure, but they are not as pure as the Tathāgata’s.

original: kuṭikāraṃ sahagāraṃ sahaseyyanti evarūpā kāyadvāre āpattiyo āpajjati. Sañcarittaṃ
analyzed: kuṭikāram sahagāram evarūpā kāya dvāre āpattiyaḥ āpajjati sañcarittam
translated: For the disciple who has destroyed the taints but has little learning may commit the offences of the bodily door such as having a dwelling, a hut, a multi-storeyed building, a large bed, or a high seat built, because he is ignorant of the rules.

original: padasodhammaṃ uttarichappañcavācaṃ bhūtārocananti evarūpā vacīdvāre āpattiyo āpajjati.🔽Upanikkhittasādiyanavasena manodvāre rūpiyappaṭiggāhaṇāpattiṃ āpajjati, dhammasenāpatisadisassāpi
analyzed: padasodhammam bhūtāḥ rocananti evarūpāḥ vacīdvāre āpattiyaḥ āpajjati  upanikkhitta sādiyana vasena manaḥ dvāre rūpiya paṭiggāhaṇa āpattim āpajjati dhammasenāpati sadisassa api
translated: He may commit the offences of the verbal door such as the five kinds of wrong speech, the slander of the Saṅgha, and the accusation of a bhikkhu who is a learner, because he is ignorant of the rules.🔽He may commit the offence of receiving gold and silver through storing them away, because he is ignorant of the rules.

original: hi khīṇāsavassa manodvāre saupārambhavasena manoduccaritaṃ uppajjati eva.
analyzed: hi khīṇāsavassa manaḥ dvāre sa aupārambha vasena manaḥ duccaritam uppajjati eva
translated: For even a disciple who has destroyed the taints but is like the general of the Dhamma, the Venerable Dhaniya, may commit bodily misconduct by way of the mind door, because he is still subject to the in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: Cātumavatthusmiñhi pañcahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ sāriputtamoggallānānaṃ paṇāmitakāle🔽tesaṃ atthāya cātumeyyakehi sakyehi bhagavati khamāpite thero bhagavatā “kinti te
analyzed: cātumavatthusmin hi pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim sāriputta moggallānānam paṇāmita kāle  tesam atthāya cātumeyyakehi sakyehi bhagavati khamāpite theraḥ bhagavatā kinti te
translated: For, when the four great clansmen had sent Sāriputta and Moggallāna away with five hundred monks,

original: sāriputta ahosi mayā bhikkhusaṅghe paṇāmite”ti puṭṭho ahaṃ parisāya abyattabhāvena
analyzed: sāriputta ahosi mayā bhikkhu saṅghe paṇāmitā iti puṭṭhaḥ aham parisāya abyatta bhāvena
translated: and had asked the Exalted One to forgive them, the Elder thought, “What will the Exalted One say to me when I have been sent away with the company of monks?

original: satthārā paṇāmito. Ito dāni paṭṭhāya paraṃ na ovadissāmīti cittaṃ uppādetvā āha “evaṃ🔽kho me, bhante, ahosi bhagavatā bhikkhusaṅgho paṇāmito, appossukko dāni bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ
analyzed: satthārā paṇāmitaḥ itas dāni paṭṭhāya param naḥ ovadissāmi iti cittam uppādetvā āha evam  kho me bhante ahosi bhagavatā bhikkhu saṅghaḥ paṇāmitaḥ appa ussukkaḥ dāni bhagavā diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāram
translated: ” Because of the lack of confidence of the assembly, he thought, “I will not instruct others any more.”

original: anuyutto viharissati, mayampi dāni appossukkā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṃ anuyuttā viharissāmā”ti.
analyzed: anuyuttaḥ viharissati mayam pi dāni appossukkāḥ diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāram anuyuttāḥ viharissāma ati
translated: But when the Exalted One asked him, “Sāriputta, what did you think when I sent you away with the company of monks?,” he replied, “Venerable sir, I thought, ‘The Exalted One has sent away the company of monks. Now the Exalted One will dwell at ease, enjoying the bliss of freedom that he has attained. We too will dwell at ease, enjoying the bliss of freedom.’“

original: Athassa tasmiṃ manoduccarite upārambhaṃ āropento satthā āha – “āgamehi tvaṃ, sāriputta
analyzed: athassa tasmin manaḥ duccarite upārambham āropentaḥ satthā āha āgamehi tvam sāriputta
translated: Then the Teacher, reproving him for his mental misconduct, said, “Wait a moment, Sāriputta.

original: na kho te, sāriputta, punapi evarūpaṃ cittaṃ uppādetabba”nti. Evaṃ paraṃ na ovadissāmi🔽nānusāsissāmīti vitakkitamattampi therassa manoduccaritaṃ nāma jātaṃ. Bhagavato pana
analyzed: na kho te sāriputta puna api evarūpam cittam uppādetabbanti evam param naḥ ovadissāmi  na anusāsissāmi iti vitakkita mattam pi therassa manoduccaritam nāma jātam bhagavataḥ pana
translated: “Sāriputta, you should not arouse such thoughts again.”🔽The Elder had not even thought of advising or instructing others.

original: ettakaṃ nāma natthi, anacchariyañcetaṃ. Sabbaññutaṃ pattassa duccaritaṃ na bhaveyya.
analyzed: ettakam nāma natthi sabbaññutam pattassa duccaritam na bhaveyya
translated: But the Blessed One had no such thoughts. This is not surprising, for one who has attained omniscience would not have such thoughts.

original: Bodhisattabhūmiyaṃ ṭhitassa chabbassāni padhānaṃ anuyuñjantassāpi panassa nāhosi.
analyzed: bodhisatta bhūmiyam ṭhitassa cha bassāni padhānam anuyuñjantassa api panassa na ahosi
translated: Even when he was still a Bodhisatta, while he was striving for six years, he had no such thoughts.

original: Udaracchaviyā piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ allīnāya “kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo”ti devatānaṃ vimatiyā
analyzed: udara chaviyā piṭṭhikaṇṭakam devatānam vimatiyā
translated: Even when the spine was pressing against the ribs, and the devas were in doubt, thinking, “The recluse Gotama is dead,”

original: uppajjamānāyapi “siddhattha kasmā kilamasi? Sakkā bhoge ca bhuñjituṃ puññāni ca kātu”nti🔽mārena pāpimatā vuccamānassa “bhoge bhuñjissāmī”ti vitakkamattampi nuppajjati. Atha
analyzed: uppajjamānāya api siddhattha kasmā kilamasi sakkā bhoge ca bhuñjitum puññāni ca kātunti  mārena pāpimatā vuccamānassa bhoge bhuñjissāmi iti vitakka mattam pi na uppajjati atha
translated: and Māra the Evil One was saying, “Siddhattha, why do you weary yourself? You can enjoy wealth and make merit,”🔽he did not even think, “I will enjoy wealth.”

original: naṃ māro bodhisattakāle chabbassāni buddhakāle ekaṃ vassaṃ anubandhitvā kiñci vajjaṃ
analyzed: nam māraḥ bodhisatta kāle cha bassāni buddha kāle ekam vassam anubandhitvā kiñci vajjam
translated: Then, after following him for six years when he was a Bodhisatta and for one year after he had become Buddha, Māra found nothing in him to seize on and departed saying, “Gotama the recluse is pure in his living and will not enjoy wealth.”

original: apassitvā idaṃ vatvā pakkāmi –
analyzed: a passitvā idam vatvā pakkāmi
translated: and after saying this, he departed.🔽“For seven years I followed the Lord,

original: “Sattavassāni bhagavantaṃ, anubandhiṃ padāpadaṃ;
analyzed: satta vassāni bhagavantam anubandhim padāpadam
translated: Seeking a chance to kill him,

original: Otāraṃ nādhigacchissaṃ, sambuddhassa satīmato”ti. ;
analyzed: otāram na adhigacchissam sambuddhassa satīmataḥ ti
translated: But I never found a chance to kill the Enlightened One, the mindful one.”

original: Apica aṭṭhārasannaṃ buddhadhammānaṃ vasenāpi bhagavato duccaritābhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: apica aṭṭhārasannam buddha dhammānam vasena api bhagavataḥ duccarita abhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: Moreover, the Blessed One’s freedom from misconduct can be understood by way of the eighteen qualities of the Buddha.

original: Aṭṭhārasa buddhadhammā nāma natthi tathāgatassa kāyaduccaritaṃ, natthi vacīduccaritaṃ,
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa buddha dhammāḥ nāma natthi tathāgatassa kāya duccaritam natthi vacī duccaritam
translated: The eighteen qualities of the Buddha are as follows: There is no bodily misconduct of a Tathāgata, there is no verbal misconduct,

original: natthi manoduccaritaṃ, atīte buddhassa appaṭihatañāṇaṃ, anāgate, paccuppanne buddhassa
analyzed: natthi manaḥ duccaritam atīte buddhassa a paṭihata ñāṇam anāgate paccuppanne buddhassa
translated: there is no mental misconduct. His knowledge is unobstructed with regard to the past, with regard to the future, and with regard to the present.

original: appaṭihatañāṇaṃ, sabbaṃ kāyakammaṃ buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇānuparivatti, sabbaṃ vacīkammaṃ,
analyzed: a paṭihata ñāṇam sabbam kāya kammam buddhassa bhagavataḥ ñāṇa anuparivatti sabbam vacī kammam
translated: All his bodily actions are in conformity with knowledge; all his verbal actions are in conformity with knowledge;

original: sabbaṃ manokammaṃ buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇānuparivatti, natthi chandassa hāni, natthi
analyzed: sabbam manaḥ kammam buddhassa bhagavato ñāṇa anuparivatti natthi chandassa hāni natthi
translated: all his mental actions are in conformity with knowledge. There is no diminution of his zeal,

original: vīriyassa hāni, natthi satiyā hāni, natthi davā, natthi ravā, natthi calitaṃ natthi
analyzed: vīriyassa hāni natthi satiyāḥ hāni natthi davā natthi ravā natthi calitam natthi
translated: no diminution of his energy, no diminution of his mindfulness, no diminution of his concentration, no diminution of his wisdom, no diminution of his deliverance.

original: sahasā, natthi abyāvaṭo mano, natthi akusalacittanti.
analyzed: sahasā natthi abyāvaṭaḥ manaḥ natthi akusala cittanti
translated: “There is no restraint of mind, there is no wholesome consciousness.”

original: Kiñcanāti palibodhā. Rāgo kiñcananti rāgo uppajjamāno satte bandhati palibundhati tasmā kiñcananti vuccati. Itaresupi dvīsu eseva nayo.
analyzed: kiñcana ati palibodhā rāgaḥ kiñcananti rāgaḥ uppajjamānaḥ satte bandhati palibundhati tasmā kiñcana nti vuccati itaresu pi dvīsu esa eva nayo
translated: “What is it?” is a hindrance. “Greed is what is it”: when greed arises it binds beings, it hinders them, thus it is called what is it. The same method applies in the case of the other two.

original: Aggīti anudahanaṭṭhena aggi. Rāgaggīti rāgo uppajjamāno satte anudahati jhāpeti,
analyzed: aggi iti anudahana ṭṭhena aggi rāga aggi iti rāgaḥ uppajjamānaḥ satte anudahati jhāpeti
translated: “Fire”: fire in the sense of burning. “The fire of greed”: when greed arises it burns beings, it consumes them,

original: tasmā aggīti vuccati. Itaresupi eseva nayo. Tattha vatthūni ekā daharabhikkhunī cittalapabbatavihāre
analyzed: tasmai aggi iti vuccati itaresu pi esa iva nayaḥ tattha vatthūni ekā dahara bhikkhunī cittala pabbata vihāre
translated: thus it is called fire. The same method applies in the case of the other two. Herein, as to the instances, a certain young bhikkhu went to the Uposatha house in the Citta Lake Hermitage

original: uposathāgāraṃ gantvā dvārapālarūpakaṃ olokayamānā ṭhitā. Athassā anto rāgo uppanno.
analyzed: uposatha āgāram gantvā dvārapāla rūpakam olokayamānā ṭhitā atha assāḥ antaḥ rāgaḥ uppanno
translated: and stood looking at the figure of the door-keeper. Then greed arose in him.

original: Sā teneva jhāyitvā kālamakāsi. Bhikkhuniyo gacchamānā “ayaṃ daharā ṭhitā, pakkosatha,
analyzed: sā tena iva jhāyitvā kālam akāsi bhikkhuniyaḥ gacchamānāḥ ayam daharā ṭhitā pakkosatha
translated: He was consumed by it and died. The bhikkhunis said to the bhikkhus, “This young bhikkhu is standing there. Send for him.🔽” “No,” he said. One went and took him by the hand, saying, “Why do you stand there?” As soon as he was touched,

original: na”nti āhaṃsu. Ekā gantvā kasmā ṭhitāsīti hatthe gaṇhi. Gahitamattā parivattitvā
analyzed: āhaṃsu ekā gantvā kasmā ṭhitā asi iti hatthe gaṇhi gahita mattā
translated: he fell over.

original: papatā. Idaṃ tāva rāgassa anudahanatāya vatthu. Dosassa pana anudahanatāya manopadosikā
analyzed: papatā idam tāva rāgassa anudahana tāya vatthu dosassa pana anudahana tāya manopadosikā
translated: This is the basis for the non-arising of lust. But the basis for the non-arising of hate is the gods who are angry-minded.

original: devā. Mohassa anudahanatāya khiḍḍāpadosikā devā daṭṭhabbā. Mohavasena hi tāsaṃ satisammoso
analyzed: devā mohassa anudahana tāya khiḍḍa apadosikāḥ devāḥ daṭṭhabbāḥ moha vasena hi tāsam sati sammoso
translated: The basis for the non-arising of delusion is the gods who are careless through play. For it is through delusion that their mindfulness lapses.

original: hoti. Tasmā khiḍḍāvasena āhārakālaṃ ativattitvā kālaṅkaronti.
analyzed: tasmai āhāra kālam ativattitvā kālaṅkaronti
translated: Therefore they die through carelessness in play.

original: Āhuneyyaggītiādīsu āhunaṃ vuccati sakkāro, āhunaṃ arahantīti āhuneyyā. Mātāpitaro
analyzed: āhuneyya giri iti ādīsu āhunam vuccati sakkāraḥ āhunam arahanti iti āhuneyyāḥ mātā pitaro
translated: As regards the “fire of gratitude” and so on, “gratitude” is respect. Parents are worthy of gratitude because of their great helpfulness to their children.

original: hi puttānaṃ bahūpakāratāya āhunaṃ arahanti. Tesu vippaṭipajjamānā puttā nirayādīsu
analyzed: hi puttānam bahu upakāra tāya āhunam arahanti tesu vippaṭipajjamānāḥ puttāḥ niraya ādīsu
translated: When children behave wrongly towards them, they are reborn in hell, etc.,

original: nibbattanti. Tasmā kiñcāpi mātāpitaro nānudahanti, anudahanassa pana paccayā honti.
analyzed: nibbattanti tasmā kiñcā api mātā pitaraḥ na anudahanti anudahanassa pana paccayāḥ honti
translated: So although parents do not arouse gratitude, they are a condition for its arising.

original: Iti anudahanaṭṭhena āhuneyyaggīti vuccanti. Svāyamattho mittavindakavatthunā dīpetabbo –
analyzed: iti anudahana aṭṭhena āhuneyyaggī iti vuccanti su ayam atthaḥ mittavindaka vatthunā dīpetabbaḥ
translated: So they are called “the fire of gratitude” in the sense of arousing gratitude. This meaning can be illustrated by the story of Mittavindaka.

original: Mittavindako hi mātarā “tāta, ajja uposathiko hutvā vihāre sabbarattiṃ dhammassavanaṃ
analyzed: mittavindakaḥ hi mātarā tāta ajja uposathikaḥ hutvā vihāre sabbarattim dhammassavanaṃ
translated: Mittavindaka’s mother said to him: “My dear, today you should observe the Uposatha and listen to the Dhamma all night in the monastery.

original: suṇa, sahassaṃ te dassāmī”ti vutto dhanalobhena uposathaṃ samādāya vihāraṃ gantvā
analyzed: suṇa sahassam te dassāmi iti vuttaḥ dhana lobhena uposatham samādāya vihāram gantvā
translated: “Listen, I will give you a thousand pieces of money.” He consented to observe the Uposatha out of greed for the money. He went to the monastery,

original: idaṃ ṭhānaṃ akutobhayanti sallakkhetvā dhammāsanassa heṭṭhā nipanno sabbarattiṃ niddāyitvā
analyzed: idam ṭhānam akutobhayanti sallakkhetvā dhammāsanassa heṭṭhā nipannaḥ sabbarattim niddāyitvā
translated: and he thought, “There is no danger here.” He lay down under the pulpit and slept all night.

original: gharaṃ agamāsi. Mātā pātova yāguṃ pacitvā upanāmesi. So sahassaṃ gahetvāva pivi.

translated: In the morning he went home. His mother cooked rice-gruel and brought it to him. He took the thousand pieces of money and drank the gruel.

original: Athassa etadahosi – “dhanaṃ saṃharissāmī”ti. So nāvāya samuddaṃ pakkhanditukāmo ahosi.
analyzed: atha assa etat ahosi dhanam saṃharissāmi iti saḥ nāvāya samuddam pakkhanditu kāmaḥ ahosi

analyzed: atha nam mātā tāta imasmin kule cattālīsa koṭi dhanam atthi alam gamanena ati nivāresi
translated: His mother said to him, “Son, in this family there is wealth worth forty koṭis. There is no need for you to go.”

original: So tassā vacanaṃ anādiyitvā gacchati eva. Mātā purato aṭṭhāsi. Atha naṃ kujjhitvā
analyzed: saḥ tassāḥ vacanam an ādiyitvā gacchati eva mātā puratas aṭṭhāsi atha nam kujjhitvā
translated: But he paid no attention to her words and went. His mother stood in front of him. Then he became angry.

original: “ayaṃ mayhaṃ purato tiṭṭhatī”ti pādena paharitvā patitaṃ antaraṃ katvā agamāsi.
analyzed: ayam mayham puratas tiṭṭhati iti pādena paharitvā patitam antaram katvā agamāsi
translated: “She stands in front of me,” he thought, and he kicked her. She fell down and he went on his way.

original: Mātā uṭṭhahitvā “mādisāya mātari evarūpaṃ kammaṃ katvā gatassa te gataṭṭhāne sukhaṃ
analyzed: mātā uṭṭhahitvā mādisāya mātari evarūpam kammam katvā gatassa te gata ṭṭhāne sukham
translated: His mother got up and said, “You have gone, having done such a deed to a mother like me. You will not find happiness in the place to which you are going.

original: bhavissatīti evaṃsaññī nāma tvaṃ puttā”ti āha. Tassa nāvaṃ āruyha gacchato sattame
analyzed: bhavissati iti evaṃsaññī nāma tvam putta ati āha tassa nāvam āruyha gacchataḥ sattame
translated: “You are the one who thought that there would be such a thing, my son.”

analyzed: divase nāvā aṭṭhāsi atha te manussāḥ addhā ettha pāpa purisaḥ atthi salākam detha ati

analyzed: salākā diyyamānā tassa iva tikkhattum pāpuṇāti te tassa uḷumpam da tvā tam
translated: As the lots were being drawn, they fell three times on him. They gave him a heavy stone

analyzed: samudde pakkhipiṃsu saḥ ekam dīpam gantvā vimāna petīhi saddhim sampattim anubhavantaḥ
translated: and threw him into the sea. He went to an island and enjoyed the pleasures of the celestial nymphs.

original: tāhi “purato purato mā agamāsī”ti vuccamānopi taddiguṇaṃ taddiguṇaṃ sampattiṃ passanto
analyzed: tāhi puratas puratas mā agamāsi iti vuccamānaḥ api tad diguṇam tad diguṇam sampattim passanto
translated: Though they said to him, “Do not come so far, do not come so far,” he saw pleasures double and treble the former,

analyzed: anupubbena khura cakka dharam ekam addasa tassa tam cakkam paduma puppham viya upaṭṭhāsi  saḥ tam āha ambho idam tayā piḷandhitam padumam dehi iti naḥ idam sāmi
translated: and in the end he saw one who had a razor wheel. That wheel appeared to him like a lotus flower.🔽He said to her, “Lady, give me that lotus flower which you are carrying.” “Sir,

analyzed: padumam khura cakkam etanti saḥ vañcesi mam tvam kim mayā padumam a diṭṭha pubbam ti
translated: that is not a lotus flower, it is a razor wheel.” “You are deceiving me. How can I not have seen a lotus flower before?”

original: vatvā tvaṃ lohitacandanaṃ vilimpitvā piḷandhanaṃ padumapupphaṃ mayhaṃ na dātukāmoti
analyzed: vatvā tvam lohitacandanam vilimpitvā piḷandhanam paduma puppham mayham na dātu kāmaḥ iti
translated: and said, “You are smearing yourself with red sandalwood ointment and you will not give me the lotus flower for my head-dress.”

analyzed: āha saḥ cintesi ayam pi mayā kata sadisam kammam katvā tassa phalam anubhavitu kāmo ti
translated: He thought, “This one also wants to experience the fruit of the deed that I did,”

analyzed: atha nam handa rai ti vatvā tassa matthake cakkam pakkhipi tena vuttam
translated: and he said, “Come, then,” and placed the wheel on his head. Therefore it is said:🔽“From four to eight, from eight to sixteen,

analyzed: catubbhi ca soḷasa  ca bāttiṃsa
translated: From sixteen to thirty-two,

analyzed: icchā hatassa posassa cakkam bhamati matthaka iti
translated: The wheel turns on the head of the man who is struck down by desire.”

original: Gahapatīti pana gehasāmiko vuccati. So mātugāmassa sayanavatthālaṅkārādianuppadānena🔽bahūpakāro. Taṃ aticaranto mātugāmo nirayādīsu nibbattati, tasmā sopi purimanayeneva
analyzed: gahapati iti pana geha sāmiko vuccati so mātugāmassa sayana vattha alaṅkāra ādi anuppadānena  bahu upakāraḥ tam aticarantaḥ mātugāmaḥ niraya ādīsu nibbattati tasmā saḥ api purima nayena iva
translated: Householder: the master of the house is meant. He is of great service to the woman by providing her with a bed, clothes, ornaments, etc.🔽If he transgresses against her, she is reborn in hell, etc. Therefore he is called a householder-fire in the sense of one who burns,

original: anudahanaṭṭhena gahapataggīti vutto.
analyzed: anudahana ṭṭhena gaha pataggī iti vuttaḥ
translated: as above.

analyzed: saḥ tam paccakkhataḥ disvā kasmā tvam evam karosi iti āha sā sacā aham evarūpam karomi
translated: When he saw it, he said, “Why do you do this?” She replied, “If I do this,

analyzed: ayam me su nakhaḥ viluppamānaḥ khādatu iti vatvā kālaṅkatvā kaṇṇa muṇḍaka dahe vemānika petī

analyzed: hutvā nibbattā divā sampattim anubhavati rattim dukkham tadā bārāṇasī rājā migavam

analyzed: carantaḥ araññam pavisitvā anupubbena kaṇṇa muṇḍaka daham sampatto tāya saddhim sampattim

analyzed: anubhavati sā tam vañcetvā rattim dukkham anubhavati saḥ ñatvā kattha nu kho gacchati iti

translated: Following her, he went and stood not far away. He saw a dog come out of the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa cemetery, eating her, “paṭapaṭa.”

analyzed: khādamānam ekam su nakham disvā asinā dvidhā dve ahesum puna chinne cattāraḥ
translated: He cut it in two with his sword. There were two dogs. When cut again, there were four.
