analyzed: puna chinne aṭṭha puna chinne soḷasa ahesum sā kim karosi sāmi iti āha sā u kim
translated: When cut again, there were eight. When cut again, there were sixteen dogs. She said, “What are you doing, my lord?” He said, “I am cutting you.”

original: ida”nti āha. Sā “evaṃ akatvā kheḷapiṇḍaṃ bhūmiyaṃ niṭṭhubhitvā pādena ghaṃsāhī”ti
analyzed: idam iti āha sā evam a katvā kheḷa piṇḍam bhūmiyam niṭṭhubhitvā pādena ghaṃsāhi iti
translated: “Here it is.” “Don’t do that. Spit it out on the ground and trample it with your foot.”

original: āha. So tathā akāsi. Sunakhā antaradhāyiṃsu. Taṃ divasaṃ tassā kammaṃ khīṇaṃ. Rājā
analyzed: āha saḥ tathā akāsi sunakhāḥ antaradhāyiṃsu tam divasam tassā kammam khīṇam rājā
translated: He did so. The dogs disappeared. That day her deed was exhausted. The king

original: vippaṭisārī hutvā gantuṃ āraddho. Sā “mayhaṃ, sāmi, kammaṃ khīṇaṃ mā agamā”ti āha. Rājā asutvāva gato.
analyzed: vippaṭisārī hutvā gantum āraddhaḥ sā mayham sāmi kammam khīṇam mā agama iti āha rājā a sutvā ava gataḥ
translated: was remorseful and started to leave. “My lord, my deed is exhausted. Don’t go,” she said. The king left without listening.

original: Dakkhiṇeyyaggīti ettha pana dakkhiṇāti cattāro paccayā, bhikkhusaṅgho dakkhiṇeyyo.
analyzed: dakkhiṇeyya aggī iti ettha pana dakkhiṇā ati cattāro paccayāḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: As for “worthy of offerings” , the four requisites are offerings. The Sangha of bhikkhus is worthy of offerings.

original: So gihīnaṃ tīsu saraṇesu pañcasu sīlesu dasasu sīlesu mātāpituupaṭṭhāne dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇaupaṭṭhāneti
analyzed: saḥ gihīnam tīsu saraṇesu pañcasu sīlesu dasasu sīlesu mātā pitu upaṭṭhāne dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇa upaṭṭhāne iti
translated: It is a great help to householders in many ways, by advising them to take up the good things of the three refuges, the five precepts, the ten precepts, the service of mother and father, and the service of virtuous ascetics and brahmans.

original: evamādīsu kalyāṇadhammesu niyojanena bahūpakāro, tasmiṃ micchāpaṭipannā gihī bhikkhusaṅghaṃ
analyzed: evamādīsu kalyāṇa dhammesu niyojanena bahu upakāraḥ tasmin micchā paṭipannā gihī bhikkhu saṅgham
translated: When householders who have thus been advised behave wrongly towards the Sangha of bhikkhus,🔽they abuse and revile it, and they are reborn in hell, etc.,

original: akkositvā paribhāsitvā nirayādīsu nibbattanti, tasmā sopi purimanayeneva anudahanaṭṭhena
analyzed: akkositvā paribhāsitvā niraya ādīsu nibbattanti tasmā saḥ api purima nayena iva anudahana ṭṭhena
translated: Therefore it is also a source of suffering in the way already stated.

original: dakkhiṇeyyaggīti vutto. Imassa panatthassa vibhāvanatthaṃ vimānavatthusmiṃ revatīvatthu vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: dakkhiṇeyyaggī iti vuttaḥ imassa pana atthassa vibhāvana attham vimāna vatthusmim revatī vatthu vitthāretabbam
translated: he is called the Worthy One, the Best of Men to be worshipped. For the elucidation of this meaning the story of Revati in the Vimānavatthu should be told.

original: “Tividhena rūpasaṅgaho”ti ettha tividhenāti tīhi koṭṭhāsehi. Saṅgahoti jātisañjātikiriyagaṇanavasena
analyzed: tividhena rūpa saṅgaho ti ettha tividhena ati tīhi koṭṭhāsehi saṅgaho ti jāti sañjāti kiriya gaṇana vasena
translated: In the passage “The inclusion of materiality is threefold” the threefoldness is by means of three sections. Inclusion is of four kinds, namely, by class, by generation, by function, and by enumeration.🔽Herein, the inclusion by class is such as “Let all nobles come,” etc.;

original: catubbidho saṅgaho. Tattha sabbe khattiyā āgacchantūtiādiko jātisaṅgaho. Sabbe kosalakātiādiko🔽sañjātisaṅgaho. Sabbe hatthārohātiādiko kiriyasaṅgaho. Cakkhāyatanaṃ katamaṃ khandhagaṇanaṃ
analyzed: catubbidhaḥ saṅgahaḥ tattha sabbe khattiyāḥ āgacchantu uti ādikaḥ jāti saṅgahaḥ sabbe  sañjāti saṅgaho sabbe hattha āroha ati ādiko kiriya saṅgaho cakkha āyatanam katamam khandha gaṇanam
translated: the inclusion by generation is such as “Let all Kosalans come,” etc.;🔽the inclusion by function is such as “Let all elephant-drivers come,” etc.;🔽the inclusion by enumeration is such as “What is the eye-base? The eye-base is reckoned as the form aggregate.”

original: gacchatīti? Cakkhāyatanaṃ rūpakkhandhagaṇanaṃ gacchatīti. Hañci cakkhāyatanaṃ rūpakkhandhena🔽saṅgahitanti ayaṃ gaṇanasaṅgaho, so idha adhippeto. Tasmā tividhena rūpasaṅgahoti
analyzed: gacchati iti cakkhu āyatanam rūpa kkhandha gaṇanam gacchati iti hañci cakkha āyatanam rūpa kkhandhena  saṅgahitanti ayam gaṇana saṅgaho saḥ idha adhippeto tasmā tividhena rūpa saṅgaho ti
translated: “Is the eye-base included in the form aggregate?”🔽This is the inclusion by enumeration, and that is what is intended here.

original: tīhi koṭṭhāsehi rūpagaṇanāti attho.
analyzed: tīhi koṭṭhāsehi rūpa gaṇanā ti attho
translated: So the meaning of “The inclusion of materiality is threefold” is that the enumeration of materiality is by means of three sections.

original: Sanidassanādīsu attānaṃ ārabbha pavattena cakkhuviññāṇasaṅkhātena saha nidassanenāti
analyzed: sa nidassana ādīsu attānam ārabbha pavattena cakkhu viññāṇa saṅkhātena saha nidassanena ati
translated: In the case of the visible-data base, etc., it is “with the visible” because it occurs in association with eye-consciousness, which occurs contingent upon itself.

original: sanidassanaṃ. Cakkhupaṭihananasamatthato saha paṭighenāti sappaṭighaṃ. Taṃ atthato
analyzed: sa nidassanam cakkhu paṭihanana samatthato saha paṭighena ati sa paṭigham tam atthato
translated: It is visible because it is capable of impingement by the eye. It is impingeable because it is impinged upon together with the resistance. In fact

original: rūpāyatanameva. Cakkhuviññāṇasaṅkhātaṃ nāssa nidassananti anidassanaṃ. Sotādipaṭihananasamatthato🔽saha paṭighenāti sappaṭighaṃ. Taṃ atthato cakkhāyatanādīni nava āyatanāni. Vuttappakāraṃ
analyzed: rūpa āyatanam eva cakkhu viññāṇa saṅkhātam na assa nidassanam ti a nidassanam sota ādi paṭihanana samatthato  saha paṭighena ati sa paṭigham tam atthataḥ cakkhāyatana ādīni nava āyatanāni vutta ppakāram
translated: it is the visible-data base only. It is not visible because it is not visible as a mode of the eye-consciousness. It is impingeable because it is impingeable by the ear, etc.🔽It is impingeable because it is impingeable together with the resistance. In fact it is the nine bases beginning with the eye base. It is not visible

original: nāssa nidassananti anidassanaṃ. Nāssa paṭighoti appaṭighaṃ. Taṃ atthato ṭhapetvā🔽dasāyatanāni avasesaṃ sukhumarūpaṃ.
analyzed: na assa nidassananti a nidassanam na assa paṭighaḥ ti appaṭigham tam atthataḥ ṭhapetvā  dasa āyatanāni avasesam sukhuma rūpam
translated: because it is not visible as a mode of the eye-consciousness, etc. It is not impingeable because it is not impingeable by the ear, etc. In fact it is the fine-material octad.

original: Tayo saṅkhārāti sahajātadhamme ceva samparāye phaladhamme ca saṅkharonti rāsī karontīti saṅkhārā. Abhisaṅkharotīti abhisaṅkhāro. Puñño abhisaṅkhāro puññābhisaṅkhāro.
analyzed: tayo saṅkhārāti sahajāta dhamme ca iva samparāye phala dhamme ca saṅkharonti rāsī karonti iti saṅkhārāḥ abhisaṅkharoti iti abhisaṅkhāro puññaḥ abhisaṅkhāro puñña abhisaṅkhāro
translated: Three kinds of formations: they form, they heap up, together with associated states, and also in the future with resultant states, thus they are formations . He forms, thus he is a former . A meritorious former is a meritorious former .

original: “Tattha katamo puññābhisaṅkhāro? Kusalā cetanā kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarā dānamayā sīlamayā
analyzed: tattha katamo puñña abhisaṅkhāro kusalā cetanā kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarā dāna mayā sīla mayā
translated: Herein, what is a meritorious former? Wholesome volition in the sense-world sphere, in the fine-material sphere, and in the immaterial sphere, which is of the nature to give, and which is of the nature to observe moral discipline,

original: bhāvanāmayā”ti evaṃ vuttānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ kāmāvacarakusalamahācittacetanānaṃ, pañcannaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanā mayā ati evam vuttānam aṭṭhannam kāmāvacara kusala mahā citta cetanānam pañcannam
translated: and the eight kinds of profitable consciousness belonging to the fine-material sphere.

original: rūpāvacarakusalacetanānañcetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Ettha ca dānasīlamayā aṭṭheva cetanā🔽honti. Bhāvanāmayā terasāpi. Yathā hi paguṇaṃ dhammaṃ sajjhāyamāno ekaṃ dve anusandhiṃ🔽gatopi na jānāti, pacchā āvajjanto jānāti, evameva kasiṇaparikammaṃ karontassa paguṇajjhānaṃ
analyzed: adhivacanam ettha ca dāna sīla mayā aṭṭhā iva cetanā  honti bhāvanā mayā terasā api yathā hi paguṇam dhammam ekam dve anusandhim  gataḥ api na jānāti pacchā āvajjantaḥ jānāti evam eva kasiṇa parikammam karontassa paguṇa jhānam
translated: Herein, the eight kinds of volition are those consisting in giving and virtue,

original: paccavekkhantassa ñāṇavippayuttāpi bhāvanā hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “bhāvanāmayā terasāpī”ti.🔽Tattha dānamayādīsu “dānaṃ ārabbha dānamadhikicca yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattaṃ,
analyzed: paccavekkhantassa ñāṇa vippayuttā api bhāvanā hoti tena vuttam bhāvanā mayā terasā api iti  tattha dāna maya ādīsu dānam ārabbha dānam adhikicca yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattam
translated: and the thirteen are those consisting in development. For just as when one is reading a text that one has already read one does not know what comes next until one has recalled the earlier part, so too when one is reviewing the kasiṇa that has been made the subject of development, the development is not associated with knowledge, and so it is called “consisting in development.” That is why it was said above “the thirteen are those consisting in development.”

original: ayaṃ vuccati dānamayo puññābhisaṅkhāro. Sīlaṃ ārabbha, bhāvanaṃ ārabbha, bhāvanamadhikicca
analyzed: ayam vuccati dāna mayaḥ puñña abhisaṅkhāro sīlam ārabbha bhāvanam ārabbha bhāvanam adhikicca
translated: Herein, as regards the kinds consisting in giving and so on, the volition that arises in giving, in virtue, and in development, and that is associated with the three profitable roots, is called the formation of merit consisting in giving, virtue, and development respectively.

original: yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati bhāvanāmayo puññābhisaṅkhāro”ti
analyzed: yā uppajjati cetanā sañcetanā cetayitattam ayam vuccati bhāvanā mayaḥ puñña abhisaṅkhāro ti
translated: The volition that arises is volition, intention, mental forming: this is called the meritorious volitional formation consisting in development.”

original: ayaṃ saṅkhepadesanā.🔽Cīvarādīsu pana catūsu paccayesu rūpādīsu vā chasu ārammaṇesu annādīsu vā dasasu
analyzed: ayam saṅkhepa desanā  cīvara ādīsu pana catūsu paccayesu rūpa ādīsu vā chasu ārammaṇesu anna ādīsu vā dasasu
translated: This is the brief treatment.

original: dānavatthūsu taṃ taṃ dentassa tesaṃ uppādanato paṭṭhāya pubbabhāge, pariccāgakāle,
analyzed: dāna vatthūsu tam tam dentassa tesam uppādanato paṭṭhāya pubba bhāge pariccāga kāle
translated: But in the case of the four requisites beginning with robes, or in the case of the six kinds of objects beginning with visible forms, or in the case of the ten objects of gifts beginning with food, the volition that occurs in the three instances, that is to say, from the time of beginning to give, at the moment of giving up,

original: pacchā somanassacittena anussaraṇe cāti tīsu kālesu pavattā cetanā dānamayā nāma.🔽Sīlapūraṇatthāya pana pabbajissāmīti vihāraṃ gacchantassa, pabbajantassa manorathaṃ🔽matthakaṃ pāpetvā pabbajito vatamhi sādhu sādhūti āvajjantassa, pātimokkhaṃ saṃvarantassa,🔽cīvarādayo paccaye paccavekkhantassa, āpāthagatesu rūpādīsu cakkhudvārādīni saṃvarantassa,
analyzed: pacchā somanassa cittena anussaraṇe ca ati tīsu kālesu pavattā cetanā dāna mayā nāma  sīla pūraṇa atthāya pana pabbajissāmi iti vihāram gacchantassa pabbajantassa manoratham  matthakam pāpetvā pabbajitaḥ vatamhi sādhu sādhu iti āvajjantassa pātimokkham saṃvarantassa  cīvara ādayo paccaye paccavekkhantassa āpātha gatesu rūpa ādīsu cakkhu dvāra ādīni saṃvarantassa
translated: and afterwards when recollecting with a happy mind, is called the formation consisting in giving.

original: ājīvaṃ sodhentassa ca pavattā cetanā sīlamayā nāma.
analyzed: ājīvam sodhentassa ca pavattā cetanā sīla mayā nāma
translated: But the volition that occurs in the following instances is called the formation consisting in virtue: in going to the monastery, in going to the place of the instruction, in the thought of going forth, in the thought of fulfilling virtue, in the thought of perfecting the virtue that has been fulfilled, in the thought of “I have gone forth, I have fulfilled virtue,” in the thought of restraint, in the thought of perfecting the restraint that has been undertaken, in the thought of “I am restrained, I have perfected restraint,” in the thought of reviewing the requisites, in the thought of guarding the doors of the sense faculties, in the thought of purifying livelihood, and in the thought of purifying the requisites of robes, alms food, resting place, and medicine.

original: Paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttena vipassanāmaggena “cakkhuṃ aniccato dukkhato anattato bhāventassa…pe…
analyzed: paṭisambhidā ayam vuttena vipassanā maggena cakkhum aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ
translated: “One who develops eye as impermanent, as painful, as not self, …🔽mind, forms, mind-consciousness, mind-contact,

original: manaṃ. Rūpe. Dhamme. Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ…pe… manoviññāṇaṃ. Cakkhusamphassaṃ…pe… manosamphassaṃ.
analyzed: manam rūpe dhamme cakkhu viññāṇam pe manaḥ viññāṇam cakkhu samphassam pe manaḥ samphassam
translated: eye-contact … mind-contact,

original: Cakkhusamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ…pe… manosamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ. Rūpasaññaṃ, jarāmaraṇaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu samphassa jam vedanam pe manaḥ samphassa jam vedanam rūpa saññam jarā maraṇam
translated: eye-contact-born feeling … mind-contact-born feeling, perception of forms, ageing-and-death,

original: aniccato dukkhato anattato bhāventassa pavattā cetanā bhāvanāmayā nāmā”ti ayaṃ vitthārakathā.
analyzed: aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ bhāventassa pavattā cetanā bhāvanā mayā nāma ati ayam vitthāra kathā
translated: as impermanent, as painful, as not self, his volition occurring as the development of that is called development consisting in keeping in being” .🔽This is the detailed explanation.🔽It is unprofitable and it is a formation, thus it is an unprofitable formation.

original: Apuñño ca so abhisaṅkhāro cāti apuññābhisaṅkhāro. Dvādasaakusalacittasampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: apuñño ca so abhisaṅkhāro ca ati apuñña abhisaṅkhāraḥ dvādasa akusala citta sampayuttānam
translated: This is a term for the volition associated with the twelve unprofitable consciousnesses.🔽And this is said: “Herein, what is unprofitable formation?🔽Unprofitable volition,

original: cetanānaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ “tattha katamo apuññābhisaṅkhāro? Akusalacetanā🔽kāmāvacarā, ayaṃ vuccati apuññābhisaṅkhāro”ti. Āneñjaṃ niccalaṃ santaṃ vipākabhūtaṃ
analyzed: cetanānam etam adhivacanam vuttam pi ca itam tattha katamaḥ apuñña abhisaṅkhāraḥ akusala cetanā  kāmāvacarā ayam vuccati apuñña abhisaṅkhāro ti āneñjam niccalam santam vipāka bhūtam
translated: in the sense world, is called unprofitable formation” .🔽It is neither-unprofitable-nor-profitable, and it is motionless, and it is peaceful, and it is a state of result,🔽and it is only immaterial, and it is a formation, thus it is a neither-unprofitable-nor-profitable-motionless-peaceful-resultant-immaterial-formation.

original: arūpameva abhisaṅkharotīti āneñjābhisaṅkhāro. Catunnaṃ arūpāvacarakusalacetanānaṃ
analyzed: arūpam eva abhisaṅkharoti iti āneñja abhisaṅkhāro
translated: This is a term for the four kinds of profitable volition in the immaterial sphere.

original: etaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Yathāha “tattha katamo āneñjābhisaṅkhāro? Kusalacetanā arūpāvacarā,
analyzed: etam adhivacanam yathā āha tattha katamaḥ āneñja abhisaṅkhāro kusala cetanā arūpa avacarā
translated: This is the term. As it is said: “Herein, what is the formation of the imperturbable? The wholesome volition of the immaterial sphere,

original: ayaṃ vuccati āneñjābhisaṅkhāro”ti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati āneñja abhisaṅkhāraḥ ti
translated: this is called the formation of the imperturbable.”

original: Puggalattike sattavidho purisapuggalo, tisso sikkhā sikkhatīti sekkho. Khīṇāsavo🔽sikkhitasikkhattā puna na sikkhissatīti asekkho. Puthujjano sikkhāhi paribāhiyattā
analyzed: puggala ttike sattavidho purisa puggalo tissā sikkhā sikkhati iti sekkho khīṇāsavo  sikkhita sikkha ttā puna na sikkhissati iti asekkhaḥ puthujjanaḥ sikkhāhi paribāhiya ttā
translated: In the section on persons, the seven kinds of person are: one in training trains in the three trainings. One with taints destroyed,

original: nevasekkho nāsekkho.🔽Therattike jātimahallako gihī jātitthero nāma. “Cattārome, bhikkhave, therakaraṇā
analyzed: na ivasekkhaḥ na asekkhaḥ  thera ttike jātimahallakaḥ gihī jātittheraḥ nāma cattāro me bhikkhave thera karaṇā
translated: because he has trained in the training, will not train again. One who is neither in training nor beyond training is a worldling, because he is excluded from the trainings.

original: dhammā. Idha, bhikkhave, thero sīlavā hoti, bahussuto hoti, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ lābhī🔽hoti, āsavānaṃ khayā bahussuto hoti, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ lābhī hoti, āsavānaṃ khayā
analyzed: dhammā idha bhikkhave theraḥ sīlavā hoti bahu sutaḥ hoti catunnam jhānānam lābhī  hoti āsavānam khayā bahu sutaḥ hoti catunnam jhānānam lābhī hoti āsavānam khayā
translated: In the section on elders, a householder who is great in age is called an elder by birth. “Monks, there are these four things that make one an elder. Here, monks, an elder is virtuous, learned, an acquirent of the attainments,🔽and has destroyed the taints. He is virtuous, learned, an acquirent of the attainments, and has destroyed the taints. He has attained the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom,

original: anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja
analyzed: anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja
translated: and dwells having known, having directly experienced, and having attained it himself in this very life.”

original: viharati. Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro therakaraṇā dhammā”ti. Evaṃ vuttesu dhammesu
analyzed: viharati ime kho bhikkhave cattāro thera karaṇāḥ dhammā ti evam vuttesu dhammesu
translated: When these things have been stated,🔽one who possesses one or other of them is called a “Dhamma elder.”

original: ekena vā anekehi vā samannāgato dhammathero nāma. Aññataro theranāmako bhikkhūti
analyzed: ekena vā anekehi vā samannāgataḥ dhammatheraḥ nāma aññataraḥ thera nāmakaḥ bhikkhu iti
translated: A bhikkhu who is called an “elder”

original: evaṃ theranāmako vā, yaṃ vā pana mahallakakāle pabbajitaṃ sāmaṇerādayo disvā thero
analyzed: evam thera nāmakaḥ vā yam vā pana mahallaka kāle pabbajitam sāmaṇera ādayaḥ disvā theraḥ
translated: or whom the novices and so on call “elder” when they see him because he has gone forth in old age,

original: theroti vadanti, ayaṃ sammutithero nāma.
analyzed: vadanti ayam sammuti theraḥ nāma
translated: is called a “conventional elder.”🔽In the bases for spiritual power, only giving is “having giving as its essence.”

original: Puññakiriyavatthūsu dānameva dānamayaṃ. Puññakiriyā ca sā tesaṃ tesaṃ ānisaṃsānaṃ🔽vatthu cāti puññakiriyavatthu. Itaresupi dvīsu eseva nayo. Atthato pana pubbe vuttadānamayacetanādivaseneva
analyzed: puñña kiriya vatthūsu dānam eva dāna mayam puñña kiriyā ca sā tesam tesam ānisaṃsānaṃ  vatthu ca ati puñña kiriya vatthu itaresu pi dvīsu esa iva nayaḥ atthataḥ pana pubbe vutta dāna maya cetanā ādi vasena iva
translated: And it is a “base for spiritual power” because it is a basis for the spiritual powers of the various kinds of supernormal power, etc.,🔽and because it is a basis for the special qualities of the fruits of the life of purity.🔽The other two should be understood in the same way. But in meaning, these three bases for spiritual power should be understood as the volition of giving, etc.,

original: saddhiṃ pubbabhāgaaparabhāgacetanāhi imāni tīṇi puññakiriyavatthūni veditabbāni.
analyzed: saddhim pubbabhāga aparabhāga cetanāhi imāni tīṇi puñña kiriya vatthūni veditabbāni
translated: together with the volition of the prior and subsequent periods, as in the case of the “having giving as its essence” already mentioned.

original: Ekamekañcettha pubbabhāgato paṭṭhāya kāyena karontassa kāyakammaṃ hoti. Tadatthaṃ
analyzed: ekam ekam ca ittha pubbabhāgataḥ paṭṭhāya kāyena karontassa kāya kammam hoti tad attham
translated: Herein, when one who is doing the action of giving, etc., does it with his body, it is bodily action.

original: vācaṃ nicchārentassa vacīkammaṃ. Kāyaṅgavācaṅgaṃ acopetvā manasā cintentassa manokammaṃ.
analyzed: vācam nicchārentassa vacī kammam kāyaṅga vācaṅgam a copetvā manasā cintentassa manaḥ kammam
translated: When he is speaking, it is bodily action. When he is thinking, it is mental action.

original: Annādīni dentassa cāpi annadānādīni demīti vā dānapāramiṃ āvajjetvā vā dānakāle dānamayaṃ
analyzed: anna ādīni dentassa ca api anna dāna ādīni demi iti vā dāna pāramim āvajjetvā vā dāna kāle dāna mayam
translated: When he is giving food, etc., it is a basis for the profitable consisting in giving at the moment of giving, either by his thinking, “I am giving food, etc.,” or by his arousing the perfection of giving.

original: puññakiriyavatthu hoti. Vattasīse ṭhatvā dadato sīlamayaṃ. Khayato vayato sammasanaṃ
analyzed: puñña kiriya vatthu hoti vatta sīse ṭhatvā dadataḥ sīla mayam khayataḥ vayataḥ sammasanam
translated: When he is giving while standing in the posture of virtue, it is a basis for the profitable consisting in virtue.

original: paṭṭhapetvā dadato bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu hoti.
analyzed: paṭṭhapetvā dadataḥ bhāvanā mayam puñña kiriya vatthu hoti
translated: When he is giving after arousing insight into fall and change, it is a basis for the profitable consisting in development.

original: Aparānipi satta puññakiriyavatthūni apacitisahagataṃ puññakiriyavatthu, veyyāvaccasahagataṃ,🔽pattānuppadānaṃ, pattabbhanumodanaṃ, desanāmayaṃ, savanamayaṃ, diṭṭhijugataṃ puññakiriyavatthūti.🔽Tattha mahallakaṃ disvā paccuggamanapattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaabhivādanamaggasampadānādivasena
analyzed: aparāni pi satta puñña kiriya vatthūni apaciti sahagatam puñña kiriya vatthu veyyāvacca sahagatam  patta anuppadānam pattabbhanumodanam desanā mayam savana mayam diṭṭhi jugatam puñña kiriya vatthu iti  tattha mahallakam disvā paccuggamana patta cīvara paṭiggahaṇa abhivādana magga sampadāna ādi vasena
translated: There are also seven other kinds of bases for the profitable consisting in giving: the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by appreciation, the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by service,🔽the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by the acquisition of what has not been acquired, the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by the storing up of what has been acquired, the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by teaching, the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by hearing, the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by view.🔽Herein, the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by appreciation should be understood as the giving of requisites to seniors by going to meet them, accepting them with outstretched neck, with outstretched hands, with a bright face, with uplifted eyes, with the words “Welcome, venerable sir,” and by arranging their seats, etc.;

original: apacitisahagataṃ veditabbaṃ. Vuḍḍhatarānaṃ vattappaṭipattikaraṇavasena, gāmaṃ piṇḍāya
analyzed: apaciti sahagatam veditabbam vuḍḍhatarānam vatta paṭipatti karaṇa vasena gāmam piṇḍāya
translated: the base for the profitable consisting in giving accompanied by service should be understood as the giving of requisites to those more distinguished than oneself by one who has risen at the appropriate time, who has removed the seat, who has removed the rubbish, who has sprinkled and swept the accommodation for the Community of Bhikkhus, who has filled the oil tube, who has set out water for drinking and water for washing, who has set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and a foot stand, who has set out a resting plank, who has lit the oil lamp, and who has arranged the seat, etc.;

original: paviṭṭhaṃ bhikkhuṃ disvā pattaṃ gahetvā gāme bhikkhaṃ samādapetvā upasaṃharaṇavasena,
analyzed: paviṭṭham bhikkhum disvā pattam gahetvā gāme bhikkham samādapetvā upasaṃharaṇa vasena
translated: When he sees a monk who has entered the village, he should know it as giving almsfood by taking the bowl and sending him back to the monastery after getting almsfood in the village.

original: “gaccha bhikkhūnaṃ pattaṃ āharā”ti sutvā vegena gantvā pattāharaṇādivasena ca veyyāvaccasahagataṃ
analyzed: gaccha bhikkhūnam pattam āharāti sutvā vegena gantvā patta āharaṇa ādi vasena ca veyyāvacca sahagatam
translated: When he hears the words “Go and bring back the bowls of the monks,” he should know it as giving service by going quickly and bringing back the bowls.

original: veditabbaṃ. Cattāro paccaye datvā sabbasattānaṃ patti hotūti pavattanavasena pattānuppadānaṃ
analyzed: veditabbam cattāraḥ paccaye da tvā sabba sattānam patti hotu iti pavattana vasena patta anuppadānam
translated: When he gives the four requisites, he should know it as giving a bowl by thinking, “May it be the cause of the attainment of all beings.”

original: veditabbaṃ. Parehi dinnāya pattiyā sādhu suṭṭhūti anumodanāvasena pattabbhanumodanaṃ🔽veditabbaṃ. Eko “evaṃ maṃ ‘dhammakathiko’ti jānissantī”ti icchāya ṭhatvā lābhagaruko🔽hutvā deseti, taṃ na mahapphalaṃ. Eko attano paguṇadhammaṃ apaccāsīsamāno paresaṃ🔽deseti, idaṃ desanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu nāma. Eko suṇanto “iti maṃ ‘saddho’ti
analyzed: veditabbam parehi dinnāya pattiyā sādhu suṭṭhu iti anumodanā vasena pattabba anumodanam  veditabbam ekaḥ evam mama dhamma kathikaḥ iti jānissanti iti icchāya ṭhatvā lābha garukaḥ  hutvā deseti tam na mahapphalam ekaḥ attanaḥ paguṇa dhammam a paccāsīsamāno paresam  deseti idam desanā mayam puñña kiriya vatthu nāma ekaḥ suṇantaḥ iti mama saddho ti
translated: When he rejoices in the bowl given by others, thinking, “It is good, it is excellent,” he should know it as rejoicing in the bowl.🔽One who teaches the Dhamma out of a desire for gain, thinking, “Thus they will know me as a preacher of the Dhamma,” does not reap great fruit. But one who teaches the Dhamma to others without seeking his own gain, thinking, “Thus my own well-learned Dhamma will not be lost to the world,” does reap great fruit. This is called the basis for the accumulation of merit consisting in the sharing of the Dhamma.

original: jānissantī”ti suṇāti, taṃ na mahapphalaṃ. Eko “evaṃ me mahapphalaṃ bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: jānissanti iti suṇāti tam na mahapphalam ekaḥ evam me mahapphalam bhavissati iti
translated: One who listens to the Dhamma, thinking, “Thus they will know me as a person of faith,” does not reap great fruit. But one who listens to the Dhamma, thinking, “Thus my Dhamma will be well learned,” does reap great fruit. This is called the basis for the accumulation of merit consisting in the sharing of the Dhamma.

original: hitappharaṇena muducittena dhammaṃ suṇāti, idaṃ savanamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu. Diṭṭhijugataṃ
analyzed: hita ppharaṇena mudu cittena dhammam suṇāti idam savana mayam puñña kiriya vatthu diṭṭhi jugatam
translated: he listens to the Dhamma with a mind of loving-kindness, which is the basis for merit consisting in giving and in virtuous behaviour.

original: pana sabbesaṃ niyamalakkhaṇaṃ. Yaṃkiñci puññaṃ karontassa hi diṭṭhiyā ujubhāveneva mahapphalaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pana sabbesam niyama lakkhaṇam yaṃ kiñci puññam karontassa hi diṭṭhiyā uju bhāvena iva mahapphalam hoti
translated: But the right view of all is the characteristic of restraint. For whatever merit one does with a right view is of great fruit.

original: Iti imesaṃ sattannaṃ puññakiriyavatthūnaṃ purimeheva tīhi saṅgaho veditabbo. Ettha
analyzed: iti imesam sattannam puñña kiriya vatthūnam purimehi iva tīhi saṅgahaḥ veditabbaḥ ettha
translated: So of these seven bases for the making of merit, the first three should be understood as included in the basis consisting in giving,🔽the giving of requisites, the giving of the material for the rains-period observance, and the giving of the material for the invitation ceremony.🔽The giving of a dwelling, the giving of a light, and the giving of medicine are included in the basis consisting in virtuous behaviour.🔽The giving of a resting place is included in the basis consisting in meditation.🔽The giving of a dwelling and the giving of a light are included in the basis consisting in meditation.🔽The giving of medicine is included in the basis consisting in virtue and in the basis consisting in meditation.

original: hi apacitiveyyāvaccāni sīlamaye. Pattidānapattabbhanumodanāni dānamaye. Desanāsavanāni
analyzed: hi apaciti veyyāvaccāni sīla maye patti dāna pattabbha anumodanāni dāna maye desanā savanāni
translated: The giving of requisites, the giving of the material for the rains-period observance, and the giving of the material for the invitation ceremony are included in the basis consisting in virtue and in the basis consisting in meditation.

original: bhāvanāmaye. Diṭṭhijugataṃ tīsupi saṅgahaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: bhāvanā āmaye diṭṭhi ju gatam tīsupi saṅgaham gacchati
translated: The giving of a resting place is included in the three.

original: Codanāvatthūnīti codanākāraṇāni. Diṭṭhenāti maṃsacakkhunā vā dibbacakkhunā vā vītikkamaṃ🔽disvā codeti. Sutenāti pakatisotena vā dibbasotena vā parassa saddaṃ sutvā codeti.
analyzed: codanā vatthūni iti codanā kāraṇāni diṭṭhena ati maṃsa cakkhunā vā dibba cakkhunā vā vītikkamam  disvā codeti sutena ati pakati sotena vā dibba sotena vā parassa saddam sutvā codeti
translated: The grounds for accusation are the reasons for accusation.🔽“On seeing”: he accuses after seeing an offence with the fleshly eye or with the divine eye.🔽“On hearing”: he accuses after hearing another’s voice with the normal ear or with the divine ear.

original: Parisaṅkāya vāti diṭṭhaparisaṅkitena vā sutaparisaṅkitena vā mutaparisaṅkitena vā
analyzed: parisaṅkāya vā ati diṭṭha parisaṅkitena vā suta parisaṅkitena vā muta parisaṅkitena vā
translated: “On suspicion”: through suspicion aroused by what has been seen, or through suspicion aroused by what has been heard, or through suspicion aroused by what has been sensed,

original: codeti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana samantapāsādikāyaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: codeti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana samantapāsādikāyam vutta nayena iva veditabbo
translated: This is the brief account here; but the detailed account should be understood as given in the Samantapāsādikā.

original: Kāmūpapattiyoti kāmūpasevanā kāmappaṭilābhā vā. Paccupaṭṭhitakāmāti nibaddhakāmā
analyzed: kāma upapattiyaḥ ti kāma upasevanā kāma ppaṭilābhā vā paccupaṭṭhita kāmā ati nibaddha kāmā
translated: “In the sense-desire realm” means in the sense-desire-object realm or in the sense-desire-gain realm. “With sense desires present” means with fixed sense desires, with fixed objects.

original: nibaddhārammaṇā. Seyyathāpi manussāti yathā manussā. Manussā hi nibaddheyeva vatthusmiṃ
analyzed: nibaddha ārammaṇā sā iyyathā api manussā ati yathā manussāḥ manussāḥ hi vatthusmiṃ
translated: Just as human beings: just as human beings. For human beings live in fixed places,

original: vasaṃ vattenti. Yattha paṭibaddhacittā honti, satampi sahassampi datvā mātugāmaṃ
analyzed: vasam vattenti yattha paṭibaddha cittāḥ honti satam pi sahassam pi da tvā mātugāmam
translated: where their minds are fixed. Having bought a woman for a thousand coins, they enjoy her as their fixed property.

original: ānetvā nibaddhabhogaṃ bhuñjanti. Ekacce devā nāma catudevalokavāsino. Tepi nibaddhavatthusmiṃyeva🔽vasaṃ vattenti. Ekacce vinipātikā nāma nerayike ṭhapetvā avasesā macchakacchapādayopi
analyzed: ānetvā nibaddha bhogam bhuñjanti ekacce devāḥ nāma catu deva loka vāsinaḥ te pi  vasam vattenti ekacce vinipātikāḥ nāma nerayike ṭhapetvā avasesāḥ maccha kacchapa ādayaḥ pi
translated: Some gods live in fixed places, too. Those who live in the four divine worlds, they also live in fixed places.

original: hi nibaddhavatthusmiṃyeva vasaṃ vattenti. Maccho attano macchiyā kacchapo kacchapiyāti.
analyzed: hi nibaddha vatthusmiṃyā iva vasam vattenti macchaḥ attanaḥ macchiyā kacchapaḥ kacchapiyā iti
translated: Some animals, too, live in fixed places, except for the animals in the hells. Fish live with their own fish, turtles with their own turtles.

original: Nimminitvā nimminitvāti nīlapītādivasena yādisaṃ yādisaṃ attano rūpaṃ icchanti, tādisaṃ
analyzed: nimminitvā nimminitvā iti nīla pīta ādi vasena yādisam yādisam attanaḥ rūpam icchanti tādisam
translated: Having created and created: having created and created whatever kind of form they want, blue, yellow, etc.

original: tādisaṃ nimminitvā āyasmato anuruddhassa purato manāpakāyikā devatā viya. Nimmānaratīti🔽evaṃ sayaṃ nimmite nimmite nimmāne rati etesanti nimmānaratī. Paranimmitakāmāti parehi🔽nimmitakāmā. Tesañhi manaṃ ñatvā pare yathārucitaṃ kāmabhogaṃ nimminanti, te tattha🔽vasaṃ vattenti. Kathaṃ parassa manaṃ jānantīti? Pakatisevanavasena. Yathā hi kusalo
analyzed: tādisam nimminitvā āyasmataḥ anuruddhassa puratas manāpa kāyikā devatā viya  evam sayam nimmite nimmite nimmāne rati nimmāna ratī para nimmita kāmā ati parehi  nimmita kāmā tesam hi manaḥ ñatvā pare yathārucitam kāma bhogam nimminanti te tattha  vasam vattenti katham parassa manam jānanti iti pakati sevana vasena yathā hi kusalaḥ
translated: and having created it, it stood in front of the venerable Anuruddha like a mind-made visible form. The gods called Nimmānaratī are those who delight in their own creations. The gods called Paranimmitavasavattī are those who delight in the creations of others.🔽For others, having understood their minds, create for them the enjoyment of the kinds of sense desires they like, and they live there in control of that.🔽How do they know the minds of others? By attending to the signs. For just as a skilled

original: sūdo rañño bhuñjantassa yaṃ yaṃ so bahuṃ gaṇhāti, taṃ taṃ tassa ruccatīti jānāti,🔽evaṃ pakatiyā abhirucitārammaṇaṃ ñatvā tādisakaṃyeva nimminanti. Te tattha vasaṃ🔽vattenti, methunaṃ sevanti. Keci pana therā “hasitamattena olokitamattena āliṅgitamattena
analyzed: sūdaḥ raññaḥ bhuñjantassa yam yam saḥ bahum gaṇhāti tam tam tassa ruccati iti jānāti  evam pakatiyā abhirucita ārammaṇam ñatvā nimminanti te tattha vasam  vattenti methunam sevanti keci pana therāḥ hasita mattena olokita mattena āliṅgita mattena
translated: and he created them like the mind-made maidens of the Thirty-three Gods in the presence of the venerable Anuruddha. The gods called Nimmānaratī are so called because they delight in creating their own pleasures. The gods called Paranimmitavasavattī are so called because they have power over the creations of others. For the latter, having known the thoughts of the former, create for them the enjoyment of pleasures as they desire, and they live on that. How do they know the thoughts of others? By attending to their nature. For just as a skilled cook knows that whatever the king eats a lot of, it must be to his liking,

original: ca tesaṃ kāmakiccaṃ ijjhatī”ti vadanti, taṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “etaṃ pana natthī”ti paṭikkhittaṃ.
analyzed: ca tesam kāma kiccam ijjhati iti vadanti tam aṭṭhakathāyam etam pana natthi iti paṭikkhittam
translated: so they know the object that is normally most agreeable to them and they create that. They live on that and indulge in sexual intercourse. But some elders say that their sexual intercourse succeeds by just laughing, by just looking, by just embracing. This is rejected in the commentary as follows: “This is not so.”

original: Na hi kāyena aphusantassa phoṭṭhabbaṃ kāmakiccaṃ sādheti. Channampi hi kāmāvacarānaṃ
analyzed: na hi kāyena a phusantassa phoṭṭhabbam kāma kiccam sādheti channam pi hi
translated: Are all fulfilled for them.

original: kāmā pākatikā eva. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: kāmāḥ pākatikāḥ eva
translated: And this is said:🔽“These six kinds of sense desires,

original: “Cha ete kāmāvacarā, sabbakāmasamiddhino;
analyzed: cha ete kāma avacarā sabba kāma samiddhino
translated: All fulfilled, are his:🔽How long is his life span,

original: Sabbesaṃ ekasaṅkhātaṃ, āyu bhavati kittaka”nti. ;
analyzed: sabbesam eka saṅkhātam āyu bhavati kittakanti
translated: Who has but a single thought?”

original: Sukhūpapattiyoti sukhappaṭilābhā. Uppādetvā uppādetvā sukhaṃ viharantīti te heṭṭhā🔽paṭhamajjhānasukhaṃ nibbattetvā upari vipākajjhānasukhaṃ anubhavantīti attho. Sukhena
analyzed: sukha upapattiyaḥ ti sukha paṭilābhāḥ uppādetvā uppādetvā sukham viharanti iti te heṭṭhā  paṭhama jhāna sukham nibbattetvā upari vipāka jhāna sukham anubhavanti iti atthaḥ sukhena
translated: “Happy rebirth” is the obtaining of happiness. The meaning is that they live happily by generating and generating the happiness of the fine-material-sphere resultant jhāna after generating the happiness of the first jhāna.

original: abhisannāti dutiyajjhānasukhena tintā. Parisannāti samantato tintā. Paripūrāti paripuṇṇā.
analyzed: abhisannā ati dutiya jhāna sukhena tintā parisannā ati samantataḥ tintā paripūrā ati paripuṇṇā
translated: “Steeped in happiness” means steeped in the happiness of the second jhāna. “Surrounded by happiness” means surrounded on all sides by it. “Filled with happiness” means full of it.

original: Paripphuṭāti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Idampi vipākajjhānasukhameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ahosukhaṃ🔽ahosukhanti tesaṃ kira bhavalobho mahā uppajjati. Tasmā kadāci karahaci evaṃ udānaṃ
analyzed: paripphuṭā ti tassa iva vevacanam idam pi vipāka jhāna sukham eva sandhāya vuttam aho sukham 🔽tesam kira bhava lobhaḥ mahā uppajjati tasmai kadāci karahaci evam udānam
translated: “Perfumed by happiness” is a synonym for that. This too is said of the happiness of the fine-material-sphere resultant jhāna.🔽“The happiness of the past” is the happiness of the past existence. “The happiness of the future” is the happiness of the future existence. “The happiness of the present” is the happiness of the present existence. “The happiness of non-becoming” is the happiness of non-becoming in the future. “The happiness of becoming” is the happiness of becoming in the future. “The happiness of the past, the happiness of the future, the happiness of the present” is the happiness of the three existences. “The happiness of non-becoming, the happiness of becoming” is the happiness of the two kinds of becoming. “The happiness of the past, the happiness of the future, the happiness of the present, the happiness of non-becoming, the happiness of becoming” is the happiness of the five kinds of becoming. “The happiness of the past, the happiness of the future, the happiness of the present, the happiness of non-becoming, the happiness of becoming, the happiness of the past, the happiness of the future, the happiness of the present, the happiness of non-becoming, the happiness of becoming” is the happiness of the ten kinds of becoming. “The happiness of the past, the happiness of the future, the happiness of the present, the happiness of non-becoming, the happiness of becoming, the happiness of the past, the happiness of the future, the happiness of the present, the happiness of non-becoming, the happiness of becoming” is the happiness of the ten kinds of becoming. “The happiness

original: udānenti. Santamevāti paṇītameva. Tusitāti tato uttariṃ sukhassa apatthanato santuṭṭhā
analyzed: udānenti santam eva ati paṇītam eva tusita ati tatas uttarim sukhassa a patthanataḥ santuṭṭhāḥ
translated: They proclaim it. Tranquil: excellent. Content: satisfied with the bliss of the third jhāna, having made it their goal.

original: hutvā. Sukhaṃ paṭivedentīti tatiyajjhānasukhaṃ anubhavanti.
analyzed: hutvā sukham paṭivedenti iti tatiya jhāna sukham anubhavanti
translated: They experience bliss: they experience the bliss of the third jhāna.

original: Sekkhā paññāti satta ariyapaññā. Arahato paññā asekkhā. Avasesā paññā nevasekkhānāsekkhā.
analyzed: sekkhā paññā ati satta ariya paññāḥ arahataḥ paññā asekkhā avasesā paññā nevasekkha anāsekkhā
translated: The seven noble kinds of clear vision are the clear vision of the trainer. The clear vision of the Arahant is the clear vision of the one beyond training. The remaining kinds of clear vision are the clear vision of neither trainer nor one beyond training.

original: Cintāmayādīsu ayaṃ vitthāro – “tattha katamā cintāmayā paññā? Yogavihitesu vā kammāyatanesu
analyzed: cintā maya ādīsu ayam vitthāraḥ tattha katamā cintā mayā paññā yoga vihitesu vā kamma āyatanesu
translated: As regards the kinds of clear vision classed as “due to knowledge,” etc., the following is the detailed explanation. Herein, what is clear vision due to knowledge? In the case of the fields of action that are well prepared,

original: yogavihitesu vā sippāyatanesu yogavihitesu vā vijjāṭṭhānesu kammassakataṃ vā saccānulomikaṃ🔽vā rūpaṃ aniccanti vā…pe… viññāṇaṃ aniccanti vā yaṃ evarūpaṃ anulomikaṃ khantiṃ diṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: yoga vihitesu vā sippāyatanesu yoga vihitesu vā vijjāṭṭhānesu kammassakatam vā sacca ānulomikam  vā rūpam aniccanti vā ape viññāṇam aniccanti vā yam evarūpam anulomikam khantim diṭṭhim
translated: in the case of the fields of craft that are well prepared, in the case of the fields of science that are well prepared, or in the case of the four noble truths,

original: ruciṃ muttiṃ pekkhaṃ dhammanijjhānakkhantiṃ parato asutvā paṭilabhati, ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: rucim muttim pekkham dhamma nijjhāna kkhantim paratas a sutvā paṭilabhati ayam vuccati
translated: the acceptance that is in conformity with the four noble truths, the view, the wish, the freedom by searching, the looking, the patience for the specific nature of dhammas that one obtains without listening to it from another, is called🔽clear vision due to knowledge. Herein, what is clear vision due to hearsay? In the case of the fields of action that are well prepared …

original: cintāmayā paññā. Tattha katamā sutamayā paññā? Yogavihitesu vā kammāyatanesu…pe…
analyzed: cintā mayā paññā tattha katamā suta mayā paññā yoga vihitesu vā
translated: wisdom born of thinking. Herein, what is wisdom born of learning? In the case of the five bases of endeavour…

original: dhammanijjhānakkhantiṃ parato sutvā paṭilabhati, ayaṃ vuccati sutamayā paññā. (Tattha🔽katamā bhāvanāmayā paññā?) Sabbāpi samāpannassa paññā bhāvanāmayā paññā”ti.
analyzed: dhamma nijjhāna kkhantim paratas sutvā paṭilabhati ayam vuccati suta mayā paññā tattha  katamā bhāvanā mayā paññā sabbā api samāpannassa paññā bhāvanā mayā paññā ti
translated: Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.

original: Sutāvudhanti sutameva āvudhaṃ. Taṃ atthato tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ. Tañhi nissāya🔽bhikkhu paññāvudhaṃ nissāya sūro yodho avikampamāno mahākantāraṃ viya saṃsārakantāraṃ
analyzed: sutāvudham ti sutam eva āvudham tam atthataḥ tepiṭakam buddha vacanam tam hi nissāya  bhikkhu paññāvudham nissāya sūraḥ yodhaḥ a vikampamānaḥ mahā kantāram viya saṃsāra kantāram
translated: Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.

original: atikkamati avihaññamāno. Teneva vuttaṃ – “sutāvudho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako akusalaṃ🔽pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhamattānaṃ pariharatī”ti.
analyzed: atikkamati a vihaññamānaḥ tena iva vuttam sutāvudhaḥ bhikkhave ariyasāvakaḥ akusalam  pajahati kusalam bhāveti sāvajjam pajahati anavajjam bhāveti suddha mattānam pariharati iti
translated: Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.

original: Pavivekāvudhanti “kāyaviveko cittaviveko upadhiviveko”ti ayaṃ tividhopi vivekova🔽āvudhaṃ. Tassa nānākaraṇaṃ kāyaviveko vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ nekkhammābhiratānaṃ. Cittaviveko
analyzed: kāya viveko citta viveko upadhi viveko ti ayam tividhaḥ api 🔽tassa nānākaraṇam kāya vivekaḥ viveka ṭṭhakāyānam nekkhamma abhiratānam citta vivekaḥ

This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.🔽Understanding that comes from what is pondered is when one obtains acquiescence in the Dhamma by pondering it oneself. This is called understanding that comes from what is pondered.

original: ca parisuddhacittānaṃ paramavodānappattānaṃ. Upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ.
analyzed: ca parisuddha cittānam parama vodāna pattānam upadhi viveko ca nirupadhīnam puggalānam
translated: and the seclusion of those whose minds are purified and who have reached the acme of purity, and the seclusion of those persons who are without clinging.

original: Imasmiñhi tividhe viveke abhirato, na kutoci bhāyati. Tasmā ayampi avassayaṭṭhena🔽āvudhanti vutto. Lokiyalokuttarapaññāva āvudhaṃ paññāvudhaṃ. Yassa sā atthi, so na
analyzed: imasmin hi tividhe viveke abhirataḥ na kutocid bhāyati tasmai ayam pi  āvudhanti vuttaḥ lokiya lokuttara paññāvaḥ āvudham paññāvudham yassa sā atthi saḥ na
translated: For one who delights in these three kinds of seclusion is not afraid of anything. That is why this is called a weapon too in the sense of reliance.

original: kutoci bhāyati, na cassa koci bhāyati. Tasmā sāpi avassayaṭṭheneva āvudhanti vuttā.🔽Anaññātaññassāmītindriyanti ito pubbe anaññātaṃ aviditaṃ dhammaṃ jānissāmīti paṭipannassa
analyzed: kutoci bhāyati na ca assa koci bhāyati tasmā sā api avassaya ṭṭhena iva āvudhanti vuttā  anaññāta ñassāmi iti indriyan ti itas pubbe anaññātam aviditam dhammam jānissāmi iti paṭipannassa
translated: Wisdom is a weapon in the sense of a worldly and a supramundane weapon. He who has it is not afraid of anything, and nothing is afraid of him. That is why this is called a weapon too in the sense of reliance.🔽The “I-shall-come-to-know-the-unknown” faculty: the faculty that has arisen in one who has entered upon the way to know a state that was previously unknown and un- known to him. This is a term for the knowledge of the path of stream-entry.

original: uppannaṃ indriyaṃ. Sotāpattimaggañāṇassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Aññindriyanti aññābhūtaṃ
analyzed: uppannam indriyam sotāpatti magga ñāṇassa etam adhivacanam aññindriyam ti aññābhūtam
translated: The “knowing” faculty: the faculty that is the state of knowing that is not unknown,

original: ājānanabhūtaṃ indriyaṃ. Sotāpattiphalato paṭṭhāya chasu ṭhānesu ñāṇassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: ājānana bhūtam indriyam sotāpatti phalataḥ paṭṭhāya chasu ṭhānesu ñāṇassa etam adhivacanaṃ
translated: that is the state of knowing that has become known. This is a term for the knowledge in the six spheres beginning with the fruit of stream-entry.

original: Aññātāvindriyanti aññātāvīsu jānanakiccapariyosānappattesu dhammesu indriyaṃ. Arahattaphalañāṇassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: aññātāvindriyanti aññātāvīsu jānana kicca pariyosāna ppattesu dhammesu indriyam arahatta phala ñāṇassa etam adhivacanaṃ
translated: The faculty of final knowledge is the faculty in the states that have reached the end of their function as the knower of what is as yet unknown. It is a term for the knowledge of the fruit of arahantship.

original: Maṃsacakkhu cakkhupasādo. Dibbacakkhu ālokanissitaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Paññācakkhu lokiyalokuttarapaññā.
analyzed: maṃsa cakkhu cakkhu pasādaḥ dibba cakkhu āloka nissitam ñāṇam paññā cakkhu lokiya lokuttara paññā
translated: The fleshly eye is the eye faculty. The divine eye is knowledge dependent on the base consisting of infinite space. The wisdom eye is mundane and supramundane understanding.

original: Adhisīlasikkhādīsu adhisīlañca taṃ sikkhitabbato sikkhā cāti adhisīlasikkhā. Itarasmiṃ
analyzed: adhi sīla sikkhā ādīsu adhi sīlam ca tam sikkhitabbataḥ sikkhā ca ati adhi sīla sikkhā itarasmin
translated: In the higher training in the higher virtue, etc., it is virtue because it is what should be developed, and it is the training because it is the training in that. In the other two

original: dvayepi eseva nayo. Tattha sīlaṃ adhisīlaṃ, cittaṃ adhicittaṃ, paññā adhipaññāti
analyzed: dvaye pi esa iva nayo tattha sīlam adhisīlam cittam adhicittam paññā adhipaññā ti
translated: the same method applies. Herein, virtue is higher virtue, consciousness is higher consciousness, and understanding is higher understanding.

original: ayaṃ pabhedo veditabbo –
analyzed: ayam pabhedaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: This is the division:

original: Sīlaṃ nāma pañcasīladasasīlāni, pātimokkhasaṃvaro adhisīlaṃ nāma. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo
analyzed: sīlam nāma pañca sīla dasa sīlāni pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ adhisīlam nāma aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ
translated: Virtue is the five training precepts and the ten training precepts. The virtue of the Pāṭimokkha is called “higher virtue.” The eight attainments

original: cittaṃ, vipassanāpādakajjhānaṃ adhicittaṃ. Kammassakatañāṇaṃ paññā, vipassanāpaññā
analyzed: cittam vipassanā pādaka jjhānam adhicittam kammassakata ñāṇam paññā vipassanā paññā
translated: are consciousness. The jhāna that is the basis for insight is higher consciousness. Knowledge of one’s kamma is understanding. Insight understanding is

original: adhipaññā. Anuppannepi hi buddhuppāde pavattatīti pañcasīladasasīlāni sīlameva, pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ
analyzed: adhipaññā an uppanne pi hi buddhuppāde pavattati iti pañca sīla dasa sīlāni sīlam eva pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam
translated: higher understanding. For even when there is no arising of Buddhas, it occurs. The five training precepts and the ten training precepts are simply virtue. The virtue of the Pāṭimokkha is

original: buddhuppādeyeva pavattatīti adhisīlaṃ. Cittapaññāsupi eseva nayo. Apica nibbānaṃ
analyzed: buddhuppādeya iva pavattati iti adhisīlam citta paññāsu pi esa iva nayaḥ apica nibbānam
translated: It occurs only at the arising of a Buddha, thus it is “supreme virtue.” The same method applies in the case of “supreme consciousness” and “supreme understanding.”

original: patthayantena samādinnaṃ pañcasīlampi dasasīlampi adhisīlameva. Samāpannā aṭṭha samāpattiyopi
analyzed: patthayantena samādinnam pañca sīlam pi dasa sīlam pi adhi sīlam eva samāpannāḥ aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ pi
translated: Moreover, the five precepts and the ten precepts undertaken by one who aspires to Nibbāna are also “supreme virtue.” The eight attainments are “supreme consciousness.”

original: adhicittameva. Sabbaṃ vā lokiyaṃ sīlameva, lokuttaraṃ adhisīlaṃ. Cittapaññāsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: adhicittam eva sabbam vā lokiyam sīlam eva lokuttaram adhisīlam citta paññāsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: Or all mundane virtue is “supreme virtue,” and supramundine virtue is “supreme virtue.” The same method applies in the case of “supreme consciousness” and “supreme understanding.”

original: Bhāvanāsu khīṇāsavassa pañcadvārikakāyo kāyabhāvanā nāma. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo cittabhāvanā🔽nāma. Arahattaphalapaññā paññābhāvanā nāma. Khīṇāsavassa hi ekanteneva pañcadvārikakāyo🔽subhāvito hoti. Aṭṭha samāpattiyo cassa na aññesaṃ viya dubbalā, tasseva ca paññā
analyzed: bhāvanāsu khīṇāsavassa pañcadvārika kāyo kāya bhāvanā nāma aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ citta bhāvanā  nāma arahatta phala paññā paññā bhāvanā nāma khīṇāsavassa hi ekantena iva pañcadvārika kāyo  su bhāvito hoti aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ cassa na aññesam viya dubbalā tassa iva ca paññā
translated: As to the meditations: the five-door body of one whose cankers are destroyed is called “meditation on the body.” The eight attainments are called “meditation on consciousness.”

original: bhāvitā nāma hoti paññāvepullapattiyā. Tasmā evaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvitā nāma hoti paññā vepulla pattiyā tasmai evam vuttam
translated: The understanding that is the fruit of arahantship is called “meditation on understanding.” For the body of one whose cankers are destroyed is well developed in the five doors. And his eight attainments are not weak like those of others, and his understanding is called “developed understanding” because it has reached the culmination of understanding. That is why it is said thus.

original: Anuttariyesu vipassanā dassanānuttariyaṃ maggo paṭipadānussariyaṃ. Phalaṃ vimuttānuttariyaṃ.
analyzed: anuttariyesu vipassanā dassanā anuttariyam maggo paṭipadā anussariyam phalam vimutta anuttariyam
translated: As to the unsurpassed things: insight is the unsurpassed seeing; the path is the unsurpassed undertaking; the fruit is the unsurpassed deliverance.

original: Phalaṃ vā dassanānuttariyaṃ. Maggo paṭipadānuttariyaṃ. Nibbānaṃ vimuttānuttariyaṃ.
analyzed: phalam vā dassana anuttariyam maggo paṭipadā anuttariyam nibbānam vimutta anuttariyam
translated: Or else the fruit is the unsurpassed seeing, the path is the unsurpassed way, and Nibbāna is the unsurpassed outlet.

original: Nibbānaṃ vā dassanānuttariyaṃ, tato uttariñhi daṭṭhabbaṃ nāma natthi. Maggo paṭipadānuttariyaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam vā dassana anuttariyam tatas uttarin hi daṭṭhabbam nāma natthi maggo paṭipada anuttariyam
translated: Or else Nibbāna is the unsurpassed seeing, for there is nothing further to be seen beyond it. The path is the unsurpassed way.

original: Phalaṃ vimuttānuttariyaṃ. Anuttariyanti uttamaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ.
analyzed: phalam vimutta anuttariyam anuttariyanti uttamam jeṭṭhakam
translated: The fruit is the unsurpassed outlet. Anuttara means supreme, best.

original: Samādhīsu paṭhamajjhānasamādhi savitakkasavicāro. Pañcakanayena dutiyajjhānasamādhi avitakkavicāramatto. Seso avitakkaavicāro.
analyzed: samādhīsu paṭhama jhāna samādhi sa vitakka sa vicāraḥ pañcaka nayena dutiya jhāna samādhi a vitakka vicāra matto sesaḥ a vitakka avicāraḥ
translated: As regards the jhānas, the first-jhāna concentration is accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought. By the fivefold reckoning the second-jhāna concentration is accompanied by sustained thought only, and the rest are without applied thought and sustained thought.

original: Suññatādīsu tividhā kathā āgamanato, saguṇato, ārammaṇatoti. Āgamanato nāma eko bhikkhu🔽anattato abhinivisitvā anattato disvā anattato vuṭṭhāti, tassa vipassanā suññatā
analyzed: suññatā ādīsu tividhā kathā āgamanataḥ saguṇataḥ ārammaṇato ti āgamanataḥ nāma ekaḥ bhikkhu  anattataḥ abhinivisitvā anattataḥ disvā anattataḥ vuṭṭhāti tassa vipassanā suññatā
translated: As regards the void, etc., the threefold teaching is according to the mode of entry, according to the special quality, and according to the object. As regards the mode of entry, there is a bhikkhu

original: nāma hoti. Kasmā? Asuññatattakārakānaṃ kilesānaṃ abhāvā. Vipassanāgamanena maggasamādhi
analyzed: nāma hoti kasmai asuñña tatta kārakānam kilesānam abhāvā vipassanā gamanena magga samādhi
translated: who, having resolved upon non-self, sees by way of non-self, and emerges by way of non-self. His insight is called void. Why? Because of the absence of defilements that cause the non-void. The concentration of the path that has arisen by the mode of entry of insight is called void concentration.

original: suññato nāma hoti. Maggāgamanena phalasamādhi suññato nāma. Aparo aniccato abhinivisitvā
analyzed: suññataḥ nāma hoti magga āgamanena phala samādhi suññataḥ nāma aparaḥ aniccataḥ abhinivisitvā
translated: and the concentration of fruition reached by the path is called “empty.”🔽Another, after determining ugliness,

original: aniccato disvā aniccato vuṭṭhāti. Tassa vipassanā animittā nāma hoti. Kasmā? Nimittakārakakilesābhāvā.
analyzed: aniccataḥ disvā aniccataḥ vuṭṭhāti tassa vipassanā animittā nāma hoti kasmā nimitta kāraka kilesa abhāvā
translated: seeing ugliness, emerges from ugliness. His insight is called “signless.” Why? Because of the absence of defilements that make signs.

original: Vipassanāgamanena maggasamādhi animitto nāma hoti. Maggāgamanena phalaṃ animittaṃ🔽nāma. Aparo dukkhato abhinivisitvā dukkhato disvā dukkhato vuṭṭhāti, tassa vipassanā
analyzed: vipassanā āgamanena magga samādhi animittaḥ nāma hoti magga āgamanena phalam animittam  nāma aparaḥ dukkhataḥ abhinivisitvā dukkhataḥ disvā dukkhataḥ vuṭṭhāti tassa vipassanā
translated: And the concentration of the path reached by insight is called “signless.” And the fruition reached by the path is called “signless.”🔽Another, after determining painfulness,

original: appaṇihitā nāma hoti. Kasmā? Paṇidhikārakakilesābhāvā. Vipassanāgamanena maggasamādhi
analyzed: appaṇihitā nāma hoti kasmā paṇidhi kāraka kilesa abhāvā vipassanā gamanena magga samādhi
translated: seeing painfulness, emerges from painfulness. His insight is called “desireless.” Why? Because of the absence of defilements that make desires. And the concentration of the path reached by insight is called “desireless.”

original: appaṇihito nāma. Maggāgamanena phalaṃ appaṇihitaṃ nāmāti ayaṃ āgamanato kathā. Maggasamādhi
analyzed: appaṇihitaḥ nāma magga āgamanena phalam appaṇihitam nāma ati ayaṃ āgamanataḥ kathā magga samādhi
translated: And the fruition reached by the path is called “desireless.” This is the exposition “as to reaching.”🔽But the concentration of the path is called “empty” because it is empty of greed, etc.,🔽and it is called “signless” because of the absence of the sign of greed, etc.,

original: pana rāgādīhi suññatattā suññato, rāganimittādīnaṃ abhāvā animitto, rāgapaṇidhiādīnaṃ
analyzed: pana rāga ādīhi suññata ttā suññataḥ rāga nimitta ādīnam abhāvāḥ animittaḥ rāga paṇidhi ādīnam
translated: and it is called “desireless” because of the absence of desire for greed, etc.,

original: abhāvā appaṇihitoti ayaṃ saguṇato kathā. Nibbānaṃ rāgādīhi suññatattā rāgādinimittapaṇidhīnañca
analyzed: abhāvā appaṇihito ti ayam sa guṇato kathā nibbānam rāga ādīhi suññata ttā rāga ādi nimitta paṇidhīnam ca
translated: “Signless” because of the absence of the sign of lust, etc., and of the sign of formations, and “void” and “incapable of being defined” because of voidness of lust, etc.

original: abhāvā suññatañceva animittañca appaṇihitañca. Tadārammaṇo maggasamādhi suññato animitto
analyzed: abhāvā suññatañca iva animittañca appaṇihitañca tad ārammaṇaḥ magga samādhi suññataḥ animitto
translated: The concentration of the path that has that Nibbana as its object is “void” and “signless” and “desireless.”

original: appaṇihito. Ayaṃ ārammaṇato kathā.
analyzed: appaṇihitaḥ ayam ārammaṇato kathā
translated: This is how the exposition should be known here “as to distinction.”🔽“Purity”: the states that cause purity are the way of practice that leads to purity. The detail here should be understood as follows. “Herein, what is bodily purity? It is abstinence from killing breathing things” , and so on.

original: Soceyyānīti sucibhāvakarā soceyyappaṭipadā dhammā. Vitthāro panettha “tattha katamaṃ kāyasoceyyaṃ? Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī”tiādinā nayena vuttānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ sucaritānaṃ vasena veditabbo.🔽Moneyyānīti munibhāvakarā moneyyappaṭipadā dhammā. Tesaṃ vitthāro “tattha katamaṃ
analyzed: soceyyāni iti suci bhāva karā soceyya paṭipadāḥ dhammāḥ vitthāraḥ pana ittha tattha katamam kāya soceyyam pāṇātipātāḥ veramaṇī iti ādinā nayena vuttānam tiṇṇam su caritānam vasena veditabbo  moneyyāni iti muni bhāva karāḥ moneyya paṭipadāḥ dhammāḥ tesam vitthāro tattha katamam
translated: “Seclusion”: the states that cause seclusion are the way of practice that leads to seclusion. The detail here should be understood in the way beginning: “Herein, what is bodily seclusion? It is the abandoning of the three kinds of misconduct of the body” ,🔽and so on.

original: kāyamoneyyaṃ? Tividhakāyaduccaritassa pahānaṃ kāyamoneyyaṃ, tividhaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ🔽kāyamoneyyaṃ, kāyārammaṇe ñāṇaṃ kāyamoneyyaṃ, kāyapariññā kāyamoneyyaṃ, kāyapariññāsahagato
analyzed: kāyamoneyyam tividha kāya duccaritassa pahānam kāyamoneyyam tividham kāya su caritam 🔽kāya moneyyam kāya ārammaṇe ñāṇam kāya moneyyam kāya pariññā kāya moneyyam kāya pariññā sahagataḥ
translated: “The state of a sage”: the states that cause the state of a sage are the way of practice that leads to the state of a sage. The detail here should be understood in the way beginning: “Herein, what is bodily sagacity? It is the abandoning of the three kinds of bodily misconduct” ,🔽and so on.

original: maggo kāyamoneyyaṃ, kāyasmiṃ chandarāgappahānaṃ kāyamoneyyaṃ, kāyasaṅkhāranirodhā
analyzed: maggo kāyamoneyyam kāyasmim chanda rāga pahānam kāyamoneyyam kāya saṅkhāra nirodhā
translated: The path is the mind’s mastery. The abandoning of desire and lust in the case of the body is the mind’s mastery. With the cessation of body-determinations

original: catutthajjhānasamāpatti kāyamoneyyaṃ. Tattha katamaṃ vacīmoneyyaṃ? Catubbidhavacīduccaritassa
analyzed: catuttha jhāna samāpatti kāya moneyyam tattha katamam vacī moneyyam catubbidha vacī duccaritassa
translated: the attainment of the fourth jhana is the mind’s mastery. Herein, what is the mastery of speech?

original: pahānaṃ vacīmoneyyaṃ, catubbidhaṃ vacīsucaritaṃ vacīmoneyyaṃ, vācārammaṇe ñāṇaṃ vacīmoneyyaṃ
analyzed: pahānam vacīmoneyyam catubbidham vacī su caritam vacīmoneyyam vācā ārammaṇe ñāṇam vacīmoneyyam
translated: The abandoning of the four kinds of wrong speech is the mastery of speech. The four kinds of right speech are the mastery of speech. Knowledge about the speech object is the mastery of speech.

original: vācāpariññā vacīmoneyyaṃ pariññāsahagato maggo, vācāya chandarāgappahānaṃ, vacīsaṅkhāranirodhā
analyzed: vācā pariññā vacīmoneyyam pariññā sahagataḥ maggaḥ vācāya chanda rāga ppahānam vacī saṅkhāra nirodhā
translated: Full understanding of speech is the mastery of speech. The path that is associated with full understanding is the mastery of speech. The abandoning of desire and lust in the case of speech, the cessation of speech-determinations,

original: dutiyajjhānasamāpatti vacīmoneyyaṃ. Tattha katamaṃ manomoneyyaṃ? Tividhamanoduccaritassa
analyzed: dutiya jhāna samāpatti vacīmoneyyam tattha katamam manomoneyyam tividha manaḥ duccaritassa
translated: the attainment of the second jhana is the mastery of speech. Herein, what is the mastery of the mind?

original: pahānaṃ manomoneyyaṃ, tividhaṃ manosucaritaṃ manomoneyyaṃ, manārammaṇe ñāṇaṃ manomoneyyaṃ,
analyzed: pahānam manomoneyyam tividham manaḥ su caritam manomoneyyam mana ārammaṇe ñāṇam manomoneyyam
translated: The abandoning of the three kinds of wrong mental conduct is the mastery of the mind. The three kinds of right mental conduct are the mastery of the mind. Knowledge about the mind object is the mastery of the mind.

original: manopariññā manomoneyyaṃ. Pariññāsahagato maggo, manasmiṃ chandarāgappahānaṃ, cittasaṅkhāranirodhā
analyzed: manaḥ pariññā manomoneyyam pariññā sahagataḥ maggaḥ manasmim chanda rāga ppahānam citta saṅkhāra nirodhā
translated: Full understanding of the mind is the mastery of the mind. The path that is associated with full understanding is the mastery of the mind. The abandoning of desire and lust in the case of the mind, the cessation of mind-determinations,

original: saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpatti manomoneyya”nti.
analyzed: saññā vedayita nirodha samāpatti
translated: the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling is the mastery of the mind” .

original: Kosallesu āyoti vuḍḍhi. Apāyoti avuḍḍhi. Tassa tassa kāraṇaṃ upāyo. Tesaṃ pajānanā kosallaṃ. Vitthāro pana vibhaṅge vuttoyeva.🔽Vuttañhetaṃ – “tattha katamaṃ āyakosallaṃ? Ime dhamme manasikaroto anuppannā ceva🔽akusalā dhammā nuppajjanti, uppannā ca akusalā dhammā nirujjhanti. Ime vā pana me

When one who is thus concentrated, etc. , unwholesome states are abandoned in him and wholesome states come into being. Or alternatively, unwholesome states that have arisen are abandoned in him and wholesome states that have arisen endure, are not lost, but increase, develop and are brought to fulfilment by development. This is called skill in growth” .
