original: Ime vā pana me dhamme manasikaroto anuppannā ceva akusalā dhammā uppajjanti, uppannā
analyzed: ime vā pana me dhamme manasikarotaḥ anuppannā ca iva akusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjanti uppannā
translated: Or else, when I am giving attention to these ideas, unwholesome ideas arise in me, and the unwholesome ideas that have arisen persist,

original: ca akusalā dhammā bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattantīti, yā
analyzed: ca akusalāḥ dhammāḥ bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā saṃvattanti iti yā
translated: and wholesome ideas that have arisen do not persist, and unwholesome ideas that have arisen increase and grow, then I understand that I shall not attain the unattained, nor realize the unrealized, nor achieve the unachieved, nor see the unseen,🔽and I shall not get rid of this doubt, nor this vacillation, nor this ignorance, nor this uncertainty.🔽I understand thus: ‘I am declining in wholesome mental states’—🔽and I understand thus: ‘I am not declining in unwholesome mental states.’🔽Or else, when I am giving attention to these ideas, unwholesome ideas do not arise in me, and the unwholesome ideas that have arisen are abandoned,🔽and wholesome ideas that have arisen persist, and wholesome ideas that have not arisen arise,🔽and I attain the unattained, realize the unrealized, achieve the unachieved, and see the unseen,🔽and I get rid of this doubt, this vacillation, this ignorance, and this uncertainty.

original: tattha paññā pajānanā…pe… sammādiṭṭhi. Idaṃ vuccati apāyakosallaṃ. Sabbāpi tatrupāyā
analyzed: tattha paññā pajānanā ape sammādiṭṭhi idam vuccati apāya kosallam sabbā api tatrupāyā
translated: I understand thus: ‘I am not declining in wholesome mental states’—🔽and I understand thus: ‘I am declining in unwholesome mental states.’🔽Or else, when I am giving attention to these ideas, unwholesome ideas do not arise in me, and the unwholesome ideas that have arisen are abandoned,

original: paññā upāyakosalla”nti. Idaṃ pana accāyikakicce vā bhaye vā uppanne tassa tikicchanatthaṃ
analyzed: paññā upāya kosallanti idam pana accāyika kicce vā bhaye vā uppanne tassa tikicchana attham
translated: and wholesome ideas that have arisen persist, and wholesome ideas that have not arisen arise,🔽and I attain the unattained, realize the unrealized, achieve the unachieved, and see the unseen,🔽and I get rid of this doubt, this vacillation, this ignorance, and this uncertainty.🔽I understand thus: ‘I am not declining in wholesome mental states’—

original: ṭhānuppattiyā kāraṇajānanavaseneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhāna uppattiyā kāraṇa jānana vasena iva veditabbam
translated: and I understand thus: ‘I am not declining in unwholesome mental states.’🔽Or else, when I am giving attention to these ideas, unwholesome ideas do not arise in me, and the unwholesome ideas that have arisen are abandoned,

original: Madāti majjanākāravasena pavattamānā. Tesu “ahaṃ nirogo saṭṭhi vā sattati vā vassāni
analyzed: madā ti majjana ākāra vasena pavattamānā tesu aham nirogaḥ vā sattati vā vassāni
translated: and wholesome ideas that have arisen persist, and wholesome ideas that have not arisen arise,🔽and I attain the unattained, realize the unrealized, achieve the unachieved, and see the unseen,🔽and I get rid of this doubt, this vacillation, this ignorance, and this uncertainty.🔽I understand thus: ‘I am not declining in wholesome mental states’—

original: atikkantāni, na me harītakīkhaṇḍampi khāditapubbaṃ, ime panaññe asukaṃ nāma ṭhānaṃ🔽rujjati, bhesajjaṃ khādāmāti vicaranti, ko añño mādiso nirogo nāmā”ti evaṃ mānakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: atikkantāni na me harītakī khaṇḍam pi khādita pubbam ime pana aññe asukam nāma ṭhānam 🔽rujjati bhesajjam khādāma ati vicaranti kaḥ aññaḥ mādisaḥ nirogaḥ nāma ati evam māna karaṇam
translated: and I understand thus: ‘I am

original: ārogyamado. “Mahallakakāle puññaṃ karissāma, daharamha tāvā”ti yobbane ṭhatvā mānakaraṇaṃ🔽yobbanamado. “Ciraṃ jīviṃ, ciraṃ jīvāmi, ciraṃ jīvissāmi; sukhaṃ jīviṃ, sukhaṃ jīvāmi,
analyzed: ārogya madaḥ mahallaka kāle puññam karissāma yobbane ṭhatvā māna karaṇam  yobbana madaḥ ciram jīvim ciram jīvāmi ciram jīvissāmi sukham jīvim sukham jīvāmi
translated: The conceit “I shall make merit when I am old; I am still young” is the conceit of youth.

original: sukhaṃ jīvissāmī”ti evaṃ mānakaraṇaṃ jīvitamado.🔽Ādhipateyyesu adhipatito āgataṃ ādhipateyyaṃ. “Ettakomhi sīlena samādhinā paññāya
analyzed: sukham jīvissāmi iti evam māna karaṇam jīvita madaḥ  ādhipateyyesu adhipatitaḥ āgatam ādhipateyyam ettakaḥ umhi sīlena samādhinā paññāya
translated: The conceit “I have lived long; I am living long; I shall live long; I have lived happily; I am living happily; I shall live happily” is the conceit of life.

original: vimuttiyā, na me etaṃ patirūpa”nti evaṃ attānaṃ adhipattiṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ katvā pāpassa🔽akaraṇaṃ attādhipateyyaṃ nāma. Lokaṃ adhipatiṃ katvā akaraṇaṃ lokādhipateyyaṃ nāma.
analyzed: vimuttiyāḥ na me etam patirūpan ti evam attānam adhipattim jeṭṭhakam katvā pāpassa  a karaṇam attā ādhipateyyam nāma lokam adhipatim katvā a karaṇam loka ādhipateyyam nāma
translated: The non-performance of evil because of the thought “I am the master of my own self” is self-mastery.🔽The non-performance of evil because of the thought “I am the master of the world” is world-mastery.

original: Lokuttaradhammaṃ adhipatiṃ katvā akaraṇaṃ dhammādhipateyyaṃ nāma.
analyzed: lokuttara dhammam adhipatim katvā a karaṇam dhamma ādhipateyyam nāma
translated: The non-performance of evil because of the thought “I am the master of the supramundane state” is Dhamma-mastery.🔽The bases of talk are the causes of talk.

original: Kathāvatthūnīti kathākāraṇāni. Atītaṃ vā addhānanti atītaṃ dhammaṃ, atītakkhandheti
analyzed: kathā vatthūni iti kathā kāraṇāni atītam vā addhā ananti atītam dhammam atīta kkhandha iti
translated: The past period is the past state, the past aggregates.

original: attho. Apica “yaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ, ‘ahosī’ti tassa
analyzed: atthaḥ apica yam bhikkhave rūpam atītam niruddham vipariṇatam ahosi iti tassa
translated: And the meaning should be illustrated here by the Sutta on the Path of the Language of Signs, which is stated thus: “Bhikkhus, any materiality whatever, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—this is called the material form category.

original: saṅkhā, ‘ahosī’ti tassa paññatti ‘ahosī’ti tassa samaññā, na tassa saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti,
analyzed: saṅkhā ahosi iti tassa paññatti ahosi iti tassa samaññā na tassa saṅkhā atthi iti
translated: The term ‘was’ is a designation, a description, a conventional expression for that. The term ‘is’ is not a conventional expression for that. The term ‘will be’ is not a conventional expression for that.🔽“Any feeling whatever …🔽Any perception whatever …🔽Any formations whatever …🔽Any consciousness whatever, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—this is called the consciousness category.

original: na tassa saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti evaṃ āgatena niruttipathasuttenapettha attho dīpetabbo.
analyzed: na tassa saṅkhā bhavissati iti evam āgatena nirutti patha suttena pa ittha atthaḥ dīpetabbo
translated: The term ‘was’ is a designation, a description, a conventional expression for that. The term ‘is’ is not a conventional expression for that. The term ‘will be’ is not a conventional expression for that” .

original: Vijjāti tamavijjhanaṭṭhena vijjā. Viditakaraṇaṭṭhenāpi vijjā. Pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇañhi🔽uppajjamānaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ chādetvā ṭhitaṃ tamaṃ vijjhati, pubbenivāsañca viditaṃ🔽karotīti vijjā. Cutūpapātañāṇaṃ cutipaṭisandhicchādakaṃ tamaṃ vijjhati, tañca viditaṃ
analyzed: vijjā ati tama vijjhana ṭṭhena vijjā vidita karaṇa ṭṭhena api vijjā pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇam hi  uppajjamānam pubbenivāsam chādetvā ṭhitam tamam vijjhati pubbenivāsam ca viditam  karoti iti vijjā cutūpapāta ñāṇam cuti paṭisandhi chādakam tamam vijjhati tat ca viditam
translated: “Knowledge” is so called in the sense of illuminating the darkness of the unknown. It is also knowledge in the sense of making known. For the knowledge of the recollection of past lives,

original: karotīti vijjā. Āsavānaṃ khaye ñāṇaṃ catusaccacchādakaṃ tamaṃ vijjhati, catusaccadhammañca🔽viditaṃ karotīti vijjā.
analyzed: karoti iti vijjā āsavānam khaye ñāṇam catur acca chādakam tamam vijjhati catur acca dhammam ca 🔽viditam karoti iti vijjā
translated: when it arises, illuminates the darkness that conceals past existences and makes past existences known, thus it is knowledge. The knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings illuminates the darkness that conceals death and rebirth-linking and makes that known, thus it is knowledge. The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers illuminates the darkness that conceals the four truths and makes the four truths known, thus it is knowledge.

original: Vihāresu aṭṭha samāpattiyo dibbo vihāro. Catasso appamaññā brahmā vihāro. Phalasamāpatti ariyo vihāro.
analyzed: vihāresu aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ dibbaḥ vihāro catasso appamaññāḥ brahmā vihāro phala samāpatti ariyaḥ vihāro
translated: The eight attainments in the monasteries are the divine abiding. The four measureless states are the divine abiding of Brahmā. The attainment of fruition is the noble abiding.

original: Pāṭihāriyāni kevaṭṭasutte vitthāritāneva.
analyzed: pāṭihāriyāni kevaṭṭa sutte
translated: The miracles are given in detail in the Kevatta Sutta.

original: “Ime kho, āvuso”tiādīsu vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti samasaṭṭhiyā tikānaṃ vasena asītisatapañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso ti ādīsu vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti sama saṭṭhiyā tikānam vasena asīti sata pañhe kathentaḥ thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friend,” etc., should be construed in the same way as above. Thus the Elder, in answering the one hundred and eighty questions by means of the thirty sets, showed the concordant meaning.

original: Tikavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tika vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the triads is finished.

original: Catukkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catukka vaṇṇanā
translated: The catukkanipāta

original: 306. Iti tikavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni catukkavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha “satipaṭṭhānacatukkaṃ” pubbe vitthāritameva.
analyzed: iti tika vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni catukka vasena dassetum puna desanam ārabhi tattha sati paṭṭhāna catukkam pubbe vitthāritam eva
translated: Having thus shown the concordant meaning by means of the triads, the Master now began the teaching by means of the catu-kkhas in order to show the concordant meaning by means of the catu-kkhas. Herein, the four foundations of mindfulness have already been given in detail.

original: Sammappadhānacatukke chandaṃ janetīti “yo chando chandikatā kattukamyatā kusalo dhammacchando”ti
analyzed: sammappadhāna catukke chandam janeti iti yaḥ chando chandika tā kattu kamya tā kusalaḥ dhammacchando ti
translated: In the four right efforts, he generates zeal: he generates the desire described thus, “Zeal is eagerness, eagerness for Dhamma, zeal for Dhamma” .

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ kattukamyataṃ janeti. Vāyamatīti vāyāmaṃ karoti. Vīriyaṃ ārabhatīti vīriyaṃ
analyzed: evam vuttam kattukamyatam janeti vāyamati iti vāyāmam karoti vīriyam ārabhati iti vīriyam
translated: He makes effort: he makes exertion. He exerts energy: he exerts the energy described thus, “Energy is persistence, persistence in undertaking” .

original: janeti. Cittaṃ paggaṇhātīti cittaṃ upatthambheti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana
analyzed: janeti cittam paggaṇhāti iti cittam upatthambheti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana
translated: He generates: he causes to arise. He exerts: he steadies. This is the brief account here. The detailed account is given in the Description of the Right Endeavours.

original: sammappadhānavibhaṅge āgatoyeva.🔽Iddhipādesu chandaṃ nissāya pavatto samādhi chandasamādhi. Padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā🔽padhānasaṅkhārā. Samannāgatanti tehi dhammehi upetaṃ. Iddhiyā pādaṃ, iddhibhūtaṃ
analyzed: sammappadhāna vibhaṅge  iddhipādesu chandam nissāya pavattaḥ samādhi chanda samādhi padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā  padhāna saṅkhārā tehi dhammehi upetam iddhiyā pādam iddhi bhūtam
translated: Concentration due to zeal is concentration arisen with zeal as the means.🔽The formations that are the chief thing are the formations of striving.

original: vā pādanti iddhipādaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana iddhipādavibhaṅge
analyzed: vā iddhipādam sesesu pi esā iva nayaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana iddhipāda vibhaṅge
translated: Endowed: provided with. The basis for success, or the success itself, is a basis for success. The same method applies in the other cases. This is the brief account here. The detailed account is given in the Description of the Bases for Success.

original: āgato eva. Visuddhimagge panassa attho dīpito. Jhānakathāpi visuddhimagge vitthāritāva.
analyzed: āgataḥ eva visuddhi magge pana assa atthaḥ dīpitaḥ jhāna kathā api visuddhi magge vitthāritā ava
translated: But its meaning is elucidated in the Visuddhimagga. And the explanation of the jhānas is given in detail in the Visuddhimagga too.🔽For the attainment of vision of knowledge and insight: for the attainment of the vision of knowledge and insight that is clear and has become unified.

original: 307. Diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāyāti imasmiṃyeva attabhāve sukhavihāratthāya. Idha phalasamāpattijhānāni, khīṇāsavassa aparabhāge nibbattitajhānāni ca kathitāni.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārāya ati imasmin yeva atta bhāve sukha vihāra atthāya idha phala samāpatti jhānāni khīṇāsavassa apara bhāge nibbattita jhānāni ca kathitāni
translated: For the attainment of pleasant dwellings here and now: for the attainment of pleasant dwellings in this very life. Herein, the jhāna that is a attainment of fruition and the jhāna that arises in the next existence in one whose cankers are destroyed are intended.

original: Ālokasaññaṃ manasikarotīti divā vā rattiṃ vā sūriyacandapajjotamaṇiādīnaṃ ālokaṃ
analyzed: āloka saññam manasikaroti iti divā vā rattim vā sūriya canda pajjota maṇi ādīnam ālokam
translated: He gives attention to the perception of light: he gives attention to the light of the sun, the moon, fire, a candle, an oil lamp, a gem, or starlight, whether by day or by night.

original: ālokoti manasikaroti. Divāsaññaṃ adhiṭṭhātīti evaṃ manasi katvā divātisaññaṃ ṭhapeti.🔽Yathā divā tathā rattinti yathā divā diṭṭho āloko, tatheva taṃ rattiṃ manasikaroti.
analyzed: manasikaroti divāsaññam adhiṭṭhāti iti evam manasi katvā divātisaññam ṭhapeti  yathā divā tathā rattinti yathā divā diṭṭhaḥ āloko tathā iva tam rattim manasikaroti
translated: He gives attention to light. He resolves upon a perception of day: he establishes a perception of day as if it were the perception of day.🔽As by day, so by night: he gives attention to the light as by day, so he gives attention to it by night.

original: Yathā rattiṃ tathā divāti yathā rattiṃ āloko diṭṭho, evameva divā manasikaroti. Iti
analyzed: yathā rattim tathā divā iti yathā rattim ālokaḥ diṭṭhaḥ evam eva divā manasikaroti iti
translated: As by night, so by day: he gives attention to the light as by night, so he gives attention to it by day.🔽With a mind that is open: with a mind that is not closed.

original: vivaṭena cetasāti evaṃ apihitena cittena. Apariyonaddhenāti samantato anaddhena.
analyzed: vivaṭena cetasā iti evam apihitena cittena a pariyonaddhena ati samantataḥ anaddhena
translated: Unrestricted: not restricted on every side.

original: Sappabhāsanti saobhāsaṃ. Ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhāyāti ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhatthāya. Iminā
analyzed: sa ppabhāsanti sa obhāsam ñāṇa dassana paṭilābhāya ati ñāṇa dassana paṭilābha atthāya iminā
translated: For the attainment of clear vision and knowledge: for the attainment of clear vision and knowledge.

original: kiṃ kathitaṃ? Middhavinodanaāloko kathito parikammaāloko vā. Iminā kiṃ kathitaṃ hoti?🔽Khīṇāsavassa dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ. Tasmiṃ vā āgatepi anāgatepi pādakajjhānasamāpattimeva
analyzed: kim kathitam middha vinodana āloko kathitaḥ parikamma āloko vā iminā kim kathitam hoti  khīṇāsavassa dibba cakkhu ñāṇam tasmin vā āgate api anāgate api pādaka jhāna samāpattim eva
translated: What is said here? The dispelling of drowsiness or the light of preliminary work. What is said here?

original: sandhāya “sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāvetī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya sa ppabhāsam cittam bhāveti iti vuttam
translated: The knowledge of the divine eye of one whose cankers are destroyed. But even when that is present or absent, it is only the attainment of the basic jhāna that is referred to by the words “he develops the mind that has had light” .

original: Satisampajaññāyāti sattaṭṭhānikassa satisampajaññassa atthāya. Viditā vedanā uppajjantītiādīsu
analyzed: sati sampajaññāya ati satta ṭṭhānikassa sati sampajaññassa atthāya viditāḥ vedanāḥ uppajjanti itiādīsu
translated: As to the words, “He knows the feelings as they arise” and so on,🔽the object is known, the object of the object is known, and the object and the object of the object are known.

original: khīṇāsavassa vatthu viditaṃ hoti ārammaṇaṃ viditaṃ vatthārammaṇaṃ viditaṃ. Vatthārammaṇaviditatāya
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa vatthu viditam hoti ārammaṇam viditam vattha ārammaṇam viditam vattha ārammaṇa vidita tāya
translated: Because of the knowledge of the object and the object of the object,🔽he knows thus, “Feelings arise thus, they continue thus, they pass away thus.”

original: evaṃ vedanā uppajjanti, evaṃ tiṭṭhanti, evaṃ nirujjhanti. Na kevalañca vedanā eva🔽idha vuttā saññādayopi, avuttā cetanādayopi, viditā ca uppajjanti ceva tiṭṭhanti
analyzed: evam vedanāḥ uppajjanti evam tiṭṭhanti evam nirujjhanti na kevalam ca vedanāḥ eva  idha vuttā saññā ādayo api avuttā cetanā ādayo api viditā ca uppajjanti ca iva tiṭṭhanti
translated: And not only feelings are referred to here,🔽but also perceptions and the rest mentioned here, and also volition and the rest not mentioned here. They are known as they arise, they are known as they appear, they are known as they disappear.

original: ca nirujjhanti ca. Api ca vedanāya uppādo vidito hoti, upaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ hoti. Avijjāsamudayā
analyzed: ca nirujjhanti ca api ca vedanāya uppādaḥ viditaḥ hoti upaṭṭhānam viditam hoti avijjā samudayā
translated: Moreover, the arising of feeling is known, its appearance is known, its disappearance is known.

original: vedanāsamudayo, taṇhāsamudayā kammasamudayo, phassasamudayā vedanāyasamudayo. Nibbattilakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: vedanā samudayo taṇhā samudayā kamma samudayo phassa samudayā vedanāya samudayaḥ nibbatti lakkhaṇam
translated: With the arising of ignorance as condition, feeling arises; with the arising of craving as condition, kamma arises; with the arising of contact as condition, feeling arises.

original: passantopi vedanākkhandhassa samudayaṃ passati. Evaṃ vedanāya uppādo vidito hoti.
analyzed: passantaḥ api vedanā khandhassa samudayam passati evam vedanāya uppādaḥ viditaḥ hoti
translated: Seeing the characteristic of generation, he sees the arising of the aggregate of feeling. Thus the arising of feeling is known.

original: Kathaṃ vedanāya upaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ hoti? Aniccato manasikaroto khayatūpaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ🔽hoti. Dukkhato manasikaroto bhayatūpaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ hoti. Anattato manasikaroto🔽suññatūpaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ hoti. Evaṃ vedanāya upaṭṭhānaṃ viditaṃ hoti, khayato bhayato🔽suññato jānāti. Kathaṃ vedanāya atthaṅgamo vidito hoti? Avijjānirodhā vedanānirodho.…Pe…
analyzed: katham vedanāya upaṭṭhānam viditam hoti aniccataḥ manasikaroto khaya tu upaṭṭhānam viditam  hoti dukkhataḥ manasikarotaḥ bhaya tu upaṭṭhānam viditam hoti anattataḥ manasikarotaḥ  suññatu upaṭṭhānam viditam hoti evam vedanāya upaṭṭhānam viditam hoti khayataḥ bhayataḥ  suññataḥ jānāti katham vedanāya atthaṅgamaḥ viditaḥ hoti avijjā nirodhā vedanā nirodha upe
translated: How is the appearance of feeling known? When he brings to mind as impermanent, the appearance as destruction is known.🔽When he brings to mind as painful, the appearance as terror is known.🔽When he brings to mind as not-self, the appearance as void is known.🔽Thus the appearance of feeling is known, as destruction, as terror,🔽as void. How is the cessation of feeling known? With the cessation of ignorance there is cessation of feeling. …🔽…

original: evaṃ vedanāya atthaṅgamo vidito hoti. Imināpi nayenettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: evam vedanāya atthaṅgamaḥ viditaḥ hoti iminā api nayena ittha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: How is the appearance of feeling known? When he brings to mind as impermanent, the appearance as destruction is known. When he brings to mind as painful, the appearance as terror is known. When he brings to mind as not-self, the appearance as void is known. This is how the appearance of feeling is known. He knows destruction, terror, and voidness in feeling. How is the cessation of feeling known? With the cessation of ignorance there is cessation of feeling. … This is how the cessation of feeling is known. The meaning should be understood in this way.🔽“Thus in visible forms”: the method here is the same as that already stated.

original: Iti rūpantiādi vuttanayameva. Ayaṃ āvuso samādhibhāvanāti ayaṃ āsavānaṃ khayañāṇassa pādakajjhānasamādhibhāvanā.
analyzed: iti rūpa nti ādi vutta nayam eva ayam āvuso samādhi bhāvanā ati ayam āsavānam khaya ñāṇassa pādaka jhāna samādhi bhāvanā
translated: “This, friend, is the development of concentration”: this is the development of the jhāna that is the basis for the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: 308. Appamaññāti pamāṇaṃ agahetvā anavasesapharaṇavasena appamaññāva. Anupadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: appamaññā iti pamāṇam a gahetvā anavasesa pharaṇa vasena appamaññā ava anupada vaṇṇanā
translated: The measureless: the measureless is the measureless state of pervading without exception. The commentary on the word “measureless” is finished.

original: pana bhāvanāsamādhividhānañca etāsaṃ visuddhimagge vitthāritameva. Arūpakathāpi visuddhimagge vitthāritāva.
analyzed: pana bhāvanā samādhi vidhānañca etāsam visuddhi magge vitthāritam eva arūpa kathā api visuddhi magge vitthāritā ava
translated: But the method of developing concentration by means of these is given in detail in the Path of Purification . And the exposition of the immaterial states is also given there in detail.

original: Apassenānīti apassayāni. Saṅkhāyāti ñāṇena ñatvā. Paṭisevatīti ñāṇena ñatvā sevitabbayuttakameva
analyzed: a passenāni iti a passayāni saṅkhāya ati ñāṇena ñatvā paṭisevati iti ñāṇena ñatvā sevitabba yuttakam eva
translated: Having reflected: having known with knowledge. He makes use: he uses only what should be used, knowing it with knowledge.

original: sevati. Tassa ca vitthāro “paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cīvaraṃ paribhuñjatī”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: sevati tassa ca vitthāraḥ paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cīvaram paribhuñjati iti ādinā nayena
translated: And its detailed explanation should be understood in the way beginning, “Reflecting wisely he makes use of a dwelling” .

original: veditabbo. Saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāsetīti ñāṇena ñatvā adhivāsetabbayuttakameva adhivāseti.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ saṅkhāya ekam adhivāseti iti ñāṇena ñatvā adhivāsetabba yuttakam eva adhivāseti
translated: Having reflected, he endures: he endures only what should be endured, knowing it with knowledge.

original: Vitthāro panettha “paṭisaṅkhā yoniso khamo hoti sītassā”tiādinā nayena veditabbo.🔽Parivajjetīti ñāṇena ñatvā parivajjetuṃ yuttameva parivajjeti. Tassa vitthāro “paṭisaṅkhā
analyzed: vitthāraḥ pana ittha paṭisaṅkhā yonisas khamaḥ hoti sītassa ati ādinā nayena veditabbo  parivajjeti iti ñāṇena ñatvā parivajjetum yuttam eva parivajjeti tassa vitthāro paṭisaṅkhā
translated: But its detailed explanation should be understood in the way beginning, “Reflecting wisely he is content with any kind of alms” .🔽He avoids: he avoids only what should be avoided, knowing it with knowledge. And its detailed explanation should be understood in the way beginning, “Reflecting wisely he avoids an angry bhikkhu” .

original: yoniso caṇḍaṃ hatthiṃ parivajjetī”tiādinā nayena veditabbo. Vinodetīti ñāṇena ñatvā
analyzed: yonisaḥ caṇḍam hatthim parivajjeti itiādinā nayena veditabbaḥ vinodeti iti ñāṇena ñatvā
translated: He removes: he removes only what should be removed, knowing it with knowledge.

original: vinodetabbameva vinodeti, nudati nīharati anto pavisituṃ na deti. Tassa vitthāro
analyzed: vinodetabbam eva vinodeti nudati nīharati antar pavisitum na deti tassa vitthāro
translated: he should dispel it, and he does so; he removes it, he takes it away, he does not let it enter in. The detail is

original: “uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāsetī”tiādinā nayena veditabbo.
analyzed: uppannam kāma vitakkam na adhivāseti iti ādinā nayena veditabbaḥ
translated: to be understood in the way beginning, “He does not consent to a thought of sensual desire that has arisen” .

original: Ariyavaṃsacatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The four kinds of noble persons

original: 309. Ariyavaṃsāti ariyānaṃ vaṃsā. Yathā hi khattiyavaṃso, brāhmaṇavaṃso, vessavaṃso,
analyzed: ariya vaṃsā ati ariyānam vaṃsāḥ yathā hi khattiya vaṃsaḥ brāhmaṇa vaṃsaḥ vessa vaṃsaḥ
translated: Noble Ones’ Grade: the grades of the Noble Ones. For just as there is the grade of the nobles , the grade of the brahmans , the grade of the merchants ,

original: suddavaṃso, samaṇavaṃso, kulavaṃso, rājavaṃso, evaṃ ayampi aṭṭhamo ariyavaṃso ariyatanti
analyzed: sudda vaṃso samaṇa vaṃso kula vaṃso rāja vaṃso evam ayam pi aṭṭhamaḥ ariya vaṃso
translated: the grade of the workers , the grade of ascetics , the grade of families , the grade of kings , so this is the eighth grade of Noble Ones. It is called

original: ariyapaveṇī nāma hoti. So kho panāyaṃ ariyavaṃso imesaṃ vaṃsānaṃ mūlagandhādīnaṃ
analyzed: ariyapaveṇī nāma hoti saḥ kho pana ayam ariya vaṃsaḥ imesam vaṃsānam mūla gandha ādīnam
translated: the Noble Ones’ tradition. And this Noble Ones’ grade is called the root-aroma of these grades,

original: kāḷānusāritagandhādayo viya aggamakkhāyati. Ke pana te ariyā yesaṃ ete vaṃsāti? Ariyā
analyzed: ke pana te ariyāḥ yesam ete ariyā
translated: like the black-flowing-after-the-white-flowing perfumes, etc., and it is called the best. But who are these Noble Ones of whose grade this is?

original: vuccanti buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca tathāgatasāvakā ca, etesaṃ ariyānaṃ vaṃsāti ariyavaṃsā.
analyzed: vuccanti buddhā ca paccekabuddhā ca tathāgata sāvakā ca etesam ariyānam ariya vaṃsā
translated: Noble Ones are called Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and the disciples of Buddhas. This is the Noble Ones’ grade of these Noble Ones.

original: Ito pubbe hi satasahassakappādhikānaṃ catunnaṃ asaṅkhyeyyānaṃ matthake taṇhaṅkaro
analyzed: itas pubbe hi sata sahassa kappa adhikānam catunnam asaṅkhyeyyānam matthake
translated: For previously, at the end of four incalculable ages plus a hundred thousand aeons, there was a Buddha called Dipankara,

original: medhaṅkaro saraṇaṅkaro dīpaṅkaroti cattāro buddhā uppannā, te ariyā, tesaṃ ariyānaṃ🔽vaṃsāti ariyavaṃsā. Tesaṃ buddhānaṃ parinibbānato aparabhāge asaṅkhyeyyaṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: medhaṅkaro saraṇaṅkaraḥ dīpaṅkaro ti cattāraḥ buddhāḥ uppannā te ariyā tesam ariyānam  vaṃsā ati ariya vaṃsā tesam buddhānam parinibbānataḥ apara bhāge asaṅkhyeyyam atikkamitvā
translated: After the passing of those Buddhas, after an incalculable aeon had elapsed,

original: koṇḍañño nāma buddho uppanno…pe… imasmiṃ kappe kakusandho, koṇāgamano, kassapo, amhākaṃ
analyzed: koṇḍaññaḥ nāma buddhaḥ uppanna upe imasmin kappe kakusandhaḥ koṇāgamanaḥ kassapaḥ amhākam
translated: the Buddha named Koṇḍañña arose. … In this aeon, Kakusandha, Koṇāgamana, Kassapa, and our

original: bhagavā gotamoti cattāro buddhā uppannā. Tesaṃ ariyānaṃ vaṃsāti ariyavaṃsā. Apica
analyzed: bhagavā gotamaḥ ti cattāraḥ buddhāḥ uppannā tesam ariyānam ariya vaṃsā ati ariya vaṃsāḥ apica
translated: own Blessed One Gotama arose. Their lineage is the Noble Lineage. Furthermore,

original: atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ sabbabuddhapaccekabuddhabuddhasāvakānaṃ ariyānaṃ vaṃsāti
analyzed: atīta anāgata paccuppannānam sabba buddha paccekabuddha buddha sāvakānam ariyānam
translated: the lineage of all the Noble Ones of the past, future, and present—the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and Buddhas’ disciples—

original: ariyavaṃsā. Te kho panete aggaññā aggāti jānitabbā. Rattaññā dīgharattaṃ pavattāti🔽jānitabbā. Vaṃsaññā vaṃsāti jānitabbā.🔽Porāṇāti na adhunuppattikā. Asaṃkiṇṇā avikiṇṇā anapanītā. Asaṃkiṇṇapubbā atītabuddhehi
analyzed: ariya vaṃsā te kho pana ete aggaññāḥ aggā ati jānitabbāḥ rattaññāḥ dīgharattam pavattā ati 🔽jānitabbā vaṃsaññā vaṃsāti jānitabbā 🔽porāṇā ati na adhunuppattikāḥ a saṃkiṇṇāḥ a vikiṇṇāḥ an apanītāḥ a saṃkiṇṇa pubbāḥ atīta buddhehi
translated: is the Noble Lineage. They should be known as the foremost of the foremost. They should be known as the foremost of those who have gone forth. They should be known as the foremost of those who have gone to the far shore.🔽They should be known as the foremost of those who have crossed over. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the shore beyond. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of peace. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of nibbāna. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the deathless. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the highest welfare. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of happiness. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of sublime peace. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of nibbāna. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of the deathless. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of the highest welfare. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of happiness. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of the highest peace. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of the highest nibbāna. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached the state of the supreme state of the highest deathless. They should be known as the foremost of those who have reached

original: na saṃkiṇṇapubbā. “Kiṃ imehī”ti na apanītapubbā? Na saṅkīyantīti idānipi na apanīyanti.
analyzed: na saṃkiṇṇa pubbā kim imehi iti na apanīta pubbā na saṅkīyanti iti idāni api na apanīyanti
translated: They have not been removed before. “What is the use of these?” They have not been removed before. They are not being removed now.

original: Na saṅkīyissantīti anāgatabuddhehipi na apanīyissanti, ye loke viññū samaṇabrāhmaṇā,
analyzed: na saṅkīyissanti iti anāgata buddhehi pi na apanīyissanti ye loke viññū samaṇa brāhmaṇā
translated: They will not be removed in the future by the Buddhas who will arise in the future. By those who are wise in the world, by recluses and brahmins,

original: tehi appaṭikuṭṭhā, samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi aninditā agarahitā.
analyzed: tehi appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi aninditā a garahitā
translated: they are not despised, not censured, not disparaged by wise recluses and brahmins.

original: Santuṭṭho hotīti paccayasantosavasena santuṭṭho hoti. Itarītarena cīvarenāti thūlasukhumalūkhapaṇītathirajiṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti paccaya santosa vasena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti itarītarena cīvarena ati thūla sukhuma lūkha paṇīta thira jiṇṇānam
translated: He is content: he is content in the sense of being satisfied with the requisites. With any kind of robe: with any kind of robe, whether coarse or fine, rough or smooth, old or new,

original: yena kenaci. Atha kho yathāladdhādīnaṃ itarītarena yena kenaci santuṭṭho hotīti attho.
analyzed: yena kenaci atha kho yathā laddha ādīnam itarītarena yena kenaci santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti attho
translated: with any kind of robe. The meaning is that he is content with any kind of robe, whether he gets it easily or with difficulty.

original: Cīvarasmiñhi tayo santosā – yathālābhasantoso, yathābalasantoso, yathāsāruppasantosoti.
analyzed: cīvarasmin hi tayo santosā yathā lābha santosaḥ yathā bala santosaḥ yathā sāruppa santosaḥ iti
translated: For there are three kinds of contentment with robes: contentment with whatever robe one gets, contentment with one’s ability to get a robe, and contentment with one’s store of robes.🔽The same method of explanation applies to alms food, etc.,

original: Piṇḍapātādīsupi eseva nayo. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā sāmaññaphale vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: piṇḍapāta ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ tesam vitthāra kathā sāmañña phale vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: and the detailed explanation of these should be understood as given in the Fruits of the Homeless Life .

original: Ime tayo santose sandhāya “santuṭṭho hoti, itarītarena yathāladdhādīsu yena kenaci
analyzed: ime tayo santose sandhāya santuṭṭhaḥ hoti itarītarena yathā laddha ādīsu yena kenacid
translated: With reference to these three kinds of contentment, the text says: “He is content with any kind of robe, with any kind of alms food, with any kind of lodging, with any kind of medicinal requisites for curing sickness that he may get.”

original: cīvarena santuṭṭho hotī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cīvarena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti vuttam
translated: He is content with robes.”🔽Herein, robe should be understood, robe-material should be understood, rag-robes should be understood,🔽and contentment with robes should be understood, and the ascetic practices connected with robes should be understood.

original: Ettha ca cīvaraṃ jānitabbaṃ, cīvarakkhettaṃ jānitabbaṃ, paṃsukūlaṃ jānitabbaṃ, cīvarasantoso🔽jānitabbo, cīvarapaṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni jānitabbāni. Tattha cīvaraṃ jānitabbanti
analyzed: ettha ca cīvaram jānitabbam cīvara khettam jānitabbam paṃsukūlam jānitabbam cīvara santoso  jānitabbaḥ cīvara paṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni jānitabbāni tattha cīvaram jānitabbanti
translated: Herein, robe should be understood:

original: khomādīni cha cīvarāni dukūlādīni cha anulomacīvarāni jānitabbāni. Imāni dvādasa🔽kappiyacīvarāni. Kusacīraṃ vākacīraṃ phalakacīraṃ kesakambalaṃ vāḷakambalaṃ potthako🔽cammaṃ ulūkapakkhaṃ rukkhadussaṃ latādussaṃ erakadussaṃ kadalidussaṃ veḷudussanti
analyzed: khoma ādīni cha cīvarāni dukūla ādīni cha anuloma cīvarāni jānitabbāni imāni dvādasa  kappiya cīvarāni kusa cīram vāka cīram phalaka cīram kesa kambalam vāḷa kambalam potthako  cammam ulūka pakkham rukkha dussam latā dussam eraka dussam kadali dussam veḷu dussanti
translated: the six robes beginning with the cloak and the six robes beginning with the linen are the twelve kinds of allowable robes.

analyzed: māsa ḍḍha māsa mattam vitakkanam vitakka santosaḥ vitakka santosena pana santuṭṭhena bhikkhunā
translated: The satisfaction of thinking for half a month or a month is satisfaction in thinking.

original: pācīnakkhaṇḍarājivāsikapaṃsukūlikattherasadisena bhavitabbaṃ.
analyzed: pācīnakkhaṇḍa rājivāsika paṃsukūlika tthera sadisena bhavitabbam
translated: A bhikkhu who is satisfied with that should be like the Elder Pañcasūkāra who lived at Khaṇḍarāji in the East.

original: Thero kira cetiyapabbatavihāre cetiyaṃ vandissāmīti āgato cetiyaṃ vanditvā cintesi
analyzed: thero kira cetiya pabbata vihāre cetiyam vandissāmi iti āgataḥ cetiyam vanditvā cintesi
translated: The elder, it seems, came to the Cetiya Monastery, thinking “I shall worship the shrine.” After worshipping the shrine he thought,

original: “mayhaṃ cīvaraṃ jiṇṇaṃ bahūnaṃ vasanaṭṭhāne labhissāmī”ti. So mahāvihāraṃ gantvā
analyzed: mayham cīvaram jiṇṇam bahūnam vasana ṭṭhāne labhissāmi iti saḥ mahāvihāram gantvā
translated: “My robe is worn. I shall get a place to live in among the many who live here.” He went to the Great Monastery,

original: saṅghattheraṃ disvā vasanaṭṭhānaṃ pucchitvā tattha vuttho punadivase cīvaraṃ ādāya
analyzed: saṅghattheram disvā vasanaṭṭhānam pucchitvā tattha vutthaḥ puna divase cīvaram ādāya
translated: saw the senior elder there, asked for a place to live in, and was given one. He lived there and on the following day took his robe,

original: āgantvā theraṃ vandi. Thero kiṃ āvusoti āha. Gāmadvāraṃ, bhante, gamissāmīti. Ahampāvuso,🔽gamissāmīti. Sādhu, bhanteti gacchanto mahābodhidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhatvā puññavantānaṃ
analyzed: āgantvā theram vandi theraḥ kim āvuso ti āha gāma dvāram bhante gamissāmi iti aham pāvuso  gamissāmi iti sādhu bhante iti gacchantaḥ mahābodhidvāra koṭṭhake ṭhatvā puññavantānam
translated: went to the senior elder, and paid homage to him. The elder asked him, “What is it, friend?” He replied, “I am going to the village gate, venerable sir.” The elder said, “I too am going, friend.”

original: vasanaṭṭhāne manāpaṃ labhissāmīti cintetvā aparisuddho me vitakkoti tatova paṭinivatti.
analyzed: vasana ṭṭhāne manāpam labhissāmi iti cintetvā aparisuddhaḥ me vitakkoti tatas va paṭinivatti
translated: “Very well, venerable sir.” As he was going, he stopped at the gateway to the Great Monastery, thinking, “I shall get a pleasant place to live in among the meritorious people who live here.” But he turned back again, thinking, “My thinking is not yet purified.”

original: Punadivase ambaṅgaṇasamīpato, punadivase mahācetiyassa uttaradvārato, tatheva paṭinivattitvā
analyzed: puna divase ambaṅgaṇa samīpataḥ puna divase mahā cetiyassa uttara dvārataḥ tathā iva paṭinivattitvā
translated: On the following day from the mango-grove, on the following day from the northern gate of the Great Shrine, he turned back in the same way.

original: catutthadivase therassa santikaṃ agamāsi. Thero imassa bhikkhuno vitakko na parisuddho
analyzed: catuttha divase therassa santikam agamāsi theraḥ imassa bhikkhuno vitakkaḥ na parisuddhaḥ
translated: On the following day he came from the mango grove, on the next day from the northern gate of the Great Shrine, and on the fourth day he came to the Elder. The Elder thought, “This bhikkhu’s thought is not yet purified.

original: bhavissatīti cīvaraṃ gahetvā tena saddhiṃyeva pañhaṃ pucchamāno gāmaṃ pāvisi. Tañca
analyzed: bhavissati iti cīvaram gahetvā tena saddhiṃyeva pañham pucchamānaḥ gāmam pāvisi tat ca
translated: He must still be thinking of the robe.” So he took the robe and entered the village with him, asking questions about the way.

original: rattiṃ eko manusso uccārapalibuddho sāṭakeyeva vaccaṃ katvā taṃ saṅkāraṭṭhāne chaḍḍesi.
analyzed: rattim ekaḥ manussaḥ uccāra palibuddhaḥ sāṭakeya iva vaccam katvā tam saṅkāra ṭṭhāne chaḍḍesi
translated: That night a man who was suffering from dysentery defecated on a cloth and threw it on the rubbish heap.

original: Paṃsukūlikatthero taṃ nīlamakkhikāhi samparikiṇṇaṃ disvā añjaliṃ paggahesi. Mahāthero
analyzed: paṃsukūlika theraḥ tam nīla makkhikāhi samparikiṇṇam disvā añjalim paggahesi mahā theraḥ
translated: The refuse-rag wearer saw it covered with blue flies and raised his joined palms in reverential salutation. The Elder asked him,

original: “kiṃ, āvuso, saṅkāraṭṭhānassa añjaliṃ paggaṇhāsī”ti? “Nāhaṃ, bhante, saṅkāraṭṭhānassa
analyzed: kim āvuso saṅkāra ṭṭhānassa añjalim paggaṇhāsi iti na aham bhante saṅkāra ṭṭhānassa
translated: “Why do you, friend, raise your joined palms in reverential salutation to the rubbish heap?”

original: añjaliṃ paggaṇhāmi, mayhaṃ pitu dasabalassa paggaṇhāmi, puṇṇadāsiyā sarīraṃ pārupitvā
analyzed: añjalim paggaṇhāmi mayham pitu dasabalassa paggaṇhāmi puṇṇadāsiyā sarīram
translated: “Venerable sir, I do not raise my joined palms in reverential salutation to the rubbish heap. I raise them in reverential salutation to my father, the One of Ten Powers. The body of Puṇṇā the slave girl was wrapped in this cloth and thrown on the rubbish heap.

original: chaḍḍitaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ tumbamatte pāṇake vidhunitvā susānato gaṇhantena dukkaraṃ kataṃ,
analyzed: chaḍḍitam paṃsukūlam tumba matte pāṇake vidhunitvā su sānataḥ gaṇhantena dukkaram katam
translated: The refuse-rag wearer picked it up, removed the grubs, and took it away from the charnel ground. He made a difficult task easy,

original: bhante”ti. Mahāthero “parisuddho vitakko paṃsukūlikassā”ti cintesi. Paṃsukūlikattheropi
analyzed: bhante ti mahā thero parisuddhaḥ vitakko paṃsukūlikassa ati cintesi paṃsukūlika theraḥ api
translated: The elder thought, “The robe-cloth of the refuse-rag wearer is pure.” The refuse-rag wearing elder

original: tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne ṭhito vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā tīṇi phalāni patto taṃ sāṭakaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne ṭhitaḥ vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā tīṇi phalāni patto tam sāṭakam gahetvā
translated: increased his insight right there, attained the three fruitions, took the cloth,

original: cīvaraṃ katvā pārupitvā pācīnakkhaṇḍarājiṃ gantvā aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: cīvaram katvā pārupitvā pācīnakkhaṇḍa rājim gantvā agga phalam arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: made it into a robe, and put it on. Then he went to the Eastern Bamboo Park and reached the highest fruit, arahatship.

original: Cīvaratthāya gacchantassa pana “kattha labhissāmī”ti acintetvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva gamanaṃ gamanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: cīvara atthāya gacchantassa pana kattha labhissāmi iti a cintetvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva gamanam gamana santosaḥ nāma
translated: When one goes out for robe-cloth, one should not think, “Where shall I get it?” One should go with the meditation subject as one’s only concern. This is called contentment with what one gets.

original: Pariyesantassa pana yena vā tena vā saddhiṃ apariyesitvā lajjiṃ pesalaṃ bhikkhuṃ gahetvā pariyesanaṃ pariyesanasantoso nāma.🔽Evaṃ pariyesantassa āhariyamānaṃ cīvaraṃ dūrato disvā “etaṃ manāpaṃ bhavissati, etaṃ
analyzed: pariyesantassa pana yena vā tena vā saddhim a pariyesitvā lajjim pesalam bhikkhum gahetvā pariyesanam pariyesana santosaḥ nāma  evam pariyesantassa āhariyamānam cīvaram dūratas disvā etam manāpam bhavissati etam
translated: When one is seeking, one should not seek it together with anyone else. One should take a modest, conscientious companion and seek it with him. This is called contentment with seeking.

original: amanāpa”nti evaṃ avitakketvā thūlasukhumādīsu yathāladdheneva santussanaṃ paṭilābhasantoso nāma.
analyzed: evam a vitakketvā thūla sukhuma ādīsu yathā laddhena iva santussanam paṭilābha santosaḥ nāma
translated: When one is seeking in this way, one should not think, “This will be nice,” or “This will be bad,” when one sees robe-cloth coming from afar. One should be content with whatever one gets, whether coarse or fine. This is called contentment with acquisition.

original: Evaṃ laddhaṃ gaṇhantassāpi “ettakaṃ dupaṭṭassa bhavissati, ettakaṃ ekapaṭṭassā”ti attano pahonakamatteneva santussanaṃ mattappaṭiggahaṇasantoso nāma.
analyzed: evam laddham gaṇhantassa api ettakam du paṭṭassa bhavissati ettakam eka paṭṭassa ati attanaḥ pahonaka mattena iva santussanam matta paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he accepts what he has got in this way, thinking, “So much will be for double-cloth, so much for single-cloth,” and is satisfied with just that much, this is called contentment with what is obtained.

original: Cīvaraṃ pariyesantassa pana “asukassa gharadvāre manāpaṃ labhissāmī”ti acintetvā dvārapaṭipāṭiyā caraṇaṃ loluppavivajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: cīvaram pariyesantassa pana asukassa ghara dvāre manāpam labhissāmi iti a cintetvā dvāra paṭipāṭiyā caraṇam loluppa vivajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he goes on his round for alms without thinking, “At such and such a house they will give me nice food,” but goes his round in order of places, this is called contentment that avoids what is sought.

original: Lūkhapaṇītesu yena kenaci yāpetuṃ sakkontassa yathāladdheneva yāpanaṃ yathālābhasantoso nāma.
analyzed: lūkha paṇītesu yena kenacid yāpetum sakkontassa yathāladdhena iva yāpanam yathā lābha santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he is able to live on anything at all, whether coarse or fine, and lives on whatever he gets, this is called contentment with what is obtained.

original: Attano thāmaṃ jānitvā yena yāpetuṃ sakkoti, tena yāpanaṃ yathābalasantoso nāma.
analyzed: attano thāmam jānitvā yena yāpetum sakkoti tena yāpanam yathābalasantosaḥ nāma
translated: When he knows his strength and lives on what he can get without difficulty, this is called contentment with what is easy to obtain.

original: Manāpaṃ aññassa datvā attano yena kenaci yāpanaṃ yathāsāruppasantoso nāma.
analyzed: manāpam aññassa da tvā attanaḥ yena kenacid yāpanam yathā sāruppa santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he gives the nice food to others and lives on what is left, this is called contentment with what is shared.

original: “Kattha udakaṃ manāpaṃ, kattha amanāpa”nti avicāretvā yena kenaci dhovanupagena udakena
analyzed: kattha udakam manāpam kattha amanāpanti a vicāretvā yena kenacid dhovan upagena udakena
translated: When he does not bother about whether the water is nice or not, but washes himself with whatever water is available for washing,

original: dhovanaṃ udakasantoso nāma. Paṇḍumattikagerukapūtipaṇṇarasakiliṭṭhāni pana udakāni vajjetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: dhovanam udaka santosaḥ nāma paṇḍu mattika geruka pūti paṇṇa rasa kiliṭṭhāni pana udakāni vajjetum vaṭṭati
translated: Washing is called “water-content.” But it is allowable to use water that is muddy, or that has become warm, or that has a smell, or that is discolored by old leaves, etc.

original: Dhovantassa pana muggarādīhi apaharitvā hatthehi madditvā dhovanaṃ dhovanasantoso nāma. Tathā asujjhantaṃ paṇṇāni pakkhipitvā tāpitaudakenāpi dhovituṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: dhovantassa pana muggara ādīhi apaharitvā hatthehi madditvā dhovanam dhovana santosaḥ nāma tathā asujjhantam paṇṇāni pakkhipitvā tāpita odakena api dhovitum vaṭṭati
translated: But washing by removing the stains with a stick, etc., and then washing with the hands is called “washing-content.” And if it does not become clean in this way, it is allowable to put it in water heated on a charcoal brazier and to wash it.

original: Evaṃ dhovitvā karontassa idaṃ thūlaṃ, idaṃ sukhumanti akopetvā pahonakanīhāreneva karaṇaṃ karaṇasantoso nāma.
analyzed: evam dhovitvā karontassa idam thūlam idam sukhumanti a kopetvā pahonaka nīhārena iva karaṇam karaṇa santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he has washed it in this way, if he makes it without storing up the thick parts and the thin parts, this is called “making-content.”

original: Timaṇḍalappaṭicchādanamattasseva karaṇaṃ parimāṇasantoso nāma.
analyzed: ti maṇḍala paṭicchādana mattassa iva karaṇam parimāṇa santosaḥ nāma
translated: Making it just to cover the three circles is called “size-content.”

original: Cīvarakaraṇatthāya pana manāpasuttaṃ pariyesissāmīti avicāretvā rathikādīsu vā devaṭṭhāne vā āharitvā pādamūle vā ṭhapitaṃ yaṃkiñcideva suttaṃ gahetvā karaṇaṃ suttasantoso nāma.
analyzed: cīvara karaṇa atthāya pana manāpa suttam pariyesissāmi iti a vicāretvā rathika ādīsu vā devaṭṭhāne vā āharitvā pāda mūle vā ṭhapitam yaṃ kiñcid eva suttam gahetvā karaṇam suttasantosaḥ nāma
translated: But if he does not investigate thus, “I shall look for a pleasant thread for making the robe,” and he makes the robe with whatever thread he gets hold of, whether it was brought by himself from the bazaar, etc., or placed at his disposal by another, this is called “string-content.”

original: Kusibandhanakāle pana aṅgulamatte sattavāre na vijjhitabbaṃ, evaṃ karontassa hi yo
analyzed: kusibandhana kāle pana aṅgula matte satta vāre na vijjhitabbam evam karontassa hi yaḥ
translated: But at the time of sewing, he should not sew more than seven tucks an inch, for if he does so,

original: bhikkhu sahāyo na hoti, tassa vattabhedopi natthi. Tivaṅgulamatte pana sattavāre
analyzed: bhikkhu sahāyaḥ na hoti tassa vatta bhedaḥ api natthi ti vaṅgula matte pana satta vāre
translated: He has no companion monk, and so there is no schism in his case. But if he does it three times in a space of three inches,

original: vijjhitabbaṃ, evaṃ karontassa maggapaṭipannenāpi sahāyena bhavitabbaṃ. Yo na hoti,
analyzed: vijjhitabbam evam karontassa magga paṭipannena api sahāyena bhavitabbam yaḥ na hoti
translated: If a monk is not his companion, he has no need to tell him. But if he is going to do it seven times on an area three inches square, he should have a companion on the path of seeing. If he does not have one,

original: tassa vattabhedo. Ayaṃ sibbanasantoso nāma.🔽Rajantena pana kāḷakacchakādīni pariyesantena na rajitabbaṃ. Somavakkalādīsu yaṃ
analyzed: tassa vatta bhedaḥ ayam sibbanasantosaḥ nāma  rajantena pana kāḷa kacchaka ādīni pariyesantena na rajitabbam soma vakkala ādīsu yam
translated: he has no need to tell him. This is called satisfaction with the work.🔽But when he is dyeing, he should not look for black dye-yielding wood-apple tree bark, etc.,

original: labhati, tena rajitabbaṃ. Alabhantena pana manussehi araññe vākaṃ gahetvā chaḍḍitarajanaṃ
analyzed: labhati tena rajitabbam a labhantena pana manussehi araññe vākam gahetvā chaḍḍita rajanam
translated: He should dye with whatever he can get, such as soma creeper, etc. If he cannot get that, he should get dye-yielding grass thrown away in the forest by people,

original: vā bhikkhūhi pacitvā chaḍḍitakasaṭaṃ vā gahetvā rajitabbaṃ, ayaṃ rajanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: vā bhikkhūhi pacitvā chaḍḍitaka saṭam vā gahetvā rajitabbam ayam rajana santosaḥ nāma
translated: or he should get hemp-waste thrown away by monks after they have used it for patching robes, and dye with that. This is called satisfaction with the dyeing.

original: Nīlakaddamakāḷasāmesu yaṃkiñci gahetvā hatthipiṭṭhe nisinnassa paññāyamānakapakaraṇaṃ kappasantoso nāma.
analyzed: nīla kaddama kāḷasa āmesu yaṃ kiñci gahetvā hatthi piṭṭhe nisinnassa paññāyamānaka pakaraṇam kappasantosaḥ nāma
translated: Taking any one of the three kinds of dye, namely, indigo, cutch, or yellow, and making a dye-pot with a base of bricks or wood or clay, he should sit on the ground and dye the robe with the dye he has prepared. This is called satisfaction with the dyeing-materials.

original: Hirikopīnapaṭicchādanamattavasena paribhuñjanaṃ paribhogasantoso nāma.
analyzed: hiri kopīna paṭicchādana matta vasena paribhuñjanam paribhoga santosaḥ nāma
translated: Using the robe just for the purpose of covering the private parts and for the purpose of warding off stiffness and chill and for the purpose of warding off flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, is called satisfaction with using.

original: Dussaṃ pana labhitvā suttaṃ vā sūciṃ vā kārakaṃ vā alabhantena ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati,
analyzed: dussam pana labhitvā suttam vā sūcim vā kārakam vā a labhantena ṭhapetum vaṭṭati
translated: But if he cannot get cloth and cannot get a maker of a robe or a needle, he may keep it.

original: labhantena na vaṭṭati. Katampi sace antevāsikādīnaṃ dātukāmo hoti, te ca asannihitā
analyzed: labhantena na vaṭṭati sace antevāsika ādīnam dātu kāmaḥ te ca a sannihitā
translated: If he can get them, he should not. If he wants to give it to his pupils, etc., and they are not near,

original: yāva āgamanā ṭhapetuṃ vaṭṭati. Āgatamattesu dātabbaṃ. Dātuṃ asakkontena adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ.
analyzed: yāva āgamanā ṭhapetum vaṭṭati āgata mattesu dātabbam dātum a sakkontena adhiṭṭhātabbam
translated: he may keep it until they come. As soon as they arrive it should be given to them. If he is unable to give it, he should determine it.

original: Aññasmiṃ cīvare sati paccattharaṇampi adhiṭṭhātuṃ vaṭṭati. Anadhiṭṭhitameva hi sannidhi
analyzed: aññasmim cīvare sati paccattharaṇam pi adhiṭṭhātum vaṭṭati an adhiṭṭhitam eva hi sannidhi
translated: And if he has another robe, he may determine even a floor cover. For the Elder Maha-Siva said that what is not determined is stored,

original: hoti. Adhiṭṭhitaṃ na hotīti mahāsīvatthero āha. Ayaṃ sannidhiparivajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: hoti adhiṭṭhitam na hoti iti mahāsīva theraḥ āha ayam sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: but what is determined is not stored. This is called the satisfaction of avoiding storage.

original: Vissajjantena pana na mukhaṃ oloketvā dātabbaṃ. Sāraṇīyadhamme ṭhatvā vissajjitabbanti ayaṃ vissajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: vissajjantena pana na mukham oloketvā dātabbam sāraṇīya dhamme ṭhatvā vissajjitabbanti ayam vissajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: But when he is giving it away, he should not give it after looking at the face of the giver. He should give it after establishing himself in the things that make for endearment. This is called the satisfaction of giving away.

original: Cīvarapaṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni nāma paṃsukūlikaṅgañceva tecīvarikaṅgañca. Tesaṃ
analyzed: cīvara paṭisaṃyuttāni dhutaṅgāni nāma paṃsukūlikaṅgam ca iva tecīvarikaṅgam ca tesam
translated: The ascetic practices concerned with robes are the refuse-rag-wearer’s practice and the triple-robe-wearer’s practice.

original: vitthārakathā visuddhimaggato veditabbā. Iti cīvarasantosamahāariyavaṃsaṃ pūrayamāno
analyzed: vitthāra kathā visuddhi maggataḥ veditabbā iti cīvara santosa mahāariya vaṃsam pūrayamānaḥ
translated: The detailed explanation should be understood according to the text of the Visuddhimagga.

original: bhikkhu imāni dve dhutaṅgāni gopeti. Imāni gopento cīvarasantosamahāariyavaṃsena santuṭṭho hoti.
analyzed: bhikkhu imāni dve dhutaṅgāni gopeti imāni gopento cīvara santosa mahāariya vaṃsena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: Thus a bhikkhu who fulfils the Great Man’s quality of contentment with any old alms obtains these two ascetic practices.🔽In obtaining them he is content with the Great Man’s quality of contentment with any old alms.

original: Vaṇṇavādīti eko santuṭṭho hoti, santosassa vaṇṇaṃ na katheti, eko na santuṭṭho hoti,
analyzed: vaṇṇa vādī iti ekaḥ santuṭṭhaḥ hoti santosassa vaṇṇam na katheti ekaḥ na santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: “One who praises contentment”: one is content but does not praise contentment;🔽one is not content but praises contentment;

original: santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti, eko neva santuṭṭho hoti, na santosassa vaṇṇaṃ katheti,🔽eko santuṭṭho ceva hoti, santosassa ca vaṇṇaṃ katheti, taṃ dassetuṃ “itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā
analyzed: santosassa vaṇṇam katheti ekaḥ na iva santuṭṭhaḥ hoti na santosassa vaṇṇam katheti  ekaḥ santuṭṭho ca iva hoti santosassa ca vaṇṇam katheti tam dassetum itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā
translated: one is neither content nor does he praise contentment;

original: ca vaṇṇavādī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Anesananti dūteyyapahinagamanānuyogappabhedaṃ nānappakāraṃ anesanaṃ. Appatirūpanti
analyzed: ca vaṇṇa vādī iti vuttam  anesanam ti dūteyya pahina gamana anuyoga pabhedam nānappakāram anesanam appatirūpam ti
translated: one is content and praises contentment. In order to show this, it is said: “he praises contentment with any old alms.”🔽“Without scheming”: without scheming of various kinds, such as going as an emissary, seeking by way of a request.🔽“Improper”: unsuitable.

original: ayuttaṃ. Aladdhā cāti alabhitvā. Yathā ekacco “kathaṃ nu kho cīvaraṃ labhissāmī”ti.
analyzed: ayuttam a laddhā ca ati a labhitvā yathā ekacco katham nu kho cīvaram labhissāmi iti
translated: “Without hankering”: without longing.

original: Puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ ekato hutvā kohaññaṃ karonto uttasati paritasati,
analyzed: puññavantehi bhikkhūhi saddhim ekatas hutvā kohaññam karontaḥ uttasati paritasati
translated: and he is afraid, he is terrified, he is struck with horror,🔽

original: santuṭṭho bhikkhu evaṃ aladdhā cīvaraṃ na paritasati. Laddhā cāti dhammena samena🔽labhitvā. Agadhitoti vigatalobhagiddho. Amucchitoti adhimattataṇhāya mucchaṃ anāpanno.
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ bhikkhu evam a laddhā cīvaram na paritasati laddhā ca ati dhammena samena  labhitvā agadhita uti vigata lobha giddhaḥ amucchita uti adhimatta taṇhāya muccham an āpannaḥ
translated: When he is satisfied with the kind of robe he gets, he does not advertise himself as being contented, nor does he despise others.🔽When he is satisfied with the kind of alms food he gets, he does not advertise himself as being contented, nor does he despise others.🔽When he is satisfied with the kind of resting place he gets, he does not advertise himself as being contented, nor does he despise others.🔽When he is satisfied with the kind of medicinal requisites he gets, he does not advertise himself as being contented, nor does he despise others.

original: Anajjhāpannoti taṇhāya anotthato apariyonaddho. Ādīnavadassāvīti anesanāpattiyañca🔽gedhitaparibhoge ca ādīnavaṃ passamāno. Nissaraṇapaññoti “yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāyā”ti🔽vuttaṃ nissaraṇameva pajānanto.
analyzed: an ajjhāpannaḥ ti taṇhāya an otthataḥ a pariyonaddhaḥ ādīnava dassāvī iti anesanāpattiyam ca  gedhita paribhoge ca ādīnavam passamānaḥ nissaraṇa pañño ti yāvat eva sītassa paṭighātāya ati  vuttam nissaraṇam eva pajānantaḥ
translated: He is not envious of the gains, honours, and fame got by others.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.

original: Itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyāti yena kenaci cīvarena santuṭṭhiyā. Nevattānukkaṃsetīti
analyzed: itarītara cīvara santuṭṭhiyā ati yena kenacid cīvarena santuṭṭhiyā na ivattā anukkaṃseti iti
translated: He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.🔽He does not envy others’ gains, honours, and fame.

original: “ahaṃ paṃsukūliko mayā upasampadamāḷeyeva paṃsukūlikaṅgaṃ gahitaṃ, ko mayā sadiso
analyzed: aham paṃsukūlikaḥ mayā upasampadam āḷeya iva paṃsukūlika aṅgam gahitam kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ
translated: “I’m a wearer of rag-robes. I took up the practice of wearing rag-robes as soon as I was ordained. Who’s like me?

original: atthī”ti attukkaṃsanaṃ na karoti. Na paraṃ vambhetīti “ime panaññe bhikkhū na paṃsukūlikā”ti
analyzed: atthi iti attukkaṃsanam na karoti na param vambheti iti ime pana aññe bhikkhū na paṃsukūlikā ati
translated: he does not praise himself. He does not disparage others: “But these other bhikkhus are not refuse-rag wearers.”🔽

original: vā “paṃsukūlikaṅgamattampi etesaṃ natthī”ti vā evaṃ paraṃ na vambheti. Yo hi tattha🔽dakkhoti yo tasmiṃ cīvarasantose, vaṇṇavādādīsu vā dakkho cheko byatto. Analasoti🔽sātaccakiriyāya ālasiyavirahito. Sampajāno paṭissatoti sampajānapaññāya ceva satiyā
analyzed: vā etesam natthi iti vai evam param na vambheti yaḥ hi tattha  dakkhaḥ ti yaḥ tasmim cīvara santose vaṇṇa vāda ādīsu vā dakkhaḥ chekaḥ byattaḥ analaso ti  sātacca kiriyāya ālasiya virahitaḥ sampajāno paṭissatoti sampajāna paññāya ca iva satiyā
translated: He does not praise himself. He does not disparage others: he does not disparage others by saying, “These other bhikkhus are not refuse-rag wearers” or “They do not even have the refuse-rag ascetic practice.” For he who is

original: ca yutto. Ariyavaṃse ṭhitoti ariyavaṃse patiṭṭhito.🔽Itarītarena piṇḍapātenāti yena kenaci piṇḍapātena. Etthāpi piṇḍapāto jānitabbo. Piṇḍapātakkhettaṃ
analyzed: ca yuttaḥ ariya vaṃse ṭhito ti ariya vaṃse patiṭṭhito  itarītarena piṇḍapātena ati yena kenacid piṇḍapātena ettha api piṇḍapātaḥ jānitabbaḥ piṇḍapāta khettam
translated: clever in that kind of ascetic practice or in the advertising of it, etc., is not a true ascetic. He is not lazy: he is not lazy in the performance of energy. He is mindful and clearly comprehending: he is endowed with the mindfulness that is the state of one who possesses clear comprehension. He is established in the Noble Ones’ heritage: he is established in the Noble Ones’ heritage of virtue.

original: jānitabbaṃ, piṇḍapātasantoso jānitabbo, piṇḍapātapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ jānitabbaṃ.
analyzed: jānitabbam piṇḍapāta santosaḥ jānitabbaḥ piṇḍapāta paṭisaṃyuttam dhutaṅgam jānitabbam
translated: With any kind of alms food: here too the alms food should be understood. The alms-food resort should be understood, the satisfaction of the alms-food ascetic practice should be understood, and the ascetic practice of alms food as a practice should be understood.

original: Tattha piṇḍapātoti “odano, kummāso, sattu, maccho, maṃsaṃ, khīraṃ, dadhi, sappi,
analyzed: tattha piṇḍapāto ti odanaḥ kummāsaḥ sattu macchaḥ maṃsam khīram dadhi sappi
translated: Herein, alms food is rice gruel, cooked rice, cakes, etc.,

original: navanītaṃ, telaṃ, madhu, phāṇitaṃ, yāgu, khādanīyaṃ, sāyanīyaṃ, lehanīya”nti soḷasa piṇḍapātā.🔽Piṇḍapātakkhettanti saṅghabhattaṃ, uddesabhattaṃ, nimantanaṃ, salākabhattaṃ, pakkhikaṃ,
analyzed: navanītam telam madhu phāṇitam yāgu khādanīyam sāyanīyam lehanīyanti soḍasa piṇḍapātā  piṇḍapāta khettanti saṅgha bhattam uddesa bhattam nimantanam salāka bhattam pakkhikam
translated: fresh butter, oil, honey, sugar, rice porridge, fresh food, cooked food, and what is licked up.

original: uposathikaṃ, pāṭipadikaṃ, āgantukabhattaṃ, gamikabhattaṃ, gilānabhattaṃ, gilānupaṭṭhākabhattaṃ,
analyzed: uposathikam pāṭipadikam āgantuka bhattam gamika bhattam gilāna bhattam gilāna upaṭṭhāka bhattam
translated: A field of merit for almsfood: a meal for the Sangha, a meal for a specific number of monks, a meal for the present community of monks, a meal for visitors, a meal for those setting out on a journey, a meal for sick people, a meal for those who are nursing the sick,

original: dhurabhattaṃ, kuṭibhattaṃ, vārabhattaṃ, vihārabhattanti pannarasa piṇḍapātakkhettāni.
analyzed: dhurabhattam kuṭibhattam vārabhattam vihārabhattanti pannarasa piṇḍapāta kkhettāni
translated: a meal offered by means of a ticket, a meal offered by means of announcement, a meal offered by the king, a meal offered by the king’s minister, a meal offered by the king’s minister.

original: Piṇḍapātasantosoti piṇḍapāte vitakkasantoso, gamanasantoso, pariyesanasantoso paṭilābhasantoso,🔽paṭiggahaṇasantoso, mattappaṭiggahaṇasantoso, loluppavivajjanasantoso, yathālābhasantoso,
analyzed: piṇḍapāta santosaḥ ti piṇḍapāte vitakka santosaḥ gamana santosaḥ pariyesana santosaḥ paṭilābha santosaḥ  paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ mattappaṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ loluppa vivajjana santosaḥ yathā lābha santosaḥ
translated: Contentment with almsfood: contentment with the thought of almsfood, contentment with going, contentment with searching, contentment with obtaining,🔽contentment with receiving, contentment with moderation in receiving, contentment with the avoidance of greed, contentment with what is obtained,

original: yathābalasantoso, yathāsāruppasantoso, upakārasantoso, parimāṇasantoso, paribhogasantoso,
analyzed: yathā bala santosaḥ yathā sāruppa santosaḥ upakāra santosaḥ parimāṇa santosaḥ paribhoga santosaḥ
translated: contentment with what is suitable, contentment with what is beneficial, contentment with the measure, contentment with enjoyment,

original: sannidhiparivajjanasantoso, vissajjanasantosoti pannarasa santosā.
analyzed: sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ vissajjana santosaḥ ti pannarasa santosā
translated: Contentment in avoiding hoarding is the fifteenth kind of contentment.

original: Tattha sādako bhikkhu mukhaṃ dhovitvā vitakketi. Piṇḍapātikena pana gaṇena saddhiṃ
analyzed: tattha sādakaḥ bhikkhu mukham dhovitvā vitakketi piṇḍapātikena pana gaṇena saddhiṃ
translated: Herein, a monk who is a good hand at it washes his face and then thinks:

original: caratā sāyaṃ therūpaṭṭhānakāle “sve kattha piṇḍāya carissāmāti asukagāme, bhante”ti,
analyzed: caratā sāyam thera upaṭṭhāna kāle sve kattha piṇḍāya carissāma ati asuka gāme bhante iti
translated: “I shall go for alms with a monk of the same disposition as myself.”

original: ettakaṃ cintetvā tato paṭṭhāya na vitakketabbaṃ. Ekacārikena vitakkamāḷake ṭhatvā
analyzed: ettakam cintetvā tatas paṭṭhāya na vitakketabbam ekacārikena vitakkamāḷake ṭhatvā
translated: He thinks thus far and no more. But one who goes alone should think while standing in the pondering place.

original: vitakketabbaṃ. Tato paraṃ vitakkento ariyavaṃsā cuto hoti paribāhiro. Ayaṃ vitakkasantoso nāma.🔽Piṇḍāya pavisantena “kuhiṃ labhissāmī”ti acintetvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena gantabbaṃ. Ayaṃ gamanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: vitakketabbam tato param vitakkentaḥ ariya vaṃsā cutaḥ hoti paribāhiraḥ ayam vitakka santosaḥ nāma  piṇḍāya pavisantena kuhim labhissāmi iti a cintetvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena gantabbam ayam gamana santosaḥ nāma
translated: If he thinks beyond that, he is outside the Noble Ones’ Dhamma. This is called contentment in thinking.🔽When he goes in for alms, he should not think, “Where shall I get a good meal?” He should go with his meditation subject at the forefront. This is called contentment in going.

original: Pariyesantena yaṃ vā taṃ vā agahetvā lajjiṃ pesalameva gahetvā pariyesitabbaṃ. Ayaṃ pariyesanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: pariyesantena yam vā tam vā a gahetvā lajjim pesalam eva gahetvā pariyesitabbam ayam pariyesana santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he is seeking alms, he should seek them without taking what is not given, and he should seek them with modesty, not with a conceited manner. This is called contentment in seeking.

original: Dūratova āhariyamānaṃ disvā “etaṃ manāpaṃ, etaṃ amanāpa”nti cittaṃ na uppādetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ paṭilābhasantoso nāma.
analyzed: dūratas vā āhariyamānam disvā etam manāpam etam amanāpanti cittam na uppādetabbam ayam paṭilābha santosaḥ nāma
translated: When he sees it being brought from afar, he should not arouse thoughts of “This is agreeable” or “This is disagreeable.” This is called contentment with what is obtained.

original: “Imaṃ manāpaṃ gaṇhissāmi, imaṃ amanāpaṃ na gaṇhissāmī”ti acintetvā yaṃkiñci yāpanamattaṃ gahetabbameva, ayaṃ paṭiggahaṇasantoso nāma.🔽Ettha pana deyyadhammo bahu, dāyako appaṃ dātukāmo, appaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Deyyadhammo🔽bahu, dāyakopi bahuṃ dātukāmo, pamāṇeneva gahetabbaṃ. Deyyadhammo na bahu, dāyakopi
analyzed: imam manāpam gaṇhissāmi imam amanāpam na gaṇhissāmi iti a cintetvā yaṃ kiñci yāpana mattam gahetabbam eva ayam paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ nāma  ettha pana deyya dhammaḥ bahu dāyakaḥ appam dātu kāmaḥ appam gahetabbam deyya dhammaḥ  bahu dāyakaḥ api bahum dātu kāmo pamāṇena iva gahetabbam deyya dhammaḥ na bahu dāyakaḥ api
translated: Without thinking, “I shall take this agreeable food and not that disagreeable food,” he should take just enough to keep him alive. This is called contentment with what is received.

original: appaṃ dātukāmo, appaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Deyyadhammo na bahu, dāyako pana bahuṃ dātukāmo,
analyzed: appam dātu kāmaḥ appam gahetabbam deyya dhammo na bahu dāyakaḥ pana bahum dātu kāmo
translated: Herein, if the offering is much and the giver wishes to give much, he should take it in moderation. If the offering is much and the giver wishes to give much, he should take it in moderation. If the offering is not much and the giver wishes to give a little, he should take just a little. If the offering is not much and the giver wishes to give a little, he should take just a little. If the offering is much and the giver wishes to give much, he should take it in moderation. If the offering is much and the giver wishes to give much, he should take it in moderation.

original: pamāṇena gahetabbaṃ. Paṭiggahaṇasmiñhi mattaṃ ajānanto manussānaṃ pasādaṃ makkheti,
analyzed: pamāṇena gahetabbam paṭiggahaṇasmin hi mattam a jānantaḥ manussānam pasādam makkheti
translated: For if he does not know moderation in receiving, he spoils people’s confidence,

original: saddhādeyyaṃ vinipāteti, sāsanaṃ na karoti, vijātamātuyāpi cittaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: saddhā ādeyyam vinipāta iti sāsanam na karoti vijāta mātuyā api cittam gahetum na sakkoti
translated: he misappropriates what is given in faith, he does not honour the tradition, and he is unable to take the mother and father of the living being into account.

original: Iti mattaṃ jānitvāva paṭiggahetabbanti ayaṃ mattappaṭiggahaṇasantoso nāma.
analyzed: iti mattam jānitvā ava paṭiggahetabbanti ayam matta paṭiggahaṇa santosaḥ nāma
translated: Knowing the right amount, he should receive accordingly: this is called contentment with what has been received.

original: Saddhakulāniyeva agantvā dvārappaṭipāṭiyā gantabbaṃ. Ayaṃ loluppavivajjanasantoso nāma. Yathālābhasantosādayo cīvare vuttanayā eva.
analyzed: saddha kulāniyā iva a gantvā dvāra paṭipāṭiyā gantabbam ayam loluppa vivajjana santosaḥ nāma yathā lābha santosa ādayaḥ cīvare eva
translated: He should go round for alms in the proper order without skipping houses: this is called contentment that avoids what is deprecated. The contentment with what is obtained and so on are as stated in the case of robes.

original: Piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā samaṇadhammaṃ anupālessāmīti evaṃ upakāraṃ ñatvā paribhuñjanaṃ upakārasantoso nāma.
analyzed: piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā samaṇa dhammam anupālessāmi iti evam upakāram ñatvā paribhuñjanam upakāra santosaḥ nāma
translated: After eating alms food, he should practice the ascetic’s duties: this is called contentment with what is useful.

original: Pattaṃ pūretvā ānītaṃ na paṭiggahetabbaṃ, anupasampanne sati tena gāhāpetabbaṃ, asati harāpetvā paṭiggahaṇamattaṃ gahetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ parimāṇasantoso nāma.
analyzed: pattam pūretvā ānītam na paṭiggahetabbam an upasampanne sati tena gāhāpetabbam asati harāpetvā paṭiggahaṇa mattam gahetabbam ayam parimāṇa santosaḥ nāma
translated: He should not receive more than a full bowl, and if there is a novice attendant, he should have him carry it. If there is no novice attendant, he should have it carried by someone else and then receive it himself. This is called contentment with the right measure.

original: “Jighacchāya paṭivinodanaṃ idamettha nissaraṇa”nti evaṃ paribhuñjanaṃ paribhogasantoso nāma.
analyzed: jighacchāya paṭivinodanam idam ettha nissaraṇa nti evam paribhuñjanam paribhoga santosaḥ nāma
translated: He should eat thinking: “This I will use to dispel hunger and to nourish my life for the sake of practicing the ascetic’s duties.” This is called contentment with using.

original: Nidahitvā na paribhuñjitabbanti ayaṃ sannidhiparivajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: nidahitvā na paribhuñjitabbanti ayam sannidhi parivajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: He should not eat without putting aside some alms food. This is called contentment that avoids storing.

original: Mukhaṃ anoloketvā sāraṇīyadhamme ṭhitena vissajjetabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vissajjanasantoso nāma.
analyzed: mukham anoloketvā sāraṇīya dhamme ṭhitena vissajjetabbam ayam vissajjana santosaḥ nāma
translated: He should answer without looking at the face, but standing on the subject of affectionate speech. This is called contentment with answers.

original: Piṇḍapātapaṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni – piṇḍapātikaṅgaṃ, sapadānacārikaṅgaṃ,
analyzed: piṇḍapāta paṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni piṇḍapātikaṅgam sa padāna cārikaṅgam
translated: But the five ascetic practices connected with alms food are the alms-food-eater’s practice, the house-to-house seeker’s practice,

original: ekāsanikaṅgaṃ, pattapiṇḍikaṅgaṃ, khalupacchābhattikaṅganti. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā visuddhimagge
analyzed: eka āsanika patta piṇḍika aṅgam khalu pacchābhattika anti tesam vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge
translated: the one-sessioner’s practice, the bowl-food eater’s practice, and the later-food-refuser’s practice. The detailed explanation of these is given in the Path of Purity .

original: vuttā. Iti piṇḍapātasantosamahāariyavaṃsaṃ pūrayamāno bhikkhu imāni pañca dhutaṅgāni🔽gopeti. Imāni gopento piṇḍapātasantosamahāariyavaṃsena santuṭṭho hoti. “Vaṇṇavādī”tiādīni
analyzed: vuttāḥ iti piṇḍapāta santosa mahāariya vaṃsam pūrayamānaḥ bhikkhu imāni pañca dhutaṅgāni  gopa iti imāni gopentaḥ piṇḍapāta santosa mahāariya vaṃsena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti vaṇṇa vādī itiādīni
translated: So a bhikkhu who is fulfilling the Great Man’s Headquarters of Contentment with Alms Food keeps to these five ascetic practices.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: By keeping them he is content with the Great Man’s Headquarters of Contentment with Alms Food. The words “one who commends” and so on are to be understood in the way already given.🔽As to “a dwelling”: here the kind of dwelling to be understood, the field for the use of a dwelling,

original: Senāsanenāti idha senāsanaṃ jānitabbaṃ, senāsanakkhettaṃ jānitabbaṃ, senāsanasantoso
analyzed: senāsanena ati idha senāsanam jānitabbam senāsana khettam jānitabbam senāsana santosaḥ
translated: contentment with a dwelling,

original: jānitabbo, senāsanapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ jānitabbaṃ. Tattha senāsananti mañco,
analyzed: jānitabbaḥ senāsana paṭisaṃyuttam dhutaṅgam jānitabbam tattha senāsanan ti mañcaḥ
translated: and the ascetic practice connected with dwellings should be understood. Herein, the kind of dwelling is a bed, a chair,

original: pīṭhaṃ, bhisi, bimbohanaṃ, vihāro, aḍḍhayogo, pāsādo, hammiyaṃ, guhā, leṇaṃ, aṭṭo,
analyzed: pīṭham bhisi bimbohanam vihāraḥ aḍḍha yogaḥ pāsādaḥ hammiyam guhā leṇam aṭṭaḥ
translated: a seat, a bed, a couch, a mat, a room, a two-storied building, a mansion, a hut, a cave, a cell, a shed,

original: māḷo, veḷugumbo, rukkhamūlaṃ, yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamantīti imāni pannarasa senāsanāni.
analyzed: māḷaḥ veḷu gumbaḥ rukkha mūlam yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti iti imāni pannarasa senāsanāni
translated: a courtyard, a threshing-sleet, the foot of a tree, or wherever bhikkhus live.

original: Senāsanakkhettanti “saṅghato vā gaṇato vā ñātito vā mittato vā attano vā dhanena paṃsukūlaṃ vā”ti cha khettāni.
analyzed: senāsana khettanti saṅghataḥ vā gaṇataḥ vā ñātitaḥ vā mittataḥ vā attanaḥ vā dhanena paṃsukūlam vā ati cha khettāni
translated: The “field” for the dwelling is one of six kinds: from the Community, from a group, from a relation, from a friend, from one’s own hand, or rags from a midden.

original: Senāsanasantosoti senāsane vitakkasantosādayo pannarasa santosā. Te piṇḍapāte vuttanayeneva
analyzed: senāsana santoso ti senāsane vitakka santosa ādayo santosā te piṇḍapāte vutta nayena iva
translated: The “satisfaction” in dwellings is the fifteen kinds of satisfaction beginning with the reflection on dwellings. These should be understood in the way given in the case of alms food.

original: veditabbā. Senāsanapaṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni – āraññikaṅgaṃ, rukkhamūlikaṅgaṃ,
analyzed: veditabbā senāsana paṭisaṃyuttāni pana pañca dhutaṅgāni āraññika aṅgam rukkhamūlika aṅgam
translated: But the five ascetic practices connected with dwellings are the practice of living in the forest, the practice of living at the foot of a tree,

original: abbhokāsikaṅgaṃ, sosānikaṅgaṃ, yathāsantatikaṅganti. Tesaṃ vitthārakathā visuddhimagge
analyzed: abbhokāsikaṅgam sosānikaṅgam yathā santatikaṅganti tesam vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge
translated: the practice of living in the open air, the practice of living in a charnel ground, and the practice of being a one-part-possessor. The detailed explanation of these is given in the Path of Purity .

original: vuttā. Iti senāsanasantosamahāariyavaṃsaṃ pūrayamāno bhikkhu imāni pañca dhutaṅgāni
analyzed: vuttāḥ iti senāsana santosa mahāariya vaṃsam pūrayamānaḥ bhikkhu imāni pañca dhutaṅgāni
translated: So a bhikkhu who is fulfilling the Great Man’s duty of satisfaction with dwellings should

original: gopeti. Imāni gopento senāsanasantosamahāariyavaṃsena santuṭṭho hoti.
analyzed: gopa iti imāni gopentaḥ senāsana santosa mahāariya vaṃsena santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: He guards them. In guarding them he is satisfied with the kind of resting place that is just sufficient to give protection from the four kinds of inclemency.

original: Gilānapaccayo pana piṇḍapāteyeva paviṭṭho. Tattha yathālābhayathābalayathāsāruppasantoseneva santussitabbaṃ. Nesajjikaṅgaṃ bhāvanārāmaariyavaṃsaṃ bhajati. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: gilāna paccayo pana piṇḍapāteya iva paviṭṭhaḥ tattha yathā lābha yathā bala yathā sāruppa santosena iva santussitabbam nesajjika aṅgam bhāvanā ārāma ariya vaṃsam bhajati vuttam pi ca itam
translated: The requisite of medicine as cure for the sick is included in alms food. Herein, he should be satisfied with what he gets, using it for mere sustenance, according to the rule of life. The ascetic practice of the refuse-rag-wearer is included in the third noble heritage, which is satisfaction. And this is said:🔽“Five in the case of the resting places,

original: “Pañca senāsane vuttā, pañca āhāranissitā;
analyzed: pañca senāsane vuttā pañca āhāra nissitā
translated: Five in the case of the kinds of food,🔽One in the case of the energy,

original: Eko vīriyasaṃyutto, dve ca cīvaranissitā”ti.🔽Iti āyasmā dhammasenāpati sāriputtatthero pathaviṃ pattharamāno viya sāgarakucchiṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ vīriya saṃyuttaḥ dve ca cīvara nissitā ati  iti āyasmā dhammasenāpati sāriputta theraḥ pathavim pattharamānaḥ viya sāgarakucchim
translated: And two in the case of the robes.”🔽So the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, having expounded the first noble heritage, which is satisfaction with the kind of robe that is just sufficient to keep the cold and the heat off and to cover the parts of the body that ought to be covered,🔽like one who measures out the earth, like one who fills the ocean with his arms, like one who spans the sky with his hand,

original: pūrayamāno viya ākāsaṃ vitthārayamāno viya ca paṭhamaṃ cīvarasantosaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ🔽kathetvā candaṃ uṭṭhāpento viya sūriyaṃ ullaṅghento viya ca dutiyaṃ piṇḍapātasantosaṃ
analyzed: pūrayamānaḥ viya ākāsam vitthārayamānaḥ viya ca paṭhamam cīvara santosam ariya vaṃsam  kathetvā candam uṭṭhāpentaḥ viya sūriyam ullaṅghentaḥ viya ca dutiyam piṇḍapāta santosam
translated: like one who raises up Mount Sineru, like one who makes the wind and fire not burn and not burn,

original: kathetvā sineruṃ ukkhipento viya tatiyaṃ senāsanasantosaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ kathetvā idāni
analyzed: kathetvā sinerum ukkhipentaḥ viya tatiyam senāsana santosam ariya vaṃsam kathetvā idāni
