translated: like one who makes the sun and moon go by his order, like one who makes the four kings of the gods his servants, like one who makes Brahmā his pupil, like one who makes Māra his friend, like one who makes Death his servant, like one who makes Nāga his slave, like one who makes the whole world with its gods his slave, like one who makes the four great kings his doorkeepers, like one who makes the thirty-three gods his servants, like one who makes the whole world with its deities, its Māras and Brahmas, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, princes and people, to submit to the Buddha’s will, like one who makes the whole world with its gods, its Māras and Brahmas, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, princes and people, to submit to the Dhamma’s will, like one who makes the whole world with its gods, its Māras and Brahmas, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, princes and people, to submit to the Saṅgha’s will, like one who makes the whole world with its gods, its Māras and Brahmas, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, princes

original: sahassanayappaṭimaṇḍitaṃ catutthaṃ bhāvanārāmaṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ kathetuṃ puna caparaṃ
analyzed: sahassa naya paṭimaṇḍitam catuttham bhāvanā ārāmam ariya vaṃsam kathetum puna ca param
translated: He has a thousand ways of teaching. He has the fourth noble lineage, that of delight in development.

original: āvuso bhikkhu pahānārāmo hotīti desanaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: āvuso bhikkhu pahāna ārāmaḥ hoti iti desanam ārabhi
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu delights in and is devoted to abandonment” .

original: Tattha āramanaṃ ārāmo, abhiratīti attho. Pañcavidhe pahāne ārāmo assāti pahānārāmo.🔽Kāmacchandaṃ pajahanto ramati, nekkhammaṃ bhāvento ramati, byāpādaṃ pajahanto ramati…pe…🔽sabbakilese pajahanto ramati, arahattamaggaṃ bhāvento ramatīti evaṃ pahāne ratoti
analyzed: tattha āramanam ārāmaḥ abhirati iti pañcavidhe pahāne ārāmaḥ assa ati pahāna ārāmaḥ  kāma chandam pajahantaḥ ramati nekkhammam bhāventaḥ ramati byāpādam pajahantaḥ ramati pe  sabba kilese pajahantaḥ ramati arahatta maggam bhāventaḥ ramati iti evam pahāne
translated: Herein, delighting in is delight; being devoted to is being devoted to. He is devoted to the five kinds of abandonment.🔽He delights in abandoning sensual desire, he delights in developing renunciation, he delights in abandoning ill will, … he delights in abandoning stiffness and torpor, … he delights in abandoning agitation and worry, … he delights in abandoning uncertainty, he delights in developing the knowledge of the ariyan way, he delights in abandoning all the defilements. Thus he delights in abandonment.

original: pahānarato. Vuttanayeneva bhāvanāya ārāmo assāti bhāvanārāmo. Bhāvanāya ratoti bhāvanārato.🔽Imesu pana catūsu ariyavaṃsesu purimehi tīhi terasannaṃ dhutaṅgānaṃ catupaccayasantosassa
analyzed: pahāna rataḥ vutta nayena iva bhāvanāya ārāmaḥ assa ati bhāvanā ārāmaḥ bhāvanāya rato ti bhāvanā rataḥ  imesu pana catūsu ariya vaṃsesu purimehi tīhi dhutaṅgānam catu paccaya santosassa
translated: He is devoted to development. He delights in development.🔽Now, in these four noble lineages, the first three are stated by way of the thirteen austerities and the contentment with any requisites whatsoever.

original: ca vasena sakalaṃ vinayapiṭakaṃ kathitaṃ hoti. Bhāvanārāmena avasesaṃ piṭakadvayaṃ.
analyzed: ca vasena sakalam vinaya piṭakam kathitam bhāvanā ārāmena avasesam piṭaka dvayam
translated: The fourth is stated by way of the rest of the two Piṭakas.

original: Imaṃ pana bhāvanārāmataṃ ariyavaṃsaṃ kathentena bhikkhunā paṭisambhidāmagge nekkhammapāḷiyā
analyzed: imam pana bhāvanā ārāmatam ariya vaṃsam kathentena bhikkhunā paṭisambhidā magge nekkhamma pāḷiyā
translated: When a bhikkhu is expounding this noble lineage that delights in development, he should expound it by the section on renunciation in the Path of Discrimination,🔽he should expound it by the ten-chapter exposition in the Long Division,

original: kathetabbo. Dīghanikāye dasuttarasuttantapariyāyena kathetabbo. Majjhimanikāye satipaṭṭhānasuttantapariyāyena
analyzed: kathetabbaḥ dīgha nikāye dasuttara suttanta pariyāyena kathetabbaḥ majjhima nikāye sati paṭṭhāna suttanta pariyāyena
translated: he should expound it by the chapter on the foundations of mindfulness in the Middle Length Sayings,

original: kathetabbo. Abhidhamme niddesapariyāyena kathetabbo.
analyzed: kathetabbaḥ abhidhamme niddesa pariyāyena kathetabbaḥ
translated: he should expound it by the chapter on the analysis in the Abhidhamma.🔽Herein, “in the Path of Discrimination by the section on renunciation” means that he delights in developing renunciation,

original: Tattha paṭisambhidāmagge nekkhammapāḷiyāti so nekkhammaṃ bhāvento ramati, kāmacchandaṃ🔽pajahanto ramati. Abyāpādaṃ byāpādaṃ. Ālokasaññaṃ, thinamiddhaṃ. Avikkhepaṃ uddhaccaṃ.
analyzed: tattha paṭisambhidā magge nekkhamma pāḷiyāti saḥ nekkhammam bhāventaḥ ramati kāmacchandam  pajahantaḥ ramati a byāpādam byāpādam āloka saññam thinamiddham a vikkhepam uddhaccam
translated: he delights in abandoning sensual desire,🔽he delights in non-ill-will, ill-will,🔽he delights in the perception of light, sloth and torpor, non-distraction, agitation,🔽he delights in defining of ideas, uncertainty, knowledge, ignorance,

original: Dhammavavatthānaṃ, vicikicchaṃ. Ñāṇaṃ, avijjaṃ. Pāmojjaṃ, aratiṃ. Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ,
analyzed: dhamma vavatthānam vicikiccham ñāṇam avijjam pāmojjam aratim paṭhamam jhānam
translated: he delights in gladness, grief, the first meditation,

original: pañca nīvaraṇe. Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ, vitakkavicāre. Tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ, pītiṃ. Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ,
analyzed: pañca nīvaraṇe dutiyam jhānam vitakka vicāre tatiyam jhānam pītim catuttham jhānam
translated: the five hindrances, the second meditation, applied and sustained thought, the third meditation, rapture, the fourth meditation,

original: sukhadukkhe. Ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ bhāvento ramati, rūpasaññaṃ paṭighasaññaṃ
analyzed: sukha dukkhe ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpattim bhāvento ramati rūpa saññam paṭigha saññam
translated: pleasure and pain, he delights in developing the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space, he abandons the perception of materiality, the perception of impingement,

original: nānattasaññaṃ pajahanto ramati. Viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiṃ…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ🔽bhāvento ramati, ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ pajahanto ramati.
analyzed: nānatta saññam pajahantaḥ ramati viññāṇam ca āyatana samāpattim pe nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim  bhāventaḥ ramati ākiñcaññāyatana saññam pajahantaḥ ramati
translated: he delights in giving up the perception of the base of nothingness.🔽He delights in developing the contemplation of impermanence;

original: Aniccānupassanaṃ bhāvento ramati, niccasaññaṃ pajahanto ramati. Dukkhānupassanaṃ,
analyzed: anicca anupassanam bhāventaḥ ramati nicca saññam pajahantaḥ ramati dukkha anupassanam
translated: he delights in giving up the perception of permanence. He delights in developing the contemplation of suffering …🔽the perception of pleasure. He delights in developing the contemplation of not-self …

original: sukhasaññaṃ. Anattānupassanaṃ, attasaññaṃ. Nibbidānupassanaṃ, nandiṃ. Virāgānupassanaṃ,
analyzed: sukha saññam anatta anupassanam atta saññam nibbida anupassanam nandim virāga anupassanam
translated: the perception of self. He delights in developing the contemplation of dispassion …🔽passion. He delights in developing the contemplation of fading away …🔽clinging. He delights in developing the contemplation of cessation …🔽the perception of compactness. He delights in developing the contemplation of relinquishment …

original: rāgaṃ. Nirodhānupassanaṃ, samudayaṃ. Paṭinissaggānupassanaṃ, ādānaṃ. Khayānupassanaṃ,
analyzed: rāgam nirodha anupassanam samudayam paṭinissagga anupassanam ādānam khaya anupassanam
translated: the perception of accumulation. He delights in developing the contemplation of destruction …🔽the perception of continuation. He delights in developing the contemplation of fall …🔽the perception of stability. He delights in developing the contemplation of change …🔽the perception of signs. He delights in developing the contemplation of the signless …🔽longing. He delights in developing the contemplation of emptiness …🔽attachment. He delights in developing the contemplation of the desireless …🔽misapprehension. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena …

original: ghanasaññaṃ. Vayānupassanaṃ, āyūhanaṃ. Vipariṇāmānupassanaṃ, dhuvasaññaṃ. Animittānupassanaṃ,
analyzed: ghana saññam vayā anupassanam āyūhanam vipariṇāma anupassanam dhuva saññam animitta anupassanam
translated: misconception. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misapprehension. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misconception. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misapprehension. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misconception. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misapprehension. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misconception. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misapprehension. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misconception. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …

original: nimittaṃ. Apaṇihitānupassanaṃ, paṇidhiṃ. Suññatānupassanaṃ abhinivesaṃ. Adhipaññādhammavipassanaṃ,🔽sārādānābhinivesaṃ. Yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ, sammohābhinivesaṃ. Ādīnavānupassanaṃ,
analyzed: nimittam apaṇihita anupassanam paṇidhim suññatā anupassanam abhinivesam adhi paññā dhamma vipassanam 🔽sāra ādāna abhinivesam yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam sammoha abhinivesam ādīnava anupassanam
translated: misapprehension. He delights in developing the contemplation of the inﬂuence of mental phenomena as a phenomenon …🔽misconception. He delights

original: ālayābhinivesaṃ. Paṭisaṅkhānupassanaṃ, appaṭisaṅkhaṃ. Vivaṭṭānupassanaṃ, saṃyogābhinivesaṃ.
analyzed: ālaya abhinivesam paṭisaṅkhā anupassanam appaṭisaṅkham vivaṭṭa anupassanam saṃyoga abhinivesam
translated: clinging to the underlying tendency to lust.🔽Contemplation of contemplation is non-contemplation. Contemplation of change is clinging to the underlying tendency to conceit.

original: Sotāpattimaggaṃ, diṭṭhekaṭṭhe kilese. Sakadāgāmimaggaṃ, oḷārike kilese. Anāgāmimaggaṃ,
analyzed: sotāpatti maggam diṭṭhekaṭṭhe kilese sakadāgāmi maggam oḷārike kilese anāgāmi maggam
translated: The Stream-Entry Path is the defilements that are to be abandoned by seeing. The Once-Return Path is the gross defilements. The Non-Return Path is the subtle defilements.

original: aṇusahagate kilese. Arahattamaggaṃ bhāvento ramati, sabbakilese pajahanto ramatīti
analyzed: aṇu sahagate kilese arahatta maggam bhāventaḥ ramati sabba kilese pajahantaḥ ramati iti
translated: The Arahant Path is the defilements that are to be abandoned by cultivation. He delights in developing the Arahant Path, he delights in abandoning all the defilements.

original: evaṃ paṭisambhidāmagge nekkhammapāḷiyā kathetabbo.🔽Dīghanikāye dasuttarasuttantapariyāyenāti ekaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvento ramati, ekaṃ dhammaṃ🔽pajahanto ramati…pe… dasa dhamme bhāvento ramati, dasa dhamme pajahanto ramati. Katamaṃ
analyzed: evam paṭisambhidā magge nekkhamma pāḷiyā kathetabbaḥ  dīgha nikāye dasa uttara suttanta pariyāyena ati ekam dhammam bhāventaḥ ramati ekam dhammam  pajahantaḥ ramati pe dasa dhamme bhāventaḥ ramati dasa dhamme pajahantaḥ ramati katamam
translated: Thus it should be spoken of in the Paṭisambhidā Magga in the section on renunciation.🔽In the Dīgha Nikāya in the Dasuttara Sutta: “He delights in developing one idea, he delights in abandoning one idea … he delights in developing ten ideas, he delights in abandoning ten ideas.” What is the one idea?

original: ekaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvento ramati? Kāyagatāsatiṃ sātasahagataṃ. Imaṃ ekaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvento🔽ramati. Katamaṃ ekaṃ dhammaṃ pajahanto ramati? Asmimānaṃ. Imaṃ ekaṃ dhammaṃ pajahanto
analyzed: ekam dhammam bhāvento ramati kāya gata asatim sāta sahagatam imam ekam dhammam bhāvento 🔽ramati katamam ekam dhammam pajahantaḥ ramati asmimānam imam ekam dhammam pajahantaḥ
translated: He delights in developing mindfulness occupied with the body accompanied by the enjoyment . This is the one idea he delights in developing. What is the one idea he delights in abandoning?🔽The conceit “I am” . This is the one idea he delights in abandoning.

original: ramati. Katame dve dhamme…pe… katame dasa dhamme bhāvento ramati? Dasa kasiṇāyatanāni.
analyzed: ramati katame dve katame dasa dhamme bhāventaḥ ramati dasa kasiṇa āyatanāni
translated: What two things? … What ten things does he delight in developing? The ten universal objects of meditation.

original: Ime dasa dhamme bhāvento ramati. Katame dasa dhamme pajahanto ramati? Dasa micchatte.
analyzed: ime dasa dhamme bhāventaḥ ramati katame dasa dhamme pajahantaḥ ramati dasa micchatte
translated: He delights in developing these ten things. What ten things does he delight in abandoning? The ten wrong courses of action.

original: Ime dasa dhamme pajahanto ramati. Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhāvanārāmo hotīti
analyzed: ime dasa dhamme pajahantaḥ ramati evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu bhāvanā ārāmaḥ hoti iti
translated: He delights in abandoning these ten things. That is how a bhikkhu delights in development.

original: evaṃ dīghanikāye dasuttarasuttantapariyāyena kathetabbo.🔽Majjhimanikāye satipaṭṭhānasuttantapariyāyenāti ekāyano, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṃ🔽visuddhiyā, sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya, dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya, ñāyassa
analyzed: evam dīgha nikāye dasa uttara suttanta pariyāyena kathetabbo  majjhima nikāye sati paṭṭhāna suttanta pariyāyena ati eka ayanaḥ bhikkhave maggo sattānam  visuddhiyā soka paridevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa
translated: Thus should it be told in the Dīgha Nikāya by the method of the Dasuttara Sutta.

original: adhigamāya, nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yadidaṃ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā. Katame cattāro?
analyzed: adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yat idam cattāro sati paṭṭhānā katame cattāro
translated: In the Majjhima Nikāya by the method of the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta: “Bhikkhus, there is one way, and one only, for the purification of beings, for overcoming sorrow and lamentation, for the disappearance of pain and grief, for reaching the right path, for the attainment of Nibbana, and that is the four foundations of mindfulness. What are the four?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati… vedanāsu vedanānupassī… citte
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati vedanāsu vedanā anupassī citte
translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the body in the body, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief regarding the world.🔽He dwells contemplating feelings in feelings, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief regarding the world.🔽He dwells contemplating mind in mind, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief regarding the world.

original: cittānupassī… dhammesu dhammānupassī… ‘atthi dhammā’ti vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā
analyzed: citta anupassī dhammesu dhamma anupassī atthi vā panassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā
translated: He abides contemplating mind as mind, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.🔽He abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. Or else he abides resolved upon the perception of mind-objects in mind-objects, ardent, clearly comprehending, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

original: hoti yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya paṭissatimattāya anissito ca viharati na ca kiñci loke
analyzed: hoti yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya paṭissati mattāya anissitaḥ ca viharati na ca kiñci loke
translated: He abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.

original: upādiyati. Evampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhāvanārāmo hoti bhāvanārato, pahānārāmo hoti
analyzed: upādiyati evam pi bhikkhave bhikkhu bhāvanā ārāmaḥ hoti bhāvanā rataḥ pahāna ārāmaḥ hoti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu is intent on development and devoted to development.

original: pahānarato. Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā gacchāmīti pajānāti…pe…
analyzed: pahāna rataḥ puna caparam bhikkhave bhikkhu gacchantaḥ vā gacchāmi iti pajānāti pe
translated: Again, a bhikkhu, when going, knows “I am going”;

original: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṃ…pe…
analyzed: puna caparam bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya
translated: Again, a bhikkhu, as though he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, connected with sinews…

original: pūtīni cuṇṇakajātāni. So imameva kāyaṃ upasaṃharati, ayampi kho kāyo evaṃdhammo evaṃbhāvī
analyzed: pūtīni cuṇṇaka jātāni saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaṃharati ayam pi kho kāyaḥ evaṃdhammaḥ evaṃbhāvī
translated: He compares this his own body with that one thus: “This body too is of the same nature, will become like that, and is not exempt from that fate.”🔽Thus he abides contemplating the body as a body internally, externally, and both internally and externally.

original: evaṃanatītoti. Iti ajjhattaṃ vā kāye kāyānupassī viharati…pe… evampi kho, bhikkhave,
analyzed: evaṃanatītaḥ ti iti ajjhattam vā kāye kāya anupassī viharati evam pi kho bhikkhave
translated: Or else he abides contemplating the nature of arising in the body, or he abides contemplating the nature of vanishing in the body, or he abides contemplating the nature of arising and vanishing in the body.🔽Or else mindfulness that “there is a body” is simply established in him to the extent necessary for bare knowledge and mindfulness.🔽And he abides independent, not clinging to anything in the world.🔽That is how a bhikkhu is intent on development and devoted to development.

original: bhikkhu bhāvanārāmo hotīti evaṃ majjhimanikāye satipaṭṭhānasuttantapariyāyena kathetabbo.
analyzed: bhikkhu bhāvanā ārāmaḥ hoti iti evam majjhima nikāye sati paṭṭhāna suttanta pariyāyena kathetabbo
translated: This is how the exposition should be understood as to the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: Abhidhamme niddesapariyāyenāti sabbepi saṅkhate aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato…pe…
analyzed: abhidhamme niddesa pariyāyena ati sabbe pi saṅkhate aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ rogataḥ
translated: In the Abhidhamma, by the method of exposition: when he sees all formations as impermanent, painful, a disease, a tumour, a dart, a calamity, an affliction, as alien, as disintegrating, as a plague, a disaster, a terror, a menace, as fickle, perishable, unenduring, as no protection, no shelter, no refuge, as empty, vain, not-self, he delights in development.

original: saṃkilesikadhammato passanto ramati. Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhāvanārāmo hotīti
analyzed: saṃkilesika dhammato passantaḥ ramati ayam bhikkhave bhikkhu bhāvanā ārāmaḥ hoti iti
translated: This bhikkhu delights in development.

original: evaṃ niddesapariyāyena kathetabbo.
analyzed: evam niddesa pariyāyena kathetabbo
translated: This is how he should be told.

original: Neva attānukkaṃsetīti ajja me saṭṭhi vā sattati vā vassāni aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattāti
analyzed: na iva attā anukkaṃseti iti ajja me saṭṭhi vā sattati vā vassāni aniccam dukkham anattā ati
translated: He does not exalt himself: today I have done the task of insight into “impermanent, painful, not-self” for sixty or seventy years.

original: vipassanāya kammaṃ karontassa, ko mayā sadiso atthīti evaṃ attukkaṃsanaṃ na karoti.🔽Na paraṃ vambhetīti aniccaṃ dukkhanti vipassanāmattakampi natthi, kiṃ ime vissaṭṭhakammaṭṭhānā
analyzed: vipassanāya kammam karontassa kaḥ mayā sadisaḥ atthi iti evam attukkaṃsanam na karoti  na param vambheti iti aniccam dukkham ti vipassanā mattakam pi natthi kim ime vissaṭṭha kammaṭṭhānā
translated: He does not exalt himself, thinking “Who is there equal to me?”

original: carantīti evaṃ paraṃ vambhanaṃ na karoti. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: caranti iti evam param vambhanam na karoti sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: He does not despise others: there is not even the mere name “insight” left, so how can these people be practising the meditation subject wandering about with their feet in fetters? He does not despise others. The rest is as already stated.

original: 310. Padhānānīti uttamavīriyāni. Saṃvarapadhānanti cakkhādīni saṃvarantassa uppannavīriyaṃ.
analyzed: padhānāni iti uttama vīriyāni saṃvara padhānam ti cakkha ādīni saṃvarantassa uppanna vīriyam
translated: The kinds of endeavour: the supreme kinds of energy. Restraint endeavour: the energy that arises in one who restrains eye-consciousness, etc.

original: Pahānapadhānanti kāmavitakkādayo pajahantassa uppannavīriyaṃ. Bhāvanāpadhānanti bojjhaṅge
analyzed: pahāna padhānam ti kāma vitakka ādayaḥ pajahantassa uppanna vīriyam bhāvanā apadhānam ti bojjhaṅge
translated: The effort of abandoning is the energy that arises in one who is abandoning sense-desire thoughts, etc.🔽The effort of developing is the energy that arises in one who is developing the enlightenment factors.

original: bhāventassa uppannavīriyaṃ. Anurakkhaṇāpadhānanti samādhinimittaṃ anurakkhantassa uppannavīriyaṃ.
analyzed: bhāventassa uppanna vīriyam anurakkhaṇa apadhānam ti samādhi nimittam anurakkhantassa uppanna vīriyam
translated: The effort of guarding is the energy that arises in one who is guarding the sign of serenity.

original: Vivekanissitantiādīsu viveko virāgo nirodhoti tīṇipi nibbānassa nāmāni. Nibbānañhi
analyzed: viveka nissita nti ādīsu vivekaḥ virāgaḥ nirodhaḥ ti tīṇi pi nibbānassa nāmāni nibbānam hi
translated: In the passages beginning, “Depending on seclusion” , seclusion, fading away, and cessation are three names for Nibbāna.

original: upadhivivekattā viveko. Taṃ āgamma rāgādayo virajjantīti virāgo. Nirujjhantīti nirodho.
analyzed: upadhi viveka ttā vivekaḥ tam āgamma rāga ādayaḥ virajjanti iti virāgaḥ nirujjhanti iti nirodhaḥ
translated: For Nibbāna is seclusion because it is secluded from all the defilements. It is fading away because lust, etc., fade away in it. It is cessation because the defilements cease in it.

original: Tasmā “vivekanissita”ntiādīsu ārammaṇavasena adhigantabbavasena vā nibbānanissitanti
analyzed: tasmā viveka nissita nti ādīsu ārammaṇa vasena adhigantabba vasena vā nibbāna nissitanti
translated: So the meaning of the words “depending on seclusion” , etc., is that they are “dependent on Nibbāna” either as the object or as the attained.

original: attho. Vossaggapariṇāminti ettha dve vossaggā pariccāgavossaggo ca pakkhandanavossaggo
analyzed: ettha dve vossaggā pariṇāmin ti ettha dve vossaggā pariccāga vossaggo ca pakkhandana vossaggo
translated: In the passage beginning with “surrendering” , there are two kinds of surrendering: surrendering by relinquishing and surrendering by entering into.

original: ca. Tattha vipassanā tadaṅgavasena kilese ca khandhe ca pariccajatīti pariccāgavossaggo.
analyzed: ca tattha vipassanā tad aṅga vasena kilese ca khandhe ca pariccajati iti pariccāga vossaggo
translated: Herein, insight surrenders by relinquishing the defilements and aggregates by abandoning them as a factor of final knowledge.

original: Maggo ārammaṇavasena nibbānaṃ pakkhandatīti pakkhandanavossaggo. Tasmā vossaggapariṇāminti
analyzed: maggaḥ ārammaṇa vasena nibbānam pakkhandati iti pakkhandana vossaggo tasmā vossagga pariṇāmin ti
translated: The path is called “the emergence of the penetration of Nibbāna” because it emerges by way of the object of Nibbāna.🔽Therefore it is said: “He develops the enlightenment factor of mindfulness that is based upon seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, maturing in release.”

original: yathā bhāviyamāno satisambojjhaṅgo vossaggatthāya pariṇamati, vipassanābhāvañca maggabhāvañca
analyzed: yathā bhāviyamānaḥ sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ vossagga tthāya pariṇamati vipassanā bhāvañca magga bhāvañca
translated: The meaning is this: he develops the enlightenment factor of mindfulness in such a way that it leads to the relinquishment of the hindrances, and that it leads to the attainment of the state of insight and the state of the path.

original: pāpuṇāti, evaṃ bhāvetīti ayamettha attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: pāpuṇāti evam bhāveti iti ayam ettha attho sesa padesu pi esā iva nayo
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the other cases.

original: Bhadrakanti bhaddakaṃ. Samādhinimittaṃ vuccati aṭṭhikasaññādivasena adhigato samādhiyeva.
analyzed: bhadrakam ti bhaddakam samādhi nimittam vuccati aṭṭhika saññā ādi vasena adhigataḥ samādhiyā iva
translated: The “excellent” is the sign of concentration, which is called “excellent” because it is the attainment of concentration itself by way of the perception of a skeleton, etc.

original: Anurakkhatīti samādhiparibandhakadhamme rāgadosamohe sodhento rakkhati. Ettha ca
analyzed: anurakkhati iti samādhi paribandhaka dhamme rāga dosa mohe sodhentaḥ rakkhati ettha ca
translated: “He guards” means he protects by purifying the defilements that are the hindrances to concentration, such as lust, hatred, and delusion.

original: aṭṭhikasaññādikā pañceva saññā vuttā. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne dasapi asubhāni vitthāretvā
analyzed: aṭṭhika saññā ādikā pañca iva saññā vuttā imasmin pana ṭhāne dasa api asubhāni vitthāretvā
translated: Here only the five perceptions beginning with the perception of a skeleton are mentioned. But in this context the ten kinds of foulness should be explained in detail.

original: kathetabbāni. Tesaṃ vitthāro visuddhimagge vuttoyeva.
analyzed: kathetabbāni tesam vitthāraḥ visuddhi magge vuttaḥ yeva
translated: The details are given in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Dhamme ñāṇanti ekapaṭivedhavasena catusaccadhamme ñāṇaṃ catusaccabbhantare nirodhasacce
analyzed: dhamme ñāṇanti eka paṭivedha vasena catu sacca dhamme ñāṇam catu sacca abbhantare nirodha sacce
translated: “Knowledge of ideas”: the knowledge of the four noble truths by way of a single penetration.

original: dhamme ñāṇañca. Yathāha – “tattha katamaṃ dhamme ñāṇaṃ? Catūsu maggesu catūsu phalesu🔽ñāṇa”nti. Anvaye ñāṇanti cattāri saccāni paccakkhato disvā yathā idāni, evaṃ atītepi
analyzed: dhamme ñāṇam ca yathā āha tattha katamam dhamme ñāṇam catūsu maggesu catūsu phalesu  anvaye ñāṇanti cattāri saccāni paccakkhataḥ disvā yathā idāni evam atīte pi
translated: and knowledge of ideas. As it is said: “Herein, what is knowledge of ideas? It is knowledge in the four paths and in the four fruits🔽of the path.

original: anāgatepi imeva pañcakkhandhā dukkhasaccaṃ, ayameva taṇhā samudayasaccaṃ, ayameva
analyzed: anāgate pi ime eva pañca kkhandhāḥ dukkha saccam ayam eva taṇhā samudaya saccam ayam eva
translated: Knowledge of the way is the knowledge that follows upon the seeing of the four truths by one’s own direct experience, in the way that ‘These five aggregates are the truth of suffering in the past,

original: nirodho nirodhasaccaṃ, ayameva maggo maggasaccanti evaṃ tassa ñāṇassa anugatiyaṃ
analyzed: nirodhaḥ nirodha saccam ayam eva maggaḥ magga saccanti evam tassa ñāṇassa anugatiyam
translated: in the future, and in the present too, this craving is the truth of origin, this cessation of it is the truth of cessation, and this is the truth of the path’ .

original: ñāṇaṃ. Tenāha – “so iminā dhammena ñātena diṭṭhena pattena viditena pariyogāḷhena🔽atītānāgatena nayaṃ netī”ti. Pariye ñāṇanti paresaṃ cittaparicchede ñāṇaṃ. Yathāha
analyzed: ñāṇam tena āha saḥ iminā dhammena ñātena diṭṭhena pattena viditena pariyogāḷhena  atīta anāgatena paresam citta paricchede ñāṇam yathā āha
translated: As it is said: ‘He leads the way by this idea that is known, seen, experienced, awakened to, and realized by himself, in the past, in the future, and in the present’ .🔽Knowledge of what can be known is knowledge of discerning the minds of others. As it is said:

original: – “tattha katamaṃ pariye ñāṇaṃ? Idha bhikkhu parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto
analyzed: tattha katamam pariye ñāṇam idha bhikkhu para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ
translated: ‘Herein, what is knowledge of what can be known? Here a bhikkhu knows the minds of other beings, of other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind. He knows a mind affected by lust to be so, and a mind unaffected by lust to be so. He knows a mind affected by hate to be so, and a mind unaffected by hate to be so. He knows a mind affected by delusion to be so, and a mind unaffected by delusion to be so. He knows a contracted mind to be so, and a distracted mind to be so. He knows an exalted mind to be so, and an unexalted mind to be so. He knows a surpassed mind to be so, and an unsurpassed mind to be so. He knows a concentrated mind to be so, and an unconcentrated mind to be so. He knows a liberated mind to be so, and an unliberated mind to be so’ .

original: paricca jānātī”ti vitthāretabbaṃ. Ṭhapetvā pana imāni tīṇi ñāṇāni avasesaṃ sammutiñāṇaṃ
analyzed: paricca jānāti iti vitthāretabbam ṭhapetvā pana imāni tīṇi ñāṇāni avasesam sammuti ñāṇam
translated: But apart from these three kinds of knowledge, the rest is conventional knowledge.

original: nāma. Yathāha – “tattha katamaṃ sammutiñāṇaṃ? Ṭhapetvā dhamme ñāṇaṃ ṭhapetvā anvaye
analyzed: nāma yathā āha tattha katamam sammuti ñāṇam ṭhapetvā dhamme ñāṇam ṭhapetvā anvaye
translated: As it is said: “Herein, what is conventional knowledge? Excluding knowledge of states and subsequent knowledge,

original: ñāṇaṃ ṭhapetvā paricchede ñāṇaṃ avasesaṃ sammutiñāṇa”nti.
analyzed: ñāṇam ṭhapetvā paricchede ñāṇam avasesam sammuti ñāṇam ti
translated: As it is said: “Herein, what is conventional knowledge? It is all knowledge except knowledge of the way to abandon, knowledge of the possible, knowledge of the definition of ideas, and knowledge of language.

original: Dukkhe ñāṇādīhi arahattaṃ pāpetvā ekassa bhikkhuno niggamanaṃ catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: dukkhe ñāṇa ādīhi arahattam pāpetvā ekassa bhikkhuno niggamanam catu sacca kammaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: ” When he has brought about the state of arahantship by means of the knowledge of suffering, etc., and he has sent out one bhikkhu, he has demonstrated the four noble Truths as a meditation subject.

original: kathitaṃ. Tattha dve saccāni vaṭṭaṃ, dve vivaṭṭaṃ, vaṭṭe abhiniveso hoti, no vivaṭṭe.🔽Dvīsu saccesu ācariyasantike pariyattiṃ uggahetvā kammaṃ karoti, dvīsu saccesu “nirodhasaccaṃ
analyzed: kathitam tattha dve saccāni vaṭṭam dve vivaṭṭam vaṭṭe abhinivesaḥ hoti no vivaṭṭe  dvīsu saccesu ācariya santike pariyattim uggahetvā kammam karoti dvīsu saccesu nirodha saccam
translated: Herein, two of the Truths are the round of rebirths, and two are the end of the round of rebirths. He is intent on the round of rebirths, not on the end of the round of rebirths.🔽He does the preliminary work on two of the Truths by learning the texts in the teacher’s presence, and he does it by hearing in the case of the other two Truths.

original: nāma iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpaṃ, maggasaccaṃ nāma iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpa”nti savanavasena🔽kammaṃ karoti. Dvīsu saccesu uggahaparipucchāsavanadhāraṇasammasanapaṭivedho vaṭṭati,
analyzed: nāma iṭṭham kantam manāpam maggasaccam nāma iṭṭham kantam manāpanti savana vasena  kammam karoti dvīsu saccesu uggaha paripucchā savana dhāraṇa sammasana paṭivedhaḥ vaṭṭati
translated: He does the preliminary work on the two Truths thus, “The Truth of cessation is desirable, lovely, an agreeable idea, and the Truth of the path is desirable, lovely, an agreeable idea.”🔽He has penetration by learning, questioning, hearing, and memorizing in the case of two Truths,

original: dvīsu savanapaṭivedho vaṭṭati. Tīṇi kiccavasena paṭivijjhati, ekaṃ ārammaṇavasena.
analyzed: dvīsu savana paṭivedhaḥ vaṭṭati tīṇi kicca vasena paṭivijjhati ekam ārammaṇa vasena
translated: and he has penetration by hearing in the case of the other two. He penetrates three by function, and one by object.

original: Dve saccāni duddasattā gambhīrāni, dve gambhīrattā duddasāni.
analyzed: dve saccāni duddasa ttā gambhīrāni dve gambhīra ttā duddasāni
translated: Two truths are hard to see because of their profundity, and two are profound because they are hard to see.

original: Sotāpattiyaṅgādicatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The four kinds of things beginning with the factors of stream-entry

original: 311. Sotāpattiyaṅgānīti sotāpattiyā aṅgāni, sotāpattimaggassa paṭilābhakāraṇānīti
analyzed: sotāpattiyā aṅgāni iti sotāpattiyāḥ aṅgāni sotāpatti maggassa paṭilābha kāraṇāni iti
translated: The factors of stream-entry: the factors of the stream-entry; the causes of the acquisition of the path of stream-entry.🔽The meaning is that.🔽Association with superior persons: approaching and associating with superior persons, Buddhas, etc.,

original: attho. Sappurisasaṃsevoti buddhādīnaṃ sappurisānaṃ upasaṅkamitvā sevanaṃ. Saddhammassavananti
analyzed: attho sappurisa saṃsevaḥ ti buddha ādīnam sappurisānam upasaṅkamitvā sevanam saddhamma ssavananti
translated: Hearing the true Dhamma: hearing the Dhamma of the scriptures that is beneficial.

original: sappāyassa tepiṭakadhammassa savanaṃ. Yonisomanasikāroti aniccādivasena manasikāro.
analyzed: sappāyassa tepiṭaka dhammassa savanam anicca ādi vasena manasikāro
translated: Proper attention: attention given by way of impermanence, etc.

original: Dhammānudhammappaṭipattīti lokuttaradhammassa anudhammabhūtāya pubbabhāgapaṭipattiyā paṭipajjanaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma anudhamma ppaṭipatti iti lokuttara dhammassa anudhamma bhūtāya pubbabhāga paṭipattiyā paṭipajjanam
translated: Practice in accordance with the Dhamma: practice in the preliminary part of the path that is in accordance with the supramundane Dhamma.

original: Aveccappasādenāti acalappasādena. “Itipi so bhagavā”tiādīni visuddhimagge vitthāritāni.
analyzed: avecca ppasādena ati acala ppasādena iti pi so bhagavā ati ādīni visuddhi magge vitthāritāni
translated: Clear confidence in the Buddha: unshakable confidence. “Such is he, the Lord,” etc., are given in detail in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Phaladhātuāhāracatukkāni uttānatthāneva. Apicettha lūkhapaṇītavatthuvasena oḷārikasukhumatā veditabbā.
analyzed: phala dhātu āhāra catukkāni api ca ittha lūkha paṇīta vatthu vasena oḷārika sukhuma tā veditabbā
translated: The four kinds of nutriment and the element of result are self-evident. Herein, grossness and subtlety should be understood according to the subject of gross and subtle.

original: Viññāṇaṭṭhitiyoti viññāṇaṃ etāsu tiṭṭhatīti viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo. Ārammaṇaṭṭhitivasenetaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti viññāṇam etāsu tiṭṭhati iti viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ārammaṇa ṭṭhiti vasena itam
translated: “Stations for consciousness” : consciousness stands in these, thus they are stations for consciousness. This is said

original: vuttaṃ. Rūpūpāyanti rūpaṃ upagataṃ hutvā. Pañcavokārabhavasmiñhi abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: vuttam rūpūpāyanti rūpam upagatam hutvā pañcavokāra bhavasmin hi abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇam
translated: with reference to the stationing of consciousness on its object. “Approached form” : having approached the form aggregate. For in the five-constituent existence

original: rūpakkhandhaṃ nissāya tiṭṭhati. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Rūpārammaṇanti rūpakkhandhagocaraṃ🔽rūpapatiṭṭhitaṃ hutvā. Nandūpasecananti lobhasahagataṃ sampayuttanandiyāva upasittaṃ🔽hutvā. Itaraṃ upanissayakoṭiyā. Vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjatīti saṭṭhipi sattatipi🔽vassāni evaṃ pavattamānaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjati. Vedanūpāyādīsupi eseva🔽nayo. Imehi pana tīhi padehi catuvokārabhave abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Tassa yāvatāyukaṃ
analyzed: rūpa kkhandham nissāya tiṭṭhati tam sandhāya itam vuttam rūpa ārammaṇam ti rūpa kkhandha gocaram  rūpa patiṭṭhitam hutvā nandūpasecananti lobha sahagatam sampayutta nandi yāvaḥ upasittam  hutvā itaram upanissaya koṭiyā vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjati iti  vassāni evam pavattamānam vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjati vedanūpāya ādīsu pi esā iva  nayo imehi pana tīhi padehi catu vokāra bhave abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇam vuttam tassa yāvatāyukam
translated: the resultant consciousness stands in dependence on the form aggregate. That is what is meant here. “With form as its object” : with the form aggregate as its domain.

original: pavattanavasena vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanā veditabbā. Catukkavasena pana
analyzed: pavattana vasena vuddhim virūḷhim vepullam āpajjanā veditabbā catukka vasena pana
translated: “With form as its support” : having become established on form. “Steeped in delight” : having become steeped in the delight associated with it, which is accompanied by greed. The other is the condition by way of decisive support. “Gains growth, increase, and maturity” : it gains growth, increase, and maturity by continuing thus for sixty or seventy years. The same method applies to the other two phrases. But by these three phrases the resultant consciousness in the four-constituent existence is referred to. Its growth, increase, and maturity should be understood to occur by the way of its continuance as long as life lasts. But by the four phrases

original: desanāya āgatattā viññāṇūpāyanti na vuttaṃ. Evaṃ vuccamāne ca “katamaṃ nu kho ettha
analyzed: desanāyaḥ āgata ttā viññāṇa upāyanti na vuttam evam vuccamāne ca katamat nu kho ettha
translated: and so it is not said that it is the condition for consciousness.🔽And if it were said, there would be confusion as to which is kamma-consciousness and which is resultant-consciousness, and so that is not said either.

original: kammaviññāṇaṃ, katamaṃ vipākaviññāṇa”nti sammoho bhaveyya, tasmāpi na vuttaṃ. Agatigamanāni vitthāritāneva.
analyzed: kamma viññāṇam katamam vipāka viññāṇan ti sammohaḥ bhaveyya tasmā api na vuttam agati gamanāni
translated: The “goings” are given in detail.🔽“For the sake of robes”: for the purpose of getting a desirable robe.

original: Cīvarahetūti tattha manāpaṃ cīvaraṃ labhissāmīti cīvarakāraṇā uppajjati. Iti bhavābhavahetūti
analyzed: cīvara hetū ti tattha manāpam cīvaram labhissāmi iti cīvara kāraṇā uppajjati iti bhava abhava hetū ti
translated: “For the sake of becoming and non-becoming”:

original: ettha itīti nidassanatthe nipāto. Yathā cīvarādihetu, evaṃ bhavābhavahetūpīti attho.
analyzed: ettha iti iti nidassana tthe nipātaḥ yathā cīvara ādi hetu evam bhava abhava hetūpī iti atthaḥ
translated: here the word “so” is a demonstrative pronoun. The meaning is: just as for the sake of robes, etc., so too for the sake of becoming and non-becoming.

original: Bhavābhavoti cettha paṇītapaṇītatarāni telamadhuphāṇitādīni adhippetāni. Imesaṃ pana
analyzed: ca ittha paṇīta paṇītatarāni tela madhu phāṇita ādīni adhippetāni imesam pana
translated: Herein, “becoming and non-becoming” refers to the more and less desirable things such as oil, honey, jaggery, etc.

original: catunnaṃ taṇhuppādānaṃ pahānatthāya paṭipāṭiyāva cattāro ariyavaṃsā desitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: catunnam taṇhuppādānam pahāna atthāya paṭipāṭiyā ava cattāro ariya vaṃsāḥ desitā iti veditabbā
translated: But the four noble lineages should be understood as taught in order to abandon the four kinds of craving for these four things.🔽The four kinds of undertaking have already been given above.

original: Paṭipadācatukkaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Akkhamādīsu padhānakaraṇakāle sītādīni na khamatīti
analyzed: paṭipadā catukkam heṭṭhā vuttam eva akkhama ādīsu padhāna karaṇa kāle sītā ādīni na khamati iti
translated: When one is making the effort to be patient, one is not patient with cold, etc.,
