Anabhijjhā dhammapadaṃ nāma alobho vā alobhasīsena🔽adhigatajjhānavipassanāmaggaphalanibbānāni vā. Abyāpādo dhammapadaṃ nāma akopo vā🔽mettāsīsena adhigatajjhānādīni vā. Sammāsati dhammapadaṃ nāma suppaṭṭhitasati vā🔽satisīsena adhigatajjhānādīni vā. Sammāsamādhi dhammapadaṃ nāma samāpatti vā aṭṭhasamāpattivasena
analyzed: akkhamā khamati iti khamā indriya damanam damā uppannam kāma vitakkam na adhivāseti iti ādinā  nayena vitakka samanam samā  dhamma padāni iti dhamma koṭṭhāsāni anabhijjhā dhamma padam nāma alobhaḥ vā alobha sīsena  adhigata jhāna vipassanā magga phala nibbānāni vā a byāpādaḥ dhamma padam nāma akopaḥ vā  mettā sīsena adhigata jhāna ādīni vā sammā sati dhammapadam nāma suppaṭṭhita sati vā
translated: and so on. This is the meaning.

original: adhigatajjhānavipassanāmaggaphalanibbānāni vā. Dasāsubhavasena vā adhigatajjhānādīni🔽anabhijjhā dhammapadaṃ. Catubrahmavihāravasena adhigatāni abyāpādo dhammapadaṃ. Dasānussatiāhārepaṭikūlasaññāvasena
analyzed: adhigata jhāna vipassanā magga phala nibbānāni vā dasa asubha vasena vā adhigata jhāna ādīni 🔽anabhijjhā dhamma padam catu brahmavihāra vasena adhigatāni a byāpādaḥ dhamma padam dasa anussati āhāre paṭikūla saññā vasena
translated: The words of the Dhamma: the sections of the Dhamma. Non-greed is a word of the Dhamma, or non-greed is the heading under which the jhana, insight, path, fruit, and Nibbana attained are stated. Non-ill will is a word of the Dhamma, or the jhana, etc., attained under the heading of loving-kindness are stated. Right mindfulness is a word of the Dhamma, or the jhana, etc., attained under the heading of mindfulness are stated. Right concentration is a word of the Dhamma, or the attainment, or the jhana, insight, path, fruit, and Nibbana attained under the heading of the eight attainments are stated. Or the jhana, etc., attained under the heading of the ten kinds of foulness are stated. Non-greed is a word of the Dhamma. The jhana, etc., attained under the heading of the four divine abodes are stated. Non-ill will is a word of the Dhamma. The jhana, etc., attained under the heading of the ten recollections, the perception of the repulsiveness in nutriment,

original: adhigatāni sammāsati dhammapadaṃ. Dasakasiṇaānāpānavasena adhigatāni sammāsamādhi dhammapadanti.🔽Dhammasamādānesu paṭhamaṃ acelakapaṭipadā. Dutiyaṃ tibbakilesassa arahattaṃ gahetuṃ🔽asakkontassa assumukhassāpi rudato parisuddhabrahmacariyacaraṇaṃ. Tatiyaṃ kāmesu
analyzed: adhigatāni sammā sati dhamma padam dasa kasiṇa ānāpāna vasena adhigatāni sammā samādhi dhamma padanti  dhamma samādānesu paṭhamam acelaka paṭipadā dutiyam tibba kilesassa arahattam gahetuṃ  a sakkontassa assu mukhassa api rudataḥ parisuddha brahmacariya caraṇam tatiyam kāmesu
translated: The phrase “the True Idea of Right Mindfulness” is attained by means of the four foundations of mindfulness. The phrase “the True Idea of Right Concentration” is attained by means of the ten kasinas and mindfulness of breathing.

original: pātabyatā. Catutthaṃ cattāro paccaye alabhamānassāpi jhānavipassanāvasena sukhasamaṅgino
analyzed: pātabya tā catuttham cattāro paccaye a labhamānassa api jhāna vipassanā vasena sukha samaṅginaḥ
translated: As regards the undertakings of the True Idea, the first is the practice of the naked ascetics. The second is the practice of one whose defilements are strong, who is unable to reach Arahantship, and who lives the completely pure spiritual life even to the extent of weeping with a tearful face. The third is the practice of one who is overcome by sensual desires. The fourth is the practice of one who is endowed with happiness by means of jhana and insight even though he does not obtain the four requisite conditions.

original: sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: sāsana brahmacariyam
translated: This is the spiritual life in the Dispensation.

original: Dhammakkhandhāti ettha guṇaṭṭho khandhaṭṭho. Sīlakkhandhoti sīlaguṇo. Ettha ca phalasīlaṃ adhippetaṃ. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Iti catūsupi ṭhānesu phalameva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma khandhā ti ettha guṇa ṭṭhaḥ khandha ṭṭhaḥ sīla kkhandho ti sīla guṇo ettha ca phala sīlam adhippetam sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ iti catūsu pi ṭhānesu phalam eva vuttam
translated: As regards the “aggregates of the True Idea,” the meaning of “aggregate” is the meaning of “mass” . “The aggregate of virtue” is the mass of virtue. And here the virtue of fruition is intended. The same method applies in the other phrases. So in all four places fruition is stated.

original: Balānīti upatthambhanaṭṭhena akampiyaṭṭhena ca balāni. Tesaṃ paṭipakkhehi kosajjādīhi akampaniyatā veditabbā. Sabbānipi samathavipassanāmaggavasena lokiyalokuttarāneva kathitāni.
analyzed: balāni iti upatthambhana ṭṭhena akampiya ṭṭhena ca balāni tesam paṭipakkhehi kosajja ādīhi akampaniya tā veditabbā sabbāni pi samatha vipassanā magga vasena kathitāni
translated: “Powers” : they are powers in the sense of supporting and in the sense of unshakability. Their unshakability by their opposites, laziness, etc., should be understood. All of them are said to be mundane and supramundane in the sense of the path of serenity and insight.

original: Adhiṭṭhānānīti ettha adhīti upasaggamattaṃ. Atthato pana tena vā tiṭṭhanti, tattha
analyzed: adhiṭṭhānāni iti ettha adhi iti upasagga mattam atthataḥ pana tena vā tiṭṭhanti tattha
translated: “Resolutions” : here the prefix adhi is merely a reiterative particle. But in the sense of the Suttas, they are resolved upon by him, or🔽they are resolved upon there, or

original: vā tiṭṭhanti, ṭhānameva vā taṃtaṃguṇādhikānaṃ purisānaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ, paññāva adhiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vā tiṭṭhanti ṭhānam eva vā taṃ taṃguṇa adhikānam purisānam adhiṭṭhānam paññā ava adhiṭṭhānam
translated: that is the resolution, the place, of men who have the special qualities, or wisdom is the resolution,

original: paññādhiṭṭhānaṃ. Ettha ca paṭhamena aggaphalapaññā. Dutiyena vacīsaccaṃ. Tatiyena
analyzed: paññā adhiṭṭhānam ettha ca paṭhamena agga phala paññā dutiyena vacī saccam tatiyena
translated: therefore it is the resolution of wisdom. And here the first is the wisdom of the foremost fruit; the second, truth of speech; the third,

original: āmisapariccāgo. Catutthena kilesūpasamo kathitoti veditabbo. Paṭhamena ca kammassakatapaññaṃ🔽vipassanāpaññaṃ vā ādiṃ katvā phalapaññā kathitā. Dutiyena vacīsaccaṃ ādiṃ katvā
analyzed: āmisa pariccāgo catutthena kilesa upasamo kathito ti veditabbo paṭhamena ca kammassa kata paññam  vipassanā paññam vā ādim katvā phala paññā kathitā dutiyena vacīsaccam ādim katvā
translated: renunciation of material goods; and the fourth, the stilling of defilements, should be understood. And by the first, wisdom of the fruit is stated beginning with the wisdom of self-reliance

original: paramatthasaccaṃ nibbānaṃ. Tatiyena āmisapariccāgaṃ ādiṃ katvā aggamaggena kilesapariccāgo.
analyzed: paramattha saccam nibbānam tatiyena āmisa pariccāgam ādim katvā aggamaggena kilesa pariccāgaḥ
translated: or the wisdom of insight; by the second, the truth of the highest sense, Nibbāna, beginning with truth of speech; by the third, the renunciation of defilements by the foremost path, beginning with the renunciation of material goods;🔽and by the fourth, the stilling of defilements, beginning with the stilling of bodily disturbance.

original: Catutthena samāpattivikkhambhite kilese ādiṃ katvā aggamaggena kilesavūpasamo. Paññādhiṭṭhānena🔽vā ekena arahattaphalapaññā kathitā. Sesehi paramatthasaccaṃ. Saccādhiṭṭhānena vā
analyzed: catutthena samāpatti vikkhambhite kilese ādim katvā aggamaggena kilesa vūpasamaḥ paññā adhiṭṭhānena  vā ekena arahatta phala paññā kathitā sesehi paramattha saccam sacca adhiṭṭhānena vā
translated: With the fourth, the stilling of defilements by the Noble Path, beginning with the stilling of defilements by the attainment of absorption.🔽Or with the first, the path knowledge of the Arahant fruit, is stated; with the rest, the ultimate truth.

original: ekena paramatthasaccaṃ kathitaṃ. Sesehi arahattapaññāti mūsikābhayatthero āha.
analyzed: ekena paramattha saccam kathitam sesehi arahatta paññā iti mūsikābhaya theraḥ āha
translated: Or with the first, the ultimate truth is stated; with the rest, the knowledge of the Arahant fruit. So said the Elder Musilābhaya.

original: Pañhabyākaraṇādicatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The four questions and answers, etc.

original: 312. Pañhabyākaraṇāni mahāpadesakathāya vitthāritāneva.🔽Kaṇhanti kāḷakaṃ dasaakusalakammapathakammaṃ. Kaṇhavipākanti apāye nibbattanato kāḷakavipākaṃ.
analyzed: pañha byākaraṇāni mahā padesa kathāya  kaṇhanti kāḷakam dasa akusala kammapatha kammam kaṇha vipākam ti apāye nibbattanataḥ kāḷaka vipākam
translated: The questions and answers are given in detail in the Great Book.🔽“Dark” is the ten courses of unwholesome kamma that are black. “With black result” is with black ripening, because of rebirth in the states of deprivation.

original: Sukkanti paṇḍaraṃ kusalakammapathakammaṃ. Sukkavipākanti sagge nibbattanato paṇḍaravipākaṃ.
analyzed: sukkam ti paṇḍaram kusala kammapatha kammam sukka vipākam ti sagge nibbattanataḥ paṇḍara vipākam
translated: “Bright” is the ten courses of wholesome kamma that are white. “With bright result” is with white ripening, because of rebirth in the heavenly worlds.

original: Kaṇhasukkanti missakakammaṃ. Kaṇhasukkavipākanti sukhadukkhavipākaṃ. Missakakammañhi
analyzed: kaṇha sukkanti missaka kammam kaṇha sukka vipākanti sukha dukkha vipākam missaka kammañhi
translated: “Dark and bright” is mixed kamma. “With dark and bright result” is with mixed ripening. For having done mixed kamma,

original: katvā akusalena tiracchānayoniyaṃ maṅgalahatthiṭṭhānādīsu uppanno kusalena pavatte
analyzed: katvā akusalena tiracchānayoniyam maṅgala hatthi ṭṭhāna ādīsu uppannaḥ kusalena pavatte
translated: one is reborn in the animal realm through unwholesome kamma, and through wholesome kamma one experiences pleasure in the course of existence.

original: sukhaṃ vedayati. Kusalena rājakulepi nibbatto akusalena pavatte dukkhaṃ vedayati.
analyzed: sukham vedayati kusalena rāja kule api nibbattaḥ akusalena pavatte dukkham vedayati
translated: He feels pleasure. If he is reborn in a royal family through profitable kamma, he feels pain through unprofitable kamma.

original: Akaṇhaasukkanti kammakkhayakaraṃ catumaggañāṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Tañhi yadi kaṇhaṃ bhaveyya,
analyzed: a kaṇha a sukkam ti kamma khaya karam catu magga ñāṇam adhippetam tat hi yadi kaṇham bhaveyya
translated: Neither-painful-nor-pleasant: the four path knowledges are intended. For if that were painful,

original: kaṇhavipākaṃ dadeyya. Yadi sukkaṃ bhaveyya, sukkavipākaṃ dadeyya. Ubhayavipākassa
analyzed: kaṇha vipākam dadeyya yadi sukkam bhaveyya sukka vipākam dadeyya ubhaya vipākassa
translated: it would give a painful ripening; if it were pleasant, it would give a pleasant ripening. But because it gives neither ripening,

original: pana adānato akaṇhāsukkavipākattā akaṇhaṃ asukkanti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: pana adānataḥ a kaṇha a sukka vipāka attā a kaṇham a sukkam ti ayam ettha attho
translated: it is neither-painful-nor-pleasant because of having neither ripening.

original: Sacchikaraṇīyāti paccakkhakaraṇena ceva paṭilābhena ca sacchikātabbā. Cakkhunāti dibbacakkhunā. Kāyenāti sahajātanāmakāyena. Paññāyāti arahattaphalañāṇena.
analyzed: sacchikaraṇīyā ati paccakkha karaṇena ca iva paṭilābhena ca sacchikātabbā cakkhunā ati dibba cakkhunā kāyena ati sahajāta nāmakāyena paññāya ati arahatta phala ñāṇena
translated: To be realized: to be realized by verifying and by obtaining. With the eye: with the divine eye. With the body: with the conascent “name.” With understanding: with the knowledge of the fruit of arahantship.

original: Oghāti vaṭṭasmiṃ satte ohananti osīdāpentīti oghā. Tattha pañcakāmaguṇiko rāgo kāmogho.🔽Rūpārūpabhavesu chandarāgo bhavogho. Tathā jhānanikanti sassatadiṭṭhisahagato ca
analyzed: oghā ati vaṭṭasmim satte ohananti osīdāpenti iti oghā tattha pañca kāmaguṇikaḥ rāgaḥ kāmogho  rūpa arūpa bhavesu chanda rāgaḥ bhava ogho tathā jhāna nikanti sassata diṭṭhi sahagataḥ ca
translated: Flood: beings are flooded by the round of rebirths, are made to sink into it, thus it is a flood. Herein, lust for the five cords of sense desire is the flood of sense desire.

original: rāgo. Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo diṭṭhogho.
analyzed: rāgaḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭha oghaḥ
translated: Lust accompanied by the will to become in the case of the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming is the flood of becoming. So too is lust accompanied by the will to become in the case of the perception-and-feeling kind of becoming. And the sixty-two views are the flood of views.

original: Vaṭṭasmiṃ yojentīti yogā. Te oghā viya veditabbā.🔽Visaṃyojentīti visaññogā. Tattha asubhajjhānaṃ kāmayogavisaṃyogo. Taṃ pādakaṃ katvā
analyzed: vaṭṭasmim yojenti iti yogā te oghā viya veditabbā  visaṃyojenti iti visaññogā tattha asubha jjhānam kāma yoga visaṃyogo tam pādakam katvā
translated: They are called bonds because they bind creatures to the round of rebirths. They should be understood as like the bonds.

original: adhigato anāgāmimaggo ekanteneva kāmayogavisaññogo nāma. Arahattamaggo bhavayogavisaññogo
analyzed: adhigataḥ anāgāmi maggaḥ ekantena iva kāma yoga visaññogaḥ nāma arahatta maggaḥ bhava yoga visaññogaḥ
translated: The foulness meditation is the disjunction from the fetter of sense desire. The non-return path, which is reached by making that meditation a footing, is called the disjunction from the fetter of sense desire in one way. The Arahant path is called the disjunction from the fetter of being.

original: nāma. Sotāpattimaggo diṭṭhiyogavisaññogo nāma. Arahattamaggo avijjāyogavisaññogo nāma.
analyzed: nāma sotāpatti maggo diṭṭhi yoga visaññogaḥ nāma arahatta maggo avijjā yoga visaññogaḥ nāma
translated: The stream-entry path is called the disjunction from the fetter of views. The Arahant path is called the disjunction from the fetter of ignorance.🔽They are called clingings because they cling to the round of rebirths. They should be understood as like the clingings.

original: Ganthanavasena ganthā. Vaṭṭasmiṃ nāmakāyañceva rūpakāyañca ganthati bandhati palibundhatīti
analyzed: ganthana vasena ganthā vaṭṭasmim nāmakāyam ca iva rūpakāyam ca ganthati bandhati palibundhati iti
translated: The body clinging is so called because it clings to the body, that is, to the material and immaterial septuple groups of existence.

original: kāyagantho. Idaṃsaccābhinivesoti idameva saccaṃ, moghamaññanti evaṃ pavatto diṭṭhābhiniveso.🔽Upādānānīti ādānaggahaṇāni. Kāmoti rāgo, soyeva gahaṇaṭṭhena upādānanti kāmupādānaṃ.
analyzed: kāya ganthaḥ idaṃsacca abhiniveso ti idam eva saccam mogha maññan ti evam pavattaḥ diṭṭha abhiniveso  upādānāni iti ādāna ggahaṇāni kāmaḥ ti rāgaḥ gahaṇa ṭṭhena upādānam ti kāma upādānam
translated: The false view of individuality is the insistence on the truth of the view “This alone is the truth,” which is the opposite of the true view.

original: Diṭṭhīti micchādiṭṭhi, sāpi gahaṇaṭṭhena upādānanti diṭṭhupādānaṃ. Iminā suddhīti
analyzed: diṭṭhī iti micchādiṭṭhi sā api gahaṇa ṭṭhena upādānanti diṭṭhupādānam iminā suddhī iti
translated: The clinging to rules and vows is the insistence on the truth of the view “Purification comes through this alone.”🔽The clinging to a doctrine of self is the insistence on the truth of the view “This alone is the truth, the rest is foolish.”

original: evaṃ sīlavatānaṃ gahaṇaṃ sīlabbatupādānaṃ. Attāti etena vadati ceva upādiyati cāti attavādupādānaṃ.
analyzed: evam gahaṇam sīlabbata upādānam attā iti etena vadati ca iva upādiyati ca ati attavād upādānam
translated: So the grasping of those who are virtuous is the clinging to virtue and practice. By “self” is meant that he speaks and clings to it.

original: Yoniyoti koṭṭhāsā. Aṇḍe jātāti aṇḍajā. Jalābumhi jātāti jalābujā. Saṃsede jātāti
analyzed: koṭṭhāsā aṇḍe jātā ati aṇḍa jā jalābumhi jātā ati jalābu jā saṃsede jātā ati
translated: “Source” is a part. Born from an egg is “oviparous.” Born from the womb is “viviparous.” Born from moisture is “moisture-born.”🔽This is a designation for those born in a bed or in rotten fish, etc.

original: saṃsedajā. Sayanasmiṃ pūtimacchādīsu ca nibbattānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vegena āgantvā
analyzed: saṃseda jā sayanasmim pūtima chādīsu ca nibbattānam etam adhivacanam vegena āgantvā
translated: Having come quickly and

original: upapatitā viyāti opapātikā. Tattha devamanussesu saṃsedajaopapātikānaṃ ayaṃ viseso.🔽Saṃsedajā mandā daharā hutvā nibbattanti. Opapātikā soḷasavassuddesikā hutvā. Manussesu
analyzed: upapatitā viya āti opapātikā tattha deva manussesu saṃseda ja opapātikānam ayam visesaḥ  saṃseda jāḥ mandāḥ daharāḥ hutvā nibbattanti opapātikā soḷasa vassuddesikā hutvā manussesu
translated: having fallen down, as it were, is “supernaturally born.” Herein, this is the difference between the moisture-born and the supernaturally born:🔽the moisture-born are born dull and as infants, while the supernaturally born are born in the sixteenth or seventeenth year.🔽For all four kinds of birth are found among human beings and among the earth deities,

original: hi bhummadevesu ca imā catassopi yoniyo labbhanti. Tathā tiracchānesu supaṇṇanāgādīsu.🔽Vuttañhetaṃ – “tattha, bhikkhave, aṇḍajā supaṇṇā aṇḍajeva nāge haranti, na jalābuje
analyzed: hi bhumma devesu ca imāḥ catasso api yoniyaḥ labbhanti tathā tiracchānesu supaṇṇa nāga ādīsu  vuttam ha etam tattha bhikkhave aṇḍa jā su paṇṇā aṇḍa ja iva nāge haranti na jalābu je
translated: and among the birds and the nāgas, etc., of the animal kingdom.

original: na saṃsedaje na opapātike”ti. Cātumahārājikato paṭṭhāya uparidevā opapātikāyeva.
analyzed: na saṃseda je na opapātika iti cātumahārājikato paṭṭhāya upari devāḥ opapātikāya iva
translated: For this is said: “Here, bhikkhus, the supernaturally born supaṇṇas seize only the supernaturally born nāgas, not the moisture-born or the egg-born or the womb-born” . And the deities above the Cātummahārājika heaven are supernaturally born only.

original: Tathā nerayikā. Petesu catassopi labbhanti. Gabbhāvakkantiyo sampasādanīye kathitā eva.
analyzed: tathā nerayikā petesu catasso pi labbhanti gabbha avakkantiyaḥ sampasādanīye kathitāḥ eva
translated: So too, in the hells. All four are found among the ghosts. The descent into the womb is dealt with in the Sampasādanīya Sutta .

original: Attabhāvapaṭilābhesu paṭhamo khiḍḍāpadosikavasena veditabbo. Dutiyo orabbhikādīhi
analyzed: atta bhāva paṭilābhesu paṭhamaḥ khiḍḍa apadosika vasena veditabbaḥ dutiyaḥ orabbhika ādīhi
translated: As regards the kinds of rebirth, the first should be understood as that of the pleasure-addicts, the second as that of the goats, sheep, fowls, pigs, cattle, etc., that are born to be slaughtered,

original: ghātiyamānaurabbhādivasena. Tatiyo manopadosikāvasena. Catuttho cātumahārājike upādāya
analyzed: tatiyaḥ manopadosikā vasena catutthaḥ cātumahārājike upādāya
translated: the third as that of the angry men, and the fourth as that of the deities of the retinue of the Four Great Kings and the deities higher than they.

original: uparisesadevatāvasena. Te hi devā neva attasañcetanāya maranti, na parasañcetanāya.
analyzed: te hi devāḥ na iva atta sañcetanāya maranti na para sañcetanāya
translated: For these deities do not die by their own volition or by the volition of others.

original: Dakkhiṇāvisuddhādicatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The four kinds of purification of offering

original: 313. Dakkhiṇāvisuddhiyoti dānasaṅkhātā dakkhiṇā visujjhanti mahapphalā honti etāhīti dakkhiṇāvisuddhiyo.
analyzed: dakkhiṇā visuddhiyaḥ ti dāna saṅkhātāḥ dakkhiṇāḥ visujjhanti mahapphalāḥ honti etāhi iti dakkhiṇā visuddhiyaḥ
translated: are so called because offerings, that is to say, gifts, are purified by them, are fruitful.🔽Purification through the giver is when the giver is virtuous,

original: Dāyakato visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakatoti yattha dāyako sīlavā hoti, dhammenuppannaṃ
analyzed: dāyakataḥ visujjhati no paṭiggāhakataḥ ti yattha dāyako sīlavā hoti dhammenuppannam
translated: and the gift is given by him as it occurs to him,

original: deyyadhammaṃ deti, paṭiggāhako dussīlo. Ayaṃ dakkhiṇā vessantaramahārājassa dakkhiṇāsadisā.
analyzed: deyya dhammam deti paṭiggāhakaḥ dussīlaḥ ayam dakkhiṇā vessantara mahārājassa dakkhiṇā sadisā
translated: but the receiver is unvirtuous. This offering is like the offering of the Great King Vessantara.

original: Paṭiggāhakato visujjhati, no dāyakatoti yattha paṭiggāhako sīlavā hoti, dāyako dussīlo,🔽adhammenuppannaṃ deti, ayaṃ dakkhiṇā coraghātakassa dakkhiṇāsadisā. Neva dāyakato
analyzed: paṭiggāhakataḥ visujjhati no dāyakataḥ ti yattha paṭiggāhako sīlavā hoti dāyakaḥ dussīlo  adhammena uppannam deti ayam dakkhiṇā cora ghātakassa dakkhiṇā sadisā na iva dāyakato
translated: Purification comes about through the receiver, not through the giver, when the receiver is virtuous and the giver is immoral,🔽and the gift is given by an illegitimate means. This offering is like the offering to a murderer.

original: visujjhati, no paṭiggāhakatoti yattha ubhopi dussīlā deyyadhammopi adhammena nibbatto.
analyzed: visujjhati no paṭiggāhakato ti yattha ubho pi dussīlāḥ deyya dhammaḥ api adhammena nibbatto
translated: Purification comes about neither through the giver nor through the receiver when both are immoral and the gift is produced by an illegitimate means.

original: Vipariyāyena catutthā veditabbā.
analyzed: vipariyāyena catutthā veditabbā
translated: The fourth should be understood in the opposite sense.

original: Saṅgahavatthūnīti saṅgahakāraṇāni. Tāni heṭṭhā vibhattāneva.🔽Anariyavohārāti anariyānaṃ lāmakānaṃ vohārā.
analyzed: saṅgaha vatthūni iti saṅgaha kāraṇāni tāni heṭṭhā vibhattāni eva  an ariya vohārā ati an ariyānam lāmakānam vohārā
translated: The bases for accumulation are the reasons for accumulation. They have been explained above.🔽The four kinds of ignoble speech are the speech of ignoble, low-class people.

original: Ariyavohārāti ariyānaṃ sappurisānaṃ vohārā.
analyzed: ariya vohārā ati ariyānam sappurisānam vohārā
translated: The four kinds of noble speech are the speech of noble, high-class people.

original: Diṭṭhavāditāti diṭṭhaṃ mayāti evaṃ vāditā. Ettha ca taṃtaṃsamuṭṭhāpakacetanāvasena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: diṭṭha vāditā ati diṭṭham mayā iti evam vāditā ettha ca taṃ taṃ samuṭṭhāpaka cetanā vasena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The four kinds of speech based on what is seen are the speech of those who say, “I have seen.” And here the meaning should be understood according to the volition that originates each kind.

original: Attantapādicatukkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: at tanta pādi catukka vaṇṇanā
translated: The four kinds of suicide

original: 314. Attantapādīsu paṭhamo acelako. Dutiyo orabbhikādīsu aññataro. Tatiyo yaññayājako. Catuttho sāsane sammāpaṭipanno.
analyzed: attantapa ādīsu paṭhamaḥ acelakaḥ dutiyaḥ orabbhika ādīsu aññataro tatiyaḥ yañña yājako catuttho sāsane sammāpaṭipanno
translated: . Among the four kinds of suicide, the first is the naked ascetic, the second is one of the types beginning with the ox ascetic, the third is the sacrifice-offerer, and the fourth is one who practices rightly in the Dispensation.

original: Attahitāya paṭipannādīsu paṭhamo yo sayaṃ sīlādisampanno, paraṃ sīlādīsu na samādapeti
analyzed: atta hitāya paṭipanna ādīsu paṭhamaḥ yaḥ sayam sīla ādi sampanno param sīla ādīsu na samādapeti
translated: The first of those who have set out for their own welfare, etc., is one who is himself endowed with virtue, etc., but does not exhort others to virtue, etc.;

original: āyasmā vakkalitthero viya. Dutiyo yo attanā na sīlādisampanno, paraṃ sīlādīsu samādapeti
analyzed: dutiyaḥ yaḥ attanā na sīla ādi sampannaḥ param sīla ādīsu samādapeti
translated: like the Elder Vakkalī. The second is one who is himself not endowed with virtue, etc., but exhorts others to virtue, etc.;

original: āyasmā upanando viya. Tatiyo yo nevattanā sīlādisampanno, paraṃ sīlādīsu na samādapeti
analyzed: āyasmai upanandaḥ viya tatiyaḥ yaḥ na evattanā sīla ādi sampanno param sīla ādīsu na samādapeti
translated: like the venerable Upananda. The third is one who is himself not endowed with virtue, etc., and does not exhort others to virtue, etc.;

original: devadatto viya. Catuttho yo attanā ca sīlādisampanno parañca sīlādīsu samādapeti
analyzed: devadattaḥ viya catutthaḥ yaḥ attanā ca sīla ādi sampanno param ca sīla ādīsu samādapeti
translated: like Devadatta. The fourth is one who is himself endowed with virtue, etc., and exhorts others to virtue, etc.;

original: āyasmā mahākassapo viya.🔽Tamādīsu tamoti andhakārabhūto. Tamaparāyaṇoti tamameva paraṃ ayanaṃ gati assāti
analyzed: āyasmā mahākassapaḥ viya  tama ādīsu tamaḥ uti andhakāra bhūtaḥ tama parāyaṇaḥ tamam eva param ayanam assa ati
translated: like the venerable Mahākassapa.

original: tamaparāyaṇo. Evaṃ sabbapadesu attho veditabbo. Ettha ca paṭhamo nīce caṇḍālādikule
analyzed: tam aparāyaṇaḥ evam sabba padesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ettha ca paṭhamaḥ nīce caṇḍāla ādi kule
translated: Herein, the first is one who is born in a low family of outcastes, etc.,🔽in a low, wretched dwelling, and he fulfils the three kinds of misconduct. The second is one who is born in such a family

original: dujjīvite hīnattabhāve nibbattitvā tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti. Dutiyo tathāvidho
analyzed: dujjīvite hīnatta bhāve nibbattitvā tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti dutiyaḥ tathāvidhaḥ
translated: and dwelling,

original: hutvā tīṇi sucaritāni paripūreti. Tatiyo uḷāre khattiyakule bahuannapāne sampannattabhāve
analyzed: hutvā tīṇi su caritāni paripūreti tatiyaḥ uḷāre khattiya kule bahu anna pāne sampannatta bhāve
translated: and he fulfilled the three kinds of good conduct. The third was born in a high family of Khattiyas, with plenty of food and drink, and with a good nature,

original: nibbattitvā tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti. Catuttho tādisova hutvā tīṇi sucaritāni paripūreti.🔽Samaṇamacaloti samaṇaacalo. Ma-kāro padasandhimattaṃ. So sotāpanno veditabbo. Sotāpanno
analyzed: nibbattitvā tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti catutthaḥ tādisaḥ uva hutvā tīṇi su caritāni paripūreti  samaṇam acalo ti samaṇa acalaḥ makāro pada sandhi mattam so sotāpannaḥ veditabbo sotāpannaḥ
translated: and he fulfils the three kinds of good conduct. The third is reborn in a good family of high social standing, with much gold, silver, and other wealth, and he fulfils the three kinds of bad conduct. The fourth is reborn in such a family and he fulfils the three kinds of good conduct.

original: hi catūhi vātehi indakhīlo viya parappavādehi akampiyo. Acalasaddhāya samannāgatoti
analyzed: hi catūhi vātehi indakhīlaḥ viya para pavādehi akampiyaḥ acala saddhāya samannāgato ti
translated: The ascetic unshaken by the wind is the unshaken ascetic. The syllable ma is merely a metrical filler. He should be understood as a stream-enterer. For the stream-enterer is unshaken by the fourfold wind, like an iron post by the four winds. He is endowed with unshaken faith.

original: samaṇamacalo. Vuttampi cetaṃ – “katamo ca puggalo samaṇamacalo? Idhekacco puggalo
analyzed: samaṇa macalaḥ katamaḥ ca puggalo samaṇa macalo idha ekacco puggalo
translated: Thus he is the ascetic unshaken by the wind. And this is said: “What kind of person is the ascetic unshaken by the wind? Here someone,

original: tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā”ti vitthāro. Rāgadosānaṃ pana tanubhūtattā sakadāgāmī
analyzed: tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam vitthāraḥ rāga dosānam pana tanu bhūta ttā sakadāgāmī
translated: by the destruction of three fetters” , etc. But because of the weakening of lust and hatred he is called the ascetic with a single seed,

original: samaṇapadumo nāma. Tenāha – “katamo pana puggalo samaṇapadumo? Idhekacco puggalo
analyzed: samaṇapadumaḥ nāma tena āha katamaḥ pana puggalo samaṇapadumaḥ idha ekacco puggalo
translated: thus he is the ascetic with a single seed. And this is said: “What kind of person is the ascetic with a single seed? Here someone

original: sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo samaṇapadumo”ti.
analyzed: sakidevaḥ imam lokam āgantvā dukkhassantam karoti ayam vuccati puggalo samaṇa padumo ti
translated: comes back only once more to this human world and makes an end of suffering. This kind of person is called the ascetic with a single seed” .

original: Rāgadosānaṃ abhāvā khippameva pupphissatīti anāgāmī samaṇapuṇḍarīko nāma. Tenāha
analyzed: rāga dosānaṃ abhāvā khippam eva pupphissati iti anāgāmī samaṇapuṇḍarīkaḥ nāma tena āha
translated: Because of the absence of greed, hate and delusion, it will soon blossom, so he is called a non-returner, a “monk’s lotus.” Hence it is said:

original: – “katamo ca puggalo samaṇapuṇḍarīko? Idhekacco puggalo pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ…pe…🔽ayaṃ vuccati puggalo samaṇapuṇḍarīko”ti. Arahā pana sabbesampi ganthakārakilesānaṃ
analyzed: katamaḥ ca puggalo samaṇa puṇḍarīkaḥ idha ekacco puggalo pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ pe ayam vuccati puggalo samaṇapuṇḍarīko ti arahā pana sabbesam pi ganthakāra kilesānam
translated: “What kind of person is a monk’s lotus? Here someone abandons the five lower fetters …

original: abhāvā samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo nāma. Tenāha – “katamo ca puggalo samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo?
analyzed: samaṇesu samaṇa sukhumālaḥ nāma tena āha katamaḥ ca puggalo samaṇesu samaṇa sukhumālo
translated: This kind of person is called a monk’s lotus.” But because of the absence of all the knots and defilements, the arahat is called the most delicate of all monks. Hence it is said: “What kind of person is the most delicate of all monks?

original: Idhekacco āsavānaṃ khayā…pe… upasampajja viharati. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo samaṇesu samaṇasukhumālo”ti.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ āsavānam khaya āpe upasampajja viharati ayam vuccati puggalo samaṇesu samaṇa sukhu mālā ti
translated: Here someone, by the destruction of the taints, enters and dwells in the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, having realized it for himself by direct knowledge. This kind of person is called the most delicate of all monks.”

original: “Ime kho, āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti samapaññāsāya catukkānaṃ vasena dvepañhasatāni kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti sama paññāsāya catukkānam vasena dve pañha satāni kathento thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friend,” etc., should be construed in the same way as above. Thus the elder, in expounding the two hundred and fifty sets of four by way of the fifty sets of five, shows the “harmony-voice” .

original: Catukkavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catukka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the sets of four is finished.

original: Pañcakavaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the sets of five

original: 315. Iti catukkavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni pañcakavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ🔽ārabhi. Tattha pañcasu khandhesu rūpakkhandho lokiyo. Sesā lokiyalokuttarā. Upādānakkhandhā
analyzed: iti catukka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni pañcaka vasena dassetum puna desanam  ārabhi tattha pañcasu khandhesu rūpakkhandho lokiyaḥ sesāḥ lokiya lokuttarāḥ upādānakkhandhāḥ
translated: So, having shown the expression of unity by way of the four, he now began the teaching by way of the five in order to show the expression of unity by way of the five.🔽Herein, the form aggregate is mundane. The rest are mundane and supramundane. The aggregates as objects of clinging

original: lokiyāva. Vitthārato pana khandhakathā visuddhimagge vuttā. Kāmaguṇā heṭṭhā vitthāritāva.
analyzed: lokiyā ava vitthārato pana khandha kathā visuddhi magge vuttā kāma guṇā heṭṭhā vitthāritā ava
translated: are mundane only. But the exposition of the aggregates in detail is given in the Path of Purity. The five cords of sense desire are given in detail below.

original: Sukatadukkaṭādīhi gantabbāti gatiyo. Nirayoti nirassādo. Sahokāsena khandhā kathitā. Tato paresu tīsu nibbattā khandhāva vuttā. Catutthe okāsopi.🔽Āvāse macchariyaṃ āvāsamacchariyaṃ. Tena samannāgato bhikkhu āgantukaṃ disvā “ettha
analyzed: su kata dukkaṭa ādīhi gantabbā ati gatiyaḥ nirayaḥ ti nirassādaḥ saha ukāsena khandhā kathitā tatas paresu tīsu nibbattā khandhā ava vuttā catutthe okāsaḥ pi  āvāse macchariyam āvāsa macchariyam tena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu āgantukam disvā ettha
translated: “They are gone to by means of good and bad actions” , thus they are “destinies” . “Hell” is “niraya” because of absence of delight . The aggregates are called “with an abode” . In the next three the aggregates that have been reborn are mentioned. In the fourth the abode is also mentioned.

original: cetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā parikkhāro ṭhapito”tiādīni vatvā saṅghikampi āvāsaṃ nivāreti.
analyzed: cetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā parikkhāraḥ ṭhapitaḥ ti ādīni vatvā saṅghikam pi āvāsam nivāreti
translated: “Stinginess about abodes” is stinginess about a dwelling place. A bhikkhu who has that characteristic, on seeing a visitor, says, “There is a store of requisites set aside there for the shrine or for the Community” , and so on, and he prevents him from entering the dwelling place belonging to the Community.

original: So kālaṅkatvā peto vā ajagaro vā hutvā nibbattati. Kule macchariyaṃ kulamacchariyaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ kālaṅkatvā petaḥ vā ajagaraḥ vā hutvā nibbattati kule macchariyam kula macchariyam
translated: When he dies he is reborn as a ghost or a sea monster. “Stinginess about families” is stinginess about families.

original: Tena samannāgato bhikkhu tehi kāraṇehi attano upaṭṭhākakule aññesaṃ pavesanampi nivāreti.
analyzed: tena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu tehi kāraṇehi attanaḥ upaṭṭhāka kule aññesam pavesanam pi nivāreti
translated: Endowed with this, a bhikkhu prevents others from entering the families that support him on account of these reasons.

original: Lābhe macchariyaṃ lābhamacchariyaṃ. Tena samannāgato bhikkhu saṅghikampi lābhaṃ maccharāyanto
analyzed: lābhe macchariyam lābha macchariyam tena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu saṅghikam pi lābham maccharāyantaḥ
translated: Stinginess about gains is stinginess about material things. Endowed with this, a bhikkhu, being stingy about gains,🔽acts so that others will not get gains even from the Sangha.

original: yathā aññe na labhanti, evaṃ karoti. Vaṇṇe macchariyaṃ vaṇṇamacchariyaṃ. Vaṇṇoti
analyzed: yathā aññe na labhanti evam karoti vaṇṇe macchariyam vaṇṇa macchariyam vaṇṇoti
translated: Stinginess about fame is stinginess about reputation.🔽Herein, the bodily reputation and the reputation for special qualities should be understood.

original: cettha sarīravaṇṇopi guṇavaṇṇopi veditabbo. Pariyattidhamme macchariyaṃ dhammamacchariyaṃ.
analyzed: ca ittha sarīra vaṇṇaḥ api guṇa vaṇṇaḥ api veditabbo pariyatti dhamme macchariyam dhamma macchariyam
translated: Stinginess about the True Idea is stinginess about the True Idea.

original: Tena samannāgato bhikkhu “imaṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā eso maṃ abhibhavissatī”ti aññassa
analyzed: tena samannāgataḥ bhikkhu imam dhammam pariyāpuṇitvā esaḥ mama abhibhavissati iti aññassa
translated: Endowed with this, a bhikkhu does not give to another, thinking “If he learns this True Idea, he will surpass me.”

original: na deti. Yo pana dhammānuggahena vā puggalānuggahena vā na deti, na taṃ macchariyaṃ.
analyzed: na deti yaḥ pana dhamma anuggahena vā puggala anuggahena vā na deti na tam macchariyam
translated: But if he does not give because he is not interested in the True Idea or in the person, that is not stinginess.🔽They obstruct the mind and overspread it, thus they are hindrances .

original: Cittaṃ nivārenti pariyonandhantīti nīvaraṇāni. Kāmacchando nīvaraṇapatto arahattamaggavajjho.
analyzed: cittam nivārenti pariyonandhanti iti nīvaraṇāni kāmacchandaḥ nīvaraṇa pattaḥ arahatta magga vajjhaḥ
translated: Desire for sensual-desires is a hindrance classed as a shackle, and it is abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: Kāmarāgānusayo kāmarāgasaṃyojanapatto anāgāmimaggavajjho. Thinaṃ cittagelaññaṃ. Middhaṃ🔽khandhattayagelaññaṃ. Ubhayampi arahattamaggavajjhaṃ. Tathā uddhaccaṃ. Kukkuccaṃ
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayaḥ kāma rāga saṃyojana pattaḥ anāgāmi magga vajjhaḥ thinam citta gelaññam middham  ubhayam pi arahatta magga vajjham tathā uddhaccam kukkuccam
translated: The underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the fetter of sensual desire, the shackle of sensual desire, are to be abandoned by the path of non-return. Drowsiness is sluggishness of mind.🔽Torpor is sluggishness of the three aggregates . Both are to be abandoned by the path of arahatship. So too restlessness. Worry is🔽

original: anāgāmimaggavajjhaṃ. Vicikicchā paṭhamamaggavajjhā.🔽Saṃyojanānīti bandhanāni. Tehi pana baddhesu puggalesu rūpārūpabhave nibbattā sotāpannasakadāgāmino🔽antobaddhā bahisayitā nāma. Tesañhi kāmabhave bandhanaṃ. Kāmabhave anāgāmino bahibaddhā🔽antosayitā nāma. Tesañhi rūpārūpabhave bandhanaṃ. Kāmabhave sotāpannasakadāgāmino🔽antobaddhā antosayitā nāma. Rūpārūpabhave anāgāmino bahibaddhā bahisayitā nāma. Khīṇāsavo
analyzed: anāgāmi magga vajjham vicikicchā paṭhama magga vajjhā  saṃyojanāni iti bandhanāni tehi pana baddhesu puggalesu rūpa arūpa bhave nibbattā sotāpanna sakadāgāmino  antobaddhāḥ bahisayitāḥ nāma tesan hi kāma bhave bandhanam kāma bhave anāgāminaḥ bahibaddhā  antosayitā nāma tesan hi rūpa arūpa bhave bandhanam kāma bhave sotāpanna sakadāgāmino  antobaddhāḥ antosayitāḥ nāma rūpa arūpa bhave anāgāminaḥ bahibaddhāḥ bahisayitāḥ nāma khīṇa asavaḥ
translated: The underlying tendency to lust for sensual desires, the fetter of sensual desire, the shackle of sensual desire, are abandoned in the path of non-return. Lethargy is sluggishness of mind. Torpor is sluggishness of the three aggregates . Both are abandoned in the path of arahatship. So too agitation. Worry is abandoned in the path of non-return. Doubt is abandoned in the first path.

original: sabbattha abandhano.
analyzed: sabbattha a bandhanaḥ
translated: The fetters are bonds. But those persons bound by them who are reborn in the fine-material or immaterial existence are called “bound within and flung without.” For their bond is in the fine-material or immaterial existence. Non-returners who are bound in the fine-material existence are called “bound without and flung within.” For their bond is in the sensual existence. Stream-enterers and once-returners who are bound in the sensual existence are called “bound within and flung within.” Non-returners who are bound in the fine-material or immaterial existence are called “bound without and flung without.” The one whose cankers are destroyed is unfettered everywhere.

original: Sikkhitabbaṃ padaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ, sikkhākoṭṭhāsoti attho. Sikkhāya vā padaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ,
analyzed: sikkhitabbam padam sikkhāpadam sikkhākoṭṭhāsaḥ ti attho sikkhāya vā padam sikkhāpadam
translated: The word pada is derived from the root sij, to learn. Sikkhitabbaṃ padaṃ = sikkhāpadaṃ. The meaning is: a section of training. Or: the word pada is derived from the root sij, to go. Sikkhāya padaṃ = sikkhāpadaṃ.

original: adhicittaadhipaññāsikkhāya adhigamupāyoti attho. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārato pana
analyzed: adhicitta adhipaññā sikkhāya adhigama upāyaḥ ti atthaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana
translated: the means to the attainment of the higher training in consciousness and in wisdom. This is the brief account here. But in detail

original: sikkhāpadakathā vibhaṅgappakaraṇe sikkhāpadavibhaṅge āgatā eva.
analyzed: sikkhāpada kathā vibhaṅga pakaraṇe sikkhāpada vibhaṅge āgatā eva
translated: the explanation of the training precepts is given in the Vibhaṅga section of the Paṭṭhāna.

original: Abhabbaṭṭhānādipañcakavaṇṇanā🔽316. “Abhabbo, āvuso, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇa”ntiādi desanāsīsameva, sotāpannādayopi🔽pana abhabbā. Puthujjanakhīṇāsavānaṃ nindāpasaṃsatthampi evaṃ vuttaṃ. Puthujjano
analyzed: abhabba ṭṭhāna ādi pañcaka vaṇṇanā  abhabbaḥ āvuso khīṇāsavaḥ bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇa nti ādi desanā sīsam eva sotāpanna ādayaḥ pi  pana abhabbā puthujjana khīṇa āsavānam evam vuttam puthujjanaḥ
translated: The five groups beginning with the impossible🔽“It is impossible, friends, for a bhikkhu whose cankers are destroyed to draw blood from a Tathāgata with a malicious thought” , etc., are the actual words of the teaching. But stream-enterers, etc., are also impossible. And the censure of worldlings and the praise of those whose cankers are destroyed are stated thus: “The worldling is blameworthy; he commits such things as matricide” ,

original: nāma gārayho, mātughātādīnipi karoti. Khīṇāsavo pana pāsaṃso, kunthakipillikaghātādīnipi na karotīti.🔽Byasanesu viyassatīti byasanaṃ, hitasukhaṃ khipati viddhaṃsetīti attho. Ñātīnaṃ byasanaṃ
analyzed: nāma gārayhaḥ mātu ghāta ādīni pi karoti khīṇa āsavaḥ pana pāsaṃsaḥ kuntha kipillika ghāta ādīni pi na karoti iti  byasanesu viyassati iti byasanam hita sukham khipati viddhaṃseti iti atthaḥ ñātīnam byasanam
translated: and “But one whose cankers are destroyed is praiseworthy; he does not commit such things as killing an ant” .

original: ñātibyasanaṃ, corarogabhayādīhi ñātivināsoti attho. Bhogānaṃ byasanaṃ bhogabyasanaṃ,
analyzed: ñāti byasanam cora roga bhaya ādīhi ñāti vināso ti atthaḥ bhogānam byasanam bhoga byasanam
translated: “He would be distressed by misfortunes” : misfortune is misfortune, loss of what is beneficial and pleasurable. The meaning is that he would be deprived of and lose that. “The misfortune of kinsmen” : the destruction of kinsmen by thieves, disease, fear, etc. “The misfortune of property” :

original: rājacorādivasena bhogavināsoti attho. Rogo eva byasanaṃ rogabyasanaṃ. Rogo hi ārogyaṃ
analyzed: rāja cora ādi vasena attho rogaḥ eva byasanam roga byasanam rogaḥ hi ārogyam
translated: The meaning is: loss of enjoyment by way of king, thief, etc. Disease itself is misfortune, thus it is disease-misfortune. For disease

original: byasati vināsetīti byasanaṃ, sīlassa byasanaṃ sīlabyasanaṃ. Dussīlyassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: byasati vināseti iti byasanam sīlassa byasanam sīla byasanam dussīlyaḥ etam nāmam
translated: destroys health, thus it is misfortune. Loss of virtue is virtue-misfortune. This is a name for unvirtuousness.

original: Sammādiṭṭhiṃ vināsayamānā uppannā diṭṭhi eva byasanaṃ diṭṭhibyasanaṃ. Ettha ca ñātibyasanādīni
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhim vināsayamānā uppannā diṭṭhi eva byasanam diṭṭhi byasanam ettha ca ñāti byasana ādīni
translated: The arising of a view that destroys right view is view-misfortune. And here the three, namely, misfortune regarding kinsmen, etc.,

original: tīṇi neva akusalāni na tilakkhaṇāhatāni. Sīladiṭṭhibyasanadvayaṃ akusalaṃ tilakkhaṇāhataṃ.
analyzed: tīṇi na iva akusalāni na ti lakkhaṇa āhatāni sīla diṭṭhi byasana dvayam akusalam ti lakkhaṇa āhatam
translated: are neither unwholesome nor affected by the three characteristics. The two, namely, misfortune regarding virtue and misfortune regarding view, are unwholesome and affected by the three characteristics.

original: Teneva “nāvuso, sattā ñātibyasanahetu vā”tiādimāha.🔽Ñātisampadāti ñātīnaṃ sampadā pāripūrī bahubhāvo. Bhogasampadāyapi eseva nayo. Ārogyassa
analyzed: tena iva na āvuso sattā ñāti byasana hetu vā iti ādim āha  ñāti sampadā ati ñātīnam sampadā pāripūrī bahu bhāvaḥ eṣa iva nayaḥ ārogyassa
translated: Therefore it is said: “Friends, beings are not destroyed through misfortune regarding kinsmen” , etc.

original: sampadā ārogyasampadā. Pāripūrī dīgharattaṃ arogatā. Sīladiṭṭhisampadāsupi eseva
analyzed: sampadā ārogya sampadā pāripūrī dīgharattam aroga tā esā eva
translated: Kinsmen’s excellence: the excellence, the fulfilment, the abundance of kinsmen. The same method applies to the excellence of wealth. The excellence of health is health-excellence. Fulfilment is long-lasting health. The same method applies to the excellence of virtue and the excellence of view.

original: nayo. Idhāpi ñātisampadādayo no kusalā, na tilakkhaṇāhatā. Sīladiṭṭhisampadā kusalā,
analyzed: nayo idha api ñāti sampad ādayaḥ no kusalāḥ na ti lakkhaṇa āhatā sīla diṭṭhi sampadā kusalā
translated: Here too the excellence of kinsmen, etc., are neither wholesome nor affected by the three characteristics. The excellence of virtue and the excellence of view are wholesome and affected by the three characteristics.

original: tilakkhaṇāhatā. Teneva “nāvuso, sattā ñātisampadāhetu vā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇa āhatā tena iva na āvuso sattā vā iti ādim āha
translated: and the three characteristics. That is why he said: “Friends, it is not for the reason of the perfection of relatives that beings … ”

original: Sīlavipattisīlasampattikathā mahāparinibbāne vitthāritāva.🔽Codakenāti vatthusaṃsandassanā, āpattisaṃsandassanā, saṃvāsappaṭikkhepo, sāmīcippaṭikkhepoti
analyzed: sīla vipatti sīla sampatti kathā mahāparinibbāne vitthāritā ava  ca udakena ati vatthu saṃsanda ssanā āpatti saṃsanda ssanā saṃvāsa ppaṭikkhepaḥ sāmīci ppaṭikkhepaḥ ti
translated: The discussion of failure in virtue and perfection of virtue is given in detail in the Great Final Nippaṇa.🔽By one who accuses: by one who accuses by means of the four grounds for accusation, namely, by showing the incident, by showing the offence, by refusing to live with , by refusing to submit .

original: catūhi codanāvatthūhi codayamānena. Kālena vakkhāmi no akālenāti ettha cuditakassa🔽kālo kathito, na codakassa. Paraṃ codentena hi parisamajjhe vā uposathapavāraṇagge
analyzed: catūhi codanā vatthūhi codayamānena kālena vakkhāmi no akālena ati ettha cuditakassa  kālo kathitaḥ na codakassa param codentena hi parisamajjhe vā uposatha pavāraṇa gge
translated: At a proper time, not at an improper time: here the time for the accused🔽is stated, not the time for the accuser. For one who is accusing another should not accuse him in the midst of the Community or at the Invitation ceremony or

original: vā āsanasālābhojanasālādīsu vā na codetabbaṃ. Divāṭṭhāne nisinnakāle “karotāyasmā🔽okāsaṃ, ahaṃ āyasmantaṃ vattukāmo”ti evaṃ okāsaṃ kāretvā codetabbaṃ. Puggalaṃ pana
analyzed: vā āsana sāla abhojana sāla ādīsu vā na codetabbam divāṭṭhāne nisinna kāle  okāsam aham āyasmantam vattu kāmaḥ iti evam okāsam kāretvā codetabbam puggalam pana
translated: in the sitting hall or in the refectory, etc.; he should accuse him when he sees that it is the proper time to do so, that is, when he has seen him committing a heavy offence or when he has been told by another bhikkhu.🔽But if he is a talkative person who will proclaim the bhikkhus’ disgrace, then he should make an opportunity by saying to him, “Venerable sir, make an opportunity; I want to speak to you.”

original: upaparikkhitvā yo lolapuggalo abhūtaṃ vatvā bhikkhūnaṃ ayasaṃ āropeti, so okāsakammaṃ
analyzed: upaparikkhitvā yaḥ lola puggalaḥ abhūtam vatvā bhikkhūnam ayasam āropeti saḥ okāsa kammaṃ
translated: But if he is a person who will not make an opportunity, then he should make an opportunity for himself by going to the place where the bhikkhu is and saying, “Venerable sir, I have something to say to you; let us go to such-and-such a place.”

original: vināpi codetabbo. Bhūtenāti tacchena sabhāvena. Saṇhenāti maṭṭhena mudukena. Atthasañhitenāti
analyzed: vinā api codetabbaḥ bhūtena ati tacchena sabhāvena saṇhena ati maṭṭhena mudukena attha sañhitena ati
translated: even without being reproved. With truth: with what is real, with what is factual. Gently: with gentleness, with mildness. With a mind that is friendly:

original: atthakāmatāya hitakāmatāya upetena.
analyzed: attha kāma tāya hita kāma tāya upetena
translated: with a mind that is friendly, with a mind that is loving.

original: Padhāniyaṅgapañcakavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the five factors of striving

original: 317. Padhāniyaṅgānīti padhānaṃ vuccati padahanaṃ, padhānamassa atthīti padhāniyo,
analyzed: padhāniyaṅgāni iti padhānam vuccati padahanam padhānam assa atthi iti padhāniyaḥ
translated: Striving is called padhana, padahana. He who has that is a padhaniyo.

original: padhāniyassa bhikkhuno aṅgāni padhāniyaṅgāni. Saddhoti saddhāya samannāgato. Saddhā
analyzed: padhāniyassa bhikkhuno aṅgāni padhāniya aṅgāni saddho ti saddhāya samannāgato saddhā
translated: The factors of the striving bhikkhu are padhaniyaṅgāni. Endowed with faith: possessing faith.

original: panesā āgamanasaddhā, adhigamanasaddhā, okappanasaddhā, pasādasaddhāti catubbidhā.
analyzed: pana esā āgamana saddhā adhigamana saddhā okappana saddhā pasāda saddhā ati catubbidhā
translated: But this faith is fourfold: faith as coming, faith as belief, faith as approval, and faith as confidence.

original: Tattha sabbaññubodhisattānaṃ saddhā abhinīhārato āgatattā āgamanasaddhā nāma. Ariyasāvakānaṃ🔽paṭivedhena adhigatattā adhigamanasaddhā nāma. Buddho dhammo saṅghoti vutte acalabhāvena
analyzed: tattha sabbaññu bodhisattānam saddhā abhinīhārataḥ āgata ttā āgamanasaddhā nāma ariya sāvakānam  paṭivedhena adhigata ttā adhigamana saddhā nāma buddhaḥ dhammo saṅgho ti vutte acala bhāvena
translated: Herein, the faith of all-knowing Bodhisattas is called faith as coming because it comes to the resolution ;🔽the faith of noble disciples is called faith as belief because it is attained by penetration ;🔽when it is said “The Enlightened One, the Dhamma, the Community,” it is called faith as approval because it is approval by way of unshakability;

original: okappanaṃ okappanasaddhā nāma. Pasāduppatti pasādasaddhā nāma. Idha okappanasaddhā
analyzed: okappanam okappanasaddhā nāma pasāduppatti pasādasaddhā nāma idha okappanasaddhā
translated: it is called faith as confidence because it is the arising of confidence. Herein, faith as approval is intended.

original: adhippetā. Bodhinti catutthamaggañāṇaṃ. Taṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ tathāgatenāti saddahati.

original: 318. Suddhāvāsāti suddhā idha āvasiṃsu āvasanti āvasissanti vāti suddhāvāsā. Suddhāti kilesamalarahitā anāgāmikhīṇāsavā. Avihātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ mahāpadāne vuttameva.🔽Anāgāmīsu āyuno majjhaṃ anatikkamitvā antarāva kilesaparinibbānaṃ arahattaṃ patto

translated: The five kinds of non-returners who are destined for the Pure Abodes are called “those who attain Nibbāna in the interval,” “those who attain Nibbāna upon landing,” “those who attain Nibbāna without exertion,” “those who attain Nibbāna with exertion,” and “those who go upstream to the highest.”

original: antarāparinibbāyī nāma. Majjhaṃ upahacca atikkamitvā patto upahaccaparinibbāyī nāma.
analyzed: antarāparinibbāyī nāma majjham upahacca atikkamitvā patto upahaccaparinibbāyī nāma
translated: The first of these is one who attains Nibbāna in the interval, the second is one who attains Nibbāna upon landing, the third is one who attains Nibbāna without exertion, the fourth is one who attains Nibbāna with exertion, and the fifth is one who goes upstream to the highest.🔽The first of these is one who attains Nibbāna in the interval, the second is one who attains Nibbāna upon landing, the third is one who attains Nibbāna without exertion, the fourth is one who attains Nibbāna with exertion, and the fifth is one who goes upstream to the highest.

original: Asaṅkhārena appayogena akilamanto sukhena patto asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī nāma. Sasaṅkhārena🔽sappayogena kilamanto dukkhena patto sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī nāma. Ime cattāro pañcasupi

original: suddhāvāsesu labbhanti. Uddhaṃsotoakaniṭṭhagāmīti ettha pana catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ.

original: Cetasovinibandhādipañcakavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the five beginning with “with the mind shackled”

translated: . “With the mind shackled” : they take hold of the mind as if they were binding it and making a bundle of it.

original: sayantassa dakkhiṇapassavāmapassānaṃ sukhaṃ hoti, evaṃ uppannaṃ sukhaṃ. Middhasukhanti🔽niddāsukhaṃ. Anuyuttoti yuttappayutto viharati. Paṇidhāyāti patthayitvā. Brahmacariyenāti🔽methunaviratibrahmacariyena. Devo vā bhavissāmīti mahesakkhadevo vā bhavissāmi. Devaññataro

translated: “The pleasure of lying down” : the pleasure of bed and chair. “The pleasure of the side” : the pleasure that arises as it does for one who sleeps turning from one side to another.

original: vāti appesakkhadevesu vā aññataro.
analyzed: vāti appesakkha devesu vā aññataraḥ
translated: “The pleasure of sleep” : the pleasure of sleep. “Addicted” : addicted to, devoted to. “Aspires” : hopes. “The holy life” : the holy life of abstinence from sexual intercourse. “May I become a god” : may I become a great god. “Or some other god” : or some other god of little importance.

translated: In the first set of five faculties, only mundane faculties are mentioned. In the second set, the first, second, and fourth are mundane.

original: lokiyāni, tatiyapañcamāni lokiyalokuttarāni. Tatiyapañcake samathavipassanāmaggavasena lokiyalokuttarāni.
analyzed: lokiyāni tatiya pañcamāni lokiya lokuttarāni tatiya pañcake samatha vipassanā magga vasena lokiya lokuttarāni
translated: In the first set of five faculties, only mundane faculties are mentioned. In the second set, the first, second, and fourth are mundane; the third and fifth are mundane and supramundane. In the third set, the first three are mundane and supramundane, being the path of serenity, insight, and the path respectively.

original: Nissaraṇiyapañcakavaṇṇanā

translated: Emancipated: detached. Elements: the realities of non-self.🔽When he gives attention to sensual desires: when he directs his mind to sensual desires, when he sends his mind to sensual desires for the purpose of investigating them, like one who, after emerging from the foul meditation, takes a medicine and tests the poison.

original: vīmaṃsanatthaṃ kāmābhimukhaṃ cittaṃ pesentassāti attho. Na pakkhandatīti na pavisati.
analyzed: vīmaṃsana attham kāma abhimukham cittam pesentassa ati atthaḥ na pakkhandati iti na pavisati
translated: Does not enter into them: does not penetrate them.

original: Na pasīdatīti pasādaṃ nāpajjati. Na santiṭṭhatīti na patiṭṭhati. Na vimuccatīti nādhimuccati.
analyzed: na pasīdati iti pasādam na āpajjati na santiṭṭhati iti na patiṭṭhati na vimuccati iti na adhimuccati
translated: Does not become glad: does not attain confidence. Does not settle down: does not become established. Does not become completely concentrated: does not become intent upon them.

original: Yathā pana kukkuṭapattaṃ vā nhārudaddulaṃ vā aggimhi pakkhittaṃ patilīyati patikuṭati
analyzed: yathā pana kukkuṭa pattam vā nhāru daddulam vā aggimhi pakkhittam patilīyati patikuṭati
translated: Just as a cock’s feather or a piece of tendon, when thrown into a fire, draws back, shrinks back,

original: pativattati na sampasāriyati; evaṃ patilīyati na pasāriyati. Nekkhammaṃ kho panāti🔽idha nekkhammaṃ nāma dasasu asubhesu paṭhamajjhānaṃ, tadassa manasikaroto cittaṃ🔽pakkhandati. Tassa taṃ cittanti tassa taṃ asubhajjhānacittaṃ. Sugatanti gocare gatattā🔽suṭṭhu gataṃ. Subhāvitanti ahānabhāgiyattā suṭṭhu bhāvitaṃ. Suvuṭṭhitanti kāmato
analyzed: pativattati na sampasāriyati evam patilīyati na pasāriyati nekkhammam kho pana ati  idha nekkhammam nāma dasasu asubhesu paṭhama jhānam tat assa manasikarotaḥ cittam  pakkhandati tassa tam cittan ti tassa tam asubha jjhāna cittam gocare gata ttā  suṭṭhu gatam su bhāvitanti ahāna bhāgiya ttā suṭṭhu bhāvitam su vuṭṭhitanti kāmataḥ
translated: He does not give confidence, he does not inspire confidence. Thus he does not inspire confidence, he does not give confidence. But when he gives attention to renunciation, his mind enters into it,🔽goes to it, plunges into it, settles on it, and becomes composed on it. His mind: his renunciation-concentration mind. Well-directed: it has gone well to its object. Well-developed: it is well developed without loss. Well-emerged: it has emerged well from the world.

original: suṭṭhu vuṭṭhitaṃ. Suvimuttanti kāmehi suṭṭhu vimuttaṃ. Kāmapaccayā āsavā nāma kāmahetukā🔽cattāro āsavā. Vighātāti dukkhā. Pariḷāhāti kāmarāgapariḷāhā. Na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedetīti🔽so taṃ kāmavedanaṃ vighātapariḷāhavedanañca na vedayati. Idamakkhātaṃ kāmānaṃ nissaraṇanti🔽idaṃ asubhajjhānaṃ kāmehi nissaṭattā kāmānaṃ nissaraṇanti akkhātaṃ. Yo pana taṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: suṭṭhu vuṭṭhitam su vimuttanti kāmehi suṭṭhu vimuttam kāma paccayā āsavā nāma kāma hetukā 🔽cattāro āsavā vighātā ati dukkhā pariḷāhā ati kāma rāga pariḷāhā na saḥ tam vedanam vedeti iti 🔽saḥ tam kāma vedanam vighāta pariḷāha vedanam ca na vedayati idam akkhātam kāmānam nissaraṇam ti 🔽idam asubha jhānam kāmehi nissaṭa ttā kāmānam nissaraṇan ti akkhātam yaḥ pana tam jhānam

original: pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto tatiyaṃ maggaṃ patvā anāgāmiphalena nibbānaṃ disvā
analyzed: pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ tatiyam maggam patvā anāgāmi phalena nibbānam disvā
translated: and having done the preliminary work, he comprehends formations and attains the third path. He sees Nibbāna with the fruit of non-return.

original: puna kāmā nāma natthīti jānāti, tassa cittaṃ accantanissaraṇameva. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: puna kāmā nāma natthi iti jānāti tassa cittam accanta nissaraṇam eva sesa padesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: Then he knows that there are no more sensual desires. His cognizance is only the ultimate escape. The same method applies in the other cases.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso, dutiyavāre mettājhānāni byāpādassa nissaraṇaṃ nāma. Tatiyavāre
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ dutiya vāre mettā jhānāni byāpādassa nissaraṇam nāma tatiya vāre
translated: But there is this difference. In the second section the jhānas of loving-kindness are the escape from ill will. In the third section

original: karuṇājhānāni vihiṃsāya nissaraṇaṃ nāma. Catutthavāre arūpajjhānāni rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ
analyzed: karuṇā jhānāni vihiṃsāya nissaraṇam nāma catuttha vāre arūpa jhānāni nissaraṇam
translated: the jhānas of compassion are the escape from cruelty. In the fourth section the immaterial jhānas are the escape from materiality.

original: nāma. Accantanissaraṇe cettha arahattaphalaṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāma accanta nissaraṇe ca ittha arahatta phalam yojetabbam
translated: But here the ultimate escape is the state of Arahantship that should be construed.

original: Pañcamavāre sakkāyaṃ manasikarototi suddhasaṅkhāre pariggaṇhitvā arahattaṃ pattassa
analyzed: pañcama vāre sa kāyam manasikaroto ti suddha saṅkhāre pariggaṇhitvā arahattam pattassa
translated: In the fifth section, when one who has reached Arahantship by discerning pure formations only🔽and who is a bare-insight worker sends his cognizance in the way beginning “On looking”

original: sukkhavipassakassa phalasamāpattito vuṭṭhāya vīmaṃsanatthaṃ pañcupādānakkhandhābhimukhaṃ🔽cittaṃ pesentassa. Idamakkhātaṃ sakkāyanissaraṇanti idaṃ arahattamaggena ca phalena
analyzed: sukkha vipassakassa phala samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāya vīmaṃsana attham pañca upādāna kkhandha abhimukham 🔽cittam pesentassa idam akkhātam sakkāya nissaraṇan ti idam arahatta maggena ca phalena
translated: to face the five aggregates as objects of clinging, after emerging from fruition attainment,🔽for the purpose of reviewing, this is called “the escape from personality described” .🔽And the path and fruition of Arahantship are the escape from the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: ca nibbānaṃ disvā ṭhitassa bhikkhuno puna sakkāyo natthīti uppannaṃ arahattaphalasamāpatticittaṃ
analyzed: ca nibbānam disvā ṭhitassa bhikkhuno puna sakkāyaḥ natthi iti uppannam arahatta phala samāpatti cittam
translated: When a bhikkhu has seen extinction and is established in it, there is no more renewed existence for him. The consciousness that is the attainment of the fruition of Arahantship arises in him.

original: sakkāyassa nissaraṇanti akkhātaṃ.
analyzed: sakkāyassa nissaraṇanti akkhātam
translated: This is called the escape from renewed existence.

original: Vimuttāyatanapañcakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vimutta āyatana pañcaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The five bases of freedom🔽The bases of freedom are the causes of freedom.

original: 322. Vimuttāyatanānīti vimuccanakāraṇāni. Atthapaṭisaṃvedinoti pāḷiatthaṃ jānantassa.🔽Dhammapaṭisaṃvedinoti pāḷiṃ jānantassa. Pāmojjanti taruṇapīti. Pītīti tuṭṭhākārabhūtā
analyzed: vimutta āyatanāni iti vimuccana kāraṇāni attha paṭisaṃvedinaḥ ti pāḷi attham jānantassa  dhamma paṭisaṃvedino ti pāḷim jānantassa pāmojjanti taruṇa pīti pīti iti tuṭṭha ākāra bhūtā
translated: One who has experience of the meaning of the text is one who knows the meaning of the text.🔽One who has experience of the text is one who knows the text.🔽Joy is tender happiness. Happiness is strong happiness.

original: balavapīti. Kāyoti nāmakāyo paṭipassambhati. Sukhaṃ vedayatīti sukhaṃ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: balavā iti kāyo ti nāma kāyo paṭipassambhati sukham vedayati iti sukham paṭilabhati
translated: The body is the mental body. It is calmed. He feels pleasure is he obtains pleasure.🔽The mind is concentrated is concentrated by means of the concentration of the fruition of Arahantship.

original: Cittaṃ samādhiyatīti arahattaphalasamādhinā samādhiyati. Ayañhi taṃ dhammaṃ suṇanto
analyzed: cittam samādhiyati iti arahatta phala samādhinā samādhiyati ayan hi tam dhammam suṇantaḥ
translated: For when he hears that Dhamma,

original: āgatāgataṭṭhāne jhānavipassanāmaggaphalāni jānāti, tassa evaṃ jānato pīti uppajjati.
analyzed: āgata āgata ṭṭhāne jhāna vipassanā magga phalāni jānāti tassa evam jānataḥ pīti uppajjati
translated: he knows wherever he goes the jhanas, insight, the paths, and the fruits. As he thus knows, happiness arises in him.

original: So tassā pītiyā antarā osakkituṃ na dento upacārakammaṭṭhāniko hutvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: so tassā pītiyā antarā osakkitum na dentaḥ upacāra kammaṭṭhānikaḥ hutvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: He does not allow it to subside in the intervals. He develops insight, making the meditation subject his vehicle,

original: arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “cittaṃ samādhiyatī”ti. Sesesupi eseva
analyzed: arahattam pāpuṇāti tam sandhāya vuttam cittam samādhiyati iti sesesu pi esā eva
translated: He reaches Arahantship. It was with reference to him that it was said: “The mind becomes concentrated. ” The same method of explanation applies in the rest of the section.

original: nayo. Ayaṃ pana viseso, samādhinimittanti aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu aññataro samādhiyeva🔽samādhinimittaṃ. Suggahitaṃ hotītiādīsu ācariyasantike kammaṭṭhānaṃ uggaṇhantena
analyzed: nayaḥ ayam pana viseso samādhi nimittan ti aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu aññataro  samādhi nimittam suggahitam hoti itiādīsu ācariya santike kammaṭṭhānam uggaṇhantena
translated: But there is this difference: “The sign of concentration” is any one of the thirty-eight objects of meditation.🔽“Well apprehended” : when he learns the meditation subject from a teacher, he learns it well.

original: suṭṭhu gahitaṃ hoti. Suṭṭhu manasikatanti suṭṭhu upadhāritaṃ. Suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāyāti
analyzed: suṭṭhu gahitam hoti suṭṭhu manasikatanti suṭṭhu upadhāritam su paṭividdham paññāyāti
translated: “Well attended to” : he attends well to it.🔽“Well penetrated by wisdom” : he makes it well evident by means of wisdom.

original: paññāya suṭṭhu paccakkhaṃ kataṃ. Tasmiṃ dhammeti tasmiṃ kammaṭṭhānapāḷidhamme.
analyzed: paññāya suṭṭhu paccakkham katam tasmin dhamme ti tasmin kammaṭṭhāna pāḷi dhamme
translated: “That idea” : that meditation subject as text.

original: Vimuttiparipācanīyāti vimutti vuccati arahattaṃ, taṃ paripācentīti vimuttiparipācanīyā.🔽Aniccasaññāti aniccānupassanāñāṇe uppannasaññā. Anicce dukkhasaññāti dukkhānupassanāñāṇe
analyzed: vimutti paripācanīyā ati vimutti vuccati arahattam tam paripācenti iti vimutti paripācanīyā  anicca saññā ati anicca anupassanā ñāṇe uppanna saññā anicce dukkha saññā ati dukkha anupassanā ñāṇe
translated: “Conducive to deliverance” : deliverance is Arahantship; they bring it to fulfilment, thus they are “conducive to deliverance.”🔽“Perception of impermanence” : the perception arisen with the knowledge of contemplation of impermanence.🔽“Perception of suffering in the impermanent” : the perception arisen with the knowledge of contemplation of suffering.

original: uppannasaññā. Dukkhe anattasaññāti anattānupassanāñāṇe uppannasaññā. Pahānasaññāti
analyzed: uppanna saññā dukkhe anatta saññā ati anatta anupassanā ñāṇe uppanna saññā pahāna saññā ati
translated: “Perception of non-self in what is suffering” : the perception arisen with the knowledge of contemplation of non-self.🔽“Perception of abandoning” :

original: pahānānupassanāñāṇe uppannasaññā. Virāgasaññāti virāgānupassanāñāṇe uppannasaññā.
analyzed: pahāna anupassanā ñāṇe uppanna saññā virāga saññā ati virāga anupassanā ñāṇe uppanna saññā
translated: Perception of the abandoning is the perception arisen through the knowledge of contemplation of abandoning. Perception of fading away is the perception arisen through the knowledge of contemplation of fading away.

original: “Ime kho āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti chabbīsatiyā pañcakānaṃ vasena tiṃsasatapañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti chabbīsatiyā pañcakānam vasena tiṃsa sata pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friend,” etc., should be construed in the same way as above. Thus the Elder showed the unity of meaning by means of twenty-six sets of five.

original: Pañcakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañcaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the set of five is ended.

original: Chakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the set of six

original: 323. Iti pañcakavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni chakkavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ
analyzed: iti pañcaka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni chakka vasena dassetum puna desanam
translated: Having shown the unity of meaning by means of the set of five, the Elder now began the teaching again in order to show it by means of the set of six.

original: ārabhi. Tattha ajjhattikānīti ajjhattajjhattikāni. Bāhirānīti tato ajjhattajjhattato
analyzed: ārabhi tattha ajjhattikāni iti ajjhat tajjhattikāni bāhirāni iti tatas ajjhat tajjhat tatas
translated: Herein, internal are those in oneself. External are those apart from oneself.

original: bahibhūtāni. Vitthārato pana āyatanakathā visuddhimagge kathitāva. Viññāṇakāyāti
analyzed: bahi bhūtāni vitthārato pana āyatana kathā visuddhi magge kathitā ava viññāṇakāya ati
translated: But the detailed explanation of the bases is given in the Visuddhimagga .

original: viññāṇasamūhā. Cakkhuviññāṇanti cakkhupasādanissitaṃ kusalākusalavipākaviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: viññāṇa samūhā cakkhu viññāṇanti cakkhu pasāda nissitam kusala akusala vipāka viññāṇam
translated: Consciousness-bodies are groups of consciousness. Eye-consciousness is profitable, unprofitable, and resultant consciousness dependent on the eye faculty.

original: Esa nayo sabbattha. Cakkhusamphassoti cakkhunissito samphasso. Sotasamphassādīsupi
analyzed: esa nayaḥ sabbattha cakkhu samphasso ti cakkhu nissito samphasso sota samphassa ādīsu pi
translated: The same method applies in all cases. Eye-contact is contact associated with the eye faculty. In the case of ear-contact, etc.,

original: eseva nayo. Manosamphassoti ime dasa samphasse ṭhapetvā seso sabbo manosamphasso🔽nāma. Vedanāchakkampi eteneva nayena veditabbaṃ. Rūpasaññāti rūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ manaḥ samphasso ti ime dasa samphasse ṭhapetvā sesaḥ sabbaḥ manaḥ samphasso  nāma vedanā chakkam pi etena iva nayena veditabbam rūpa saññā ati rūpam ārammaṇam katvā
translated: Except for these ten kinds of contact, all the rest is called mental contact.🔽The same method applies to the feeling triad. “Perception of forms”: the perception that arises with a form as its object.

original: uppannā saññā. Etenupāyena sesāpi veditabbā. Cetanāchakkepi eseva nayo. Tathā taṇhāchakke.
analyzed: uppannā saññā etena upāyena sesā api veditabbā cetanā chakke pi esa iva nayaḥ tathā taṇhā chakke
translated: The rest should be understood in the same way. The same method applies to the volition triad. So too, to the craving triad.

original: Agāravoti gāravavirahito. Appatissoti appatissayo anīcavutti. Ettha pana yo bhikkhu
analyzed: agāravaḥ ti gārava virahitaḥ appatissaḥ ti appatissayaḥ anīca vutti ettha pana yaḥ bhikkhu
translated: “Lack of respect”: absence of respect. “Lack of deference”: absence of deference, absence of a reverential manner. Herein, a bhikkhu🔽who does not attend upon the Teacher during the three watches of the night,

original: satthari dharamāne tīsu kālesu upaṭṭhānaṃ na yāti. Satthari anupāhane caṅkamante🔽saupāhano caṅkamati, nīce caṅkamante ucce caṅkamati, heṭṭhā vasante upari vasati,🔽satthudassanaṭṭhāne ubho aṃse pārupati, chattaṃ dhāreti, upāhanaṃ dhāreti, nahāyati,
analyzed: satthari dharamāne tīsu kālesu upaṭṭhānam na yāti satthari an upāhane caṅkamante  saupāhano caṅkamati nīce caṅkamante ucce caṅkamati heṭṭhā vasante upari vasati  satthu dassana ṭṭhāne ubho aṃse pārupati chattam dhāreti upāhanam dhāreti nahāyati
translated: who walks up and down when the Teacher is sitting,

original: uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā karoti. Parinibbute pana cetiyaṃ vandituṃ na gacchati, cetiyassa
analyzed: uccāram vā passāvam vā karoti parinibbute pana cetiyam vanditum na gacchati cetiyassa
translated: who sits when the Teacher is lying down, who wears his upper robe on one shoulder when the Teacher is wearing it over both shoulders, who wears his robe over both shoulders when the Teacher is wearing it on one shoulder, who covers both ears when the Teacher is covering only one, who covers only one ear when the Teacher is covering both, who walks too close behind the Teacher, who walks too far away from the Teacher, who walks on a higher walk when the Teacher is walking on a lower one, who walks on a lower walk when the Teacher is walking on a higher one, who stays in a place too far away when the Teacher is staying too near, who stays in a place too near when the Teacher is staying too far away, who sits too close to the Teacher, who sits too far from the Teacher, who sits higher than the Teacher, who sits lower than the Teacher, who sits on the same level as the Teacher without first being invited to do so, who sits on a seat higher than the Teacher’s without first being invited to do so, who sits on a seat lower than the Teacher’s when he is able to sit on one even with the Teacher’s, who sits on a seat even with the Teacher’s when he is able to sit on one higher than the Teacher’s, who sits on a seat higher than the Teacher’s without first being invited to do so, who sits on a seat lower than the Teacher’s when he is able to sit on one even with the Teacher’s, who sits on a seat even with the Teacher’s when he is able to sit on one higher than the Teacher’s, who sits on a seat higher than the Teacher’s without first being invited to do so, who sits on a seat lower than the Teacher’s when he is able to sit on

original: paññāyanaṭṭhāne satthudassanaṭṭhāne vuttaṃ sabbaṃ karoti, ayaṃ satthari agāravo nāma.
analyzed: paññāyanaṭṭhāne satthu dassanaṭṭhāne vuttam sabbam karoti ayam satthari agāravaḥ nāma
translated: He does all the things mentioned in the case of the teacher in the place of training. This is called disrespect towards the teacher.

original: Yo pana dhammassavane saṃghuṭṭhe sakkaccaṃ na gacchati, sakkaccaṃ dhammaṃ na suṇāti,
analyzed: yaḥ pana dhammassavane saṃghuṭṭhe sakkaccam na gacchati sakkaccam dhammam na suṇāti
translated: But one who, when the Dhamma is being recited, does not go to hear it attentively, does not listen attentively to the Dhamma,

original: samullapanto nisīdati, sakkaccaṃ na gaṇhāti, na vāceti, ayaṃ dhamme agāravo nāma.
analyzed: samullapantaḥ nisīdati sakkaccam na gaṇhāti na vācā iti ayam dhamme agāravaḥ nāma
translated: sits yawning, does not grasp the Dhamma attentively, does not recite it, this is called disrespect towards the Dhamma.

original: Yo pana therena bhikkhunā anajjhiṭṭho dhammaṃ deseti, nisīdati, pañhaṃ katheti, vuḍḍhe🔽bhikkhū ghaṭṭento gacchati, tiṭṭhati, nisīdati, dussapallatthikaṃ vā hatthapallatthikaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ pana therena bhikkhunā an ajjhiṭṭhaḥ dhammaṃ deseti nisīdati pañham katheti vuḍḍhe  bhikkhū ghaṭṭentaḥ gacchati tiṭṭhati nisīdati dussa pallatthikam vā hattha pallatthikam
translated: But one who, not being asked by an elder bhikkhu, teaches the Dhamma, sits down, answers a question, goes about bumping into elder bhikkhus,

original: vā karoti, saṅghamajjhe ubho aṃse pārupati, chattupāhanaṃ dhāreti, ayaṃ saṅghe agāravo
analyzed: vā karoti saṅgha majjhe ubho aṃse pārupati chattu pāhanam dhāreti ayam saṅghe agāravaḥ
translated: stands, sits, makes a sunshade-holder or a foot- wiper out of the robe-material, wraps both shoulders in the robe in the midst of the Sangha, carries an umbrella and a staff, this is called disrespect towards the Sangha.

original: nāma. Ekabhikkhusmimpi hi agārave kate saṅghe agāravo katova hoti. Tisso sikkhā pana
analyzed: nāma eka bhikkhusmim pi hi agārave kate saṅghe agāravaḥ kato va hoti tisso sikkhā pana
translated: For when disrespect is shown to even one bhikkhu, disrespect is shown to the Sangha. But one who does not fulfil the three trainings

original: apūrayamānova sikkhāya agāravo nāma. Appamādalakkhaṇaṃ ananubrūhayamāno appamāde
analyzed: a pūrayamānaḥ iva sikkhāya agāravaḥ nāma appamāda lakkhaṇam an anubrūhayamānaḥ appamāde
translated: is called “disrespectful towards the training.” One who does not maintain the characteristic of heedfulness, who does not maintain heedfulness,

original: agāravo nāma. Duvidhampi paṭisanthāraṃ akaronto paṭisanthāre agāravo nāma. Cha gāravā
analyzed: agāravaḥ nāma duvidham pi paṭisanthāram a karonto paṭisanthāre agāravaḥ nāma cha gāravā
translated: Disrespect: he does not do the two kinds of paying of respect.

original: vuttappaṭipakkhavasena veditabbā.
analyzed: vutta paṭipakkha vasena veditabbā
translated: The six kinds of respect should be understood in the opposite sense to the six kinds of disrespect.

original: Somanassūpavicārāti somanassasampayuttā vicārā. Somanassaṭṭhāniyanti somanassakāraṇabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: somanassūpavicārā ati somanassa sampayuttāḥ vicārā somanassa ṭṭhāniyanti somanassa kāraṇa bhūtam
translated: Ruminations of joy: the kinds of thought associated with joy. Reasons for joy: the things that are the cause of joy.

original: Upavicaratīti vitakkena vitakketvā vicārena paricchindati. Esa nayo sabbattha. Domanassūpavicārāpi
analyzed: upavicarati iti vitakkena vitakketvā vicārena paricchindati esa nayo sabbattha domanassu upavicārā api
translated: He ruminate upon them: he thinks with applied thought and determines with sustained thought. The same method applies in all cases. Ruminations of grief

original: evameva veditabbā. Tathā upekkhūpavicārā. Sāraṇīyadhammā heṭṭhā vitthāritā. Diṭṭhisāmaññagatoti
analyzed: evam eva veditabbā tathā upekkhu upavicārā sāraṇīya dhammā heṭṭhā vitthāritā diṭṭhi sāmañña gatā ti
translated: should be understood in the same way. So too with ruminations of on-looking. The things that make for cleaving are given in detail below .

original: iminā pana padena kosambakasutte paṭhamamaggo kathito. Idha cattāropi maggā.
analyzed: iminā pana padena kosambaka sutte paṭhama maggo kathito idha cattāro api maggā
translated: The same as the view: by this phrase the first path is stated in the Kosambiya Sutta . But here all four paths are intended.

original: Vivādamūlachakkavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the four roots of disputes

original: 325. Vivādamūlānīti vivādassa mūlāni. Kodhanoti kujjhanalakkhaṇena kodhena samannāgato.
analyzed: vivāda mūlāni iti vivādassa mūlāni kodhanaḥ ti kujjhana lakkhaṇena kodhena samannāgato
translated: Roots of disputes: the roots of disputes. Angry: endowed with anger, which has the characteristic of annoyance.

original: Upanāhīti veraappaṭinissaggalakkhaṇena upanāhena samannāgato. Ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānanti
analyzed: upanāhī iti veraa paṭinissagga lakkhaṇena upanāhena samannāgataḥ ahitāya dukkhāya deva manussānaṃ ti
translated: Bear malice: endowed with malice, which has the characteristic of non-abandoning of enmity. To the harm and suffering of gods and humans

original: dvinnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vivādo kathaṃ devamanussānaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattati. Kosambakakkhandhake🔽viya dvīsu bhikkhūsu vivādaṃ āpannesu tasmiṃ vihāre tesaṃ antevāsikā vivadanti. Tesaṃ🔽ovādaṃ gaṇhanto bhikkhunisaṅgho vivadati. Tato tesaṃ upaṭṭhākā vivadanti. Atha manussānaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam bhikkhūnam vivādaḥ katham deva manussānam ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattati kosambaka khandhake  viya dvīsu bhikkhūsu vivādam āpannesu tasmin vihāre tesam antevāsikāḥ vivadanti tesam  ovādam gaṇhantaḥ bhikkhuni saṅghaḥ vivadati tatas tesam upaṭṭhākāḥ vivadanti atha manussānam
translated: In the Kosambī Khandhaka,🔽when two monks had a dispute, their pupils also disputed.🔽The nuns’ Sangha, which was receiving their advice, disputed. Then their supporters disputed. Then the protective deities of the people split into two factions.

original: ārakkhadevatā dve koṭṭhāsā honti. Tattha dhammavādīnaṃ ārakkhadevatā dhammavādiniyo
analyzed: ārakkha devatāḥ dve koṭṭhāsāḥ honti tattha dhamma vādīnam ārakkha devatāḥ dhamma vādiniyo
translated: The protective deities of those who spoke in accordance with the Teaching became those who spoke in accordance with the Teaching,

original: honti adhammavādīnaṃ adhammavādiniyo. Tato ārakkhadevatānaṃ mittā bhummā devatā bhijjanti.
analyzed: honti adhamma vādīnam adhamma vādiniyaḥ tatas ārakkha devatānam mittāḥ bhummāḥ devatāḥ bhijjanti
translated: and the protective deities of those who spoke contrary to the Teaching became those who spoke contrary to the Teaching. Then the deities of the earth who were friends of the protective deities split.

original: Evaṃ paramparā yāva brahmalokā ṭhapetvā ariyasāvake sabbe devamanussā dve koṭṭhāsā
analyzed: evam paramparā yāva brahmalokāḥ ṭhapetvā ariyasāvake sabbe deva manussā dve koṭṭhāsā
translated: In this way, the process continued all the way up to the Brahma worlds. Except for the noble disciples, all the gods and humans split into two factions.

original: honti. Dhammavādīhi pana adhammavādinova bahutarā honti. Tato “yaṃ bahukehi gahitaṃ,
analyzed: honti dhamma vādīhi pana adhamma vādinaḥ uva bahutarāḥ honti tatas yam bahukehi gahitam
translated: But those who spoke in accordance with the Teaching were more numerous than those who spoke contrary to the Teaching. Then those who spoke in accordance with the Teaching said,

original: taṃ taccha”nti dhammaṃ vissajjetvā bahutarāva adhammaṃ gaṇhanti. Te adhammaṃ purakkhatvā
analyzed: tam tacchanti dhammam vissajjetvā bahutarā ava adhammam gaṇhanti te adhammam purakkhatvā
translated: They then speak in favor of what is contrary to the Dhamma,

original: vadantā apāyesu nibbattanti. Evaṃ dvinnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vivādo devamanussānaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti.🔽Ajjhattaṃ vāti tumhākaṃ abbhantaraparisāya. Bahiddhā vāti paresaṃ parisāya.
analyzed: vadantā apāyesu nibbattanti evam dvinnam bhikkhūnam vivādaḥ deva manussānam ahitāya dukkhāya hoti  ajjhattam vāti tumhākam abbhantara parisāya bahiddhā vāti paresam parisāya
translated: and they are reborn in states of misery. This is how a dispute between two monks is harmful and detrimental to many people, to gods and humans.🔽In your own community: in your own assembly.🔽In the other community: in the other assembly.🔽Scornful: possessing the characteristic of scorning the good qualities of others. Arrogant: possessing the characteristic of being difficult to admonish.

original: Makkhīti paresaṃ guṇamakkhanalakkhaṇena makkhena samannāgato. Paḷāsīti yugaggāhalakkhaṇena🔽paḷāsena samannāgato. Issukīti parasakkārādīni issāyanalakkhaṇāya issāya samannāgato.🔽Maccharīti āvāsamacchariyādīhi samannāgato. Saṭhoti kerāṭiko. Māyāvīti katapāpapaṭicchādako.
analyzed: makkhī iti paresam guṇa makkhana lakkhaṇena makkhena samannāgataḥ paḷāsī iti yuga ggāha lakkhaṇena  paḷāsena samannāgataḥ issukī ti para sakkāra ādīni issāyana lakkhaṇāya issāya samannāgataḥ  maccharī iti āvāsamacchariya ādīhi samannāgato saṭho ti kerāṭikaḥ māyāvī iti kata pāpa paṭicchādako
