translated: Envious: possessing the characteristic of envying the gains, respect,🔽commendation, and homage received by others. Stingy: possessing the characteristic of being difficult to support.🔽Crafty: deceitful. Deceitful: concealing one’s bad conduct.

original: Pāpicchoti asantasambhāvanicchako dussīlo. Micchādiṭṭhīti natthikavādī ahetukavādī
analyzed: pāpa iccho ti asanta sambhāvanā icchakaḥ dussīlaḥ micchādiṭṭhī iti natthika vādī ahetuka vādī
translated: Evil-willed: unvirtuous, wishing for gain and honor. Wrong view: the view that there is no giving, no offering, no good result from good deeds, no bad result from bad deeds; that there is no this world, no next world, no mother, no father, no spontaneously reborn beings; no ascetics and brahmins who, faring rightly and well in this world, proclaim this world and the next after having directly known and realized it for themselves.

original: akiriyavādī. Sandiṭṭhiparāmāsīti sayaṃ diṭṭhimeva parāmasati. Ādhānaggāhīti daḷhaggāhī.
analyzed: akiriya vādī sandiṭṭhi parāmāsī iti sayam diṭṭhim eva parāmasati ādhāna ggāhī iti daḷha ggāhī
translated: He is a nihilist. He is one who holds to what is seen, etc., in that he holds to his own view of what is seen, etc., as supreme. He is one who grasps at rules and vows: he grasps them firmly.

original: Duppaṭinissaggīti na sakkā hoti gahitaṃ vissajjāpetuṃ.
analyzed: duppaṭinissaggī iti na sakkā hoti gahitam vissajjāpetum
translated: He is hard to admonish: he cannot be made to relinquish what he has grasped.

original: Pathavīdhātūti patiṭṭhādhātu. Āpodhātūti ābandhanadhātu. Tejodhātūti paripācanadhātu. Vāyodhātūti vitthambhanadhātu. Ākāsadhātūti asamphuṭṭhadhātu. Viññāṇadhātūti vijānanadhātu.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti patiṭṭhā dhātu āpaḥ dhātu uti ābandhana dhātu tejaḥ dhātu uti paripācana dhātu vāyo dhātu uti vitthambhana dhātu ākāsa dhātu uti asamphuṭṭha dhātu viññāṇa dhātu uti vijānana dhātu
translated: The earth element is the element of support; the water element is the element of cohesion; the fire element is the element of maturing; the air element is the element of distension; the space element is the element of inhesion; the consciousness element is the element of cognizing.

original: Nissaraṇiyachakkavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “escape”

original: 326. Nissaraṇiyā dhātuyoti nissaṭadhātuyova. Pariyādāya tiṭṭhatīti pariyādiyitvā🔽hāpetvā tiṭṭhati. ‘Mā hevantissa vacanīyo’ti yasmā abhūtaṃ byākaraṇaṃ byākaroti,
analyzed: nissaraṇiyā dhātuyā uti pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti  hāpetvā tiṭṭhati mā hevantissa vacanīyo ti yasmai abhūtam byākaraṇam byākaroti
translated: The escape from materiality is the immaterial states. It “stands pervading” in that it stands having pervaded.🔽It “stands having pervaded” in that it stands having pervaded and taken them as its object. “He should not be told: ‘Don’t say so’” because he gives an answer that is not in accordance with fact.

original: tasmā mā evaṃ bhaṇīti vattabbo. Yadidaṃ mettācetovimuttīti yā ayaṃ mettācetovimutti,
analyzed: tasmai mā evam bhaṇi iti vattabbaḥ yat idam mettā cetaḥ vimutti iti yā ayam mettā cetaḥ vimutti
translated: “This deliverance of will by loving-kindness”: this deliverance of will by loving-kindness,

original: idaṃ nissaraṇaṃ byāpādassa, byāpādato nissaṭāti attho. Yo pana mettāya tikacatukkajjhānato
analyzed: idam nissaraṇam byāpādassa byāpādataḥ nissaṭā ati atthaḥ yaḥ pana mettāya tika catukka jhānato
translated: is the escape from ill will, in that it is the escape from ill will. But one who has attained the jhāna of loving-kindness in the fourfold or fivefold way,

original: vuṭṭhito saṅkhāre sammasitvā tatiyamaggaṃ patvā “puna byāpādo natthī”ti tatiyaphalena
analyzed: vuṭṭhitaḥ saṅkhāre sammasitvā tatiya maggam patvā puna byāpādaḥ natthi iti tatiya phalena
translated: and after emerging he comprehended the formations and attained the third path and fruit, and with the third fruit🔽

original: nibbānaṃ passati, tassa cittaṃ accantaṃ nissaraṇaṃ byāpādassa. Etenupāyena sabbattha attho veditabbo.🔽Animittā cetovimuttīti arahattaphalasamāpatti. Sā hi rāganimittādīnañceva rūpanimittādīnañca🔽niccanimittādīnañca abhāvā “animittā”ti vuttā. Nimittānusārīti vuttappabhedaṃ nimittaṃ
analyzed: nibbānam passati tassa cittam accantam nissaraṇam byāpādassa etena upāyena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbo  animittā cetaḥ vimutti iti sā hi rāga nimitta ādīnam ca iva rūpa nimitta ādīnam ca  nicca nimitta ādīnam ca abhāvāḥ animittā ati vuttā nimitta anusārī iti vutta ppabhedam nimittam
translated: When he has emerged from it, he comprehends formations and he attains the third path. He sees Nibbāna with the third fruit. His cognizance is utterly freed from ill will.🔽The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances.🔽The signless mind-deliverance is the attainment of the fruition of Arahantship. That is called “signless” because of the absence of the signs of greed, etc., and of the signs of materiality, etc.,

original: anusaratīti nimittānusārī.
analyzed: anusarati iti nimitta anusārī
translated: and of the signs of permanence, etc.🔽He pursues the sign: he pursues the sign of the kind already stated.

original: Asmīti asmimāno. Ayamahamasmīti pañcasu khandhesu ayaṃ nāma ahaṃ asmīti ettāvatā
analyzed: asmi iti asmimānaḥ ayam aham asmi iti pañcasu khandhesu ayam nāma aham asmi iti ettāvatā
translated: I am: the conceit “I am.”🔽This is how the declaration of Arahantship is made.

original: arahattaṃ byākataṃ hoti. Vicikicchākathaṃkathāsallanti vicikicchābhūtaṃ kathaṃkathāsallaṃ.🔽‘Mā hevantissa vacanīyo’ti sace te paṭhamamaggavajjhā vicikicchā uppajjati, arahattabyākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: arahattam byākatam hoti vicikicchā kathaṃkathā sallanti vicikicchā bhūtam kathaṃkathā sallam 🔽mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ ti sace te paṭhama magga vajjhā vicikicchā uppajjati arahatta byākaraṇam
translated: The doubt-needle of uncertainty: the doubt-needle that is uncertainty.

original: micchā hoti, tasmā mā abhūtaṃ bhaṇīti vāretabbo. Asmimānasamugghātoti arahattamaggo.
analyzed: micchā hoti tasmai mā abhūtam bhaṇi iti vāretabbaḥ asmimāna samugghāto ti arahatta maggo
translated: The “eradication of the conceit ‘I am’” is the path of arahatship.

original: Arahattamaggaphalavasena hi nibbāne diṭṭhe puna asmimāno natthīti arahattamaggo asmimānasamugghātoti vutto.
analyzed: arahatta magga phala vasena hi nibbāne diṭṭhe puna asmimānaḥ natthi iti arahatta maggaḥ asmimāna samugghāto ti vutto
translated: For when Nibbāna is seen through the path of arahatship and its fruit, the conceit “I am” has no further existence.

original: Anuttariyādichakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anuttariya ādi chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The six kinds of “unsurpassedness”

original: 327. Anuttariyānīti anuttarāni jeṭṭhakāni. Dassanesu anuttariyaṃ dassanānuttariyaṃ.
analyzed: anuttariyāni iti anuttarāni jeṭṭhakāni dassanesu anuttariyam dassana anuttariyam
translated: are the unsurpassed, the highest. The unsurpassedness of seeing is the unsurpassed seeing.

original: Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Tattha hatthiratanādīnaṃ dassanaṃ na dassanānuttariyaṃ,🔽niviṭṭhasaddhassa pana niviṭṭhapemavasena dasabalassa vā bhikkhusaṅghassa vā kasiṇāsubhanimittādīnaṃ🔽vā aññatarassa dassanaṃ dassanānuttariyaṃ nāma. Khattiyādīnaṃ guṇakathāsavanaṃ na
analyzed: sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ tattha hatthi ratana ādīnam dassanam na dassana anuttariyam  niviṭṭha saddhassa pana niviṭṭha pema vasena dasabalassa vā bhikkhu saṅghassa vā kasiṇa asubha nimitta ādīnam  vā aññatarassa dassanam dassana anuttariyam nāma khattiya ādīnam guṇa kathā savanam na
translated: The same method applies in the other cases. Herein, the seeing of the elephant treasure, etc., is not the unsurpassed seeing.🔽But the seeing of the Master of the Ten Powers by one of confirmed faith, or of the Community of Bhikkhus by one of confirmed affection, or of the kasiṇa sign, etc., by one of confirmed understanding, is called the unsurpassed seeing.🔽The hearing of the praises of the qualities of the khattiyas, etc., is not the unsurpassed hearing.

original: savanānuttariyaṃ, niviṭṭhasaddhassa pana niviṭṭhapemavasena tiṇṇaṃ vā ratanānaṃ guṇakathāsavanaṃ
analyzed: savana anuttariyam niviṭṭha saddhassa pana niviṭṭha pema vasena tiṇṇam vā rata nānam guṇa kathā savanam
translated: But the hearing of the praises of the qualities of the Three Jewels by one of confirmed faith, etc., is the unsurpassed hearing.

original: tepiṭakabuddhavacanasavanaṃ vā savanānuttariyaṃ nāma. Maṇiratanādilābho na lābhānuttariyaṃ,
analyzed: tepiṭaka buddhavacana savanam vā savana anuttariyam nāma maṇi ratana ādi lābhaḥ na lābha anuttariyam
translated: Or else, hearing the Buddha’s word in the three Piṭakas is the “unsurpassed hearing.” The acquisition of the jewel treasure, etc., is not the “unsurpassed acquisition.”

original: sattavidhaariyadhanalābho pana lābhānuttariyaṃ nāma. Hatthisippādisikkhanaṃ na sikkhānuttariyaṃ,
analyzed: sattavidha ariya dhana lābhaḥ pana lābha anuttariyam nāma hatthi sippa ādi sikkhanam na sikkhā anuttariyam
translated: But the acquisition of the seven kinds of wealth of ariyans is the “unsurpassed acquisition.” The training in elephant-craft, etc., is not the “unsurpassed training.”

original: sikkhattayapūraṇaṃ pana sikkhānuttariyaṃ nāma. Khattiyādīnaṃ pāricariyā na pāricariyānuttariyaṃ,
analyzed: sikkhattaya pūraṇam pana sikkhānuttariyam nāma khattiya ādīnam pāricariyā na pāricariyānuttariyam
translated: But the fulfilment of the three trainings is the “unsurpassed training.” The service of the khattiya, etc., is not the “unsurpassed service.”

original: tiṇṇaṃ pana ratanānaṃ pāricariyā pāricariyānuttariyaṃ nāma. Khattiyādīnaṃ guṇānussaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam pana ratanānam pāricariyā pāricariyānuttariyam nāma khattiya ādīnam guṇa anussaraṇam
translated: But the service of the three treasures is the “unsurpassed service.” The recollection of the virtues of the khattiya, etc.,

original: nānussatānuttariyaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ pana ratanānaṃ guṇānussaraṇaṃ anussatānuttariyaṃ nāma.
analyzed: na anussata anuttariyam tiṇṇam pana ratanānam guṇa anussaraṇam anussata anuttariyam nāma
translated: is not the “unsurpassed recollection.” But the recollection of the virtues of the three treasures is the “unsurpassed recollection.”

original: Anussatiyova anussatiṭṭhānāni nāma. Buddhānussatīti buddhassa guṇānussaraṇaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: anussatiyaḥ eva anussati ṭṭhānāni nāma buddha anussatī iti buddhassa guṇa anussaraṇam evam
translated: The recollections are called the “bases of the unsurpassed recollection.” The recollection of the Buddha is the recollection of the virtues of the Buddha.

original: anussarato hi pīti uppajjati. So taṃ pītiṃ khayato vayato paṭṭhapetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: anussarataḥ hi pīti uppajjati so tam pītim khayataḥ vayataḥ paṭṭhapetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti
translated: For when one recollects in this way, happiness arises. He, having begun with the destruction and fall of that happiness, attains arahatship.

original: Upacārakammaṭṭhānaṃ nāmetaṃ gihīnampi labbhati, esa nayo sabbattha. Vitthārakathā
analyzed: upacāra kammaṭṭhānam nāma etam gihīnam pi labbhati esa nayaḥ sabbattha vitthāra kathā
translated: This is not a meditation subject for the laity. The same method applies in all cases.

original: panettha visuddhimagge vuttanayeneva veditabbā.
analyzed: pana ittha visuddhi magge vutta nayena iva veditabbā
translated: The detailed explanation should be understood as given in the Path of Purity.

original: Satatavihārachakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: satatavihāra chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The six constant practices

original: 328. Satatavihārāti khīṇāsavassa niccavihārā. Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti cakkhudvārārammaṇe🔽āpāthagate taṃ rūpaṃ cakkhuviññāṇena disvā javanakkhaṇe iṭṭhe arajjanto neva sumano
analyzed: satata vihārā ati khīṇa āsavassa nicca vihārā cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati cakkhu dvāra ārammaṇe  āpātha gate tam rūpam cakkhu viññāṇena disvā java nakkhaṇe iṭṭhe a rajjantaḥ na iva su mano
translated: The six constant practices are the constant practice of one whose cankers are destroyed.🔽On seeing a visible object with the eye: when a visible datum as object comes into focus in the eye door, on seeing that visible datum with eye-consciousness, at the impulsion moment, he is not greedy, not hating, not confused,

original: hoti, aniṭṭhe adussanto na dummano. Asamapekkhane mohaṃ anuppādento upekkhako viharati
analyzed: hoti aniṭṭhe a dussantaḥ na dummanaḥ a samapekkhane moham an uppādentaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati
translated: he dwells equanimous, mindful, and fully aware.🔽The same method applies in the case of the other doors.

original: majjhatto, satiyā yuttattā sato, sampajaññena yuttattā sampajāno. Sesapadesupi eseva🔽nayo. Iti chasupi dvāresu upekkhako viharatīti iminā chaḷaṅgupekkhā kathitā. Sampajānoti
analyzed: majjhattaḥ satiyā yutta ttā sataḥ sampajaññena yutta ttā sampajāno sesa padesu pi esā iva  iti chasu pi dvāresu upekkhakaḥ viharati iti iminā chaḷaṅga upekkhā kathitā sampajānoti
translated: So he dwells equanimous, mindful, and fully aware: by this he shows the six kinds of equanimity.

original: vacanato pana cattāri ñāṇasampayuttacittāni labbhanti. Satatavihārāti vacanato aṭṭhapi
analyzed: vacanato pana cattāri ñāṇa sampayutta cittāni labbhanti satata vihārā ti vacanato aṭṭha pi
translated: And by the word “fully aware” he shows that the four kinds of consciousness associated with knowledge are present.🔽The six constant practices: by this he shows that the eight kinds of consciousness associated with the noble path are present.

original: mahācittāni labbhanti arajjanto adussantoti vacanato dasapi cittāni labbhanti. Somanassaṃ
analyzed: mahācittāni labbhanti a rajjantaḥ a dussantaḥ ti vacanataḥ dasa api cittāni labbhanti somanassam
translated: “He is not bound, not angry” : ten he is not bound, not angry, and he can get ten consciousnesses.

original: kathaṃ labbhatīti ce āsevanato labbhati.
analyzed: katham labbhati iti ce āsevanataḥ labbhati
translated: How does he get the happy consciousness? He gets it by repetition.

original: Abhijātichakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: abhijāti chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “black-and-white” kind of person🔽“Black-and-white” : the kinds of persons are black, white, black-and-white, and neither-black-nor-white.

original: 329. Abhijātiyoti jātiyo. Kaṇhābhijātiko samānoti kaṇhe nīcakule jāto hutvā. Kaṇhaṃ
analyzed: abhijātiyaḥ iti jātiyaḥ kaṇha abhijātikaḥ samānaḥ iti kaṇhe nīca kule jātaḥ hutvā kaṇham
translated: “Born in a black family” : he is born in a low family.

original: dhammaṃ abhijāyatīti kāḷakaṃ dasadussīlyadhammaṃ pasavati karoti. So taṃ abhijāyitvā
analyzed: dhammam abhijāyati iti kāḷakam dasa dussīlya dhammam pasavati karoti saḥ tam abhijāyitvā
translated: “He produces the black idea” : he produces, he does the black idea, the idea of the ten courses of unwholesome kamma. Having produced it,🔽he is reborn in hell.

original: niraye nibbattati. Sukkaṃ dhammanti ahaṃ pubbepi puññānaṃ akatattā nīcakule nibbatto.
analyzed: niraye nibbattati sukkam dhammanti aham pubbe pi puññānam a kata ttā nīca kule nibbattaḥ
translated: “The white idea” : “Formerly, because I did not make merit, I was reborn in a low family.

original: Idāni puññaṃ karomīti puññasaṅkhātaṃ paṇḍaraṃ dhammaṃ abhijāyati. So tena sagge nibbattati.🔽Akaṇhaṃ asukkaṃ nibbānanti nibbānañhi sace kaṇhaṃ bhaveyya, kaṇhavipākaṃ dadeyya.
analyzed: idāni puññam karomi iti puñña saṅkhātam paṇḍaram dhammam abhijāyati saḥ tena sagge nibbattati  a kaṇham a sukkam nibbānanti nibbānam hi sace kaṇham bhaveyya kaṇha vipākam dadeyya
translated: Now I make merit” : he produces the white idea, the idea of merit. He is reborn in heaven because of that.🔽“Neither black nor white, extinction” : for if extinction were black, it would give a black ripening.

original: Sace sukkaṃ, sukkavipākaṃ dadeyya. Dvinnampi appadānato pana “akaṇhaṃ asukka”nti
analyzed: sace sukkam sukka vipākam dadeyya dvinnam pi appadānato pana a kaṇham a sukkam ti
translated: If it were white, it would give a white ripening. But because it gives no ripening at all, it is neither black nor white.

original: vuttaṃ. Nibbānañca nāma imasmiṃ atthe arahattaṃ adhippetaṃ. Tañhi kilesanibbānante
analyzed: vuttam nibbānam ca nāma imasmin atthe arahattam adhippetam tat hi kilesa nibbāna ante
translated: and that is said. And in this case it is Arahantship that is intended by “Nibbāna.” For that is called “Nibbāna” because it is the cessation of defilements.

original: jātattā nibbānaṃ nāma. Taṃ esa abhijāyati pasavati karoti. Sukkābhijātiko samānoti
analyzed: jāta ttā nibbānam nāma tam esa abhijāyati pasavati karoti sukka abhijātikaḥ samānoti
translated: He is born in the happy destiny, he produces, he makes it arise. He is born in the happy destiny,

original: sukke uccakule jāto hutvā. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sukke ucca kule jātaḥ hutvā sesam vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: having been born in a high, noble family. The rest should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Nibbedhabhāgiyachakkavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nibbedhabhāgiya chakka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Faculties

original: Nibbedhabhāgiyāti nibbedho vuccati nibbānaṃ, taṃ bhajanti upagacchantīti nibbedhabhāgiyā. Aniccasaññādayo pañcake vuttā. Nirodhānupassanāñāṇe saññā nirodhasaññā nāma.
analyzed: nibbedha bhāgiyā ti nibbedhaḥ vuccati nibbānam tam bhajanti upagacchanti iti nibbedha bhāgiyāḥ anicca saññā ādayo pañcake vuttā nirodha anupassanā ñāṇe saññā nirodha saññā nāma
translated: The faculties are called “the faculties of penetration” because they resort to , i.e. approach, Nibbāna, which is called “penetration.” The five beginning with the perception of impermanence are stated. The perception of cessation is called “perception of the cessation of formations” in the knowledge of contemplation of cessation.

original: “Ime kho, āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti dvāvīsatiyā chakkānaṃ vasena bāttiṃsasatapañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti dvāvīsatiyā chakkānam vasena bāttiṃsa sata pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friend, are the four foundations of mindfulness” , etc., should be construed in the way already stated. So the elder showed the unity of the teaching by means of twenty-two faculties in answering the thirty-two hundred questions.

original: Chakkavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chakka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the faculties is ended.

original: Sattakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Persons

original: 330. Iti chakkavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni sattakavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: iti chakka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni sattaka vasena dassetum puna desanam ārabhi
translated: Having thus shown the unity of the teaching by means of the faculties, he now began the teaching again in order to show it by means of the persons.

original: Tattha sampattipaṭilābhaṭṭhena saddhāva dhanaṃ saddhādhanaṃ. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: tattha sampatti paṭilābha aṭṭhena saddhā va dhanam saddhā dhanam esa nayo sabbattha
translated: Herein, faith is the wealth of faith in the sense of acquisition of excellence. So with all.

original: Paññādhanaṃ panettha sabbaseṭṭhaṃ. Paññāya hi ṭhatvā tīṇi sucaritāni pañcasīlāni🔽dasasīlāni pūretvā saggūpagā honti, sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ, paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇañca
analyzed: paññā dhanam pana ittha sabba seṭṭham paññāya hi tīṇi su caritāni pañca sīlāni  dasa sīlāni pūretvā saggūpagāḥ honti sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam pacceka bodhi ñāṇam sabbaññuta ññāṇañca
translated: But the wealth of understanding is the best of all. For it is by means of understanding that the three kinds of good conduct, the five training precepts,

original: paṭivijjhanti. Imāsaṃ sampattīnaṃ paṭilābhakāraṇato paññā “dhana”nti vuttā. Sattapi🔽cetāni lokiyalokuttaramissakāneva kathitāni. Bojjhaṅgakathā kathitāva.
analyzed: paṭivijjhanti imāsam sampattīnam paṭilābha kāraṇato paññā dhananti vuttā satta pi  kathitāni bojjhaṅga kathā kathitā ava
translated: the ten training precepts, and the higher virtue are fulfilled and one goes to heaven and penetrates to the three kinds of enlightenment, namely, the knowledge of the disciple’s perfection, the knowledge of the Hermit Enlightened One’s enlightenment, and the knowledge of the Fully Enlightened One’s enlightenment. And it is called “wealth” because it is the cause for acquiring that excellence.🔽All these seven are called mundane and supramundane mixed. The explanation of the enlightenment factors is finished.

original: Samādhiparikkhārāti samādhiparivārā. Sammādiṭṭhādīni vuttatthāneva. Imepi satta parikkhārā lokiyalokuttarāva kathitā.🔽Asataṃ dhammā asantā vā dhammā lāmakā dhammāti asaddhammā. Vipariyāyena saddhammā
analyzed: samādhi parikkhārā ti samādhi parivārā sammādiṭṭha ādīni ime pi satta parikkhārāḥ lokiya lokuttarā ava kathitā  asatam dhammāḥ asantā vā dhammā lāmakāḥ dhammā ati asat dhammāḥ vipariyāyena sat dhammāḥ
translated: The requisites of concentration are the requisites of concentration’s attendant states. Right view, etc., are in their usual meaning. These seven requisites are called mundane and supramundane.

original: veditabbā. Sesamettha uttānatthameva. Saddhammesu pana saddhādayo sabbepi vipassakasseva
analyzed: veditabbā sesam ettha uttānattham eva saddhammesu pana saddhā ādayaḥ sabbe pi vipassakassa iva
translated: Bad ideas are either bad or ideas that are bad, that is, blameworthy ideas. Good ideas should be understood in the opposite sense. The rest here is clear in its meaning. But as regards good ideas, all these, beginning with faith, are for one who has insight.

original: kathitā. Tesupi paññā lokiyalokuttarā. Ayaṃ viseso.
analyzed: kathitā tesu pi paññā lokiya lokuttarā ayam viseso
translated: and the wisdom in them is mundane and supramundane. This is the difference.

original: Sappurisānaṃ dhammāti sappurisadhammā. Tattha suttageyyādikaṃ dhammaṃ jānātīti dhammaññū.
analyzed: sappurisānam dhammā ati sappurisa dhammā tattha sutta geyya ādikam dhammam jānāti iti dhammaññū
translated: “Dhamma of good men” is “dhamma of good men” . Herein, one who knows the Dhamma consisting of the Suttas, songs, etc., is a “knower of the Dhamma” .

original: Tassa tasseva bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānātīti atthaññū. “Ettakomhi sīlena samādhinā paññāyā”ti
analyzed: tassa tassa iva bhāsitassa attham jānāti iti atthaññū ettakaḥ umhi sīlena samādhinā paññāyāti
translated: One who knows the meaning of what is spoken in each instance is a “knower of the meaning” . “I have so much virtue, concentration, wisdom”

original: evaṃ attānaṃ jānātīti attaññū. Paṭiggahaṇaparibhogesu mattaṃ jānātīti mattaññū. Ayaṃ
analyzed: evam attānam jānāti iti attaññū paṭiggahaṇa paribhogesu mattam jānāti iti mattaññū ayaṃ
translated: and so he knows himself is a “knower of himself” . One who knows the measure in accepting and using is a “knower of measure” .

original: kālo uddesassa, ayaṃ kālo paripucchāya, ayaṃ kālo yogassa adhigamāyāti evaṃ kālaṃ
analyzed: kālaḥ uddesassa ayam kālaḥ paripucchāya ayam kālaḥ yogassa adhigamāya ati evam kālam
translated: “This is the time for recitation, this is the time for interrogation, this is the time for devotion, this is the time for attaining” — thus he knows

original: jānātīti kālaññū. Ettha ca pañca vassāni uddesassa kālo. Dasa paripucchāya. Idaṃ
analyzed: jānāti iti kālaññū ettha ca pañca vassāni uddesassa kālaḥ dasa paripucchāya idaṃ
translated: the time is a “knower of the time” . And here the time for recitation is five years, the time for interrogation is ten years, and this is too much.

original: atisambādhaṃ. Dasa vassāni pana uddesassa kālo. Vīsati paripucchāya. Tato paraṃ yoge🔽kammaṃ kātabbaṃ. Aṭṭhavidhaṃ parisaṃ jānātīti parisaññū. Sevitabbāsevitabbaṃ puggalaṃ
analyzed: atisambādham dasa vassāni pana uddesassa kālaḥ vīsati paripucchāya tato param yoge  kammam kātabbam aṭṭhavidham parisam jānāti iti parisaññū sevitabba a sevitabbam puggalam
translated: But the time for recitation is ten years, the time for interrogation is twenty years, and after that devotion should be undertaken.

original: jānātīti puggalaññū.
analyzed: jānāti iti puggalaññū
translated: One who knows the eight assemblies is a “knower of assemblies” . One who knows the person to be served and the person not to be served is a “knower of persons” .

original: 331. Niddasavatthūnīti niddasādivatthūni. Niddaso bhikkhu, nibbīso, nittiṃso, niccattālīso,
analyzed: niddasa vatthūni iti niddasa ādi vatthūni niddasaḥ bhikkhu nibbīsaḥ nittiṃsaḥ niccattālīso
translated: The terms that are to be defined: the terms “defined” and so on. The bhikkhu who is defined, the bhikkhu who is without fever, the bhikkhu who is without distress, the bhikkhu who is without anxiety,

original: nippaññāso bhikkhūti evaṃ vacanakāraṇāni. Ayaṃ kira pañho titthiyasamaye uppanno.
analyzed: nippaññāsaḥ bhikkhū iti evam vacana kāraṇāni ayam kira pañhaḥ titthiya samaye uppanno
translated: The words “the grounds for the description” are the grounds for the description as “the dried-up one,” etc. The dried-up bhikkhu, the passionless one, the one who has destroyed the fetters, the one who has laid down the burden, the one who has reached his own goal, the one who has gone to the right end, the one who has crossed over the flood, the one who has put down the burden, the one who has destroyed the fetter of becoming, the bhikkhu who has reached the right end of suffering—these are the grounds for the description.🔽This question, it seems, arose among the sectarians.

original: Titthiyā hi dasavassakāle mataṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ niddasoti vadanti. So kira puna dasavasso
analyzed: titthiyāḥ hi dasa vassa kāle matam nigaṇṭham niddaso ti vadanti saḥ kira puna dasa vassaḥ
translated: For when a Nigaṇṭha died after ten years, the sectarians said, “He is dried up.” He was not dried up again after ten years.🔽And not only after ten years,

original: na hoti. Na kevalañca dasavassova. Navavassopi…pe… ekavassopi na hoti. Eteneva nayena
analyzed: na hoti na kevalam ca eka vassaḥ upi na hoti etena iva nayena
translated: but also after nine years … after one year.

original: vīsativassādikālepi mataṃ nibbīso, nittiṃso, niccattālīso, nippaññāsoti vadanti.
analyzed: vīsati vassa ādi kāle pi matam nibbīsaḥ nittiṃsaḥ niccattālīsaḥ nippaññāsaḥ ti vadanti
translated: In the same way, when one died after twenty years, etc., they said, “He is passionless, he has destroyed the fetters, he has laid down the burden, he is dried up.”

original: Āyasmā ānando gāme vicaranto taṃ kathaṃ sutvā vihāraṃ gantvā bhagavato ārocesi. Bhagavā āha –
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ gāme vicarantaḥ tam katham sutvā vihāram gantvā bhagavataḥ ārocesi bhagavān āha
translated: The venerable Ānanda heard this conversation while wandering for alms in the village. He went to the monastery and told the Blessed One. The Blessed One said:

original: “Na idaṃ, ānanda, titthiyānaṃ adhivacanaṃ mama sāsane khīṇāsavassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: na idam ānanda titthiyānam adhivacanam mama sāsane khīṇāsavassa itam adhivacanam
translated: “Ānanda, that is not a description of the sectarians. It is a description of those in my dispensation who are arahants.

original: Khīṇāsavo hi dasavassakāle parinibbuto puna dasavasso na hoti. Na kevalañca dasavassova,
analyzed: khīṇāsavaḥ hi dasa vassa kāle parinibbuto puna dasa vassaḥ na hoti na kevalam ca dasa vassā uva
translated: For one who is an arahant and has attained final Nibbāna after ten years is not reborn after ten years. And not only after ten years,

original: navavassopi…pe… ekavassopi. Na kevalañca ekavassova, dasamāsikopi…pe… ekamāsikopi.
analyzed: eka vassaḥ pi na kevalam ca eka vassaḥ uva dasa māsikaḥ pi pe eka māsikaḥ upi
translated: and one of nine years, and one of eight years, and one of seven years, and one of six years, and one of five years, and one of four years, and one of three years, and one of two years, and one of one year, and one of ten months, and one of nine months, and one of eight months, and one of seven months, and one of six months, and one of five months, and one of four months, and one of three months, and one of two months, and one of one month, and one of twenty days, and one of nineteen days, and one of eighteen days, and one of seventeen days, and one of sixteen days, and one of fifteen days, and one of fourteen days, and one of thirteen days, and one of twelve days, and one of eleven days, and one of ten days, and one of nine days, and one of eight days, and one of seven days, and one of six days, and one of five days, and one of four days, and one of three days, and one of two days, and one of one day, and one of twelve hours.

original: Ekadivasikopi. Ekamuhuttopi na hoti eva. Kasmā? Puna paṭisandhiyā abhāvā. Nibbīsādīsupi
analyzed: eka divasikaḥ api eka muhuttaḥ api na hoti eva kasmā puna paṭisandhiyā abhāvā nibbīsa ādīsu pi
translated: And he is not even one of twelve hours. Why not? Because he has no rebirth-linking.

original: eseva nayo. Iti bhagavā mama sāsane khīṇāsavassetaṃ adhivacana”nti –
analyzed: iti bhagavā mama sāsane khīṇāsavassa itam
translated: The same method applies in the case of those without terror, etc. So this is a designation for those whose cankers are destroyed in my dispensation.”

original: Vatvā yehi kāraṇehi so niddaso hoti, tāni dassetuṃ satta niddasavatthūni deseti.🔽Theropi tameva desanaṃ uddharitvā satta niddasavatthūni idhāvuso, bhikkhu, sikkhāsamādānetiādimāha.
analyzed: vatvā yehi kāraṇehi so niddasaḥ hoti tāni dassetum satta niddasa vatthūni deseti  theraḥ api tam eva desanam uddharitvā satta niddasa vatthūni idha āvuso bhikkhu sikkhā samādāna iti ādim āha
translated: Having said this, he taught the seven grounds for being called “dried-up” in order to show the reasons why he is dried up.🔽The elder, having taken up that same teaching, said: “Here, friend, a bhikkhu undertakes the precepts of virtue.”

original: Tattha idhāti imasmiṃ sāsane. Sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hotīti sikkhattayapūraṇe🔽bahalacchando hoti. Āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemoti anāgate punadivasādīsupi
analyzed: tattha idha ati imasmim sāsane sikkhā samādāne tibba chandaḥ hoti iti sikkhattaya pūraṇe  bahala chandaḥ hoti āyatim ca sikkhā samādāne a vigata pemo ti anāgate punadivasa ādīsupi
translated: Here means in this dispensation.🔽Undertakes the precepts of virtue: he has great desire for the fulfilment of the three trainings.🔽And he has not lost his desire for undertaking the precepts of virtue in the future: he is endowed with desire for the fulfilment of the training in the future, on the following day, etc.

original: sikkhāpūraṇe avigatapemena samannāgato hoti. Dhammanisantiyāti dhammanisāmanāya.
analyzed: sikkhāpūraṇe avigata pemena samannāgataḥ hoti dhamma nisantiyā ati dhamma nisāmanāya
translated: For the investigation of the Dhamma: for the investigation of the Dhamma.

original: Vipassanāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Icchāvinayeti taṇhāvinayane. Paṭisallāneti ekībhāve.
analyzed: vipassanāya itam adhivacanam icchā vinayā iti taṇhā vinayane paṭisallānā iti ekībhāve
translated: This is a term for insight. In the taming of desire: in the taming of craving. In seclusion: in solitude.

original: Vīriyārambheti kāyikacetasikassa vīriyassa pūraṇe. Satinepakketi satiyañceva nepakkabhāve
analyzed: vīriya ārambha iti kāyika cetasikassa vīriyassa pūraṇe sati nepakka iti satiyam ca iva nepakka bhāve
translated: In the arousing of energy: in the fulfilment of bodily and mental energy. In mindfulness and full awareness: in mindfulness and in the state of being fully aware.

original: ca. Diṭṭhipaṭivedheti maggadassane. Sesaṃ sabbattha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca diṭṭhi paṭivedhe iti magga dassane sesam sabbattha vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: In the penetration of views: in the seeing of the path. The rest should be understood in the way already given.

original: Saññāsu asubhānupassanāñāṇe saññā asubhasaññā. Ādīnavānupassanāñāṇe saññā ādīnavasaññā
analyzed: saññāsu asubha anupassanā ñāṇe saññā asubha saññā ādīnava anupassanā ñāṇe saññā ādīnava saññā
translated: In the knowledge of contemplation of foulness in the case of perceptions, the perception is called perception of foulness. In the knowledge of contemplation of danger in the case of perceptions, the perception is called perception of danger.

original: nāma. Sesā heṭṭhā vuttā eva. Balasattakaviññāṇaṭṭhitisattakapuggalasattakāni vuttanayāneva.
analyzed: nāma sesā heṭṭhā vuttā eva bala sattaka viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattaka puggala sattakāni vutta nayāni eva
translated: The rest have already been given. The seven strength, seven stations for consciousness, and seven persons are in the way already stated.

original: Appahīnaṭṭhena anusayantīti anusayā. Thāmagato kāmarāgo kāmarāgānusayo. Esa nayo
analyzed: appahīna ṭṭhena anusayanti iti anusayā thāma gataḥ kāma rāgo kāma rāga anusayo esa nayo
translated: They follow by way of non-abandonment, thus they are inherent tendencies. Lust for sense desires that has become habitual is the inherent tendency of lust for sense desires. So too with all.

original: sabbattha. Saṃyojanasattakaṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: sabbattha saṃyojana sattakam uttāna attham eva
translated: The seven fetters are self-explanatory.

original: Adhikaraṇasamathasattakavaṇṇanā
translated: The seven kinds of settling of litigation

original: Adhikaraṇasamathesu adhikaraṇāni samenti vūpasamentīti adhikaraṇasamathā. Uppannuppannānanti
analyzed: adhikaraṇa samathesu adhikaraṇāni samenti vūpasamenti iti adhikaraṇa samathāḥ uppanna uppannānanti
translated: In the settling of litigation the litigations are settled, thus the settling of litigation is settling of litigations. Arisen:

original: uppannānaṃ uppannānaṃ. Adhikaraṇānanti vivādādhikaraṇaṃ anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ āpattādhikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: uppannānam uppannānam adhikaraṇānanti vivāda adhikaraṇam anuvāda adhikaraṇam āpatta adhikaraṇam
translated: “Of the legal issues that have arisen”: of the legal issues consisting of a dispute, a charge, an offense,

original: kiccādhikaraṇanti imesaṃ catunnaṃ. Samathāya vūpasamāyāti samathatthañceva vūpasamanatthañca.
analyzed: imesam catunnam samathāya vūpasamāyāti samatha attham ca iva vūpasamana ttham ca
translated: and business. “For settling and for quieting”: for the sake of settling and for the sake of quieting.

original: Sammukhāvinayo dātabbo…pe… tiṇavatthārakoti ime satta samathā dātabbā.🔽Tatrāyaṃ vinicchayanayo. Adhikaraṇesu tāva dhammoti vā adhammoti vā aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi
analyzed: sammukhā vinayaḥ dātabbā upe ti ime satta samathāḥ dātabbā  tatra ayam vinicchaya nayaḥ adhikaraṇesu tāva dhammaḥ iti vā adhammaḥ iti vā aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi
translated: “Resolution face-to-face should be given”: the seven principles for settling should be given:

original: vivadantānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yo vivādo, idaṃ vivādādhikaraṇaṃ nāma. Sīlavipattiyā vā ācāradiṭṭhiājīvavipattiyā🔽vā anuvadantānaṃ anuvādo upavadanā ceva codanā ca, idaṃ anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ nāma. Mātikāya
analyzed: vivadantānam bhikkhūnam yaḥ vivādaḥ idam vivāda adhikaraṇam nāma sīla vipattiyā vā ācāra diṭṭhi ājīva vipattiyā  vā anuvādaḥ upavadanā ca iva codanā ca idam anuvāda adhikaraṇam nāma
translated: Here is the method of deciding. In regard to the legal issues, a dispute among monks who are arguing about the Teaching or the Monastic Law, or about what is proper or improper, or about offenses or the settling of offenses, is called a legal issue arising from a dispute.

original: āgatā pañca, vibhaṅge dveti sattapi āpattikkhandhā, idaṃ āpattādhikaraṇaṃ nāma. Saṅghassa
analyzed: āgatā pañca vibhaṅge dve iti āpatti kkhandhāḥ idam āpattādhikaraṇam nāma saṅghassa
translated: A charge against a monk who is being charged with failure in morality, failure in conduct, failure in view, or failure in livelihood is called a legal issue arising from a charge. The five classes of offenses listed in the Monastic Code and the two classes of offenses in the additional rules, that is, the seven classes of offenses, are called a legal issue arising from an offense.

original: apalokanādīnaṃ catunnaṃ kammānaṃ karaṇaṃ, idaṃ kiccādhikaraṇaṃ nāma.
analyzed: apalokana ādīnam catunnam kammānam karaṇam idam kiccādhikaraṇam nāma
translated: The four kinds of legal procedures—reproving, instructing, ejecting, and relinquishing—are called a legal issue arising from business.

original: Tattha vivādādhikaraṇaṃ dvīhi samathehi sammati sammukhāvinayena ca yebhuyyasikāya
analyzed: vivāda adhikaraṇam dvīhi samathehi sammati sammukha avinayena ca yebhuyyasikāya
translated: Herein, a legal question arising out of a dispute is settled by two settlements, namely, by resolution face-to-face and by majority decision.

original: ca. Sammukhāvinayeneva sammamānaṃ yasmiṃ vihāre uppannaṃ tasmiṃyeva vā aññattha vūpasametuṃ
analyzed: ca sammukha avinayena iva yasmin vihāre uppannam tasmin yeva vā aññattha vūpasametum
translated: When it is settled by resolution face-to-face, it is settled either in the same dwelling where it arose or else by going to settle it elsewhere,

original: gacchantānaṃ antarāmagge vā yattha gantvā saṅghassa niyyātitaṃ tattha saṅghena vā
analyzed: gacchantānam antarāmagge vā yattha gantvā saṅghassa niyyātitam tattha saṅghena vā
translated: or else by the Sangha there to which it has been reported,

original: saṅghe vūpasametuṃ asakkonte tattheva ubbāhikāya sammatapuggalehi vā vinicchitaṃ
analyzed: saṅghe vūpasametum a sakkonte tattha iva ubbāhikāya sammata puggalehi vā vinicchitam
translated: or else, if the Sangha there is unable to settle it, by the Sangha there deciding on a committee to settle it.

original: sammati. Evaṃ sammamāne ca panetasmiṃ yā saṅghasammukhatā dhammasammukhatā vinayasammukhatā
analyzed: sammati evam sammamāne ca pana itasmin yā saṅgha sammukha tā dhamma sammukha tā vinaya sammukha tā
translated: And when it is settled in this way, the presence of the Sangha, the presence of the True Idea, the presence of the Discipline,

original: puggalasammukhatā, ayaṃ sammukhāvinayo nāma.🔽Tattha ca kārakasaṅghassa saṅghasāmaggivasena sammukhībhāvo saṅghasammukhatā. Sametabbassa
analyzed: puggala sammukha tā ayam sammukhāvinayaḥ nāma  tattha ca kāraka saṅghassa saṅgha sāmaggi vasena sammukhībhāvaḥ saṅgha sammukha tā sametabbassa
translated: and the presence of the persons concerned—this is called “resolution face-to-face.”

original: vatthuno bhūtatā dhammasammukhatā. Yathā taṃ sametabbaṃ, tatheva sammanaṃ vinayasammukhatā.
analyzed: vatthunaḥ bhūta tā dhamma sammukha tā yathā tam sametabbam tathā iva sammanam vinaya sammukha tā
translated: And here the presence of the Sangha that is the body effecting the settlement is the presence of the Sangha in the sense of the unity of the Sangha. The actuality of the case to be settled is the presence of the True Idea. The settlement in accordance with that case to be settled is the presence of the Discipline.

original: Yo ca vivadati, yena ca vivadati, tesaṃ ubhinnaṃ atthapaccatthikānaṃ sammukhībhāvo
analyzed: yaḥ ca vivadati yena ca vivadati tesam ubhinnam attha paccatthikānam sammukhībhāvaḥ
translated: And the presence of both parties to the dispute, the one who is disputing and the one he is disputing with,

original: puggalasammukhatā. Ubbāhikāya vūpasame panettha saṅghasammukhatā parihāyati. Evaṃ
analyzed: puggala sammukha tā ubbāhikāya vūpasame pana ittha saṅgha sammukha tā parihāyati evam
translated: is the presence of persons. But in the settling of a legal issue on the basis of a majority decision, the presence of the Sangha is absent.

original: tāva sammukhāvinayeneva sammati.
analyzed: sammukha avinayena iva
translated: This is how a legal issue can be settled by resolution face-to-face.

original: Sace panevampi na sammati, atha naṃ ubbāhikāya sammatā bhikkhū “na mayaṃ sakkoma
analyzed: sace pana evam pi na sammati atha nam ubbāhikāya sammatāḥ bhikkhū na mayam sakkoma
translated: If it is still not settled, then the monks who have decided on a majority decision say, “We’re unable to settle this legal issue.”

original: vūpasametu”nti saṅghasseva niyyātenti, tato saṅgho pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: vūpasametunti saṅghassa iva tatas saṅghaḥ pañcaṅga samannāgatam bhikkhuṃ
translated: They hand it over to the Sangha. The Sangha then appoints a monk who has five qualities as the counter for the voting tickets.

original: salākaggāhāpakaṃ sammannati. Tena guḷhakavivaṭakasakaṇṇajappakesu tīsu salākaggāhesu🔽aññataravasena salākaṃ gāhāpetvā sannipatitaparisāya dhammavādīnaṃ yebhuyyatāya yathā
analyzed: salāka gāhāpakam sammannati tena guḷhaka vivaṭaka sakaṇṇa jappakesu tīsu salāka ggāhesu  aññatara vasena salākam gāhāpetvā sannipatita parisāya dhamma vādīnam yebhuyyatāya yathā
translated: He should distribute the voting tickets in one of three ways: by whispering, by a covered hand, or by repeating after someone else.🔽The majority of those present who speak in accordance with the Teaching decide the legal issue.

original: te dhammavādino vadanti, evaṃ vūpasantaṃ adhikaraṇaṃ sammukhāvinayena ca yebhuyyasikāya ca vūpasantaṃ hoti.
analyzed: te dhamma vādinaḥ vadanti evam vūpasantam adhikaraṇam sammukhā vinayena ca yebhuyyasikāya ca vūpasantam hoti
translated: The legal issue is settled by resolution face-to-face and by majority decision.

original: Tattha sammukhāvinayo vuttanayo eva. Yaṃ pana yebhuyyasikākammassa karaṇaṃ, ayaṃ🔽yebhuyyasikā nāma. Evaṃ vivādādhikaraṇaṃ dvīhi samathehi sammati. Anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ🔽catūhi samathehi sammati – sammukhāvinayena ca sativinayena ca amūḷhavinayena ca🔽tassapāpiyasikāya ca. Sammukhāvinayeneva sammamānaṃ yo ca anuvadati, yañca anuvadati,🔽tesaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā sace kāci āpatti natthi, ubho khamāpetvā, sace atthi, ayaṃ nāmettha
analyzed: tattha sammukhā vinayaḥ vutta nayaḥ eva yam pana yebhuyyasikā kammassa karaṇam ayam  yebhuyyasikā nāma evam vivāda adhikaraṇam dvīhi samathehi sammati anuvāda adhikaraṇam  catūhi samathehi sammati sammukhā vinayena ca sati vinayena ca amūḍha vinayena ca  ca sammukha avinayena iva sammamānam yaḥ ca anuvadati yaṃ ca anuvadati  tesam vacanam sutvā sace kāci āpatti natthi ubho khamāpetvā sace atthi ayam nāma ittha
translated: Herein, the resolution by means of a face-to-face meeting is in the way already described. But the carrying out of the procedure consisting of the majority is

original: āpattīti evaṃ vinicchitaṃ vūpasammati. Tattha sammukhāvinayalakkhaṇaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: āpatti iti evam vinicchitam tattha sammukha avinaya lakkhaṇam vutta nayam eva
translated: called a majority verdict. So a legal question arising out of a dispute is settled by means of two settlements, namely, by resolution face-to-face and by majority verdict. A legal question arising out of an accusation is settled by means of four settlements, namely, by resolution face-to-face, by resolution through recollection, by resolution because of past insanity, and by further penalty. When it is settled by means of resolution face-to-face, then, after listening to the statement of the one who accuses and to the statement of the one who is accused, if there is no offence, it is settled by making them exchange greetings; but if there is an offence, it is settled by adjudicating it thus: ‘This is the offence here.’ Herein, the characteristic of resolution face-to-face has already been explained.

original: Yadā pana khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno amūlikāya sīlavipattiyā anuddhaṃsitassa sativinayaṃ
analyzed: yadā pana khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno amūlikāya sīla vipattiyā an uddhaṃsitassa sati vinayam
translated: But when a monk whose cankers are destroyed is accused groundlessly of failure in morality, and he asks for resolution by means of a verdict of innocence,

original: yācamānassa saṅgho ñatticatutthena kammena sativinayaṃ deti, tadā sammukhāvinayena
analyzed: yācamānassa saṅghaḥ ñatti catutthena kammena sati vinayam deti tadā sammukha avinayena
translated: and the Order gives him resolution by means of a verdict of innocence by means of a transaction requiring the full number of the Order consisting of a motion and a single announcement, then it is settled by means of resolution face-to-face and by means of a verdict of innocence.

original: ca sativinayena ca vūpasantaṃ hoti. Dinne pana sativinaye puna tasmiṃ puggale kassaci anuvādo na ruhati.
analyzed: ca sati vinayena ca vūpasantam hoti dinne pana sati vinaye puna tasmin puggale kassaci anuvādaḥ na ruhati
translated: and by resolution through recollection. But when resolution through recollection has been given, then no one can accuse that person again on that same basis.

original: Yadā ummattako bhikkhu ummādavasena assāmaṇake ajjhācāre “saratāyasmā evarūpiṃ āpatti”nti
analyzed: yadā ummattakaḥ bhikkhu ummāda vasena assāmaṇake ajjhācāre sarata ayasmai evarūpim āpattin ti
translated: When a monk who is insane accuses a monk of an offense entailing expulsion, saying, “Do you remember committing such-and-such an offense?”

original: bhikkhūhi codiyamāno “ummattakena me, āvuso, etaṃ kataṃ, nāhaṃ taṃ sarāmī”ti bhaṇantopi🔽bhikkhūhi codiyamānova puna acodanatthāya amūḷhavinayaṃ yācati, saṅgho cassa ñatticatutthena
analyzed: bhikkhūhi codiyamānaḥ ummattakena me āvuso etam katam na aham tam sarāmi iti bhaṇantaḥ api  bhikkhūhi codiyamānaḥ iva puna a codana tthāya amūḍha vinayam yācati saṅghaḥ ca ssa ñatti catutthena
translated: and the accused monk, being insane, says, “I did it while insane. I don’t remember it,”🔽and he asks for resolution through recollection,🔽and the Sangha gives him resolution through recollection by means of a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements,

original: kammena amūḷhavinayaṃ deti, tadā sammukhāvinayena ca amūḷhavinayena ca vūpasantaṃ
analyzed: amūḍha vinayam deti tadā sammukha avinayena ca amūḍha vinayena ca
translated: then the legal issue is resolved face-to-face and through resolution through recollection.

original: hoti. Dinne pana amūḷhavinaye puna tasmiṃ puggale kassaci tappaccayā anuvādo na ruhati.
analyzed: hoti dinne pana amūḷha vinaye puna tasmin puggale kassaci tad paccayā anuvādaḥ na ruhati
translated: But when resolution through recollection has been given, then no one can accuse that person again on that same basis.

original: Yadā pana pārājikena vā pārājikasāmantena vā codiyamānassa aññenaññaṃ paṭicarato
analyzed: yadā pana pārājikena vā pārājika sāmantena vā codiyamānassa aññena aññam paṭicarataḥ
translated: When a monk is accused of an offense entailing expulsion or an offense similar to one entailing expulsion, and he replies with something else, saying, “I didn’t do it,”

original: pāpussannatāya pāpiyassa puggalassa “sacāyaṃ acchinnamūlo bhavissati, sammā vattitvā
analyzed: pāpussanna tāya pāpiyassa puggalassa sacā ayam acchinna mūlaḥ bhavissati sammā vattitvā
translated: Thinking, “If he has not cut off his root of goodness, he will be able to get readmission by conducting himself properly.

original: osāraṇaṃ labhissati. Sace chinnamūlo ayamevassa nāsanā bhavissatī”ti maññamāno saṅgho🔽ñatticatutthena kammena tassapāpiyasikaṃ karoti, tadā sammukhāvinayena ca tassapāpiyasikāya
analyzed: osāraṇam labhissati sace chinna mūlaḥ ayam eva assa na āsanā bhavissati iti maññamānaḥ saṅghaḥ  ñatti catutthena kammena tassa pāpiyasikam karoti tadā sammukha avinayena ca tassa pāpiyasikāya
translated: If he has cut off his root of goodness, he will be lost,” the Sangha does a further penalty procedure against him by means of a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement.🔽Then the legal issue is resolved by resolution face-to-face and by further penalty.

original: ca vūpasantaṃ hotīti. Evaṃ anuvādādhikaraṇaṃ catūhi samathehi sammati. Āpattādhikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: ca vūpasantam hoti iti evam anuvāda adhikaraṇam catūhi samathehi sammati āpatta adhikaraṇam
translated: In this way, a legal issue arising from an accusation is resolved by four principles for settling it.

original: tīhi samathehi sammati sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca tiṇavatthārakena
analyzed: tīhi samathehi sammati sammukhā vinayena ca paṭiññāta karaṇena ca tiṇavatthārakena
translated: A legal issue arising from an offense is resolved by three principles for settling it: by resolution face-to-face, by acting according to what has been admitted, and by covering over as if with grass.

original: ca. Tassa sammukhāvinayeneva vūpasamo natthi. Yadā pana ekassa vā bhikkhuno santike
analyzed: ca tassa sammukhāvinayena iva vūpasamaḥ natthi yadā pana ekassa vā bhikkhuno santike
translated: It is not resolved by resolution face-to-face.🔽But when a monk confesses a light offense to another monk

original: saṅghagaṇamajjhesu vā bhikkhu lahukaṃ āpattiṃ deseti, tadā āpattādhikaraṇaṃ sammukhāvinayena
analyzed: saṅgha gaṇa majjhesu vā bhikkhu lahukam āpattim deseti tadā āpatta adhikaraṇam sammukha avinayena
translated: or in the midst of the Sangha, then the legal issue arising from an offense is resolved by resolution face-to-face

original: ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca vūpasammati.
analyzed: ca paṭiññāta karaṇena ca vūpasammati
translated: and by acting according to what has been admitted.

original: Tattha sammukhāvinaye tāva yo ca deseti, yassa ca deseti, tesaṃ sammukhībhāvo puggalasammukhatā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽Puggalassa gaṇassa ca desanākāle saṅghasammukhatā parihāyati. Yā panettha ahaṃ, bhante,🔽itthannāmaṃ āpattiṃ āpannoti ca āma, passāmīti ca paṭiññā, tāya paṭiññāya “āyatiṃ
analyzed: tattha sammukhā vinaye tāva yaḥ ca deseti yassa ca deseti tesam sammukhībhāvo puggala sammukha tā sesam vutta nayam eva  puggalassa gaṇassa ca desanā kāle saṅgha sammukha tā parihāyati yā pana ittha aham bhante  itthannāmam āpattim āpannaḥ ti ca passāmi iti ca paṭiññā tāya paṭiññāya āyatim
translated: Herein, as regards resolution by recollection, the presence face to face of both the one who confesses and the one who is confessed to is the presence of persons face to face. The rest is as already stated.

original: saṃvareyyāsī”ti karaṇaṃ, taṃ paṭiññātakaraṇaṃ nāma. Saṅghādisese hi parivāsādiyācanā
analyzed: saṃvareyyāsi iti karaṇam tam paṭiññātakaraṇam nāma saṅgha ādi sese hi parivāsa ādi yācanā
translated: When the confession is made to an individual or to a chapter, the presence of the Community face to face is absent. But the admission of the offence by the one who has fallen into an offence with the words, “Venerable sirs, I have fallen into such and such an offence” and the consent given by the one who is confessed to with the words, “I see it” and the undertaking given by the one who confesses with the words, “I will undertake restraint in future” are called the act of admitting.

original: paṭiññā. Parivāsādīnaṃ dānaṃ paṭiññātakaraṇaṃ nāma. Dve pakkhajātā pana bhaṇḍanakārakā🔽bhikkhū bahuṃ assāmaṇakaṃ ajjhācaritvā puna lajjidhamme uppanne sace mayaṃ imāhi
analyzed: paṭiññā parivāsa ādīnam dānam paṭiññātakaraṇam nāma dve pakkhajātā pana bhaṇḍana kārakā  bhikkhū bahum assāmaṇakam ajjhācaritvā puna lajji dhamme uppanne sace mayam imāhi
translated: For in the case of a saṅghādisesa, the asking for the probation, etc., is the admission, and the giving of the probation, etc., is the act of admitting.

original: āpattīhi aññamaññaṃ kāressāma, siyāpi taṃ adhikaraṇaṃ kakkhaḷattāya saṃvatteyyāti
analyzed: āpattīhi aññamaññam kāressāma siyā api tam adhikaraṇam kakkhaḷattāya saṃvatteyya ati
translated: But when two monks who have taken sides have misconducted themselves in many ways unbecoming to ascetics, and then, when the occasion for shame has arisen, they think, “If we deal with each other for these offences, then perhaps this legal question will continue for a long time,”

original: aññamaññaṃ āpattiyā kārāpane dosaṃ disvā yadā tiṇavatthārakakammaṃ karonti, tadā
analyzed: aññam aññam āpattiyāḥ kārāpane dosam disvā yadā tiṇavatthāraka kammam karonti tadā
translated: When they see the harm in making each other confess an offence, then they do the covering over as with grass.

original: āpattādhikaraṇaṃ sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca sammati.
analyzed: āpatta adhikaraṇam sammukha avinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca sammati
translated: Then a legal issue arising from an offence is settled by resolution face-to-face and by the covering over as with grass.

original: Tattha hi yattakā hatthapāsūpagatā “na metaṃ khamatī”ti evaṃ diṭṭhāvikammaṃ akatvā
analyzed: tattha hi yattakāḥ hattha pāsu upagatāḥ na mā etam khamati iti evam diṭṭhā vikammam a katvā
translated: For in this case, all those who have committed an offense, who have not done a procedure of acknowledgment, who have not fallen asleep,

original: niddampi okkantā honti, sabbesaṃ ṭhapetvā thullavajjañca gihipaṭisaṃyuttañca sabbāpattiyo
analyzed: niddam pi okkantāḥ honti sabbesam ṭhapetvā thullavajjam ca gihi paṭisaṃyuttam ca sabba āpattiyaḥ
translated: are cleared of all offenses except for a serious offense and one connected with a lay person.

original: vuṭṭhahanti, evaṃ āpattādhikaraṇaṃ tīhi samathehi sammati. Kiccādhikaraṇaṃ ekena🔽samathena sammati sammukhāvinayeneva. Imāni cattāri adhikaraṇāni yathānurūpaṃ imehi
analyzed: vuṭṭhahanti evam āpatta adhikaraṇam tīhi samathehi sammati kicca adhikaraṇam ekena  samathena sammati sammukha avinayena iva imāni cattāri adhikaraṇāni yathānurūpam imehi
translated: In this way, a legal issue arising from an offense is settled by three principles. A legal issue arising from business is settled by one principle:

original: sattahi samathehi sammanti. Tena vuttaṃ – uppannuppannānaṃ adhikaraṇānaṃ samathāya
analyzed: sattahi samathehi tena vuttam uppanna uppannānam adhikaraṇānam samathāya
translated: by resolution face-to-face. These four kinds of legal issues are settled by these seven principles, as appropriate. That’s why it was said:

original: vūpasamāya sammukhāvinayo dātabbo…pe… tiṇavatthārakoti. Ayamettha vinicchayanayo.
analyzed: vūpasamāya sammukha avinayaḥ dātabba upe ti ayam ettha vinicchaya nayo
translated: ‘Resolution face-to-face should be given for the settling and resolving of legal issues that arise. … The covering over as with grass should be given.’” This is the method of deciding.

original: Vitthāro pana samathakkhandhake āgatoyeva. Vinicchayopissa samantapāsādikāyaṃ vutto.
analyzed: vitthāraḥ pana samatha khandhake āgataḥ yeva vinicchayaḥ pissa samantapāsādikāyam vutto
translated: The detail is given in the Samathakkhandhaka itself. And the exposition is given in the Samantapāsādikā.

original: “Ime kho, āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti cuddasannaṃ sattakānaṃ vasena aṭṭhanavuti pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti sattakānam vasena aṭṭhanavuti pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friends, are the four kinds of legal issues,” etc., should be construed in the same way as above. So the Elder, in answering the ninety-eight questions by means of the fourteen groups of seven, showed the unity of the Dispensation.

original: Sattakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sattaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the group of seven is ended.

original: Aṭṭhakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the group of eight

original: 333. Iti sattakavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni aṭṭhakavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha micchattāti ayāthāvā micchāsabhāvā. Sammattāti yāthāvā sammāsabhāvā.
analyzed: iti sattaka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni aṭṭhaka vasena dassetum puna desanam ārabhi tattha micchattā ati a yāthāvā micchā sabhāvā sammattā ati yāthāvā sammā sabhāvā
translated: Having thus shown the unity of the Dispensation by means of the group of seven, the Elder began the teaching again in order to show it by means of the group of eight. Herein, wrongness is the state of being otherwise than it really is; rightness is the state of being as it really is.

original: 334. Kusītavatthūnīti kusītassa alasassa vatthūni patiṭṭhā kosajjakāraṇānīti attho.
analyzed: kusīta vatthūni iti kusītassa alasassa vatthūni patiṭṭhā kosajja kāraṇāni iti attho
translated: The grounds for laziness: the grounds for the lazy, the indolent; the reason for laziness is the meaning.

original: Kammaṃ kattabbaṃ hotīti cīvaravicāraṇādikammaṃ kātabbaṃ hoti. Na vīriyaṃ ārabhatīti
analyzed: kammam kattabbam hoti iti cīvara vicāraṇā ādi kammam kātabbam hoti na vīriyam ārabhati iti
translated: Work has to be done: the work of considering robes, etc., has to be done. He does not instigate energy:🔽he does not instigate either of the two kinds of energy. In the case of what has not been attained:

original: duvidhampi vīriyaṃ nārabhati. Appattassāti jhānavipassanāmaggaphaladhammassa appattassa
analyzed: duvidham pi vīriyam na ārabhati appattassa ati jhāna vipassanā magga phala dhammassa appattassa
translated: in the case of the states of jhāna, insight, path, and fruit.

original: pattiyā. Anadhigatassāti tasseva anadhigatassa adhigamatthāya. Asacchikatassāti tasseva🔽apaccakkhakatassa sacchikaraṇatthāya. Idaṃ paṭhamanti idaṃ handāhaṃ nipajjāmīti evaṃ🔽osīdanaṃ paṭhamaṃ kusītavatthu. Iminā nayena sabbattha attho veditabbo. “Māsācitaṃ🔽maññe”ti ettha pana māsācitaṃ nāma tintamāso. Yathā tintamāso garuko hoti, evaṃ garukoti
analyzed: pattiyā anadhigatassa ati tassa iva anadhigatassa adhigama tthāya a sacchikatassa ati tassa iva  a paccakkha katassa sacchikaraṇa tthāya idam paṭhamanti idam handa aham nipajjāmi iti evam  osīdanam paṭhamam kusīta vatthu iminā nayena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ māsa ācitam  maññā iti ettha pana māsācitam nāma tinta māsaḥ yathā tinta māsaḥ garukaḥ evam garukā iti
translated: ‘To attain’: for the purpose of attaining that which has not been attained. ‘To realize’: for the purpose of realizing that which has not been realized. ‘This is the first’: this lying down thus, ‘Now I shall lie down’, is the first instance of indolence. The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances. ‘As if it were plastered with lime’ . Herein, plastered with lime is lime-plastered. As a lime-plaster is heavy, so it is heavy.

original: adhippāyo. Gilānā vuṭṭhito hotīti gilāno hutvā pacchā vuṭṭhito hoti.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ gilānā vuṭṭhitaḥ hoti iti gilānaḥ hutvā pacchā vuṭṭhitaḥ hoti
translated: ‘To attain’: for the purpose of attaining that which has not been attained. ‘To realise’: for the purpose of realising that which has not been realised. ‘This is the first’: this lying down is the first ground for indolence. ‘I will lie down’ is the first ground for indolence. In this way the meaning should be understood in all cases. ‘As if it were smeared with honey’ : here ‘smeared with honey’ is the same as ‘covered with honey’. The intention is that it is heavy as if it were a heavy month. ‘He has recovered from his illness’: having been ill, he has later recovered.

original: 335. Ārambhavatthūnīti vīriyakāraṇāni. Tesampi imināva nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: ārambha vatthūni iti vīriya kāraṇāni tesam pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: . ‘Reasons for undertaking’ : reasons for making effort. The meaning should be understood in this way too.

original: 336. Dānavatthūnīti dānakāraṇāni. Āsajja dānaṃ detīti patvā dānaṃ deti. Āgataṃ disvāva
analyzed: dāna vatthūni iti dāna kāraṇāni āsajja dānam deti iti patvā dānam deti āgatam
translated: . ‘Reasons for giving’ : reasons for giving gifts. ‘He gives a gift after inviting’ : he gives a gift after going to the place. Having seen the arrival,

original: muhuttaṃyeva nisīdāpetvā sakkāraṃ katvā dānaṃ deti, dassāmi dassāmīti na kilameti.
analyzed: muhuttaṃ yeva nisīdāpetvā sakkāram katvā dānam deti dassāmi dassāmi iti na kilameti
translated: he sits down for a moment, and after doing the honour, he gives the gift. He does not hesitate, thinking ‘I will give, I will give.’

original: Iti ettha āsādanaṃ dānakāraṇaṃ nāma hoti. Bhayā dānaṃ detītiādīsupi bhayādīni dānakāraṇānīti
analyzed: iti ettha āsādanam dāna kāraṇam nāma bhayā dānam deti bhaya ādīni dāna kāraṇāni iti
translated: So here the obtaining is the reason for the giving. In the case of the other phrases, “He gives out of fear” and so on, the fear and so on should be understood as the reasons for the giving.

original: veditabbāni. Tattha bhayaṃ nāma ayaṃ adāyako akārakoti garahābhayaṃ vā apāyabhayaṃ
analyzed: veditabbāni tattha bhayam nāma ayam a dāyakaḥ a kārakaḥ iti garahā bhayam vā apāya bhayam
translated: Herein, fear is the fear of blame, thinking “This man is ungenerous and niggardly,” or the fear of states of deprivation.🔽“He gave to me” means he gives thinking “This man gave me such and such before.”

original: vā. Adāsi meti mayhaṃ pubbe esa idaṃ nāma adāsīti deti. Dassati meti anāgate idaṃ
analyzed: vā adāsi mā iti mayham pubbe esaḥ idam nāma adāsi iti deti dassati mā iti anāgate idam
translated: “He will give to me” means he gives thinking “In the future he will give me such and so.”

original: nāma dassatīti deti. Sāhu dānanti dānaṃ nāma sādhu sundaraṃ, buddhādīhi paṇḍitehi🔽pasatthanti deti. Cittālaṅkāracittaparikkhāratthaṃ dānaṃ detīti samathavipassanācittassa🔽alaṅkāratthañceva parivāratthañca deti. Dānañhi cittaṃ mudukaṃ karoti. Yena laddhaṃ🔽hoti, sopi laddhaṃ meti muducitto hoti, yena dinnaṃ, sopi dinnaṃ mayāti muducitto
analyzed: nāma dassati iti deti sāhu dānam ti dānam nāma sādhu sundaram buddha ādīhi paṇḍitehi  pasatthanti deti citta alaṅkāra citta parikkhāra attham dānam deti iti samatha vipassanā cittassa  alaṅkāra attham ca iva parivāra attham ca deti dānam hi cittam mudukam karoti yena laddham  hoti saḥ api laddham mā iti mudu cittaḥ hoti yena dinnam saḥ api dinnam mayā ati mudu cittaḥ
translated: “Giving is good” means he gives thinking “Giving is good, it is beautiful, it is praised by the wise, by the Buddhas and so on.”🔽“For the adornment of the mind and for the embellishment of the mind” means he gives for the sake of adorning and embellishing the mind of serenity and insight.

original: hoti, iti ubhinnampi cittaṃ mudukaṃ karoti, teneva “adantadamanaṃ dāna”nti vuccati. Yathāha –
analyzed: iti ubhinnam api cittam mudukam karoti tena iva adantadamanam dānam ti vuccati yathā āha
translated: For giving makes the mind pliant. He to whom it is given becomes pliant of mind thinking “I have received a gift.” He who gives it becomes pliant of mind thinking “I have given a gift.” Thus it makes both men’s minds pliable. That is why it is said, “Giving is the taming of the untamed” . As it is said:

original: “Adantadamanaṃ dānaṃ, adānaṃ dantadūsakaṃ;
analyzed: a danta damanam dānam a dānam danta dūsakam
translated: The gift that does not harm the giver,🔽By giving, by speaking kindly,

original: Dānena piyavācāya, unnamanti namanti cā”ti.
analyzed: dānena piya vācāyaḥ unnamanti namanti ca ati
translated: They rise and fall, the high and low.”

original: Imesu pana aṭṭhasu dānesu cittālaṅkāradānameva uttamaṃ.
analyzed: imesu pana aṭṭhasu dānesu citta alaṅkāra dānam eva uttamam
translated: Of these eight kinds of giving, the giving of mental adornment is the best.🔽“The kinds of rebirth due to giving”: the kinds of rebirth that are due to giving.

original: 337. Dānūpapattiyoti dānapaccayā upapattiyo. Dahatīti ṭhapeti. Adhiṭṭhātīti tasseva
analyzed: dāna upapattiyaḥ ti dāna paccayāḥ upapattiyaḥ dahati iti ṭhapeti adhiṭṭhāti iti tassa eva
translated: “It burns”: it keeps burning. “It determines”: this is a synonym for the same thing.

original: vevacanaṃ. Bhāvetīti vaḍḍheti. Hīne vimuttanti hīnesu pañcakāmaguṇesu vimuttaṃ. Uttari🔽abhāvitanti tato uttari maggaphalatthāya abhāvitaṃ. Tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattatīti yaṃ
analyzed: vevacanam bhāveti iti vaḍḍheti hīne vimuttam ti hīnesu pañca kāmaguṇesu vimuttam uttari  abhāvitanti tatas uttari magga phala tthāya abhāvitam tatru upapattiyā saṃvattati iti yam
translated: “It develops”: it increases. “Freed from the low”: freed from the five lower strands of sense pleasure.🔽“Not developed further”: not developed further for the purpose of the path and fruit.

original: patthetvā kusalaṃ kataṃ, tattha tattha nibbattanatthāya saṃvattati.
analyzed: patthetvā kusalam katam tattha tattha nibbattana tthāya saṃvattati
translated: “Leads to rebirth there”: it leads to rebirth here and there for the purpose of being reborn there where the wholesome has been done in quest of.

original: Vītarāgassāti maggena vā samucchinnarāgassa samāpattiyā vā vikkhambhitarāgassa. Dānamatteneva
analyzed: vīta rāgassa ati maggena vā samucchinna rāgassa samāpattiyā vā vikkhambhita rāgassa dāna mattena iva
translated: “For one free from lust”: for one whose lust has been cut off by the path or whose lust is suppressed by attainment.

original: hi brahmaloke nibbattituṃ na sakkā. Dānaṃ pana samādhivipassanācittassa alaṅkāro
analyzed: hi brahma loke nibbattitum na sakkā dānam pana samādhi vipassanā cittassa alaṅkāro
translated: For one cannot be reborn in the Brahmā-world merely by giving; but giving is an adornment for the consciousness of concentration and insight.

original: parivāro hoti. Tato dānena muducitto brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahmaloke nibbattati.
analyzed: parivāraḥ hoti tatas dānena mudu cittaḥ brahmavihāre bhāvetvā brahma loke nibbattati
translated: and he has a following. Then, with mind softened by generosity, he develops the divine abidings and is reborn in the Brahmā-world.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “vītarāgassa no sarāgassā”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam vīta rāgassa no sa rāgassa ati
translated: Hence it was said above: “for one free from greed, not for one greedy” .

original: Khattiyānaṃ parisā khattiyaparisā, samūhoti attho. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: khattiyānam parisā khattiya parisā samūhaḥ ti attho esa nayaḥ sabbattha
translated: A company of nobles is a “company of nobles” . The meaning is a collection. So with all.

original: Lokassa dhammā lokadhammā. Etehi mutto nāma natthi, buddhānampi hontiyeva. Vuttampi
analyzed: lokassa dhammā loka dhammā etehi muttaḥ nāma natthi buddhānam pi vuttam pi
translated: The states of the world are “worldly states” . There is no one free from them, not even the Buddhas. For this is said:

original: cetaṃ – “aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti, loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme
analyzed: aṭṭhime bhikkhave loka dhammā lokam anuparivattanti loko ca aṭṭha loka dhamme
translated: “Bhikkhus, these eight worldly states revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly states” .

original: anuparivattatī”ti. Lābho alābhoti lābhe āgate alābho āgato evāti veditabbo. Yasādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: anuparivattati iti lābhaḥ alābhaḥ iti lābhe āgate alābhaḥ āgataḥ eva ati veditabbaḥ yasa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: “Gain” should be understood as the arrival of gain, and “no gain” as the arrival of no gain. So too with fame and the rest.

original: 338. Abhibhāyatanavimokkhakathā heṭṭhā kathitā eva.
analyzed: abhibhāyatana vimokkha kathā heṭṭhā kathitā eva
translated: The explanation of the bases of mastery and the liberations has already been given .

original: “Ime kho, āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti ekādasannaṃ aṭṭhakānaṃ vasena aṭṭhāsīti pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti ekādasannam aṭṭhakānam vasena aṭṭhāsi iti pañhe kathentaḥ thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friend” , etc., should be construed as above. So the elder, in answering the eighty-eight questions by means of the eleven and the eight, showed the principle of synthesis.

original: Aṭṭhakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the eights is ended.

original: Navakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: navaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The nines

original: 340. Iti aṭṭhakavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni navakavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ
analyzed: iti aṭṭhaka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni navaka vasena dassetum puna desanam
translated: Having thus shown the word of unity in the eightfold way, he now shows it in the ninefold way, beginning with the nine dhammas that are very helpful.

original: ārabhi. Tattha āghātavatthūnīti āghātakāraṇāni. Āghātaṃ bandhatīti kopaṃ bandhati karoti uppādeti.
analyzed: ārabhi tattha āghāta vatthūni iti āghāta kāraṇāni āghātam bandhati iti kopam bandhati karoti uppādeti
translated: Having thus shown the word “harmony” in the eightfold way, he now began the teaching in order to show it in the ninefold way. Herein, grounds for annoyance are reasons for annoyance. He binds himself with annoyance: he binds himself with hate, he makes it arise, he generates it.

original: Taṃ kutettha labbhāti taṃ anatthacaraṇaṃ mā ahosīti etasmiṃ puggale kuto labbhā,
analyzed: tam kutas ittha tam anattha caraṇam mā ahosi iti etasmin puggale kutas labbhā
translated: How can I get it? How can I get that harm-doing from this person?🔽Thinking thus, he dispels annoyance. Or alternatively, if I were to be annoyed, how could I get that ground for annoyance in this person? What reason is there for getting it?

original: kena kāraṇena sakkā laddhuṃ? Paro nāma parassa attano cittaruciyā anatthaṃ karotīti
analyzed: kena kāraṇena sakkā laddhum paraḥ nāma parassa citta ruciyā anattham karoti iti
translated: For a person is called another only because he does not do what one wants him to do.

original: evaṃ cintetvā āghātaṃ paṭivinodeti. Atha vā sacāhaṃ paṭikopaṃ kareyyaṃ, taṃ kopakaraṇaṃ🔽ettha puggale kuto labbhā, kena kāraṇena laddhabbanti attho. Kuto lābhātipi pāṭho,
analyzed: evam cintetvā āghātam paṭivinodeti atha vā sacā aham paṭikopam kareyyam tam kopa karaṇam  ettha puggale kutas labbhā kena kāraṇena laddhabbanti atthaḥ kutas lābhā atipi pāṭhaḥ
translated: Thinking thus, he dispels annoyance. Or alternatively, the reading is “ kuto lābhaṃ,”

original: sacāhaṃ ettha kopaṃ kareyyaṃ, tasmiṃ me kopakaraṇe kuto lābhā, lābhā nāma ke siyunti🔽attho. Imasmiñca atthe tanti nipātamattameva hoti.
analyzed: sacā aham ettha kopam kareyyam tasmin me kopa karaṇe kutas lābhāḥ lābhāḥ nāma ke siyunti 🔽attho imasmin ca atthe tanti nipātam attam eva hoti
translated: and the meaning is this: “If I were to be annoyed, how could I get that ground for annoyance in this person? What reason is there for getting it?” And in this meaning the word “kuto” is merely an expletive.

original: 341. Sattāvāsāti sattānaṃ āvāsā, vasanaṭṭhānānīti attho. Tattha suddhāvāsāpi sattāvāsova,
analyzed: sattāvāsā ti sattānam āvāsāḥ vasanaṭṭhānāni iti tattha suddhāvāsā api satta āvāsā uva
translated: “Abodes of beings”: the abodes of beings, their dwelling places, is the meaning. Herein, the Pure Abodes are an abode of beings,

original: asabbakālikattā pana na gahitā. Suddhāvāsā hi buddhānaṃ khandhāvārasadisā. Asaṅkhyeyyakappe
analyzed: asabbakālika ttā pana na gahitā suddhāvāsāḥ hi buddhānam khandhāvāra sadisāḥ asaṅkhyeyya kappe
translated: but they are not included because they are not always so. For the Pure Abodes are like a district for the Buddhas.

original: buddhesu anibbattantesu taṃ ṭhānaṃ suññaṃ hotīti asabbakālikattā na gahitā. Sesamettha
analyzed: buddhesu a nibbattantesu tam ṭhānam suññam hoti iti asabbakālika ttā na gahitā sesam ettha
translated: When Buddhas are not arisen, that place is empty because it is not always so. The rest here

original: yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: is as already stated.

original: 342. Akkhaṇesu dhammo ca desiyatīti catusaccadhammo desiyati. Opasamikoti kilesūpasamakaro.
analyzed: akkhaṇesu dhammo ca desiyati iti catu sacca dhammo desiyati opasamikaḥ iti kilesu upasama karo
translated: “The Dhamma is taught in the right way”: the Dhamma of the Four Truths is taught. “It is peace”: it causes the stilling of defilements.

original: Parinibbānikoti kilesaparinibbānena parinibbānāvaho. Sambodhagāmīti catumaggañāṇapaṭivedhagāmī.
analyzed: parinibbānikaḥ ti kilesa parinibbānena parinibbāna āvahaḥ sambodha gāmī iti catu magga ñāṇa paṭivedha gāmī
translated: “It leads to Nibbāna”: it leads to Nibbāna by means of the stilling of defilements. “It leads to full enlightenment”: it leads to the penetration of the knowledge of the four paths.

original: Aññataranti asaññabhavaṃ vā arūpabhavaṃ vā.🔽343. Anupubbavihārāti anupaṭipāṭiyā samāpajjitabbavihārā.
analyzed: aññataranti a sañña bhavam vā a rūpa bhavam vā  anupubba vihārā ati anupaṭipāṭiyā samāpajjitabba vihārā
translated: “Any other”: either the non-percipient realm or the formless realm.🔽“Gradual abidings”: abidings to be entered upon in due succession.

original: 344. Anupubbanirodhāti anupaṭipāṭiyā nirodhā.
analyzed: anupubba nirodhā ti anupaṭipāṭiyā nirodhā
translated: “Gradual cessations”: cessations to be reached in due succession.

original: “Ime, kho āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti channaṃ navakānaṃ vasena catupaṇṇāsa pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti channam navakānam vasena catupaṇṇāsa pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti
translated: “These, friend,” etc., should be construed in the same way as above. Thus the Elder showed the unity of the Teaching by means of the forty-five questions on the ninefold Teaching.

original: Navakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: navaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the ninefold Teaching is ended.

original: Dasakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dasaka vaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the tenfold Teaching

original: 345. Iti navakavasena sāmaggirasaṃ dassetvā idāni dasakavasena dassetuṃ puna desanaṃ🔽ārabhi. Tattha nāthakaraṇāti “sanāthā, bhikkhave, viharatha mā anāthā, dasa ime,
analyzed: iti navaka vasena sāmaggi rasam dassetvā idāni dasaka vasena dassetum puna desanam  ārabhi tattha nātha karaṇā ti sa nāthāḥ bhikkhave viharatha mā anāthāḥ dasa ime
translated: Having shown the unity of the Teaching by means of the ninefold Teaching, the Elder now began the exposition of the tenfold Teaching in order to show the unity of the Teaching by means of the tenfold Teaching.

original: bhikkhave, dhammā nāthakaraṇā”ti evaṃ akkhātā attano patiṭṭhākarā dhammā.
analyzed: bhikkhave dhammā nātha karaṇā ti evam akkhātāḥ attanaḥ patiṭṭhā karāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: Herein, the ten dhammas that are a protection are the dhammas declared as follows: “Bhikkhus, live with a protector, not without a protector. These ten dhammas are a protection” .

original: Kalyāṇamittotiādīsu sīlādiguṇasampannā kalyāṇā assa mittāti kalyāṇamitto. Te cassa
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittaḥ ti ādīsu sīla ādi guṇa sampannā kalyāṇā assa mittā ati te ca assa
translated: A good friend: he has good friends, thus he is a good friend.🔽He is a good companion because he is not separated from them in walking, standing, sitting, and lying down.
