It is blameworthy both in the case of a slight wish to do harm and in the case of a great wish to do harm. Its two constituents are the living being and the wish to kill.

original: ca. Parasattavatthuke hi kodhe uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti, yāva “aho🔽vatāyaṃ ucchijjheyya vinasseyyā”ti tassa vināsaṃ na cinteti.🔽Yathābhuccagahaṇābhāvena micchā passatīti micchādiṭṭhi. Sā “natthi dinna”ntiādinā🔽nayena viparītadassanalakkhaṇā. Samphappalāpo viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca. Apica
analyzed: ca para satta vatthuke hi kodhe uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti yāva aho  vata ayam ucchijjheyya vinasseyya ati tassa vināsam na cinteti  yathā abhucca gahaṇa abhāvena micchā passati iti micchādiṭṭhi sā natthi  nayena viparīta dassana lakkhaṇā samphappalāpaḥ viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca apica
translated: For even when anger has arisen in regard to a living being, there is no breach of the path of action until he has decided to kill him.🔽Wrong view is the wrong seeing of things as they are. Its characteristic is the seeing of things contrary to fact, as in the view “There is nothing given” . It is blameworthy both in the case of a slight wrong view and in the case of a great wrong view. Moreover,

original: aniyatā appasāvajjā, niyatā mahāsāvajjā. Tassā dve sambhārā vatthuno ca gahitākāraviparītatā,
analyzed: aniyatāḥ appasāvajjāḥ niyatā mahāsāvajjā tassāḥ dve sambhārāḥ vatthuno ca gahita ākāra viparīta tā
translated: it is blameless when it is unfixed, and blameworthy when it is fixed. Its two constituents are the object and the contrary mode of seeing.

original: yathā ca taṃ gaṇhāti, tathābhāvena tassūpaṭṭhānanti.
analyzed: yathā ca tam gaṇhāti tathābhāvena tassu upaṭṭhānam ti
translated: and the way it is apprehended is the way it appears.

original: Imesaṃ pana dasannaṃ akusalakammapathānaṃ dhammato koṭṭhāsato ārammaṇato vedanāto mūlatoti pañcahākārehi vinicchayo veditabbo.
analyzed: imesam pana dasannam akusala kamma pathānam dhammataḥ koṭṭhāsataḥ ārammaṇataḥ vedanātaḥ mūlato ti pañcahā ākārehi vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: The exposition of these ten unprofitable courses of action should be known by kind, by clause, by object, by feeling, and by root.

original: Tattha dhammatoti etesu hi paṭipāṭiyā satta cetanādhammāva honti. Abhijjhādayo tayo cetanāsampayuttā.
analyzed: tattha dhammato ti etesu hi paṭipāṭiyā satta cetanā dhammā ava honti abhijjhā ādayo cetanā sampayuttā
translated: Herein, by kind: in the case of these, seven are simply states of consciousness, namely, the first seven in the regular series. The other three are associated with consciousness.

original: Koṭṭhāsatoti paṭipāṭiyā satta, micchādiṭṭhi cāti ime aṭṭha kammapathā eva honti,🔽no mūlāni. Abhijjhābyāpādā kammapathā ceva mūlāni ca. Abhijjhā hi mūlaṃ patvā lobho
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā satta micchādiṭṭhi ca ati ime aṭṭha kammapathāḥ eva honti  no mūlāni abhijjhā abyāpādā kamma pathā ca iva mūlāni ca abhijjhā hi mūlam patvā lobho
translated: By clause: seven are simply courses of action, namely, the first seven in the regular series, and wrong view.

original: akusalamūlaṃ hoti. Byāpādo doso akusalamūlaṃ hoti.🔽Ārammaṇatoti pāṇātipāto jīvitindriyārammaṇato saṅkhārārammaṇo hoti. Adinnādānaṃ sattārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: a kusala mūlam hoti byāpādaḥ dosaḥ a kusala mūlam hoti  ārammaṇato ti pāṇa atipātaḥ jīvitindriya ārammaṇato saṅkhāra ārammaṇaḥ hoti adinnādānam satta ārammaṇam
translated: The other three are both courses of action and roots. For covetousness is the unprofitable root greed that has become a course of action. Ill will is the unprofitable root hate that has become a course of action.🔽By object: killing living beings has formations as its object since it has the life faculty as its object. Taking what is not given has either living beings as its object or formations as its object. Misconduct in sensual pleasures has formations as its object since it has contact as its object.

original: vā saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ vā, micchācāro phoṭṭhabbavasena saṅkhārārammaṇo. “Sattārammaṇo”tipi
analyzed: vā saṅkhāra ārammaṇam vā micchācāro phoṭṭhabba vasena saṅkhāra ārammaṇaḥ satta ārammaṇaḥ ti pi
translated: “It has living beings as its object” is said

original: eke. Musāvādo sattārammaṇo vā saṅkhārārammaṇo vā, tathā pisuṇavācā. Pharusavācā sattārammaṇāva.
analyzed: eke musāvādaḥ satta ārammaṇaḥ vā saṅkhāra ārammaṇaḥ vā tathā pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā satta ārammaṇā ava
translated: Lying is either with a living being as object or with formations as object. So too, malicious speech. Harsh speech is only with a living being as object.

original: Samphappalāpo diṭṭhasutamutaviññātavasena sattārammaṇo vā saṅkhārārammaṇo vā. Tathā
analyzed: samphappalāpaḥ diṭṭha suta muta viññāta vasena satta ārammaṇaḥ vā saṅkhāra ārammaṇaḥ vā tathā
translated: Gossip is either with a living being as object or with formations as object, according to whether it is about what is seen, heard, or sensed or about formations. So too,

original: abhijjhā. Byāpādo sattārammaṇova. Micchādiṭṭhi tebhūmakadhammavasena saṅkhārārammaṇā.
analyzed: abhijjhā byāpādaḥ satta ārammaṇā uva micchādiṭṭhi tebhūmaka dhamma vasena saṅkhāra ārammaṇā
translated: covetousness. Ill will is only with a living being as object. Wrong view is with formations as object, according to whether it is concerned with the three planes.

original: Vedanātoti pāṇātipāto dukkhavedano hoti. Kiñcāpi hi rājāno coraṃ disvā hasamānāpi
analyzed: vedanāto ti pāṇātipāto dukkha vedano hoti kiñcā api hi rājāno coram disvā hasamānā api
translated: As to feeling: killing living beings has pain as its feeling-tone. For even though kings, on seeing a thief,

original: “gacchatha naṃ ghātethā”ti vadanti, sanniṭṭhāpakacetanā pana dukkhasampayuttāva hoti.
analyzed: gacchatha nam ghātetha iti vadanti sanniṭṭhāpaka cetanā pana dukkha sampayuttā ava hoti
translated: say, “Execute him,” and laugh and joke while doing so, yet the volition that consummates the action is associated with pain.

original: Adinnādānaṃ tivedanaṃ. Micchācāro sukhamajjhattavasena dvivedano. Sanniṭṭhāpakacitte
analyzed: adinnādānam ti vedanam micchācāro sukham ajjhatta vasena dvi vedano sanniṭṭhāpaka citte
translated: Taking what is not given has three feelings. Misconduct has two feelings, being pleasant and neutral. But in the consummating volition

original: pana majjhattavedano na hoti. Musāvādo tivedano. Tathā pisuṇavācā. Pharusavācā dukkhavedanā.
analyzed: pana majjhatta vedanaḥ na hoti musāvādo ti vedano tathā pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā dukkha vedanā
translated: there is no neutral feeling. Lying has three feelings. So too, malicious speech. Harsh speech has pain as its feeling-tone.

original: Samphappalāpo tivedano. Abhijjhā sukhamajjhattavasena dvivedanā tathā micchādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: samphappalāpaḥ ti vedanaḥ abhijjhā sukha majjhatta vasena dvi vedanā tathā micchādiṭṭhi
translated: Gossip has three feelings. Covetousness and wrong view have two feelings, being pleasant and neutral.

original: Byāpādo dukkhavedano.
analyzed: byāpādaḥ dukkha vedano
translated: Ill will has painful feeling.

original: Mūlatoti pāṇātipāto dosamohavasena dvimūlako hoti. Adinnādānaṃ dosamohavasena vā🔽lobhamohavasena vā. Micchācāro lobhamohavasena. Musāvādo dosamohavasena vā lobhamohavasena🔽vā tathā pisuṇavācā samphappalāpo ca. Pharusavācā dosamohavasena. Abhijjhā mohavasena
analyzed: pāṇa atipātaḥ dosa moha vasena dvimūlakaḥ adinnādānam dosa moha vasena vā  lobha moha vasena vā micchā ācāraḥ lobha moha vasena musāvādaḥ dosa moha vasena vā lobha moha vasena  vā tathā pisuṇa vācā samphappalāpaḥ ca pharusa vācā dosa moha vasena abhijjhā moha vasena
translated: As to root: killing living beings has two roots, being rooted in hate and delusion. Taking what is not given is rooted in greed and delusion or

original: ekamūlā. Tathā byāpādo. Micchādiṭṭhi lobhamohavasena dvimūlāti.
analyzed: eka mūlā tathā byāpādaḥ micchādiṭṭhi lobha moha vasena dvi mūlā ati
translated: in hate and delusion or in greed and delusion. Misconduct is rooted in greed and delusion. False speech is rooted in hate and delusion or in greed and delusion or in greed and delusion. So too, malicious speech and gossip. Harsh speech is rooted in hate and delusion. Covetousness is rooted in delusion. So too, ill will. Wrong view is rooted in greed and delusion.

original: Kusalakammapathadasakavaṇṇanā
translated: Ten courses of wholesome kamma

original: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇiādīni samādānasampattasamucchedavirativasena veditabbāni.
analyzed: pāṇa atipātāḥ veramaṇi ādīni samādāna sampatta samuccheda virati vasena veditabbāni
translated: Abstinences from killing living beings, etc., should be understood as undertaken by undertaking, as abandoned by abandoning, and as abstention.

original: Dhammato pana etesupi paṭipāṭiyā satta cetanāpi vattanti viratiyopi. Ante tayo cetanāsampayuttāva.
analyzed: dhammato pana etesu pi paṭipāṭiyā satta cetanā api vattanti viratiyaḥ api ante tayo cetanā sampayuttā ava
translated: But in the case of all of them, too, the seven kinds of volition occur in order, and also the abstentions. In the last three only volition associated with the three is found.

original: Koṭṭhāsatoti paṭipāṭiyā satta kammapathā eva, no mūlāni. Ante tayo kammapathā ceva
analyzed: koṭṭhāsato ti paṭipāṭiyā satta kammapathā eva no mūlāni ante tayo kammapathā ca iva
translated: As to class: the first seven courses of kamma are only courses of kamma, not roots. The last three are both courses of kamma and roots.

original: mūlāni ca. Anabhijjhā hi mūlaṃ patvā alobho kusalamūlaṃ hoti. Abyāpādo adoso kusalamūlaṃ.
analyzed: mūlāni ca anabhijjhā hi mūlam patvā alobhaḥ kusala mūlam hoti a byāpādaḥ a dosaḥ kusala mūlam
translated: and roots. For non-greed, having taken the root of non-greed as its object, becomes the profitable root non-greed. Non-ill-will is the profitable root non-hate.

original: Sammādiṭṭhi amoho kusalamūlaṃ.
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi amoho kusala mūlam
translated: Right view is the profitable root non-delusion.

original: Ārammaṇatoti pāṇātipātādīnaṃ ārammaṇāneva etesaṃ ārammaṇāni. Vītikkamitabbatoyeva
analyzed: ārammaṇato ti pāṇātipāta ādīnam ārammaṇāni eva etesam ārammaṇāni
translated: As to object: these have as their objects only the objects of the things beginning with killing living beings. For it is only when these have been transgressed that

original: hi veramaṇī nāma hoti. Yathā pana nibbānārammaṇo ariyamaggo kilese pajahati, evaṃ
analyzed: hi veramaṇī nāma hoti yathā pana nibbāna ārammaṇaḥ ariya maggo kilese pajahati evam
translated: abstinence is called a “path of action.” But just as the noble path, which has Nibbāna as its object, abandons defilements,

original: jīvitindriyādiārammaṇāpete kammapathā pāṇātipātādīni dussīlyāni pajahantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: jīvitindriya ādi ārammaṇa apete kamma pathā pāṇātipāta ādīni dussīlyāni pajahanti iti veditabbā
translated: so these paths of action beginning with abstinence from killing living beings should be understood as abandoning the kinds of failure beginning with killing living beings, which have the life faculty, etc., as their objects.

original: Vedanātoti sabbe sukhavedanā honti majjhattavedanā vā. Kusalaṃ patvā hi dukkhavedanā nāma natthi.🔽Mūlatoti paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇasampayuttacittena viramantassa alobhaadosaamohavasena
analyzed: vedanāto ti sabbe sukha vedanāḥ honti majjhatta vedanāḥ vā kusalam patvā hi dukkha vedanā nāma natthi  mūlato ti paṭipāṭiyā satta ñāṇa sampayutta cittena viramantassa alobha a dosa a moha vasena
translated: As to feeling: all are associated with the feeling of pleasure or with that of indifference. For there is no such thing as a profitable action associated with pain.

original: timūlāni honti, ñāṇavippayuttacittena viramantassa dvimūlāni. Anabhijjhā ñāṇasampayuttacittena
analyzed: ti mūlāni honti ñāṇa vippayutta cittena viramantassa dvi mūlāni anabhijjhā ñāṇa sampayutta cittena
translated: As to root: when one abstains by means of a consciousness associated with knowledge, then the abstention has three roots in the case of each path of action, being non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion. When one abstains by means of a consciousness dissociated from knowledge, then the abstention has two roots, being non-greed and non-hate. For non-delusion is not found dissociated from knowledge.

original: viramantassa dvimūlā, ñāṇavippayuttacittena ekamūlā. Alobho pana attanāva attano
analyzed: viramantassa dvi mūlā ñāṇa vippayutta cittena eka mūlā alobho pana attanā ava attano
translated: when he refrains, they are rooted in two, when he is without knowledge they are rooted in one. But non-greed is itself

original: mūlaṃ na hoti. Abyāpādepi eseva nayo. Sammādiṭṭhi alobhādosavasena dvimūlā evāti.
analyzed: mūlam na hoti abyāpāde pi esa iva nayo sammādiṭṭhi alobhā dosa vasena dvi mūlāḥ eva ati
translated: and when he is abstaining, it is with two roots, with consciousness not associated with knowledge. But non-greed is not its own root. The same method applies in the case of non-hate. And right view is rooted in non-greed and non-hate, thus it is rooted in two.

original: Ariyavāsadasakavaṇṇanā🔽348. Ariyavāsāti ariyā eva vasiṃsu vasanti vasissanti etesūti ariyavāsā. Pañcaṅgavippahīnoti
analyzed: ariyavāsadasaka vaṇṇanā  ariya vāsā ati ariyāḥ eva vasiṃsu vasanti vasissanti etesu uti ariya vāsā pañcaṅga vippahīno ti
translated: The explanation of the ten bases of the noble ones🔽The noble ones have dwelt, are dwelling, and will dwell in these, thus they are bases of the noble ones .

original: pañcahi aṅgehi vippayuttova hutvā khīṇāsavo avasi vasati vasissatīti tasmā ayaṃ pañcaṅgavippahīnatā,
analyzed: pañcahi aṅgehi vippayuttaḥ uva hutvā khīṇa āsavaḥ avasi vasati vasissati iti tasmai ayam pañcaṅga vippahīna tā
translated: With the five factors abandoned: having become one in whom the five factors have been abandoned, the one with cankers destroyed dwells, has dwelt, will dwell. Therefore this is the abandonment of the five factors.

original: ariyassa vāsattā ariyavāsoti vutto. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: ariyassa vāsa ttā ariya vāsaḥ ti vuttaḥ esa nayaḥ sabbattha
translated: Because it is the dwelling of the noble one, it is called the noble one’s dwelling. The same method applies in all cases.

original: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hotīti chaḷaṅgupekkhāya samannāgato
analyzed: evam kho āvuso bhikkhu chaḷaṅga samannāgataḥ hoti iti chaḷaṅga upekkhāya samannāgataḥ
translated: Thus, friends, a bhikkhu possesses six factors: he possesses the six-factored equanimity.

original: hoti. Chaḷaṅgupekkhā nāma keti? Ñāṇādayo. “Ñāṇa”nti vutte kiriyato cattāri ñāṇasampayuttacittāni
analyzed: hoti chaḷaṅgu pekkhā nāma kā iti ñāṇa ādayaḥ ñāṇan ti vutte kiriyato cattāri ñāṇa sampayutta cittāni
translated: What is meant by “six-factored equanimity”? Knowledge, etc. When “knowledge” is said, four kinds of consciousness associated with knowledge are obtained.

original: labbhanti. “Satatavihāro”ti vutte aṭṭha mahācittāni. “Rajjanadussanaṃ natthī”ti vutte
analyzed: labbhanti satata vihāraḥ ti vutte aṭṭha mahācittāni rajjana dussanam natthi iti vutte
translated: When “constant abiding” is said, eight great kinds of consciousness are obtained. When “no lust and no hate” is said,

original: dasa cittāni labbhanti. Somanassaṃ āsevanavasena labbhati.
analyzed: dasa cittāni labbhanti somanassam āsevana vasena labbhati
translated: Ten kinds of consciousness are possible. It is possible by way of the development of joy.

original: Satārakkhena cetasāti khīṇāsavassa hi tīsu dvāresu sabbakālaṃ sati ārakkhakiccaṃ
analyzed: satā ārakkhena cetasā ti khīṇāsavassa hi tīsu dvāresu sabbakālam sati ārakkha kiccam
translated: “Mindful, with guard upon the doors of sense”: for one whose cankers are destroyed, mindfulness performs the function of a guard at all times in the three doors of action.

original: sādheti. Tenevassa “carato ca tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ🔽ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hotī”ti vuccati.🔽Puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānanti bahūnaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ. Ettha ca samaṇāti pabbajjupagatā.
analyzed: sādha iti tena ivassa carataḥ ca tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam  ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti iti vuccati  puthu samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ti bahūnam samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ettha ca samaṇā ati pabbajja upagatā
translated: Therefore it is said of him: “Whether he is walking or standing or sleeping or awake, mindfulness is established and ever present” .🔽“The many a brāhmaṇa and recluses”: many brāhmaṇas and recluses. And here “recluse” is one who has gone forth into homelessness;🔽“brāhmaṇa” is one who speaks of “bhava.” “The many a truth”: many a truth taken separately, the meaning is.🔽“This view alone is true, this view alone is true” .

original: Brāhmaṇāti bhovādino. Puthupaccekasaccānīti bahūni pāṭekkasaccāni, idameva dassanaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇa ati bhovādino puthu paccekasaccāni iti bahūni pāṭekkasaccāni idam eva dassanam
translated: “The many a view”: many a view taken separately.🔽“The many a doctrine”: many a doctrine taken separately.🔽“The many a faith”: many a faith taken separately.🔽“The many a belief”: many a belief taken separately.

original: saccaṃ, idameva dassanaṃ saccanti evaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ gahitāni bahūni saccānīti attho.
analyzed: saccam idam eva dassanam saccanti evam pāṭiyekkam gahitāni bahūni saccāni iti attho
translated: “The many a adherence”: many an adherence taken separately.🔽“The many a attachment”: many an attachment taken separately.🔽“The many a affection”: many an affection taken separately.🔽“The many a desire”: many a desire taken separately.🔽“The many a passion”: many a passion taken separately.🔽“The many a lust”: many a lust taken separately.🔽“The many a love”: many a love taken separately.🔽“The many a liking”: many a liking taken separately.🔽“The many a wish”: many a wish taken separately.🔽“The many a inclination”: many an inclination taken separately.🔽“The many a pursuit”: many a pursuit taken separately.🔽“The many a cleaving”: many a cleaving taken separately.🔽“The many a bondage”: many a bondage taken separately.🔽“The many a obsession”: many an obsession taken separately.🔽“The many a entanglement”: many an entanglement taken separately.🔽“The many a ensnaring”: many an ensnaring taken separately.🔽“The many a fetter”: many a fetter taken separately.

original: Nunnānīti nihatāni. Paṇunnānīti suṭṭhu nihatāni. Cattānīti vissaṭṭhāni. Vantānīti
analyzed: nunnāni iti nihatāni paṇunnāni iti suṭṭhu nihatāni cattāni iti vissaṭṭhāni vantāni iti
translated: “The many a underlying tendency”: many an underlying tendency taken separately.🔽“The many a underlying tendency to lust”: many an underlying tendency to lust taken separately.🔽“The many a underlying tendency to hatred”: many an underlying tendency to hatred taken separately.

original: vamitāni. Muttānīti chinnabandhanāni katāni. Pahīnānīti pajahitāni. Paṭinissaṭṭhānīti
analyzed: vamitāni muttāni iti chinna bandhanāni katāni pahīnāni iti pajahitāni paṭinissaṭṭhāni iti
translated: “The many a underlying tendency to delusion

original: yathā na puna cittaṃ āruhanti, evaṃ paṭinissajjitāni. Sabbāneva tāni gahitaggahaṇassa
analyzed: yathā na puna cittam āruhanti evam paṭinissajjitāni sabbāni eva tāni gahita gahaṇassa
translated: They are “given up” in the sense that they do not ascend the mind again.

original: vissaṭṭhabhāvavevacanāni.🔽Samavayasaṭṭhesanoti ettha avayāti anūnā. Saṭṭhāti vissaṭṭhā. Sammā avayā saṭṭhā
analyzed: vissaṭṭha bhāva vevacanāni  ettha avayā ati anūnā saṭṭhā ati vissaṭṭhā sammā avayā saṭṭhā
translated: All these terms are synonyms for “dispersed” in the sense of “grasped and dispersed.”

original: esanā assāti samavayasaṭṭhesano. Sammā vissaṭṭhasabbaesanoti attho. Rāgā cittaṃ vimuttantiādīhi
analyzed: esanā assa ati sama vaya saṭṭha esano sammā vissaṭṭha sabba esanā ti attho rāgā cittam vimuttam ti ādīhi
translated: “The search for a mixed-up dispersion”: “avaya” is “not deficient,” “saṭṭha” is “dispersed.” “Sammā avaya saṭṭha esanā assā” is “the search for a mixed-up dispersion.” The meaning is: the search for a dispersed search for all .

original: maggassa kiccanipphatti kathitā.
analyzed: maggassa kicca nipphatti kathitā
translated: “The mind is liberated from passion” and so on show the fruition of the path.

original: Rāgo me pahīnotiādīhi paccavekkhaṇāya phalaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: rāgaḥ me pahīnaḥ ti ādīhi paccavekkhaṇāya phalam kathitam
translated: “Passion is given up in me” and so on show the reviewing of the fruition.

original: Asekkhadhammadasakavaṇṇanā🔽Asekkhā sammādiṭṭhītiādayo sabbepi phalasampayuttadhammā eva. Ettha ca sammādiṭṭhi,
analyzed: asekkha dhamma dasaka vaṇṇanā  asekkhā sammādiṭṭhi iti ādayo sabbe pi phala sampayutta dhammā eva ettha ca sammādiṭṭhi
translated: The explanation of the ten dhammas of the adept

original: sammāñāṇanti dvīsu ṭhānesu paññāva kathitā. Sammāvimuttīti iminā padena vuttāvasesā.
analyzed: sammāñāṇanti dvīsu ṭhānesu paññā ava kathitā sammāvimutti iti iminā padena vuttā avasesā

original: Phalasamāpattidhammā saṅgahitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: phala samāpatti dhammā saṅgahitā iti veditabbā
translated: They should be understood as the dhammas of fruition attainment.

original: “Ime kho, āvuso”tiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ. Iti channaṃ dasakānaṃ vasena samasaṭṭhi pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasaṃ dassesīti.
analyzed: ime kho āvuso tiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam iti channam dasakānam vasena sama saṭṭhi pañhe kathento thero sāmaggirasam dassesi iti

original: Dasakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dasaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the section in tens is ended.

original: Pañhasamodhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañha samodhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on the summing up of the questions

original: 349. Idha pana ṭhatvā pañhā samodhānetabbā. Imasmiñhi sutte ekakavasena dve pañhā🔽kathitā. Dukavasena sattati. Tikavasena asītisataṃ. Catukkavasena dvesatāni. Pañcakavasena
analyzed: idha pana ṭhatvā pañhā samodhānetabbā imasmin hi sutte ekaka vasena dve pañhā  kathitāḥ duka vasena sattati tika vasena asīti satam catukka vasena dve satāni pañcaka vasena
translated: Here the questions are to be summed up as follows. In this sutta two questions are asked in the section on the single ;🔽seventy in the section on the dyad ; one hundred and eighty in the section on the triad ; two hundred and forty in the section on the tetrad ;

original: tiṃsasataṃ. Chakkavasena bāttiṃsasataṃ. Sattakavasena aṭṭhanavuti. Aṭṭhakavasena
analyzed: tiṃsa satam chakka vasena bāttiṃsa satam sattaka vasena aṭṭhanavuti aṭṭhaka vasena
translated: three hundred and sixty in the section on the pentad ; four hundred and eighty in the section on the hexad ; ninety-six in the section on the heptad ;

analyzed: aṭṭhāsīti navaka vasena catupaṇṇāsa dasaka vasena sama saṭṭhi iti evam sahassam cuddasa pañhā kathitā
translated: eighty-eight in the section on the octad ; forty-five in the section on the ennead ; and sixty-three in the section on the decade. Thus one thousand and fourteen questions are asked.

original: Imañhi suttantaṃ ṭhapetvā tepiṭake buddhavacane añño suttanto evaṃ bahupañhapaṭimaṇḍito
analyzed: imam hi suttantam ṭhapetvā tepiṭake buddha vacane aññaḥ suttantaḥ evam bahu pañha paṭimaṇḍito
translated: For apart from this sutta, there is no other sutta in the nine-fold collection of the Buddha’s word so rich in questions.

original: natthi. Bhagavā imaṃ suttantaṃ ādito paṭṭhāya sakalaṃ sutvā cintesi – “dhammasenāpati
analyzed: natthi bhagavā imam suttantam āditaḥ paṭṭhāya sakalam sutvā cintesi dhammasenāpati
translated: There is none. The Exalted One listened to the entire discourse from the beginning and thought: “The General of the Dhamma

original: sāriputto buddhabalaṃ dīpetvā appaṭivattiyaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati. Sāvakabhāsitoti vutte🔽okappanā na hoti, jinabhāsitoti vutte hoti, tasmā jinabhāsitaṃ katvā devamanussānaṃ
analyzed: sāriputtaḥ buddha balam dīpetvā appaṭivattiyam sīha nādam nadati sāvaka bhāsitaḥ iti vutte  okappanā na hoti jina bhāsitaḥ ti vutte hoti tasmā jina bhāsitam katvā deva manussānam
translated: Sāriputta has roared his irreversible lion’s roar, illuminating the power of the Buddha. If it is said to have been spoken by a disciple,

original: okappanaṃ imasmiṃ suttante uppādessāmī”ti. Tato vuṭṭhāya sādhukāraṃ adāsi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: okappanam imasmin suttante uppādessāmi iti tatas vuṭṭhāya sādhukāram adāsi tena vuttam
translated: there will be no confidence. If it is said to have been spoken by the Victor, there will be confidence. Therefore, I will make it spoken by the Victor and arouse confidence in gods and men in this discourse.” Then he arose and gave his approval. Therefore it is said:

analyzed: atha kho bhagavā vuṭṭhahitvā āyasmantam sāriputtam āmantesi sādhu sādhu sāriputta
translated: “Then the Exalted One arose and addressed the venerable Sāriputta: ‘Good, good, Sāriputta,

analyzed: sādhu kho tvam sāriputta bhikkhūnam saṅgīti pariyāyam abhāsi iti
translated: it is good that you have spoken this discourse on the collection of the monks’ for the monks.’”

analyzed: tattha saṅgīti pariyāyanti sāmaggiyā kāraṇam idam vuttam hoti sādhu kho tvam
translated: Herein, discourse on the collection means the cause of unity. This is what is said: “It is good that you,

original: sāriputta, mama sabbaññutaññāṇena saṃsanditvā bhikkhūnaṃ sāmaggirasaṃ abhāsī”ti.
analyzed: sāriputta mama sabbaññu ta ññāṇena saṃsanditvā bhikkhūnam sāmaggirasam abhāsi iti
translated: Sāriputta, having been confirmed by my knowledge of omniscience, have spoken this discourse on the collection of the monks, which is a word for unity.”

original: Samanuñño satthā ahosīti anumodanena samanuñño ahosi. Ettakena ayaṃ suttanto jinabhāsito
analyzed: samanuññaḥ satthā ahosi iti anumodanena samanuññaḥ ahosi ettakena ayam suttanto jina bhāsito
translated: The Teacher approved, i.e. he approved by rejoicing.

original: nāma jāto. Desanāpariyosāne imaṃ suttantaṃ manasikarontā te bhikkhū arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsūti.
analyzed: nāma jātaḥ desanā pariyosāne imam suttantam manasikarontā te bhikkhū arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu iti
translated: The Teacher approved by rejoicing: he approved by rejoicing in it. With this much this Thread is called “spoken by the Victor” . At the end of the teaching, those bhikkhus who were paying attention to this Thread reached Arahantship.

original: Sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Commentary on the Long Division called the “Spring of Grace”

original: Saṅgītisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṅgīti sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā

original: 11. Dasuttarasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Ten-&-One Thread

original: 350. Evaṃ me sutanti dasuttarasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā – āvuso bhikkhaveti
analyzed: evam me sutam ti dasa uttara suttam tatra ayam apubba pada vaṇṇanā āvuso bhikkhave ti
translated: Thus have I heard: the Ten-&-One Thread. Herein, this is the commentary on the words not yet commented on:

original: sāvakānaṃ ālapanametaṃ. Buddhā hi parisaṃ āmantayamānā ‘bhikkhave’ti vadanti. Sāvakā
analyzed: sāvakānam ālapanam etam buddhāḥ hi parisam āmantayamānāḥ bhikkhava iti vadanti sāvakāḥ
translated: Friends, bhikkhus: this is an address to disciples. For Buddhas speak thus when they are addressing a following, saying “Bhikkhus”. But disciples,

analyzed: satthāram ucca ṭṭhāne ṭhapessāma ati satthu ālapanena an ālapitvā āvuso ti ālapanti te

analyzed: bhikkhū iti te dhammasenāpatim parivāretvā nisinnāḥ bhikkhū ke pana te bhikkhū ti a nibaddha vāsāḥ
translated: Those bhikkhus: those bhikkhus who were sitting round the General of the Dhamma. But who were they? They were not settled in any particular residence,

analyzed: disāgamanīyāḥ bhikkhū buddha kāle dve vāre bhikkhū sannipatanti upakaṭṭha vassūpanāyika kāle
translated: In the time of the Buddha, the monks assembled twice: at the time of the beginning of the rains,

original: ca pavāraṇakāle ca. Upakaṭṭhavassūpanāyikāya dasapi vīsatipi tiṃsampi cattālīsampi
analyzed: ca pavāraṇa kāle ca upakaṭṭha vassūpanāyikāya vīsatipi tiṃsampi cattālīsampi
translated: and at the time of the Invitation ceremony. At the time of the beginning of the rains,

original: paññāsampi bhikkhū vaggā vaggā kammaṭṭhānatthāya āgacchanti. Bhagavā tehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: paññāsam pi bhikkhū vaggāḥ vaggāḥ kammaṭṭhāna tthāya āgacchanti bhagavā tehi saddhiṃ
translated: ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty monks, in groups, came for the subject of meditation. The Blessed One,

original: sammoditvā kasmā, bhikkhave, upakaṭṭhāya vassūpanāyikāya vicarathāti pucchati. Atha
analyzed: sammoditvā kasmā bhikkhave upakaṭṭhāya vassūpanāyikāya vicaratha ati pucchati atha
translated: after exchanging friendly greetings with them, asked, “Why, monks, do you wander about at the time of the beginning of the rains?” Then

analyzed: te bhagavā kammaṭṭhāna attham āgatamha kammaṭṭhānam naḥ detha iti yācanti

analyzed: moha caritassa uddeso paripucchā kālena dhammassavanam kālena dhammasākacchā
translated: and the recitation and interrogation of the Dhamma to one of deluded temperament, saying, “Listen to the Dhamma at the proper time, discuss the Dhamma at the proper time,

analyzed: idam tuyham sappāyanti ācikkhati vitakka caritassa āna apāna sati kammaṭṭhānam deti
translated: and this will be helpful to you.” He gave the subject of mindfulness of breathing to one of speculative temperament.

original: Saddhācaritassa pasādanīyasuttante buddhasubodhiṃ dhammasudhammataṃ saṅghasuppaṭipattiñca
analyzed: saddhā caritassa pasādanīya suttante buddha su bodhim dhamma su dhamma tam saṅgha suppaṭipattiñca
translated: He expounds the Sutta on the Inspiring Truths for one whose temperament is dominated by faith, showing the Enlightened One’s perfect enlightenment, the True Idea’s perfect profundity, and the Community’s perfect practice.

original: pakāseti. Ñāṇacaritassa aniccatādipaṭisaṃyutte gambhīre suttante katheti. Te kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pakāseti ñāṇa caritassa anicca tā ādi paṭisaṃyutte gambhīre suttante kathā iti te kammaṭṭhānam
translated: He expounds a deep sutta concerned with impermanence, etc., for one whose temperament is dominated by understanding.

analyzed: gahetvā sace sappāyam hoti tattha iva vasanti no ce hoti sappāyam senāsanam pucchitvā

analyzed: gacchanti te tattha vasantā temāsikam paṭipadam gahetvā ghaṭetvā vā āyamantā sā utāpannā api
translated: Staying there, they take up the three-month period of rains residence, and by striving and struggling they reach the paths and fruits,

analyzed: honti sakadāgāminaḥ api anāgāminaḥ api arahantaḥ api  tatas vuttha vassā pavāretvā satthu santikam gantvā bhagavā aham tumhākam santike
translated: becoming stream-enterers, once-returners, non-returners, and even arahants.

translated: Then, after emerging from the rains, they perform the Invitation ceremony and go to the Teacher. “Venerable sir, I have reached the fruit of stream-entry, … I have reached the supreme fruit, arahantship,” they announce their attainment to the Blessed One.

original: ārocenti. Tattha ime bhikkhū upakaṭṭhāya vassūpanāyikāya āgatā. Evaṃ āgantvā gacchante
analyzed: ārocenti tattha ime bhikkhū upakaṭṭhāya vassūpanāyikāya āgatāḥ evam āgantvā gacchante
translated: Here these bhikkhus have come for the coming rains. They have come in this way and will go in this way.

original: pana bhikkhū bhagavā aggasāvakānaṃ santikaṃ peseti, yathāha “apaloketha pana, bhikkhave,
analyzed: pana bhikkhū bhagavā aggasāvakānam santikam peseti yathā āha apaloketha pana bhikkhave
translated: But the monks said to the Blessed One, “The Blessed One sends us to the chief disciples, saying, ‘Ask the chief disciples, monks.’

analyzed: sāriputta moggallānā iti bhikkhū ca vadanti kim nu kho mayam bhante apalokema sāriputta moggallānā iti
translated: And we say to them, ‘What should we ask the chief disciples, venerable sirs?’

analyzed: atha ne bhagavā tesam dassane uyyojesi sevatha bhikkhave sāriputta moggallāne
translated: Then the Blessed One sends us to see them, saying, ‘Associate with the chief disciples, monks;

analyzed: bhajatha bhikkhave sāriputta moggallāne paṇḍitāḥ bhikkhū anuggāhakā sabrahmacārīnam
translated: serve the chief disciples, monks. The wise monks are the supporters of their companions in the holy life.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, janetā evaṃ sāriputto. Seyyathāpi jātassa āpādetā evaṃ moggallāno.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave janetā evam sāriputto seyyathā api jātassa āpādetā evam moggallānaḥ
translated: Sariputta is like a mother, monks, and Moggallana is like a nurse.

original: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, sotāpattiphale vineti, moggallāno uttamatthe”ti.🔽Tadāpi bhagavā imehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ paṭisanthāraṃ katvā tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ āsayaṃ
analyzed: sāriputtaḥ bhikkhave sotāpatti phale vinā iti moggallānaḥ uttamatthā iti  tadā api bhagavā imehi bhikkhūhi saddhim paṭisanthāram katvā tesam bhikkhūnam āsayam
translated: Sariputta trains in the fruit of stream-entry, and Moggallana in the supreme state.”🔽Then the Blessed One, having exchanged courteous greetings with those monks, surveyed the disposition, temperament, character, and nature of the monks and saw that they were tractable.

original: upaparikkhanto “ime bhikkhū sāvakavineyyā”ti addasa. Sāvakavineyyā nāma ye buddhānampi
analyzed: upaparikkhantaḥ ime bhikkhū sāvaka vineyyā ati addasa sāvaka vineyyāḥ nāma ye buddhānam pi
translated: He saw that they were capable of understanding the Dhamma.

analyzed: dhamma desanāya bujjhanti sāvakānam pi buddha vineyyā pana sāvakāḥ bodhetum na sakkonti
translated: They are enlightened by the teaching of the disciples of the Buddha. But the disciples of the Buddha are not able to enlighten those who are to be enlightened by the Buddha.

original: Sāvakavineyyabhāvaṃ pana etesaṃ ñatvā katarassa bhikkhuno desanāya bujjhissantīti
analyzed: sāvaka vineyya bhāvam pana etesam ñatvā katarassa bhikkhuno desanāya bujjhissanti iti
translated: But knowing that they are to be enlightened by the disciples of the Buddha, he thought: “By the teaching of which bhikkhu will they be enlightened?”

original: olokento sāriputtassāti disvā therassa santikaṃ pesesi. Thero te bhikkhū pucchi “satthu
analyzed: olokentaḥ sāriputtassa ati disvā therassa santikam pesesi thero te bhikkhū pucchi satthu
translated: Looking around, he saw Sāriputta. So he sent them to the Elder. The Elder asked the bhikkhus: “Why have you come, friends?”

original: santikaṃ gatattha āvuso”ti. “Āma, gatamha satthārā pana amhe tumhākaṃ santikaṃ pesitā”ti.
analyzed: santikam gatattha āvuso ti āma gatamha satthārā pana amhe tumhākam santikam pesitā ati
translated: “Yes, we have come. But the Teacher has sent us to you.”

analyzed: tatas theraḥ ime bhikkhū mayham desanāya bujjhissanti kīdisī nu kho tesam desanā
translated: Then the Elder thought: “These bhikkhus will be enlightened by my teaching. What kind of teaching will be suitable for them?

analyzed: vaṭṭati iti cintentaḥ ime bhikkhū samagga ārāmā sāmaggirasassa dīpikā nesam desanā  vaṭṭati iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā tathārūpam desanam desetu kāmaḥ dasuttaram pavakkhāmi itiādim āha
translated: These bhikkhus are fond of unity. A teaching that illustrates the unity of the aggregates will be suitable for them.”🔽Having thus decided, and wishing to give them such a teaching, he said: “I shall expound the Dasuttara.”

original: Tattha dasadhā mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā vibhattoti dasuttaro, ekakato paṭṭhāya yāva dasakā
analyzed: tattha dasadhā mātikam ṭhapetvā vibhatto ti das uttaro ekakataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva dasakā
translated: Herein, it is “tenfold” because it is distributed under ten headings. It is “successive” because it is stated in successive sets of one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, and ten.

analyzed: gataḥ itipi dasuttaro ekekasmin pabbe dasa dasa pañhāḥ visesitāḥ tipi dasuttaro tam dasuttaram
translated: and also because it is “tenfold” in the sense that there are ten questions in each of the ten sections, it is “tenfold” in the sense that it is distinguished by ten questions in each section.

analyzed: pavakkhāmi iti kathessāmi dhammanti suttam nibbāna pattiyā ati nibbāna paṭilābha tthāya
translated: I shall expound: I shall teach. The Dhamma: the sutta. For the attainment of Nibbāna: for the acquisition of Nibbāna.

analyzed: dukkha ssanta kiriyāya āti sakalassa vaṭṭa dukkhassa pariyanta karaṇa ttham sabba gantha ppamocanam ti
translated: For the ending of suffering: for the purpose of ending the whole suffering of the round of rebirths. For the release of all bonds:

original: abhijjhākāyaganthādīnaṃ sabbaganthānaṃ pamocanaṃ.🔽Iti thero desanaṃ uccaṃ karonto bhikkhūnaṃ tattha pemaṃ janento evametaṃ uggahetabbaṃ
analyzed: abhijjhā kāya gantha ādīnam sabba ganthānam pamocanam  iti theraḥ desanam uccam karontaḥ bhikkhūnam tattha pemam janentaḥ evam etam uggahetabbam
translated: for the purpose of releasing all the bonds, such as the bodily tie of covetousness.🔽Thus, making the teaching resound, arousing love for it in the bhikkhus, he extolled it with four terms, thinking, “They will consider that it should be received thus,

original: pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ dhāretabbaṃ vācetabbaṃ maññissantīti catūhi padehi vaṇṇaṃ kathesi,

original: “ekāyano ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo”tiādinā nayena tesaṃ tesaṃ suttānaṃ bhagavā viya.

translated: And he extolled it in the way the Blessed One did in the various suttas beginning with “Bhikkhus, this is the direct path for the purification of beings” .

original: Ekadhammavaṇṇanā
analyzed: eka dhamma vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the one Dhamma

original: 351. (Ka) tattha bahukāroti bahūpakāro.
analyzed: ka tattha bahu kāro ti bahu upakāro
translated: Herein, helpful is useful.

original: (Kha) bhāvetabboti vaḍḍhetabbo.
analyzed: bhāvetabbo ti vaḍḍhetabbo
translated: To be developed is to be increased.

original: (Ga) pariññeyyoti tīhi pariññāhi parijānitabbo.🔽(Gha) pahātabboti pahānānupassanāya pajahitabbo.
analyzed: pariññeyyaḥ ti tīhi pariññāhi parijānitabbo  gha pahātabbo ti pahāna anupassanāya pajahitabbo
translated: To be fully understood: to be fully understood by means of the three kinds of full understanding.🔽To be abandoned: to be abandoned by means of the contemplation of abandoning.

analyzed: ṅa hāna bhāgiyaḥ ti apāya gāmi parihānāya saṃvattanakaḥ
translated: To lead to the falling away: to lead to the falling away of one who goes to the woeful states.

analyzed: ca visesa bhāgiyaḥ ti visesa gāmi visesāya saṃvattanako

original: (Cha) duppaṭivijjhoti duppaccakkhakaro.
analyzed: cha duppaṭivijjhaḥ ti duppaccakkhakaro
translated: Hard to penetrate: hard to see.

original: (Ja) uppādetabboti nipphādetabbo.
analyzed: jaḥ uppādetabbo ti nipphādetabbo
translated: To be realized: to be accomplished.

original: (Jha) abhiññeyyoti ñātapariññāya abhijānitabbo.
analyzed: abhiññeyyaḥ ti ñāta pariññāya abhijānitabbaḥ
translated: To be directly known: to be directly known by means of the full understanding of what is to be directly known.

original: (Ña) sacchikātabboti paccakkhaṃ kātabbo.
analyzed: sacchikātabbaḥ iti paccakkham kātabbaḥ
translated: To be realized: to be realized by direct experience.

analyzed: evam sabbattha mātikāsu attho veditabbaḥ iti āyasmā sāriputto yathā nāma dakkhaḥ veḷukāro

analyzed: hīram hīram karontaḥ phāleti evam eva tesam bhikkhūnam sappāyam desanam upaparikkhitvā
translated: so, having examined the bhikkhus’ suitability for the teaching,

original: dasadhā mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā ekekakoṭṭhāse ekekapadaṃ vibhajanto “katamo eko dhammo bahukāro,🔽appamādo kusalesu dhammesūti”tiādinā nayena desanaṃ vitthāretuṃ āraddho.
analyzed: dasadhā mātikam ṭhapetvā ekeka koṭṭhāse ekeka padam vibhajanto katamaḥ ekaḥ dhammo bahu kāro  appamādaḥ kusalesu dhammesu iti ādinā nayena desanam vitthāretum āraddhaḥ
translated: He began to expound the teaching by dividing each of the terms into one by one, beginning with the first term, “What is the one thing helpful?”🔽“Appamāda, in profitable ideas” is the profitable idea that is helpful everywhere.

original: Tattha appamādo kusalesu dhammesūti sabbatthakaṃ upakārakaṃ appamādaṃ kathesi. Ayañhi
analyzed: tattha appamādaḥ kusalesu dhammesu iti sabbatthakam upakārakam appamādam kathesi ayaṃ hi
translated: For this

analyzed: appamādaḥ nāma sīla pūraṇe indriya saṃvare bhojane mattaññu tāya jāgariya anuyoge sattasu

analyzed: saddhammesu vipassanā gabbham gaṇhāpane attha paṭisambhidā ādīsu sīlakkhandha ādi pañca dhammakkhandhesu
translated: good qualities, in conceiving the embryo of insight, in the four discriminations, in the five aggregates of virtue, etc.,

analyzed: ṭhānāṭṭhānesu mahāvihāra samāpattiyam ariya saccesu sati paṭṭhāna ādīsu bodhi pakkhiyesu
translated: in the four bases for success, in the four great references, in the four foundations of mindfulness, etc., in the thirty-seven states par- tial to enlightenment,

analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇa ādīsu aṭṭhasu vijjāsu iti sabbesu anavajja ṭṭhena kusalesu dhammesu bahu upakāraḥ
translated: in the eight knowledges beginning with insight knowledge, in all profitable ideas in the sense of being blameless.

translated: That is why the Blessed One extols him with the simile of the hand and the fingers, saying: “Bhikkhus, just as the peak of the Himalayas, king of mountains, is the highest, noblest, chief, and best of all the peaks of the Himalayas, king of mountains,

analyzed: appamādaḥ tesam dhammānam aggam akkhāyati itiādinā nayena hatthi pada ādīhi opammehi opamento  saṃyutta nikāye appamāda vagge nānappakāram thometi tam sabbam eka padena iva saṅgahetvā
translated: so too, among wholesome states, right concentration is declared to be the highest, that is, in the development of concentration dependent on will, in the development of concentration dependent on energy, in the development of concentration dependent on mind, and in the development of concentration dependent on investigation” .🔽In this way he extols him in various ways in the Appamādavagga of the Saṃyutta Nikāya.🔽The Elder includes all this in a single expression when he says: “Appamāda is the root of wholesome states.”

original: thero appamādo kusalesu dhammesūti āha. Dhammapade appamādavaggenāpissa bahūpakāratā
analyzed: theraḥ appamādaḥ kusalesu dhammesu iti āha dhamma pade appamāda vaggena api ssa bahu upakāra tā

translated: and by the story of King Asoka.🔽(Ka) For when King Asoka heard the verse “Appamāda is the path to immortality” from the novice monk Nigrodha, he was so pleased that he said: “Stop, my dear Nigrodha, you have recited the three Piṭakas of the Buddha’s Word to me.”

original: tāta, mayhaṃ tayā tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ kathita”nti sāmaṇere pasīditvā caturāsītivihārasahassāni
analyzed: tāta mayham tayā tepiṭakam buddha vacanam kathitanti sāmaṇere pasīditvā catur āsīti vihāra sahassāni

original: kāresi. Iti thāmasampannena bhikkhunā appamādassa bahūpakāratā tīhi piṭakehi dīpetvā🔽kathetabbā. Yaṃkiñci suttaṃ vā gāthaṃ vā appamādadīpanatthaṃ āharanto “aṭṭhāne ṭhatvā
analyzed: kāresi iti thāma sampannena bhikkhunā appamādassa bahu upakāra tā tīhi piṭakehi dīpetvā  kathetabbāḥ yaṃkiñci suttam vā gātham vā appamāda dīpana attham āharantaḥ aṭṭhāne ṭhatvā
translated: So the monk who is possessed of energy should expound the great usefulness of diligence by means of the three Piṭakas.

original: āharasi, atitthena pakkhando”ti na vattabbo. Dhammakathikassevettha thāmo ca balañca pamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: āharasi atitthena pakkhando ti na vattabbaḥ dhamma kathikassa iva ettha thāmaḥ ca balam ca pamāṇam
translated: And when he quotes any suttas or stanzas that illustrate diligence, he should not be told that he is “quoting from a wrong source and is out of his depth.” For the measure of a preacher of the Dhamma is his energy and strength.

original: (Kha) kāyagatāsatīti ānāpānaṃ catuiriyāpatho satisampajaññaṃ dvattiṃsākāro catudhātuvavatthānaṃ
analyzed: kāya gatā asatī iti āna apānam catu iriyāpathaḥ sati sampajaññam dvattiṃsa ākāro catu dhātu vavatthānam
translated: Mindfulness occupied with the body: this is a term for mindfulness of breathing, mindfulness occupied with the postures, clear comprehension, the thirty-two-fold aspect, the analysis of the four elements,

analyzed: dasa asubhā nava sivathikā cuṇṇika manasikāro kesa ādīsu cattāri rūpa jhānāni iti ettha  uppanna satiyāḥ etam adhivacanam sāta sahagatā ati ṭhapetvā catuttha jhānam aññattha
translated: the ten kinds of foulness, the nine cemetery contemplations, the contemplation of the bloated, the worm-infested corpse, etc., the contemplation of the bones, and the four jhānas in the kasiṇas beginning with the earth kasiṇa.

original: sātasahagatā hoti sukhasampayuttā, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sāta sahagatā hoti sukha sampayuttā tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: It is associated with pleasure: except for the fourth jhāna, it is associated with pleasure in the other jhānas and with happiness in the immaterial states. It is said with reference to that.

original: (Ga) sāsavo upādāniyoti āsavānañceva upādānānañca paccayabhūto. Iti tebhūmakadhammameva niyameti.
analyzed: sa asavaḥ upādāniyo ti āsavānam ca iva upādānānam ca paccaya bhūto iti tebhūmaka dhammam eva niyameti
translated: It is subject to cankers and is clung to: it is a condition for the arising of the cankers and for the clinging.

original: (Gha) asmimānoti rūpādīsu asmīti māno.
analyzed: rūpa ādīsu asmi iti
translated: The conceit “I am” is the conceit “I am” in regard to materiality, etc.

original: (Ṅa) ayoniso manasikāroti anicce niccantiādinā nayena pavatto uppathamanasikāro.
analyzed: ayonisaḥ manasikāro ti anicce nicca nti ādinā nayena pavatto uppatha manasikāro
translated: Improper attention is the wrong attention that occurs in the mode of regarding the impermanent as permanent, etc.

original: (Ca) vipariyāyena yoniso manasikāro veditabbo.
analyzed: ca vipariyāyena yonisas manasikāraḥ veditabbo
translated: Proper attention should be understood in the opposite sense.🔽The uninterrupted concentration of mind is the concentration of mind that is uninterrupted by any other thought.

original: (Cha) ānantariko cetosamādhīti aññattha maggānantaraṃ phalaṃ ānantariko cetosamādhi
analyzed: ānantariko cetaḥ samādhi iti aññattha magga anantaram phalam ānantariko cetaḥ samādhi
translated: In other places the fruition attainment that immediately follows the path is called the “uninterrupted concentration of mind.”

original: nāma. Idha pana vipassanānantaro maggo vipassanāya vā anantarattā attano vā anantaraṃ
analyzed: nāma idha pana vipassanā anantaraḥ maggaḥ vipassanāya vā anantarattā attanaḥ vā anantaram
translated: But here the path that immediately follows insight is intended, or the path that gives its fruit immediately after itself,

original: phaladāyakattā ānantariko cetosamādhīti adhippeto.
analyzed: phala dāyaka ttā ānantariko cetosamādhi iti adhippeto
translated: is called the “uninterrupted concentration of mind.”

original: (Ja) akuppaṃ ñāṇanti aññattha phalapaññā akuppañāṇaṃ nāma. Idha paccavekkhaṇapaññā adhippetā.
analyzed: akuppam ñāṇanti aññattha phala paññā akuppa ñāṇam nāma idha paccavekkhaṇa paññā adhippetā
translated: The unshakable knowledge is the knowledge of fruition in other places. But here the knowledge of reviewing is intended.

original: (Jha) āhāraṭṭhitikāti paccayaṭṭhitikā. Ayaṃ eko dhammoti yena paccayena tiṭṭhanti, ayaṃ eko dhammo ñātapariññāya abhiññeyyo.
analyzed: āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati paccaya ṭṭhitikā ayam ekaḥ dhammo ti yena paccayena tiṭṭhanti ayam ekaḥ dhammo ñāta pariññāya abhiññeyyaḥ
translated: The support by nutriment is the support by conditions. This one idea is to be directly known as the idea that should be directly known through full understanding as abandoning.

original: (Ña) akuppā cetovimuttīti arahattaphalavimutti.
analyzed: akuppā cetaḥ vimutti iti arahatta phala vimutti
translated: The unshakable deliverance of mind is the deliverance of mind that is arahantship.

original: Imasmiṃ vāre abhiññāya ñātapariññā kathitā. Pariññāya tīraṇapariññā. Pahātabbasacchikātabbehi
analyzed: imasmin vāre abhiññāya ñāta pariññā kathitā pariññāya tīraṇa pariññā pahātabba sacchikātabbehi
translated: In this section, the full understanding by scrutinization is stated as the full understanding by knowledge. The full understanding by overcoming is stated as the full understanding by abandoning.

original: pahānapariññā. Duppaṭivijjhoti ettha pana maggo kathito. Sacchikātabboti phalaṃ kathitaṃ,
analyzed: pahāna pariññā duppaṭivijjhaḥ ti ettha pana maggo kathito sacchikātabbaḥ iti phalam kathitam
translated: The path is stated as the hard-to-penetrate. The fruit is stated as the to-be-realized.

original: maggo ekasmiṃyeva pade labbhati. Phalaṃ pana anekesupi labbhatiyeva.
analyzed: maggaḥ ekasmiṃ yeva pade labbhati phalam pana anekesu pi
translated: The path is found in one place only, but the fruit is found in many places.

original: Bhūtāti sabhāvato vijjamānā. Tacchāti yāthāvā. Tathāti yathā vuttā tathāsabhāvā.
analyzed: bhūtā ati sabhāvataḥ vijjamānā tacchā ati yāthāvā tathā ati yathā vuttā tathāsabhāvā
translated: “Existent” means existing in actuality. “True” means as it really is. “Real” means having the same nature as stated.

original: Avitathāti yathā vuttā na tathā na honti. Anaññathāti vuttappakārato na aññathā.
analyzed: avitathā ati yathā vuttāḥ na tathā na honti anaññathā ati vutta ppakārataḥ na aññathā
translated: “Not otherwise” means not being otherwise than stated. “Not different” means not different from the stated mode.

original: Sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhāti tathāgatena bodhipallaṅke nisīditvā hetunā kāraṇena🔽sayameva abhisambuddhā ñātā viditā sacchikatā. Iminā thero “ime dhammā tathāgatena
analyzed: sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā ati tathāgatena bodhi pallaṅke nisīditvā hetunā kāraṇena  sayam eva abhisambuddhā ñātā viditā sacchikatā iminā theraḥ ime dhammā tathāgatena
translated: “Rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata” means that the Tathāgata, sitting on the seat of enlightenment, by means of cause, by means of reason,

original: abhisambuddhā, ahaṃ pana tumhākaṃ rañño lekhavācakasadiso”ti jinasuttaṃ dassento okappanaṃ janesi.
analyzed: abhisambuddhāḥ aham pana tumhākam raññaḥ lekha vācaka sadisaḥ ti jina suttam dassento okappanam janesi
translated: awakened to, knew, understood, and realized them by himself. By this, the Elder generated confidence, showing the Jina Sutta, saying: “These things were awakened to by the Tathāgata, but I am like a scribe or messenger for your king.”

original: Ekadhammavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: eka dhamma vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of one thing is ended.

original: Dvedhammavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dve dhamma vaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of two things

original: 352. (Ka) ime dve dhammā bahukārāti ime dve satisampajaññā dhammā sīlapūraṇādīsu appamādo viya sabbattha upakārakā hitāvahā.
analyzed: ke ime dve dhammā bahu kārā ati ime dve sati sampajaññā dhammā sīla pūraṇa ādīsu appamādaḥ viya sabbattha upakārakā hita āvahā
translated: . (Ka) “Which two things? “ These two things, mindfulness and full awareness, are helpful everywhere, like heedfulness in fulfilling virtue, and so on.

original: (Kha) samatho ca vipassanā cāti ime dve saṅgītisutte lokiyalokuttarā kathitā. analyzed: samatho ca vipassanā ca ati ime dve saṅgīti sutte lokiya lokuttarā kathitā imasmin dasuttara sutte pubbabhāgā kathitā  cha sattānam saṃkilesāya sattānam visuddhiyā ati ayonisaḥ manasikāraḥ hetu ca iva paccayo  ca sattānam saṃkilesāya yonisas manasikāraḥ visuddhiyā tathā dovacassatā pāpa mitta tā  saṃkilesāya sovacassatā kalyāṇa mitta tā visuddhiyā tathā tīṇi akusala mūlāni tīṇi
translated: (Kha) “Tranquillity and insight” are spoken of in the Saṅgīti Sutta as mundane and supramundane. In this Dasuttara Sutta they are spoken of as the prior stage.

original: kusalamūlāni. Cattāro yogā cattāro visaṃyogā. Pañca cetokhilā pañcindriyāni. Cha
analyzed: kusala mūlāni cattāraḥ yogā cattāraḥ visaṃyogā pañca cetas khilā pañca indriyāni cha
translated: (Cha) “For the defilement and the cleansing of beings” : unreasonable attention is both the cause and the condition for the defilement of beings, and reasonable attention is for their cleansing. Likewise, difficult to correct and bad friendship are for defilement, and easy to correct and good friendship are for cleansing. Likewise, the three roots of unprofit and the three roots of profit, the four yokes and the four unyokings, the five mental hindrances and the five spiritual faculties, the six roots of contention and the six roots of non-contention, the seven falsenesses and the seven rightnesses, the eight worldly ideas and the Noble Eightfold Path, the nine causes of disputes and the nine factors of initiative for reconciliation, the ten courses of unprofitable action and the ten courses of profitable action.

original: agāravā cha gāravā. Satta asaddhammā satta saddhammā. Aṭṭha kusītavatthūni aṭṭha
analyzed: agāravā cha gāravā satta asaddhammā satta saddhammā aṭṭha kusīta vatthūni aṭṭha
translated: There are six kinds of disrespect and six kinds of respect. There are seven kinds of bad qualities and seven kinds of good qualities. There are eight grounds for laziness and eight grounds for arousal of energy.

original: ārambhavatthūni. Nava āghātavatthūni nava āghātappaṭivinayā. Dasa akusalakammapathā
analyzed: ārambha vatthūni nava āghāta vatthūni nava āghāta paṭivinayāḥ dasa akusala kammapathā
translated: There are six kinds of disrespect and six kinds of respect. There are seven kinds of bad dhammas and seven kinds of good dhammas. There are eight grounds for laziness and eight grounds for exertion. There are nine grounds for annoyance and nine ways of overcoming annoyance. There are ten unwholesome courses of action

original: dasa kusalakammapathāti evaṃ pabhedā ime dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhāti veditabbā.
analyzed: dasa kusala kamma pathā ti evam pabhedāḥ ime dve dhammāḥ duppaṭivijjhā ti veditabbā
translated: and ten wholesome courses of action. These two dhammas should be understood as hard to penetrate in this way.

original: (Jha) saṅkhatā dhātūti paccayehi katā pañcakkhandhā. Asaṅkhatā dhātūti paccayehi akataṃ nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhatā dhātu uti paccayehi katā pañca kkhandhāḥ asaṅkhatāḥ dhātu uti paccayehi akatam nibbānam
translated: (Jha) The formed element: the five aggregates formed by conditions. The unformed element: Nibbāna, not formed by conditions.

original: (Ña) vijjā ca vimutti cāti ettha vijjāti tisso vijjā. Vimuttīti arahattaphalaṃ.
analyzed: vijjā ca vimutti ca ati ettha vijjā ati tissaḥ vijjā vimutti iti arahatta phalam
translated: (Ña) Clear vision and deliverance: Herein, clear vision is the three kinds of clear vision. Deliverance is the fruit of arahantship.

original: Imasmiṃ vāre abhiññādīni ekakasadisāneva, uppādetabbapade pana maggo kathito, sacchikātabbapade phalaṃ.
analyzed: imasmin vāre abhiññā ādīni ekaka sadisāni eva uppādetabba pade pana maggo kathito sacchikātabba pade phalam
translated: Or in this section the path is stated under the heading of what is to be generated, and the fruit under that of what is to be realized.

original: Dvedhammavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dvedhamma vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the two dhammas is ended.

original: Tayodhammavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tayodhamma vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the three dhammas🔽(Cha) The escape from sensual desires is this: namely, renunciation.

original: 353. (Cha) kāmānametaṃ nissaraṇaṃ yadidaṃ nekkhammanti ettha nekkhammanti anāgāmimaggo
analyzed: cha kāmānam etam nissaraṇam yat idam nekkhammanti ettha nekkhammanti anāgāmi maggo
translated: Herein, renunciation is the non-return path.

original: adhippeto. So hi sabbaso kāmānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ. Rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ yadidaṃ āruppanti
analyzed: adhippetaḥ saḥ hi sabbaso kāmānam nissaraṇam rūpānam nissaraṇam yat idam āruppanti
translated: for that is the escape from all kinds of sensual desires. The escape from material things is the immaterial states.

original: ettha āruppepi arahattamaggo. Puna uppattinivāraṇato sabbaso rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ nāma.
analyzed: ettha āruppe pi arahatta maggo puna uppatti nivāraṇato sabbaso rūpānam nissaraṇam nāma
translated: Herein, the path of arahatship is the immaterial states too, since it prevents further arising.🔽And cessation is the escape from them,

original: Nirodho tassa nissaraṇanti idha arahattaphalaṃ nirodhoti adhippetaṃ. Arahattaphalena🔽hi nibbāne diṭṭhe puna āyatiṃ sabbasaṅkhārā na hontīti arahattaṃ saṅkhatanirodhassa
analyzed: nirodho tassa nissaraṇan ti idha arahatta phalam nirodho ti adhippetam arahatta phalena  hi nibbāne diṭṭhe puna āyatim sabba saṅkhārāḥ na honti iti arahattam saṅkhata nirodhassa
translated: for here the fruit of arahatship is intended by “cessation.”

original: paccayattā nirodhoti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paccaya ttā nirodhaḥ ti vuttam
translated: For when the fruit of arahatship has seen Nibbāna, no formations whatever occur again in the future. So arahatship is called “cessation” because it is a condition for the cessation of formed things.

original: (Ja) atītaṃse ñāṇanti atītaṃsārammaṇaṃ ñāṇaṃ itaresupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: atīta ṃse atīta ṃsa ārammaṇam ñāṇam itaresu pi esa iva nayo
translated: Knowledge of the past is knowledge of the past as object. The same method applies in the other two cases.

original: Imasmimpi vāre abhiññādayo ekakasadisāva. Duppaṭivijjhapade pana maggo kathito, sacchikātabbe phalaṃ.
analyzed: imasmim pi vāre abhiññā ādayo ekaka sadisā ava duppaṭivijjha pade pana maggo kathito sacchikātabbe phalam
translated: Or alternatively, in this section too the kinds of direct-knowledge, etc., are the same as the single kinds. But in the case of the “difficult to penetrate” the path is stated, and the fruit in the case of the “to be realized.”

original: Tayodhammavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tayodhamma vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the three ideas is ended.

original: Cattārodhammavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cattāro dhamma vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the four ideas

original: iriyāpathacakkaṃ, sampatticakkanti pañcavidhaṃ. analyzed: iriyāpatha cakkam sampatti cakkanti pañcavidham tattha yam panidam samma rathakāra  cakkam chahi māsehi niṭṭhitam chārattūnehi iti idam dāru cakkam pitarā pavattitam  cakkam anuppavatteti iti idam ratana cakkam pavattitam cakkan ti idam dhamma cakkam  catu cakkam nava dvāram ti idam iriyāpatha cakkam cattāri imāni bhikkhave cakkāni
translated: the Wheel of Conduct, the Wheel of Attainment. Herein, “But, dear Rathakara, this wheel that you have finished in six months and six days” is the wheel of wood. “The wheel set rolling by my Father is rolling on” is the wheel of gems. “The wheel set rolling” is the wheel of ideas.🔽“The wheel with four spokes and nine doors” is the wheel of conduct. “Bhikkhus, there are these four wheels,

original: yehi samannāgatānaṃ devamanussānaṃ catucakkaṃ pavattatī”ti idaṃ sampatticakkaṃ. Idhāpi etadeva adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: yehi samannāgatānam deva manussānam catu cakkam pavattati iti idam sampatti cakkam idha api etat eva adhippetam
translated: The Wheel of Conduct, the Wheel of Splendour, the Wheel of the True Idea, the Wheel of the Four Factors of Stream-Entry, and the Wheel of the Four Factors of Stream-Entry as Splendour. Herein, the wheel of six months and six fortnights is the wheel of wood. The wheel set rolling by the Father that is still rolling on is the wheel of gems. The wheel set rolling is the wheel of the True Idea. The wheel with four spokes and nine doors is the wheel of conduct. The four wheels, bhikkhus, by means of which the wheel-turning noble-wheel-rolling deities and human beings roll the wheel with four spokes are the wheel of the four factors of stream-entry. Herein, it is this last that is intended.

original: Patirūpadesavāsoti yattha catasso parisā sandissanti, evarūpe anucchavike dese vāso.
analyzed: pati rūpa desa vāso ti yattha catasso parisā sandissanti evarūpe anucchavike dese vāso
translated: Dwelling in a suitable locality: dwelling in a suitable district where the four assemblies can be seen.

original: Sappurisūpanissayoti buddhādīnaṃ sappurisānaṃ avassayanaṃ sevanaṃ bhajanaṃ. Attasammāpaṇidhīti
analyzed: sappurisa upanissayaḥ ti buddha ādīnam sappurisānam avassayanam sevanam bhajanam atta sammāpaṇidhi iti
translated: Association with True Men: attending on, serving, and honouring True Men such as Buddhas, etc. Right disposition in oneself:

original: attano sammā ṭhapanaṃ, sace pana pubbe assaddhādīhi samannāgato hoti, tāni pahāya🔽saddhādīsu patiṭṭhāpanaṃ. Pubbe ca katapuññatāti pubbe upacitakusalatā. Idamevettha🔽pamāṇaṃ. Yena hi ñāṇasampayuttacittena kusalaṃ kataṃ hoti, tadeva kusalaṃ taṃ purisaṃ
analyzed: attano sammā ṭhapanam sace pana pubbe assaddha ādīhi samannāgato hoti tāni pahāya  saddhā ādīsu patiṭṭhāpanam pubbe ca kata puñña tā ati pubbe upacita kusala tā idam eva ittha  pamāṇam yena hi ñāṇa sampayutta cittena kusalam katam hoti tat eva kusalam tam purisam
translated: and his own right establishment. But if he was previously possessed of faith, etc., and he abandons them,🔽and he is established in faith, etc., then his previous performance of merit is the cause for his being established in faith, etc. This is the measure here:🔽for whatever profitable action is done with consciousness associated with knowledge, that profitable action is the cause for his being established in faith, etc.

original: patirūpadese upaneti, sappurise bhajāpesi. So eva ca puggalo attānaṃ sammā ṭhapeti.
analyzed: patiḥ upadese upaneti sappurise saḥ eva ca puggalaḥ attānam sammā ṭhapeti
translated: and his own right establishment. But if he is possessed of faith, etc., already, then it is the establishment of faith, etc., in him that is meant. And the performance of merit in the past is the cause for the manifestation of faith, etc., in the present. This is the measure here: for whatever profitable action is done with consciousness accompanied by knowledge, that profitable action leads that person to a suitable place and associates him with true men. And that person himself establishes himself.

original: Catūsu āhāresu paṭhamo lokiyova. Sesā pana tayo saṅgītisutte lokiyalokuttaramissakā
analyzed: catūsu āhāresu paṭhamaḥ lokiyaḥ uva sesā pana tayo saṅgīti sutte lokiya lokuttara missakā
translated: As regards the four nutriments, the first is mundane only. But the other three are said in the Saṅgīti Sutta to be mixed mundane and supramundane.

original: kathitā. Idha pubbabhāge lokiyā.
analyzed: kathitā idha pubbabhāge lokiyā
translated: Herein, in the earlier stage they are mundane.

original: (Ca) kāmayogavisaṃyogādayo anāgāmimaggādivasena veditabbā.
analyzed: ca kāma yoga visaṃyoga ādayaḥ anāgāmi magga ādi vasena veditabbā
translated: (Ca) The bond of sense desire, etc., should be understood as the path of non-return, and so on.

original: (Cha) hānabhāgiyādīsu paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhī kāmasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti
analyzed: cha hāna bhāgiya ādīsu paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhī kāma sahagatā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti

analyzed: hāna bhāgiyo samādhi tad anudhamma tā sati santiṭṭhati ṭhiti bhāgiyo samādhi vitakka sahagatā
translated: that is concentration conducive to giving up. When mindfulness that is in conformity with that is established, that is concentration conducive to maintenance. When he gives attention to perceptions and attentions accompanied by disliking, that is concentration conducive to decline. When he gives attention to perceptions and attentions accompanied by happiness, that is concentration conducive to distinction.
